Although I don't recommend J-walking.

This is my new late night grub place when I stay at The Inn on Castro.

The slices are big, pizza is good and the service is friendly and fast.
I always have a nice experience when grab a slice.

I still want to try one of their toasted sandwiches. Another task that needs to be accomplished on my next trip.

My favorite slice?
sausage and mushrooms
Favorite movie projected on the wall at the time of my visit?
The Princess Bride

For late night pizza in SF, the best!

Soft dough-y crust. Lightly crisped on the bottom. Even though I just tried a few bites of my friend's after it had gotten cold, I could tell it was quality stuff.
The pizza by the slices are very good. The staff just needs to be a little bit more friendlier.

On a Friday night of hunger, this place calls out with it's globe marquis and small alcove appearance.  Don't be put off, it's incredible pizza with giant windows in order to "eye the merchandise" that is coming through the door.

I ordered a medium mushroom and pepperoni pizza, had a small bottle of red to split and sat patiently.  If you are in a rush, get it by the slice.. but if you want a treat allow some patience to get it fresh baked how you like.  It was incredible pizza- the sauce was tangy and tomato based, the cheese was a mass of goo, melty and buttery in flavor, the pepperoni was spicy and of course mushrooms were absolutely amazingly well cooked- tender but not overly so.

Screw forks and knives, dig in with the bare hands, pile on the napkins and be prepared to watch out the window.

Only be weary when a homeless person will come up and stare at you eating... that homeless person followed me around Castro for the duration.. even stopping to shout within a foot of me about being the "secret service for Obama" and how, "Charlie's Angels were all really men,"

But when I am eating, I am gone.  So it didn't ruin my pizza experience.

The best drunk slice West of the Mississippi!

Slices bigger than your face for a decent price.

Friendly (and tolerant!) staff.

I'm always skeptical of pizza when leaving NYC pizza, but this place got really good reviews and it turns out I was super impressed!

I also love how cruisey it is with club lights and basically a catwalk to come in. lol. I haven't been at night, but I'm sure it's a scene.

Amazing fresh slices of thin crust pizza. My favorites are the pesto potato and the pepperoni/sausage. The service is always superb, but MAKE SURE YOU ARE PREPARED AS THEY ARE CASH ONLY.

There are always people in this establishment, but I don't recall ever having a long wait for my food. No soda fountain, but water/soda available in bottles.

I've had a string of good luck while dining in SF in the last few weeks. I found some real gems and MPE is one of them.

Came on Friday at 6:15 with a party of 4 and they gave us a table as long as we would be done by the 740 reservation. The space is really cool and the old ovens really do impress. The servers largely had Italian accents and the tables/chairs were old and colorful. Definitely felt like I was dining in Europe!

We ordered a salad with beets and goat cheese to start and shared 3 pinsa. The salad was actually a generous portion and the 3 pinsa were more than enough for our group of 4. We got a margherita, the maranella (spicy sausage and broccolini), and one with prosciutto and pesto/pine nuts. I liked all 3 but the maranella was my fave.

We also ordered some drinks to start. I highly recommend their Rosé (the Tempranillo blend). They seemed to have a good wine list--comprehensive but not overwhelming.

Pinsa came out very fast. It's definitely lighter than regular pizza but the claims of it being "low in calories" is BS. It's covered in cheese and meats after all. Just enjoy your food and worry about your diet at another restaurant ;) The char on the crust here is unreal and the pinsa come whole--pizza cutters are given to cut to your liking.

Everything we ate was simple and delicious. Refreshing to have a pizza place I know is good and is centrally located. Adding this to our dinner and date night rotation!

*Notes on the location.*
MPE is in an alley on Stevenson/6th. If that makes you nervous, don't come. If you are worried about "sketchy" or "seedy" neighborhoods, stay in a part of the city more to your liking/sensibilities and leave the pinsa for the rest of us. But if you're someone who realizes that living in a major city includes the full array of peoples and situations, then YOU can come! You'll be rewarded with some pretty awesome food!

If you ever feel like heading to an authentic Italian restaurant in the city, head to this place and I swear you'd feel like you're in Italy. The only actually "Pinseria" in San Francisco, this place has a rustic, earthy Italian vibe to it. Everything from the pinsas, panini, salads and appetizers are what you'd probably get in a restaurant in Italy. Their wine collection would pique the interest of any wine connoisseur.

One of the major downsides of this place though is its very sketchy location in an alley on 6th Street.

This was my first time having pinsa and yeah, it's basically pizza but on a lighter, fluffier dough/crust (which I liked, but it coulda been thicker). The choices of toppings for the pinsas were a bit underwhelming and while we got one that was supposed to Mozzarella, Porcini Mushroom, Artisanal Lardo (cured pork fat back), and Parsley, all we saw on our pizza were mozzarella cheese and little brown chewy & gooey things (which seemed to be mushroom-like), so that was a little disappointing.

We also ordered the Tagliere Misto which came with 3 decent-sized chunks of cheese and 3 servings of meats, with some honey, jam, and toasted almonds and everything on that plate was awesome! In fact, we ended up adding some of the cheese and meats from that plate onto our pinsa!!

The wine menu was pretty impressive and they had a nice selection of wines by the glass. The dessert menu wasn't too exciting so we skipped that.

The space inside is crowded with random old-timey items and unnecessary counters and cabinets and there aren't many tables and not much room to move in there. All the chairs are also old-timey and "rustic" which means they're rusted metal and not comfortable to sit in. The service was fast and the staff were nice. We had to wait about 15 minutes for a table on a Thursday at 6pm, which wasn't too bad and they texted us when our table was ready, but we still had to wait about 5 more minutes after they texted us. Also, it's not in a great part of town but while waiting in front of the restaurant the many random panhandlers wandering by mostly didn't bother us.

Very extensive menu with sooo many yummy options! I settled on the Casal Bertone which had a subtle sweetness to the dough. The pinsa dough is made with rice, soy and wheat flour and was perfectly chewy and fluffy.

Service was decent, our waitress disappeared halfway through the meal and I had to flag down multiple people for the check. Like others have mentioned, location is pretty sketch.

This is our favorite spot for date night. We love coming for a good bottle of wine paired with meats, cheeses, and delicious spreads. The pinsas are amazing! The staff is knowledgeable and attentive. We will keep coming back. The Covid friendly rooftop dining is a great addition in the short term. Just learned they have a delivery kitchen in Oakland, too!

So good!! Came here for a work lunch and enjoyed everything we ordered. The greens / veggies / healthier dishes were so fresh and colorful. Loved it.

The real star for me was the Pancetta Pinsa - absolutely loved this one. All the pizzas came out fresh and fluffy. Super tasty and big enough to share.

Everything was preordered so I didn't see the bill, but overall I enjoyed the pizzas most. Service was on the slower side, and it gets busy during lunch.

After a busy Pride weekend, all we wanted was some food. Pizza to be exact. Up popped this joint on Yelp and I am so glad this came up under pizza or I never would have found this Roman nirvana. It's a really cool looking joint and for being a small place, the seating with the bars and long tables is conducive to getting a lot of people in at once which was a huge plus. We were seated at the bar and I had a lot of time to observe the decor. Everything is curated very tastefully and it's really fun to look around the room.

I've never had a pinsa before this experience and I would say I would never go back to pizza but alas, there aren't any pinserias near me in South Bay. I shared a Casal Bertone, the stars being guanciale and honey, as well as a Trullo that featured a lamb sausage. I heard that the Trullo was one of the favorites on the menu and it was very tasty. For me, the Casal Bertone way overshadowed it because it was so incredible. I've always been a sucker for honey on white pizzas but this took it to the next level. The combo with the salty and crispy guanciale was a dream. Also the big difference between a pinsa and a pizza is the way the crust is made. I don't not like crust but I will tend to leave it if there's more "main" to finish. I did not leave any of the crust this time. It was that good.

With the incredible entree pinsa experience, I jumped at the chance to get a dessert pinsa. The pinsa was filled with a smooth, creamy *pistachio nutella* and dusted with sugar. The filling was absolutely divine. The whole thing is served warm and I can't get it out of my head 2 days later.

Was in the mood for pizza and happened to pick this place. It did not disappoint. Great atmosphere, it truly transported me to Italy. We sat at the bar and our waitress happened to be a Sommelier, she recommended a great bottle of Turkish wine. We got the olives, sun dried tomatoes, house salad and the Margherita pisca. A good selection of vegetarian options but I would still ask about things (turns out the sun dried tomatoes have anchovies inside). The pisca pizza was amazingly light and fresh. Truly melted in my mouth.

All I would say is uber here if you don't live in the area. As many have said it's a pretty sketchy area.

Wow! Mangia!! Mangia!  Excellent Italian lunch, excellent service.  The prosciutto panini "Albano" was off the hook amazing from the fresh bread to the melt in the mouth mozzarella to the scrumptious prosciutto.  Authentic Italy.  I am Italian, this place brought me back to Italy.

The
Best
Pinseria
Ever

Great service, cozy and intimate, popular.

The pizza was good. The person who waited on was was friendly. But we felt a bit of rudeness in general. It felt a bit cold (literally  and figuratively).
There were a bunch of us sitting out at the tables in the patio and they turned off the heater only at our table as they were nearing the end of the service.

I often have to visit a place more than once before giving it 5 stars. So for my first time, I'll outline my experience.

We used the Yelp app to get on the waitlist. Recommended on Saturday nights.

We arrived when second in line and were being seated almost immediately after. But we then chose to sit at the bar (something I enjoy doing). Bartender was a great guy. Personable and attentive.

Now the food. They offer vegan cheese. Great flexibility. And they have vegan "meat" options like sausage. Not many places do that. Definitely a plus for flexibility. We went for happy hour/apps at Tropsieuno (a place full of nostalgia for me and another excellent option) so we didn't finish the pizza (Mrs G inhaled it back in the hotel room). But it was tasty.

We got a salad To share and a bottle of mineral water to share. Bill was under 30 bucks. Hard to do that these days. So solid price point for 2 (share a pizza, share a salad, share a large mineral water).

Overall we will be back and may upgrade.
We enjoyed our pizza and the dessert was FANTASTIC. We had good service which adds to the sparkle.
Great service and food. I was impressed with the everything from arrival through payment.

If you're near Union Square and have the craving for pizza, then Delarosa is the spot. It was very cold in the city, and I wanted to eat something warm. Delarosa is located near Peet's Coffee and Ambrosia Restaurant.
I recommend joining the Yelp waitlist while you make your way through.

The hostesses kept checking up on us, letting us know the situation on our seating. It's nice of them going out of their way, instead of me having to go up and ask how much more the wait time was.

As soon as we were seated in my party of 3, I ordered. The food came out in literally less than 10 minutes. We ordered two pizza's, about 6 slices per. The pizza was good, I am a big fan of the thin crust. These whole pizza's are more on the pricer side, and if you add extras. Then again it is San Francisco, everything is an extra $$.

Overall, great ambience and minimal wait time.
This place never disappoints. I like coming here after a film nearby. Great pizza and mussels and salad dishes and drinks. Solid.
Amazing meatballs and marinara sauce. Excellent pizzas, especially white. Even vegetarian!
Great service and the staff was really comfortable with engaging in conversations, and positive joking in order to make the table comfortable.

Came here twice, once for a late night meal after a fashion show and another for goodbye lunch.

Have to say the food here is significantly more enjoyable the first time around than the second. Partially due to Italian food is always more enjoyable when you are starving on a cold night lol.

I will recommend ordering more pasta than pizza even though both are signature here.

Out of the 4 pizzas I ordered, only the margaritas I think are really good while everything else is just a bit disappointing one way or the other (not enough cheese, too thin to the point it falls apart, barely any sausage or meat to carry the flavor). I also have noticed the quality of the pizzas here is not the most stable.

The pasta here though, are never a disappointment. Have tried first 2 on the menu and both amazing. They are simple but flavorful with all the juices of the ingredients absorbed in the sauce. Just amazing!

Just be aware that this restaurant has community tables so it can be quite loud and service is usually quite slow and inattentive because of that.

Nice place! We came during busy hours, but we didn't wait too long. And I also want to bring awareness to excellent service from waiter named Zhumadil, he was very nice to us, super friendly, helpful and pretty fast. We enjoyed our meal. Recommend

A nice little pizza place with a good crispy thin crust. Sauce was good and sausage was high quality meat. Toppings were generous,  and veggies were not overcooked.  House wines were good, and the large house salad before hand was tasty and enough to share for four. Restroom was clean and had nice artwork.  Would go back again.

This review is for the gluten free pizza only. Solid pizza... I got the Little Star with spinach, onion, garlic etc. Even though the menu said DD only they made it for me on GF crust. The toppings were high quality and delicious. They mentioned this was the most popular pizza. The gluten free crust was just ok...definitely not the best I've ever had. Tony's GF pizza is for sure better. BUT this pizza still hit the spot and when you can't get all the way to North Beach this is still a solid choice. Even my non-gf husband and brother enjoyed the pizza a lot!

I have Celiac so I always check on the cross contamination situation. They use the same oven for all pizzas but assured me they try to keep everything separate and use a cooking sheet under the gf pizza in the oven. I didn't get sick.

Also, I ordered this pizza to go (for pick up), and it was ready as soon as my husband walked in the door to get it! I literally thought he may have stolen the pizza he walked out so fast ;)

I went to college in Chicago, the deep-dish capital of America... and HATED deep dish pizza. I don't get it. Too much sauce, too much cheese, flimsy crust... why ruin a good pizza?? I somehow managed to avoid deep dish for the last 5+ years.

Then, my boyfriend convinced me to try Little Star (hey I'll give everything a second chance). I had low expectations and not that much of an appetite. We ordered the original (small) with extra pepperoni and a couple drinks.

The pizza blew my mind, from the delicious sauce and toppings to the yummy cornmeal crust. WHY did I wait so long to try this place?? Yes it is heavy, but soooo good.

Service was great, the line wasn't too bad (for SF), and the vibes are cool. Nice wine and beer menu.

Little Star, you're my new favorite.

I've been looking for a solid tomato sauce for quite some time in California. And being a Chicago style pizza fan I can unapologetically recommend Little Star Pizza.  If you are on the hunt for some good zesty, chunky, crunchy deep dish pizza. In a town where ethic food is king it's nice to sit back with friend and family and share a slice off the ole pie and remiss of Chi-Town!
This is our favorite neighborhood pizza place for both pick up and dine in! We enjoy both the thin crust a s deep dish options. Our favorite is White pizza!

Really good deep dish. Dang! We ordered a medium veggie and the pizza arrived at our table hot and crispy. Keep in mind our taste buds are wired for deep dish from Chicago and so we had really high expectations. Little star pizza delivered! Can't wait to visit once I am back in San Francisco.

Solid Chicago style pizza that doesn't taste like you're eating 1,000 calories per slice.

Came here with a group of 4 people on a Saturday night without a reservation. We waited about 10 minutes to get a table, but were allowed to place our order ahead of time. Upon being seated, we ordered an appetizer of spicy wings (only deep dishes can be pre-ordered). Overall, service was speedy and both our appetizer and pizza came out at appropriate times.

The wings were pretty special--on a totally different level than the Popeyes a couple blocks down the street. They were moderately crisp without being overly drenched in oil which I liked. They were, on the other hand, pretty spicy in a peppery kind of way.

Now, for the pizza. We ordered the Mediterranean Chicken which had chicken breast, artichoke hearts, red bells, green olives, onions, and feta cheese. A stray away from the typical meat lovers Chicago style pizza, but still a deep dish and just as savory. The acidity from the artichoke and olives blended perfectly with the seasoned chicken and marinara. The pizza tasted really special aside from the fact that it was a deep dish. The crunchy yet buttery crust was also really unique and appealing.

I must still be mesmerized by my meal from last night, but I can't yet say whether Little Star trumps Zachary's.. They both have great things going for them and I feel that even though both establishments serve deep dish pizzas, they are unique in their own ways that it'd be unfair to compare the two. Love them both though and I'm definitely a fan! 4.5 stars

Do you see the 5 glowing stars for this review?

I've been thinking of powerful words to really bring home how I feel about Little Star Pizza.  

I had a first draft.

And a second draft.  

Then I gave up.

It was my  first time having LSP the night of our happy hour at Madrone.  Yes, I'm making a grand statement when I say "it's damn good deep dish pizza".  Wait.  Scratch that.  

It's not a grand statement.  It's a fact.

We called in our order for take-out and promptly picked it up in 30 mins.  A small Classic deep dish with sausage, mushrooms, onions and green bell peppers.  But savvy yelpers know to ask for the Brass Monkey which is not on the menu.  (It is #60 on the Big Eats SF list.)

A little bit over half an inch thick crust topped with ricotta and feta cheese, sausage, spinach, onions, garlic, mushrooms. Everything just seems to marry well together.  It's like lasagna on a pizza pie. You may automatically conclude that this deep dish is chewy, but it's not.   You take that first bite.  Your teeth literally sinks into the heavenly crust.  The billion nerve endings on your taste buds get excited by the zesty sauce and as the chunky tomatoes hit it full force, it makes you salivate for more.  

More.  

Judging from the 1000+ reviews on this place, it's safe to say that LSP has mastered the art of deep dish pizza awesomeness.  

5 glowing stars.

Zachary's used to be my go to deep dish. Tried deep dish in Chicago (maybe I went to the wrong place but wasn't impressed?). This is my top 3 favorite pizza ever IN LIFE!!!! Sooooo good I crave it all the time. It gets super busy so prob better to take out and eat at home. Sometimes you can beat the rush if you go a little before 6-630ish. I usually get the little star which I think is the one with spinach-- whatever the spinach one is get that one!

It's nice it's next to bars so you can easily wait it out or pop into a bar after dinner. Love this place. Wish they had one in atx where I now live. I'd buy this online and ship it here if I could. Nom nom nom

First time here & came because of all the great reviews. Went around 6pm on a weekday & were seated right away. We ordered the garlic bread, which was good & a small Classic deep dish pizza to share. The pizza was delicious & I especially loved the crust & the cornmeal flavor.
I do, however, think they could improve a bit on the atmosphere - kind of dark & depressing.  Overall, great place to grab a pizza.
Yummy Spaghetti al Pesto pasta!

Pass on the zucchini sticks and special salad.

Definitely save room for some tiramisu though!

And the pizza... simply excellent! No need to go to NYC for thin crust yumminess when it's right here in the city! Bruce's pizza hit the spot with the garlic flavor, texture of mushrooms, saltiness of salame and sausage. Crust is toasty (not crunchy) on the edges while still soft on  the inside.  Order more than you can finish so you can have a few slices for lunch the next day.

Residential and metered parking in the neighborhood. Should take about five minutes of circling to find a spot on a Friday night.

Great for groups and children. (Kids, ask the pizza man for some pizza !) Juke boxes in the side booths and checkered table cloths make for an old diner feel.

Friendly and efficient staff.

Only real pizza place in the city. Taste just like my dad used to make when he was trying to make pizza like in East Haven. It makes me feel like I'm with all my Italian relatives when I go there. Now I can order takeout of pizza. May not be a great place for yuppies used to nouveau pizza.

Ordered a few takeout pizzas from here for a friends party. Was def not the best pizza I had. The veggie was my least favorite and I LOVE veggie pizza. We also got the chicken which was decent. Not sure if its better eaten there but for pretty pricey pizzas I was expecting much much more.

A step back in time.

Decent food. Pleasant, fast service.

Entertaining jukebox. American classics are a bit scratchy.

I've only had takeout, but wow is this some delicious food. I had to take a break from chewing this delightful garlicky cheesy slice to write this because they are just so good! Their meatballs have a perfect texture, I just wish there was even more of this amazing marinara to pour all over it.

My husband went inside to pick up the order and I think they accidentally made a mushroom instead of a margherita, so they made a new one. They needn't have bothered; I would scarf down ANY pizza from those ovens!

I moved here from NY and thought Arinells was it as far as NY pizza went, but I was wrong! This is truly delightful; I'm going back to chewing now! Eat this food!!

The pizza here is uber-greasy. But, so freakin' delicious.

Normally, I'm a priss about greasy pizza, but this pizza makes me bend all the rules while flippin' off my fat backside in every mirror.

Maybe it's the atmosphere with the fake grapes hanging from the ceiling that makes me want to sing dreamily "peel me a grape".

"Don't try to fool me bejewel me
Either amuse me or lose me
I'm getting hungry, peel me a grape"

What the Hell...let's get everyone in the mood for some delicious grapey wine and dine on icky-gooey deliciously greasy pizza. youtube.com/watch?v=Tt7W…

No, you probably won't hear that song at the restaurant, but you will hear "That's amore!"
youtube.com/watch?v=zeWV…
Possibly 3 times during your visit! But, don't let that deter you.

There's a pizza here for everyone from veg-heads to meat lovers and the I'm tryin' to be a veg-head but I love delectable Italian sausage types, like myself.
Yes, I do love italian sausage.

I must say this gooey thin crust pizza is reasonably priced.
Small pizza - $10.50 to $13.
Medium - $14 to $17.50
Large - $16.50 to $19.50
Extra Large - $19.50 to $22.50

If you decide to get the Gaspare's Special Salad. Make sure the person on either side of you and the one you're going home with eats it too. This salad is I can smell your breathe a mile away ultra-garlicky.

I've always been too full to try the desserts...but one day I'll write about it.

Overall: Decent prices for pizza, pasta, and salads. Great neighborhood pizza parlor for us Richmond District folk and the rest of you SF'ers.

Gaspar's Ghosts- Last night I ordered a medium Gaspare's Special. I went to pick it up right before they close at 11. Unfortunately, they were already closed. What was interesting to me was that nobody was there at 10:59. After ringing the doorbell, it was clear that no one was answering. Why would nobody be there at 10:59 cleaning up and closing? Which leads me to my theory- Gaspar's Ghosts

Gaspare's....that's a lovely thin crust pizza. The atmo? 5 stars for that even if the food sucked. Like you were in Jersey, that kind of interior....booths, little juke boxes, all the ye olde Italian trappings, in a good way.

Maaaaaaaybe the staff is too nice for Jersey, but this is Frisco we're talking here.

It was a Paulie Walnuts look-a-like sighting near the bocce court at Aquatic Park that inspired our most recent visit to Gaspare's - the fella was driving a late model land yacht, blasting Sinatra, adjusting himself in Paulie fashion. Does Paulie live in San Fran?

Best Italian food ever had! My son and I were in town for a week and during that week we had dinner here twice. The pasta (lasagna and mancotti) were excellent. The pizza was amazing. The service was spot on as well! If you are considering Italian in San Francisco, this is the place to go!!

Oh I shouldn't forget to mention the creme brûlée!! To die for.

Quaint quality Italian food made by chef with authentic Italian DNA.
Shrimp in the Shrimp Marinara ( a tad spicy but you can request it not be) were delicious and large sized.
Eggplant parmesan was delicious and very fresh made. Perfect thickness slices and cheese balance.
Lasagna was the show stopper! It was creamy and bountiful! The wine list was reasonable in size but it isn't size that matters - it's what's on it. They offer several varieties by the glass so you can start with one with your fresh crisp Cesar salad and must have the caprese with fresh thick tomatoes slices and mozzarella and just the right amount of fresh basil leaves.
For  a special treat (not on the menu - you need to know to ask for it) for dessert, ask for the chocolate salami with a demitasse of raspberry sauce! OMG it was the best cap on an already delicious dinner.
(Oh - and the wait staff was super nice and über friendly!!)
A must-go spot when in San Francisco.

So I was reminded again last night, that san francisco's hip, new, young food critics lose all credibility when they leave Tommaso's  off their precious lists. For what it's worth, I'm from Bensonhurst, been in north beach 30 years, and even with golden boy, and tony's, this place is still a super star. And it's not 'just' the pizza. their old style Italian entrees are delicious. and the place also still looks like an old New York Italian restaurant in the best possible way.. down a couple stairs .. booths .. a big table in the middle. And of course, the key to it all, the oldest brick pizza oven west of the Mississippi. The waiters and waitresses have been there forever, and the whole 'gruff' thing is an act. Just go. Ps- i just want to thank a young employee, who's name i think was Alfredo, for making last night's dinner even more fun than usual.

When I arrived around 7pm I was told it would be a 30 minute wait but I only waited 15 mins! Based on the reviews I tried the seafood linguine and lagsana. Both were delicious! We waited longer tha n usual according to our waiter because the kitchen was so slammed. We even got a canoli on the house as an apology. What a gem, I can see why this establishment has been around for 80 years

Food was awesome and delicious from appetizer to salad to entree!  Servers were nice and effective.
Seafood pizza was absolutely perfect!

Ooh my goodness!  How come I haven't been to Tommaso's until now?!  

If I were born Italian, I wish I had a mother who cooked like this!  I suggest ordering their pizza, pasta and lasagna.  Or, come with your entire family and order everything! :)

It's a long wait so it's a good idea to come early.  It's worth it!  Or, you can order online!

Great old school Italian joint in North Beach.  Smallish and cozy.  I usually get pizza, but have certainly eyed pastas and the like as they headed to other tables.  Service was fine.  Reasonable prices for SF in a tourist area.

i had a fantastic time at tommaso's - it feels like youre in an italian aunt's home. someone takes your name at the door, you wait a bit, you're seated in a romantic little cove, or at the somewhat large communal table in the middle of the restaurant. when you walk in - you know immediately that youre gonna have a wonderful meal..

we ordered of their private label wine - a syrah - for about $40 a bottle, a steal! it was light and went with the food nicely.  there are appetizers, salads, pastas, and pizzas to choose from. we got the scampi asparagus - 5 large shrimps resting on a bed of asparagus stalks in a creamy white wine sauce with parsley and garlic. OMG - and we sopped up ALL the sauce with the house bread they bring you. olive oil and vinegar are at the table for you to drown the bread in as well. but that appetizer set things up nicely! i would order it again.

we did half n half on a large pizza - 15 inch - cuz why not?! half fresh spinach and cheese, half mushroom and sliced sausage. the crust is amazing - fluffy and thin, but withstands the weight of the delicious and fresh toppings. i would go back to try ANY of their other pizzas - seafood, clams, the new carbonara, proscuitto - or the pastas that looked delicious on everyone else's table. NOMSIES. we didnt save room for dessert, sadly, so must return!

great food experience. service is friendly but brisk - food is definitely the star here!

This underground Sicilian replica is just fine. Good sized portions, good tasting pizza.

It's just dark and closed in for my ambiance preference.

Its the best lasagna i've ever had - by far.  I'm not even a huge lasagna fan but this stuff is truly special.  Ask for extra sauce.  Best pepperoni mushroom pizza I've ever had.  This place is the real deal.

I've been going to / ordering from Pasquale's on Irving since 1968. I used to tell anyone who'd listen how great the pizza was. Last night was the first time I've felt completely ripped-off by them.  I ordered a small pizza with onions, tomatoes and basil.  The toppings were literally paper-thin and there were hardly any on the pizza.  When I pay $20.80 ($24.80 with a $4 tip) for a small pizza - I expect that the toppings I paid for will be meaningfully represented.  Not only were there barely any of the paid-for toppings, but even the sauce and cheese were mostly missing.  I would have called immediately, but had a friend over  - so just served the pizza and apologized for the terrible quality.  I am so disappointed by how Pasquale's felt free to rip me off!!!

This is pizza that I remember as a kid.  I've been looking for pizza like this.  I love most pizza.  One of my favorite foods.  I was searching around for a new one to try tonight.  i have driven by several times, and finally said, lets order one.  

I got a medium pepperoni and sausage and the pesto garlic bread.  It's fantastic!  The crust is not too thin or thick.  Crispy, with a good chew and a little sweet.  The sauce is just spicy enough.  Quality ingredients.  The pesto garlic bread is really tasty and not overdone.  So many places toast it so you cut your mouth while eating it.  This was done just right.

I'll definitely be ordering again and want to try the House Special.  I want to go and sit down and try their pasta dishes too.

Nice service . pizza is very  good Thank you Mahmoud
Your pizza delicious
Very good I give you five stars

I ordered chicken strips from this place (it was 9pm on a Thursday)    I had to wait over 20 minutes. Once I opened my food I saw why it took so long.   They overcooked most of it.  

The fries were unsalted and the chicken fingers were bland AF.   Probably one of the worst food experiences I've had in a while.

Grabbed a quick slice after a soul cycle class and enjoyed it out in the sun! The pizza comes out fast and is reliable -- nothing special or crazy, but hits the spot if you're hungry and want a huge slice to satisfy your craving. No seating except for two outdoor tables, so it's more for picking up when you're in a rush!

My significant other and I have enjoyed pizza here many times over the last 10 years, usually eating late Friday or Saturday nights.  We've never ordered delivery, however.

This is an old school, late night pizza place.  Not a fine dining venue, so don't expect that.  Be prepared for plastic table cloths and old carpet flooring.

That said, every pizza we've eaten over the years has been well prepared, with toppings evenly and generously distributed, all fresh tasting.  The crust is on the thinner side and is baked perfectly and consistently.  Our favorite is their house special.

For appetizers, their chicken wings are well prepared, crispy on outside, moist and meaty on inside.  Their bread is served warm with generous pats of butter on the side.  

We also enjoy their reasonably priced bottles of interesting Italian wines.

For pasta and pesto lovers, their pesto tortellini is a great choice.  Their pesto sauce is fresher and much better than some Italian restaurants we frequent.  They serve a generous portion, so you may have left overs, which taste even better the next day!

Mita, their main server on Fridays/Saturdays is warm, efficient and ensures the customers are enjoying their meal.  

Maybe late at night, the flies that other Yelpers have mentioned, aren't around?  We've never seen flies in the dozens of times we've eaten here.

Thanks, Pasquale's, you're the real deal!

Total Amateur hour.  Ordered delivery at 6:30pm, called back at 8pm and was told the order was out.  Thirty minutes later, called back, new person answered (may have been a driver), said he couldn't find the ticket and that they didn't have a computer.  Sweet.

Pasquale's serves basic Italian American food, made well every time. It's not like going to Italy. It's not a trendy, gourmet or avant garde hotspot. It's just Italian American home cooking.  It comes to your table with good, polite, conscientious service.  But what really kicks this from 3 to 4 stars is that Pasquale's food is pleasantly affordable.

After having gone here inconsistently for years, last night my family ordered cheese ravioli with marinara, baked ziti and 3 personal pizzas for the kids. We also started out with some pesto garlic bread. All of the above was just good, solid food. The kids devoured the pizzas. My ravioli was plentiful and filling. Really, nothing remarkable, but absolutely nothing bad to say.  I was only able to finish half, and as I type this I am eating the left overs for breakfast. The ziti is advertised as "East Coast", which is funny because my wife was asking if I knew much about baked ziti and I explained that it's difficult to find a good rendition of the dish out West after having grown up on the stuff in NYC. Even so, I thought the ziti was good. It was cooked perfectly, and I really like their ricotta. My only complaint was that the dish was perhaps a bit watery, maybe from the marinara? The only drink of consequence was a glass of cheap chianti. The restaurant was a bit warm, and so was the wine.

When we were done eating, my wife and I wondered why we don't come to Pasquale's regularly as we have lived just a few blocks away for years.  We love Italian food and it's not as though every Italian dinner on a night out with the family has to be SPQR or Delfina.

We will definitely make this a more regular go-to spot for our family neighborhood walks.

The pizza was excellent but the pasta dishes sucked.   The chicken mushroom pasta dish did not have the chicken Cooked well and we told the busboy and he said that was not his issue.  If it was not for the pasta Linwood probably give this place a few more stars.  The owner should pay attention to his crew and customer service

Wondered here waiting for the Uber to come after the bars. We got two slices of pizza to go! And wow was it better tasting than I expected. Pizza is large like NYC slices and thin too, was worried it would lack flavor BUT took a bit of the pepperoni when I got home and it was so packed of flavor and the pepperoni had a good spice to it. Still tasted good after a 12 minute Uber ride home

More pizza in the Castro. I had a veggie combo slice today and it was about $6. You know I dig my SF pizza. This place offers crepes, gyros, and sandwiches too in one menu with pizza. Haven't seen it very much. Small stand shop near the theatre.
Their pizza hit the spot if you're hungry for a slice of pizza. Big toppings and generous with portions! I approve!

Another pizza spot in the Castro, I know, I know. But hear me out, it's actually pretty good! The pizza has a good amount of sauce, cheese, toppings, and large crust. It really hits the spot when you want some umami.

I'm actually really impressed with their chicken tenders, which are made to order. They are large, with  a nice deepfried coat that leaves them juicy. Plus they come with a good amount of crispy fries.

Outside area dirty. dirty sidewalk, windows dirty. Ordered Chicken Sandwich still wasn't there 15 minutes later. Lone employee said 3 more minutes and he continued to wash dishes and do who knows what. I wasn't happy about the dish washing jet sprayer being located so close to the cooking and prep area. I told him to give the sandwich to a homeless person meanwhile I'm out $16. Don't go here. Chicken Sandwich at Super Duper is $10 and the place is clean.  So much for supporting neighborhood businesses.

We wandered into Pasquales,  looking for a bite before a Segway Tour in Golden Gate State Park.  The vintage sign brought us in.

We had a great pizza.  Very fresh and flavored by the vegetables and not a mix.  We love thin crust!  They knew we were in a bit of a hurry and got our meal to us quickly so we could eat at a more leisurely pace.  I'd like to eat a full meal there some time on a future visit to San Francisco.  It had a great neighborhood feel.

Really good food; love the pizza and the pasta dishes.
Docking 2 stars for the terrible service: 4 of us eating and all got our food separately with about 10 - 15 minutes between each plate's arrival. My husband got his side dish a good 20 minutes before his meal, and my son's spaghetti with butter arrived last which was strange since it was the simplest thing we ordered.
By far the unfriendliest waitress I have ever been served by. EVER! She was in a hurry, very brusque and definitely in a bad mood. Twice she knocked my son's menu out of his hands in a bid to put cutlery and napkins on the table and she sighed when I asked to see a wine list. Think I'll stick to their pick up/delivery.

If I could give no stars I would waiting 2 hours on my pizza still waiting pizza good, but not worth 2 hours waiting. And they put me on hold for 5 minutes to find out about my order......

Update- just got pizza an it is cold! Now I have to spend 10 minutes reheating? This is crap!

I've eaten Pasquale's a couple of times. The pizza was subpar. The place itself smelled like a gas leak, which was alarming and uncomfortable.

This most recent time, I ordered delivery, and the total was inexplicably $4 to $5 higher than the price advertised on their own website. I agreed and proceeded with the order anyway because it was late, I was hungry, and there weren't many other options.

The pizza arrived lukewarm, which is disconcerting because I live only 4 blocks away.

honestly it wasn't anything special, but it really hit the spot after a night of clubbing. The slices were around $5 each for a slice, but it was warm, cheesy and had a nice flop. The slices were reheated and I was in and out within 5 minutes. I wouldn't go back if I was sober, but it is clutch in the deep of night.
Is this place ever open? I've tried to go 3 times in the middle of the day and it's always closed

FLAVOR (5/5) They heat up the slices you want when you order so you can experience the warm cheese pulls when you bite into the pizza. The pesto veggie and combo tasted great. The clam garlic is very strong on garlic. Despite it being their more unique and popular flavor, it might be too overpowering for some to finish the whole slice. The dough is just the right thickness for it to have a slight crunch but not taste like raw flour. I'm not too keen on thin crust pizzas, therefore I really enjoyed the crust they offered here.

INSTAGRAM WORTHY (3/5) You might be able to take a shot from the outside with the window of pizza/the sign. The inside is a narrow standing countertop situation with walls covered in stickers.

SERVICE (5/5) One person rings you up when you tell them what slices you want. Another person bring the pizza to you if you're eating there. Otherwise everything else is self service!

TAKE AWAYS: Try their pesto veggie and combo. Clam garlic is REALLY pungent, you've been warned.

We were waiting for a table at Sotto Mare and wanted to walk around the neighborhood. Then. We. Saw. Pizza. It looked really good so we decided we had to try a piece.

Slices are $5 and it's cash only. It is cut like a square and had cucumbers (quite interesting touch might I add), pepperoni, and cheese.

A nice little pit stop turned out some good food!
Love this for a quick bite that's reasonably priced and so delicious. Pizza that definitely hits the spot, I'd recommend the combo
Always to go to for late night. Line can be long and grabbing a slice surrounded by 20 other people can be off putting, but I think it's better than Square Guys
Really enjoyed how good the pizza was especially the vegetarian options. Pricing is amazing and the staff was super friendly.  The line is too small for a pizza this nice

I think we found one of our favorite pizza joints. Great pizza! How do they get the crust so crispy? It felt like I was eating a fresh cookie. We loved the clam garlic and the sausage pizza. Lines can get long because they charge a reasonable price. Yes, I said it....reasonable price in SF.

I had high hopes for this place considering all of the glowing reviews on yelp. We got the clam and garlic pizza since that's what they are known for and then a few indivisible slices to try as well. My individual slice was good, just plain pepperoni. I was very underwhelmed with the clam and garlic. Let me preface this by saying that I LOVE garlic on everything. Even strong garlic. However, this was just too much. The garlic was completely overpowering and clams were just meh. Easy place to stop for a quick bite, and would maybe return for a slice if I was near, but overall there are much better pizza places in the area.
Call in the order!    It's an easy pick up for a good pizza.   The crust is very flavorful.
It's a nice spot to get pizza after you've been drinking all day! The vibes were fun, but there's no outdoor seating. The staff is nice and get your food out as quick as possible.

We came mid afternoon on a weekend and still there was a line out the door. It's a small establishment but there are a few bar stools in the back if you choose to eat there, though it seemed like most people took a few slices out in boxes to enjoy later.

While waiting in line, we were able to see their pizza offerings and peek at their prices. For a slice about the size of a spread open hand its $4.5 and once you bite into it its definitely worthwhile. My favorite was their clam pizza which I enjoyed some of right in the store. It was piping hot (they heat up each order before putting it in the box) and the cheese was stringy and the toppings flavorful, fresh and generous. The crust was overall soft with a slight crisp. I enjoyed my veggie pizza at work the next day and it was almost as tasty heated up.

I oddly do not crave pizza, but if anyone were to suggest pizza in North Beach with no frills, I would recommend Golden Boy.

Great vibe, great taste, great price. Bring some friends/fam and enjoy.

Brunch is fun if that's your jam. Not a crowded chaos.

Great little pizza place. I was in the area and looking for lunch. I chose this spot based on Yelp reviews. I had one of the pizzas off the menu with a glass of red wine for a Sunday lunch. The flavors were fresh and good. I sat at the bar area and service was good. The atmosphere was lovely and fun. You can watch the cooking action from this location. On a Sunday at noon there was quick service and seating for one.

Broccoli pizza & butter salad were great.
Spaghetti was just so so.. would try the other pasta next time & the octopus dish.
SF
Great wine, pizza and pasta. It is a smaller spot but we still went with a group of 6 and shared everything. It was great. I loved the mushroom crostini and the clam pizza.

We recently moved out of SF and miss this place so much! Excellent brunch and dinner. The sausage pizza and baby lettuce salad are some favorites. Great wine choices and loved all the dessert options. Love the ambiance and decor.
Had a nice and easy pizza brunch here. They take reservations so you don't have to deal with a big line or standing around. Pizzas were good and the bay area legends wall-paper is very cool.

Fiorella is truly a 5 star establishment in my book. The service, food and ambiance are all wonderful. I have yet to have a dish that doesn't excite me or have anything less than awesome service. The portion sizes are great, 3 people = one app, two pizzas, one pasta. We cleared our plates and we're not feeling weighed down.  Recommend the crispy butternut squash app, the burrata pizza, and the cacio e pepe.

The service and food here were both unappetizing. First of all walking in the host/possibly manager seemed concerned about tables and seating us, even tho we had made an open table reservation. Not very inviting and the waitress was rude as well. They picked up our table the instant the last bite of food was off our plates and quickly dropped off the check. I have never felt so rushed to get out of a restaurant.
The food is very flat. The only thing that made it tasty was the spicy oil and that's not saying much. I honestly was surprised there was a line at the door. I don't understand the hype.

Positives of this restaurant: the wallpaper, the spicy oil and the bartender (?) who brought my drink, he seemed nice.

I've been here twice - it's cute, small modern and has the best wallpaper ever.

The service was terrific - we were there for brunch. The lettuces salad was delicious, the avocado toast (was which sent on the house) was delicious, and the fried potatoes are a treat. I would come back for the food and service alone...and what really topped it off was that after my friend mentioned her husband's cider (Far West Dry Cider) was on their menu, the server was so nice and talked about how he was going to try it after his shift and gave us 15% off the tab. Didn't need to do that but was being neighborly, which we appreciated!

Great addition to the hood.
Jessie C was the BOMB.  Amazing service.  Great food.  I highly recommend to all my fans, friends, and future fans.

Dear Delfina,

I'm sorry I only gave 4 stars when I reviewed your Margherita pizza 4 years ago.
I was so wrong. Your Margherita pizza deserves 5 stars or even more. It really is as good as it gets. I have yet to find a better Margherita pizza from anywhere else.

When I first had a Margherita pizza in Italy in 2010, my comment to my husband after my first bite was "OMG, Delfina's is so much better...". It wasn't in Napoli but still it was in Italy recommended by a local... Since then, we've tried Margherita pizza in Italy or in the US whenever we could, and we haven't found a one that is better than yours or even close to be as good as yours.

So, dear Delfina, your Margherita is really as good as it gets, and it's heavenly.
Order it to go if you can, it's much easier since you'll wait a long time at the restaurant otherwise. I love the pizza with creme on top, and the crust here is just perfect.

Best pizza in the city and arguably elsewhere, if you are okay letting go to deep dish or NY pie. The margarita as well as the salsiccia are always a must (yes both). The bottom crust is charred perfectly so you have the original and authentic Neapolitan pizza with out it being flimsy.

Food and service is always amazing at Delfina. The burrata, fungi, and salsiccia are amazing dishes. I would however recommend having the servers read up on some of their wines if they want to try and embarrass their customers. I asked for their Barbaresco (clearly printed on the menu), the server had a confused look on her face, looked at their menu and condescendingly said "oh it's not Barbaresco it's Nebiollo that's the grape". Knowing that this the appellation in the Langhe region of Piedmont, it's also a style of wine such as a Bordeaux or and red Burgundy. To be clear, the Nebiollo grape is famously made in Barolo and in Barbaresco, Barbaresco being the lighter style of the 2 powerful, high tannin wines from Piedmont. I'm not saying I know everything about wine, but I also don't want to look like a fool in front of my date!!! Haha

Hands down the best PIZZA in SF! Fresh toppings,homemade sauce and the best crust ever!All together makes for the best pie in the Frisco Bay. Favorite margarita & fennel sausage is what brings me back every time! Btw they know what there doing with meatballs and appetizers.(corn & spicy cauliflower).

I know I am going to be an anomaly here but I'm ok with that.

I came here with my aunt and my two kids. They wanted pizza and my aunt thought this would fit the bill. Oh wow, were we wrong! This is definitely not a place for kids. The environment is loud and aggressive. Music is thumping on the speakers. People are nearly screaming at each other to be heard. Service was poor - part of our order was missed and never delivered. To their credit they gave us desert for free. When we asked for a tweak to their standard offering they refused. All we wanted was for them to go easy on the sauce. Nope. It had to become a battle with the chef. We won, which was nice.

The food is fine otherwise. My kids ate their pizza. The salad my aunt and I had was tasty. It's just not a family friendly place.

Yuuuuuuuuuum.

You honestly just can't go wrong. I've had many different pies, and goddamn, but they've all been great.

I think my favorite is the Spicy Clam Pie, and not just because I'm a lesbian. It really is delicious and hits all the right notes, balancing fire and shellfish nicely. The Margherita is also a can't-go-wrong classic.

We also usually started the Tricolore salad, sometimes rounded off with the burrata...

Service is always nicely balanced. Relaxed but not slow, and I've never been rushed through a meal, even though this is obviously a hopping joint.

In any event, you should go.

Food: 5/5 - The thin crust pizza is authentic, arguably the best in SF (Tony's Pizza?), yet offers toppings like egg, clam, broccoli raabe, and others that make it unique. Fried pig ears are like fresh pork rinds, with lime and chili oil that give it some zest and spice.

Service: 3/5 - Since it gets busy during prime dinner hours, the service can be slow at times, but still remains friendly.  

Ambiance: 4/5 - Despite being a busy spot, the tables aren't too close/crowded in most cases, and the overall feel is clean and well kept.

Value: 5/5 - With full sized thin crust pizzas at $10-17, this is well worth it as long as you are either willing to wait, take out, or go during an off-peak time. Best shared of course, so that you can try a variety.

Typifies the stereotyped "SF Smug" attitude that I'm not a fan of. The food is tasty, but I come from the East Coast where good pizza abounds. And I've spent less than half the price at zillions of East Coast pizza places for pizza that is twice as good. For me, it wasn't worth the hype and I won't be going back unless someone else is paying for me and I don't have to talk to the rude servers!
First time since I have left Atlanta.    Yeah. Eclectic food. Yummy. Made in front of me. Great service.  So happy.

Seriously the line/wait/pastries/bread/price did not disappoint me  happy to line up and nom nom in the car. Always excited to see what's baked for the day (nicely displayed behind the window) -"I'd like to try that!"
One of my favorite bakeries, and much more reasonably priced than some of the other bakeries in the sunset. Their vegan focaccia is always really good and a good deal!

Usually not a fan of cinnamon but LOVED the pecan roll! Nice thick gooey texture with a hint of cinnamon and caramel undertone!
The pizzas are also good! Tried Wednesday, Thursday and Sunday so far and Sunday's special was my favorite (thanks to the overflowing kale sitting on top of my pizza.)
Potato rolls and Challah rolls are also good - I made mini burgers with them for my family and it was a winner!
Will return until I try EVERYTHING!

Arizmendi makes what is easily some of the best pizza I've ever had. We got a half pie of the daily special: Kalamata olives, spinach, Parmesan, garlic, and other goodness. The crust is thin, almost black in places, which is exactly the way I like it. But it is not a Neapolitan crust.

My gf had to drag me away from the pastry displays. I would have easily devoured the cherry corn scone, the wolverine roll, or the pecan roll.

Minus one star because I would have liked to have been able to wash my hands somewhere on site before devouring my pizza.
The bread and pastries are so good. The bread has a great texture and flavor. The pastries are sweet but not overwhelming. Definitely recommend this bakery.

I don't know what to say except this place is the f****ing best! Their croissants and focaccia squares are amazing. If you like English muffins, their 6 packs are perfect for making breakfast sandwiches at home.

Decent pizza. Other bake goods were fine. I personally would visit just for the pizza.  Although, I do think the east bay and cheese board locations were better than this Sunset location.  Pizza here were slightly mushy side. If you like your extra crispy pizza, you wont get it here. If you're new to Arizmendi, the pizzas change everyday, so I cannot comment on which one is better. So come here for the treasure hunt and discover what they have for the day.

We love the asiago cheese bread and the scones. If you go early in the morning they come out fresh and you avoid the lines.
Overall, everything is good here. We've been returning for a couple of years now and quality has never gone down! Love this place!

I've only been here once and I'm hooked. The flatbread daily special is off the hook! They are fancy and gourmet ingredients and baked to perfection. Also for only $3, you can't go wrong. Definitely get two if you're hungry. So cool that they offer a variety of baked in the house goods. So many to choose from it's awesome. It's cool that they have vegan options too. Can't wait to go back and try the other flatbreads. :)
The best vegan muffins :) I love the banana walnut and lemon poppyseed! You will not be disappointed!

Whenever I eat at Giorgio's, I imagine that this is the restaurant that Billy Joel was thinking of when he wrote his "Scenes from an Italian Restaurant" song.  You've got your plastic grapes hanging from the arbors on the ceiling, checkered tablecloths, rich aromas coming from the big ovens.  

Giorgio's gets five big juicy stars from me because they serve perfect pizzas.  Because they've been around for a long, long time, the ovens impart that rich, slightly brown flavor that is impossible to get from new establishments (without being "blackened," like Amici's).  The sauce is balanced, the toppings are generous, the cheese melts beautifully, and the total experience is great.  

I also love LOVE jukeboxes, and they have a wonderful one at Giorgio's, filled with classics like Rosemary, Frank and Mel, as well as some current hits.  I just wish the volume could be turned higher, to drown out the noise from the other patrons -- it is a smallish place and can get pretty noisy.  

The Calzones are great, stuffed with cheese and goodies, and the crust is tender and perfectly baked.  The antipasto plate is wonderful as as starter for the table to share.  

Parking is a true pain in the ass in this part of Clement -- we only go to Giorgio's if our parking kismet is working for it.

Simply delicious here at Giorgio's. If you want scrumptious spaghetti and meatballs or a pizza pie (my son likes the penne with meat sauce or calzones), this is the spot. Eager to come back in the future for other entrees...Arturo and Seth from San Antonio

We ordered two medium Specials and they were reminiscent of the pies we grew up eating back in the 70's....nice thin crust that isn't too soggy in the middle.  Apparently ordering the XL the past 10-15 years doesn't allow the crust to crisp up like a good NYC pizza should.  We'll probably order Smalls or Mediums from now on!

OK - this is really a 3.67 star review - but I will be generous! :)

If a pizza joint could be a dive, then this would be it. The place is kinda cheezy (not just the pizza) and a little tacky. It reminds me somewhat of It's Tops (which is!), only it's an "Italian" pizza restaurant and not an American Diner. Wood paneling and phony Mediterranean decor.... NICE! I do love a good dive.

But full marks for the rest of the evening - we explained that we were in something of a hurry and the service was friendly, prompt, and fast -and the thin-crust pizza weren't half bad either. (Thick also available.)

A great place to grab a bite on your way out drinking in the Richmond, especially if you don't feel like a Korean!

Thank god this restaurant exists, because otherwise I don't know WHERE all the families with small children would eat dinner on a Friday/Saturday night. Seriously, this place is like Chuck-E-Cheese without the games and creepy animatronics.

But don't be fooled by the delicious smell wafting out of here, because like so many other pizza places in San Francisco, this pizza is bland bland bland. Like, "pass the hot sauce so I can swallow this" bland.

Summary: if you have a small child, or just the tastebuds of one, you've found your new favorite pizza parlor.

Cool atmosphere.  Very traditional pizza place.  Everything is authentic even the table cloths which are red and white checked.  I like the aesthetic feel of this restaurant.  The smell of pizza wafts you as you come in the door.

The best part of our pizza was the fresh basil which was julienned and scattered over the top.  Sometimes the basil is cooked into the pizza but in this case it was raw which was very refreshing.  The tomatoes and other vegetables were also fresh.  The crust is neither thick nor thin.  Not too cheesy.  I didn't have to mop the grease with a napkin.

I had a bit of east coast nostalgia here.  Feel like I could sing 'You've lost that loving feeling' from Top Gun.  Would have to try another time to give a more accurate review.

A slice and a soda for under $5.00 at lunch is a winner everytime. Quality ingredients; sauce, real stringy cheese, as good a NY pizza you will find in SF. Even has the oil drip when you find the slice in half. Never disappoints.

Everyone know's I'm not a huge pizza fan...

Correction: I'm NO pizza apologist.

The fact is MOST pizzas suck. This one does not. It's not the best in SF, but it's up. And if you really want a good experience have them make it extra thin... This should be an option everywhere.

Let's see where to begin, it's Friday night we get there around 645 we were told 20-30 minute wait.  That's fine.
3 of us go wait outside the 4th person stayed inside, she is sitting there watching other parties of 4 being seated who arrived after us.
She says something to the hostess who was a rude biatch and lied to our faces about why we were being ignored and everyone and their mothers were being seated before us.
We finally get seated after waiting an hour and 20 minutes the table was so small we asked if we could move to the table behind us the rude hostess told us NO but the manager told us we could..
The food was okay nothing to rave about, maybe we just had a bad taste in our mouth after being treated so rudely.

This pizza was awful. I ordered a margherita pizza & added pepperoni, and it came (looking nothing like the pictures online, I might add), greasy & rubbery & just genuinely the worst pizza I've ever had. I couldn't even cut through the crust because of how rubbery it was & we had to lay paper towels over the cheese to sop up the grease. Very little flavor, and vaguely sweet crust. I'm all for crappy pizza nights, but I would have ordered Pizza Hut or even Little Caesar's over this- and paid less, too!
This square pizza is really unique. The taste, the presentation. It is really worth the price. Fast service. Accommodating staff. This is such a great deal

Omg RANCH! I love you! Pizza you are amazing. Ranch, I need to recreate you at home because your that good! This place is of the chart! Beware there are lookalikes out there and they have nothing on this masterful eatery.

Came on a Thursday night with a few friends and it was a good crowd. There's tables and bar seating downstairs and more seating along the ledge upstairs.

We ordered:

- lean green sausage machine pie: they are cut in 4 big slices, but I would actually suggest them to do 6 instead. It was on the heavier side, but tasted great and the honey drizzle is a nice addition. It was a good balance of savory and sweet. Good to share for 2 people, or 3 if you add some appetizers

- dry Schezwan wings to share: really enjoyed the flavor on this one! I would actually return more so for these wings than the square pies!

Good ambience and noise level. One unisex restroom inside. Staff were quick and friendly. The neighborhood is dimly lit and in a quite isolate area at night, so be careful!

Let me preface this by saying that I understand businesses have suffered greatly from Covid and they need all the support they can get from us. My family is in the food service industry and I get it, trust me.

With that said, I regret supporting this business and will never be going back here again. Going into this order, I already knew they were snobby-- declining to make any substitutions or changes to their pizza toppings, making sure to *only* go up to the counter when we get the text saying our order is ready-- but it was whatever, I placed a pickup order through the website anyway. Order was to be ready in 35 mins.

Walked from Union Square to this joint around 6:30 PM and the walk was sketchy as hell. Got there and waited among a sea of DoorDashers, while a homeless person literally squatted right next to the establishment and took a dump on the pavement, the disgusting smell of feces wafting all up in our faces. Don't worry SPG, I'm not taking stars off for these things, I'm just setting the scene.

As we're waiting for our pizza, we observe the man who is manning the "counter" and he is absolutely unpleasant. Barely looking at people's phones and swiftly telling them "Not ready!". As he brings orders out, he tells a couple delivery drivers who are waiting on more than one delivery order to just go and drop off the first one and come back as the other one is not ready yet. Um what? Who are you to tell them this? They probably picked up these orders with the intent to deliver all at once. He also tried to dissuade two people who were trying to walk up and order the regular way instead of through the app/site, saying it'll take a long time. Bro, let these people make their own decisions instead of giving them annoying, unsolicited advice. Anyway, I'm getting real agitated at how rude this man is, while I'm eyeing these bags that are clearly ready to be dispersed, just sitting there inside.

I get a text saying my order is ready (7 mins later than indicated). I flag the guy down and he BARELY glances at my phone and says "Not yet ready." I tell him that the text says it is ready and he says that sometimes it is wrong. My husband and I obviously lose our cool and demand that he at least CHECK (because he was saying all this without knowing the name of the order nor checking that shelf with all those READY pickup orders). He snarkily tells us that he's sure it isn't ready yet but sure, he will go check. Well what do you know, it WAS ready, and I had been staring at that same bag for at least the last five minutes. Absolutely ridiculous.

Pizza was lackluster, super overpriced ($53 for two pizzas roughly 10"x8") and expect to pay an extra 5% surcharge for the SF Mandate. Not sure why they won't open up their dining room for regular folks who want to just walk in and eat. I mean, at the very least, open up the dining room for people to stand and wait because standing outside in that area is neither enjoyable nor safe. I think it's pure laziness for businesses to continue with this lame takeout model especially when they have a fully functional dining room. But it doesn't matter, people who can afford it are gonna keep supporting this overhyped business through delivery apps nonetheless.

If you read this far, go support local hole-in-the-walls who make you feel like a valued customer and will serve you bomb food. Not this establishment.
The food in this restaurant is very good. I enjoyed eating it, but the price is a little bit expensive.
Omg the best pizza I've had ever! Make sure you ask the hot honey sauce, you'll thank me later.

cool spot, my partner & I ordered the plant squares 2.0 with a gluten free crust. To my surprise the crust was super fluffy and thick! The pizza lacked flavor tho, I think next time we'll probably go with a pepperoni pizza.
Nothing to complaint about. Solid Detroit style pizza. Flavourful crust. And just look at those pepperoni cups!

Dinner review.

3 - Cheeseburger salad

5 - The big von (Mean green sausage machine + Pepperoni instead of broccoli)

5 - Custom pizza (Pepperoni, sausage, chorizo, mushrooms, cream sauce)

+Beer selection

Overall, "as good as it gets."

Hands down, one of the best pizzas I've had in long time. We ordered the Big Von with a side of red sauce and had it delivered to the Outer Richmond. Our pizza arrived warm and perfectly crispy! That said, SPG was a bit pricier than your average pizza joint, so this may not be our regular "go to" spot, but definitely on our radar if we feel like splurging on pizza.

What did SPG do well?
*Crispy, buttery flavorful crust on the edges and bottom. I hate soggy pizza bottoms.
*Light and fluffy on the inside
*Not overly greasy
*Super crispy pepperoni
*Good size, pretty dense. Don't be fooled by the small size, it's pretty filling after 2 slices. It was shared between 2 people.

They didn't have calamari when I went here, which was a bummer, but that doesn't stop the 5 star review.

I've been here twice and their food does not disappoint. My family and I ordered the Little Italy Salad with chicken, it was surprisingly soo tasty.

We also had the Pasta Genovese, so creamy and good! My parents are not fans of pasta, but they loved this. For pizza, we ordered the Detroit Motorhead - it's so thick and full of flavor. Super filling and delicious.

Their cannoli the perfect dessert to top it all off. The cream was perfectly sweet and the shell was nice and crunchy. If you're ever looking for great Italian food, this is the place to go.

(I'd also recommend putting yourself on the Yelp waitlist before even showing up so your wait time is cut down to just several minutes once you arrive.)

I'm generally not a huge pizza person, but I have to admit, the pizzas here are definitely unique!

My group of 4 came for dinner on Memorial Day. We came right before 7 pm, and was told the wait was close to 1 hour. We added ourselves to the Yelp waitlist and got some drinks + appetizers nearby, only to get a text maybe 30 minutes later saying our table was ready. We had to scramble to finish and pay the bill, since we weren't expecting the table to be ready so quickly. It seems like the wait isn't as bad as it seems...

There is some seating indoors as well, but I'm glad we were seated in an outdoor booth. There was quite a bit of outdoor seating, they've really made good use of all the sidewalk and road space around the restaurant!

We perused the menu for a while. The number of options on there is honestly a bit overwhelming, but it helped they marked all the medal winners. We finally decided upon one experimental pizza and one classic. For the former, the Cal Italia ($27), and for the latter, the New Yorker ($32).

The Cal Italia was interesting with the balsamic reduction and the sweet fig preserve, but my favorite of the two was hands down the New Yorker, which was essentially a meat lover's pizza. They don't skimp on the meat, and there was a bite of pepperoni or sausage in every bite, which I loved.

Maybe it was because we were sitting outside, but service was a bit slow. Every time we needed something, we had to wait a while for our server to come by.

The service was terrible. We waited 20 mins to order and then an additional 45 min for two pizzas. Not to mention we were in the cold next to a heat lamp that didn't work well. When we asked to move tables the host had told me that if we were to move we would be put in the back of the waitlist. None of the waiters/waitresses were attentive or helpful when we asked them to check on our order.

The pizza was good, but not worth putting up with the bad service. I'm not coming back.

The Italian salad was delicious. You can taste the difference in their olive oil and balsamic vinegar. Delicious and fresh greens and walnuts.
I also got a pizza with vegan cheese. It was delicious.
They even have good coffee.
Must try!

Always delicious. Got the award winning Margarita pizza. Simple, chewy & so flavorful.
This is my second time at this location. I've also been to his place in Vegas, Pizza Rock. I believe I like this location best, it's also closer to home.
This time we got the 3 meatballs app... pork & beef mixture, so meaty & delicious. The sauce was simple & very fresh.
I got the Caesar too. Big enough to share. Good flavor. Loved the cheese. The lettuce was crisp & fresh.
We'll definitely go again.
The wait can be long, but you can check in via Yelp prior. Also, bring a jacket or blanket. It can be cold, if you're waiting outside/seated outside... even in July!

My wife and I went on a trip to San Francisco and look up best pizza in San Francisco.  Tony's and a bunch other places came up, but sealed the deal was all the locals saying that Tony's was the best. We went the next day and waited in a line before it opened. Service was great, we had our server and their were meny bus boys helping out because this place does get busy. The 2 pizzas were on point. Dough was fresh and ingredients tasted fresh. We will definitely will be back to bring our family.  They make you feel like home.

Normally, I love this place and would give it 1 billion stars but my experience most recently was different. I ordered this place on door dash and it unfortunately took almost 2 hours for the delivery to arrive within the city. On top of that, they forgot our ranch! That was unfortunate, especially since we had paid extra for it.

The pizza tasted it good, but it probably would've been better if it was fresh. The pizza arrived almost cold and stale. I know this is not the restaurants fault, and the food was good but I will try to stop in next time I am craving Tonys.

We got the sausage with ricotta and it was so good! We even had leftovers and save them for later. The slices were as good as they could be given the fact that they were almost cold.

My gf marked this restaurant as one of her places to check out in her to find great pizza. She was correct in doing so, which I learned when we stopped by when we happened to be in North Beach not long ago.

We began with the fried artichokes, which I had never heard of, but my gf insisted on, as it is one of her favorites (and apparently a rarity at most restaurants, so when she sees it, she always gets it). It was delightful: delicate breading on the outside with a warm, full-bodied flavor of ricotta on the inside.

We ordered two pizzas. My metric for a pizza place is its margherita pizza, and Tony's is apparently award-winning, so we ordered that (and it arrived first). Basically, the pizza was perfect. The cheese was soft, creamy, and delicious, the sauce was a lovely accompaniment (light and slightly sweet), and the crust was a divine combination of a toasted marshmallow on the outside and a pillow on the inside.

The second pizza we ordered was the Cal Italia. This one was a little more niche and artistic. The salty spice of the prosciutto, the sour bite of the balsamic, creaminess of the cheese, and sweetness of the fig all came together well atop a (once again) perfect crust. We liked the first pizza better, but this was quite nice, too.

On a non-culinary note, I also really liked the vibe of this place. We ate on the inside (one of our first times doing so since the pandemic began). It was nicely lit (dark in parts in a mood lighting sort of way) with walls decorated with old pictures in frames, and cushy, leatherish seats. It was classy and classic, and added to our dining experience. I would go back for the food for sure, but also just to have a drink at the bar (which was cool and had what appeared to be a substantial beer list).

Went there because this place won awards and great yelp reviews. Pretty underwhelming, poor service and prices that don't match quality or taste. Long wait times were expected and I am NOT dinging them for that. There is a small park right across where one could enjoy their food or just chill. Nice location.
Margherita Pizza - 5/10. We were served lukewarm pizza. Totally unacceptable. The flavors were there but their service was too slow. The server defended that the pizza was lukewarm because of the type of oven they used for this pizza. Sounded crazy to me.

Coccoli with artichoke cream, arugula 2/10. Flavor missing.
Veggie Pizza 5/10 - This was served hot but didn't taste any better than some chain restaurant Pizza.
Tiramisu 1/10. Total yuck. This is not Tiramisu.
I asked for an Italian red wine and it was pretty bad too. Forget about the wine glass. Not going there again.

their pizza is very good, the waiter friend was very nice, the taste is excellent

Award Winning Margherita

AH-MAZING.  This crust is ridiculously delicious.  Swoon worthy.  We had the prosciutto pizza and it was piled high with freshly grated Parmesan curls and fresh arugula.  Best pizza I have ever had.  Go here.

I can't wait to get back to your restaurant!!!! The best napolitan pizza in town no question about it!!

I hope you are all safe and healthy! And see you soon!!!!

#ThankYouThursday

What can I say? I used to live next to the North Beach Il Casaro and it was one of my favorite places to get pizza. This is the first time I've tried this particular Il Casaro and it's equally as good. It's just always so damn good. When I crave pizza, I almost always crave Il Casaro. It's the closest I've found in SF to the Neapolitan pizza that is so incredible in Europe.

This time around I got the burrata antipasti (which comes with tomatoes, arugula and some flatbread) and one pizza: half broccoli and salssicia and half Il Casaro. The great thing about their pizzas is that you can do halves - as long as the sauces match. So either two white sauce pizzas or two red sauce pizzas to make up one whole pizza.

I had high hopes for Il Casaro based on all the great reviews... but in the end, it was just another average pizzeria.

3 stars for the beet salad that lacked beets and flavor

3 stars for the grilled shishito peppers that were small and lacked heat

3 stars for the bufalino cheese pizza that was bland

2 stars for the calzone that lacked flavor (starting to see a theme here????)

4 stars for the one saving grace - tuna pizza

Despite the disappointing blandness of the food, service was 5 stars
Wow! This is real Italian pizza! Together with the view, it is like you are in Europe! Even single pizza with only mozzarella cheese and little basil is already amazing.

Just one word to describe their pizza:
                    A M A Z I N G!!!!
It brought me back to the time I have spent in Italy, in particular when I lived in Naples!
The dough is fluffy, airy, soft with a nice bubbled crust, exactly how it is must be (in order to be qualified as a Neapolitan pizza). I enjoyed a margherita with extra burrata, fresh and delicious. Service was fast and efficient.
Prices are average considering the area, parking can be a bit challenging, but definitely it's worth the wait!

We got the Calabrese. The sausage was tasty. I would say that this combination of ingredients would have been wonderful, but it was as if they made it in a huge rush, and slapped on too much cheese and made a few more misteps. The crust was burnt in more places than I think is acceptable. If you look at the photo, the largest slice is like more than twice the size of smallest. Such a big slice would be soggy as the dough around the middle of the pizza is thinnest. Honestly a four stars at least if these issues were fixed.

Not sure if related to the rush, but I found that the dough here was less impressive (kind of just puffy and plain) than many of the other pizza places and Italian restaurants in the Bay Area, where the pizza game is so competitive. I've lately been impressed so many times by the pizza restaurants here that perhaps this one just didn't stand out.

This place was also extremely loud. I don't think we ever managed to hear anything on the first iteration.

Junst arrived in San Francisco, hungry and tired.
The pizzas are awesome and the delivery arrived earlier! One pizza was customized.

This place was really interesting during our 3rd visit to San Francisco.  Located in North Beach (Little Italy), it is right off the main road leading into the area on Columbus Ave.  We get there on a Friday night and had to wait for an open table because it was packed, but we didn't wait long though.
