Anywho, once we got seated, the service was great.  There was a bit of a language barrier there because I'm sure these guys were straight up Italian, like from the old country Italian, :)  because when we put in our order, I think something got lost in translation, because our first set of pizzas were all wrong.  I think we screwed them up because we ordered 2 pizzas, with half this and half that and add this and not that type of order and I think they aren't used to that, plus the dude didn't write any of it down either, sooooo.

Well needless to say, they didn't take it too well by us sending​ food back, but hey the pizzas were all wrong.  So this waiter gets insulted and complains to his manager, then comes back to our table and says that his manager will be taking over because apparently he can't get our order right.  So then she comes to our table and acts as if it was our fault or something and then started to take our order again, and again she didn't write it down either, so what the heck!?  And that's when the service declined.  We did get our pizzas how we ordered them, but with an attitude, LOL!!

Now to the food: The pizzas were great, as any neapolitan pizza would be and the pasta carbonara was decent.  You can tell the pasta was old school style, nothing fancy, but still good.  As a matter of fact, the whole place was old school, nothing fancy, just a cool little restaurant to have some good Italian food.  At any seat in the house you'll be able to hear and see that hustle and bustle of Columbus Ave.  I would recommend this place to anyone out there, just don't order a half this, half that pizza.  :)  I would have given them 5 Stars if it weren't for the attitude.

The last time I was in San Francisco, my friend and I shared an Uber with a man from Italy.  We asked him where the best pizza in SF was, and he told us it was Il Casaro.  When I came back, I knew I had to try it for myself.

Il Casaro is small inside and usually will have a wait, but it wasn't unreasonable. Once inside, service was generally friendly if a little inattentive - they seemed like they only had a couple of people covering several tables each, and since our table was a little out of the way it was a little harder to get the waiters' attention.

I ordered the Il Casaro Pizza and added sauce at the suggestion of our server, and my friend got the margherita.  The pizza had everything I like - fresh mozzarella, mushrooms, and prosciutto. The crust was crispy and slightly chewy in the way that only pizza cooked in a very hot wood-burning oven is.  All of this added up to an enjoyable pizza, but I'm not sure that I'm convinced it's necessary better than the other pizzerias offering a similar style - there weren't any factors that really took it over the top. It's certainly a solid option, but the jury is still out for me on the title of best pizza in SF.

Outstanding! Sat at the bar and loved watching the pizza artists. Everyone really works together to provide excellent service and atmosphere, despite the cozy quarters.

Housemade meatball/fennel pizza was our favorite

Tons of take out orders being placed/picked-up too!

This place was absolutely amazing. Food was delicious and the sparkling wine was great!! We ended our night with the flour less chocolate cake and panna cotta and it was yummo!  Oliver was our waiter and he was very friendly and very welcoming. In my eyes he should get a raise! We need more waiters like Oliver.  If he is your waiter tip him good.  We'll be coming back and hopefully Oliver will be our waiter!

Closed for maintenance !?! Man, nothing was said about this plan or closure online or on their voicemail message when I called today. Came in from out of town to try out Pizza 211 and found sign on door :/ = closed.
Quaint neighborhood spot. Excellent thin crust pizza with friendly staff. We'll definitely be back,

So I'm sure this is a local hangout being its location hidden away in the Richmond. But thanx to yelpers and some deep searching we had a really amazing lunch today. My husband and I had a "date" to see the Chihuly @ the DeYoung Museum (which I think the last time I was there was like when I was in 4th grade? shit eons ago) Anyhoo after visiting the museum and being inspired by all the amazing glass work we wanted something good for lunch. I had already scoped out this place on yelp yesterday and read all the reviews and it sounded quaint and the food sounded fresh and unique.
I liked the feel of the neighborhood, and the size of the restaurant being very intimate and cozy (though I could see it being crazy at dinner time). We arrived around 1:30 on a Thursday and it was pretty full, but were able to get a seat inside for two. They also have a few tables for outside seating, and on a nice day like yesterday was perfect(but they were taken).
We ordered two of the pizzas of the day a summer squash with tomatoes and ricotta cheese and another with pine nuts, rosemary and a very pungent cheese  I can't remember the name but had quite a "kick" with every bite. The crust was thin and crunchy and the cheese perfect and chewy!
Each pie is made to order and fresh, fresh, fresh!
Like someone said its cash only (we were prepared) and with a couple of beers and a fabulous piece of flour less chocolate cake (I don't know how they make it so light and fluffy?) it was $42. Worth every penny!
We brought one piece of pizza home with us.
The the salads of the day also looked wonderful too.
Parking is challenging but we found some metered parking out on Clement with an easy walk. I know we aren't "locals" but it made our day out in SF. I love the flavor of the city and I prefer finding those out of way "gems" to have a really great meal.
I added my two pizza's to the pics.

Would totally pass on this place. Staff made me and my friend feel totally unwelcome. Hardly a greet or a smile when we first walked in (door was ajar) and asked if they were open and they shut the door after they responded with an aloof "We open in five minutes." Later, they welcomed the other people in (outer Rich locals?) so we just followed and sat ourselves. When I asked what they recommended, she replied "well... it's all good." ... I dunno if she just didn't know what I meant by "recommend." Ordered the farm egg pizza and a mexican coke.
Just really a meh experience, the place is incredibly tiny.
I like to support local businesses, but not if the staff carries a "locals only" or arrogant attitude.

I'd been meaning to eat here for a year and a half and I finally tried it for my birthday dinner this year. I'm not into waiting so we arrived at 5:30 on a Monday and got the last available table.
A salad, a pizza and a desert, split between 2 people is a perfect amount of food.
We had
organic greens and cheese salad
mushroom and green garlic and some cheese I'd never heard of pizza
flourless chocolate cake.
Hot damn. Everything was amazing. Just schlep over to the Richmond as early as you can and eat here!

This is my new favorite restaurant & it's vegetarian friendly!  We ordered their 2 daily specials for starters:  1) purple cauliflower salad w/ greens, farro, chopped almonds & creamy dressing, 2) sautéed broccolini w/ croutons & olive oil; for our main dish, we got 2 Pizzettas:  1)farm egg, mix mushroom, spinach & ricotta cheese; 2)margherita.  Everything was so fresh & delicious!  I highly recommend Pizzetta 211.  I bet you would want to come back for more once you get a taste of their delicious specials & pizzettas!

Okay, went back with my sister and actually ate in the restaurant this time.

Service was super friendly and the pizza, as always, was good. My sis and I had to wait for about 15 minutes or so for a table to free up, but we didn't mind.

They took our orders, brought us our appetizer, brought us our pizzas, and gave us dessert (it was closing time and we were the last ones there).

Pizzas: Margherita and the Farm Egg pizza. Both good.

Appetizer: Eggplant with pine nuts and something else (cous cous, I think?) Very good if you like eggplant.

Service: Super friendly without being fake.

Love this place.

Note: Takeout only

This place rocks!

My sis wanted to get lunch and since the baby was sick and fuzzy, we figured that eating at a restaurant wouldn't be ideal. We left her house and she said that she saw a pizza place around the corner and that she wanted to try it out... OMG...was I thankful she found this place!

We got there and it seemed packed (considering it's a very tiny place...intimate would be the ideal word.)

The bf got the menu and we ordered for takeout. I had the pancetta with goat cheese, sis and the bf had that marinara with pepperoni as well as the calzone.

We waited outside for our food (gorgeous day, just hella windy!)

Got the food and went home to discover the good stuff!

First bite...we were all "WOW!" Everyone seemed to declare...this is really good pizza...it's our new favorite place...and so forth. It was funny but of course, all true. My pizza had two eggs in it and that was a surprised. The taste was just right, crispy everywhere.

Will definitely be going back here for more... Really rocks!

PS: my sis also likes this place even more b/c they serve Blue Bottle!

This place was OK. Nothing great about it,
Nothing bad about it.  I think it would be a good late night meal if ur drunk.
Stopped by after a show around midnight. Pizza was good. You can tell the girl who served us seriously hates her job. Oh well.

I feel like if I don't stop eating the U Say Potato slices I'm going to develop that garlicky B.O. that you can sometimes smell in crowded places.

But that pizza is so damn good! I counted about 15 cloves of garlic on my last slice, every single one of them cooked to sweet, spreadable perfection. I never used to be ok with having whole cloves of garlic in my food, but this pizza has completely changed my mind abou that.

As I was sitting in the Castro location today I found myself thinking about how much money I would save on groceries if I just bought a while pie and rationed it out to myself slice by slice every week. As twisted as it seems, I could go on a U Say Potato diet! I seriously don't want to eat for the rest of the day after eating here because I don't want to taint that delicious lingering garlic pesto flavor. I'm sorry, was that gross? TMI?

Oh well, I love that pizza. And it seems Haight piles on the garlic a little more than Castro, in case you were wondering.

Kurt Russell has nothing over the Haight on a full-moon Saturday night in San Francisco.  EF-N Pizza racks some serious star points for ultra-thin crust slices topped with hot (hot) cheese and pep, with compact seating and patrons current and past that would scare the bejeezus out of the GOP faithful.  

The psychedelic ranting tirades of the drug-crazed sidewalkers in the door reawake the primal urge ... eat fast.... danger coming...  so down the hatch it all goes, and punch card punched its on to The Bike for my Ninja slalom ride home.

The trouble with this pizza joint is that, like a smoking hot pickup, it knows it's hot shit and can get away with murder.  And, for the most part, it is hot shit.  Did I find the staff to be a little smug?  Hell, let them. This is good pizza.

That said, don't expect to use the bathroom here (they don't have one), don't expect to find a place to sit comfortably with your friends (very limited space, no tables outside), don't expect to save by ordering a pie (everything is by the slice), and bring cash.

Nevertheless, the food is solid and I fed five hungry guys for $30 with drinks.  I disagree with reviews that call this place is pricy.  If you can find a seat it's fun to be inside -- they place a solid rock mix and there's all kinds of fun movie and music memorabilia on the wall to stimulate your conversation and pass the time.  A fun date spot?  With the right person, definitely.

However, it's my NOT kind of pizza.  I'm of the sweet sauce school of pizza consumption, so the garlic-laden tomato blend wasn't my cup of tea.  Regardless, the crust is delicious and the vegetables and meats seemed fresh overall.  I won't crave it but I can see why others might.  It's probably the best pie in Haight/Ashbury -- overlooking the annoyances of the eatery.

NY-style pizzas with California-style toppings.  

It may sound something out of the California Pizza Kitchen book; but it isn't done that heavy handed.  The place serves up friggin delicious slices.  There's also a wide variety of different pizzas: from the Pesto/Garlic/Potato to the Spinach/Feta/Artichoke/Sun-Dried-Tomato to the usual pizzeria fare.  I love a slightly browned crust, and this place usually has it right about there.  I also love the seasoning on their pizzas.  

Slices are cheap, but there is little sitting room: plan on standing to eat your slice.  That usually suits me just fine; as I'm usually on-the-go if I'm ordering a slice from here.  An added plus is that this place is open late, 2am on the weekends; making it a prime destination of the bar crowd in the area.

One of my regular stops in the Haight; and one of my favorites in the city.

Woah! What happened?
Had a very disappointing experience tonight. I used to come here very frequently but admit that it has been a while since my last visit. Tonight I was shocked at the reduced sizes of slices and selection. Don't  come here for the pizza but it's ok to stop by if you are starving.

When I walked into Escape from New York Pizza my reaction was upsetting. It looks dirty and cashier as well. She has purple hair, in her mid 50's and looks very dirty and unhealthy. She kept rolling her eyes at us from the moment we walked in. I felt unwelcome and will not be returning here. The pizza was great but unfortunately customer service was not.

BEST. MUSHROOM. PIZZA. ANYWHERE!

They sure do not skim on those mushrooms, and they're not your typical lame-pizza-place mushroom that are extra thick and usually fall off your slice when you pick it up, no sir!  These are thinly sliced, and the  cheese melts around/on them like it's holding them in warm embrace, a delicious warm embrace.

I'm afraid I can't review any of the other pies, since I ALWAYS get the mushroom.  Even if the don't have any, I'll wait!!

The joint itself is your typical pizza-by-the-slice place, there's some table and chairs, but usually not enough room for all the patrons, so you end up meeting new people all the time.

Sometimes I wish I could escape TO New York! I come here when I'm too lazy to cook and too cheap to go anywhere else. For what it is, Escape from NY offers some stellar thin crust - and they serve it up quick!

Ambiance: Well, still feels like SF. I'd say it's pretty "hole-in-the-wall." There's a framed picture of the NY subway map to remind you that this is a "New York themed restaurant." Oh yes, and some fun concert posters. Limited and not comfortable, seating.

Food: Solid slices of pizza. Great specials like their Greek pizza with artichokes, feta, and spinach. There's also regular pepperoni and cheese for the minimalists.

Service: They warm up each slice for you. If you want it to go, you'll get your pizza on a paper plate that's covered and put into a brown paper bag - great disguise from haight street bums.

Tips: Great after a night of drinking. Easy to order when inebriated - just point and nod your head.

So I picked this Italian restaurant for lunch one fine cool crisp day because it had decent reviews...And most restaurants you find through Yelp in San Francisco are usually spot on.
Usually.. very rarely.. do you get a bad seed. Most restaurants here are all amazing with superb service..

This one..hmmm how shall I put it not so much.. a bad seed.  

I ordered the Panzanello Salad with chicken: diced heirloom tomatoes, English cucumber, red onion, toasted fennel croutons, red wine vinegar, evoo.

And I what got was raw chicken under cooked... Ahh the horror.. Who eats raw chicken?

When I explained to the waitress about my under cooked chicken, she responded" oh that's how the chicken is cooked" Hmmm. No that's not how I cook my chicken... no pink and when you cut it open you can see the silky membranes still attached to the chicken. that to me is undercooked. And what happend to the customer is always right? The server was not accomodating nor was she friendly about it. After sitting there not touching it, she comes back after 20 mintues. No customer service skills. Why didn't you get the manager or apologized and tried to get me something else and not say do you want to take it to go? Yeah, and actually cook it in my kitchen.. Thanks but no thanks..

And my fiance had the smoked proscuitto panini that was ham..ham like sandwich ham..

Stay clear of this one my friends...  you will get sick..!

Ordered for delivery at 5:30, and were told it would be ready at 6. We watched for an hour and a half as the delivery time kept being pushed back...the pizza was delivered cold at 7:10. And there were no utensils for the salad, so we had to drive out of our way to pick up some at a different restaurant.

This was the first place I went to after they reopened outdoor dining and it was an excellent experience. Everyone was super friendly, welcoming, and took COVID precautions. We ordered bruschetta, crab arancini's, and three pizzas. Everything was delicious. I liked how spaced out the outdoor seating is. 10/10 would go again!!

Great atmosphere, good food, good service, all at fairly reasonable prices. Would offer a 5 star but the chairs are uncomfortable.

Anyway, the meatballs are awesome. Something about the sauce is just fantastic. Salads are great because they are a bit different. But, as everybody knows, this is about the pizza. I do not look like veggies on my pizza[ salads are for veggies] but they meat topping pizzas are awesome.  Easy to eat dough, tasty sauce, quality meats.  All good. Give Delrosa a try.
I love Delarosa! So many gluten free options (both pizza and pasta), fun ambience, delicious food! Highly recommend!

Aside from the hostess being a bit snippy when we walked in, I really loved Delarosa.

They were super quick at getting us a table during some peak busy times when the restaurant was crowded. Sat down and immediately ordered some drinks, which came out super quick!

Firstly started with the Brussels sprouts and roasted cauliflower for an appetizer. Bursting with flavor and perfectly cooked, but a little light on size for four people. So we ordered the burrata bruschetta with hazelnut and honey. Perfectly toasted bread and a wonderful burrata and AMAZING honey.

And of course, all of this came before the pizza. Prosciutto di parma, arugula and mozzarella pizza was great. The crust was perfect! And there was so much prosciutto on it. Not like other pizzas where theres only a few pieces. And with all the apps, this was plenty of food for four people. Came to just over $100 as well!

I was having dinner with girlfriends in the Marina and Delarosa popped up on Yelp as a great option. I saw on the website that the team behind Delarosa has connections to Beretta (amongst other restaurants) - I love Beretta and was excited to try Delarosa. Delarosa was great and I would definitely go back.

The bar is a great spot to post up while you're waiting for friends or to dine with another friend. We were there on a Monday night and we were able to get a table quickly at 7:30. The big windows give it an open and airy feeling, and there are a few tables outside for those rare warm SF evenings. Most of the tables inside are communal and by the time we finished dinner (around 9:30), the music had been turned up to levels that made it tough to converse.

The following is how I would rank the dishes we ordered:
- Crispy taglioni dumplings: imagine a cheese and prosciutto-filled dumpling deep-fried and sitting in marinara sauce. So good, so gooey.
- Mushroom pizza: great pizza dough - I normally don't eat crust but this was an exception.
- Crab arancini: yes, more deep-fried food and this was also cheesy and delicious but maybe not the best I've ever had
- Panzanella salad: great flavored with the fennel croutons but the tomatoes were a bit too soft / over-ripe and didn't hold up well in the salad

Always good. Delicious food. Appetizers and salads are best.
Couple time I've been there it's loud and happening.
I have nothing but love for this place. The ambiance is very chique and the food is great. Make sure to try their Prosciutto di parma pizza!

In the mood for pizza?  This is the place!  Very nice decor inside!  Looks very hip :)  Seated right away and our orders were taken!  Our waitress recommended some dishes and we were sold when she said the "Pappardelle Napoletana" was made by hand!  This was an ultimate favorite in the restaurant so we had to get it!  We ordered:

Pizza Prosciutto di Parma ($16.00): if you like prosciutto with the combination of arugula, this is for you!  The do not skimp out on the prosciutto like other places!  Very good pizza!

Pappardelle Napoletana: ($11.00):  Handmade pasta with meat!  I don't know how to describe this!  Very tasty and soft, and well seasoned.  You can tell this was homemade!  JUST GET IT!  A bit pricey and not big enough but it is great!

Definitely need to come back and try other things!  Maybe in a few years!

NOTE:
-one bathroom per gender

This place will never have my business. We came all the way here, and they seated us 30 minutes before closing. We ordered and the waitress rushed us and seemed stressed out. After ordering everything, she came back and said we have to get our food to go, but that we can have the drinks we ordered. What? It's not closing time, and don't appreciate the BS and attitude. Never coming back. Thanks a lot for everything, PO.

This place was phenomenal! We ordered the pesto pasta dish and the eggplant pasta and both were very, very good. Service was friendly and engaging (but not too engaging) and the chef/owner came out to discuss our experience, you can tell he puts a lot of heart into his food. Next time I'm in San Francisco this will be my first stop.

Great spot for a date or just hanging out with friends. The food is delicious and the service is excellent. It's a popular spot but the wait wasn't long at all. The pizzas are a rare find, definitely worth a try! I also loved the atmosphere. Glad I found this place thanks to other Yelpers!
Loved this place. Would make a special trip or go outta my way to dive into the best pie around. They musta sold. Not the same. Damn. Maybe an off night? Super nice guys though!

What a find. Great service and amazing food. The meatballs are delicious! We also loved the Sicilian and the Tyson Punch Out! The Sangiovese recommended in another review rounded it out well. Great neighborhood addition.
Great delivery experience! Margarita pizza was delicious.  We will definitely be ordering from pink onion again.
Delicious pasta, and a great selection of draft beer and wine. The wait staff are very friendly, and attentive. Highly recommend the pesto pasta, and the burrata appetizer.

HIGHLY impressed with this hidden gem! Tucked in the middle of a side street in SF, this place is definitely worth the find. My guy and I came here after a day party full of good music, dancing and drinking. After 6 hours of dancing we were ready for some pizza in our lives. We seem to eat a lot of pizza but Pink Onion stood out to both of us. Like, If MySpace was still a thing, pink onion would be on our top 8 for sure lol.

They started us out with some fresh baked bread and a very rich, complex tasting olive oil- I swear I picked up notes of arugula in this olive oil! I loved it and didn't even need balsamic to compliment it. What really stood out to us was the creativity of the pizza topping combinations.  We ordered the Kanoute pizza because it's not every day you see pistachio on pizza and I happen to love the combo of pesto and arugula. The blend of ricotta and mozzarella also made this unique to me. The crust itself was chewy and airy, not to thin and not too thick! Just how I like my pizza. It had that wonderful charred taste to it from the wood fired oven. You can tell they make their pizza's with love here! I recommend pairing their pizza with a nice glass of pinot, to truly highlight the flavors :) This was our last meal in SF before heading back to San Diego, definitely worth every dollar spent. Since we have been back we have been raving to all our friends about the "best pizza we've ever had." Thanks Pink Onion!

Went there for the first time this past week. Cute little place, pizza tasted great, service was friendly and fast. I was definitely going to come back. Unfortunately, I don't think I will ever be back now. Took leftovers home with me, ate one slice back home, and found a snail shell while chewing. Probably from the Arugula they put on the pizza....a shocking first for me and scary given the meningitis causing parasites that live in snails. I called them to let them know - some person (chef? manager?) chuckled and said it sounds kind of funny and offered to send me another pizza. "Absolutely not!" was my answer.

They need to double and triple wash their produce. Better yet, please buy it triple washed.

Abysmal and horrible delivery service. First the order kept changing to a later and later delivery time. Then the order was rudely and abruptly cancelled. F*** you, Pink Onion. I will never, ever give you my business again. Such incredibly awful customer service. PSA: DON'T GO HERE!

Completely worth the wait.

My friend and I waited 1hour and 45 minutes to get a seat in this restaurant. It's understandable considering how small the place is and how popular it is. (esp. on weekends!) The service was superb though. Once we made it inside the lady at the front cheered for us (because we actually waited that long and because we finally made it out of the cold haha).

But I have never been more proud of a decision than this. We ordered bread with oil and vinegar as an app and then ordered wild nettle pizza with pancetta. So delicious. The flavor combination was awesome and the pizza was actually quite big. Therefore, the price we paid for this meal did not feel bad at all. I just wish it wasn't so crowded so I could come here more often (...or like, every day). One of the most interesting and fun dining experiences I've had. So a word of advice: patience is definitely a virtue at this restaurant, have fun with it.

Color me surprised!  Fresh ingredients all around. The roasted fennel soup was bursting with flavor--maybe the best soup I've ever tasted. The pastas were delicious. A fresh variety of locally picked mushrooms with a hint of chili on one; another with pork sugo was magical.  Even the pizzas surpassed expectation--go for the artichoke one.  The chef here is incredible.

Meh. The pizza is thin crust, which can be great. It's crispy, it's light, it's good. The outer edge gets air bubbles and puffs out. It's cool. I had a moto and a margherita.

But on both pies, the crust is so thin around the edges that the top of the bubbles burn. About 25% of the crust around the pizza was burned (burnt?). I like crust. I'm here to eat the whole pizza.

The margherita had so little cheese that 2 of the pieces (out of 8) had no cheese at all. Zero. I looked. They clearly don't shred the mozzarella and spread it around. They put down a few mozzarella balls and they spread out as they melt but clearly not enough to cover all the pieces.  Seriously guys, take the "sophistication" down a notch and just grate the cheese. I'm from Wisconsin.  I order pizza so that I can eat cheese.

So one pie with too little cheese. Two pies where I couldn't eat a big percentage of the crust. If you are going to go all foofy and make pies with butternut squash and  portobello mushroom and calabrian chilies, at least get the basics right. Don't burn it. Put cheese on every piece.

One of the best pizza places in SF.

My one experience ordering an "entree" was disappointing (four just-OK little seared scallops atop a mound of fava beans for $24), so I stick to pizzas and antipasti. Love the beet salad.

Waits can be very long any night of the week.

I came hearing how amazing the pizza is. Pizza dough was good but nothing fabulous. Toppings were super super salty!!  The pasta dish we got was also insanely salty. The kale salad was ok. I wish they used another type of greens the kale was tough to eat. I left needing lots of f water and an upset friend who I brought to the restaurant.  She was uoset about the mediocre service.

Our party of seven was seated at the outside gazebo with a holiday party and a reservation. The food was amazing, the owner was lovely and visited our party several times and Tink, our waitress, was warm, funny and full of great recommendations. I highly recommend the warm dates with gorgonzola (4 to an order) and the kale salad, which came as a generous portion in a lovely Heath bowl. I highly recommend the Bianca, and the Chanterelle pizzas, as well as the outstanding butternut squash rigatoni. Fantastic.
Love the pizza here! They always use fresh and creative ingredients. My favorite is the the one with figs and pork belly!

The pizza was good, but the service was not worth it. After waiting well past the time we were quoted the hostess pointed out a table that would be ours as soon as it was cleared. So excited when that finally happened only to have it given to someone else, the worst thing was this was not the end of our seating nightmare. I don't care how good your pizza is or how busy you are, don't lie to your customers. Don't rush to this place, you'll be left waiting.
One of the best pie's in the city  4 sure get there fast before the hierloom pizza is all gone. Pizza Monster Approved.

so quintessentially divis.
no trouble at all cozying up to the bar in a completely packed house on a monday night. the heat of the blazing pizza oven may be killer to the hard working and kickass cooks in the kitchen, but it set the house to a warm, ambient, delicious toasted cheese-scented environment.
the crust on this pizza is delicious. i could swathe it in some green olive oil and be happy...
you can't miss the 'moto' pizza. it is perfection.
ragazza is a haven for locals who just want a romantic, luxurious, delicious, and low key dinner composed of ingredients and skill of the highest caliber.
loved it.

Can you say super scrummy?!  This pizza is the best I've found locally and the portions are HUGE.  Surprisingly the salads are good too, if that's what you're craving.  They are NOT open late night though, which crushed me at 2 am the other night.. I think I actually wept....
This pizza is hardly pizza - yes it's round, has red sauce and cheese but that's where the similarity ends.  The crust was practically pastry crust - buttery and flaky.  Yuck.

Tried them for the first time on Friday night on a friend's recommendation. It was the worst pizza I've had in a long time. My brother and I split a large - half meat combo, half veggie combo. It was undercooked, greasy and the ingredients were far-from fresh. Maybe it was on off-night. Or an off-pizza. Dreadful.

Perfect spot to grab a great slice and had over to the castro theater  to catch a flick, Sorry to say a bit better then Escape in the stro, Thanks for telling me it's one of the best slices in the city A brother.

Marcello's has by far the best pizza in town!  I usually just drop by for a slice and am psyched when I catch their bacon and feta cheese pizza pie.  But my favorite is their Mexican pizza.  When I order it, I request to get it vegetarian - with beans instead of meat - and to go light on the jalapeno.  I actually eat meat, but for some reason, I love this pizza veggie style.  Just ordered one today.  I'm home sick with the flu and that little bit of jalapeno was perfect for clearing up my sinuses.  :-)
Hands-down, my favorite pizza in the city.  The crust is so perfect!  If you order from there, you have to try the special meatball pizza.  It's delicious!
I love to get a slice at Marcello's and eat it while I wait in line at the Castro Theater. So yummy! FYI cash only.

Care to experience the worst service of your life in one minute flat?
Look no further than marcello's, the soup nazi of pizzerias.
Here is how my experience went:
I first waited inline for 5 minutes. the time was around 11:30 pm. Now I don't mind waiting in line if it is worth it and at this hour of the night getting fast food is not easy. Plus it really looked like the staff was scrambling up. When it comes to be our turn ( I was with one friend), waiter number one looked at me, asked what I wanted and suddenly turned around to grab something for another customer. strike 1. Nice service would be him apologizing for it, but it is rush time and I can deal with some rudeness. After he was done he came back to me, asked me again what I wanted and quickly turned around to help another customer. Strike 2. Not a word of apology, not even a "Im sorry" look. Then comes waiter number 2 who looks at us first then proceed to look at the person behind us to take her order! strike 3.
After some complaining, (a well placed WTF!!??) We finally got our pizzas (luck warm and not that great tasting) and proceeded to pay. My buddy hands a 20 dollar bill then got his change. you might now think our hell was over....NOPE!! the same waiter that proceeded to ignore us twice in a row decided that we handed him a ten instead of a 20 and wanted his change back (note that would it have been true we would have return his change back but it wasn't the case AND it would have been his mistake)
Strike 4.
So waiter number one, you're lucky I don't own this place, because after looking at how you treated your customers and your staff, I would have fired you and made sure you never work in the service industry again.
By far the best delivery pizza I have encountered.  Each time I have ordered it it was fantastic...even the one time it was late and on the cold side....that's good pizza.

what i ordered... a slice of thick crust w/ sausage, salame and pepperoni and a slice of original w/ mushroom and pepperoni

...the dough for the thick crust was of the same taste as the original but airy and soft just like a dinner roll with a very crispy thin crust at the bottom and topped with their fabulous marinara sauce and meat toppings. original was good as ever.

...it seems like the slice got bigger and more toppings as well, hence am giving it a high five. (for the freshly cooked one's not the preheated one's)

fyi, the place only accepts cash.

Overhyped.

The ambiance is great. Rustic modern interior, servers with a thick Italian accent, fresh pinsas in the oven... I had high hopes.

I remember eating pinsa for the first time in Rome. The perfectly chewy and flavorful dough with fresh rucola and fragrant olive oil left me forever romanticizing Rome.

Unfortunately, the pinsas at montescaro left me feeling like a hopeless romantic still fantasizing about the real deal.

Beet Salad: 3.5 stars -- Nothing special, but the quality of the goat cheese was memorable. Slightly underdressed but that is my preference so I welcomed it.

Margherita pinsa: 3.5 stars -- meh. As a Margherita pizza fanatic, I can confidently tell you you will find better Margherita pizza in the city from at least three different locations. The dough was underseasoned, and there wasn't enough tomato sauce or basil. Overall tasted a bit bland. Decent pizza but not worth the hype..

Anchovy pizza: 3 stars -- my friend got the anchovy pizza which looked and tasted very similar to mine, but a shit ton saltier. The flavor fell flat for me, maintaining only the one salty note throughout.

Overall, disappointing experience. Might give it another try in a bigger group setting so I can try their meat and cheese plates and a few other dishes.

I came to this place because it was close to the Orpheum for a show and it delivered what I wanted. I wouldn't say this is overhyped, I think it delivers what it claims - a quality pinsa made the way the restaurant claims is a tradition. They also claim the wheat flour is imported from Rome, not sure if that would truly make a total difference.

The lunch special is hard to beat - for only $15 you get a salad (subtlely oiled and salted), a beautiful and generously sized margherita pinsa (well cooked with nice chewy dough), and an espresso.

Location is less than desirable on a side street next to a plethora of homeless people. After the sun sets, it may not be the kind of street to walk down for some folks.

A different experience for sure! This is not your regular pizza!! This pinsa is a delicious alternative to your normal pie. I loved the light crispy crust paired with delicious and unusual toppings. I ate a pinsa topped with smoked salmon, cheese, dill, and zucchini. It was as if a bagel with lox had turned into my dinner! My sister had the more traditional margherita which was equally delicious. The restaurant also has a very authentic vibe. Our waiter was exceptionally knowledgeable and friendly. Definitely visit this "pinseria" for a authentic and different experience!
I love this hidden spot in a bit of a rough part of town... Try the kale salad and the margarita pinsa!

I love this place and their food!!! I always had great times at this place. Good food, good service, good wine menu and the atmosphere is very cozy. I would not walk around the neighborhood thats in located and would only go there if my uber/lyft/taxi would drop me off by the door. I would highly recommend trying this smaller pizza place, you won't be disappointed.

Delicious! Note that it's not a pizza place -- it's pinsa, which is slightly different (More like what many places call flatbreads). With that in mind, the food is fantastic. It's genuine and flavorful. And the restaurant has a sort of pleasant, unpolished atmosphere that I enjoyed.

The pinsas are pretty affordable and filling, but your meal can get expensive if you order extras (sides, a glass of their expensive wines, etc.).

The reason why I'm not giving this 5 stars is the chairs were so uncomfortable. They were probably chosen to fit the rest of the decor, but the backs were uncomfortable to lean against to the point where it distracted me from my meal.
incredible food. perhaps the best pizza i've had in SF. bathroom and atmosphere was original and interesting. food was incredibly fresh.

It always amazes me when a pizza place remains the best pizza you've ever had (well, in California at least), and for a long time, sometimes years, it holds true, even after you've tried many challengers that aspire to, but don't quite beat it out. Until one does. This is it.

To be fair, my grandmother made some pretty good pizza, and there are one or two places in Detroit (yes, Detroit) and Chicago that are up there. Let's count those as a different style (although Little Star gives the Chicago places a run for the money). I also don't have the chops to compare pizza from Italy and elsewhere abroad; I'm a rookie when it comes to the foreign pizza scene. But I am including NYC, Boston, and everywhere else in the USA! This place is legit!

One last point. I like some of the choices here for sure better than some of the others. And I wouldn't say every choice is better than any other pizza anywhere. But some, like the Infernetto (Smoked buffalo mozzarella, 'nduja) are going to be tough to beat. I can't wait for that to happen, if it ever does.

now open on weekends, and quite a unique place -- both for its historical oven and antique decor collection as well as introducing pinsa to the area, which is more like a crisp airy bubbly oval flatbread but still with a good chew.  Rome inspired, back alley location.  3 people can share two pinsas.  light toppings.
Marcella - Burrata , Broccolini, Spicy Pork Sausage -- excellent spicy sausage, slightly superior to the lamb sausage
Trullo - Tomato, Lamb Sausage, Mushroom, Yogurt, Mint -- also great but a bit much on the yogurt which added a lot of tang.  overall good but not able to eclipse the top brick oven pizzas.

One of the best meals that I have enjoyed ever period. I went here a few months ago and had the Pinsa ( I don't think that's how it's spelled, oops) which was so bubbly and crunchy at the same time. The staff are so nice and were able to sit me and my friend right away at the bar. I think this is because we went on a weekday. But, I would definitely recommend making reservations if you want to get in. I tried going again recently but forgot to make them and the line was out the door. Just make reservations and be ready for an awesome meal.

For a Friday night at 6pm, my husband and I were lucky to snag a place! We were greeted by our hostess and server, they both gave us a quick heads up that happy hour only lasted 15 more minutes. I thought that was nice of them so that we could hurry and browse the happy hour menu.

We quickly received our appetizers and drinks. As we were only 50% finished with our appetizer, my plate came out but not my husbands. Let me mention that we were sitting outside and it was a bit cold with a wind. I covered my pasta plate with my napkin, expecting my husbands food to follow. We continued to eat our appetizer and about 10-12 minutes later, my husbands pizza arrived. I'm sure the same goes for everyone when I say this but I think it's normal to eat a meal together, not watching one another.

Another thing I am disappointed about it that the pasta I ordered said that the dish included summer squash. I come from a family who has worked and owned a produce wholesale company since I was born. I know my fruits and veggies! I did NOT receive summer squash on my plate but instead classic zucchini. I'm sure the restaurant wouldn't think people would notice and I am sure those who ordered it didn't! But then you get that one person and YEP I NOTICED.

Service was good but also felt rushed. It's like they want people to eat and go because it gets busy.

Wish the experience was better.

Nice location in the alley by Yerba Buena Gardens. I've been here twice for lunch and once for happy hour/dinner. Plenty of seating inside as well as some outside.  My work team and I like coming here.

I love the appetizers and drinks. Pizza is good also--pasta is hit or miss. I didn't enjoy the mushroom risotto. It seemed to be just a touch underdone. Flavor was good, but texture was all wrong. It is quite easy to mess up risotto though.

Favorite apps:
-fried asparagus with lemon aioli
-any salad
-the crab and rice balls

I enjoyed two happy hour cocktails (can't remember the names). The orange one was light and sweet.

Come early or during off times to guarantee seating. Isn't as busy as Tropisueno next door, but definitely gets packed also.
The food was good and everything that we ordered came out pretty fast but I still wouldn't return again. Taking off two stars for the service.

I would like to start thanking Jonathan for making our evening delightful, he recommended is everything we order, the food, the wine, the burrata bruschetta , the beets , kale and avocado salad, and the prosciutto di parma pizza. With his great service made everything perfect for our evening. Will be coming back.

This is definitely my go to pizza place. Love the staff, ambience and food.  
My fiance and I are a big fan of their burrata cheese! Definitely recommend that people try this place out.

Our dinner was very tasty and we (5 of us) got a bunch of items to share: 2 pizzas, calamari, burrata with hazelnuts and honey (definitely get this!), shrimp, and plenty of Italian wine.
The tables are mostly family style so you may be sitting next to people you don't know and it's very close quarters.
There is a lot of outdoor seating for nice weather days and nights too.

We came here for an office lunch. I really enjoyed the burrata bruschetta which had all things I love- a crunchy toast, burrata, hazelnut and honey. I would have liked to see more than 2 in a plate though. My colleagues ordered various pizzas which were a hit. The pesto veggie panini was yummy. Service was decent. They boxed up the rest of pizza for us. They have a good variety of pizza, pasta,salads and panini options.

It was my birthday this last weekend. I felt I had to follow up with this review. The food and drinks were beyond all expectations for my whole party. We had a large party of 14. From the beginning, the staff was welcoming and very attentive. The restaurant manager Alessandro definitely worked hard in ensuring that our dining experience went smoothly, which it did!  For anyone looking for an amazing meal and experience, I highly recommend Delarosa.

PS- the crab Arancini and the Burrata Pizza are A MUST!!!!
Burrata Toast and Caesar salad were great. There was a really long line to get in but hop on the waitlist and you'll be fine. Service was great! Would come back

This is one of my favorite places to eat in the city.
Amazing and kind staff, craft cocktails, and such delicious food. It's always busy, so it can get really loud as most tables are communal. Seating at the bar or outside is best when it comes to the ambience and noise level.

The burrata toast with toasted nuts and drizzled honey is divine and slightly sweet, the meatballs have a great homemade hearty but fresh taste, and the pizzas with the chili oil for dipping is addictive. Loved the donuts too. I could have drank the dipping sauces. Basically everything here is great.

Known for their thick crust, but they have amazing thin crust too. It's perfectly thin and just the right amount of chewy. Friendly, fast service and great pizza. The toppings are really tasty and fresh. I like to DIY a sausage, mushroom, and spinach pizza.

Little Star is a quality choice for pizza. They serve deep dish with a corn bread crust. Not as good as Chicago style, but certainly a satisfying pie. They also have really good gluten free crust, if you're into that. Unfortunately they aren't open for lunch, but give them a try for dinner!

What an adorable little find in SF! This was by far the best restaurant we ate at all trip! The place is very small, maybe around 20 tables with a small bar.

We ended up doing 1 small pizza, half of thin crust pesto chicken and the other half was their special. Their special was an olive oil based sauce with tomatoes, garlic, basil, and goat cheese. DELICIOUS!!!

We enjoyed that this restaurant had deep dish pizzas as well as the thin crusted ones too! We weren't terribly hunger so the thin crust was perfect for us!

Their bar was limited, 2 white wine selections, about 5 red wines, a few champagne cocktails, and about 5 beers. It was perfect for us but if you are looking for a big bar menu this isn't for you.

My heart belongs to Zacharys out in the EB, but I have to admit the cruchiness of the deep dish crust of Little Star did have me smiling this evening.

Master P and I went, to give into our pizza craving, and feeling more adventurous and oh so bored of my usual haunts, I convinced him to drive me down to Little Star.

The atmosphere was super hip--a nice change from the uber preppiness of the Pac Heights/ Marina I usually frequent, and the jukebox, the friendly and quick service were all definite pluses.
The roasted garlic and bread was yummy and the pizza great!

The ingredients seemed fresh, the crust crunchy and the pizza hot.

I don't know if I would be thrilled to sit in on a crowded night, but this evening's dinner was perfect--right down to the rockstar parking outside the restaurant.

I

OK. I've had better deep-dish pizza, but not in San Francisco.  I'll keep looking, but in the meantime, I'll probably stick with Little Star.  I don't really understand why it's so difficult to find real deep dish in San Francisco.  It's not all that complicated to make.  It's not like the pizza shops in Chicago or even Detroit have some special magic.  

On a side note, I HATE HATE HATE places that are cash only.  I'd almost give this place 3 stars for that fact alone.  Come one.  Who carries cash anymore?  Get a credit card machine already.

So I'm on a strict cheapish eats budget for the rest of the summer and Little Star had been at the top of my list for months.   After driving around the TL and finding nothing appealing, we somehow ended up on Divis in front of Little Star.

Shared the Mediterranean Chicken deep dish, with feta, green olives, and artichoke hearts.  The pizza took about thirty minutes to arrive, which seemed standard.  One bite and we both agreed that the pizza was fantastic!  It's all about the cornmeal crust, which was crunchy on the outside and soft inside.  Ohh, so good.

I'm not sure what possessed us to get a large, but after about two huge slices, I was completely stuffed.  A 9" pizza probably would've been plenty.

Add on a glass of Racer 5 IPA and dinner for two was $30.  With a serious amount of leftovers the next day.

Cash only and no reservations taken, though we only waited about 15 minutes for a table.  Atmosphere is kind of hipster, but friendly with good service.

Still thinking about that crust.  And it even holds up well after a night in the fridge!

Fabulous. I highly recommend trying this place out.

They know how to make deep dish pizza here. The crust is perfectly baked so that the bottom is lightly crispy and the rest is soft as a pillow.

The buffalo wings are pretty good too, but I had better.

They need to get rid of the dim lights so I can see my gorgeous pizza!

I am so mad at myself that I did not bring my camera that day. :(

Some quick reasons for this place being so popular...

1. The ingredients are very high quality. You can really taste the peppers, onions, and of course plenty of tomato sauce in each bite.

2. The presentation when it arrives is nothing short of spectacular. This piping hot smoldering disk of goodness just automatically puts you into ravenous mode! I mean it's one thing to be hungry and crave something, but to be hungry,crave pizza, and get this type of treat is on a different plane of existence.

3. The crust! Love the cornmeal textured crust. It can stand up to all that moisture from the tomatoes and retain the crunch and flavor without getting soggy. Any chance of creating a sourdough cornmeal crust? I

All things considered, this is an amazing pizza, yet I have a reservation. I'm not sure what IT is, but that little IT is what keeps it short from getting the 5 stars. Call me crazy but just serving a great product is 99% of the battle, but that 1% is very elusive indeed!

Stars: 3.5

I went to Little Star on a Monday night and it was not packed. We walked right in and got seated right away. It is a small place. I don't like the lighting though. It's too dark for my liking.

We ordered three items:
1. Wings - little, tiny but delicious! The blue cheese dip wasn't too strong which is also good. There's a slight kick to it.
2. Large special - It was like a combo of the Little Star and the Classic. We wanted this because it had meatballs (basically, meat)! So we tried it. I really like this one. I like the flavors in it. There's definitely a lot of tomato sauce but I thought it went well.
3. Large Mediterrean - We wanted chicken, and I personally wasn't a big fan of it. I think I am biased because whenever there's artichoke hearts and chicken, I want my creamy white sauce instead of tomatoes on it.

I think the best part of the pizza is the crust. The crust is so good. So for three of us, this was a lot of food. Maybe we should have went with the small. We overestimated ourselves.

Note:
They do take cards (Visa/Mastercard) even though they have an ATM machine in front!

Came here because of outrageous reviews. Came and was put on the wait list which was not bad because we got parking right out front and waited in the car. They have a great waiting system that uses text to tell you how long your wait is - very convenient. The service there is a1. I liked the pizza it was different the corn meal crust is great however I didn't care to much for the sauce it was too much for me. It's a tad pricey but if you like this style of pizza you will most likely love it. I would definitely come back again to try a different dish.

Old school pizza place...wonderful in so many ways and a true San Francisco North Beach classic.

Pizza is great, but it's more than just that...the atmosphere and service transports me to a different place and time.  Been coming here for years and I am always happy when I am here.  Italia!  

Years ago, I took a drama queen girlfriend here and even she felt the same way about the place.  That says a lot.  Beware, she's still out there somewhere. :)

The pizza is amazing here and it's really reasonably priced. They don't take reservations, so it's best to come right when they open or at odd times; otherwise you will have to wait.

They make the pizza within minutes and the service is terrific.

PIZZA PARTY!!!

Bored with the case of beer and chips and dip for your party? Throw a pizza party. Schedule deliveries all night long from different pizza joints all over the city and have people taste and rate their favorites.

It is so much fun.

We ordered from Za Gourmet, North Beach, Tommaso's and Tony's. Yes, Tommaso's and Tony's don't deliver, but they are right by my apartment and it was an easy pickup. All were good, but Tomasso's was the clear winner. Gourmet pizza eaters loved it. Round Table pizza eaters loved it. It was the hit of the night.

I dock it one star only because the vegetarian is not very successful.  I am not sure how to balance the sloppiness of the tomatoes with Tommaso's thin crust, but as a pizza joint, it is a problem that needs to be solved.

Service-wise: These guys take a little time to warm up to -- The woman who owns the establishment is a family friend of an old co-worker, and although she wasn't all smiles to begin with, she warmed up to us a little and smiled & such towards the end (I think maybe cos it was super busy & she was a little overwhelmed?) -- The water-boy had this really cherub-like face - so cute!, and the asian dude kinda grabbed at our plates as he was clearing the table and whatnot, but again warmed us to us by the time we go to the dessert.. yay for eventually-nice service!

But the food was amazing -- hands down - the BEST calzone I've had in my l-i-f-e.
And HUGE! -- 2 guys and I comfortably finished it off, and most of our veggie pizza (good, but not half as good as that calzone dude) - except the latter ended up in a box to-go instead...

Awesome (pink) zinfandel too -- sweet, but nothing too riesling-ly - mahvellously complimented the meal..

did i mention the creme brulee?  no ?!?!

oh, lord.

Once upon a time, there was a creme brulee..

I seriously love this place, I think it is the best Italian in the city. Be warned, the wait can be RIDICULOUS but it is well worth it. Try to plan ahead by going a little early...I've waited anywhere from 30 min to 2 hours for a table, ick. At least you can start drinking your wine in line.

Everything here is good- pizza, ravioli, pasta, salads, you name it. I love that this place has so much SF history and that is it still family run. It can be a little tourist heavy but that's ok. I just realized they serve cannoli for dessert, but I'm always too full to have some. Next time...

The best lasagna is nowhere but at Tommaso's, and that's a proven fact. To be honest I don't even like lasagna or at least I am not a big fan of lasagna. The sauce really makes the lasagna literally melt in your mouth. The garlic pizza is quite good too, it is the perfect side plate for my main course. Also make sure to order the tiramisu because It is excellent. I went for my friends birthday with a big group of picky eaters, and the staff was very knowledgeable and friendly. Everyone had a great time at this restaurant which is quite weird because my friends always have something to say but that did not happen at Tommaso's.

The marinated vegetable appetizers are so delicious- try the broccoli, but they are all great. The spinach pizza is always good but I like to try their pizzas of the month too. Everyone is so nice there too.
Loved the lasagna and prosecco. He had the apaghetti. Super authentic and absolutely delicious would highly recommend.

Horrible service if it were up to me I would give them zero stars, I called in advance to try and make reservations and the hostess immediately gave me attitude and told me they don't take reservations it is first come first serve. She sounded like she was trying to be sarcastic or a smart ass over the phone.

I decided to go to the restaurant, which is extremely small and crowded and not to mention hot.

The hostess seem fustrated when I asked her questions about the wait time. I tried to order take out but she seemed like she was not interested in taking my order, when I asked questions about the menu she answered very rude with zero details.

Then she began to rush me when ordering, she seemed interested in taking care of her Caucasian customers who were before us coming back and forth to them and then to us.

As a tourist, I would not recommend this place at all, I walked to their restroom and the man handling the register gave me a nasty look, I felt unwanted and unwelcome. Maybe I wasn't dressed up for their dress code, but they missed a hell of a tip and profit.

I cancelled my order and went to a pizza joint around the corner.

I'll set the scene....It's a hot summer night in the city, I'm three years old and my parents finally manage to snag a parking spot on Broadway. It's the late 70's and the street's jumpin', all the freaks are out, the barkers are hawking their fleshy wares in front of the strip clubs and my mother is trying, unsuccessfully, to shield my eyes from the glimpses of sex toys and boobies that I can see as we pass by the smut shops on our way to Kearny St. for another wonderful meal at Tomasso's.....

OK, full disclosure time here people....my review could be a little biased 'cause I really have been eating here since I was three, and I'm friends with the lovely Crotti family who owns the place. My dad played poker with the family my entire childhood and we used to eat here at least once a week. It was as wonderful then as it is now - not much has changed, and that's part of the charm.

The pizza and calzone are truly heavenly when eaten hot out of the wood burning oven (it's still good, but not the same when taken To Go). I recommend sticking with only a few simple toppings on the pizza to really let the tasty crust and cheesy goodness shine through. Our other family favorites include the marinated broccoli, asparagus, and garbanzo bean antipasti, the calamari, and of course, the garlic bread. We usually stick to the pizza and calzone since they border on the divine, but all the pasta dishes I have had have been good as well.

This is truly a North Beach institution and the perfect place to bring people from out of town who want to check out the North Beach/ Barbary Coast vibe. You can stand outside while you wait for a table and enjoy the hip-shakin' neon goddess as she gyrates outside the Lusty Lady across the street or watch thick-necked bouncers herd horny business men into the Hustler club. Inside you'll get excellent food and great wine (ask Dario to help you pick out a good bottle) in an old school Italian atmosphere. This place is the real deal - the anti-Olive Garden if there ever was one!

This restaurant is a neighborhood gem. It is family owned and humbly run. The food is delicious always. Chicken dore is one of my favorites, but you also can't go wrong with any pizza or pasta. The hassle of finding parking in the area is totally worth it!!

This is more a review about the delivery driver than the food. I still enjoy the food but I dislike dishonesty and not taking responsibility for one's actions. Driver was upset with me because he said he rang my doorbell and a guy answered and said he didn't order a pizza. Driver calls me and says he's at another address and that they also said they didn't order a pizza. I gave him my address again and he says please come outside, he's walking to my home. i go outside and he repeats what he said earlier and gives me attitude. I told him I'm the only adult in the house and he did not ring my bell, he said why would he park at the wrong house unless he was directed there. For my own piece of mind, I checked my cameras, he did NOT come to my place at all! He does not appear in the video AT ALL, neither driving by or walking by my house, not even going to my neighbors! I hate liars!
Super delicious pizza and really good prices. Also they have may good pastas. Must have in SF.
Just as I remember this pizza is one of the best! Try it you'll like it!!

From my perspective, Pasquale's is relatively unfortunate.  They have pretty good pizza.  I'd even venture to say it is above average for the city.  Nonetheless, the interior decor is pretty plain and uninspired.  Accordingly, I'd much rather go to Villa Romana for pizza, or grab a slice and a super cheap beer from Milano's around the corner.  

Truthfully, the pizza at both Villa Romana and Milano's is even better than the above average pizza here.  Accordingly, I can't really ever imagine a good reason to go to Pasquales.  If Pasquale's and I were both in "almost" any other neighborhood in this city - I'd have absolutely no problem making this one of my regular places for pizza.  

The same is definitely true for the pasta here.  Good - but not great, and with Villa Romana just a block over - Pasquale's always loses out.

Pasquale's has become one of my favorites and go-to places not only for pizzas, but for Italian food. I came here a few years ago and completely fell in love with the items on the menu. I love that this place closes late as well! Nowadays, I usually order an appetizer and pizza if I'm with friends, but I have tried a good selection of what they have here. I am a big fan of their lasagnas and stuffed potatoes! The servers are usually always nice and they always come by to fill up our waters and pack up our leftover food. I'm so glad that even throughout the years that this place has not changed.

I REALLY want to give this place five stars, but they don't do refills on soda. COME ON.

I love the minestrone here. Almost every time I've had it, it warmed up MY SOUL. The sandwiches here are fantastic and a GREAT value. $8-9 gets you a HUGE chicken parmigiana/neapolitan steak/veal sandwich + fries/salad. They're all tasty, and the bread is super good sourdough. The only thing the bread lacks is crunch, but they have that SF sourdough taste down to a T. I love coming here with my friends because we all leave happy and full, and it's light on the old wallet. Pizza is very good as well, but I come for the sandwiches and the minestrone.

Best story I have about this place is when I was hanging around, waiting for my takeout order, and I talked to the owner. I told him how much I loved his minestrone. And he had a big to-go bowl of it just packed up in a paper bag, ready for someone else to take home, but he just gave it to me, and said, "Enjoy." The pride he takes in the soup... he probably knew it would end up in me blabbering about how awesome this place is.

Almost legendary status. Just give me the Coke, dammit.
Best pizza in SF for sure! I always get pepperoni, green peppers and onions for the big ones and a personal size cheese for the littles. The personal pizzas start at 4.75!
I enjoy pizza! Over the past few years it's been hard to find good pizza in California. Well I found it! This place is the bomb. Great food don't miss out!

Fabulous pizza!  We be sure to stop in when in San Fran! We get xl size pizza to take home to Sacramento area cuz it is huge! The home made Italian sausage is perfection and the eggplant topping is excellent!  No skimping here - you get a lot!  Staff is very friendly and service is fast.

Gaspare's is home to my favorite pizza of all-time: Bruce's Special. Linguica, Salame, Mushrooms, Garlic, Olive Oil, Oregano, Mozzarella Cheese and Tomato Sauce.

It's got a great thin crust and every bite on this pie has so much flavor it brings new meaning to the word mouth-watering.  I can eat more slices of this pizza than any other pizza.  The only time I don't leave here satisfied is if I hadn't eaten enough pizza!

I've tried other entrees here and they are good, but honestly not memorable to bring me back here like Bruce's.  A must try.

Follow-up review: (I though only freaks used this option...)

A few weeks ago, my BF and I wanted to redo Valentine's dinner. So I called Gaspare's at 5pm to arrange a pick up after my shift at work, around 9. I arrived at 9:10 to pick up my medium margarita pizza + feta, only to have the chefs and owner not know what I was talking about. The woman I placed the order with remembered me because I had called in advance.The owner mentioned that next time I should call about 15-30 minutes ahead of time to avoid this situation. Look, I work in the food industry, too. A couple hours ahead isn't that much of a pain in the butt. I understand misplacing the order in 24 hours but not 4.

Anyway, I waited 10 minutes for the pizza, paid full price, and headed home to meet my man. Excited and hungry, we flung the box open only to have a $16 FETA cheese pizza. No basil or tomatoes! Lame.

The quality of the food is so dead-on, I will go back. I'm just a little irked that I got screwed only the second time around... sad face.

Got the Bruce's special, very tasty ground salami, good topping coverage, but the crust was under-cooked, or super soggy, either way, the best bite of the pizza was not its best part.  I would think that they would leave it in the oven longer for pizzas with more toppings.  I had the small, so i'm guessing its undercooked, dunno for larger sizes. Crust was crispy but otherwise bland.  Maybe it was an off night, and i also got some meatballs, they were good size, flavorful and fresh, but a little soft, it might be the meat is fatty, i tend to like leaner meats, but hey, meatballs are meatballs, you can't really go wrong! Doesn't have to be cloudy for a chance of Meatballs! haha

Great service and ambiance, and invites a second chance!

I don't usually like thin crust pizza. But something about this place won me over. The ingredients just mixed so well, the pizza sauce... the cheese. And the music - each booth has a little jukebox interface. Excessively charming if you ask me, but I'm not complaining.

The bruschetta was perfect for three, and if you don't order whole garlic cloves on your pizza, you're missing out. I used to live within 15 blocks of this place, and never went. Now that I'm across the city, I want to go all the time. That's just life, I suppose!

Wow, a lot of people have really bad taste when it comes to Italian food.

I am Italian, so maybe I am a tad bit more critical when it comes to pizza, but this place defines the word "mediocre."

I got a margarita pizza, you know- fresh sliced tomatoes, mozzarella basil? What I got was a cheese pizza- imagine Dominos. We asked the waitress if she screwed up our order- nope.

The crust was dripping with oil, soggy, disgusting. The garlic bread was french bread with uncooked chopped garlic on top. Gross.

The boyfriend ordered Eggplant Parmigiano, what he got was one big mess of blandness in a Ragu sauce.

All this for about 40 dollars.

Never again- ever. no.

House wine tasted like vinegar and the pizza was a step above high-school cafeteria quality.  Excessive grease came complimentary as a topping.  For those of you who want quality pizza, try Pizetta, Delfina's, Little Star, or Giovanni's at Deluxe.

Another mom-and-pop Italian establishment in SF ... another embarrassment to Italian food.

I went to the SF Academy of Science and my friend and I were starving and were trying to find a place nearby to eat. We yelped nearby restaurants and we found Gaspare's, and we were very glad we did!

It actually didn't start off too great; the bread wasn't all that great, but it was free so who cares right? Also, the water tasted very tap watery, which usually doesn't bother me that much, but this was pretty potent water haha. So we both ended up ordering sodas to quench our thirst.

Anyway, onto the important part- my friend and I ordered a sausage and mushroom pizza and linguine with clams. Both dishes were pretty simple, but very very delicious. The pizza was piping hot, you can tell it just came out of the oven since the cheese was perfectly gooey (you can see the oven from the dining area so you could also tell by just looking...). The linguine was straight up noodles, marinara, and lots of clams. Like I said, pretty simple, but really tasty.

To put a little cherry on top, the waitress was very nice and helpful. She came by to offer us refills on our sodas often, and she was nice and cheery, which is always a good thing.

Randomly found this place while walking looking for food while our friend was getting a tattoo in a shop a few blocks down. Had never heard of this place and me and my boyfriend said f*ck it lets try it. As soon as we walk in I LOVE the atmosphere. It was like a realll local spot and family owned I believe.

As we walk in we were instantly greeted by someone and told us to sit anywhere we'd like. Took a nice booth and got menu's and water right away. Our server came over a few minutes late and gave us the whole deal of the food and we ordered. We got the Margrite Pizza and Spinch raviolli. The pizza was GREAT! I dont know if I was just really hungry but it was like an orgasim in my mouth. The raviolli's were good too.

The art work around the place was all san francisco pictures painted which i loved. Everyone in there seemed to be usuals as they carried on conversations with the servers and said goodbye to everyone as they left and also saying they'll be back soon. I believe the owner was in and he was making sure everyones dinner were great.

nice place. CHECK IT OUT!

I don't eat Italian food very often.  This place was okay.  The waitress, who worked there for ten years, was lovely.  Their meatballs, while the sauce was tasty, the actual meat was soft - like they pulverized it or added filers or something.  Couldn't make heads or tails of it.  Or, maybe that's what was in there.

I'm kidding!

My chicken parmigiana was, again, tasty.  But not stupendous.  I did like that there were some crispy ends from the crust - yum.

It was obvious that the place has a loyal following of locals, and even on a Tuesday  night, had most of the tables filled.  It was neighborhood-y, had comfortable booths (everyone likes a good booth!), with period music on, lots of talking and laughter.

My favorite pizza place ever.
AMAZING PIZZA.
I have never strayed away from the margarita pizza and probably never will, it is that good.
Don't order it take out, it is so much better super fresh, but if you don't feel like being in a restaurant setting, I understand and am guilty of it as well, but it wasn't the same.
Sit down, season your pizza with chili flakes and parmesan, drink your wine and listen to the music. There is also a Russian bakery down the road with great canolis.

I was told this is one of the best places in the city to get a good slice of pizza and all their combos are good. I've tried it twice now and I'm just not sold. I honestly don't understand the hype... First time, I purchased the veggie pesto, pepperoni, and sausage slices and I wasn't pleased with neither the pepperoni or sausage. Definitely on the drier side and I like my pizza to be saucy. The veggie pesto was definitely delicious first time around. But when I Came back a second time, I only got the veggie and it was just ok. I'm not knocking this place, but it's definitely not my first choice.

Pizza rating 10/10
Store rating 7/10
Their pizza is like a deep dish style but the flavor of the supéreme and the garlic clam is amazing! It's not too cheesy or really skimpy, it has enough on each slice that you are able to taste everything. I would definitely recommend those 2 flavors.
The store rating is lower since their location isn't the best for finding parking and their was a line to even pick it up. Defiantly try this place but plan ahead!

It's a little weird walking up and not seeing a huge line... I wonder if that added to the flavor or the taste haha. Anyhow - they're operating under COVID-19 but the ordering over the phone is a little hit or miss. Ordered two half pies and they ended up with a half pie only for my order because I had mentioned number of people eating and they assumed the smaller order would be more than enough (which it turned out to be). Still the same great flavor though it did get cold and had to be reheated to keep the flavor. Glad they're open right now though!!

You honestly can't go wrong exploring and eating pizza in the North Beach area and this place is no exception. Expect lines to go out the door since the place is pretty small, but it does go quickly.

I enjoy that this place is dive bar-esque with its own vibe and tons of stickers lining the walls. The seating here is more stools lined up against the back wall and near the entrance so not really a sit down type of place. But it's a great place to enjoy a slice by yourself!

***CASH ONLY***

FAVES: veggie, combo, and clam & garlic

I originally was going to come and order 2 slices just for me, but once I saw the portions I only ended up getting one and it was perfect just for me. Slices vary between $3.25-$4.25.

I enjoy that the pizza here has a nice thick crust and crunch when you bite into it. They have the right amount of toppings and cheese without it being overwhelming.

The clam is a fave but it was definitely more garlic than clam. Don't get me wrong it was tasty, but I was expecting to have even portions of both ingredients. Some might get turned off by all the herbs on top but it added to its flavor for sure.

If you're area definitely stop by to grab a slice, a spot by the register, and have a great conversation with the workers!

Sicilian slice thick pizza with a line that resembled the wait in New York.

And mind you this was at 10pm.

OMG this place has great service and a great slice of pie.

The crust was perfect and the flavor of the toppings and cheese rocked it for me.

They heat up each and every slice even though it's already piping hot from the quick turnaround.

Cool joint....hole in wall pizza spot for locals and tourists alike!

I recommend going with any of their slices, from pepperoni to combo, to their clam. It's all a bunch of YUM!

Cheese quality is 1 star.  IF the topping quality & quantity were better, it would be a contender.  As is, absolutely not.  
All we could taste of the clam & garlic pizza was raw garlic, mounds of it.  Ugh.  No cheese taste, no clam flavor, we could neither see or taste clams.  Focaccia crust was light & crispy but again, absolutely no flavor.  Our pepperoni & sausage pizza was also a miss, 2 tiny pieces of sausage, 3 pcs of paper thin pepperoni and again, the flavorless gluey cheese & crust.

Not NY pizza by the slice, but pretty good pizza!

When some 20 years ago I left Brooklyn for San Francisco I immediately felt certain withdrawal symptoms, two top ones being that of NY bagels and NY pizza by the slice.

It took me a few months to discover Golden Boy Pizza, but once I did, my shaking hands somewhat stabilized, my nerves settled and I stopped being a short tempered SOB!! I knew then that whenever I craved a slice, I could go to Golden Boy and sniff up a couple of cheese or pepperoni slices and all be fine!! Shoot, I could even do it as late (or early) as 2:30 am on Saturdays and Sundays!!

Listen you fellow NYers who may read this, I still miss NY's pizza badly, the kind that you could buy at any neighborhood pizzeria, drain of grease, fold in half and swallow in four bites, but being on this side of the continent at least I have Golden Boy! So please be understanding and instead of disowning me, come and try a slice of Golden Boy Pizza and judge for yourself!

Hands down the best pizza I've had since moving to the
Bay Area almost 21 years ago.

I had the sausage and cheese slice as well as the combo.
First of they come in these square pizza slices,not the traditional triangle. The dough is so soft and each bite was heaven.

The two drawbacks were standing in line( I'd say we stood for about 20-25 minutes) and finding there was no place to sit. It's a very small shop and there aren't any tables available , just chairs and a metal counter that sat against the wall.  The place was packed. We walked over near Washington Square Park and sat on the steps at Italian American Athletic Club. Next time, we will probably take it back to the hotel.

One more important fact I almost forgot to share. It's cash only. Leave the plastic at home.

Golden Boy could be our new Ike's.

Golden Boy Pizza is so good. I miss the days when you could walk in and choose which square sheet you were going to devour, but they're still open and still serving some of the most delicious pizza pie you will ever have.

This review should've been written the first time I laid my hands on a slice of Golden Boy Pizza. Soft and fluffy with slightly crispy edges, not too saucy and square...just the way I love my pizza! The price isn't too bad either for a whole pizza with two toppings. It was under $30 and fed a family of 4 with a couple slices leftover for tomorrow.

They're definitely a favorite in our family and definitely worth the trek and lack of parking on a busy Saturday night. I recommend calling ahead and then showing up 30 mins later as they're no longer serving ready baked single slices due to pandemic. All staff members wore their masks and they had hand sanitizer out for you to use. They even take card now when before it was cash only.

Pizzeria Delfina is simply fantastic! This is perhaps the best place for pizza in the city. The Margherita pizza is delicious (it is topped with  Bufala Mozzarella) and so is the Panna pizza which has more of a cream based sauce. For starters I'd recommend ordering the Warm Marinated Olives! Since there is always a line, I'd recommend planning to get here at 5:45 or 6 to avoid the line or ordering take out. But the long wait sure is worth it. I truly believe that this place really does live up to the hype. I'm glad that this is in my neighborhood!

the pac heights menu: pizzeriadelfina.com/paci…

I would give this 3.5 stars.  We were fortunate to get there before it got crowded (it was a late lunch/early dinner).  When we left, it was PACKED!

I can't exactly remember what we had as a starter.  I believe it was a crostini with artichoke hearts that was good.

My fiance and I split a prosciutto pizza, which was pretty good.

The service was very friendly.  We found an interesting soda there which is apparently hard to find -- I can't remember the name, but it was some cherry coke-like drink from the South, which we found charming.  Would definitely come here again; the daily specials look the most intriguing.

Delicious pizzas!

Too bad there is always a wait - the food is awesome here!
Lots of Italian wines to choose from and there are 3 seats out front under a heater - usually open bc its so cold.

The menu is short but they have perfected what they got - try it out!
Be patient.....

Most definitely will be heading back here. The pizza was flavorful, not drowning in sauce, and the service was outstanding. Too bad I cant remember the servers name... But she was fantastic.
