Thursday night 6 pm, small line starting to form, right? No worries, she greeted them all before seating us, and then spent time making sure we had no questions about the menu or pizzas. She gave us an amazing recommendation for the Amatriciana (sp?) pizza special, which, if i ever run into i will be ordering again. Oh and we started with the pulled mozzarella appetizer with arugula and bread - delicious! The breadsticks are very good as well, and just sit there begging to be eaten as you sit down.

The cheese, peppers and fresh oregano are a nice touch on the table next to the vase of breadsticks. definitely makes for a nice atmosphere. It might be very dififcult if you're more than two people to find somewhere to sit BTW to heads up.

Most definitely try it if you're in the area. If you're not in the area, it's very BART-able from the 16th street BART station. Parking can be pretty difficult after 6pm, but worth the trip.

Greg and I LOVE LOVE LOVE this place.  Neither one of us can ever say no to pizza, especially when it comes from Pizzeria Delfina.  We've had a number of dates here, so when it came time to leave Pac Heights and start our new life in a new neighborhood, we felt that it was necessary to have our last dinner here.  The wait wasn't very long, although being that it was a Sunday, there was still about a 20 minute wait for a table inside.  Feeling a little adventurous, we ordered the special appetizer of the night: Baked Lumachine with Sunday Supper Sauce.  The dish was basically a rendition of Mac n Cheese and it was oh so delicious!  Seeing the bubbly cheese in the red sauce made those calories worth every bite.  We've also had the meatballs in the past, but this definitely takes the cake on best appetizer!  For our pizza, we ordered the Margherita and added the Fennel Sausage and Fra'Mani Salami Piccante.   Both Greg and I like our pizza pretty straightforward so while I wanted to try the Carbonara, this was a safe bet for him.  We also had a bottle of the Piedirosso La Sibilla Campania to go with dinner.  I want to take off 1/2 a star for the service we had when the wine came; someone just dropped it off on the table without allowing us to try it.  It was a good (and reasonably priced) bottle, but that seemed a little rude.  Our waitress was really nice, and while she wasn't all that knowledgeable on the type of wine we should have with our meal, she was really attentive and made sure we had everything.  We passed on dessert to splurge on Yoppi across the street but the desserts there still sounded delicious.

There were no leftovers to take with us down to South Beach, and I'm totally OK with that.  Hope to see you soon Pizzeria Delfina!

I came here for a late lunch on a Monday - and the place was PACKED!  So, beware if you are going during peak lunch or dinner hours because you will be waiting.  

We sat at the bar.  Did you know they have wine on tap?....can I get one of those in my house?

Anyway, on to the food.  

-Artichoke, arugula, ricotta salad - SO GOOD!...and really simple.
-Cheese fried in some dough - I can't remember the proper name and thought they were 'meh.'
-Spicy cauliflower - not spicy, and overcooked
-Proscuitto pizza - the most expenisve pizza on the menu and worth every penny!!  It had arugula with truffle oil and was absolutely dreamy.

This is the perfect place to come with a few friends so you can share a bunch of the dishes - atmosphere is fun and loud, just like a pizza place should be!

One of my favorite restaurants, great pizza and love their apps.  They once had grilled fresh marinated sardines as a special, wish they'd bring that back.  

I am a big fan of the carry out "half baked" pizzas.  10 minutes in your oven and they are as good as being at the restaurant.

The wait can be long, but just get your name on the chalkboard, and go have a cocktail at Elite Cafe around the corner.

PROs:
+Delicious pizza!
+Good potions.
+Stone IPA... Mmmmm.

CONs:
-Tiny restaurant.
-Waiting for a table.
-Loud.

I always leave happy when I go to pizzeria delfina-

the service is on par, the prices are reasonable, the food never fails to disappoint, and the ambiance is very welcoming.

I suggest going at not peak hours- 3pm-5pm to get a table right away.

The best pizza I've ever had, anywhere.  Sorry.  That's just the way it is.  

You'll obviously have to have strong feelings about super thin crust and minimal cheese to agree with me.  

I've tried many, many others.  I always come back here.

This bakery is about as good as it can get. The first time I stepped in through those doors and saw all the amazing looking and smelling baked goods it was a kid-in-a-candy-store moment for me.

I stopped by 15 minutes before closing and finally decided on a cheese roll, a tomato focaccia bread and picked up their last slice of their chocolate cake with the salted caramel frosting. After devouring what I had purchased, all I can was able to think was "WOW".

Yes, their baked goods are so worth the extra hour at the gym.

I bought a current scone.

I ate the current scone.

It was a yummy current scone.

I'd like to come back to try the pizzas. They looked delicious and overloaded with toppings.

Yelp is forcing me to add this review as a tip because it's so short but what else can I say??

SCONES, SCONES, SCONES!

I brought about a dozen to work & they were a huge hit! I brought currant, oat, cherry & corn, and blackberry-pear (which disappeared the fastest). Although a bit pricey at about $2.50-$3 each, I know I will still be back especially for those pizzas. Just superb. Not much can be said about this place other than the quality and fresh ingredients they use.

I love the smell of freshly baked goods in the morning. Precisely why I keep coming back.

Good wild mushroom pizza, but pecan swirl was dry and way too sweet. Terrific friendly service, but not nearly enough seating. Such a shame that the moms with kids, who were camping out at largest communal table, would not take their bags off the seats to free them up for other customers. Ya think they'd want to set a better example for their kiddies.

Amazing amazing amazing!! :D

LOVE me some Mendi!!

I already wrote a very long review for the arizmendi in Oakland on lakeshore ave so i don't have energy to do it again haha

best pizza EVER! Hands down! Healthy, local, sustainable, amazingness!!!!!! =D love it! Pizza is amazing every day and nver has let me down, only made me smile!

one kind of Veg pizza daily that even meat eaters will go crazy for! And great baked goods and cheese as well! Yum!

Oh what Arizmendi can do with flour, butter and sugar!  I've been coming here off and on since it first opened and the baked goods are consistently great!   It takes every ounce of willpower not to stop by here every day and pick up a little something to nosh on.  

The food is fresh, flavorful and high quality.  You can taste the ingredients that went into each item...no shortcuts taken here!  Nothing is too sweet or too salty.  Turnover is pretty high so there's no opportunity for anything to sit on the shelf for long periods of time.

My favorite items are the corn cherry scones and the mushroom focaccia, especially when they are fresh out of the oven.  Their breads, rolls, scones, pastries and pizza are good too.  I haven't tried their cookies so I can't speak to them.  Don't forget to try their salted caramel chocolate cake.  The extra workouts are so worth every bite of that moist and deeee-licious cake.    

The store is on the small side and there's usually a line out the door at
all hours, but it moves fairly quickly.  Be prepared to make your selections as you are standing in line for the register.  Very limited seating is available inside and outside.  Check out their website to view a list of their specials for the day.

I found myself this morning, craving carbs like a mad woman... damn ovaries again!  When I got to Arizmendi, I felt like I had stepped back into the womb ... but not in a damp and gross way.  Arizmendi is cozy (i.e., packed with other hungry people who had returned to the womb) and smells heavenly!!

There is something very nourishing and hearty about every one of the SIX items that I (and the bf) unconsciously stuffed into paper bags and carried up to the counter.  You will find no pansy-ass, flaky pastry at Arizmendi.  These goods are not for delicate eaters; these are like Tonka truck-grade baked goods.  I will not have to eat for days, I'm sure (although we all KNOW that I will, anyway...).

Here is what I got for $10.25 (you can see the pix I posted, too):

* Chocolate mint cookie: dense, rich dark chocolate with a cool mint aftertaste.  So-so...
* Hazelnut shortbread cookie: finely chopped hazelnuts in a buttery host.  So-so...
* Chocolate brioche:  brioche not to scantily laden with rabbit pellet-like chocolate jewels.  So-so...
* Raisin brioche knot: brioche laden with plump golden raisins knotted with a light sugar glaze.  Pretty good.
* Cheese roll:  whole wheat dough roll topped with asiago (?) cheese.  Mighty tasty! Would be a fabulous base for a sammich...
* Peach-raspberry scone: Golden crunchy outside encapsulating moist bits of peach and raspberry in buttery goodness.  Amazingly delicious.  I couldn't stop saying "oh my god... this is so frickin' good" the entire time I was eating it.

"Heaven... I'm in heaven, And my heart beats so that I can hardly speak. And I seem to find the happiness I seek..."  at Arizmendi!!

3 and a half stars.
Amazing place, lovely people and very, very good food!! Bakery for both sweet and salt flavours, it's a shame it is not closer to where I live

The almond cookie blew my mind man.... the cinnamon babka was really tasty as well. Their gingerbread is really spicy and not super sweet which I liked as well. Great little spot. Next time I'll try all of the cheesy breads and pizza for sure.
Love this place. Freshly baked bread, but I always come in for the slices of pizza. Love the customer service and how good the quality is. Always a staple here.

Update ****5/9/08***
It was another weekday and hubby and I were tired. This was not a night to cook, so we thought why not pizza. We walked to Giorgio's after work and got there by 5ish. OMG!!!!! There is a Kid's Happy Hour 4-6, it might be every weekday and it was packed with..........KIDS!

Almost every table had a child and there was a big 'ol kid's birthday party going on. It was pizza daycare.

But, this gave us a chance to eat in. I had not seen the Sicilian thin sliced pizza on the take out menu - maybe I didn't notice maybe it wasn't there. BUT, it was on the menu when we went. I finally get some awesome thin crust pizza I thought, and I was not disappointed.

It was crispy, thin the sauce was perfect and the amount of cheese just right.

We also got a bleu cheese (I think it was bleu cheese, it was some kind of cheese) salad. Yum yum yum. I couldn't stop eating. The pizza the salad. It was so good I forgot there was a kid crawling over the seat in back of me and falling on me and others running around and screaming. Pizza daycare. Crazy - havoc.

The waitresses were amazing. Amid all the kid craziness they were attentive and never lost their cool with all the kids.

I can't wait to go back for my thin crust, but just not at 4-6 p.m. unless I have a kid with me.

**********************************************************************
Had a pizza craving so decided to try out Giorgio's. We got a basic medium pizza with mushrooms, pepperoni, and olives to go ($13.60 with $1.35 for each additional topping). Service was fast and friendly and the pizza pretty good. Liked the crust and the sauce.

I'm a fan of Giorgio's pizza. It's tasty, made with fresh veggies, not too greasy.

I've only done take out, never dined in so I can't speak to that experience. But otherwise, I've always been happy.

A great place for a good, old fashioned pizza party. We had nine people dancing around the table sharing pizza and salad for about $20/person (with alceehall of course).

Great food, good service.

If I could, I'd give it 3-1/2 stars.

The delicious smells from this place waft down Clement Street and beckon you like a cheap hooker. Once inside, it's very pleasant - those of you who, like me, are always cold, will appreciate the toastiness of the place, even in the middle of winter. The ivy covored ceilings and red-and-white-checkered table cloths definitely lend an adorably kitschy flair.

What prevents me from leaning towards 4 stars instead of 3 is that the pizza just isn't amazing to me. When it arrives on your table, it looks a bit better than it tastes. There's a lot of grease (and I'm not even a sensitive blotter), and the crust seems a little doughier than it should be. And I was very disappointed to discover that the basil they count as TWO toppings isn't even the fresh kind, but rather what you'd expect from one of those little seasoning dispensers.

Don't get me wrong - it's satisfying enough. And great for families and others who might want to save some dollars - the portions are quite sizable for the money. But that smell outside the restaurant sets your expectations just a little too high.

I'm a nurse historian, so I was visiting San Francisco to conduct research. I took a break from writing to get some pizza, and I decided to order food to go from here. As I waited, I took in the restaurant's great ambience. But then as time went on, I saw customers who ordered after me get their orders first...one after the other. I waited almost an hour before I received my order, which negated the point of getting back to work quickly. However, I didn't mind that the food was late. As a nurse, accountability goes a long way, so what irritated me the most was that no apology was given. I saw staff behind the counter whisper and look at me, so they acknowledged that my order was forgotten. And I suppose, that left a bad taste in my mouth because the pizza's taste was not as illustrious as the restaurant's appearance.

My husband is obsessed with Detroit style pizza. He became obsessed when we lived in Canada and would make trips to Detroit for his work. He loves the way these guys do their thing. They are true artisans. App/web based during Covid, prompt friendly employees, five star through and through!

Right now this is my favorite pizza place in San Francisco. Their "square" (technically rectangular) pizza hits a nice balance between flavorful crust, sauce and toppings. I've also tried their burgers and enjoyed them, though they're not quite as distinctive as their pizza offerings.

Since I live in the neighborhood I've mostly been getting take-out orders (easy and seamless, you get a text when the order is ready for pickup), but the place is nice inside and the part of Mission Street that they're on (across from the 9th circuit courthouse) is a bit less sketchy than some of the neighboring areas.

Very welcome addition to the mid-SOMA neighborhood.

Ordered pick up and it was ready to go when I arrived. We ordered 3 pies (Mushroom, Bacon Bacon & JLIN), Crispy Brussel sprouts and the Chilled Bowl Salad - all were well executed, high quality and super delicious. The standouts were the JLIN pie and the salad/Brussels. We will be back soon to try more!

Now personally I'm partial to thin crust pizza at A-16 or Delfina, so I'm not as taken with this pizza as most of the rest of the world. But if you're on Clement Street and are looking for something other than Asian food, this is a great option.

They do have a thin crust pizza (which our waitress tried to talk us out of) that was pretty good.

The atmosphere is awesome - reminds me of post soccer game pizza parties when I was a kid - red checkered table cloths and all!

If you're looking for a cornucopia of delectable flavors to dance across your palate, try some skittles and pop rocks.  

If you want some good, old fashioned pizza pie, go to Giorgio's.  

The pizza is seriously good.  Their beer and wine selection is a bit lacking, but all you really need is a hef to go with that slice.  

Since the last time I was there, they remodeled a bit.  But it is everybit as good as I had remembered.

Plus, there's a pretty cute dark haired hostess there.  

The only thing missing is a huge flat screen playing some sort of ball game.

Thin crust pizza always has a place in my heart, that and really good antipasto salad. Giorgio's has both of these and I must say that it's pretty good all around. If you decide to eat in the service is on point and the food is fast, can't argue with that!

Tips and pointers:
-Try the combination pizza
-Antipasto salad is amazing
-Bathrooms are clean, servers are friendly
-Wait isn't too long, even on the weekends
-Prices are fair and not high

[APPROVED]

I'm having trouble figuring out why I haven't already reviewed Giorgio's b/c I come here often enough and love it.

I love their salads and the chicken parmigiana. All the food comes with a very generous portion that I can't ever finish, but I do like trying. Everyone I take here really enjoys the food and leaves happy and full.

I freaking love Square Pie Guys. The pizza is so good that you'll spend your days yearning for another slice. Very few places can live up to Square Pie Guys and their quality ingredients, inventive toppings, and consistent execution. FEED ME!!!!

I had a pepperoni pizza and It was ok. The edges of the pizza had a fishy taste. The waitress that brought my pizza to my table didn't say one word to me, no hello, no enjoy, nothing. Everyone's entitled to have a bad day I guess. The worst thing I saw while I was sitting there eating my pizza was a woman behind the counter handling food. She touched her face, was digging in her scalp, and stroking her hair and she didn't bother washing her hands before handling food again. No thank you, but that's enough for me not to go back.
Wow super delicious pizzas and the Szechuan wings are amazing but pricey at $12 plus tax for 6 small wings. Salads are excellent I mean really really good too

Expect a long wait time if you order from this place. They take FOREVER to prepare your food. I waited over 2 hours before having to cancel. They said it would have taken at least another hour to finish preparing my food. Total wait time would have been 3 hours if I had not canceled. Square Pie Guys?? More like SLOW Pie Guys!!
This pizza was freaking delicious. I'm from New York and these guys kill it. Crispy but soft and great quality toppings. It's definitely $$$ but it's worth it.
I cannot believe that the Double Cheeseburger and the Wings are so amazing at this Pizza place, it doesn't make sense, this is the best cheeseburger that I have ever had!

A very thoughtful fellow once took me on the best Valentine's date here after he discovered my parents used to go on dates here in high school (and no, the decor has not changed since 1965).

Best pizza in San Francisco. There, I said it.

Don't know why I never found this place sooner. This is the real deal with thin crust italian style pizza.  The cheese pizza is my favorite by far. This together with a side salad is all it takes for me to be happy and content!

Can get crowded but believe that the wait is worth the while!

The gourmet pizza is really good, and it's only like $3.50 for a huge huge slice. It's thin and crispy on the bottom, and nice and soft with just the right amount of sauce cheese and toppings.

Overall it's definitely a good deal, and it hits the spot without making you feel like a fat grease monkey like after eating pizza hut

This place sells cheap and good pizza. Their crusts are very good, perfect thickness and crunchyness.
I ordered a hawaiian and it was pretty much perfect.
Minus one star (possibly 2) for the shady neighborhood, and super cold establishment:  If you don't mind the 41 degrees inside the joint when its like 40 degrees outside or the panhandlers who freely roams these nether parts of the city this place will fix you a delicious slice of pizza heaven!

They *DO* take credit cards, at least on Haight street and if you order a whole pie. Didn't know about the "buy one get one free" coupons though. Definitely going to hit Janet D up after I finish writing this.

Anyhow, I live a couple blocks away from this place and always order/get slices from here. They make good pizza, and the people are nice.

Thin crust pizza with unique toppings, this is where it's at!One of my favs is the potato pesto garlic pizza. They are fast and cheap and even cheaper if you rip out the free soda coupon from the sf guardian. I heart escape from NY.

Went here during our San Fran vacation and I ordered a slice of The Gourmet and the boyfriend got a slice of the classic standby pepperoni. He enjoyed his, but I was in LOVE with mine. Ah mah gahd. Soooo good. If I lived near here, I'd most certainly be about 20 pounds fatter because I'd go here at least twice a week, upwards of 7 days a week. Everything from the toppings to the mild sauce to the cheese and the nicely hand tossed crust it was amazing. The only thing I wasn't quite a fan of was there was only 1 shaker of "pizza condiments" and my boyfriend had to wait awhile for the crushed peppers due to someone hogging them. Want yummmmy pizza? Go go go!

FOUR STARS FOR "You Say Potato" Pizza. I dont care about the others. All you need to know is that there are whole garlic cloves baked on the pizza. So sweet and delicious!

After a trip to Height or to "Hippie Hill" in Golden Gate Park, I'm suuuure you'll need it.

This place is my go-to for something quick on my lunch break. The slices are big, I usually just get one and I'm happy. Their cheese slices are fine, but my favorite is the "U Say Potato," which has giant chucks of garlic and potatoes and pesto sauce. Yummmmmm.

I come here because it's no nonsense. You order your pizza, its ready within 1-2 minutes, the staff is efficient, and you get what you want!

it is 20 years since i  last ate here.  But I am told it is still just as good.  As I have said I am a pizza snob from NYC  so when I rave about a pizza parlor it is with that as a background.  So my wife and I are on line to get some slices noticing the wall of fame and the movie poster for the eponymous movie starring Kurt Russell, Ernest Borgnine  and the incomparable Adrienne Barbeau.  Any way glancing around the place I came to notice one of my neighbors growing up who is from back east.  She told me it was the only good pizza in the bay area.  

You poor bastards in San Fran, at least you got this place.
Great place to eat pizza on Haight street when you're craving for one. A slice is very filling and it's all worth it. I love their veggie gourmet pizza. Best ever!

I have had the pizza here a few times and it has been generally pretty good. I decided to do delivery last night, but that didn't work out so well. It arrived cold, but I don't blame the restaurant for that. The delivery guy was on a scooter, so all of that open rushing air cooled it down quick.  The main problem was the pizza was way over baked and the sausage tasted reheated. The crust was very dark and tough and the cheese was pretty dried out. I ordered the extra large since I like to have plenty of leftovers, but this pie was way too overdone to handle any reheating. I ate a piece and then scrapped the topping off two others, but it wasn't any better. Bottom line: $47 (pie+topping+delivery fee + sales tax +tip) completely wasted. I sent a note to the restaurant to let them know it was a bad experience, but I guess they don't care since there was no response.  I know they can make a decent pizza now and then, but I  won't gamble $47 bucks in hopes they get it right. I would have been happy to wait longer for a properly baked pizza, then to just settle for whatever comes out of the oven.
Delicious pizza. One of our new favorite spots, definitely looking forward to coming back. The pizza dough is almost like a naan bread so amazing!!!
Great location; authentic Italian food; awesome service (thanks George and team).

When you do not want to wait three hours at Tony's Pizza Napoletana, go here. The wait is not as bad, I'd say 5-10 minutes wait on Friday night despite the limited seating.

Soon as you get seated, you'll hear a bunch of Italian people, that's how you know you're in the right place for some legit Pizza in the Bay Area.
Few minutes after the server took your order, drop everything and prepare your camera for an ultimate photo of pizza making show, dough tossing up in the air and all.
I love this place and best their chilly olive oil spice. Both the one on market and on north beach

Still leaving the rating at 5, but there was one blemish with our most recent visit.  The food here is REALLY good and very reasonably priced.

We ordered the roasted cauliflower and it was delicious.  The Calabrese pizza was really good, but after slicing it up it was underdone a little in the middle.  Next time I will check--I wished I had asked them to put it the oven again.   But the toping was delicious as was the crust that was cooked.

The tiramisu was just okay.  The tiramisu at Cafe Greco is better.

One of the worst pizza's I have ever eaten. Ordered the Capricosa which was a huge disappointment, the pizza arrive not just soggy but wet, could not lift a slice up without all the pizza toppings falling off, even the cheese slide off the crust. Also tried the Cavolfiori which was decent but very oily, and could have used more capers to balance the dish.

Service was lack luster, but given it was a busy Friday night can't really doc too many points for that.

Perhaps we ordered the wrong dishes, but not sure I would spend the $ to try this place again.

Wow. This pizza was phenomenal. We ordered the Fried Mozzarella and the Prosciutto pizza. We were not disappointed.

We were seated immediately. The entire restaurant was booming. Seating was a little tight. The table we were placed almost felt squeezed in, but the staff is extremely nice. If you're looking for a quiet place to eat, this may not be it. But if you're looking for quality food, you've found it.

This place gets it right. Napoli pizza is not meant to be fancy, it's street food. The focus is in the quality of ingredients and the technique in its creation. Il Casaro is the most authentic Neapolitan pizza joint in San Francisco. Super friendly service and pizza that is out of this world.

Know that this style is different. Don't go in looking for your local pizza joint. One person could eat one pizza. But the flavor is incredible.

I love sitting at the bar and watching them work. Highly recommended if looking for great food in San Francisco!
Meatballs were great. Pizza was good, but being from close to New Haven,CT and Pepe's and Sally's Pizza being so good. Hard to say this is better. It's good though for California. I would come again.
Best pizza in the city - love that they have thin crust + smaller pie size so you can order 2 and try a little bit of both. Can get crowded but waitlist should not take long.

Quick Tip: Egg on pizza. Yum.

I'm always looking for a pizza place that makes pizza without tomatoes. I'm allergic to tomatoes, so you can see why this is a big thing for me, and this place makes really good pizza.

It's a hole in the wall. My boyfriend use to live a few blocks away from this place, but never really ate there until a few years later. The place is in a residential neighborhood, and parking can be a b*tch to find, so patience is definitely required in that department. Oh yah, and patience is also required in the waiting-for-your-order department as well.

This is a small place, so it can be a little difficult to find, especially if you aren't familiar with the Richmond district. There are a couple of tables outside, and you think..."oh, this is cute. There's an outdoor area." And for good reason...the maximum number of people that fit in the place itself is about...15? Maybe less. it's a small space, but in my opinion (as well as our friends), it's worth it.

We usually get the cheeseboard which is pretty damn awesome, especially if you decide to eat it with wine. The menu tends to change on the types of cheeses, but from the times I've been there...it's always been really good.

The menu isn't as fluffy with other types of pizzas. it's straight to the point, and I make sure to get the pizza with egg. When I first tried pizza with an egg, it was because all the other pizzas had tomatoes and this one didn't. It was delicious. So delicious that I hope they never take it off their menu!

The wait for the pizza can be a little long, especially if you're going there on a super empty stomach. It's because they make it fresh. You can see their oven in the store, and the little bar area they have. It's a cute place and I go there whenever I get a craving for a thin crust pizza with egg.

it's worth the try. As the saying goes, "don't knock it 'til you try it."

We almost missed it driving by for lunch because it was such a tiny place, tucked between Clement and California next to a laundromat. It looked adorably cozy - I doubt that twenty people can squeeze into this place comfortably - and I was excited. The smaller the place, the more attention given to the customers and the orders, I hoped.

When we got there, one other table was taken, and we were seated by the window on a long, cushioned bench.The server was very nice and friendly, a UCSD alumni who checked in on us several times to make sure that things were A-OK. He kindly advised my friend and I not to spend all our time at college studying, which had been my initial plan. No idea what to do with my college life now, but I do know that when I get back to SF on the occasional weekend, I will be returning here sometime.

Between three people we shared three pizzettas, each ten inches in diameter and very thin, yet boasting a nice crust. The amount of ingredients was just right for the amount of dough, which was slightly toasted on the bottom yet still soft underneath the cheese and tomato sauce. The Rosemary and Pine Nuts pizzetta was my favorite; it definitely had plenty of the herb for a rich, delicious flavor and the pine nuts, which is not the usual fare for pizza, added a lovely crunchy texture, though it was not overwhelming in the least. And that cheese! It just melted in the mouth.

The Basil, Mozzarella, and Tomato pizzetta sounded simple but tasted fantastic, and the basil was sprinkled generously, complementing the cheese and sauce nicely. It was very yummy. The same pizzetta with anchovies, was not my favorite, but my fellow diners loved it. I'm usually not fond of fish, and especially not on pizza, but I had a bite and it was rich with unique flavor. A nice addition, though not for me.

If I did not fit into the typical broke-college-student mold, I would love to frequent this place more often, but alas, the bill came to about fourteen dollars a person after tip. A nice lunch, and definitely the best pizza I've had in a long while, but the amount was not quite satisfying. I liked the style of pizza with a very thin crust, but I couldn't see it filling up any starving customers. Anyone who is seeking a light-medium lunch and doesn't mind forking over the cash should definitely stop by.

Ordered two pizzas here with a friend... I can't remember the first one, but it was pretty good.

As for the second one... rosemary, fiore sardo cheese, and pine nut pizzetta (we also added sausage to it) was so amazingly delicious, I couldn't put it down!

In fact, I'm still having dreams about this pizza...

Honestly? Overrated. We had the Farm Egg pizza, Bacon/Brussel Sprouts pizza, and the Margherita Pizza. The pizzas were good, but the pizzas at Arizmendi are just as good. We arrived 10 mins before they opened, and there was already a long line..on a Monday. Naturally we had high expectations. The verdict? Not worth the wait (or the money). The venue is small. The service is mediocre (they served TWO tables that arrived after us..screwed up our Farm Egg pizza and had to redo it...and oh yeah screwed up our Bacon/Brussel Sprouts pizza too.) The only mildly exceptional pizza was the Margherita. They do make a good margherita. But the service ruined it for us. They did apologize and give us a complimentary apple cobbler, BUT their sorry was not genuine, the waiter came off as completely unapologetic, and bottom line it was too little too late.

Won't be returning. SORRY I'M NOT SORRY.

God, this was a great decision.

It was my second of two nights in SF and I wanted pizza. My friend picked out this spot and after a wild adventure finding parking, we finally got there...only to wait outside for about 45 minutes. It was kinda cold, and there was not a place to sit, but we each got a drink and waited patiently.

There were three tables of two outside and maybe a total of 15 seats inside. What a tiny place!

We finally got seated (opted for the bar) and had a great view of the chefs making the salads and pizzas, and preparing desserts.

We got a heirloom tomato salad (their special of the night) and the lamb sausage pizza. Both were incredible.
The salad was so fresh and light, with just enough parm and croutons garnished on top. The pizza was perfect. It was airy, not too tomato-y, and the crust was just browned enough.

We were in love. We talked to the waiters and to the woman behind the bar, making pizzas. She described the place as kind of a "co-op," with several of the staff having small shares of ownership.

Overall, we had a great experience. The place was really cute, with a great ambiance and nice decor. The menu was small but everything tasted and looked delicious. The staff was very helpful and kind. It was worth the wait and worth the price. I love it!

The food here is amazing, their menu has only a few items which completely makes sense since their kitchen is so tiny. But boy do they do a great job at doing every single item to perfection. We had heirloom tomato & roasted corn salad to start, the corn and tomatoes where sweet and delicious, it has been two weeks since then and I Still think about lol. Yes it was that good :)

I love this place!  I had a delicious farro and brussels sprout salad and a cheese pizza for lunch with my toddler.  While in a corner seat, we enjoyed a delicious meal with friendly service. I can't wait to go back!
It always manages to be a special meal when I eat here. The pizza offerings are always spot-on. Even the more imaginative combinations.

What a gorgeous, cozy pizza shop!  Serves passionately inspired, carefully sourced & artfully crafted seasonal pizzas, along with one of the most glorious chocolate cakes I have ever had.  Which was accompanied by an *incomparable* chantilly cream.  The ingredients here?  Are seriously exquisite.
It's a remarkably teensy space, only accommodating four small parties (2-4 per table) indoors, with a couple/three weather-permitting outdoor tables.  The ambiance is intimate, with upper-class, rural-rustic overtones... it made me feel like I was living the first world white collar dream, for sure.  I would gladly return for a dine-in experience in a heartbeat with treasured friends or family, and gladly order take-out for a highbrow night on the couch.

This is the best pizza in San Francisco ... so why not 5 stars?  The crust is fabulous, toppings sparse and well chosen, all in all my current favorite pizza.  I love the beautiful salads  and the homey deserts ... the strawberry shortcake is wonderful and the olive oil cake when they make it is as good as any I've had in Italy.  SO WHY NOT 5 STARS?

This place loves pizza and the process of cooking and creating food and it is great if you live close by, (I do not) or you can get there by 5PM, (which is something  I can't  do very much) you're golden.  I've driven out to foggy side of town only to be told they were out of dough ... oh, the disappointment.  It's really not a take out place and it is a tiny  space with room for about ten inside and about six more outside when the weather permits.  I love this place because of its quirks  and its great pizza, but those same quirks have to cost them a star.  

Still the best pizza in San Francisco!

There were a waiting list and a wait of 30 minutes for the 8 of us, which is to be expected on a nice sunny day. We order plenty of dishes and everything was family style serving so everyone got a bit of everything. I'm not too crazy with all that I had nor did it hit my taste bud. We drop by hearing it was one of to go places from family members. We did out door dining and it was quite cold out. We didn't have lamp heater which could of made it a bit more convenient. But overall its an ok experience and the food I would rate it 3.5 of 5 stars.

Tony's.    Drive all the way from Morgan Hill CA just to pick up pizzas here. Call the order in and after a 75 mile drive get there in time to pick them up and drive home (the smell all the way home is a killer!) reheat in the oven and we chow down!

Love it period. Visited around 9pm on a Saturday night and they were able to seat us right away. The menu has a variety of pizzas and everything sounded good so it was hard to choose. We ordered two pizzas: the New York style (5/5) and Prosciutto E Pomodorini (5/5). Both of these pizzas were perfect. The prosciutto was really good quality, added just the right amount of cherry tomatoes. The mozzarella cheese was incredible, and the pizza crust was delicious, thin, and crispy in the right parts. The New York style pizza was effin good. Everything was perfection from the crust to the sauce, and cheese/pepperoni. Lol I kept eating all of the crust even though I was full because that dough was so gooood!! Great customer service and flavorful food. I will definitely have to try some other pizzas on the menu.
Cold outside one spot has a heater on both backs. The pizza was filling. The staff was quick too.

Hands down one of the best pizza places in SF! I'd do dine in rather to go or delivery since the pizza was pretty warm when I dined in and I could see the pizza may get soggy if consumed after awhile. I'd love to be back!

It's the best pizza in the city. Go with friends and get a drink next door because the 2 hour wait isn't worth it. Take it to go and eat it in the park but I have not been able to stop thinking about the chicken parm pizza with vodka sauce for 4 weeks nos
Very good, I love all the choices!  The crust was good, the toppings were yummy. And great outdoor seating.

I go to SF at least once a year for a weekend getaway. I always make it a point to stop and grab a pizza and meatballs from Tony's. Parking is definitely the biggest hassle, but what do you expect from the location. The service has always been great regardless of how busy the restaurant may be at the time of my arrival. COVID forced them to expand their outdoor seating, but it has helped reduce their wait time. You can't go wrong with any dish here.
The real party in my mouth... very long waitlist but after it worth the wait... trust me!

I've visited Tony's restaurant recently this year during Covid before the June reopening.  The wait wasn't too bad.  The host does their best to get parties seated.  They did have a weird line setup for the restroom that started outside the restaurant, but I guess it's to not over crowd the restaurant with people waiting for the restroom.  I've also visited their to-go that is right next door before in the past for quick slices to-go.

The menu is pretty good with a variety of pie styles from New York, Italian, Naples, Californian, Sicilian, etc., even a pizza from Detroit!??  They also have antipasti, pasta, sandwiches, and a burrata burger!  They also sell their Hot pepper olive oil for $10 or $11 bucks which I did buy a bottle to take home.

We ordered the classic Margherita and Peroni beer battered fried artichokes.  Both were very good, but I thought the prices were high for the Margherita $25 and you only get 3 or 4 artichokes for $15.  The prices are definitely aimed at tourists and you can get good comparable if not better Margherita pizza at other places.  However, when you're in North Beach and wanting pizza, Tony's is the best place to go if you want to try other pizza varieties.  I will probably visit again just to try other options.

Great lunch place. Loved the warm winter salad with cauliflower and peanuts. Margherita pizza w/burrata was downright indulgent.

Cool industrial earthy modern design. Great service.

A modern take on a pizzeria. Has a club-type feel to it. The food is above average, the price is probably about what it should be, and the experience is alright. Good place to take someone who isn't from a city so they can get pizza from a place that isn't similar to their local pizzeria.

We came here last weekend with a party of around fifteen. The host graciously took our orders and swiftly got us all the pasta our hearty little tummies would allow.

Would come again - try their mussels.

It isn't  as expensive as you may think for a large group. We ordered appetizers, pasta, seafood, salad, and four or five pizzas with beer. All came out to around thirty a person.

Came here after Off the Grid on a Friday night for drinks. Bartender was very nice in helping us select a cocktail since it was our first time.

Nothing bad about this place, inside was clean and dim lit, like most other bars. Its a short walk from the marina.

Drinks were $10+, typical since we were in the city. We didn't get a chance to try their food menu. Would come again if I was in the area. Nothing particularly special about this place.
This place was recommended by our hotel.  It was a disappointment- the "kids pasta" was worse than making noodles and sauce out of a jar.  Location it the one thing they have going for them.

Nothing unique or different about their food. Marinara will always be Marinara.

I have not yet found an Italian restaurant in the city that I am exactly crazy about especially because of my gluten-intolerance. It is rare that I can actually have the pasta at these italian restaurants so I am always forced to find alternative. At Delarosa I found that the only thing I could really have was a salad and the polenta cake. The salad lacked any flavor. My plate consisted of 5 different veggies that were shredded and topped with a vinaigrette. Not amazing or tasty. Then the polenta cake was just cut and put into a marinara sauce. Once again nothing amazing or different. Bland, not creative and things I've seen before. I wouldn't waste my time.
Consistently good pizza, drinks and service. Can be crowded and noisy, especially on Fridays and Saturdays. Eat outside for the best Marina people watching.

I went back in March but I still find myself dreaming of Delarosa! Great prices for San Francisco, plus the food was amazing. The bruschetta with ricotta was delicious. The salad was super refreshing. The pizza was also very tasty. The staff was super friendly for a busy, crowded restaurant. Love Delarosa and definitely recommend going for a fun evening out!

I truly forgot how good Delarosa is. I usually dismiss it as expensive pizza, but after eating there again last week I truly forgot how good it is. We got the bruschetta and carbonara pizza. Mmm. So good. If you don't order drinks it really isn't all that expensive either.

I feel like I go here at least once a week now since its right around the corner from the restaurant I work at and when I get off this place is a saving grace being open til 1am.

The usual suspects: Bottle of the Vermentino Casamatta, the beets carpaccio (mmm white truffle...), margherita with buratta (YUMMMM light cheesey creamy goodnesssss), and copa mela (chunks of apple pie, vanilla ice cream, and a spicy caramel sauce) or the housemade donuts for dessert.

There's also other great things I've tried here such as the black olive gnocchi with rock shrimp, beer steamed mussels, and polenta bastoncini w/gorgonzola dolce to name a few but the above is just my favorites. you MUST try the beets and the margherita with buratta. that is all.
Really good pizza at a good price. I had the mushroom pesto. Really tasty. The service was very good. The young woman who served us was very likable and courteous.
good choice for a quick cheap bite if your in the neighborhood. not a destination spot. they're delivery time can be a bit spotty but we order from them on a regular basis.

After living in New York, I have difficulty finding pizza that meets my picky standards.  Marcello's is about the closest thing I've found on the west coast to New York style pizza.  It's thin with just the right amount of sauce and not too much cheese.  They sell by the slice and from now on will be my go to place for food after hitting all of the bars in the Castro.

I don't know why people are knocking this place, I think the pizza is amazing!!  I have actually gone to the Castro specifically for pizza from here.  It's very well priced compared to most other pizza places, and sitting at the neon lit counters eating pizza and drinking apple juice is a really great way to end a crazy night.

I have only lived here a little under a year but so far this is the best pizza in the bay area, hands down!!! What's so great about this place is that they sell by the slice and they make interesting/unusual pizza. If that's not your thing, they also make plenty of regular type pizzas ex. pepperoni. If you dine in, the service is fast and the cooks/workers are very polite. My only complaint is that they don't take card. Who doesn't take cards??? Their pizza style is a thin new york type pizza crust. My first visit there I had this weird salami, green and black olive pizza. It was one of the best pizzas I've ever tasted. So if you see that, and like olives, be sure to get it. What is also neat about this pizzeria is that the pizza changes constantly, so you don't know exactly what they might have (This is only for those who are walking in for a slice). So it's a little adventurous. I know they also have sandwiches, bread, and other goodies but the pizza is where its at. They also deliver, but only to certain areas. That's a bummer for suburbanites, but it's worth the trip down there. I can't remember if the pricing is descent, but it doesn't matter!! It's worth forking any amount of change. Ummmm, yeah, it's awesome. Go try some!!
The food in this place is delicious, don't miss the chance to eat there, small, casual, fresh, awesome. I will go back

DON'T DO THAT! Was screamed at me by the manager (Julette?) when I raised my hand to get the check.  I listened calmly until she continued the harangue...then I was forced to stand up and leave.  WHEN does a manager have the right to chastise a customer for a reasonable behavior:  it's service is lazy, (I asked for her check and then the waitress disappeared), the manager stood in the middle of the restaurant -on a obviously intense personal cell phone call for ten minutes, then marched over to me to bark this order. I wrote to Giancarlo, the GM,  whom I several times who failed to respond. Food OK but who do they think they are treating people this way!!!

Went on Thursday night for a pre birthday dinner. Food and service was very nice. Our server, Roberto, took good care of us. We got few different appetizers and the prosciutto plate was excellent. We got the margarita pizza as well as the special pizza which was with black truffle. Both very good. The restaurant remind me  small restaurant in Italy. Love it and will definitely be back

This place is a great find. The location is a bit sketchy, but the pizza (pinsa) is good and the staff friendly. The dough is not as stretchy as the traditional napolitaine pizza, but a bit tougher. I had the maranella(?) which was delicious. The salad was just ok, but then again it was just a salad. I'd like to come back to try other items on the menu
The wine listed for $12 was charged for $44. No explanation. Outrageous!!! Pizza was okay though.

This is the best pizza in SF.  The sauce has a little spice and their combos are very original.  I sometimes go in for just a slice of something original or get delivery.  Love the Bacon and Feta Cheese and Pesto Rosemary Potato combos and tonight just got through eating just plain cheese.  They are a little pricey, but I have gotten coupons for other places and used them thinking I would save a little money only to be so disappointed and wishing I spent the few extra dollars on my favorite pizza.
Delicious pizza.  Try it if you're hungry after hours in the Castro. You won't regret it!
i could look at that front server..alllllll day!
Love this pizza. Best sacue in the city. Vibrant atmosphere, great service and definitely my favorite pizza in the city.

Now that we've moved out of the Castro, Marcello's is a Muni ride away, but it's SO worth it. I could eat there every night. Their cheese pizza slices are perfect -- the crust, sauce, and cheese are all done right. I've been eating there for 7+ years and it's been consistently great. If you're lookin' for a fantastic New York style pizza slice, Marcello's is  your spot.

Very friendly place for a casual meal.   Great selection of cheeses and meats and Italian and Spanish wines.   The Pinsa is a delightful lightness with lots of flavor.

Great service and cozy environment.

Came in on wednesday night around 7 and waited about 15 mins for a table. After being seated, we waited another 10 minutes without being ackowledged. I told the hostess we were ready and heard her tell a waiter we wanted to order.
Waited anoher 10 minutes without anyone helping before we left. The only time we spoke to a waiter was as we were leaving, over 20 minutes after sitting.
Terrible service and a waste of almost an hour.

If you want to eat what people in Rome eat, you come here.
If you're one of those who think pizza pepperoni, caesar salad, fettuccine Alfredo and spaghetti meatballs is real Italian food, don't even bother stopping by.
Light and delicious pinsa, fine ingredients, rustic and unique ambiance is what you'll find here, Roman owner and Roman pinsa guy at work... A gem in downtown SF.
Forza Roma!
The atmosphere and delicious food is worth the wait. I always feel like I'm in Italy when dining here. Highly recommend. If my stomach was big enough, I would get 1 of everything on the menu.
Fantastic hole-in-the-wall with remarkable pizza (pinsa) and solid wine. The food is every bit as good as the ambiance. Will be back again soon.

Finally got around to trying this place. Let it be known that I'm not a huge fan of deep dish pizza... I ended up eating 3 slices all by myself. So satisfying and had so much flavor! We ordered the "little star" and added sausage to it- you must add sausage! I can't imagine the pizza having the same taste without the added sausage. We shared the 9in and that was perfect for the two of us. Definitely left stuffed and satisfied!

Yes... I may be just one of the 1000+ reviews here for Little Star Pizza, but I do hope that my review will have some sort of weigh to it as I purposely seeked out "The Best" pizza joint in SF and I live down here in the nice & sunny southern California area...

It was between either Little Star Pizza or Tony's Pizza Napoletana... Little Star won out this time due to the fact I didn't feel like going into the city on the way to Santa Rosa... but don't worry, next trip up to SF Tony's here I come...

So this is a tiny little pizza joint right offer Divisadero... it can be easily missed but just seek out the little star logo and you will be fine... the building is painting in dark colors but I'm sure you will see people there for the food....

Let's start from the outside and work our way in...

Parking is metered like everywhere else in SF... very limited around the area so good luck... Nina R. and I visited this place at about 2:15pm so we scored a perfect parking spot right in front... however, $0.25 for 8 minutes???  Is "The City" that strapped for cash???  Sigh... I had no change so I had to ask the LS hostess for some change for parking...

Upon entering, the hostess was very nice and cordial and immediately get me the change I needed... so back out I went to pop some coins in for parking...(remember... bring lots of coins!!!  It's gonna run you about $3 bucks or so for sure!)

Place is dimly lit... about 10 tables or so... clean, quiet (during the time I was there), and pretty intimate.....

Bathroom was clean and artistic just like most of the places in SF....

So we went ahead and ordered the Spinach Feta/Mediterranean half and half pie (deep dish)...  

Be prepared.... it took 30 minutes for the pie to come out... yes it's hand freshly made to order, but man.... 30 minutes..... there is at least $1 out of parking already.....

When the pizza came out it was piping hot and cute!  It looked small but the small portion was filling enough for 2 people with left overs... the Spinach Feta was delicious and creamy while Mediterranean tasted healthy than it should be which is not a bad thing....

I do believe it was corn meal crusted... not my favorite cup of tea as I love them buttered up crust baked to crisp that tasted like a Danish butter cookie.... so Little Star take note.... get more butter on your crust please!!!

The bill came out to about $28 + $3 for one pizza... little steep but can't beat the experience...

So here's the Pros and Cons part...

Pros:  Tasty pizza, great service, nice atmosphere, clean bathroom...
Cons:  No parking, expensive price point

I would of given it a 3 star due to parking and the cost, but I did enjoy the experience and the food so bumping it up one star is very fair in my opinion....

Now that I've tackled one of the top pizzeria in SF... I got to compare it to the other one on the other side of the town... Give them a try.... I do believe you will enjoy their deep dishy goodness!

Up date.
As I wrote, we had so much left over "pizza" from the Little Star.
3 days after.
Still no one touched the lousy edible triangular-sponges in refrigerator.
Yes, I call it "LOUSY EDIBLE TRIANGULAR-SPONGES".

In general speaking, don't we all like left over pizza?
Yes, we like left over pizza.
But not this one. You won't believe how the thick layer of Tomato gets so sour like son of B.
I never threw left over pizza away to garbage can.
Never!

4th day, all those lousy edible triangular-sponges out of refrigerator to compost bin.
That's how bad the thing was.
No regret.
Glad to see that triangular-sponges in GARBAGE, and more room in refrigerator.

Ain't no thing but a chicken wing!

I love wings. I mean I loooooooooooooooooooove wings and am pretty much willing to toss aside whatever eating plan I am on to sloppily devour a pile of them at any time or hour of the day or night. Am I proud of this weakness? Hell yeah I am, a girl who can eat is a girl you wanna know.

SO last night while throwing back glass upon glass of vino at Bar 821, the ol' belly boasted about being starving. "Feed me!!!" Yeah, yeah, in a minute, I'm in the middle of being attacked by Yelp haters.

My friend then suggested Little Star and my belly and I were very happy at the idea of some pizza. The bartender then tossed us the menu and as we were looking at the pizza choices my eyes automatically drifted up toward Chicken Wings. Hell yeah!!

The guy sitting next to us at the bar said they were pretty phenomenal and seeing as how I have yet to really find wings that make me sing here in SF, I figured what the hell, let's give them a go. When they arrived, they smelled divine. Definitely on the garlicky side which i would normally steer away from, but last night was girl's night, so who cares, hehe.

As for the taste, holy cow! Or chicken I guess in this case. These wings are bomb! Not a typical "hot wing" or buffalo wing, but just a perfectly cooked and deliciously seasoned masterpiece for the mouth. YUM! I will definitely be getting them again and you should too!

I don't know why I hadn't been in here before. I think it was their sign outside; maybe I thought it was just a socialist meeting house or something? But anyway, now I know better. Not like I even need to review it. But I'll be the 1,567th person to give Little Star five stars, because it's wonderful.

I was very surprised by the size of the dining room. I expected smaller I guess. But it's deceiving from the street - you really can't see inside. Which is probably why I thought it was a secret society of some kind. And when I first walked in, I expected to feel like the least attractive, least hip person in the room (as I often do at places like this) but I was pleasantly surprised at the diversity. I even saw some blue collar folk. Fancy that.

The interior is seductive. Dark, design-y, neutral. And yet artsy. Which I dig. The wall art was painted on window panes (and if you know me you know about my fenestration fetish) so I took it as an omen (because I'm nuts) and decided that this might be my new favorite restaurant.

But actually, it might qualify in more substantial categories, too. Like the service. Our waiter was probably the best I've ever had, and that includes fancy downtown places. I don't know what his name was. I thought of asking him ("Excuse me, sir, could I get your name to post on the internet?") but decided against it. Anyway, you'll know him if you get him. Because he is AWESOME.

Speaking of awesome, they have Henry Weinhard's root beer, which pairs itself nicely with their fantastic pizza. It's deep and crispy in the right places and filled with everything you could possibly want and I'll be here twice a week for eternity, k thx. Also, I grew up eating Zachary's and I think this is better. Just to throw my hat into that ring, which will probably come back to haunt me and be a huge pain in my ass, but yes, I think Little Star is better than Zachary's.

But, we should not have gotten a large. Seriously, get a small for two people. I may never eat again. And I'm pretty good at eating.

I waited far too long to try Lil Star. I have always been a Patxi's fan but after getting stuffed with the Chicago style here on sunday I am a convert.  Its all in the cornmeal crust, which is just plain delicious.

Golden, crispy, buttery, crusty...its like crack.   It puts this Chicago style over the top.  I grew up outside of Chicago and had plenty of the world famous pizza but NONE of those spots had a crust like this.  I would order a side of crust if I could.  Plus the toppings come in a fantastic array topping combos.

I'm usually an experience-seeker.  When I go places I like to soak up everything and try my hardest to file my feelings at that moment into my memory.  I am leaving in a week for Germany to visit a friend and I have no plans - I am going there and I KNOW I will see historic ruins and museums, but I don't have an itinerary.  I usually like it that way.

That said, Yelp has made me an information-seeker.  I go places now and find myself dorking out in the corner being like "no she DIDN'T just roll her eyes when I asked about the nightly specials!!"  I'm constantly noting things that may or may not go in my reviews on Yelp.  Collecting factoids, if you will.  Point in case, my experience at Little Star Pizza.

I've heard from friends that Little Star made awesome pizza, and then I Yelped it.  It might just be the #1 yelped about spot in SF. . .there's an overwhelming yay response to the place.  Another friend of mine has said in (hers and others' opinion) that yelp in general is pretty hard on restaurant and bar reviews.  I kind of agree, it ain't hard to get three stars, but it's damn near impossible to get an overall 4.5 stars as an establishment.  Usually, when a place on yelp has a solid 4 stars or above, I just KNOW I'm gonna have a great meal/time.

However, my overall experience at Little Star felt like a field trip.

"Here I am, FINALLY made it to Little Star. . . now what makes this place so special. . ."

The food is wonderful of course, but I have to say it lacked that great pizza place atmosphere.  It's pizza, I just think it's one food that even if you are in San Francisco the place should be more comfy and homestyle, yo.  There's enough restaurants in SF that try uber-hipster or super she-she.  I wanted there to be maybe one TV, and great domestic beers served in red plastic cups for 4.5 yelpstars, I guess.

:shrug/sigh:

Pizza was delicious! Love the crust and super fast and friendly service. It's a tiny place, all bar stools seating. Definitely look for the hand pointing it's finger down and bam you found the Little Star Pizza

Can an East bay kid fall in love with Little Star?

I had dinner here this past weekend with the siblings, and because I had heard so much about it, I was pretty intrigued. However, my deep dish heart was already taken years ago by Zachary's.

It's easy to miss on Divisadero, so keep your eye out, but parking wasn't too bad. If you stay patient in the neighborhood behind LS, you'll be just fine.

My sister had a hankering for some wings, so we invited a plate of them to the table and they were delicious. Not your traditional wings dunked in a bath of lava, but more with a nice spice rub on them. The blue cheese dipping sauce gave it a nice bite, but I have to say a wings plate without celery sticks is a bit odd...

Moving onto the pie. We ordered a large 'Classic' ( Sausage, mushrooms, onions, green bells ) and it was fantastic. You never saw anything become extinct so fast.

What makes the pizzas here different than Zachary's is the crust. The cornmeal crust is simply amazing. Great crunch, a slight hint of flavor, but keeps the heavy pie in its place.

BUT, I still have to give it to Zachary's!

The filling at Zachary's is much more rich, heavy, and off course I'm grading on a slightly biased scale. However, Little Star is a hit. There's always room for pizza in my life, especially great pizza, and Little Star can claim the title of best deep dish IN San Francisco.

Not the bay...

It's always super busy so I've actually never eaten in, only ever done takeout, so I can't comment on a dine in experience. But food wise, it's pretty solid! I've only had the deep dish, and it's really filling. One small pizza was enough to fill me and 1 other friend. It was the perfect amount and prevented me from overeating :) we got the Classic with pepperoni substituting out the sausage. The cornmeal crust really stood out to me - it was super flavorful and really delicious with amazing texture. Not too hard, not too soft. I usually don't finish all my crust but I ate it all! The cheese, sauce, and toppings in the deep dish were all done well with good balance, though the bottom of the pizza does get a tad soggy.

Great place!  Just moved in down the street from this amazing pizza establishment.  If you like good pizza and are willing to pay alittle extra for it this is the spot for you.  The staff is extreemly friendly and the atmosphere is great.  I've ordered pasta here twice and it leaves something to be desired, but the pizza alone earns it 4 stars at least.

I have been to this place many times and every time, the food is great. The decor has the feel of an old country Italian Restaurant. The only downside is it is a bit pricey with items averaging $10-$20. The margarite pizza is very greasy, but by far my favorite thing on the menu.

The restaurant with the secret looking front door. Although the sign outside is quite large, the front door seems very unwelcoming. Don't let this door deceive you, because inside is a restaurant capable of fulfilling your deepest desire, rich and completely perfect pizza. Besides the crust being crispy to perfection, it is obvious that they drizzle on olive oil either before or after the baking process because every bite is filled with oily goodness. Your hands, your napkins, your plate, your shirt, and the tablecloth will be soaked with oil by the time you leave the restaurant. You just can't say no to that kind of dedication to creating deliciousness.

This place is solid!!! To be honest I haven't tried anything else but their pizzas.  I have wanted to try other menu items however their pizza keeps louring me back for more.  I like their pizza because it is extremely thin and light, and it is nice and salty.  I love that about this place.  I also love how they are so close to home, and when you call in for a to-go order, it is ready in no time.  Take the 38-Geary and it drops you off right in front.  I recommend this place for a nice casual inexpensive place to eat.
Good food, nice environment, great service, good prices, close to home :)

Gaspare's is more a solid 3 and a 1/2 but I'm rounding up today because the bars on the windows outside is super gansgta mafiaish. The pizza is good, although it does get kinda greasy/soggy in the middle.....but that's mostly because they put so much toppings, which you can't fault them for.

Had the mozzarella (FRESH!), basil, tomato salad: yummy! Fried Calamari: average and kinda dissapointed because they only gave a homemade tarter/aiolish sauce, no marinara. Steamed white wine clams: pretty yummi and great for bread dipping. Pizza with ground salami (wowza! tastes like corned beef =) ) and mushrooms.

Prices are resonable, beer is cold, and the owner serenaded us when he danced out with the pizza. Will come again.

Anyone at Gaspare's on Wednesday 3-25? What is going on at this place? If it were 6 months ago I would rate this place at least 4 stars but not now, no way. It seems that whenever we go here and there is a party of 15+on top of the regular crowd, the kitchen falls apart. This has happened the last three visits here. The pizza was like nothing I have ever seen or tasted on this day. Dry, stale, thrown together, left on the sidewalk and stepped on would describe it. Not completely sliced through so you had to tear it apart. Will go back again to hopefully prove myself wrong. I know this place can do better. Service was excellent.
Great atmosphere, but as far as the pizza goes, I'd say a little bit above average. Service is top-notch as well.

came here for valentines day=)
the wait time was ridiculous ! the boyfriend forgot to make reservations.. so thats not the restaurant at fault.
I had the ravioli ! it was delishhh!! &we had a salad too, also wonderful.
the atmosphere is really cute, really.. throwback. the service was helpful too ! id come back.

This place is unreliable!!!!! We made reservations for 12 people one week in advance only for them to call us 2 hours from our reservation time the night of to cancel! Apparently they had a reservation for a party of 30 an hour before our reservation time. Did they not think to tell us??? That is just shady. It doesn't matter if they have good or bad food at this point. They just suck. Don't bother making reservations with them.. apparently it doesn't mean a thing.

Great pizza, always space, good luck with parking.

Whenever we have a big group, there are NO worries here. They easily accommodate a bunch of groups at the same time.

Good tasting pizza, good thin crusts, really friendly staff, good for late night dinner and decent prices.

Parking is the only pull back.

We were only in town for a week and the food was good enough to take extended family and go back for a second meal.  Pizza and Veal Parmesan were really good and the pesto sauce was really good too.  Meatball sandwich was only ok.

AS GOOD AS IT GETS!!!   My family has been eating Pasquale's Pizza for over 50 years!!!  Love the FAMILY, pizza, pasta, sandwiches, salads and service!  They hand make their own Italian sausage...a must order!  They are one of the very few pizza makers left in SF that use the highest quality "old school" mozzarella cheese slices, not prepackaged shredded oil filled cheese out of a bag.  The weight of the box will prove the highest bang for the buck.  The dough is perfection...order it thin, original or thick ~  it's ALL good!  Ravioli's with meat sauce, Caesar salad and the BEST freshly baked "HOT out of the oven" sourdough bread with melted butter...DEELISH!  Need comfort food, look NO further!  There is NO other pizza place in San Francisco that can compare to this staple.  This is SAN FRANCISCO STYLE PIZZA, not NY nor Chicago...enough said!  XX

well pasqualie's pizza has been around since i can remember living in the sunset which is over 30+ years.  all i can say is the pizza is great & it continues to be so.  my family really enjoys their food which keeps us coming back.  

the decor really has not changed much since the 70's.  i remember much of the same decor, its abit dated but rustic at the same time.  there is booth & table seating, the restaurant is fairly good sized so there is typically no wait to get seated.  

they offer a fairly large variety of pizza & topping options to almost suit everyone.  the pizzas are fairly good sized, tasty, not overly cheesy nor is the crust too crisp or thick.  there is a good meat to cheese to crust ratio.  the waitstaff is pretty helpful, friendly & courteous.  the prices are reasonable & the pizza is great.  they accept cash & credit cards.

the street parking in the area is almost non existent.  best to get there kinda early to try to find street parking or just pay the 10.00 on 9th & irving (between irving & lincoln way) for the parking lot after 6 pm.   there are several muni stops in the area.  

delivery is pretty quick & fast, usually in about 30 minutes or less.

Their Mediterranean pizza is absolutely delicious...all the toppings tasted so fresh and the crust was at perfect consistency. Their antipasto salad with mortadella, salami, and mozzarella cheese was also fantastic. It was a HUGE salad for $10. Great service, great food.

i came here to pick up a personal pepperoni pizza for my brother one night because we were all having indian and i guess it just wasnt his cup of tea. haha. so we went down the street to the nearest pizza place, which so happened to be pasquale's.

i took a bite just to try it and yea.. it was pretty good, especially for being just pepperoni. i personally anything with mushrooms on my pizzas. =D

pasquale's definitely warrants a second try, so next time im in the neighborhood (and i most definitely will be! esp for HOLY GELATO!) i'll try some sort of mushroom pie.

Their Delivery is Faster than Superman on CRACK. :-D

This was tonights dinner:

Plain cheese Pizza for the BF, (and puppy) an order of Garlic Bread with Cheese, and Calamari for myself... SO GOOD.
THe Cheese pizza CRUST is crunchy, just how it should be. The Sauce- Not too much, not too little, JUST RIGHT. The Cheese is not overpowering the Pizza, FANFREAKINTASTIC!!!!
The Garlic bread w/cheese- standard, and not dripping with oil or butter ( winning!)
The Calamari- So, it melts in your mouth, its orgasmic. perfectly done.

This is where I go on my cheat days from now on....

I've been here for a sit down dinner and their Wine selection is pretty good as well. No long lines to sit down and eat, and quick delivery. Just great service all around!
PARKING CAN SUCK, sooo be aware of your surroundings, you may be around my people on Irving who don't know how to drive.( I swear its our little eyes and bad vision)

Out of all the Pizzeria's in San Francisco, this is my favorite GO TO for a nice mushroom only pizza.  Something about their sauce, not too tangy or sweet.  I grew up on this Pizza in high school and still come back 30 years later!  My youngest daughter loves it too and reminds me to get Pasquale's when in SF.  Latest price was $16.99 for a large mushroom, which went a long way!  Locations on Sloat and one on Irving (harder to park).
Great home made sausage, crispy crust. damn great any time. it is surprisingly good, probably the one of best in the city.  O and i like their meatballs too.

bad -- very bad.

this used to be my last minute, one-stop italian place in the hood.  located right around the corner from where i live, they even delivered -- no problemo.  yesterday however, the bf and i decided to order out.  we called and placed the order like we usually do.  when we got there, there wasn't a long queue.  when it was time for me to pay, they over charged me -- lame.  after having to explain myself to the owner, he gave in and fixed the bill.  this was not the worst.

when we got home and opened up our bag, my order was completely wrong.  we called, got hung up on -- TWICE.  the owner actually hung up on us... instead of him fixing the problem and having one of his goon's walk around the corner to exchange meals with us, he balked and hung up on us -- the customers.

if you want cheap Italian, this is an ok place to stop by last minute.  if you want somewhere to go where locality and loyalty play part in the service, stay away.

i will never go back.

Casual ambiance. Great to grab a bite with coworkers. I love the fact that service is fast without compromising quality. They have a nice front patio for a summer afternoon with sangria and you must order the burrata.

Tip: if you want to come to this place just take the Bart to Powell station because parking is a nightmare.

Enjoyed dining here on traditional Italian fare at lunch. It was packed! We got the burrata and hazelnut on crostini app, salad, and two pizzas (sausage and ham/artichoke) and ended up loving the one with artichoke though we usually go for meat lovers. Food was presentable and delicious. Wine was ok- wish there was more of a selection of bold reds. Service was good and attentive. Would def come back!

I love this location of Delarosa! So great for a work lunch or just a quick bite to escape the craziness of Soma/Downtown lunchtime chaos. They've added long benches and tables outside too to accommodate larger groups. I love the menu, I really think you can't go wrong if you're in a group setting! My team has come here twice for work lunches and we've all walked away happy and full. The starters are really practical and filling as well! Highlights include the burrata bruschetta, the kale & romaine caesar (and trust me, I dislike kale, but this is so yummy with the pecorino and croutons), the heirloom beet salad is delicious and yummy for beet lovers like myself, and the meatballs in spicy marinara also are a crowd pleaser. They come in two (can order three) and are served with a generous portion of sauce paired with crusty toasted bread for dipping - heaven!!

The pizzas are obviously the real highlight here, so let's give them the credit they deserve. First of all, I love that you can add burrata to any pizza, that is just a wonderful option more places should get in the habit of doing! But back to the menu, the margherita pizza with burrata, the spicy fennel sausage, the prosciutto di parma/mozzrella/arugula pizza (could have less arugula), and the funghi misti/fontina are all worth trying. Good luck deciding! I've also had the arancini which are nice and a side of the grilled steak which is simple and quite nice. This is the type of place that you want to keep coming back and trying everything on the menu, which I plan to do since there is a whole pasta and panini section that I've never explored.

All around, really delicious food that is great for sharing or for two people. The atmosphere is fun, inviting, and clean - the only thing I wish was a bit better would be the service. Other than that, absolutely worth checking out Delarosa if you're in the mood for Italian and pizza, which should be always, because come'on, it's the best! I've also just recently learned they now have happy hour from 4-6! Yay!

Came here on a weekday night around 6pm with a coworker. The food was good, but the atmosphere.....not so much.

We ordered:
1. Brussel sprouts
2. Meatballs
3. Burrata Margherita
4. Salad with Chicken

Before I even get into the food, I need to talk about the environment. Most of the seating at the restaurant is communal table seating, which would be ok, except that it got so loud because you were sitting so close to other people that I could barely hear myself talking or my dining companion speaking. That really ruined the whole vibe of the restaurant for me.

We both really enjoyed the brussel sprouts and the burrata margherita pizza. The meatballs were ok (came with 2 large meatballs and 2 slices of bread), and the salad that my coworker ordered was very bleh. She was forced to order a salad because she was on one of her diets and she only took about 2 bites of it.

The serve was very subpar. The only time you could get a hold of anybody was if they were bringing you food that you ordered. Other than that, good luck. They were clearly short staffed and that ruined the service for everybody in the restaurant. The poor family that sat next to us with a very fidgety and hungry 3 year old had the most miserable time trying to get hold of their waiter so that they could quickly eat and get out.

I think that I would come back if somebody in my party wanted cheaper Italian food that was near FiDi and didn't mind a more casual vibe.

I visited this location before the stay at home order in November and I got the spicy marinara, Calíbrese chilies, olives pizza and added Parmesan and burrata and it was SOOO good. Probably one of the most satisfying pizzas I've ever had in my life. The few downsides were the expensive drinks and slow service. He was nice, though. Also, the burrata cheese does not hold up in cold weather (only outdoor dining was being offered). It imitates an over easy egg texture when it gets cold which, personally, I do not want on my pizza. I was visiting from San Diego and overall I was happy and full at the end.

Wow- this place is DELICIOUS.

A small little spot hidden in the alleyway-esque right across the Contemporary Jewish Museum has got some incredible burrata cheese dishes (including one that I absolutely loved with nuts and honey) and a burrata-cheese pizza that descended straight from heaven above to land on our plates that night.

Came with a large group so got the chance to try a ton of dishes- the meatballs were actually just okay... they are grandma's recipe per the waiter, and I don't doubt that, but it ain't my grandma and it didn't appeal to me. That isn't to say everything else was not divine, which it was. The pizza was fantastic- crispy and definitely thin-crust and not filling but quite tasty which is my preference anyways.

We spent the afternoon wondering around San Francisco enjoying clam chowder, cocktails, all-time classic places like Tadich grill and Irish Bank.

Such a great way to celebrate ending a successful service year the last day of August: meandering around San Francisco on a sunny and slightly breezy late summer afternoon. Perfection!

We ended up six hours later at this place at this location. Fabulous! Only a 15 minute wait and well worth it. The kale Cesar salad is to die for! I think I'm going to order that just for myself next time. LOL

We ordered three different types of pizza, fabulous, Kale Caesar salad, mixed green salad, and the seafood risotto! Our group of I've shared everything and simply loved it! We even ordered a bottle of Chianti to share  and it was fabulous!

This is the closest I have felt to being in Italy since I've visited there years ago.

It's a must go place!

It does have communal seating, that's not for everybody, and yet can be super fun!

Oh no! I just realized I didn't take any pictures while we were there! I thought I did in those pictures evidently are only in my head! You just got to go here and enjoy!

I'm a burrata enthusiast. If I were to ever be on death row for slaying burrata then my last supper would be a margherita pizza! (With burrata, obviously.)
