All this to say, I would have no problem ordering the last meal of my life from Delarosa. My aforementioned favorite goes well with any of their seasonal salads. They have a great wine/beer/cocktail list and their servers and 'tenders are all wearing ubiquitously unique plaid hipster shirts. So you're in the hip spot yo. Pizza crust has game. And if you're feeling excessive then also get the burrata
crostini with honey and hazelnuts for an appy. RIP burrata.

We had lunch at Delarosa on a Sunday and it wasn't busy at all when we arrived at 12. We got seated immediately and had two great pizzas, the margarita with burgatta pizza, and the potato with *insert here other toppings* pizza. Both were great and I recommend both of them! The staff was great, and our group had a good time at Delarosa.

Don't really understand the "4 star" review.  We gave it a try based on the reviews, total disappointment.  We ordered 2 appetizers and 4 entrees.  We specifically made sure the waitress understood that there were appetizers before entrees.  Literally, the appetizers came out, then the entrees also came out within 5 minute.  Hello!!! We haven't even started on our appetizers yet.  When we told our waitress, she simply said that's how things are done here at the restaurant, "thing just comes out as it's ready".  NO...appetizers should come out first...then entree.  Totally ruined our experience.  The last time for us.

I have only had their pizza, so I can only comment on that. In my opinion, it is a little too greasy and salty for me. I do not like my pizzas overloaded with cheese and meat. Pizza should have a few simple ingredients; it should not be difficult to make or heavy to the touch. So, in my opinion, their pizza is a little too heavy to be considered good pizza. It was just mediocre for me, as the taste was nothing to write home about.

Being of the starving nature on a cool fall Thursday evening, I (we) needed food. And every place we had in mind, so did everyone else....hmmmm? And the last choice was closed after what seemed like walking in circles. We had already eaten around the world in our minds with ideas from our group on where to go on foot, when finally we just needed to land "somewhere". As we walked defeated in the fact that our first 3 choices had massively failed, We strolled by Tommaso's (and maybe had walked by already in our travels?) My friend says "you know I had lunch here the other day and the pasta and pizza was really wonderful"...okay I don't remember what explicative she used, but it was convincing.
We open the big door/no window front and you walk down a few steps as you enter into the restaurant.
Teaming with food, noise and smells of happiness....Yes let's do it!
They find us a table promptly and we start with the veggie antipasto (which my friend states she had and is excellent) and kudo's to her, the asparagus and green beans crisp and lightly covered in a vinaigrette. Really nice starter. I ordered the Pesto spinach cheese ravioli, rich and flavorful (and to take some home just couldn't finish them all) The pizza's on the other tables looked pretty darn good too. Oh and damn that bread! So fresh and delicious, choice of dipping oil or butter...ate too much of that with my meal.
Great dinner on a whim really since we had other idea's of where to go, happy we were accommodated so quickly since it was 8pm and HUNGRY!

Excellent food and service!

After reading about this restaurant from fellow Yelpers, I decided to try this place for a birthday dinner. We came in at about 6 PM on a Tuesday and there was a wait! I took this as a good sign!

Once we got seated, we ordered the calamari appetizer. It was cooked perfectly, but needed a bit of salt. However, it came with a large side of their delicious marinara sauce! One of the best around! There wasn't any left by the end. Then, we ordered the Spinach and Shaved Parma. Cheese pizza, with Proscuitto. Yum! They know how to make a pizza! Garlicy, cheesy, and perfectly cooked crust pizza. SO worth the calories! And, the prices we not too bad.

Finally, we enjoyed the Tiramisu. If you like Tiramisu, you are going to love Tommasos! They use Vanilla wafers instead of lady fingers which give a subtle vanilla flavor. Again, one of the best Tiramisus I've had.

Worth the wait!!

Another place I tried because of the pizza quest.  The pizza wasn't spectacular and it wasn't terrible.  The pizza was super cheesy and the vegetarian slice was tasty.  We arrived when they first opened so the place wasn't too crowded, but as our meal progressed, it became more and more difficult to hold a conversation.

It's unfortunate that they're not open during the lunch hour because I'd hit this place for a good lunch in the FiDi.

Who knew that me losing a vicious battle of my pizza place can beat up your pizza place would be such a delightful loser's prize?  

Aside from the fact that the woman working the door looked about as happy as the chicks working the stipper poles at the nearby clubs, this place was amazing!  The wines are all well priced and well selected and the veggie pizza was insane....

Also, the coo coo (WTF?) clams were super scrummy and I'm 99% sure they resulted in me being particularly garlicy today, sorry sir on the Muni, oh what? I'm standing on your foot? Sorry, go to Tommaso, feel wayyy better.

I haven't eaten here in over 5 years and I almost forgot how yummy this place is!!! Tommaso is a homey, authentic pizzeria located in the heart of North Beach. Although the wait is long, the pizza is definitely worth it! Just order a glass of vino and time will go by fast!

The pizza selection is very extensive, so it was really hard to decide what to order. Luckily, you can order half and half, so we decided to order half Italian sausage with mushrooms and half prosciutto and gorgonzola cheese. YUMMY! The crust was just the right portion, not too thin and not too doughy. The prosciutto pizza was a special, so that one was extra unique to my taste. I loved it.

This place is real Italian - they have anchovies on their pies - by request! The thin crust is crispy on the outside, soft on the inside. Yum! The lasagna just melts in the mouth. Don't forget to get a bottle of marinara sauce home!

The hospitality is amazing. Warm, friendly and accommodating, Tommaso's has a warm family atmosphere.

The wait can be excruciatingly long. For those troopers that are willing to wait, Tommaso's offers glasses of wine for those who wait - and nothing warms up the body more during those cool summer nights in the City!

First off, I'm no prude but hanging out in North Beach on a Friday night makes we want to run home and watch Toy Story 2 while nursing a nice, wholesome glass of warm milk.  It's this crazy den of debauchery where strippers, dudes with thick necks and middle-aged tourists collide in a maelstrom of noise, booze and boobies.

So after being hypnotized for 30 minutes while waiting for our table and standing across from a flashing neon naked lady sign, Tommaso was a very nice respite.  Sure, it's a bit hectic in there but the staff is friendly, the smell of baked cheese and garlic is in the air, and the quickly poured drinks warm the belly in a hurry.

(One tip: if you can't wait to get your drink on before get to your table, the host is happy to take your order and serve you beer and wine in the waiting area)

We ordered simple stuff, which is pretty much the deal here: green beans with lemon and olive oil, steamed asparagus with lemon and parmesan, and a large sausage and mushroom pizza.  They cheat a bit on the thin-crust pizza by piling on the cheese, but thats' OK; it's delicious.

Despite the crowds, our food came quickly and the waiter was attentive.  And while nothing about this place will blow you away, it's very comfortable and surprisingly fun.  Everyone around you is eating well and having a blast and you can't help but stuff yourself and smile.

Best pizza in SF if you ask me. Delicious, wood-ovened, thin-crusted, greatness. The pepperoni is my favorite. It's covered with little pepperonis that curl up nice and crispy. The meatball pizza is pretty awesome too.

I really like the staff, particularly the guy doing the greeting and seating, who also appears to be in charge of everything. I can't remember his name, but he's a very friendly and attentive older gentleman who makes the whole waiting experience very pleasant.

And you will be waiting. That's the only thing that can be sort of annoying -- they don't take reservations -- but if you go in with friends or a date and the right attitude and get to work on a bottle of wine while you're standing around, it's still a blast. And if you don't want to wait, you can call in ahead (or just show up) and order to-go. A pie only takes about 15 minutes or so.

There is really not much to say about Tommaso's that has not already been said (I say that but, really, I'm only guessing, because who has time to read all of these reviews?).  It is awesome and makes me happy, once again, that I do not live someplace like Danville where, I imagine, there is no Tomasso's.

That being said, here is something that perhaps no one else has said: last time I was in Tommaso's, I read about it the next day on the facebook.  Some crazy lady posted on my ex-bf's page that she had spent the entire night, in Tommaso's, giving me the evil eye.  High drama in North Beach!  Anyhow, the point is - had I recognized said crazy lady, and noticed that said crazy lady was giving me the "evil eye" (instead of just assuming her face had frozen like that at birth), and pointed out to the staff that I believed I was the victim of said crazy lady's said evil eye - I have no doubt the staff would have promptly asked her to leave, because Tommaso's is no place for the evil eye, my friends. No place at all.

Tommaso's!

Square slice focaccia pizza? Yes please!

I almost always end up here whenever I'm in the area. Even when I'm not in the area I seem to end up here. My go-to definitely has to be their garlic clam slice, plenty of clams, garlicky goodness, melted cheese, all on top of a fluffy focaccia with a crispy bottom. My boyfriend usually gets the pepperoni or sausage slice and we split a combo slice on top of that, super satisfying.

Unless you're coming here for late night drunchies, highly recommend coming in the afternoon if you don't want to wait in a long line as it gets pretty crowded at night.

Food: 5/5 Very large and thick slices (squares).

Combo -- scrumptious onion, bell pepper, pepperoni, and sausage on top of cheese and thick crust

Garlic Clam -- combination of garlic and clam yields an interesting, strange taste

Pepperoni -- friend said it was delicious

Ambience: 4.5/5 Place is popular so a bit crowded with long lines and narrow seating along bar stools next to the wall. Fascinating combination of graffiti and stickers from all over plaster all the walls, including the bathrooms.

Service: 4.5/5 Friendly staff behind the counter to take your order. One person took our order and then another took over, putting freshly heated pizza slices into a nice box for us. The second person got a bit confused with our order first, but promptly corrected it.

Value: 4.7/5 Definitely a cool experience for pizza in Little Italy! Not suitable for low-carb diets.

Honestly the pizza is good that's why I give it two stars. However the service is the worst! Blonde lady running the front is very rude. Came at a slow time and was rushed to order and she had a lot of attitude. Tries to be too quick with each customer and doesn't properly listen to your order. I ordered clam and garlic with two cheese slices but she got it completely wrong. Didn't even offer to switch it out when I came back to tell her. She just tried making me buy another slice when I already ordered 3. If she's working, will not come back to this location ever.
Tastes like a frozen pizza. The ingredients are higher quality than a frozen pizza but the taste is very lackluster. Also not a fan of the thicker crust
Great pizza place. Definitely should bring your friend and family to go try it. Hard to find parking though so prepare for that :)

If you ever wondered what it feels like to bite into a cloud of airy, crispy, cheesy, salty goodness, go to Golden Boy Pizza.

The Combo, The Clam, The Sausage, and The Pepperoni are all very delicious.

Expect a long line and bring cash.  The street is a little sketchy, and the beggars can be a bit aggressive, but it's worth it.  It's most likely that you've never had pizza like Golden Boy.

There's pizza and then there's pizza.  Golden Boy has been serving its delicious Sicilian style pizza at its Green St location in North Beach since 1978.  The line waiting is a testament to how good is the pizza.

The pizza is prepared on rectangular sheets and you can order per slice or sheet. There are six choices, cheese, pepperoni or sausage, combination, pesto veggie and clam and garlic.  You can eat in or take out your pizza.  They will put your pizza into the oven to make sure its piping hot when you get it.  Enjoy your pizza with their large selection of tap beers.  There's bar counter seating in front and along the wall in back.

Tried the combination and the clam and garlic.  Both were delicious, but I liked the uniqueness of the clams, garlic and pesto pizza.  The savory clams with the potent taste garlic.  Heaven!  But what makes the pizza so delicious is the focaccia bread crust that supports the toppings.  This focaccia is so light and airy than your typical focaccia.  

So glad that I finally was able to try Golden Boy's pizza and I was not disappointed. Will definitely be back.
The best damn pizza I've ever had in my whole life. Focaccia + sauce + cheese = pure bliss

$3.50 per slice. We ordered the clam pesto and the combo. Asked for the corner slices because crust is my favorite. Pizza didn't disappoint but be prepared to wait in the line that goes out the door and around the corner.
Awesome Sicilian pan pizza out a window from the side walk! Super friendly staff as well. Sausage & clam garlic were wonderful; crispy & hot!

I'm torn between a three and four star rating...and yes I would go back.  My reason for going back was that the service and food was good.  I was a cool atmosphere and I had a window seat....However, I'd like to have one more type of pizza before I go crazy and fall in love with the place....COME ON, YOU KNOW WHAT I MEAN!!!  JUST NEED ONE MORE PIECE!....ok, i'm going back because the piece that I got was good....COME ON, YOU KNOW WHAT I MEAN....

Bottom-line - Good pizza, good service, hip place, around a good neighborhood.

Best. Pizza. E V E R. Yes.

My husband is so picky with food but really enjoyed their tricolore salad (still talks about it in fact..)

There is usually a wait, but it is sooo worth it.

Delfina is my favorite pizza in the city. I love there this location is just steps away from my apartment so I never really have to wait for a seat because I just call it in to-go. My two favorites are the margarita and panna with sausage. The crust is always super thin and perfectly cooked. The sauce on the panna is tomato with a bit of cream, and it is incredible. I generally reserve Delfina for dinner on nights where I had a completely horrible day at work, it is some seriously amazing comfort food. If you are a pizza lover you definitely need to give Delfina a try.

I love Pizzeria Delfina!

This was my first time checking out the location in Pacific Heights, I usually go to the one in the Mission but I loved the atmosphere of this location.

It was definitely a shorter wait, they had a cute parklet outside the restaurant, and some tables you can have a drink at while you wait.

Ordered two beers, a mushroom pizza, olive appetizer and the meatballs. Everything was delicious!!

We came here around 6:30 on a Thursday night and waited about 20 minutes for a table. No other restaurants on Filmore street had a wait, so we figured that this was the best place around, and we were right! We ordered glasses of wine while we waited, which made the time go by. The turnover is really fast and they try to seat people as soon as possible.
Loved the hole-in-the-wall atmosphere and cozy feel of the restaurant. I wish that they served real bread instead of the breadsticks because we were starving, but I guess that doesn't coincide with authentic Italian cuisine. We ended up having to Google a bunch of words off the menu because we had no idea what the ingredients were. We finally decided on Pecorino Lucano for an appetizer and Salsiccia for our pizza. And YUM did we make great choices! I highly recommend both. The appetizer came with a lot of cheese and it was a great pairing with the fava beans. The pizza was cooked perfectly and had just enough spice. The sausage, bell peppers, and onions were a great flavor combination and I would definitely order it again. Perfect size for two people. The prices here are also reasonable. I didn't find anything to be overly expensive (for SF).
Next time I want to sit at the chef's bar and try the meatballs, fresh mozzarella, and prosciutto pizza.

Come early and grab a seat, because this place definitely gets more and more busy as the night goes on. Me and a couple friends decided to do a girls night, which consisted of shopping and then eating pizza here.

Anyways, the pizza is good, and crisp, and delicious, and everything you can imagine.

Came here for lunch the other day and while the food was good, I was a bit turned off by the brusque and haughty attitude I received from the lady manning the front desk.

Prosciutto and arugula pizza - Lots of arugula on this pie. It was almost like eating a separate salad!  But the best part was the crust. Nicely seasoned, crispy and thin. Very good.

Fries with eyes - Fried smelt was tasty but it was a rather small plate (~10 smelt maybe)

All in all, good food but lost a star due to bad attitude. Don't hate just b/c I'm asian.
Long lines again! (seems to be standard SF feature). Pizza was OK, meatballs were amazing. Cramped space; would prob be better for takeout. They do have outside seating but they are usually taken.
Amazing service, great atmosphere and delicious food. The speck pizza is perfection :)
Above-average pizza and fine service, but the restaurant is overcrowded and too loud.

Some of the best pizza I've had in this city so far.  Whether you're eating in or taking out, it's going to be a good experience. The restaurant it self isn't the prettiest or biggest place, but the service is good and the people are really nice.

Pretty good pizza.  If I was rating just the food I would give 4 stars, but rating the entire experience, only 3.  Had a friend visiting and got a recommendation for this place for pizza, as I rarely travel west of Van Ness.  First of all, the parking.  Dunno how people deal with it on a day to day.  Constant circling for 20 min resulted in a spot 2 blocks away.  Then when we arrived, it was an oven inside.  Sign says this place was in business since 1972 - so 40 years and you can't figure out the ventilation?  It honestly was over 85 degrees inside - very uncomfortable after a walk in a brisk 55 degree evening.  The beer selection was lacking - Peroni is no one's favorite.  The wings were good.  I liked them more than my buddy - he was put off by the smoke flavor, but I enjoyed them.  The pizza was very good, nice crust consistency and decent sauce - but another SF pizza joint that skimps on toppings.  One piece of pepperoni and one sausage nugget on each slice of pizza, and a light sprinkling of mushrooms throughout.  Mushrooms are cheap, dude - load up.  The service was ok, nice friendly girl, but it did take a while to get the check.  The price was average - 2 beers, a medium pizza, wings, tax and tip for $55.  So the pizza was good, but factoring in the parking and the heat - the experience was nothing special.  I would go again, but I wouldn't drive all the way out to the wild west to east here.

One of my favorite brunch places out of all the brunch places I've been to! Had the Salmon Benedict with crunchy potatoes cakes every single time. I love how their hollandaise sauce is really thick and isn't too runny.

What more could you ask for from a local business?

Fresh food
Quality products
Local and independent
Workers part of the ownership

Most of all, the pastries and pizza are outstanding!  I still prefer coffee from Beanery, but it's a great combination just a few steps away!

I LOVE this place. Everyday, they have something different. I definitely recommend the pizza, and the focaccia bread. They are made to perfection. They have all different kinds of breads, sweet pastries, etc.

Bring cash, or it's a $10 minimum with cards.  Overall, I definitely recommend this place :)

I was so surprised when I found this place and so upset that it took me so long in my life to know this place existed!

I came on a Sunday and the line was out the door but it moved quick. My bf and I were going to an outdoor concert later that day so we bought a few pastries to go and had a slice of their pizza.

Cheese bread thing they have there. AMAZING. Also had the artichoke pizza.. Really good! Destroyed that slice of pizza in seconds. We also had a few other pastries and they were good but those two stood out the most. Prices are pretty decent and definitely will be returning to try out the other stuff.

They have different items everyday so check out their specials. And if you're looking for healthy anything.. Yeah this isn't the place for you. Lol

Great breads and pizza. The service can use some improvement. Came yesterday and the tall man behind the counter dealt with the customers including me with such sarcastic remarks that they were offensive. For instance he called out to someone shouting, hey, (name of person) pick up your order now. Your pizza is getting cold. When I came up to order, I felt like I was being rushed and since I wasn't familiar with the types of pizza they sold and he asked impatiently how he could help me, I responded, I would like to order some slices or pizza and said this while I was looking at the menu trying to figure out how many and what type and he answered sarcastically, "some slices", I don't know what that means. A typical cashier would say "how many would you like?"  Then I asked what type of pizza they had that day and he just walked off without responding. Good thing the other cashier heard me and explained. Their food is good; customer service can use improvement or maybe with just the particular guy we had.

Their pizza reminds me very much of Gaspare's on Geary.  I don't know why?  Probably the sauce.  But I just remembered on the very first try here, I just thought to myself Gaspare's.  But that's not a bad thing.  Both of these "G" Pizza spots are two of the more fine pizza places I have been to in SF...

This is my favorite sit down pizza joint in the city. It has that old world red/white checkered table cloth with jugs of wine feeling. They serve the pizza on a when can only be called an elevated pizza serving dish because that's exactly what it is. Get yourself some cheap vino or a pitcher of root beer to go with that pie and salad. Good stuff. Fun for groups.

We walked into Giorgio's Pizzeria in complete ignorance. I had never heard of the place but we decided to go in since we had walked all the way down Geary on the way home and we were hungry. To our surprise the place was packed and the pizza came in a matter of moments. It was a thin, crisp crusted pie with all of the fixings and it was really good...but greasy. Go to Giorgio's if you're in the Richmond and you've walked too far to go to Bella or to Orgasmica.

Great pizza.  As an East Coast Pizza aficionado, I am usually disappointed by places in California claiming to be such.  This place, while not quite on a par with the New York (and New Haven, North End) places of my youth, comes pretty darn close!  And the staff was really friendly, especially with our young son, who proceeded to trash the place.  We'll be back!

I've been going to Giorgio's for over a decade now, so I've been around to see the highs and lows of their pizza making.  However, the one thing that has stayed consistently Earth shattering is their M. Calzone, a convection that sports mounds of meat, mushrooms, and enough garlic to kill Edward Cullen.  Guys, this dish is the real deal; you'll literally FEEL your waist go up a belt size.

I love their sourdough croissants. One of the only places in SF that I'll actually go out of my way to get this.

Also, their chocolate fudge cake (or salted) are to die for. Dense chocolate cake that isn't overload but definitely filling for a dessert. So make sure you save room after you try out some of their pizzas!!

Disclosure: Pizza offered changes daily and there is only one type a day. The day I went, it was an amazing garlic, spinach, tomato invention that made me feel like a vegetarian for the day - in a great way! Pizza slices are about $2.50 each and for the quality, I would say that it's wonderful!

I also opted for a "chocolate thing" which was a chocolate and bread pastry that tasted better than any other chocolate and bread combination I've had in a while. It was so simple, yet so fresh and good - I didn't know how I felt until I was still thinking about it the next day.

Arizmendi seems like an inner sunset treasure, and well-deserved it is. I can't wait to go back and be delightfully surprised with the pizza of the day and some baked goodies!

PS - $10 minimum for credit cards, so bring cash!

I am a natural-born carnivore. I love meat. I need meat. I devour meat.
I try to steer clear of Vegetarian/Vegan places - I like to know that I can get meat if I wan meat, even though I don't necessarily eat meat for every meal.

There are few similar places with similar concept around bay area - basically, single type of Vegetarian pizza sold, with menu posted online beforehand. Other than Arizmendi's, there are Cheeseboard (Berkeley) and Sliver (also in Berkeley)
Out of these 3 (which are basically the same thing), I'd like to rate Arizmendi #3. It is really good - and their pizza is absolutely wonderful. Just not as good as Cheeseboad or Sliver.
If you are in the neighborhood, it's pretty cheap meal (depending on how many slices you eat), and good food :)

This place probably doesn't need another review, but I have to say they make my favorite baguette in the city, their pecan roll for breakfast is a real treat to wake up to, and their pizza is better than at most pizza shops. Worthy of waiting in the line out the door that will inevitably be there.
Decent pizza, but a bit on the pricey side ($3/slice) given the size. I think a more fair price would be $2.50. The combination of toppings were ok but not great; could be the day I had visited.

I. LOVE. THIS. PIZZA.  Amazing flavor, haven't found anything like it in the city. Highly recommend getting sausage on your pizze - great flavor. Definitely better for a pick up or delivery, although the dining space isn't anything to look twice at, it does seat a lot of people.

O.K. here is a good way to judge a pizzeria that has pasta dishes too. Just order a simple plate of spaghetti with marinara sauce. If they get that right chances are good everything else will be good also. I come here a couple of times a week for there lunch menu which is pretty darn good. I highly recommend this place. Bonapetite.

Yeah I have to agree with T Bone that the decor is quite something.  I think my expectations were so high that the first time I was disappointed because our crust was burnt a bit.  The second time I recall also having a neutral reaction.  But three's a charm.  Go for the calzones, my friend.  Go for the calzones.  First of all, the small is filling for two people and the extra large is like a small house.  Second, it comes with an entire tray of pizza sauce you can dump or dunk into.  And lastly, the magic of ricotta takes pizza ingredients to the Nth dimension, the Q-zone, if you will.

My only stop for pizza whenever I visit Haight. If you're like me and you visit this street mostly for Amoeba's, you should grab a free small drink coupon before you get your grub on up (yes, as in an upward incline) the block.

Now, I haven't been to NY since I was a wee youngin' (and I remembered none of it), but I assume that metropolis has a shitload of small pizzerias like this one. Well, don't be a snob and compare it to NY pizza-- this pizza is damn good. The crust is not too soggy not too dry, but just right with a faint taste of sourdough (cause that's how we do things in the BAY! MAN UP, BITCHES!!!!) and a flavorful tomato sauce.  And I don't know if NY Pizza only comes with the usual ingredients (pepperoni, combination, sausage, etc.), but whenever I'm at Escape from NY I always get the potato pesto and garlic. Very San Franciscan of me, I know... but when do get to eat whole cloves of garlic and potato slices on  green pizza? That's right-- NEVER!!!!!!! Being the fatass that I am, I order two slices-- that and whatever else-- and use my free drink coupon or you can get bottle drinks like the organic juice brand in which the name escapes me, but it has a nice packaging.  When you get your slices, you can enjoy looking at the many concert posters from extinct concert venues (Martime Hall ring a bell?) and autographs of the many celebs that dropped by that fill the wall up to the ceiling.

I'm never disappointed whenever go to this place. And if you like pizza, then you won't either.

Seriously, we went to NY Pizza after a bad experience at another restaurant left us still hungry.  EFNY was just OK.  Although undoubtedly a favorite for the Haight crowd, it really didn't do much for us.  Sufficiently greasy with a six drip average after a solid napkin blot, the pepperoni was pretty good.  It could have been served hotter, but from the time we walked in to the time we finished eating at 10 minutes, I guess they didn't have much time to heat it.  I have no doubt that in a drunken state this might be construed as the best pizza ever.  For those of us who are sober - you might just want to pass.

The sad reality of living in NoPa is that the city's best pizza options are not within walking distance. Escape From NY Pizza is. We picked up a Medium 'You Say Potato' pizza, covered with a generous amount of unpeeled potato slices, roasted garlic cloves and pesto.  Despite the abundance of toppings, we found the pizza lacking any real flavour.  We accented our wheel with extra virgin olive oil, fresh grated parmesan, and drizzled lemon juice, and after this at-home customization our tastebuds were singing a different tune.  Without accessorizing, this was a slightly above average pizza with a dry, trash-bound crust.  EFNY is worth ordering...but only if your pizza fix can't be met with a trip to Tony's or Una.

I really like the fact that they are open so late and if you go there at night, parking is really easy. I also like the fact that they warm up your pizza when you buy it so it comes out nice and crispy. The pizza although tasty, isn't the best. Zachary's is so much better but given the convenience, it's a great place for a quick bite. Try the pesto cheese pizza, you won't be disappointed!

The potato garlic pesto pizza was awesome! This is what I am talking about!  Pizza like this is why I came to San Francisco to go to school! All the pizza's are great and it depends on your personal preference or mood.  GO to Amoeba and pick up their free drink coupon and get a free fountain drink with your pizza.  The pizza is cheap and makes you wonder if you are still in San Francisco paying top dollars for everything.

I love this place! The staff are friendly and polite, the service is quick, and the pizza is tasty-delicious.

I come here a few times a week, and I've never had a bad slice of pizza from this location.

It's not New York pizza, that's for sure.

The Potato slice, come on people. Potatoes on a pizza, not good.

The Hawaiian was great. Would definitely come back for it.

This was suppose to be THE place to goto for a decent slice of new york style pizza.  It was just ok.  The dough was too thick for a new style pizza.  The amount of cheese and sauce made up for the typical bland tasting dough of california pizza.  All in all I would stop by for a snack, but I would not go out of my way to get a slice of pizza from here.  It was good, but not out of this world good.

Sorry, it wasn't all that.  I got a slice of the pesto/potato pizza and a slice of regular cheese pizza.  Both were good but not amazing.  The worst part is that I totally got a stomachache afterwards and now, about 5 hours later I still feel too gross to eat anything.  Pizza is decent but I don't appreciate the subsequent loss of appetite. :\

If you have had pizza from anywhere in north beach, do not go here. You will inevitably be disappointed as I was. The crust was way to crunchy, flavor was so bland. But also I got pepperoni, maybe one of the more exotic flavors is better

Love, love, love!! Wonderful place for a cozy date night. Probably wouldn't want to come here with more than one person, though, or you might wait a while -- there's only a handful of tables in this intimate, neighborhood-y joint.

Nice selection of microbrews (thought not on tap, sadly). A little more pricey than the average (i.e., mediocre) pizza place, but the freshness and interesting flavor combos more than make up for it. We got a pizza with a fried egg on top, all Euro style, and a delicious calzone with goat cheese, among other things. Flourless chocolate cake for dessert, and I was a happy lady.

Friendly service, and the kitchen is right there, which is fun.

They change their menu all the time, so there's lots of incentive to go back regularly!

Love, love, love everything about this place!

My first experience was over a year and half ago. My current boyfriend and I had just started dating and he decided to order pizza and salad to go for our date. We picked it up, drove to his apartment, and sat on his roof watching the sunset over the pacific ocean (doesn't get much better than that!).

I cannot recall EXACTLY what we ordered, but the pizza had an egg on top of it. He raved about how good it would be and I was a bit hesitant because I've never had an over easy egg on pizza. We can just say...that now I am hooked! I remember biting into the homemade crust with the toppings on top and telling him how delicious it was. His response, "I know. That's why I wanted us to have it."

Since then him and I will often go back together or with his Mom. Each time we have a wonderful experience and we both love the atmosphere. Yes, it is small and quaint, but it is intimate and warm. I don't mind waiting for a table (it is well worth it).

Their menu changes, but they always seem to have a pizza with an egg on it (usually at the top of the menu). I highly recommend it to anyone. I love to break and the yolk and swirl its contents over the pizza and taste all the yummy richness in each bite.

I look forward to our next dinner date when we go back.

Been wanting to try this place for a while.  

The place is tiny, so waiting for a table is almost guaranteed.  The blankets they provide outside is a nice touch to keep you warm while waiting outside.  I love the cozy atmosphere and think it's worth the wait.

I ordered the Farm Egg, Prosciutto, Walnut and Arugula pizza - delicious!  Also tried a slice of the House Made Sausage, Broccoli Raab and Parmesan pizza, which was even better!  The cheese salad was also wonderful.  

The staff were great in general, very friendly.  They made a couple of mistakes, including one on our bill.   I don't blame them though, there seems to be too few of them, given how busy they are between the eat in and take out crowd.

Pizzetta 211 is always a fantastic place to eat. The staff couldn't be more amazing, they tend to your every need and will fix anything without question if you have a concern, not that we ever do!

Love Lauren! Super sweet chick and she makes the best pizza.

Dining in is worth the wait which sometimes can be long but try take out if youre crushed for time.

Best pizza in the city? Yup Id say so

There is TLC in the pizza served at Pizzetta 211.  The setting has a rustic overtone and the attitude is half French, half barista.  It's cozy.  Don't come in a hurry, but the food is something you should savor anyway.  You'll find yourself wanting to order "one of each" of the pizzas they've put on the menu for the day.  High quality, farm fresh ingredients cooked on thin crust and wood fired.

If they are serving beet salad, whether or not you are a fan of beets, you must order that while you wait for your pizza.

I love this little pizzetta shop.  If I lived here, in this neighborhood, I would go to Pizzetta 211 several times a week.

My husband and I had the pizza with anchovies and a cheese salad.  I was pleasantly surprised and very happy with the salad.  It was almost a cheese plate with greens that were tossed in light balsamic dressing.  A good amount of olives and some nuts also garnished the plate.  It was everything you could ask for in a salad.  In one word, it was a fancy salad and great with a glass of wine.

I hesitated to go back to Pizzetta for a few years because of the awful wait times.  But, a random rainy Saturday afternoon had me craving pizza, and we figured at 3pm it shouldn't be too hard to get a seat. So happy I went back! Not that the food was bad the first time I went, far from it, but it was better the second time around.
The farm egg pizza is incredible... the runny egg, greens... perfectly done crust... I want more. Now.
Their house made sausage is amazing as well. It has fennel seeds in it, and I don't even like fennel that much! But, I scarfed it down and wanted seconds.
We finished with a great blood orange tart.
I left full and happy and I definitely won't wait another year or two before I go back.

I like this place a lot. It is very, very small so go at an off time.

Pizzas with egg are the way to go. I've tried 4 pizzas and all were great except  their standard pepperoni pie, which is fine unless you're expecting a more traditional pepperoni pizza flavor.
Fantastic flavors, great service,  and nice quaint ambience.  Get the pizza with the egg and bacon. Amazing!
They know how to roast mushrooms and the pizzas are very good, they put actually roasted mushrooms on your pizza. The place is hiding behind the tree .

Great Pizza and great service!!!  It was amazing how quickly we got our food and it was fantastic!!! Even our Uber driver said we are going to have a great dinner!!

Thanks for the great experience!!!

Excellent!

I grew up eating wood-fired pizza exclusively and have always had a hard time finding that crisp/burnt taste in San Francisco. Well, the search is over, Il Casaro is it!

We were seated immediately and started off with prosciutto and fresh mozzarella. As soon as we took our first bite, we knew we'd found our new favorite pizza joint. The prosciutto was delicious and mozzarella so fresh and creamy I'm still thinking about it five days later.

Then came the true test. I ordered a sausage & anchovy pizza and could not have been happier. The crispness of the dough, the freshness of the toppings, delicious! My girlfriend called it the best pizza she's had in the States... And she's half Sicilian!

Great spot and I will definitely be back when my next wood-fire craving hits, most likely before the end of the month.

I'm from Italy and I've been living in the States for one year and a half. Needless to say, I really miss authentic Italian food out here and it's extremely hard to find good Italian restaurants. You'll not go wrong with Il Casaro though. I've been here three times now and it became my favorite pizza place in the Bay area. Since I crave pizza all the time I only got pizza there, but I can tell you it's exactly how we have it in Italy: light and delicious.

i also loved the fact that the staff is actually from Italy, and I got to talk with the waitress in Italian, which was pretty awesome and unexpected.

I'm honestly taking all my friends one by one to this restaurant because it's simply the best. The wait might be a little long during rush hours due to the limited seating, but the max I've ever waited was probably 30 minutes at 7pm on a Saturday night, which makes sense since every single restaurant in the city is packed at that time.

Go there!! You won't regret it!!

One of my favorite spots in San Francisco. It was one of the first restaurants that my fiancé and went to and the place where we got engaged. The whole staff went the extra mile to make everything special for us. This is our go-to spot for a wonderful dinner, social occasions, and our special moments.

This place came highly recommended by my Italian coworker, and it really hit the mark. Get ready for some truly authentic pizza, as close to the original dish as you'll get without flying to Naples. For the basics, get the Margarita or Buffalina pizza; The burrata is also unbelievable.

I loved this place!! From the interior to the service to the awesome food. The pizzas here are so good and it seems very authentic. My group and I ordered the Prosciutto, Diavolo, and Margherita. They were all very good. My personal favorite was the Diavolo!! We also tried the Carbonara pasta and it was also really delicious. Usually whenever I order carbonara pastas they are usually just super heavy and creamy, but this one was perfect. I'm already craving this place again. I highly recommend coming here!
Pizza napoletana in a wood burning oven. Fresh ingredients and Calabrian chilies on request. More authentic than Tony's. What more do you want.

Really enjoyed pizzas and salads we had here.  Pizza could have been cooked a few more seconds, but was still great. Ingredients were fresh and food comes very quickly.  Service was good. Try the spicy cauliflower for something unusual.  5 of us ate for around 90 bucks which is not bad in North Beach.

Pizza is the Best in San Francisco. Whenever I go to San Francisco I stop by for Last 5 years.
Saturday afternoon was first time I had Really Bad service. The wailer never offered us any drinks.
Was to busy outside and taking to staff.
I saw people walking out and table next to me had lots of questions. Wailer No help.
Please improve your service.
You Food is the Best

Best pizza in the Bay. Pizzas are made with fresh ingredients and gourmet cheeses.

Grab a seat at the bar to watch your pizza being made. They have a stone oven. The service is fast and the staff care a lot about the customers comfort and happiness.

Instead of squeezing us in at the bar - the host gave us a lot of room and said - it's not how many people we fit in here, it's how they enjoy themselves.  

Come here for amazing pizza and great service!
Fun jukebox, friendly service. Order the garlic bread to start and the deep dish!

If I had to try to come up with something negative to say about Little Star, it would have to be that my crust-anticipation can at times detract from my enjoyment of the rest of the pizza. It tastes so damn good that I find myself rushing through the toppings-covered parts just to get to the pure, unadulterated crust.

Toppings-wise they match deliciousness with Zachary's, but Little Star's crust utterly dominates their Berkeley nemesis.

Take note Zachary's, and do whatever you can to copy Little Star's crust style!

And oh yeah, I wouldn't even bother with the thin-crust here - this is a Chicago style pizza place, and they just can't hang in the thin department.

My sister's swimming teammates took us to Little Star Pizza. I am quite the pizza lover, so I was excited to hear of a Chicago Style pizzeria in SF.

This place has the BEST Chicago Style pizza in the SF Bay Area!!  Definitely better than Zachary's...in my opinion. OVERALL in the bay area, Little Star is #2 behind Rainbow Pizza.  (Overall Grade:  A)

We ordered a large "Classic" (combo) pizza. I've been to 3 pizzerias in Chicago and Little Star seems authentic. It was definitely deeeeeeep dish and had a great crust. It had a pretty good amount of toppings. The sauce was pretty good, but not nearly as good as Rainbow Pizza's. The sauce also had some tomatoes that I picked off. (I know, some of you like tomatoes.)

If you like or love pizza, then I recommend you try Little Star Pizza in San Francisco!

I've only been here twice and both times I've gotten the pesto chicken pizza and garlic bread. I am usually not a fan of thin crust pizzas because they get soggy. But here the thin crust pizzas are so crispy that you can hold up an entire slice without it falling apart. The garlic bread is excellent. They serve the sourdough bread with an entire bulb of roasted garlic so you can spread as much or as little garlic onto your bread as you'd like. I'd highly recommend getting it if you're into garlic.

The only downer about this place is the parking.

I had high hopes for this place but their pizzas are nowhere nearly as good as Patxi's.

First impression: What a cute place. Dimly lit restaurant, kind of small, and hey, look, a candle on every table. How romantic.

Second impression: Hmm, the menu is pretty straight forward. It's broken down into 4 sections: appetizers, deep-dish pizzas, thin-crust pizzas, and desserts. Mmm, oh yeah, I definitely want a deep-dish pizza. *******(My boyfriend took me here on a date because I've been ga-ga-ing about how I've never had deep-dish pizza before so we only ordered a deep-dish pizza to share for dinner. We decided on a large classic deep-dish ($24) and alas, the waiting game started.)

Third impression: Checked my cell phone for the time constantly. Damn, I'm hungry. Where's the pizza? Should we order some wings? No complimentary bread and olive oil? Aw phooey.

Fourth impression: *After 30 minutes* Yes! The pizza is here. *Take a bite* Uh...why is it lukewarm? Why is the cheese not melty? Ew.. cold tomato sauce. At least the crust is nice and crunchy.

Fifth impression: Well, that was just A-OK.

Thus far the best deep dish pizza I've had EVER -- and I've visited Chicago. Stopped by one Friday with a buddy of mine. Luckily we were quickly seated as a party of 2. There were other larger parties waiting, but they had a table for 2 readily available.

We ordered the Litte Star topped with Sausage. The sausage complimented the spinach and mushrooms quite nicely. The dough wasn't heavy. It was delicious! A small is more than enough for a party of 2.

I will definitely be back!

Eddo was right. The pizza God exists! (and lives on Divisadero, go figure!)
That cornmeal crust can stuff my face any day.
My only concern is their Large(st) size.
Two hungry homos had no problem going thru' this puppy all by themselves.
So if you're calling in and have a big party at your place, remember: Order a bit more than usual. Definitely not Mid-West size!

and what's up with no being open for lunch? or taking plastic cards?
I'd take a Little Star (tm) off, but this sh*t is too good to complain.

a big Mahalo to all of u who recommended!
~T

****Best Crust Evar!!!!****

The construction of food is something that gets overlooked so often.  Perhaps its because people don't usually tend to care about the small details in life.  A well planned day.  A perfect golf swing.  A perfectly timed joke.  

This pizza was probably the most well constructed piece of food I've eaten in a long time.  One gripe about most pizza is how it breaks apart when its picked up.  This pizza had none of those careless characteristics.  

Probably the best part of the pizza was that it was right before our kickball game and their was no crowd when we got there at 5.  We had the classic Deep which consisted of Sausage, mushrooms, green bell peppers and onions.  The tomato sauce was also on top, which was a change of pace, but the toppings....um...middlings were fresh.  

Again if you are a person who likes the well constructed things in life, then this is the place for pizza.

I don't know what is the deal w/ all the other 4 & 5 star ratings. I can only say satisfactory over all. I had better deep dish pizza else where although I am not a pizza aficionado. I don't like the crust so much, not with cornmeal. Also, i would prefer a bit more cheese. The sauce is not too bad; so, for the pizza. I would say 2 stars.

The salad was simple and good, but the chicken wings were just standard. Plus the modest interior but not the usual Italian cliche, I give an overall 3 stars.

I will have another try of the thin pizza. I hope that's what I am missing.

Last thing, it's very hard to find it at night. I drove by three times not seeing it. It's sign was dark and small. Maybe I was expecting the usual cliche for the sign like white, green, and red stripe awning says" Little Star Pizzeria," but, no. It is at the end of the strip and doesn't seem to have any more business, you know.  Should the management pay some attention to this ^_^, I don't know.

Anyway, you need to have its address to find it. It's at the conner of an unlikely place.

REVIEW IS FOR TAKEOUT ONLY.

Now the "just okay" 3 stars could be the fact that I waited 30 minutes to actually eat the pizza because of the long drive home.  But it's also because they messed up on one of our pizzas.  They gave us a thin crust instead of a deep dish and I really wanted to try the deep!  The take out counter people were very friendly and the wait for our pizza was only 20 minutes!

Mediterranean Chicken - chicken breast, artichoke hearts, red bell peppers, green olives, onions, feta.  Very good!  All ingredients went well together and didn't overpower each other (I was worried about the olives because they were cut bigger than normal, the artichoke hearts which can be tart & the feta which is just strong in general).  I couldn't taste the feta distinctively in any bite so they must incorporate it throughout the sauce.  Overall, a very unique pizza and delight to eat.

Pesto Chicken - pesto, roasted chicken, mushrooms, onions.  This was okay.  The pesto is very lightly distributed on the pizza.  Tasted generic.

Spicy Chicken Wings - pound of wings served with baby carrots and blue cheese dressing.  Chicken wasn't very spicy.  They give you 5 pieces of baby carrots.  Nothing special.

Don't get me wrong.  I definitely want to come back for a dine-in visit and see what the pizza is like... deep dish and FRESH.

**Note: They only take cash but there's an ATM machine instead with a transaction fee of only $.25!!  Amazing.

The experience at Gaspare's was an interesting one.  I had called a week ahead to make reservations for an early family dinner (a party of six) in order to avoid having to wait, just in case, knowing that I would have a toddler that evening.  I chose this place based on Yelp's ratings, and reviewers comments as I thought that this place would suit a warm/family style dinner.  

Minus:  
1. When we first got there, there was no host.  A waiter came over and I told him that I had made a reservation.  He seemed surprised, and went to the back of the restaurant to "check" with other colleagues.  Subsequently, they pushed two tables together and gathered utensils to set up our table.  Hmm...
2. Once seated, we were left there without menu for a few minutes until we inquired it from idle waiters.  

Plus (kicked in, as the evening progressed):
1.  Once the waiter came over to take our orders, he was really attentive, patient and helpful as he came over twice to refill our glasses, asked twice to check on us and asked if we needed anything else .
2. The owner, Gaspare, came over to our table to welcome us and made sure that we had a pleasant evening.  He even managed to get a smile from my little boy!
3.  The food not excellent but good.  Good and even better with the reasonable prices and generous portions.  We started dinner with two appetizers to share - the antipasti plate and fried calamari.  They were good and homey.  My husband and I ordered pizzas.  We both enjoyed the thin crust and very tasty toppings especially "Bruce's Special".  We were both surprised to see how large the small 12" pizzas were at the price of $12.50/$13.  The rest of my family had pastas and a veal dish.  The Fettucine Alfredo my father ordered was rich, tasty and pretty heavy.  The spaghetti, Italian sausage bolognese my brother chose was nothing special, taste was pretty standard.  Just lots of pasta with sauce and a big Italian sausage slabbed on top.  However the veal with mushrooms my mother ate was generously garnished with vegetables.  The meat was quite tender too.  The dish was a little under seasoned, and just needed to a bit more salt, which was not a problem.  
4.  To end the evening, Gaspare made sure to say goodbye to us on our way out.  

Overall: Despite the poor start, we experienced good service, good food, warm and friendly atmosphere, and reasonable bill.

Sitting at Gaspare's feels like a big warm hug from your favorite grandpa. Neon signage, brick walls, fake grapevine and chianti-bottle ceilings. Olive-green vinyl booths with personal jukeboxes containing Mario Lanza and Lionel Richie tunes. Checkered tablecloths. Pink ladies' room. Vintage restaurant-length murals of 1950s San Francisco (my fave is the Chinatown one!) - and delicious Italian-American pizza and pasta dishes to top it all off. The garlicky dressing on their special salad is my favorite. Always busy for dinner, especially on weekends and cold foggy nights in the Richmond. Lots of big groups at the center tables, convivial and loud. Gaspare's has the real-deal charm and pride of family ownership that chains like Buca di Beppo only dream about.

I've been going to this place ever since I was a kid, when it used to be called Vince's.  When my parents first moved to San Francisco this was their first taste of pizza. Gaspare's has now become a family favorite and we go there whenever we want good, quality pizza. The décor is the same from when I was a child. The place never changed and that's what we love about it.  It has that old charm feel to it that reminds me of my childhood. Vince, the original owner sold the restaurant to one of his employees, Gaspare, so the recipes have remained the same. We always get the Bruce's special which is a pizza topped with sausage, salami, mushrooms and garlic. Their sausage is so good, unlike any other pizzeria's.   I've recently discovered how yummy and fluffy their meatballs are too.  This is surely a place you want to try!

Tried the Bruce Special, it has become my new favorite. It's oily, garlicy, and good amount of meat. Combo fantastico is a Supreme pizza with everything on it. it was good but missing a explosion of flavor like Bruce Special garlic pizza. The regular crust is baked just right, not too hard, not too chewy, it's like good bread.
Absolutely wonderful food!!!  Pleasantly delighted with the "homey" atmosphere and delicious grub. We had marg pizza, spag n balls, & veal parm. All fantastic!

This place has the best authentic thin crust pizza in town. The red and white checker table clothes + mini jukeboxes at each table make this a different experience -- its not fancy or pretentious. Its best to order a pitcher of beer, the house salad and two pizzas, one to eat at the restaurant and the other to take home to your jealous friends. You might not want to go here all the time, but its perfect for when you really feel like good, greasy pizza.

I love this place! I lived in the neighborhood for many years and would frequently dine here on nights when we were too tired to cook. I recently got married and my mom insisted on paying for our rehearsal dinner. I wanted to pick some place reasonable as she was paying and I thought, what better restaurant than Gaspare's?! Everyone here is great! The owner, who we've met several times before, is such a nice guy. The food and wine are very reasonable and my entire party was full and content at meal's end. We did however save room for the amazing cheesecake that the owner's wife makes herself. Lactose intolerance be damned! My mom asked the owner if he had already added gratuity to our bill and he said typically he would, but since my husband and I are good customers, he didn't feel he needed to in advance! Now that's a neighborhood restaurant with old fashioned values and appreciation for their loyal customers. Bravo Gaspare's!
Great food, great atmosphere! Been coming here for 15 yrs!  Only thing I don't like is no liquor like the Marin location, Gaspare get a liquor license please!  I like to get to drinking with dinner.

I lived in the richmond for almost 2 years and always went by this restaurant on the bus, but never stopped in until my last night living out in the avenues.  The sign outside is dated but prominent, and my roommate and I decided to give it a go.  It's a bit awkward when you first go in: the "waiting area" is RIGHT as you walk in the door, and is maybe a 4x4 foot square, which can get crowded.  We waited maybe 20 minutes to get seated on a Friday night, and it was worth it.  The service was great, the ambiance has a really home-like feel to it, and Gaspare himself came out to see how our food was and have some friendly conversation with us.  I loved the atmosphere: really cute and welcoming, little juke boxes at the table, and light up grapes that wove their way around the interior.  The pizza was decent.  Not the best that I have ever had....but because of the service and charm, I would be willing to try it again.
I love this place.  Great food, great service, great atmosphere.  Very old school Italian Restaurant that are more common on the East Coast.  Enjoy!

WE WERE DENIED SERVICE BECAUSE WE JUST WANTED TO HAVE DRINKS! (Saturday April 2, 2011) The hostess, who was standing right by our table (place is so crammed and loud), saw that I gestured to the busser to please not place dinner plates and she leaped at us and said we couldn't have a table if we wouldn't eat dinner. "People are waiting for a dinner table!" A couple of things to mention: (1) It was after 10:30p.m.; (2) the table looked more like a communal bar area which didn't really leave space for dinner entrees and pizza.

We had gone to Delarosa around 9pm and they said it was a 1 1/2 hour wait, so we walked around the corner to PARMAS (which was delicious and no wait.) We figured we would eat at PARMAS, and then go to Delarosas for drinks. There was 4 of us, and we easily, EASILY, would have spent over $200 in drinks alone. We had spent over $200 at the Irish sports bar around the corner the night before, which was surprisingly fun. Would you deny service to people if they said they would only eat dinner and not get $10 alcoholic drinks?  I had never heard of a place doing this?  I understand minimums, but this really made no sense.  

I was disappointed because I had read great reviews about the monarch and wanted to try the "salty dog". PARMA only has wine and beer, so we wanted to get hammered on hard liquor. Too bad for us. It ruined our night. We went to another bar, but we were bitter about this experience.

I normally don't write any negative reviews, but the way we were treated, I needed to warn people.

Being a big fan of Beretta, I had huge hopes and expectations for Delarosa!  Thankfully, they came through, and I really couldn't have been happier.  

I got the meatballs w/ spicy marinara, my friend the pappardelle
napoletana, and we shared the prosciutto/arugula/mozzarella pizza.  Sitting at the community table, we were swayed by those around us and the gorgeous food coming out. So glad we copy-catted...everything was tasty and flavorful and felt...hearty.  

Our one misstep was dessert.  We had the coppa siciliana w/ the limoncello.  The alcohol was so overpowering that the rest was almost inedible.  

It was, of course, a cluster there...on a Tuesday night no less...because it was warm and the Marina-types were out in full force.  Minus 1 star just for being in the Marina.  :)

The place is tiny and they don't take resi's, so be prepared to wait a bit.

Fantastic! Love their pizza (thin crust and not oily) and they make great drinks.
Nothing else to say! ;-)

Finally made it in to Beretta's sister spot and wasn't dissapointed. Came here on a Tuesday for a casual birthday dinner, called ahead to be placed on their 45 minute wait list - very handy!

First I love the relaxed decor and communal vibe. I started off with some wine and I wasn't sure what kind of red I was feeling. Our server was super helpful and gave me a small taste of a few so I could decide. I went with the Norello, and it was a great choice!

We started with the Eggplant caponatina with burrata. It was kind of alike a roasted vegetable salad (without greens). primarily eggplant but also some tomatoes and green olives which gave it a nice kick. Then the creamy burrata just adds extra deliciouness. Then we got the Dungeness crab arancini. They were like yummy little crab cake balls with an italian twist. For our pizza we got the Hot salami, coppa, tomato, diavolicchio. I also added burrata to our pizza (can you tell I LOVE burrata?!). First I love the diavolicchio (hot oil) - combind with the meats made it nice and spicy without being overly hot, but then adding the burrata added a creamy component to balance out the spicy. Great addition and totally doing it again.

For dessert we shared Coppa Mela (Vanilla gelato, scoop of apple pie, crème anglaise, spiced caramel sauce). It was good, probably the least amazing thing but still a really good sunday.

and to top it off, prices are totally reasonable. All our food plus 3 glasses of wine and 2 beers for about $90. Great spot!

Better be in the mood for communal tables...

They do an amazing job with their menu. I've been changing up my selection every time I come here. Everything that I've tried I've been very impressed with.

I highly recommend trying the brunch menu.

The team behind Beretta, Starbelly and now Delarosa is as consistent as a Tim Lincecum start... Win!!

The food as usual is a homerun.

Pizzas... good.
Meatballs in spicy marinara... good.

Beer steamed mussels
Polenta bastoncini, gorgonzola dolce.
Mixed greens and verdure salad topped with: Grilled beef...
all good!

Delarosa is like Lincecum's bad game... You struggle a bit... it is not your best effort... but you still put out a winning effort at the end.

The food is an allstar effort.
But I did not like the cramp cafeteria like layout of the restaurant.

But if you're around the area... do stop by!

Otherwise, Delarosa, Starbelly and Beratta as my 1-2-3.
Beratta is 3rd because it is my best hitter and Delarosa first to get the rally started.

I stopped by here a couple of Monday's ago with my fiance and her parents for lunch.  We were walking down Chestnut looking for a good place to eat whenever this place became an option.  We looked at the menu outside before starting down the street again only to have a change of mind a couple of steps later and head back to here.  The inside of this restaurant was pretty trendy with the dining area containing a number of tables and it being reminiscient of a beer hall with a large number of tastefully exposed hanging light bulbs over the communal tables.  The exposed areas of the kitchen mostly showed stainless steel while the bar area had a huge bar and back display for the liquor with a cool set of lighting above the bar.

For my lunch entree here I decided to go with the garganelli which consisted of garganelli pasta with porcini, pancetta and sage while my fiance ended up going with the roasted  turkey,  squash,  cranberry and gruyere panini.  The food must go out to the tables as it comes up as my fiances dad and I were the first two people to be served, followed a couple of minutes later by my fiances meal and then last but not least my fiance's mother was served 5 minutes or more after I was.  The lunch portion sizes here ended up being quite large and so my fiance gave me half of her panini which ended up being pretty good.  I am not so sure that I would have ordered it myself, especially with the squash but it ended up being pureed and was almost like a sauce for the sandwich which was unique.  My pasta started out tasting pretty good with the pancetta being my favorite part but by the end I thought it was a bit too salty.

The bottom line for me is that I would head back here again in the future.  Most of the food that I had here was good and I think that I may have chosen poorly for my meal since every other table seemed to have a pizza on it and so I would certainly like to try it.

10/10! I recently moved to San Francisco and had an awesome experience at Delarosa. My friends and I ordered the brussels sprouts and burrata pizza... Out of this world delicious. Seriously. In addition to the crazy tasty food though, the vibes of Delarosa were just awesome. Our server was patient and personable, and we really enjoyed the communal seating! Can't wait to go back.

I don't like having to wait 3 hours for dinner, especially when I'm being told the ENTIRE time that it will be another 15, another 20, another 15...

I am incredibly patient though.  It's part of why I'm good at my job, and it also means I can and will sit outside a restaurant for hours waiting for what I hear is delicious food.  

After finally being seated, our party huddled together at our spot on the communal table so that we could, if we used our outside voices, hear one another.  It's loud inside (to be expected, but always a bit of a pain).

We started with the Brussel sprouts, which I thought were amazing.  How do you deep fry something and leave no greasy aftertaste?  I'd love to know their secret.  We moved onto the winter salad, also a win, and the scallops.  The scallops were also very tasty.  So far so good (really good actually).  The three stars at the top of my review are for these three dishes.

No stars for the pizza, which was nothing special and very oily.  A disappointing end to a meal, that I'm now not sure was worth the wait.

Absolutely delicious!

This is definitely one of my favorite pizza places in SF (prob in 2nd place, overall) which is pretty good considering all the awesome choices we have in the city.

What my friend and I ordered:
verdure crude salade (carrots/turnips/beets/etc shredded for $8- large)- skip it if you're craving a real salad since this is just stringed veggies.
meatball in spicy marinara ($8)- exactly how it's described but superb flavors and definitely one of the best meatballs i've ever had at a restaurant. the marina sauce was delicious too so save it if you wanna dip your pizza crust in it.
broccolini, pancetta, tomato, and mozarella ($14)- perfect pie with the amount of dough to topping ratio for a thin-crust pizza. you could taste each ingredient as a whole! yum. i def plan to go back to try all the other options

Pros:
+ seated right away on a Wednesday evening at 7pm ( I think we got lucky since many parties right after us had to wait)
+ lots of pizza choices and they're DELICIOUS!

Cons:
- parking is awful in the neighborhood so either walk or carpool here
- loud environment- ~90% of the seating available are on these long communal tables so you may be sandwiched between strangers and find yourself tilted forward to hear your companion. Definitely not the ideal arrangement for claustrophobics

Their pizza is consistently good, which I can not say for other pizza places in San Francisco.  Even though other pizzas may periodically be better than Pasquales, they have always disappointed me when I've gone back, which Pasquales never has done. Now they have an awesome mosaic Jester eating a slice near the entrance of their building. Adding art to our neighborhood is worth at least two stars!
been way too long since I've had Pizza there. I recommend the home made sausages on their pizzas.

This review is not for the restaurant decor. The service was prompt. This review is for the delicious food. My college friends and I would come here for the combination pizza, delicious. Before I came to Pasquales, I had never eaten veal scallopini or veal cacciatore, or linguine with clams and red sauce. I love their linguine.

I have 3 pre-requisites:

1.A regular pie should NEVER be over $20--think about it, how much does flour, water, sauce, cheese, and 1 probably underpaid kitchen worker cost?  Not $20.

2.There should be some grease. No fat cheese is not cheese, it's crap. Cheese should never have the consistency of plastic.

3.The crust should be even just a little crispy.

This place meets all the pre-req's.   There's nothing worse than paying more than $20 for a crappy pie.

I work at UCSF and not only do order frequently from Pasquale's, so do a lot of my friends.  Last night I ordered two nights worth of food.  When I opened my order for tonight's dinner, I had been given shrimp (that stinks), instead of the steak salad, I had ordered.  I called them tonight.  I even said I would order some more wings if they would make good on my salad.  I was told that there was nothing they could do tonight, and to call at 3 tomorrow afternoon.  I explained, I am hungry now, and I would be 50 miles away, home and in bed at that time, and again was told to call at 3 tomorrow afternoon.  Suffice it to say, I won't ever be calling them again.

Do not eat here!!!! This is not what pizza is supposed to taste like. I can honestly say this is the worst pizza I have ever eaten, I would rather eat frozen Costo pizza. We have had this pizza a few times, we had it after a few drinks and remember that it was not good, but thought we would try it again while sober...NOPE, still not good!! All the toppings were tossed in the middle of the pizza and it wasn't cooked. And whats with the hand tossed dough out here, doesn't anyone know how to roll a proper pizza. All and all this place was the worst I've ever had, do not eat here...ever..drunk or sober! Now Patxis is where it's at for real pizza!!

Having patronized this place for over 5 years, I'm finally done.  Recently, their drivers are so dumb they've failed to deliver my food twice in a row!  Both times, they've had BS excuses like my phone didn't work, and they actually coped an attitude when I refused to tip them when it took two attempts to get my food.

Life is too short to pay inept people to make you wait.

The place has been around for as long as I can remember so they must be doing something right. Not the best pizza in San Francisco but hey, variety is the spice of life. I think it is cool they are still there after all these years. =)

My husband and I like the pizza here. This place makes good pizza. However, there's a middle age Russian delivery guy who always seems upset about coming to the lower Sunset. Several times he asked me why don't I order from their location on Sloat. I tell him I don't like their pizza. He gets mad and claims its the same pizza. I tell him it's not and he wants to argue about it.. Dude needs to talk to his boss and not me. Good pizza and punk ass delivery guy!!!!!!!!

I came here last winter with a friend who had been raving about this place. Needless to say, I was not super impressed.

We ordered the House Special pizza and some penne pasta dish. The prices were decent and the portions were huge. However, the quality was pretty typical, nothing that stood out.

I love that they have different styles of pizzas and vegan cheese. I really wanted to go to the other pizzeria named after the neighborhood, but they didn't have the vegan cheese which my wife and kids need. This was a great surprise and just as good, if not etter.

I visited Tony's Pizza for the first time yesterday! I've wanted to try it for a while but I don't live close by and it's always so crowded. During this time, they are doing delivery and takeout. My husband and I ordered a classic pepperoni and added some additional toppings. I love that you can really customize your pizza. There are tons of options and you can easily add toppings to one half as well. The pizza was great! My only issue is: we ordered our pizza and our confirmation said it would take 35 minutes. We arrived exactly 35 minutes later and our pizza had clearly been ready for a while. I did have to include my phone number and email when I placed my order. I wish they would have notified me when our order was ready because our pizza was lukewarm (and we ate it right away). Although it had a great flavor, it would have been so much better pipping hot!

Margherita pizza is all about execution. Simple ingredients, prepared well and combined meticulously. (kind of like burritos or donuts...different discussions). On quality alone, Tony's knocks it out of the park. The San Marzano tomato sauce, in particular, stood out for its floral taste (fresh, not too sweet), and the mozzarella was also very fresh. The dough was appropriately thin, yet retained its structure. My challenge is the cost. At $25, it is simply unacceptable. Tony's reputation is well known, and they are admired by tourists and locals alike. However, I cannot in good conscience give them a high rating when they are so very clearly milking it. Why do I say this? Two reasons, primarily: 1) at the end of the day, it's pizza. We're not talking some far-off delicacy where ingredients are hard to come by or we've entered into Michelin star presentation. There is a ceiling to how much you can reasonably charge for pizza. And 2) perhaps more controversial, there are other options for equally well-executed Margherita pizza in SF, at substantially less cost (like, at least $10 less). One, in fact, not so far from Tony's. So it pains me to write this, because the pizza was very good, but unfortunately the value so very overtly misses the mark.

I've heard rave reviews about Tony's and finally had a chance to try! We ordered the margherita and the New Yorker which are both prize-winning pizzas. Unfortunately the margherita was soggy and almost fell apart in our hands. I've had thin crust pizzas at other places that aren't wet on the bottom, so I wasn't expecting that. The New Yorker had great meats, I really liked the pepperoni and sausage. I'd recommend this one for meat lovers.

Each pizza feeds about 2 people and costs at least $30, so it's not exactly a cheap bite. Sadly Tony's doesn't compare to the pizza I had in New York, so I'll keep looking for my go-to here.

Always enjoy eating Tony's! Both times had the same server (blonde and tall) sorry, I can't remember her name but she is so sweet and attentive! The detroit pizza is super saucy and thick and cheesy, and the Spicy Bucatini is to die to. It's $28, which is more than I would usually be comfortable with, but the portion is absolutely ginormous and it's completely worth it for the quality of the spicy sausage and will completely fill your belly. A must try!

The food was delicious. The margherita is ridiculously good. Service was great. Fast and professional. Really enjoyed the experience.

Feedback: waiter/waitresses pick the straws with their bare hands as we're coming out of a pandemic. They pick them up towards the tip of the straw. The straws are in an open glass towards the end of the bar. Consider using individually protected straws or find a different solution that could prevent them from being touched by someone.

This is something somewhat niche: restaurant offers high chairs for toddlers however the bathroom doesn't have a changing table. Confirmed with our very friendly waiter. Would be adding a foldable changing table possible?

Will definitely go again, not using the straws and hopefully, this time, my kid won't have an accident :)

It's incredible - you don't really need another person to say it. All I want to emphasize is that they cap the number of margarita pizzas by day. It's truly one of the best things I've ever had - I'd go early just to get it.

I went there today probably for the fourth time all the way from Cupertino. Because they serve good pizza.

But today I was totally disappointed. I ordered one margherita pizza and one Don Giovanni pizza over the phone after I reached the restaurant and found a parking spot. I Parked my car one and half block away and walked to the place. Maximum five minutes of walk time.

I paid and waited for my pizza, It was given to me after 5 minutes of wait. Then I walked back to the car to discover my margherita pizza was COLD. Other one was okay.

If I wanted a cold pizza I would get a DiGaiorno from local Safeway.

Takeout order #71 around 1 pm for reference.

I've heard nothing but amazing things about Tony's and it didn't disappoint! We joined the waitlist through Yelp before we left our apartment to make sure we got a spot, and it was really easy and convenient. After checking in, we were seated within 5 mins!

My main complaint was that it was a little hard to know what kind of pizza you were ordering. The menu had a ton of different styles of pizza, which is great, but no explanations--which worked in our favor for the Sicilian pizza, but made it hard to order.

The cheesy garlic bread was a perfect start to the meal, and the fresh roasted garlic made it stand out from normal garlic bread.

We ordered the classic Margherita (Napoletana) which has a limited # made per day--it was a world pizza cup winner in Naples, Italy! It was tasty, but surprisingly not my favorite and thought it was overpriced.

My favorite pizza was the "Drunken Sicilian" which came out in a HUGE pan, and the crust was made with focaccia bread. SO delicious and also very filling. Plenty to take home for leftovers! Expensive, but you get your money's worth here.

We have been coming to Tonys for several years now. We were there on April 23rd. We ordered a order of three meatballs,lasagna, caesar salad and my favorite the Margherita pizza. Along with a bottle of wine and couple beers. We sat at bar and it was fairly busy. Took a little bit for pizza and lasagna which was ok. Margherita usually cooks fast though. We got pizza and lasagna. We knew we should have complained but didnt. The lasagna and pizza was not even hot at all.  We will wait to go next visit. Hopefully it wont happen again. Prices are not cheap to be served cold food.

Ever since discovering this place a year  and half ago, I have become a big fan of this pizza joint. I love thin crust pizza and this place makes it just right. I would say it's probably the only pizza joint I have found in California that comes close to tasting like NYC's pizza. I just wish I could find something like it in Orange County.

Everytime I'm in SF which is about 2-3 times a year, I always make sure I hit up this place for some of their yummy pizza and they have never disappointed me. I totally understand why it's been open for over 75 years and that's cause their pizza is the BOMB!

My husband and I came here upon recommendation from a friend whose family owns this restaurant in San Francisco.   We liked that it was listed as casual Italian dining which meant we didn't need to change out clothes after spending the day out at the beach.  

The place isn't that hard to find but parking is a problem if you expect to find something on the street.  We ended up parking at the Hilton which was advertising $7 dollar parking for the evening.  We walked a couple blocks to the green door which is Tommaso's.
