This place is really small and very crowded.  We came in after a bunch of people had just gotten seated so we were able to get our name in with the guy running the show up front.    The guy then disappeared for awhile and the people that came in after us were not able to get their names in right away.   It gets very crowded in the waiting area but we were seated within 30 minutes.  However, we got the table which we like to refer to as the "middle seat".   We got the table that is in the middle of two other tables squeezed tightly together that you rub elbows with your neighbor.  I took away a star because of this.  It wasn't that great listening to our neighbors talk (they were pretty annoying).    It was also very very loud in there which wouldn't have been so bad if we had gotten a booth seat.  

The food was good.  My husband got the ceasar salad and I got the spinach salad.  The spinach salad was edible but not as  good as the ceasar.   The people next to use got the special which was heirloom tomatoes in some sort of balsamic vinegar.  It looked way better than my spinach salad.  

The table was very small so we had to finish the salad quick so we'd have room for the pizza.   We got the italian sausage pizza and it was delicious.  I got tired of the sausage though and picked it off and just ate cheese pizza.  The pizza is wood fired and the sauce and cheese taste amazing!  

Most of my stars go to the pizza.   It is a reasonable price compared to what is on the rest of the menu.  Also the waiter was pretty aloof but I think it was because it was busy.  

I will go back again when I'm in the area for the pizza!

Don't let the sleezy neighborhood fool you!  Although there is a strip club across the street... and around the corner... and down the block.... this restaurant is a diamond in the rough.  

Nice, traditional, Italian food, nothing too fancy.  Reminded me of the fare the brothers in Big Night were going for while other establishments were settling on serving Americanized Italian dishes.

This is a North Beach treasure. It's a weird setting (placed between adult stores/strip clubs) and feels a bit dated but maybe in a classic way.

The thing to get is the Neapolitan pizza. We had the artichoke and chicken pizza which came out terrific -- right up there with Tony's or any other North Beach institution. They definitely pride themselves on their pizza.

I also tried the chicken cacciatore which I found to be good but not great. It wasn't particularly flavorful but it had a healthy, filling portion. The accompanying pasta didn't seem to be house made and wasn't anything noteworthy.

I'd definitely come by here again for the pizza in a casual occasion.
Great food and service. I liked the pizza. I wish it was a little less doughie. All of the apps were great loved the anti pasta.

Their spinach salad with cherry tomatoes and shaved almonds and parmesan was absolutely delicious. The vinaigrette dressing was the perfect amount of sweet, and the shaved parmesan added a great touch!

The marinated vegetables were nothing to write home about, though.

Their pizzas are great! The crust is of a good thinness and the tomato sauce was so good! Not heavy at all.

Their pepperoni and olive pizza was delicious; the pepperoni was cut into quarter-sized pieces, and when it came out, their edges were crispy and curled up from the oven! Yum...

Their prosciutto pizza was really good; the taste was really well-balanced and not too "prosciutto-y".

The apple and gorgonzola pizza was also pretty good! Interesting taste.

For dessert, we had tiramisu, the creme brulee, and espressos. The creme brulee was fluffy, and the crust was blowtorched to a crispy finish! The portion was much bigger than I'd expected for the price ($6 - quite reasonable!), so I'm glad I split it with my coworker.

We didn't wait at all because we booked it there as soon as we got off work at 5 (they open at 5) on a Wednesday night. It filled up steadily while we were there, but there didn't seem to be much of a long wait with the other patrons. The location didn't bother me at all, haha!

Overall, A+, would do again.

I came here during a Giants Play-off game so basically, I didn't have to wait for a table since the rest of the city was busy.

+ Spinach salad was very standard. It tasted exactly like the ingredients it was made of - spinach, nuts, tomatoes)

- We got the artichoke pizza, but substituted the chicken with sausage. The pizza was average. I prefer my pizza to be thinner. I also expected to be more wow-ed for $20.

Came here because my friend told me the lasagna is to die-for. We probably have different taste because I honestly would've preferred a Stouffer's lasagna. The ratio of filling to pasta sheets was off (too much pasta) and I wasn't a fan of the meat sauce that was poured on top of it. The sauce was too spaghetti-like. Also, my favorite part about lasagna is the cheese that is slightly burnt at the top. The lasagna here was missing that. I was disappointed.

However, the pizzas are good and the tiramisu is amazing! I've never had anything like it. It was very smooth and creamy, almost like a mousse.

Tip: stay away from the lasagna. Stick to pizzas and finish it off with tiramisu!

It's in an interesting spot. A classy restaurant in the middle of an area with a bunch of strip joints. But again, it's way classy and a nice spot.

A tad expensive but great quality. We split a pizza and shared lasagna and it was plenty. High quality ingredients, you could tell. Great service as well. They let me charge my iPhone in their cash register area.

You wouldn't think much of this place from the street. It has a small awning with no windows. We came on a Tuesday night and I was surprised to say the place was packed. We were seated right away.

The menu was alright. Very basic Italian food. You want spaghetti and meatballs? They have that. And some other basics. No white sauce or anything fancy. The bread that they brought to the table was nice and fresh.

The water was in plastic cups which drives me nuts but oh well.

Would I go back? Maybe. Probably not with all of the other fabulous Italian places right in north beach.
Pretty good oven pizza. The pizzas are good size, freshly made and very simple. You get exactly what you would expect

Just walking around downtown San Fransisco and started chatting with a lady in line at a store.  She had used Yelp to find a place to have a drink.  Asked her if she could recommend a place to eat and she asked me if I used Yelp. Said yes and right then she got a alert about Delarosa.  So here I sit eating a fabulous dish of Risotto with butternut squash, field mushrooms and herbs.  The bartender suggested because she said it was new on menu today and she loved it and so did I!!  Spot on for an impromptu dinner in downtown San Francisco.  The ambiance was great and a very happening place.  Would come back if back in town.

You NEED to get the meatballs okay? Need.

My friend and I ate here for lunch as a we need an escape from law school treat and everything was delicious. The service is great as well. Our waiter Matthew was very accommodating. Anyway highly recommend.

Service is stellar.
Location is ideal.
Pizza kinda sorta tastes like every pizza in San Francisco.

For real though, if there isn't a pizza style called San Francisco style there should be because 80% of pizza places in this city seem to taste exactly the same and lack a bit of character. I don't think any of them are bad, they're just not exciting, nor anything I would write home about and definitely not something I want to spend that kind of money on.

I think for a fast casual lunch Delarosa is a perfectly fine option but as with all of SF, it's pricey for what you get and not a total standout.

Inside is almost deafeningly loud so it's hard to accomplish anything with dining partners over a meal, but could be a decent option for Happy Hour. The set up of the place is clean and makes for it to be a great place for servers to turn and burn tables, but not so much a place you want to stay, relax, and relish in your meal (hello communal seating and seats with no backs).

I feel like it's a place that caters its menu toward the casual business lunch/business happy hour crowd where people are a little more in and out and maybe dining on the company dime so they don't mind the smaller portions, slightly larger prices, and lack of intimacy, which is totally fair given this area, but I'm ready for a place that goes hard with its confidence in character and serves a good unique pizza for the people.

Met a friend here visiting/working from Connecticut and what a great choice for dinner.  I have literally walked by this place many times because it was so crowded, well it surely was worth the wait.

Had the kale/ceasar salad and the eggplant mezzemani.  It was just a tad bit spicy, but not overwhelming and yummy.  Washed it all down with a sidecar, one of two that was comped by the manager because the bartender forgot to make the initial one. #score #comingbackalthoughitsalilpricey
Delicious pizza and fun lively atmosphere. Meatballs were delicious too! Will definitely be back!

Families please be aware. We ate dinner here as a family tonight with grandparents and our 7, 5 and 2 year old. We were visiting from the Central Valley, as we frequent the city for events like the tree lighting in union square. The food was great as well as the service. The music was very loud but didn't bother too much until we repeatedly heard cuss words.  Towards the end of our meal the song frequently repeated F***, s*** and B****. This was at 6pm in the evening. Maybe if this was past 8 or 9pm but not as families are eating at an earlier time. My husband politely asked to speak to the manger where he told him how great the food and service was but brought up the language in the music, the manager replied "It happens".       My husband felt like he brought up a legitimate issue and was blown off and disrespected. A simple, "I'm sorry" would have made all the difference. Why would anyone want to return after being dismissed like this?

As a Restaurant Couple we aren't "Yelpers" but we had to share about our experience. Cecilly our server was attentive, even while her section was constantly full.  She was friendly, had great suggestions and made sure our first dinner as a married couple was perfect. We were blown away by
EVERY DISH placed in front of us. The Crispy Tagliolini, pizzas and Burrata toast were all special in their own rite. The chefs nailed every note and we had a special experience here. Love finding a place on vacation that you will make sure to come back to every time you're in town.

You know, pretty serviceable pizza for a place attached to a hotel technically. Stopped in for a quick bite, and was impressed.

One thing never to miss is the burrata with honey and hazelnuts. Personally wouldn't be my first choice for burrata combinations (arugula and grilled peaches would be), but it was mind blowingly good. Almost ordered a second portion.

My wine tasted off, and there was some weird sediment on the bottom of the glass...but the server seemed busy and so I didn't raise the issue.

Wow! Just finished eating the Pizza, Caesar salad and Parpadelle pasta (sharing with my mother) and we are totally blown away by how delicious everything was. As we were craving some pizza and pasta, I yelped a nearby place and Delarosa was one of the closer restaurants to our hotel and I'm so happy we ordered from here. Customer service is at its finest and everyone was super helpful. Although my time here was short since we wanted to bring the food back to the hotel, each interaction with the couple employees were wonderful! We come into the city and stay at the hotels quite often and I'll definitely be coming back!

This is a local favorite very expensive. They have a very small salads $10 soup which was all broth nine dollars had a tiny bit of egg inside a loser for sure -pizzas one size it was OK we have had so much better.pompous servers$$$

I find myself here every 2 weeks now, (since July 2013) and I have no regrets or intention to stop coming even though its a 50 minute drive to get some fresh, hot pizza. If this is the closest I'll get to Naples, then its absolutely worth it. Although my wallet says otherwise ;p
First time been there, ordered Clam Pie which I never tried. It tasted good. My son suggested we should go there more often. While it's a little pricy to me. Will recommend it to friends.

The pizza crust and sauce were good but the broccoli in the pizza was salty. could be a one off mistake.

The dessert was awesome. Wouldn't rule this place out.

LEGIT.  The wait can be long here, but once you get seated, the service and food are fantastic.  I have had three different types of pizza here so far over a multiple number of visits, and everything I've had has been great.  You really can't go wrong here no matter what you order.

Four stars, if only because it IS pretty overpriced. Then again, it IS also found in Pac Heights. The wait at 6:45 on a Sunday night for 3 people was almost an hour!!! But we got a nice booth in the back. Ultimately, I think the food made up for it. We got two pizzas: the Proscuitto and the Salsicca. Both were excellent, but I was partial to the Proscuitto with its generous sprinkling of fresh arugula on top. We also got a side of the grilled asparagus, which didn't disappoint. It was generously covered in lardo butter and topped with crispy breadcrumbs and more proscuitto. Yum. I could eat this alone...maybe they can turn it into a pizza? :) We ended with some of their homemade gelato: hazelnut and pistachio hit the spot. I liked the fact that they include whole pistachios and hazelnuts in their ice creams. I would return, but probably with only one other dining companion in order to speed up the wait. Or, maybe I'll just get takeout, which half of the diners seemed to do. I'll definitely keep this place in mind the next time I'm in Pac Heights. The service was friendly and efficient and unobtrusive, just the way I like it. And they didn't pressure us to get out, which I also appreciated.
Love this place! Great food, great atmosphere. Its fun to eat in or take out, the only downside can be the wait. Everyone who works here is very accommodating and friendly. Best Pizza in SF!

This is one legit pizzeria and restaurant. Some of the best Italian food prepared in the Bay Area. Simple, delicious. Reminded me of some of the better restaurants in Italy. It is hard to imagine that you will be disappointed--but I think they sometimes have an "off" day and the food and/or service can be less than stellar. This place is worth the risk, though. Just good food with quality ingredients.

I honestly think I could eat at Delfina every day for the rest of my life and be perfectly happy with every encounter... even though I've cut meat and dairy from my diet! Sound crazy? Well, of course it does....

There's not much I can say about their fine array of delectable, artisan Italian pizzas that you haven't read previously, but for the vegan types out there who still like to join their pals for a gluttonous night on the town, don't let a stop through this particular pizza parlor leave you with the desolate, sexless option of eating nothing but garden salads and crushed red pepper.

Upon asking my lovely server if they could whip up something that'd be appropriate for precocious youngster who doesn't animal byproducts, it was no sweat off of her perty little brow to recommend a vegan pizza consisting of spicy marinara, broccoli, mushrooms, and fresh basil. Once piping hot and sitting in front of me, the flavors worked so well together, I honestly think the presence cheese would have been a bit of a deterrent. It was easily one of the best vegan pies I've ever consumed, and it totally beat previous vegan versions I've consumed with that strange synthetic soy cheese alternative that most other pizza joints use in lieu of actual Mozzarella for difficult eaters like myself. Of course, that's not to say I'm complaining about spots that substitute Daiya cheese or some other cheese-but-not-really-cheese product, it's just that with ingredients this good, all you need are the plant based goods for a remarkable creation.

What makes it even better is that the pizzas are small enough to where if there's any contention over which pie will arrive on the table, it's quite possible for each person to order their own individual pizzas and avoid a crisis. If you've worked up a pretty mean hunger, it's easy to pounce on a whole pizza just by yourself, but if you're more sated half way through, you'll walk out with a couple of slices to heat up in the company communal toaster oven the following afternoon. Problem solved!

The pizza here is good, and the service is excellent. I am just not so sure that it's good enough to wait in line for. The margherita pizza, the ultimate litmus test, is as good and in my opinion about as good as any other restaurant's version.  One caveat, I didn't get a chance to try their homemade gelato...there's always next time.

Wow...amazing pizza.  I guess it has to be considering they serve nothing else.

I had the veggie pesto.  Amazing crust....crunchy and gooey all in the same bite.

There is very limited seating and no air conditioning (normally that's not an issue in SF, but dang was it hot out today).

If you want super delicious pizza, be sure to stop in!

Soooo gooooooood. We waited in line for maybe 30+ mins for two slices of pizza each, but totally worth it. The pizza slices are generously portioned and just so, guiltily amazingly, good.

I tried a slice of the garlic and clam pizza and the pepperoni and cheese. Garlic and clam was definitely a lot more garlicky thank I expected, and I probably wouldn't get it again because I couldn't get the taste/smell off of me for the whole weekend, but I'm glad I did - it was great! The pepperoni was my favorite. The crust on both was the right amount of "crispy" and "doughy," the cheese was nice and melty, and everything was flavorful. Two slices was more than enough to leave me feeling really full!
Bomb ass pizza soo good and yummy. That's all I have to say and was ready at my time of pickup

Okay it's no lie that we're not in Chicago or New York you're here in San Francisco... But we also have good pizza as well this one of my favourite's so delicious & fresh..(How can you go wrong)) U  can't!!!!!
   This is a delightful pizza experience.. Go and get u sum...
  Yummy 2Ur tummy...

Cash only.
Line can be long on the weekends and there is barely any parking near by.
Best to take a Lyft and just wait there in line or take your car and have a person drive around.
I'm not a huge pizza lover but I really liked the garlic clam  and I did like the pesto veggie.
I only eat seafood so I never will try the combo.
The price per slice isn't bad and their pizza boxes are large for a full sheet.

I have never sat inside because it has always been super busy.

Had the pleasure of trying their vegetarian and clam garlic pizza, delicious nonetheless.

We came right when they opened so the line wasn't too bad. Quick and easy. Choose your flavah and move on. I believe this is ca$h only, just FYI.

Overall, would come back!
Garlic and clam definitely lived up to the hype! The combo was just as delicious. My first time at Golden Boy but definitely not my last.

One of our pizza must trys during our SF trip over the weekend. A few of us were waiting in line at Mama's on Washington Square brunch and a couple of us wanted to bring back some pizza to try.

Golden Boy was not too far down so we walked over and decided to get the Garlic and Clam pizza (what they're known for) and the Vegetarian Pesto which looked promising.

They only take cash so make sure you have cash ready!

We tried it right away and OMG BOTH WERE SO DELICIOUS AND FLAVORFUL!
The Garlic and Clams one was full of garlic flavor which we all love and the Vegetarian Pesto was full of pesto flavor which is always a favorite.

I would definitely recommend if you are looking for good quality pizza!

This place! Come here for the deep dish pizza you've always needed!

Friendly staff, sticker adorned walls, low prices, and pizza that makes you happy you're alive!

Only thing deeper than this delish pizza was my conversation through bites of dinner- but let's not dive into that right now! Lol

My oh my. When I tell you this is THE BEST pizza place I have ever had in my 22 years of life. I could not believe my mouth once I took my first bite. The crust bite off was nice and clean. No struggle like your typical pizza joint. It was like the crust was made to be for pizza. I tried out the clam pizza because my friends who took me there for my first time highly suggested it. I know! Clam on pizza!?!? That's unheard of. And honestly I never would have tried it if I wasn't for my friends native to the city. This pizza completely changed my life. I'm making this pizza place MY PLACE that I have to eat at whenever I go to NorCal.

It's just that good.

I had a streak going recently, where I came here every morning for 10 days straight.  I was surprised that there was a different crew behind the counter every day and the sizes of the muffins and scones varied as well.  I think Wednesday was biggest (just kidding, sorta).

The point is, either there's cocaine in the food and coffee, or it's just that good.  I am going through Arizmendi-withdrawl because they decided to close between Xmas and New Year's.  Thanks guys.  I'm dizzy and shaking.

In my opinion, the coffee is actually the best part.  It has a hint of chocolate to it, and I'm not usually one to go off about crap like that.  I also love the bran muffins, oat scones, banana walnut muffins, and blueberry cornbread muffins.

Some people love the "pizza."  I think it's not pizza.  To each their own.

On weekends you're likely to see a mentally handicapped man panhandling outside.  I'm pretty sure he's not homeless, and you have to to give the guy credit--of all places in the neighborhood to panhandle, Arizmendi has the most foot-traffic AND the people most likely to give money to a panhandler.  How much would he get in front of Starbucks?

YUM!

Every time I've walked by Arizmendi, there's a line out the door. I finally tried it with my friend J on a rainy Saturday morning, around 10:45am. The baked goods, sweet and savory, are in glass (plastic?) cases. You get a bag, some wax paper, and serve yourself.  

We were able to get in, serve ourselves, pay and get a seat in a few minutes. We were lucky; chances are you won't get a seat. Small space, only a few tables and chairs. I got their scone of the day, blueberry: berry-licous. J got the lemon poppy seed muffin. It was amazing with real lemon taste! Not just "flavor".

I came back later with my sister F on a weeknight. We shared a slice of the salted caramel (chocolate) cake, ~$4. Generous slice and so dense and rich that you definitely need someone to share with. Even my massive sweet tooth couldn't conquer it alone. They should include a glass of milk with it, lol. Now I just need to try their pizza.

Check their website for their baked goods of the day.

Arizmendi is part of the reason why I moved to San Francisco. That and the fact that I'm getting married to a man who lives here.
But let's get back to the important things. This bread is the most amazing stuff. The foccacia pizzas are to die for. Their loaves of rye and sourdough and so so so good and make for the best toast. Those little cheese rolls, fantastic. The scones are actually properly made and packed full of deliciousness. I love the variety of seasonal flavors and toppings they offer. I haven't even had a chance to have their pizza yet but I'm pretty sure it's good. I would love to eat this entire bakery someday.
It's bustling in there so try to go at an off time. Run in, get some breads and you will be happy.

LOVE! Arizmendi puts a lot of bakeries in the OC to shame. I would never have thought to enter this unpretentious bakery while visiting SF if it wasn't for Yelp.

The brioche knot was ridiculously good. I gobbled that thing up like I hadn't eaten in weeks. I dipped some pieces in my coffee :) I would not mind eating this for breakfast everyday!

Marinated artichoke and spinach pizza... fucking good. The only pizza I have in the morning is yesterday's cold leftovers from Pizza Hut after a hangover so this is a major upgrade. The artichoke was delicious and it made me feel good having some veggies for breakfast. Hey, throw in a little spinach and the guilt goes away quick. Spinach dip? Oh, it's fine. There's spinach in it. It's good for you!

Multigrain baguette. There isn't too much you can say to describe a multigrain baguette but all the little seeds made this taste so good. There was a perfect amount of sea salt on it.

Cherry scone. I'm not a big fan of cherries unless there's a maraschino in my Long Island, but I had to try this because of the billions of reviews about it. It was so good. It was Joe's favorite. Scones tend to be rock hard and dry and just not pleasing but these scones were really good. Again, dipped in coffee and you're good to go!

I loved going to Arizmendi when I lived in the Richmond.  Sometimes I'd walk across the park, but usually I bussed it in because I'm lazy   :D

My favorite there is the olive provolone bread.  I have made it to Cheeseboard in Berekley to get it a few times but it isn't the same.

The pizza here is really good too.  Simple ingredients, ever-changing menu.  They used to give you a discount if you showed you took public transportation.

Oh, and I love that it is a cooperative business and I try to support that as often as I can.  Too bad the place is so darn crowded sometimes you can barely move around.

What San francisco Yelpers review list would be complete without a review of the famous Arizmendi Bakery??!

Let me just say, if you haven't been here then you are really missing out!  

They have a very good size variety of freshly baked and delicious choices.  I absolutely love their various kinds of focaccia's.  I make it a point to try something new every time i come here and i have to say that i have yet to be disappointed by anything i try!  Plus, all the people that work here are all very nice and helpful, make so to ask them their opinion if you can't decide what to get :-)

The only small knock i have on this place is their cash only policy, but for this place, i am always OK with getting some extra cash.

There isn't very much to say that hasn't already been said by everyone on this page, so ill just say, if you are in the mood for a very delicious snack that is absolutely reasonably priced, then this is the place for you.  This is one of the few places in this large city that you cannot go wrong with no matter what you choose! :-D

On my very first day working in the neighborhood, a customer offered me some advice. She said that every day, at 11:30, I should walk about half a block down 9th Avenue to the green and yellow house and buy some pizza.

So one day, a week or so later, I finally did. I also bought some focaccia. And a cheese roll. Oh, and a shortbread cookie. And then I repeated this sequence for about two weeks.

The pizza was tasty, and way better than more expensive slices elsewhere. The cookie was good, kind of salty, pretty satisfying. I wasn't too fond of the cheese roll. The focaccia tends to be a little bit tough, and really depends on the toppings for flavor, but can be delicious. My favorite so far was the marinated artichoke hearts and tomato focaccia. Yum!

The prices are really good, and though the lines can be long (especially at fresh pizza time), they move quickly and are worth standing in.

Love the pecan roll - moist, lots of pecans, not too sweet (but flavorful), and the right amount of glaze. Not too enthused about their cookies or tomato/olive focaccia (not that it was bad - just something I wouldn't crave for). Also, the thin-crusted, basil/tomato/artichoke pizza is delicious! Most, if not all of their daily special pizzas are amazing!

Their chocolate cake with salted caramel frosting is also yummy - (but check the color of the frosting - if there's some discoloration - do not buy it! It's not fresh, and blatantly - inedible. Arizmendi should really chuck it otherwise)

Ultimately, I am sooo thankful that this bakery is within the vicinity of my workplace...this makes the sunset district so much better.

Arizmendi, your pizza rocks just as much as your name and I love you in so many ways that I'm often left speechless, usually after my first bite nomnomnom.. mmm nomnomnom mmmm...
This co-op produces amazing pizzas, and they sell a slice for only $2.25, and by half and whole pizzas for take out or bring home and bake. Only one kind of pizza a day. I've trekked over to the inner sunset so many times just to get a slice of pizza. I usually chill on the abandoned wooden bench across the street, and just savor every bite. Dude.. the crust is thin, crispy, and sourdoughy, cheese is gooey with perfect touch of saltiness and the toppings are always fresh and aromatic.  Such ghetto gourmet heaven!  My favorite is anything pizza with mushrooms.. but they've got tons of other goodies as well, scones, breads, sweets, and treats, all worth trying.  

*Miss Piggy's stamp of approval*

You can find me at Arizmendi at least 4 days a week (and only because it is closed on Mondays). The aroma of delicious baked goods tempts me from a block away. Never have I ever been disappointed with Arizmendi. Ever.

My breakfast rotation consists of the scone of the day (especially if it has blueberries in it!), the brioche knot, and the corn blueberry muffin. Fresh with actual fruits in it? WHAT A NOVELTY!

I will see you there at 7:45am (but please don't stalk me) :)

For a city that has never produced a truly amazing pizza (or bagel, for that matter), Giorgio's is as close as you'll get to what a pie should be.

But you have to order right: go with one of the super-thin crust  Ishcian pies--we always get the Corsican. Nice and light, never weighed down with all the grease and oil that makes you think more of Jiffy Lube than a pizzeria.

The veggie and mediterranean salads are both good to start. And if you feel like you're not getting enough carbs, don't miss out on the garlic bread.

And for whatever reason, it's the only place where Budweiser tastes like beer.

Giorgio's has a great, relaxed atmosphere that works well for both couples and large groups.  The pizza is decent, but the crust is just a bit too chewy for my tastes.  If you like eating crust, be prepared for a serious jaw workout.  The pasta here (especially with red sauce) is always memorable for me.

Other than that, it's pretty straightforward.  The jukebox and kids' soccer parties can get a bit noisy at times, so if you're looking for a quiet night out, you might wanna pass.
Old school pizza place complete with the red checkboard table clothes.  Perfect place for kids complete with stroller valet and make your own pizza for the kids.

A real gem! An authentic Italian restaurant!
It has a true family-friendly oriented attitude
with service which is prompt,friendly and attentive! The food is tasty,the ingredients are fresh and the presentation is inviting. We all love the pizzas, which match the quality of the pizzas of New York where we used to live,the baked Penne,the Chicken Parmigiana and the great salads!
Our kids LOVE to go there and so do we!

Dinner with roomates !
It was a great moment. The atmosphere is warm and family. The most important, about the pizza : i share a pepperoni with one of my roomate and it was very good. great paste and great pepperoni quality. The only thing is the pizza was little bit too oily but it's ok. Another thing the root beer was not great, too bad ! I put 4 stars but if 3,5 stars were exist i had chosen that.

i grew up right around many corners in the richmond dist and we would come here for treat night.

( and actually, the sausage factory in the castro was our ALL time fave pizza spot in the city, but they closed and we started going here)

28 years later this place still has great sauage pizza and the same smell of an old pizza joint. the waitresses aren't as friendly as they used to be, but that's okay. The food is simple and tasty and they have stayed true all these years.
This is one good pizzeria - keep up the great work, Giorgios
Great  food , great people!! Plus its In the neighborhood ... Been going there since 1983...

if you're thinking about starting a family and moving to suburbia, you must come to giorgio's on sunday evening for a sneak preview:

families, weekend jocks or wannabe jocks after their manly softball games, kids running around, babies crying...

*shiver* and *more shivers*

the only thing missing is a gigantic suv. oh wait, a chevy suburban just pulled in.

wow! it's the whole shebang!

are you scared yet? we are. the girlfriend and i are scared out of our panties whenever we come here. i mean, we expect this sort of a scene when we visit our family in nowhere california, but not in frisco. nevertheless, despite the madness, giorgio's is our destination if we happen to be in richmond. this is an excellent neighborhood pizzeria.

the pizza is quite delicious and comes in various styles. kinda like round table, but much much better. actually, it would be quite a challenge to find an authentic family pizzeria that would top giorgio's in the suburbia. perhaps frisco is not such a bad place to raise a family. no?

you definately get a NY feel at this place. wed & white table cloths, cozy/dark seating with candles, good pizza. but i was hungry and this place, for some reason, doesnt give bread. an italian place that doesnt give bread while you wait for your food? i think i know why. later on, ryan showed up and paid $9, including tax & tip, for 2 pieces of plain bread and maranara sauce. that's a little ridiculous, considering you'd get that for free anywhere else...
Always a priority to stop here when in the area.  I'm not always in the mood to deal with all the smells in the Haight, but the smell of this place always hits the spot.

Pizza here is pretty awesome if you prefer thin crust like I do. The dough is a little too chewy for my taste, I'd prefer it to be a little more crispy but it was good anyways. The slices are fairly cheap for the size you get but I paid over 18 bucks for a medium pepperoni and a large drink so that kept it from being a 5 star review for me. Still worth it though.

As someone who actually did escape from New York just two short weeks ago, this is the only decent slice of pizza I have been able to get in San Francisco. I love this city, but what passes for pizza here is barf-stix on bread. I can't! I'm no fan of the Haight, but I had to stick around for an appt. and got hungry. I had the thinly sliced potato, cheese and pesto slice. It was great. My only issue is the girl didn't heat it properly and it was a bit cold. Still good. So, thank you for feeding me. Properly.

This place really is an escape from New York. Though it isn't as good as New York pizza, it's about good as it gets outside of the East Coast. The crust is perfection and without them, I would have never started my love affair with pesto pizza. The You Say Potato is also delicious, it has sliced gold potatoes, their pesto, and chunks of roasted garlic. The only red sauce slice I have tried is the Sausage and Tomato, which was also delicious. They are open late and deliver, which is convenient. Escape from New York is a little on the pricier side, but it is well worth it to treat yourself to a slice every once in a while. The staff has its days, sometimes they're super nice and sometimes they're rude.

Do yourself a favor and first stop by Ameoba Records (A block up towards Stanyon) and pick up enough yellow coupons for everybody in your party to get a free drink with their slice (especially important since prices have risen  U Say Potato $4.25 Pepperoni $3.85 Cheese $3.25).If you can ignore the New-Age Hippie Children outside then you can enjoy the best Pizza on Haight Street.

I really like the mushroom pizza. It has a lot of sauce. It's the best pizza they have. I've tried most of their topping things. The hawaiian is just okay, the mushroom is way better. The garlic potato is weird and not what a pizza should be, it's also kinda bland. The pepperoni and cheese are standard, but good because there is sauce. The mushroom is better.

The service is efficient and nice. They give free water very willingly. It doesnt have a bathroom which is sad, and is a little grungy. The pizzas are a bit oily, so it always helps to pat it down with napkins before digging in.

Try the mushroom.
I go ga-ga for the "You Say Potato" pizza every time.  I love stopping by here for delicious garlic, potato, pesto pizza before heading a few doors down to the hookah place for smoking and drinks.
Really good! Prices weren't bad and the pizza is awesome. I got the hawaiian and it was pretty good, but i wish i had gotten the pepperoni.

parking is always difficult on the haight.

ordered a pizza...with a 50% entertainment coupon.  and it still got up to 20 dollars...for 5 toppings.  THATS EXPENSIVE!

the pizza right out of the oven was great.  good toppings, fresh taste.  no complaints.  it was XL too.

the thing is.  it was slightly salty.  2nd.  i rate pizza on how good it tastes cold.  this pizza when it got cold...hated it.  i don't know what it is.  its like the cheese got hard and saltier.  the ingredients and the sauce just got more bitter.

i'll go back but i'll eat it while its hot.

Pretty great late night spot. I was here on a weeknight so it was less crowded than usual, but service was quick and everything seemed fresh. (I tried three different slices and liked them all). I'll be back whenever I'm in Haight late night.

Very good authentic napoli style pizza. Tiny place, but fast kind service. Tried the buffalina which was wonderful, simple and delicious, and the diavola- warning I think they might put some chili oil on it so a bit spicy! Highly recommend

I've heard much about the food at Il Casaro; most notably the burrata & pizza being outstanding.

My first attempt to dine here was about 6 months ago.  Went by early on a weeknight to check out the menu & the space.  Problem was the lighting.  It was so bright that I said pass.  I do not want to sit down for dinner in a place that's lit like Walgreen's.  

I guess they heard me, because they've fixed that.  The lighting is dim & inviting.  Win.

Our picks...
The meatballs.  The burrata.  The diavola pizza.

The meatballs.  2 & 1/2 stars.  The sauce was zesty & flavorful, but the meatballs were very dry.  Pass.

The burrata.  5 stars!  Imported from Italy every week.  It was creamy divineness.  The dressed arugula it's partnered with was delicious.  Full of flavor.  Simply perfect.  Win.

The diavola pizza.  2 & 1/2 stars.  A spicy pie, thanks to the addition of chili oil.  Sauce & flavors on point, but the crust was majorly soggy.  This really surprised me considering all of the stellar reviews.  With an appropriately crisp crust, this pie would be outstanding.

Our server was delightful.  Personable & warm.  Win.

A great casual neighborhood spot.  

3 & 1/2 stars.

Amazing cheese on everything. The asparagus with shaved Parmesan was to die for. The Gorgonzola on the Quattro formaggi was fantastic. The service (Alex, our server) was attentive and awesome. Will definitely be coming back here soon!

The pizza here is amazing. They make the best crust I have ever tasted. They are also very accommodating and make pizza without cheese for my intolerance to lactose.

The location is also great. Sitting at one of the tables next to the windows makes for a great lunch. Would highly recommend!

Great, cheap, simple, Italian food in North Beach? This hasn't happened in ages. Get there before the lines get ridiculous.

Their pizza margherita is currently better than A16, Delfina and Zero Zero. No kidding.
We got the margherita pizza & cannoli. Both were delicious! I loved being able to watch the chefs make the pizzas while sitting at the bar! Probably the best cannoli I've ever had.

So, two things.
#1. Great food. Some of the best marinara sauce I've ever had on a pizza. Delicious crust. Flavorful cheese.

#2. Terrible service. And not even to my party. Saw the owner absolutely lose it and scream at a woman with a small child in front of the whole restaurant. Kept yelling, "You're the worst customer EVER!" to her as her kid cried. He was very close to her face and kept making these violent hand gestures. Now, I couldn't hear her part of the conversation as she was sitting down and speaking in a calm voice. Maybe she was an awful customer but his behavior was unacceptable and abusive. We wrote a note on our receipt to the owner. Normally we would say something but this guy seemed way too hotheaded and we weren't in the mood to throw down. I almost felt like I was watching an episode of Kitchen Nightmares.

We were going to go to the Cliff House but looking at the menu it was ordinary and just that the restaurant has that tourist-trap food price. We would have waited but the host told us they've stopped taking orders.

Thank goodness we went to Little Italy and checked out IL Casaro!

Have you ever really had "real, authentic" pizza? Get the prosciutto pizza - it's to die for laden with mozzarella, araguls and prosciutto!

Ask for Augustina, she's friendly  he's the owner and he's very accommodating. Calls you Mama and Papa, very original. The server was awake, cool ink on her arms, and Ricky, he won't let your drink run dry.

A few nights ago, I found myself home alone, hungry, & lazy. I was searching for something, & I thought the Internet could help me find my true match. I opened up my favorite site, Caviar, hoping to find the answer to my dilemma. I began to scroll through the photos, focusing on the "type" I was looking for tonight - Italian. Gorgeous photos of pizza were everywhere. But I'd been through so many of them before. Sure, they were fine, but I was sure that tonight I could do better. Some were clearly gold-diggers (Tony & his $45 pizza - yikes). I started to despair. Maybe this whole internet thing just isn't for me. Maybe I should just go old-school and call an old regular.

But remember, I'm lazy so I persevered. Suddenly, I came upon Il Casaro Pizzeria & Mozzarella Bar. The pictures were all I needed to see, not to mention the elevation of amazing mozzarellas in the very name. It was love at first sight. I could see us in Italy in a beautiful, romantic restaurant. I could use all the Italian words I know: per favore, Grazie, delizioso, formaggio, etc.

Arriving early, and not the worse for wear after the indignity of being shoved in a cardboard box for the trip across town, I was blown away by what came through my door. Always wondering if the photos would match the reality, and ladies (& gentlemen!) did it ever. This was the real deal. So, I'm here to say, do yourself a favor & spend an evening with il Casaro.

P.S. I ordered the calzone (San Marzano tomatoes, smoked mozzarella, ham, & mushrooms) and the imported Burrata. Both were outstanding. The arugula & cherry tomato salad w the calzone was a wonderful touch. My only gentle complaint: two small bread pieces with the Burrata was not nearly enough. Maybe at least double that for take-out?

Our pizzas, especially the ingredients, were very good. Would have liked them a bit more crispy but maybe that's Chicagoans expecting it was a cracker crust. The Burrata with Calabrese peppers was great. Service was good. Upbeat staff. Be sure to sign in on the list hanging outside the doorway and not waste your time waiting for the busy hostess to tell you to do the same.
I am going to make this quick: If you haven't eaten at Pizzetta, you haven't experienced life.

I have been coming here maybe three times a month  since the original owner had it.  That's  quite a while--seven years?  On the one hand, I LOVE Pizzetta for many things.The food is awesome, done with hands down mastery.
The music they play is totally eclectic tasteful and ultra cool
all over the map good stuff.  I like the care and  simplicity and lack of decadence and waste. Cash only is smart, keeps down the overhead, etc.

Now...on the other hand....the place is crawling with spoiled
obnoxious affluent yuppies and soccer mom types.
Because they always find out what's good and
descend like a plague of clueless locusts. It's annoying
to me, but probably not to most yelp people, because, uh, well, that
pretty much describes most yelp people.

The staff is quirky and temperamental, like people in general.
They have their good days and bad days, so what?  They are a
bit aloof-hipster-like, but not off the scale. Personally I think they are
quietish because the space is small and it's prudent to keep it chill.

The food's been slipping a bit recently, and I speak as one who knows.

Just sayin'.

Great tiny place. Great service. Creative, well done food. Only 4 small tables inside plus a few tiny tables on the street "patio". Worth the wait for fresh thin crust pizza. Probably the best pizza we've had in CA.

beer selections could be better BUT the food made up for it!
deep dish bbq chicken pizza was LEGIT!

Such an adorable little pizza place hidden in the inner Richmond. Customer service is so nice, feels like a little restaurant in Italy. Delicious pizza and even more delicious wine. I don't want to write this review, because I don't want the wait to be even longer, but too good not to share!

i never anticipated san francisco to be such a heavy influencer of my pizza choices in life. from this city, so many different pizza experiences have come to my attention and shaped my entire being, forever changing me as a person - for the better. from fast, cheap pizza late at night to deep dish to gourmet, i've found so many ways to enjoy this seemingly simple food.

last night i went to pizzetta 211 with three close friends for a birthday dinner. i was immediately impressed with the size of the restaurant (small), location (quiet, residential neighborhood in the outer richmond), seating options (there are heaters for the outdoor tables and it was cold last night), coziness, and design. as an additional bonus, there is nothing gimmicky about this place. one of my personal favorites was in the bathroom. above the toilet is a tiny television with its own stage and curtains.

the menu was very nice. we decided to get a few pizzas and a salad so we could share. the waiter remembered some of my friends from a few months ago and was extremely friendly. he even brought us over a free appetizer because he knew we'd love it - the sausage-stuffed squid in tomato sauce with polenta. we had a pizza with hen of the woods mushrooms, one with pepperoni and white anchovies, and the potato and fried egg pizza with prosciutto. the crusts are thin without being too crispy and everything went down smoothly with a french red.

i'm not sure how i had not heard of this place before, but i would definitely love to return soon.

it's off the beaten path, but they still have to back crowds back with a stick. the style of the place makes me think of french peasants begging for bread rations at neighborhood boulangeries during the revolution. yes, it is small, in demand, a bit snotty and it has an awesome brick oven. let them eat pizza!

it's really all about the pizza-- thin crust, tossed in front of you, and EGG!  oh hallelujah! way too rare in the states. you can get drippy, runny yolks on anything-- best on the four onion special though.

this is the kind of place where you literally see hands on the food, and that's a good thing. maybe i'm a masochist, but i enjoy the wait when i know it's for quality. everyone else in line seems to have a peaceful understanding of the quest for quality as well. you can also bring your own wine bottles. i think the corking fee is reasonable, like 5 or 10. reservations are not allowed. go on a dark and stormy night when you want to cozy up, and fill up."

pizza oh how i love thee, let me count the ways... as a former new yorker, i find eating pizza to be a challenge in the bay area - not worth eating most of the time - it will pale in comparison to anything i grew up with... until pizzetta 211

love the cool & funky ingredients on pizza here - goat cheese on pizza? figs? they put the most incredible ingredients together on a delicious little pizza that are just so ... darn ... tasty. i don't know how they do it but it's so good "when it touches your lips it's so good" (will ferrell, old school movie quote)

wanna know why it's not 5 stars? "hey rich & z, let's go to pizzetta 211 tonight" "cool, sounds good." (20 minute drive later & we're in front of pizzetta 211) "uh oh, it's 9:15 pm on a saturday night and they ran out of pizza dough..."

note to self: leave early on saturday night to eat @ pizzetta 211

Such a tiny place filled with so much charm! Their menu is inventive and fresh, and everything we tried was delicious. The handmade pizza was incredible, but the loss of one star is for the pizza maker that kept checking her cell phone every 3 minutes. Call me a germaphobe, but handling your cell phone between bare handed pizza dough pressing struck me as icky. Wish I hadn't seen that, but we were seated at the bar facing her, so if was impossible to ignore. It didn't freak me enough to swear off the place or anything. I'd definitely go back and try more menu items. The bathroom had some trippy entertainment. Check it out, even if you don't have to pee. :-)

Our favorite neighborhood restaurant. Great thin crust pizza without being a cheesy pizza parlour. Always try their special sides or salads for the day. The fresh ingredients combined with the simple recipes make for real, unencumbered, pure food. Who would have thought eggs on a pizza was a good idea? Cheeze is fresh and high quality. Cozy, romantic, and won't break the piggy bank. A great date spot for those who want to impress another with a hidden, intimate, simply great thin crust pizzas. Low lighting makes everyone look good.

I've heard about Little Star through word of mouth and then saw it on Check Please. After I watched it on Check Please I got a huge hankering for pizza so we decided to give it a go. We go there at 830 on Sat. night and boy was the wait long! The lady taking names said it could be 1.5 hours for a table... so unfortunately we had to leave because I was starving and would pass out...fast forward a week...

Came back to Little Star on a Weds at 6pm - no wait!!! Yay! We were promptly seated and our server came by and gave us the special for the day. We ordered the caprese salad and a small brass monkey. Caprese salad was okay, nothing spectacular ... and finally after waiting and waiting our pizza came out! The small had 6 pieces... definitely enough for 2 people. It was soo good!!! I'm so glad I followed fellow yelpers advice and ordered this! The sausage was yummy as well as the other toppings. I loved the crust and it did not get soggy like other deep dish pizzas I've had in the past. The flavors worked well together and left me craving more after eating 2 slices. I was good though and took the rest home. Our meal was about $40 for two people..a little pricey but definitely worth it.

If there is a long line, there's a takeout line off to the side you can order from. Also this place is cash only! They do have an ATM machine inside if you don't have cash on you.

One of the TOP TWO pizzas i've had. The other winner goes to a popular pizza joint in NY. I've never been to chicago, so i don't know how chicago pizza is. I do not like deep dish. I much prefer THIN crust pizza.

But whoa. This blew me away!

Got here on a late sunday afternoon, around 5.30pm. Parking wasn't good and had to park like 4 blocks away. It was surprisingly a full house for being 5.30pm.

Ordered the garlic bread and spicy wings, which was brought out speedily.

Garlic Bread, the bread was warm but nothing special. However, the butter was melted to perfection. The garlic was, well, a softened whole garlic, which is plenty for your bread and guaranteed stinky breaths!

Spicy chicken wings, a good portion, I didn't count how many, but i would presume there was around 10? delicious and didn't even need the ranch! However, by the time I had finished these (shared) I was regretting the order of 2 appetisers.

The pizza took about an additional 10 minutes. I didn't think it looked big, only 12" long (that's what she said =p) By long, i mean in diameter! But after the first slice, even if you skip the crust...you remember, it is a deep dish with an overload of ingredients on it, leaving the quest to finish the pizza to be a very daunting task. Actually, impossible after eating the two appetisers. I only managed to squeeze in 2 slices and was full for the next 12 hours. Meanwhile, my bf finished 3 slices. The pizza was indeed, very well made. The crust wasn't soggy at all. The best of the pizza was somewhat crunchy and a great foundation for the pizza. I personally preferred the Little Star, even though it lacked the meat, it was filling enough. the Mediterranean chicken had a little sourness from the artichoke and i didn't think it matched well. Overall though, incredibly well made! Water, which was essential, was refilled every so often.

What's even more amazing was that after 3 days, I had 3 slices of pizza left. I microwaved a slice for 1 minute and toasted it in my toaster oven for another 10 minutes in 350 degree. It was still very good! Not soggy at all! Amazing!

They accept card now!!! Thank goodness! But the ATM is only $0.25 anyways.

***

Tips: Get the little star, get the garlic bread, get the wings, dare i say one of the best wings and pizza ever! One appetizer to share, with a large pizza is enough for 2! Leftovers aren't that bad. Get half and half! Weekends, come early and you wouldn't have to wait for a seat.

Favorites: Little star pizza and chicken wings!

Do not want: Too full. Garlic bread was too stuffy. A little plain on the bread. I expected more?

Last words: Come and get a pizza, you will not regret it!

Didn't care for the deep dish at all.  I found it bland even though it was swimming in what appeared to be crushed tomatoes right out of the can. And, cornmeal crust?  Umm--no.  Pizza on the west coast couldn't be more different than pizza on the east coast.  I truly believe that it has become cultural and people like what they are used to--kind of like Red Vines vs. Twizzlers. Tully's coffee vs. Dunkin' Donuts coffee etc.  
To each his own!
Chow on Church/Market makes the kind of pizza that I enjoy. Ditto for Marcello's in the Castro.
Great pizza, cool vibe, noisy without being too much so. Ate here while moving daughter into dorms at USF. Will definitely return when coming up for visits.

As several others have said, when you want Zachary's but don't want to drive across the bridge, Little Star is a good choice. I think their food has improved since they first opened, and the vibe is hip, yet unpretentious (a rare combination).

One suggestion -- they should have Ranch dressing so my ghetto-ass doesn't have to dip my crusts in bleu cheese.

I think it was a Wednesday right after work. We walked over. I'd heard the rumors of this incredible deep dish place out in what people used to call the Western Addition. City folk tried to compare it to Zachary's Pizza. While I had faith that it was good, I didn't realize how good.

The walk was nice. From Pac Heights to there is a little sketchy. Not unsafe so much as keep your eyes open and be aware of your surroundings at all times...OK, that's a gross exaggeration. The neighborhood appears it's going through the gentrification pains.

Walking into the dark space that is Little Star immediately differentiated it from any other pizza place I'd been to. I'd expected lines out the door based on the mythology that surrounds this place. Our wait was self-imposed as we tried out several different tables before making our selection.

Started with a salad that was full of good stuff. I like a good salad. And, this was a great salad. The pizza came hot from the oven. From start to finish, each bite proved to me this was worthy of the hype.

The service was great. The waiter looked like he'd escaped the tattoo parlor a little too late to avoid illustration. He looked like he could rumble. But he was a very kind and generous person.

So I've been once...We'll be going back...It's just a matter of time.

My friend and I were in the city and we decided to go out for pizza and I found this place on YELP.

When I first stepped in here, I was kind of surprised. I was expecting a cheesy pizza parlor. The setting seem more date-ish. Lights dimmed candle light dinner kind of thing. I felt kind of trapped and out of pace.

Anyway, I ordered my pizza before I was seated because the hostess told me deep dish pizzas take 30 minutes to cook. When I was seated an hour later, I waited another 15 minutes for the food to come. We ordered the Little Star Deep Dish. It taste so simple and fresh. The best pizza I've ever had in my life. I don't know how I could possibly go back to pizza hut. The crust was so crispy and buttery. The cheese was cooked at the right temperature cause when I took a bite out of it the mozzarella was nice and stringy. The tomatoes were perfectly cooked. So sweet and perfectly seasoned with oregano. We ordered a large and regretted it the instant it got to the table. It's so big! I don't even think the two of us could even finish a small. We still had half the pizza left by the time we were completely full.

If you've been dying for good tasting pizza in the bay. Don't overlook Little Star.

CONS:
Parking is hell, the wait for a table during dinner is insane, and their isn't much room.

A slice of Little Star pizza can get me pretty full already. Because it is the city's finest pizza place, my boyfriend said that it was time that I tried it, since he lives fairly close the the restaurant. When we went to pickup our order, it was packed with people in the tables and people waiting for their takeout, it really says something about Little Star's popularity.

It's just me, but I dislike how it's drenched in marinara sauce; I don't think it needs that much sauce.  It could just be that pizza we ordered that was drenched in it, I don't know.  but other than that, it was still one of the best pizza I've ever had. Very impressive, I wouldn't mind going to try out the other pizzas.

Pretty darn good.  Lots of distinct spices.  Good flavor.  Had the veggie deep dish.  

Small and a bit dark.  But the service was good  wait was minimal

It's good. Damn good. I can't say if it's better or worse than Zachary's or Patxi's, but it's good. Interestingly different from the others with a corn meal crust. The only downsides were that the wine by the glass we picked wasn't all that great, and it was REALLY LOUD, but that may have simply been due to the presence of a large party.
Read my full review here: sibilous.blogspot.com/20…

This place is absolutely amazing and worth every penny. It may be on the more expensive side when you get salad, drinks, appetizers, and pizza, but it is definitely possible to do it on a budget. My friend and I can come out of there for $12 each if we get pizza and the herb bread and no drinks. This is totally enough food and really isn't that much for how great it is. It is also located in a great location and is very hip and trendy. There are lots of young people there on weekend nights.This place is hands down my favorite pizza place, if not restaurant , in San Francisco. They use delicious and fresh ingredients and have a delicious variety of options. I love the margarita burrata and the prosciutto arugula pizzas.

I'm only giving it 1 star because they say they offer GF and in reality they don't. I don't know if it's a Yelp thing but this place does NOT really offer GF options. The regular food is supposed to be good and I must say it does smell fabulous. Anyhow, they said they could do GF pasta but they would cook it in the same water as regular pasta which is sort of ridiculous if you have Celiac's or sensitivity to gluten. I asked if they could cook the pasta separately but it was apparently too much of an imposition on a busy night according to our not-too-stoked to be serving us server. Oh so I ended watching my family eat again, since we had walked out of another place that advertised as having GF options but didn't.

Delarosa is your typical, urban city nice Italian pizza restaurant - which isn't a bad thing. Came by for a late lunch on a Friday and ordered the brussels sprouts and spicy marinara-pepperoncini-olive pizza with extra burrata on top (highly recommend this addition). Everything was great, but there were definitely moments I felt the brussels sprouts were a bit over-roasted and not as meaty as they could be. The aperol spritz was also great!

Meh...

Came here recently on a packed Sat night.  I'm not sure if they take reservations but what they do is allow you to call in within an hour of when you want to come and they put your name on the list and then you can show up around the time you want or they will call you.  We did this and it worked okay but it was also just two of us and they were able to squish us in next to a large party at one of their long wooden tables.  It was interesting to sit so close to another party - especially when a pizza they ordered arrived and smelled like funky feet/homeless person, I'm not joking.  We kept hoping that that was not the same pizza we ordered - pee-ew!

Luckily, our pizza didn't stink and it was pretty good (ordered the Funghi), nothing too special though.  I liked the mussels we ordered for app, those stood out a bit more I think.

Came here for dinner on a Saturday night, and was able to get seating right away. The tables are community style, which is always fun but was kind of cramped. Ordered the Margherita pizza, and the Roman Popsicle. The pizza was SO good, but the drinks were ehhhh. Definitely not what I thought it would be, and not as tasty as it sounded on the menu either. Also our waitress didn't bring us straws for our drinks, so I had to go to the bar and ask for straws. Our waitress was also pretty slow... we kept looking around for her but she just never came close to our table for us to get her attention.
Fantastic burrata at an amazing price. We had the burrata pizza and it was incredible. Amazing prices and wonderful food.
We came in for a quick bite and cocktails We loved the food, the atmosphere and the drinks!!

WE LOVE DELAROSA!!!!

This list is sure to grow but so far we have tried and enjoyed :

1. Meatballs...tender and delicious
2. Margherita with burrata pizza
3. Winter chicories with cauliflower (needed a little salt but after properly salted was great).

Can't wait to go back for more even if it means driving clear across town and hunting for parking!

I stumbled across Delarosa whilst being very hungry and impatient after attending the USC v Cal football game (Fight on!). I truly think that more dinner places should be open past 10pm . .what's with this city! I digress.

To my pleasant surprise, Delarosa was open and happenin'!

The bar was packed and looked tons of fun - as were their interesting drink concotions.

However, we were hungry and we wanted food. Here's what we ordered:

Fried brussel sprouts with aioli - While delicious, fried and unique . . . definitely a dish to share with 2+ people. It was a bit overwhelming

Beer Steamed Mussels - Naturally we were curious . . and not disappointed! Unique flavors and a delicious fennel / "beer' broth. Loved it.

Garganelli, Porcini, pancetta - Basically, delicious pasta with pancetta. Amazing. Very small plate though so order accordingly.

Beef Spiedini - Disappointing. It was pretty much kababs on skewers. The beef was not moist or tastey. Very tough. The arugula, onions and carrots were the most redeeming items of the dish, on which the skewer was presented upon. Eh, could've gone without it.

Overall, fun place with great food. Luckily it was a warm night so we really enjoyed sitting out on the front sidewalk. Will definitely go back again as I have tons more items I want to try, including the pizza!

...so I see this place as a hip trendy hang for the 30 somethings, with a sprinkle of maturity for those who are over 30 and keeping it real...nice crowd with a scattering of pretty career women...just enough to keep the guys lurking just a little bit...

...the pizza is simple and good, and the donuts...yeah!  the donuts...they add a little somethin somethin to the overall late night munchies experience.

Bottom-line -- Check it out!  Cool place with a cool vibe...

It's a family owned Italian restaurant. The owner's daughter (hostessing for the night) met us at the front and shared some history of the restaurant. Originally opened in 1937, her family  bought the restaurant 40 years ago. The wait staff was never intrusive while making sure our glasses were full and our table was cleared. The chicken parmigiana was made without breading, which is my favorite way and almost impossible to find. The homemade manicotti was perfect and the desserts were divine. We also heard amazing things about the pizza but ran out of time for a return visit. We were there early, so   Great option in North Beach.

Disappointed with our experience here. Started out well, the restaurant has a very quaint, authentic feel and only had a short wait for 4 of us and our orders were taken quickly. Good (not the best, but yummy) food and if we had stopped there I probably would go again, but we decided for dessert. We ordered the tiramisu, cheesecake, and gelato. Everything tasted as if it had been sitting in the freezer a VERY long time.

We also never got refills on our water, our waiter never came to check on us, and never refilled our wine. I don't like it when waiters are overly attentive but this guy paid no attention to us at all.

We forgot to mention we wanted two checks, but since the check was hand written and clearly not entered into a machine, we thought we would tell him what to put on card and the rest would be cash. He got very upset with us and told us it would take him a long time because we didn't tell him beforehand. I would understand if he had to enter information into a machine and it had to reprint but he hand wrote it and we were trying to tell him what we wanted on one card and the rest cash. He was very stubborn and rude about it.

When he brought it back and saw we were paying 1 check by card he got upset we weren't paying cash. He said "he just likes cash."

This guy was so rude, stubborn, and did not serve us at all. I don't know why we tipped him as well as we did. We are nice people who are usually understanding when people have bad days but the more I think about it, the more I realize how unnecessary his bad attitude was. I tried to sympathize with him, maybe we should have remembered to let him know we were splitting checks (only 2 ways) but even if we were wrong, do you really want to treat your customers like they are putting you out? Are you not being paid to serve us? I always feel bad getting angry with bad service but it's unacceptable to be in the customer service business and treat your customers so poorly.

I came here because friends of mine recommended but I will never go back. There are too many great Italian places in North Beach to waste time dealing with the negativity here. I will not recommend to friends or visitors either.

I took my little sister her for her 21st birthday.

We got there around 5:45 and were seated promptly. The place is pretty small, but cozy!

I got the clam linguine with white sauce. My sister got spaghetti and meatballs. Both dishes were yummy! The portions are decent sized. We both cleaned our plates and left full and satisfied!

My favorite Italian in San francisco.  They don't book - and it is part of the charm.  I think the banter with the MD whilst waiting for a seat is all part of the fun - and very Italian.  

The kind of place where you can make requests and it is considered an honor, not a pain.  

Their food is exquisite, but it is the atmosphere (LOUD), the service, the family feel (am I in a back alley in Rome?) and the mix of crowd (families mix with young couples mix with tourists) that make it.

And have the Coo Coo Clams.  Even if you don't like clams.

What can one say? This is the spot for benchmark pizza in the bay area. Simple, classic, extremely consistent and not trying to be anything other than what it is, it's no wonder there's always a line at the door. The wood burning oven is one of the, if not the, oldest in San Francisco. And the folks who work the dining room and kitchen will work even harder for you when one's clear as to what to expect so as they can efficiently take care of their many table turns.

I have found one of the best ways to eat here and blend a traditional pizza menu with contemporary style is to order a margarita with a plate of sliced prosciutto, roasted bell peppers, and arugula salad on the side, as well as some red pepper flakes and grated Parmigiano (or Romano). Then mix and match at the table.

Can't wait to go back and get my fix.

I came here with a group of friends for dinner. As soon as we walked in we could smell the food and it was like grandma's italian kitchen. The place has a very warm and cozy atmosphere. We were greeted as soon as we walked in the door. The server was very attentive and the food was excellent. One of my friends is a chief and studied in Italy and she thought the food was excellent.
Next time I want to try the pizza though.

We got the idea for this place straight off of Yelp. Tucked quaintly between several porn shops, it is an interesting location. Once safely inside, we were quickly seated and ordering our food. We had the pizza and salad along with their house red wine (which was actually quite good). It was an enjoyable meal (as long as eating next to people you don't know is not a problem for you).

I would gladly return.

I've lived in San Francisco for 2 years... well as Italian I needed a good pizza in the city!
No doubt, Tommaso is the best real italian pizza in San Francisco.period.
Sometimes you will likely wait for a while since they don't take reservations, but believe me.. the wait is worth it!
Enjoy!

LOVE IT!!!  Order me the vegetable antipasto, the spinach and shaved parmesan pizza (large, of course) and a Peroni Red and I'm in heaven!
FANTASTIC!

Not a better pizza / Italian dining experience out there.  Classy, romantic, warm, family owned type of restaurant.

If I'm anywhere within an hour of this place I make the trip.  It's worth it!  All the pizza's are great; I've had almost all of them.  I'm usually a veggie pizza guy but the meats on these pizzas make me lean the other way, especially the pepperoni.  The veggie-type pizzas can't be beat either.

Desserts: ABSOLUTELY THE BEST TIRAMISU I'VE EVER HAD... EVER!!! (and I've had way too much from just about everywhere).  Unfortunately, I discovered this after going there multiple times because I always ate too much pizza to have dessert.  I've tried a few other desserts and they were good also but the relative goodness of the tiramisu is undeniable.  

Appitizers:  I've tried them all.  The Coo-Coo Clams are very good, and even better, the sauce they're in makes the slightly dry bread you get taste excellent when you dip it in the juice.  The Carpaccio somehow makes eating thinly sliced raw beef taste great.

The only down side is that the sodas come in cans.  I'm a big fan of sucking down about 5 glasses of diet cola with my meals.  Despite this drawback, I somehow feel like fountain drinks could detract from the feel of this restaurant.
Meatballs in spicy tomato sauce  ahhhmazing! My friends and I ordered four different kinds of appetizers and entrees and let me just say every dish ordered was fucking great !!!

I loved the modern feel that this restaurant gives off. You can see the brick oven from your seats. We got the burrata pizza with the pappardelle with napolenta sugo. Both were absolutely fantastic. The burrata on the pizza does drip everywhere, but don't let that deter you from getting it. The pappardelle pasta was incredible. It was fresh and the meat sauce that accompanied it was very tasty! HIGHLY RECOMMEND THIS RESTAURANT.

Food was good, although most of the toppings for my slice slid off when taking it off the serving tray. The topping to crust strength ratio wasn't great.

HOWEVER, music was much too loud, couldn't hear my friends conversation.
Great pizza and super accommodating staff. In my opinion, good people (a good experience) makes the food taste that much better.

5 stars for the food. 1 for the service. Got there late afternoon weekday so wasn't very crowded. Ordered 2 pizzas. Took forever to come & we got no updates along the way. We were getting hungry. Finally the order arrived.. But wait, we got told it was the wrong two pizzas .. Snatched away from the table just as we were about to eat. Some lame excuse about a broken printer in the kitchen... More waiting with no updates. Finally pizzas arrived 45 mins after ordering. Too tired and hungry to complain. Ate & left

Beautiful outdoor ambiance!!! My husband and I came here Sunday night to have a quick bite to eat. The location was quiet and tucked in. He ordered a Coke in the glass bottle and I picked out a beer! We shared a pizza and were not disappointed in the least! Both the host and our waitress were very good and we felt welcomed and relaxed the entire time.

I had lunch here and the service was very disappointing. I ordered the beets and goat cheese salad with chicken. It took forever to be served and when it was, the salad arrived with shrimp, not the chicken that I ordered. I give it three stars because the salad and shrimp were actually quite tasty.
We ordered our 2 pizzas on a Friday at noon and after 45 min still no sign of them. Or bread to wait. Far too long. Good pizzas when they arrived through.

We really wanted some good Italian food and found this place close to our hotel. We were sat immediately and the place was buzzing so I figured it had to be great. It is almost a family style seating where they jam as many people as they can at a table. We were sat at the end of a very long table next to a larger group, I was finding myself looking for a space to put my purse and noticed the majority of women had their purses in their lap which made for awkward eating. I ordered the seafood pasta and we got a margarita pizza as well. The pasta was rather good but the pizza was so so. I'm giving this place 3 stars for the pizza and all around feeling extremely crammed and uncomfortable while eating.
Food and atmosphere is great but manager (Shawn) isn't. They aren't very family friends. The owner should look into the attitude and behavior of the manager Shawn.

Amazing pizza, best in the city that we have found so far.  Better than A16.  Everything tastes great, customer service is good, but lacks value on first courses.  Need to be a little bigger or cost less.  Obviously they are doing well because they are always busy!  Monday nights seemed to be easy to get in but plan on at least an hour and a half wait any other night.  The pizza is worth the wait!

I went to the Pac Heights location and yes there was a wait. As a New Yorker i have a pretty high standard for Pizza but not an inflexible one. There are many great pizzeria''s in the bay area - Pizzaiolo, Little Star, etc.....Pizzeria Delfina is not one of them. To me the sauce is the biggest culprit - it taste's like a budget brand of canned tomato sauce (think from the dented can aisle) and just ends up making the crust soggy. The pizza's are also a little too spartan lacking any kind of visual presentation or flair. The best part of going there to me is the solid Italian sourced wine list which is reasonably priced with many choices. Pizzeria Delfina isn't bad but it's not worth paying the premium to go there and depending on time of day the wait.

5 stars - Mozzarella en Carrozza - one of the most delicious things I've ever eaten. It's a breaded and deep-fried skewer of mozzarrella and bread topped with anchovy sauce. There's some kind of seasoning and in the breading that just makes it divine.

4 stars - Sausage pizza - very good sausage, and the rest of the pizza wasn't shabby.

1 star - crushed red pepper - they give you a sprinkle of crushed red pepper on the plate next to a small mound of parmesan. if you're like me, the amount of crushed red pepper that they give is used on one slice. If you ask for more, they return with a tiny dish of a similar amount of pepper. And if you ask again, they again return with the same amount of pepper. And so on. Is their crushed red pepper expensive or something? And who thought it'd be a good idea to put a sprinkle crushed red pepper in a plate? Vastly inferior technology to the shaker.
I tried a lot of pizza places in the city and I have to say Delfina is still my favorite.

This review is about the poor customer service of the hostess that worked the lunch time on December 15. I walked in as a single and spoke to the first person that greeted me. I asked if I would be able to order and finish my pizza in 45 minutes since I had a doctor appointment nearby. She said yes and I then asked where I could sit. I mistakenly thought she said anywhere including the booth since there were plenty of other tables or the counter. I placed my coat and umbrella in a booth and went to the restroom. When I returned another woman evidently the hostess said I couldn't sit in the booth which was meant for a larger party. Which makes sense and totally understand. I mentioned to her I thought the person who I spoke with (evidently a waitress) said  I could sit anywhere but I was fine in moving. What got me upset as she was walking away she muttered that the waitress never told me that.  Basically calling me a liar. I know she hadn't asked the waitress. I summoned the waitress and asked if I misheard her. She was courteous and said she didn't offer the booth and was just miscommunication. I told her even though I was in the wrong the hostess didn't need to have a condescending attitude and should learn some customer service skills and tact. I have been to this particular location many times and have always enjoyed their pizza and service.  She said she will mention my feelings to the hostess. Other than that the waitress who did serve me provided excellent service and the pizza was great as usual and served quickly. It's a shame that the first person a customer usually see first is the hostess and that greeting can help or ruin the entire dining experience. I'm writing this Yelp review so that management can read my experience and have a one on one with this particular hostess.

- Super noisy with horrible loud music
- Service can be random, good to horrible
- Decent pizza
-over priced
- pathetic crowd
Very solid pizza for SF. Chocolate gelato is really great too.

Not much more can be written about Delfina's pizzas - even if those in Pac Heights seem to lack some of the magic of the original Mission location. It's a great addition to the neighborhood.
