For desert, try ordering both the fried pizza dough drizzled with marscaponé and some chocolate covered vanilla gelato. We combined them and it made for a great, serendipitous desert.

Supposed to be "Third is a charm"??
My third experience in Delfina was more than dissapointing!

The "Margherita pizza" was dry and didn't see or taste any mozzarella cheese, 'Clam Pie" had only 5 pieces of diced clams for $17.00 and the dough was very dry. "Insalata Tricolore" were so salty, couldn't tast anything else and it certainly not was tri-color,
I think they became too popular too fast, they don't care for the quality??
I regret that I ever recommended the restaurant to my friends.
had sausage pizza and meatballs pizza was good meatballs needed a little help

Tl; dr; the pizza is ok, but they're kind of assholes

The pizza is decent. I'll be honest, I don't like clams. The rest of their pies are ok, but I'd recommend Tony's, Little Star, Delfina, Zachary's (East Bay), Delarosa, and some others over Golden Boy. Probably top 15 in San Francisco. A solid 3 stars if it were only the pizza I was rating.

The service is why they deserve 1 star. We waited 45 minutes until they told us, as we walked up to the window, that they were closed. Why couldn't they tell us, 45 minutes earlier, that we'd likely not be able to get pizza? Even 15 minutes? I'm not even asking for a guarantee; just a "we're running low" warning ... It's not required, but it would have been a nice thing for them to do.

Anyway, I'm personally not a fan of Golden Boy. They're golden only because they're open late; not because of their pizza or their manners.
Must Try. The line is well worth waiting in. The clam and garlic pizza is absolutely the best pizza on the menu. I would have gone for more than one slice if I knew how incredible it was.

The pizza itself is average. I had a slice of the Clam & Garlic pizza and the Pepperoni pizza. Both were FRESH out the oven and I was really surprised to find out that the pepperoni tasted much better. I definitely had high expectations since so many people raved about this place. Not a bad joint at all though. Nice people, average pizza.

Still as good as it gets. I had it again for the first time in a while and it was so good!! It doesn't matter what slice you choose, you'll love it. It's quick, cheap, and the ultimate meal. It's truly a gem and the ultimate drunchies choice. I was craving it after that first time, I forced my coworkers to come with me (not really, I merely suggested it and everyone agreed that it was the best choice any of us had made in weeks). They were so impressed and happy with our choice that we literally were sitting at the bar 2 bites into our slices and we begged the workers to allow us to quickly purchase another slice because we didn't want the slice of heaven to stop. All in all, an amazing little shop and I can not wait for my next slice!
Great pizza, a real SF original!!! Unreal staff, history, and delicious pizza, well worth any wait! Da bes!!!

We went to a nearby bar to celebrate my roommate's birthday and when everyone bounced, we made our way naturally to get pizza!

I'm so glad Golden Boy was a 1-minute walk away from that bar or else we would've ended up at some mediocre pizza joint. When we arrived, like any tasty place in SF, there was an expected line on the sidewalk. I like lines, I can reflect on life or really debate on which pizza to get. I ended up doing the latter.

My beau ordered some green pizza with clams on it and I opted for a combo and a pepperoni. I'm the fatty in our relationship and it's ok. My other roommate also opted for two slices and she ended up reheating the second slice the next morning (I was jealous!) I wish I ordered extra for leftovers sake because it was so good!

Probably my favorite pizza spot in SF!

This place is an awesome pizza place!
Golden Boy Pizza definitely stands out. They have a unique style of square slices with fresh ingredients is definitely worth a try. Since this place is popular The line can get long but it moves fairly quickly. Your best choice is to grab a slice for about 4 bucks. A whole sheet will set you back 30-40.

Came to San Francisco with three hungry boys so I wanted something filling and good while not breaking the bank.  I Googled "cheap eats in SF" and found this place.  

Let's start with the pizza.  The crust was focaccia bread and served square.  Very generous with the toppings and very flavorful.  The service was fast and very friendly.  The only drawback I found was the parking around there is insane.!  I ended up parking in some spots marked for motorcycles.  There's a line that stretches out the door and down the sidewalk but it appears to move fairly quickly.  I ordered a sheet (whole pizza) over the phone and was instructed to bypass the line and just pay up front.  

All in all, I consider this one of my golden finds while here and would definitely come back again and again..!

Loved everything about this place!!! Great friendly service. I'm a vegetarian and had the vegetarian pesto, my husband had the sausage.

Delicious !!!! Highly recommend

This is my favorite pizza in the country. It's SO Good. Whenever we are in line, if we go at night, people always ask us if it's worth the wait... oh yes, it is :) we are living in LA right now and we usually drive straight to Golden Boy when we pull in to the city every other month or so.

It's cash only so make sure you're prepared. The slices are big, square pieces. We get the cheese and they're about $3.50 each. I want to say a whole sheet is about $40. Enjoy!
Escape from bad pizza places by going HERE, Escape From New York Pizza! U SAY POTATO, I love you so much. Keep doin what you do and satisfy my tastebuds.
this is really good regular pizza (as opposed to gourmet like delphina and little star). you can get pieces by the slice. im a huge fan of the potato and roasted garlic kind.

For the price of a slice of pizza I think this gives you a decent experience. I didn't particularly think it was reminiscent of New York Pizza, but when there is nothing else open at 2AM this place hits the spot. During that time, they stop serving pies and you would have to start ordering by the slice. The line for this place is also slightly lengthy as you will have to wait 15 minutes to get your order in. I had the pepperoni pizza, and I was satisfied.
had the pesto pizza, just a slice, for all my efforts of walking today.  it was very tasty.

The pizza is pricey, but is really pretty solid. Ive searched for the best pizza in SF, and Escape From New York comes up short, but just because they have multiple locations don't underestimate them. The pesto, potato, and garlic pizza is fantastic. Always a solid place to stop and get a slice!

i've found the haight st store to be quite inconsistent on quality. sometimes under-done, sometimes good.   on the whole, the chain is "mediocre" NY-style pizza (no integration between toppings and crust; poor foldability; too much sauce), but waaaaaaay better than North Beach or some of the alternatives.
this is pretty good, thin style pizza. fast by-the-slice turnover so the pizzas are usually fresh. i really like the potato garlic pizza. i have never ordered a whole pizza, but the slices are good.

This place is seriously overrated.  I had high hopes when I moved into the neighborhood for a good NY-style pizza joint, but to no avail.  The ingredients aren't great, the pizza usually swims in oil, and the crust is often undercooked when you order a whole pie.  The slices taste a lot better because they retoast them in the oven.  Plus, it's super overpriced.  Almost four bucks for a slice!  Come on now.

the potato/garlic pizza is deeeeelish, and totally worth the sketch neighborhood.  if you're eating there, bring a jacket cuz it's always really cold for some reason.  and although it's about $4 a slice, they're GIGANTIC.  they take up a whole dinner plate.  and this is just me, but i really appreciate the fact that every single time i've put a tip in the jar, someone has made a point to say "thank you" to me.  right on.

This is some straight up terrible pizza.  It was really greasy and I don't think it was real cheese.  If this was real cheese, they somehow manipulated it to turn into a disgusting slab of slop.  After eating it I thought, meh, that wasn't bad.  About 2 hours later I thought I was going to have a heart attack and die.  Something in that pizza did not mix well with me.  Needless to say, I will not be returning.  The best thing about this place is its location, but personally I'd rather see a different restaurant here.

What a total mess. DONT'T EVER GET ANYTHING TO GO. They will guarantee to get it wrong and blame you. This is the second time our to-go order has been a mess. I will contact the business with my concerns, as this place has been going down the hill with service and needs to revamp its employees, as our to-go order was not ready when they said(25m) it will be and kept telling us, it will be ready in few minutes, especially after we paid. Instead of telling the truth that they forgot or haven't started the order, we were told 3 times that our order will be ready in minutes, while waiting another 10 to 15m, we saw the employee tell another employee to prepare our to-go order. Why even have a to-go setup if you have to wait that long after one places an order. And, how about telling the truth, instead of making customers wait with false hope of only few minutes.

I admit that I let a couple of years pass without visiting this busy place. I'm glad I went back to check it out.

They have quite a few styles of pizza now - various oven types and temperatures, but my favorite is the classic Napolitan Margherita. I promised myself that I will branch out and try the other styles as well, but if you love pizza, you should start there.

Weekends are super-busy, but my Thursday visit went well, a few seats were available without waiting.

Pro tip: If you visit on Tues/Wed/Thurs or Sunday - you might meet their newest manager - Michele Di Rocco, one of the best italian hosts in SF. His superpower is to make every visit a special occasion, and every guest feel like family.

I'm not sure what I did with the photos I took I attach the one I could fine. We absolutely love this place every time we're in town we try to go. No matter what pizza we've had her or appetizer we've never had a bad one would definitely recommend if you're a pizza lover. I don't remember how many pizza ovens he has but I think it's at least five different ones that cook a different temperatures which allows you to have many different styles and options.

My boyfriend and I came and got takeout for his birthday here! Oh my goodness, the pizza is insane! We got the NY 20 Margherita and the flavor profile is nothing like I've ever tasted before! First off the pizza is enormous, the pizza itself has a sweet and savoriness to it, and I love love love that they don't go ham on the basil. I do feel like many restaurants tend to just throw ingredients on their pizzas but this particular pizza is definitely handcrafted and it truly tasted like an incredible amount of thought was put into the recipe.

LOVE THEIR SPIN ON PIZZA OF THE DAY!

their kabocha and some'in some'in that I had a couple of weeks ago made me want to sing. and i never sing.

lalalalalalalalal - go to arizmendi's and grab a solidly good bite to eat!

Best scones in the world! I once flew 3000 miles for 2 nights in SF and went straight to Arizmendi to get an Oat Scone (small currants, lots of crunchy whole oats), and a Corn Cherry scone (like cornbread with dried, sweet cherries covered with a layer of sugar?). I like sugar! What can I say?
I also come here all the time for the Pizza.
The Cheeseboard coop in Berkeley is and older business, but apparently shared the recipes because they are a co-op and nice like that. However, I think Arizmendi has perfected the recipes and offers even better pizza!

Everything here is stellar. They do a wide range of baked goods including standard (but delicious) breads, scones, and cookies as well as seasonal variations of each and some amazing focaccia and pizzas. Like others have said, be ready to wait in line but it generally moves very quickly.

** UPDATE** Went to the store finally. Chocolate cake? I had thought it couldn't get better than the cherry corn scones. I was sooooo wrong.

I have never been here to the actual store. My coworker, however, goes every Thursday morning in order to provide us minions with buttery, 700 calorie each mounds of sweet heavenly goodness. I usually eat three. Sometimes I try to be good and still end up eating three. Now, I'm not too picky when it comes to things with sugar in them, but this stuff is fabulous!

Probably the best pizza I have ever had! Highly recommend this place for a delicious lunch and dinner. Gluten free bread sticks were surprisingly very good as well. Service is great and fun atmosphere! Plenty of outdoor seating. Only complaint is the bathroom line is extremely long at all times of the day. Other than that it was a perfect experience!

If you're planning on dining at Tony's, your best bet is to (1) come in for a late lunch or early dinner, (2) put your name down and then explore the area for 1-2 hours, or (3) just don't go. Seriously, if you're in a rush or just in need of a quick bite, this place is not for you. Tony's pizzas are meant to be enjoyed, and the crazy long waits ensure you'll have to work for that pleasure.

But waiting there is half the trouble. If you have the misfortune of driving to Tony's and need to park somewhere, you will end up circling the area for quite some time before you get lucky. I can't believe there's no parking lots readily available in the area... Oh, San Francisco, how cruel you can be...

The actual food, once it's finally your turn to sit, is delicious. Huge and delicious. I've had the Little Italy Salad for $12, the Tartufo Pizza for $26 (mozzarella, goat cheese, mushrooms, truffles, prosciutto, and arugula), and the New Haven Lou Pizza with meatballs for $30 (mozzarella, ricotta, spinach, garlic, and red peppers). Pricey, which is to be expected. The Little Italy Salad was your typical house salad, with a few extra elements like chopped olives, walnuts, gorgonzola, and cherry tomatoes.

The pizzas had a thinner crust and were both so filling. The New Haven Lou is especially huge -- like 16 inches -- and meant to serve 2-4 people. Definitely take your leftovers home, as they're just as good the next day.

Also note that they are closed on Tuesdays. Otherwise, they're open  noon-10pm on Mondays and noon-11pm on any other day.

Got the Coal Fired Don Giovanni, the sauce was amazing and the pizza yummm!
Dropped in too late, couldn't add the chicken parm though.
Great place for outdoor dining too.

Nothing about Tony's is as it was. I have noticed a steady decline over past 2 years. Is it because of all the other restaurants he opened that this place has gone downhill. It used to have a fun vibe. Italians running the place. Fun bartenders and staff. Good beers etc. now........ just another pizza place in a sea of pizza places in SF. Will definitely be looking for a new place to get our pizza fix. Don't let all the reviews and stars trick you  it's all hype now.

Four stars, because the cheese bread I had was a three star, and the currant scone was five stars!  I am a scone officianado and when I move to SF I will definitely make this one of my stops for scone cravings.  I really want to try the traditional oat scone because now I know they are professionals at this place (they definitely did not scimp on the cream in the batter....bueno!)  
Clearly however this is not a place to stick around in too long, because it is quite cramped, but for an in and out trip it is perfect.

I am late to the game and I think the game has been over for a while??

We arrived on a busy Sunday afternoon for a midday nosh. We picked up some focaccia, cheese bun, crumb cake, and a piece of pizza. I got a cup of drip coffee.

The focaccia was alright. The cheese bun was overtly oily and not very tasty. It was even on the stale side- hard to bite into.

While the pizza was good it soooooooo oily. It was dripping into my plate.

The best was the crumb cake. But nothing really to write home about.

My coffee was awful. The Ethiopian brand is just atrocious. Couldn't even take a second sip.

Maybe we got something weird? Maybe it was an off day? But we don't get this place...

By far the best bakery I have encountered. Tons of people flock to this spot for fresh local baked good and pizza. The constantly offer new and delicious scones, muffins, breads, cheeses and pizzas.

The pizzas are topped with the freshness of local produce. Only one type of pizza is offered but you can't go wrong. They all truly taste unreal. You can call ahead to place a pizza order, along with a specific pick-up time.

Once, I was sitting in Arizmendi bakery, having a happy pizza lunch, and there was a gap in the music, a cd obviously come to its end. A moment of silence, and then I heard the opening of the first track from Ruby Vroom. I looked my slice of pizza, and turned to Benjy S, and said, "If someone wearing Tom Ford walks in that door, I think my head will explode, from everything I love being in the same room."

Everything has been said, mostly; wonderful pizza and bread and treats from wonderful people. I take the train for twenty minutes just to get a scone. Also, one of the cheapest places in the city to buy fancy cheese, though their selection is (naturally) less than cousin co-op (and my first love) the Cheese Board.

Cruised in and got myself a $1 breadstick the other day....just what I wanted!

Also, I saw that on election day, you can come in and get free Election Day Sugar cookies! But the only way to get them is to show your voting stub!

I think that is pretty rad. Hey people, if you're not gonna vote on your own, at least do it for free cookies!
Ordered the meatballs and the coal-fired New Yorker. The meatballs were excellent and so was the pizza. Little bit of spice on the pepperoni and it had a great crust. Come with an appetite!

1 star good Italian food in sf.
1 star friendly service
1 star many Italian food options on menu.

This bakery is outstanding. The pizza is terrific and baked good are always wonderful.

My favorite savories are the zampanos, the special pizza, and the focaccias. My favorite sweets are the cherry corn scone, the currant scone, the oat scone, and usually whatever fresh fruit pastry they have is wonderful.

My only gripe is it's cash only. And for those who are confused- this is the exact same thing as the place on Lakeshore in Oakland. Same place, same stuff. I've never noticed a difference in taste or quality and I've been to both locations many times

I saw this place listed in Sunset  magazine and ... being a tourist ... the out of the way location appealed to me because I was looking for something that felt authentic San Francisco.  
I hopped on a bus across town, expected a long wait (from previous yelp reviews) and as I walked block after block to get to the location, I hoped that I didn't just waste a lot of my vacation time getting to and from this place.  I wasn't disappointed.
Luckily a couple tables opened up outside - where i quickly jumped at the one under the best heat lamp!  the little lights dangling under the tree in the sidewalk, as well as the stack of blankets available to anyone while waiting, created a cozy atmosphere that was totally enjoyable.  Inside it looked like there were only a few tables, but I was very happy sitting outside.
The pizza was excellent.  Thin crust and kind of healthy feeling! Both the pepperoni and mozza/tomato/basil were excellent and there were no doggie bags to carry around afterwards.
Pizzetta 211 will always be in my memory not only for how great the food and ambience was, but because it was also my first location ever having blue bottle coffee...
I'd say it's worth the trip from where ever you are.
The best pizza pie on the West Coast. Authentic all the way.

wow.
the combination of all of the flavors. really something magical.
plus the atmosphere was great- very tiny, but i think that added to my enjoyment...
wouldve given 5 stars,- the only downside is that they don't accept credit card.

Great thin crust pizza joint. You'll most likely need to wait for a spot as the restaurant only has 4 tables and a few bar seats. The kitchen is open so you get to see them make the pizza and all the dishes they have to offer. Their pizza selection changes weekly so don't get attached to one. Def a change from the usual large loud restaurants i frequent. Will return soon to try other pizzas.

Because it's been 3 days and I'm still thinking about this meal I feel compelled to write a review. Yes, it's tiny and hipster, but in the most lovable way possible. The farm egg pizza got me to like goat cheese for the first time and the zucchini with toasted almonds, tomatoes, and some unfamiliar cheese (waiter could use some tips on cheese descriptions as he descibed it only as "salty", but I was sold) was absolutely amazing. The wax bean special was an amazing combination of ingredients I would have scoffed at putting together.  Now I'm a fan that has to drive to the Richmond for pizza.

Yes! Feel very fortunate that Pizzetta is in the neighborhood... we are remodeling the kitchen so when we want to feel like we are having a home cooked meal, we come here... great little spot, probably the best pizza in the City, or at least top 3, not many seats... I wish they could limit the service to the Richmond district!

This place makes the Richmond seem charming. Pizza with egg and very salty ham was sublime. The sausage pizza with nuts was overwhelmed by sweet mushrooms. Service was kooky and scattered, but generally sweet. We sat outside, in low 60s, and were comfortable for dinner under the space heaters.

This place has the best thin crust pizza around.    Parking is a bit of problem and the place is kind of a hole in the wall.   Beware, they only take cash.  No credit cards and no freezer.   Everything is fresh.
I love this place. Amazing pizza and decent wine way out in the avenues.

Great neighborhood gem for farm-fresh California style pizza.  Side salads just as delicious.

rosemary with egg lamb sausage mint pizza
Try the butternut squash sage pizza

We stopped in for a quick pre show dinner and thoroughly enjoyed our food.  The pizza buffolina I think it was called and the lasagna.
I loved the pizza but the lasagna was off the charts.  Without question the best lasagna I've ever eaten!  It was food that you get as a diner and feel gratitude for afterwards.  
The flavor of tomato was so warm and welcoming and the bolognese mixed with it perfectly.  
Bravo!
This is my go to pizza place in the city! Way better than Tony's, the wait is never too long and the pizza is incredible. I try to restrain myself to go only once a week ;) !
Very tight space and the service was mediocre but the food was great exactly what we were looking for some authentic Italian food ! The service can be a little friendlier and welcoming

Not a place to go if you're really hungry. While the pizzas are certainly tasty - they're thin and tiny.  We left there hungry - and at the price we paid, that should not have been the case!  Also not the best place if you're claustrophobic - they squeeze as many people in there as they can - very little room to move once you're in your seat.

Absolutely incredible food and experience. We came on a Sunday night and got sat immediately. We sat at their beautiful bar so that we could watch the pizzaiolo make the pizzas. We started with the Buffala mozzarella and the green olives. The mozzarella tasted fresh and exactly like it would taste in Italy. We ordered the margherita pizza and the uovo pizza and drizzled them both with their homemade pepperoncini oil. This is the most authentic pizza you're going to find outside of Italy. It was incredible, and the dough was chewy and puffy, just the way I like it. The ingredients were fresh and simple, all of the flavors came together perfectly. I was in pizza heaven. They also have a really interesting wine list, with a lot of Italian wines that are worth trying.

I really like what they did with the space and the food can't be beat. The pizza is incredibly authentic and the prices are so reasonable. I will only be ordering pizza from Il Casaro from now on.

3.5 stars rounded up to 4 stars.

Whenever we go to Italian Pizzeria, we order Margherita to compare Margheritas.

Their Margherita was so much better than the over rated (in my opinion) Tony's Napoletana down the street, but not even close to Delfina's.

We'll be back to try some other items on the menu.

Came in on Wednesday March 26th, 2014 around 9:45 PM and got an empty seat at the bar. My server, David Y, came by to take my order of an Anchor Steam for $5 plus Proscuitto Pizza for $17 for $22 overall plus tax or $23.93 plus tip.

I sat at the counter for awhile awaiting my drink as numerous employees passed over a 15 minute period. Finally, one of the kitchen staff members who was cooking right in front of me asked if I had placed my order and I mentioned that the server had taken it. It appears that the server forgot to put in my order which was a reason for the decline in stars in this review.

Overall, the pizza was quite tasty and spot on especially compared to Una Pizza Napoletana for example at the price point. I'd recommend if in the area.

came here for late dinner and glad they were able to seat us this time around before last call. they're open until 11 on weeknights and 12 on weekends

ordered:
-arancini: good but i've had better ones
-croquette: liked this better than the arancini
-il casaro: mozzarella, grana padana, cremini mushroom, proscuitto crudo
-broccoli and salsiccia: scamorza cheese, broccoli rabe, itialian sausage

we were able to get half and half pizza.. the pizza is great for 2. full but not uncomfortable. if you're super hungry you can eat one pizza by yourself, almost a personal pizza size. there are 6 slices.

great food and everything is really affordable.

i liked that i heard a several different groups speaking italian. always a good sign when italians are eating at a italian place.

if you can't come in, they deliver through caviar and postmates.

can't wait to come back and try the rest of the menu

In my opinion this pizza restaurant is better than tony's - value for money in any case! We come here a lot and it's perfect and cozy whether alone, with one friend or ten. They take reservations and make things happen for you - even last minute.
When you come here next, try their starters too - we love the mozzarella, meatballs ...

High quality really authentic Italian food. I have lived in north beach for three years and  have also traveled to Italy and this restaurant stands out in the bunch. Come here if you love and admire the simplicity of Italian cuisine- the way it should be. AMAZING mozzarella!!!

This place is good for sure.  Although, I was coming in here expecting the place to be better than Windy City in San Mateo - and I didn't think it was.  I ordered the garlic bread, and was unpleasantly surprised when it was actual baked cloves of garlic to spread on slices of bread.  Where is the grease?  I'm sorry, garlic bread should not taste healthy.  They should rename the garlic bread to be called "baked garlic cloves".

The pizza was very flavorful and the crust was nice and crispy.  I haven't had authentic Chicago style pizza, but I am now curious to try it to see for myself how this place stands up against it.

There was a long wait for a weekday night.  They said it'd be an hour wait, and it only took 30 minutes.  They've got a small bar that you can get some beers while you wait though, so it wasn't that bad.  They also have take-out, so that is an option.

Even if sprecks of grizzled pepperoni wax played hooky from my roommates half to my off limits quadrant, the heaping veggie commando fired back in flavor, gusto, size and overall presentation. The vegan precinct was not held back by a goddamn thing, the absentee dairy digestive inhibitor would have actually prevented elation emancipation.

I sway you not in vain: anyone get the veggie, minus cheese plus spinach and you there is such a notion that you will experience asymptomatic recognizance for at least 25 minutes. That sauce, that crust, garlic infused foliage............ this some smack ya momma grub, straight up. Less hours in a hospital bed never appeared so feasible!

p.s. The bill ain't gonna lower though, thats where the last star is hiding. No matter the star size, the shit's a splurge trouffe. Take your helping, shut up, and save up for the next brilliant installment.

I really don't understand the bad reviews. Sure, maybe you caught one of the employees on a bad day or mom didn't make you Mickey Mouse shaped pancakes this morning so your day was off to a terrible start but I can't think of one thing wrong with this place. Well, it felt slightly cramped but, it's in San Francisco-- what do you expect?

The pizza here is awesome, plain and simple. I'm not one of those "pizza experts" from Chicago, or New York or whatever who claims that a pizza joint isn't as good as that hole in the wall Greasy Eddie's on the corner of 5th and Pretentious in some slum on the east coast. All I know is this pizza is good. Really good.

I, of course, went with the deep-dish style because after I tried that, I never thought of thin crust again. The deep-dish crust is probably the best part of the pizza. I had a veggie pizza with spinach, garlic, and mushrooms--- perfect. The sauce, while it could stand a few more spices thrown in, was also perfect. I used to be a die-hard Patxi's fan but that might be changing...

The garlic bread-- what can I say about this garlic bread... they give you a sourdough roll sliced. In a separate container you get butter and olive oil whipped together and then a whole BULB of roasted garlic. You spread it all on the bread yourself and it is glorious. I think I liked it even more than the pizza to be honest.

The beer is a little overpriced but, beer and pizza is like PB and J so, I had to go for it anyway.

The atmosphere and service were awesome. We hardly waited at all for anything to come out after we ordered it and we were seated within 2 minutes. Granted, it was a Thursday evening so I don't know what the weekends are like but, still impressive.

The dark and velvety atmosphere is perfect. Although you are fairly exposed and close to everyone else, it doesn't really feel like it. It is both communal and intimate.

As for parking... again, it's San Francisco. Take the bus or walk.
.

Honestly, I didn't want to like this place.  Ratings this high for a pizza joint in San Francisco?  Unheard of.  Really.  Is it because we don't have good pizza in this city???  No.  I can appreciate quality pizza just as much as the next person.  Is it because we have have a bunch of pizza snobs (I like to call them PS's) amongst us?  More likely, eh.  I'm not going to lie.  I really wanted to give this place a scathing review just to knock some PS's on their asses.  But ... I can't, dammit.  Instead, this pizza knocked ME on MY ass.  I'm not even a huge fan of deep dish, and the pizza here was ... hmmm... delectable.  It's a good thing that Little Star is a nice, longish walk from my house.  Walk it off, baby, walk it off :)

The inside of the place is fun too ... good jukebox, kinda dark.

Always good, but never blown away.

It's funny, we as Californians are just so damned spoiled... my classic story is being in Chicago for a week and going to a different deep dish pizza place every day, from a list compiled by natives and long-time deep-dish freaks... I was never wowed. Don't get me wrong, it's deep dish and as Stephen Baldwin said, "Even when it's bad, it's still pretty good."

But those delightful pies were still missing something, even on their hometurf. When you have "Chicago-style deep dish" at Little Star or Zachary's, for example, the ingredients taste fresher, the pie is less oily, and the whole experience is just overall... tastier.

Now, to touch upon the Zachary's vs Little Star face-off. Not necessary. They're two different styles of deep dish, and although inherently stem from the same wonderful Chicago origin, they're tough to compare, much less compete. Little Star is much more like its Chicago roots than Zachary's -- it's a little more shallow and has flattened the ingredients internally -- some purists actually prefer that, as they think Zachary's is "too jumbly in there," allowing the extra ingredients to hop around too much.

The real difference, however, is the crust. Little Star has that cornmeal crust... that's really what it comes down to. If you prefer that, you're a Little Star fan 'til the end. But if you prefer a more traditional wheat crust while still prefering the "Chicago-style" to ACTUAL Chicago, then Zachary's is the place for you.

LONG story short, Little Star is delish, just not my preference. Can't we all just get along?

Little Star's pizza is freaking delicious!  I especially like the signature Little Star deep dish; their regular crusts are aiiight, but, if you ask me, deep dish is the way to go here.  The sauce they use is something heavenly and their pizza tastes great the next day for breakfast!

The service is great too.  Great place to come with no more than 4 people, please!  That's my one gripe about the place: there is ALWAYS a wait.  It is well worth it though.

Best deep dish pizza, EVER!! Try the brass monkey it's not on the menu, but it's the little star with sausage added and it's quite delicious!

Fun Tip: This place is cash only, but the fee on their ATM is only 25 cents!! How awesome is that?

After hearing great things from co-workers about both the thin/regular crust and deep-dish pizzas we figured we should try LIttle Star...

We had a friend visiting from Chicago, and while he passed approval on the regular pie, the deep-dish was not up to (his) snuff.

Conversely, my boyfriend and I thought the deep dish was tasty (not the best either of us has ever tried) but the thin crust was waaaaay too cornmealy. The texture was much too grainy.

Overall, the experience was OK. Not great, not terrible. Just OK. And a little pricey.

Oh and their website says they deliver. They do not. You have to call a bike messenger service which charges an additional $6(?) dollars. Not worth it.

Weird a 4 star review from me.  I know, right!?

The pizza was delicious and while not quite as filling as some of the other reviews indicate it was still filling.  The crust was awesome, the cheese plentiful and gooey, the sauce was just good.

I would skip the 9" pizza even if ordering just for yourself.  I read the other reviews that made each slice sound gargantuan and should have known better.  Typical of most yelp reviewers they were delusional.  The slices are plenty filling, but I ate all but 1 slice of the 9" pizza.  Not leaving me enough to satisfy the next day.

LSP had a decent ambiance but again the delusional here seem to think it is a great date spot.  I would avoid taking a date here, at least not if you haven't been dating a while.  This place is to noisy to have any kind of conversation or to get to know someone without yelling.

The service was pretty good.  They were friendly and didn't mess my order up(something I consider to be a required minimum not worthy of a star), but i called ahead for pick up and was told it would be 30 minutes.  It took just shy of 40.  It wasn't a horrible delay and I was in no rush and would rather get the pizza late and just from the oven than have it only take 20 and be ten minutes old when I show up to pick it up.  That said many of the reviews here indicate that they are busy and they should have been able to anticipate based on how busy the place was when I showed up that it would take more than 30 minutes.

The pizza was not cheap, but was more filling than the usual 'Za and was delicious.  If you are on a budget or just looking for something cheap it's not the place for you.  Not cheap but a decent value for the fillingness and delicousness of the pizza.

If you are the typical yelper you would probably consider this a 5 star place.  Unfortunately I have standards and believe 5 stars actually means something.
Great service. Called in for a Togo order and she answered all my questions and helped us figure out what pizza would fit our needs. We are excited to try the classic and original pizzas.

i can't speak to the pizza, which everyone seems to rave about, but i can go on about the lasagna.  can you say amazing?  i truly love lasagna, and  unfortunately, it is rarely up to par, but these folks have the touch.

note: if you are getting take out like i was, shove ahead of the line, smile at the kindly italian man who seems to act as host, and he'll take care of you quick!

If you can find parking and a place to sit this is the PLACE for good OLD WORLD Italian Pizza! This is the closest to east coast pizza my family and I have found. I love how thin the crust is and the freshness of the ingredients and when you walk in you can just smell the heaven of awesomeness of their meatballs and pizzas! They have a old style fire oven which makes you really feel like your back in time. The antipasto platter is great especially if you love proscuitto like I do. The decor is old and you see the old tablecloths like in the godfather and that always makes me smile.

My friend recommended this place, said he's heard a lot about this place but never had a chance to check it out, so last night we came here with a small group of friends. Knowing that it's located in the Northbeach area, u know that parking is going to take forever, and the wait was going to be forever too. We got here at around 8 on a Friday night and had to wait for around 45min.

The restaurant itself is a bit small but pretty cozy. It's not fancy but gives you a warm and family-esque feeling. The waiters are also very nice. Between the 5 of us, we shared:

+ANTIPASTO: prosciutto with all kinds of meet. very tasty cuz i've always been a fan of this dish. Has a good amount, I'd say perfect for a group of 5-6ppl.
+FRIED CALAMARI: veryyyy delicious!! they fry it JUST RIGHT and just tastes super fresh and yummy! Definitely highly recommended to get as an appetizer!
+DELUXE PIZZA: their pizzas are definitely the highlight of this place. they've got a huge selection, and considering we had a bigger group, we decided to get the one with everything on it. The bread is medium thick and the ingredients were very delicious. Could have used a bit more cheese but I'd definitely say that they make VERY GOOD PIZZAS!
+SPAGHETTI WITH CLAMS IN WHITE SAUCE: we substituted the linguini with spaghetti. This dish was very delicious, but I'd say that their pastas aren't the greatest, and they're not very big portions either. The clam sauce was very yummy, it was what made this pasta.
+MACARONI WITH SAUSAGE & MUSHROOMS: the sausage was veryyyy delicious, but I'm not a fan of their macaroni. expected it to be cooked more to be warmer and softer, but it was a bit on the hard end. didn't quite meet my expectations.

These 5 things definitely stuffed us up like crazy. Their pizzas are pretty big and definitely what I recommend the most. I would say that I'm slightly disappointed that they don't give you oil and vinegar for the bread. Most italian restaurants would have that. Everything is pretty good here, but I'm a bit surprised that it has an average of 4.5 stars. It was good but didn't really meet my expectations. Would still come back though, the prices are pretty decent.

We waited two hours for a table.  There is no place to sit while you wait so we stood for two hours.... It really wasn' t worth it.  My spinnach salad was very good but not amazing.  Pizza was ordinary enough.  Nothing very good about this place.  Because of the lack of comfort and other people waiting, you feel rushed while you eat.

I have been recommending Tommaso's for several years and have never had anyone come back with anything, but fantastic reviews. Yes it defines hole in the wall and yes you will probably have to sit at the big table right next to people you have never met. The staff and owners are great and the food is .I am very surprised to see that no one seems to be mentioning getting complimentary vino while waiting on the little stairs at the entrance for your seats. This is a great place for small groups of two or four and a great place to take visitors from out of town for an old school SF experience that they will take with them and always remember. 5 Stars, Va Molto Bene! Mangia!

I have been wanting to go to Tommaso again since a long time( I had been there 5 years ago and did not exactly remember much).

We reached there at 6:15 PM on a Sunday and there was a 1 hour wait:(.
The place is so small and there were so many people waiting that it was almost a fire hazard.

We walked around on North Beach and decided to eat somewhere else...but I was determined to eat Tomasso's as part of my  pilgrimage( I am trying to eat at all the top pizza places in SF).

After a long wait we finally got a very nice table. We ordered a veggie assortment as appetizers and that was decent however not worth the 16 bucks.

We are vegetarians and ordered one veggie pizza, the veggie special of the day(arugula) and the garlic,oregano pizza.

The first two pizzas were very average...the only good pizza was the garlic,oregano pizza..it has the right amount of spices and was very tasty.

I personally think the place was a little over-rated...though not bad.

I am not a big fan of the NY style pizza and this place fails to impress me. I might eat here again if there is no wait and I am in the area...but no coming here again specially!

My family has been coming here since it was Lupo's. The menu has barely changed in 80 years and is consistently amazing.  The wait is well worth it-- I always feel like I'm being welcomed by the Italian family I always wished I had growing up! Carmen is the absolute best! Everyone here is wonderful and friendly :)

I haven't tried to many Italian restaurants in SF, but I'm sure glad this gem showed up early in the search.  As a New Yorker, I take my pizza seriously, and I have to admit, Tommaso's has turned into one of my benchmarks.  Please don't tell anyone I actually admitted that...

oooooooooooomg amaaaaaaazing.
i loooooooove tommasos!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
been a fan foooooreeeeeeeever.

get #10. best pizza they have. i order it eeeeeeevery time.

the staff is awesome. so welcoming. so friendly. if you dont know what to order they will help you. AWESOMENESS.

every time i go there. order a bottle a wine. maybe a salad if were hungry but we only get the pizzas. heaven in your mouth i can probably eat the prosciutto everyday. it is hella good!!!!!!!

theyre closed during the holidays. so sad. i need it now!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

Absolutely delicious and great wine as well, but there is ALWAYS a wait. There are so many other great Italian restaurants in North Beach and I am probably the most impatient person ever when it comes to food, so I am not sure I will be coming back very often. They definitely need to expand since there are more people in line than there are actually eating.
Coolest, sincere bartenders, always make us feel welcomed as though we are coming back to friends. Great cocktails and price point for food and quality of drinks is the best in the neighborhood

Very good food and great service.  Someone knows what they're doing. Hopefully, the owners take care of the upper management because that's who sets the standards and makes it happen. If the owners don't, that team will be scooped up by the competition or start their own restaurant. Thanks to the entire staff for spoiling us!

Yum yum! This place is so good and the ambiance is very nice. I was walking down chestnut looking for something to eat and stumbled across this place. I got the sausage pizza and my boyfriend got a panini with the best housemade potato chips I've ever eaten. I can't wait to go back.

The only they didn't have was an affordable wine to go along with the rest of the affordable menu (large pizza $11-14, Panini - $10)

As soon as this place opened, it became my staple.  It is my go-to place whenever friends/family are visiting.  
The pizza's are outstanding.  Pretty interesting combinations.  My favorite so far is the funghi.
Apps I've tried:
Eggplant with burratta- How could you go wrong with burratta?  You CAN NOT!  However, make sure you order a side of bread to go with this, it doesn't come with any.
Beet carpaccio- This is SO GOOD.  Thinly sliced golden and red beets with a shaved goat cheese and a salad of peppery arugula with a citrusy vinaigarette drizzled over it all.

I mostly sit at the bar when I come here- the bartenders are nice- fun to talk to.  They have a pretty good beer list- it's not HUGE, but there are about 25 good beers- about 10 on tap, 15 in a bottle- and I'm pretty sure they rotate them.  My favorite is the Foret Dupont.  YUM!

Everything but the wait is amazing about this place. The dishes have so much flavor and the atmosphere was full of energy (and good looking people). We stuck to all veggie dishes and did our classic over order. Brussel Sprouts, bruschetta, mushroom pizza and eggplant pizza all hit the spot. I cannot wait to get back to this place. So stoked that it's right down the street.

We called in advance and were told the wait was 15 minutes if we came right then. We got there and proceeded to wait for over an hour. But it was well worth it. And the GM Alvin comped us a round of drinks for our efforts which didn't hurt.

Ok, I usually reserve my updates for adding stars, not taking them away, so I am doing this somewhat apologetically.

I still like delarosa, don't get me wrong, but my second visit was not a "i'm a fan" kind of dinner.  it was just A-ok, so i feel the need to update.
The polenta  was not very good at all, the chicken spedini was under cooked- as in pink in the middle still, and the wine pour i got was so wimpy i almost confronted the bartender about it with a point to the glass and a raised eyebrow "really?".  Service was fine and the meatballs were still delicious, so overall: a 3.
sorry delarosa!

Good variety of items.

Fried brussel spouts were good.
I don't like polenta so I can't judge it.
Pasta was just okay.

Pizza was okay.  But on chestnut street, I rather eat at A16.

Been there twice and I have to admit, I'm a fan!

Delarosa does an excellent job of serving up excellent food. Unique, intricate dishes that incorporate various flavors.  I never thought I'd be a fan of fennel or truffles, but after enjoying Fennel sausage pizza and Beet Carpaccio with truffles, I am a changed person.

I agree that the community seating is odd.  You are basically sitting 1 foot away from a complete stranger and sometimes you are sitting across from a stranger too...but I don't think it's a bad thing.  I embrace the community experience.

Besides the Carpaccio of gold and red beets, goat ricotta, truffle, and Sausage Fennel pizza, I also had the Eggplant caponatina with burrata...Good.  Meatballs in spicy marinara...AMAZING!  Prosciutto di Parma, arugula, mozzarella...Good but not as good as Delarosa.

And they have a lot of unique beers on tap.  Take advantage...ask for a sample (or two...or three)!

Great beer selection - they had about 15 microbrews / foreign beers on tap, most of which I'd never heard of before (I had the Drake's IPA and the Linden St. Black Lager - yummy!). Our waitress suggested the crab arancini as a starter, which was delicious.

The pizza was good, not great. We got two pizzas - one with pancetta and broccolini, the other with mushrooms. I'm a fan of thin crust, but Delarosa's crust is actually too thin, such that the middle is completely soggy and difficult to eat. However, the super thin crust works well for leftovers. The next day, after a couple minutes in the toaster oven, the crust was nice and crispy. Probably not the best selling point - Delarosa: decent today, better tomorrow.

Sooo good!!! We ordered the black olive gnocchi, dungeness crab arancini and the fennel sausage pizza with tomato and scamorza.

ALL. SO. GOOD!!!

The one that stood out were the arancini. It was perfectly seasoned, crunchy and had a perfect balance of fresh crab and risotto. Ooh and btw the risotto was cooked perfect too. It wasn't underdone or so overcooked that it turns into an unidentifiable mass.

Pizza was good pizza, gnocchi was def tasty and different.

Sadly I must knock off a star cuz it took them foreverrrrr to seat us, get us menus, water etc. Still going back though. The beer steamed mussels and fava bean bruschetta are still calling my name...

I've been twice in recent months and enjoyed it both times. From the delightful house red (Unti Segromigno) to the simple yet delicious pizzas, I'd highly recommend Delfina. Just be prepared to wait for a table (but they do let you order drinks while you wait...).

Went on a Thurs night and was greeted with a line out the door but I must say this place is worth the wait. Put your name on the chalkboard just inside the door and see all the names waiting for a table ahead of you. Then order a drink at the counter and cozy up next to a tree or parking meter. They will bring it out to you. When you finally get seated enjoy any one of their pizzas.The sausage was my favorite. Can't wait to go again.

I can't even begin to describe how great this place is. I'm a huge fan of Italian food and this place does it for me. It is by far the best Italian food I've ever had. I hate meat balls but their meat balls quickly became my favorite dish on the menu. And don't even start me on the pizza. Thin crust, tasty, and garlicky pizza that will get you addicted, not only to pizza, but to carbs altogether. We did have to wait for them to take our order but not because of lack of service but because they were way too busy. The food is authentic and everything smells like home made. I can't wait to go back. BRAVO!

Underwhelmed by my meal here. After working up an appetite while shopping on Fillmore, I was in the mood for some pizza and was caught in a dilemma -- cheap eat Dino's or fancy, rave reviewed Pizzeria Delfina, two store fronts down. My friend and I opted for Delfina and overall didn't think it was that amazing -- maybe I missed something? Perhaps the hype killed it for me? Got the Saliccia pizza which was all right - the sausages were great, but overall the mozzarella was just okay. Our salad that we started with was overly bitter. We didn't finish either, and I'm typically licking the plate clean.

Delicious pizza and salad. If you want something different, or for an ap, I totally recommend the meatballs. They're probably a million calories but are awesome. Usually the wait is not too long (between 20-45 minutes) depending on the size of your party.

So-so. The pizza didn't have enough cheese on it; there were entire areas without cheese, that sometimes had some other topping (sausage) but often did not. Cheese is the most important part! Disappointing for a pizza place. Also, they don't take reservations, and when we arrived they told us the wait would be around 15 minutes, but really we had to stand around (outside in the cold) for forty minutes. If we'd known, we could have gone somewhere else.

But the rum baba dessert was delicious, and by itself would get 5 stars.
Lucky to live right down the street from this delicious pizza! Downside, lunch on Sunday was an hour wait. Still, I'll go back and wait again!

We ate here for lunch with our two young children. Breadsticks were crunchy and delicious. Prosciutto pie with arugula was very good, and different from anything I had ever seen before on a pizza. I had the sausage which was as greasy as I expected, but also delicious. Our waitress was very friendly and came back to check on us often. We tried the Dublin Dr. Peppers. Fabulous.

I tried the cherry tomato pizza, mushroom and salsiccia all of which were pretty good. I do have to say however that I enjoyed the mushroom pizza from Tony's Pizza far more than that from Delfina's as well as the salsiccia from Caffe BaoNecci. The cherry tomato pizza was also a tad bit watery on top, but overall it's really splitting hairs as there is no doubt that I would eat each and every one of Delfina's pizzas in a heartbeat. Still a place that I would return to without a doubt.

Pretty good service and the pizza was good with reasonable price; however, the wait is way too long.  Their appetizers were just okay though.  Will be back for the pizza.  Maybe I should try the take-out next time.

Thank god I don't live in this neighborhood! I would eat nothing but breads and pastries and pizza....

Everything here is incredible and reasonably priced. My favorites are the cherry cornmeal scones and the daily pizza ($2 for a slice of seasonal thin crust deliciousness!).

Hmm... #5 restaurant on all of Yelp? This is something I need to check out.

Scone of the day, apricot-blackberry, was amazing. Everything looked delicious (well except for the pizza of the day, ewww... mushrooms...).

I'm glad I don't live nearby, otherwise I would be stopping by here all the time.

The best bakery in SF - hands down.  Warm pecan rolls when they come from the oven, are the best.  People that bake / work at Arzimendi's are top notch.

Not a fan of the coffee - they don't keep Equal or Splenda (those aint natural)...and not like there aint sugar in the pecan rolls.

Something not on the menu: Ask for pizza dough to make your own pizza at home.  The dough is well yeasted and has the perfect hint of sourdough tangy-ness.

Yummy!

The brioche knot is so good. It's soft and the sweetness is just right, not too much but a little bit. One brioche knot will fill my tummy. Unfortunately, I didn't try their pizza but I will definitely next time.

Wow!  This place lived up to all of the hype and then some.  Their pizzas are incredible and their bread selection is wide (and delicious!)

I came in here and ordered several slices of the fennel/spinach/balsamic pizza.  It was really tasty, light, and had a great flavor profile.  I really like the model of offering a daily veg pizza.  After I came back from walking around, I wanted to try some of their normal bread- I got an onion bialy and a swiss/tomato focaccia bun, both of which were great.  I wish I was hungry enough to have more, but I had already stuffed myself full of their bread!

The main downside is that inside seating is really limited and the place feels cramped in a way that the Cheese Board in Berkeley doesn't.  Also, my friend's chai tasted harsh and a little off, so I'm a little bit skeptical of their drink selection.

Oh Arizmendi's, how I miss thee!

So enamoured was I of the goodies sold at the co-op, I broke down and bought the cookbook.  I've made countless batches of the currant scone, and have tried my hand at the cornmeal cherry scones a couple of times, but have earmarked a bunch of other recipes to try.

Top 5, in order of favorites:
Brioche knots: a soft bready pastry studded with plump golden raisins and sprinkled with cinnamon sugar. Part of the reason I love it so much is that it's fun to pull apart and consume
Thin sourdough crust pizza: they only serve one kind daily, vegetarian, and it's so delicious you don't mind that there's no meat!
Foccacia: topped with all kinds of roasted goodness, soft and pliable on the inside with a nice cornmeal-studded crust on the bottom.  sold by weight, so it is definitely a great deal!
Cherry cornmeal scones: the cornmeal gives it a pleasant textural heft while the dried cherries' tartness plays against the sweetness of the scone
Currant scone: One of the most popular bakery items sold here.  A great combo of moist scone interior, with a golden, crunchy crust that is liberally sprinkled with cinnamon sugar

The only things I tried that I didn't love were the chocolate things (anything with chocolate chips invariably gets compared to chocolate chip cookies, and is disappointing by comparison) and the fresh seasonal scones.  The latter wasn't as tasty as the dried fruit scones because the fruit burst during baking and made parts of the scone soggy, and tasted sour compared to the sweet scone dough.

Yelp for iPhone is SO COOL!

I'm sitting in a coffee shop on 9th Ave and Irving, and i yelp my iphone to find what's good in tha neighborhood.  One of the highest rated was Arizmendi Bakery. Sounded interesting. So on my way to get the bus  home I walked by there. Then I walked in. Wow. all the pizza things and all the sweet bready things.

I got a slice of focaccia pizza which was still warm, and a "chocolate things" bun.

I'm so happy for this discovery. What a find.

Thx yelpers. And Thanks Yelp for iPhone.

-no lies, just love

-Jj

I just got the half baked pizza of the day to take home - definitely a quality purchase!  Nice and thin sourdough crust that stays chewy on top and brown and crispy on the bottom, topped with an array of veggies and different cheeses.  You might wonder how this thing reheats, but I'll say that it reheats perfectly and there is no sacrifice in taking this beauty home and baking it yourself.  

It's pretty unique from your standard italian pizza place, but it's really good!  You can tell that the ingredients are super high quality and this thing was made with LOVE!  You might be better off calling ahead to let them know you're coming since it's becoming a very popular dinner item, but get over there and try this homemade pizza.  It's special and really good!  They make a different pizza everyday, so check their calendar to see what's up.

Oh why, oh why do I love Arizmendi?

Is it because of their organic coffee or their SPICY chai latte?  Or is it because of their amazing pizzas with sourdough crust?  (By the way - you can now pre-order the crust un-cooked & make your own at home!)

Perhaps its because they make the best sourdough English muffins every day fresh or surprise us with new treats like fresh tabbouleh salad (every Thursday)?

Hmmm ... maybe its just the absolute deliciousness of everything they do from muffins to scones to bread sticks to loaves to cookies!  I could go on forever and never decide on a true answer.  

I'm just glad I live so close!

I'll admit the pizza here is so-so. The crust gets a little too chewy on me but it may be a matter of preference and luck of the draw when it comes to toppings since there's only one choice.

What really gets me is the pecan rolls. They are incredible. I know there's butter in them there rolls. It has the right balance of sugar and cinnamon and is completely delectable.

HOLLY PIZZA!!! I was so excited to finally try Golden Boy Pizza!
I had the chance to try this gem this weekend and let me tell you the pizza was BOMB.Like all great hole-in-the-wall type spots, it's a very small space with limited seating. We ordered at the counter after waiting 15 minutes in line but every minute was worth it!

I had a hard time picking which pizza I wanted and ultimately went with the combo which was very good. The pizza is hearty and although thick, I love that the outer crust is crunchy & seasoned.One square slice of the pizza washed down with Stella on tap was more than enough for me. And to think I actually debated ordering 2 slices. This place is great for late night bite after a long night out in the bars of North Beach!

Can't wait to be in the area again just so that I can grab a bite to eat here :)

This place has pizza squares for $4!

There was a line out the door at 2pm on a Sunday. This is a bit deceiving considering you order just inside the door (so don't get discouraged by the line). If you eat in, they warm your pizza and then bring it to where you're sitting.

A cup of water is free, thankfully.

There's beer on tap and a TV for sports fans!

Employees are friendly and helpful.

Cash only

DAMN YOU!
So good.
So effin good.
Please for one square of combo??
One pint and one square??
Pleeeeeeeeeease?!!!!

LITERALLY SOME OF THE BEST PIZZA I HAVE EVER HAD!!!! You MUST MUST MUST try the clam and garlic pizza. Forget calories and do yourself a favor and order 2 pieces! The entire kitchen was so helpful and nice. The vibes of the restaurant was awesome and had a 90's grunge feel to it with great music. It is a little small inside but honestly the pizza was well worth it. I cant wait to come back to SF to eat at the gem of a pizzeria again!! Hey Golden Boy!! Bring this to LA, we need REAL pizza!!!

This place is such a good place for pizza - especially drunk eating. They have a clam pizza and it's definently different from the norm. We also got a combo pizza, which wasn't too special. But the clam slice was so good and I'm craving it right now as I am thinking about it.

-Kristen

5 stars from Kristen, Edmund still wasn't here to rate.

Found this place on yelp and wasn't disappointed. The pizza tasted like pizza lol. No but it was delicious! Service was on point, prices were not ridiculous and did I mention he the pizza tasted good. I will be visiting this spot on the regular. Great location and plenty of street parking nearby. Check this place out, you won't be disappointed. Nice selection and the right amount of draft beers!

For 2000+ reviews, I expected a lot more from Golden Boy Pizza. Don't get me wrong - it's still good and definitely worth a try. But coming here again isn't worth spending 25+ min looking for street parking and getting yelled at from other drivers because Erick T. was pretending to be an Uber driver parked in the middle of the street with his blinkers on. Guess it was reasonable for him to get yelled at because he was was the source of traffic while I ran inside and ordered to go. I'd totally pay $$$ for a parking lot but there was unfortunately none nearby. I guess this is what needed to be done in order to simply grab a slice of the famous Clam Garlic pizza.

The Clam Garlic pizza. Sounds so unique and so interesting... well, it did taste very unique and interesting just like you'd imagine. There was surprisingly tons of garlic on the pizza which I absolutely loved because I love garlic, but I prefer to have clams and garlic with my pasta or soup dishes. Or maybe it's because the clam was room temperature so my pizza wasn't really hot? As you all know, the best pizza is always really hot with stringy cheese after each bite. Yum. :0) Dunno, but a regular italian sausage combo pizza from Pizza My Heart would've probably fulfilled my pizza craving for that night.

Restaurant is extremely small - maybe about 10 bar style seats. Expect to doggy bag your pizza and eat it at home, which TONS of people do! Maybe you can throw it in the microwave too.

P.S. Check out the bathroom! Sort of dark for my liking but sort of cool!

Came here in hungry anticipation, after reading the reviews. Approximately, 15 minutes in line on Friday during lunch time, I suppose wasn't too bad.

Most slices are $4.25, and come fully loaded.  

Unfortunately, the pizza was nothing special.  I liked that the bottom of the pizza was crisp, while the inside was soft and doughy.  The clams tasted like what one would get from a can.  Of the three of us who ate it, one person really liked it, while 2 of us thought it edible.

We also ordered a pesto veggie pizza, which was said to be so-so.

The combo pizza was also reportedly okay, though my lunch date said he has had better.  

So all in all an okay experience. Nothing that I foresee myself ever craving.  However nothing really to complain about.  

Extra kudos for good service.

I've been to the Marina location once and loved it, so I was excited to see a location open up closer to me. First of all, this place is L-O-U-D. Don't come here on a first date because you'll be yelling at each other. The decor is great and the service friendly. The food came out quickly, which is always a plus!

Burrata Bruschetta (4/5) - Drizzled with honey, hazelnuts, and cracked pepper. Only two slices. Delicious, but I wish the burrata wouldn't have been cold. The warm bread called from warm cheese!

Kale Caesar (1/5)- I had this at the Marina location and was happy to order it again. It came way overdressed and I didn't even eat more than a few bites because it tasted like dressing soup. The couple next to me ordered it too and they had the same problem.

Spicy Fennel Sausage (4/5)- I love Delarosa pizza! The sauce is more of a stewed tomato taste, as opposed to a marinara-based sauce. Light on the cheese. The menu listed it as having "onions", which turned out to be spring onions that I picked off because they were big hunks (not the cute ringed slices used as garnish). I think sauteed onions would have been tastier, but maybe some people would like this?

Overall- I'd go again for a special occasion and I'd recommend you give it a try.

My husband and I came here on a friday and ordered a pizza with kale caesar salad. I enjoyed the family style however it was very loud and hard to hear your own conversation. The food was just ok. I expected more flavor . The server was nice but the foos and ambience was just ok.

Stopped in for some appetizers and wine and determined that I must come back for dinner. The burrata bruschetta with honey and hazelnuts was divine and so were the meatballs. Especially liked that they had a little heat to them. Great option for some good eats when you're around Yerba Buena.
Good place with good crevice.  Nice atmosphere and polite costumer service. I will recommend this place for my friends

Line was worth the wait!  Standard cheese and one with the works were EXCELLENT.  The crust was light, buttery and crispy.  But the stand out was the clam pizza, which sounded like it'd be a questionable topping, but was anything but!! Like, why aren't clams a topping we can normally order?!?  It was AMAZING.  The showstopper.  Unexpected.  Delicious.  Golden Boy Pizza lived up to the hype.

I'm an avid pizza eater, and I had been wanting to try this place for a while. I usually prefer traditional ingredients on pizzas but the flavors of the clam and garlic paired together so well. Be prepared to stay in line because this place is popular! Also, it is cash only. There is some seating at the counter and at tables but it's dimly lit and not a large space. I would suggest getting the pizza to go and eating it at Washington Square Park if the weather is comfortable.
They have one or my favorite vegan pizzas. They have vegan sausage for their pizzas too. On Friday night the place was busy, energetic and loud.
If you go on a weekend there might be a little bit of wait time. They had a good range of unique pizzas and appetizers. My friends ordered the shrimp appetizer and really loved it.

I think the location is what makes this place interesting. In terms of the food, I thought the pizza was okay. It was so windy our toppings were flying away! The staff was really nice and attentive, I think I am just spoiled by the food in Sonoma/Napa.

This place had great pizza but their service was just ok. Our waitress had a little attitude and was not that helpful. I was little afraid to order and she made me feel when i wanted to order something else i was bothering her. She kept saying what?! Little rude and uncomfortable but the manager was very nice!  I think she was overwhelmed bc it was very busy on New Years Day. Their beer was in a can for 9$ and their 1/2 toasted burrata was expensive! $8 for that, not worth it in my opinion. I dont know if i will ever return to thia place again.
Burrata w/ honey and hazel nuts is yum! Pizzas are good too. Reasonable priced and nice ambience
Amazing!  The warm salad has hazel nuts; perfect flavor and texture.  Get the Brussels sprouts and on New Years Day their music was the best!...90s R&B.

Amazing pizzaeria with excellent service and food! Honestly as authentic as Italy, and they even have Italian beer (not Peroni, but the good stuff). The only downside is that they don't take reservations and there is a long wait.
Most of north beach is a tourist mob with high priced mediocre Italian but this place is a gem! Everything is delicious and service is great
Great pizza and pasta, with friendly service, no wait to be seated, and quick food delivery to the tables. 10/10 would recommend going here.

I am addicted to this place. I eat here once a week-twice if I am lucky. The employees are all very friendly and I never have to wait long to get my food.  I get the prosciutto and arugula pizza with no cheese. The roasted cauliflower is so good, I think it has chili oil mixed in to it. My mouth is watering as I type this ....Five stars for sure.

I ate most of the (real) Italian pizza of the Bay Area, and by far this is the best one! Not only a great quality, but also a reasonable price: as Italian, I refuse to spend $25 for a margherita (I.e: Una Pizza Napoletana) and so should you.

First time in San Francisco and I am so glad I decided to walk into this place. Pizza can easily be compared to the ones I ate in Italy. Amazing service, pleasent atmosphere. And for us sugar junkies, don't go there without trying pana cota. Tiramisu is usually my go to dessert in Italian places but my server recommended pana cota and I am so happy he did. This is one of those places where I wish there is a sixth star as an option for true greatness.

By far my favorite pizza in San Francisco! The food and atmosphere take me back to Italy. The owner is very nice and his attention to detail is obvious between the food, presentation and overall ambiance.

Whenever I have friends or family visiting, this is the first restaurant I think to take them. I always leave il Casaro satisfied. My favorite pizzas are the Norma and the Margherita. This is also my favorite place to get an espresso. Very good quality.

Enjoy!
Incredible spot. Great for a date! Food is always great and wine is affordable. Tough to get in some times but well worth the wait.

A hipper, younger more club-atmosphered North Beach Italian eatery than Francesco's A++ restaurant, Vicoletto, a couple of blocks up on Green Street.

As one of the biggest proponents of Italian buffala cheese and burrata as a host of private dinner parties, I love Il Casro's branding around esoteric and fragrant cheese:

The "Mozzarella Bar"

Gotta love it! :)

The centerpiece of the restaurant is a tiled dome that gleams like a mosque. It is a wood burning oven imported from Naples, Italy -- designed by Stefano Ferrara.

It took Francesco months to code, ship and get that object of foodie art through U.S. Customs.

A passion project which a whole city has come to love.

Ill keep this brief.  They just opened so they have a few things to work out, nothing major.  
We started with the arranchini (spelling) and another app with the salad.  The salad was the standout.  Really light and good.  
We also shared 4 pizzas.  All of which were great.  I would say the prosciutto pizza was our favorite.  The service was good, they are still running around a bit, but that is too be expected 2 weeks after opening.  If there is a wait, I would recommend waiting, the pizza was really good.  Chewy crust, definitely very fresh, and everything was what you would expect.  I will be going back.
Very unique pizzas.  Try the one with the poached eggs.  You'll need one pizza per person, however.

Amazing pizza and atmosphere.  It was a treat

A little misleading with their claims on using only locally sourced items in their menu.  When asked why no Californian or North American wines made their menu list, a lack of local selection was explained to be the rationale.  True? Perhaps.  Greenwashing? Perhaps.

we came just after dinner opened, with 3 small kids. got a cheese plate salad--yum. also the bean soup, great flavor. had the farm egg pizza--kids were all over that. barely left any for me! the crust is superb. then the kumquat goat cheese tart. who thinks of such a combo? had to take an extra tart to go.

the restaurant is so small. if only i were young and single again, it would be so quaint. kids found some free play on the sidewalk. the service people were nice about our kiddie group.

Have been going here for years and was always singing its praises, but the last time I went it wasn't as good as it has been.  I will still go back and tell folks that if they're in the neighborhood they should stop in, but the pizza is not as great as it has been.  The pizzas I've had in the past I still dream about (first clam pizza I ever had was here, and would order it again in a heartbeat if it was on the menu), but this time the crust was more like a cracker.  The place itself is so small and so cute, and every time I've ever been there the people working there have been awesome!  Hoping that the next time it lives up to my memories!
Good enough. Not quite a homerun, but definitely a double.
Still my favorite restaurant in the city.  Service is always great (seems like very little staff turnover).  Food is great.  If they offer the sausage and orzo appetizer - it's fantastic.
This is a small hole in the wall restaurant.  It has good artisan pizza.  If you are looking for traditional pizza or spacious seating, then I would look elsewhere.

Visit here every time I am in SF (I'm a New Yorker.)  Outstanding food.  Efficient service.  My only suggestion is it's a little odd there isn't a Sangiovese on the menu (the classic pizza/wine pairing.)

Great small neighborhood place.   Decent service, only a couple of wines, but the food is excellent.   It's not always consistent and sometimes they run out of pizza dough on a busy dinner evening.  But it is definitely worth checking out especially if you live in the hood.  Great for a date if you want impress in low-key! :-)

Good pizza, cozy ambiance but fairly pricy.  The place is small. TEENY tiny. You might not even find if if you go out lookin' for it. It's like a micro-restaurant or something.

Sometimes they run out of dough during the evening.  Not sure if this is a good thing or a bad thing.

Too many hipsters! Look, the place is good but I have had MUCH better. Across the bay, Zachary's kills this place in the deep dish department and does it without all the coolness and trendiness that Little Star has. I can name 5 spots in downtown Chicago that would destroy Little Star (Edwardo's, Giordano's, Lou's, Uno's, Gino's). It's good for San Francisco standards, where everybody can pat themselves on their back and relish in how cool and unique this place is. But in my opinion, the deep dish is average, I just don't like their spaghetti sauce, err tomato sauce, that  they use for their pies.

I will say that their thin crust is much better and tastier. The crust is very crispy and it has a good balance of cheese, sauce, and toppings. In fact, I would even say that it is in the top 4 for thin crust with Gialina, Pizzetta 211, Delfina, and A-16 battling for top spots. I would give the thin crust 5 stars and the deep dish 2.5. But I still can't get over the fact that one has to have the secret password, look at my cool tattoo on my wrist mentality. It is a fucking pizza parlor! Get over yourselves already...

I walked in expecting deep dish pizza on par with what I'm used to at Chicago Fire in the Sacramento area.  But when I took that first bite I realized what I had been missing all this time -- flavor.

The pizza at Little Star is has really good ingredients.  All of the ingredients in the pizza tasted fresh and flavorful; the sauce, the sausage, cheese....

Contrary to what many have said, Little Star does take credit cards.  Parking is a problem here, but we parked on Turk and walked a few blocks which wasn't a big deal.  

I would definitely stop by Little Star again when I'm in the area.

While my husband and I are new to San Francisco (we've been living here for about two months now), Little Star Pizza has become our go to place to take out of town guests.

First of all, it's a short walk from our place.  Secondly, the pizza is truly unique and absolutely delicious.  I love how they serve their salad family style, so you can order just one and share it with the table.  And the portions for the pizza are just right, so you don't overeat or have a bunch left over.  I've tried both the deep dish and the thin crust and I was very pleased.  On the menu you will see the deep dish choices and the thin crust choices, but they are happy to mix it up and make a deep dish choice thin or vice versa.  The bar service is fast and efficient, which is good because every time I've been to this place there has been at least a twenty minute wait.  Definitely a favorite and will visit again soon.

I love Little Star!  I love Little Star!  I Love Little Star!

Their cornmeal crust is perfect!  Try the deep-dish Little Star or Classic.  And try out some chicken wings too!

Ok, now I know I may be the last person in the Bay Area to "discover" Little Star, but I still feel compelled to write this review.

I lived in Chicago for 5+ years and thought I knew everything about deep dish.  I tried Uno, Due, Giordanos, Lou Malnati's, Gino's East, and dozens of Chicago imitators.  I didn't like deep dish the first time I had it.  It was too much like pie, not enough like pizza in its floppy, cheesy deliciousness.  Despite countless years of eating deep dish, I never liked it any better.  

Until Little Star!  I've eaten there twice and been so impressed!  The Little Star pizza is fantastic.  It's the classic spinach, mushroom, onion deep dish.  The crust has a delicious cornmeal crust, is slightly chewy inside, and not overly buttery.  The toppings make the difference - everything is super fresh.  The tomatoes in the sauce were particularly sweet, flavorful, and tart.    

Yum!

We've been at Little Star a few times and haven't been disappointed. Of course, their deep dish pizzas are the star here. The crust is always a great combination of the right crispiness (never soggy) and nutty butterness. You can't go wrong with any but our favorite are the Classic and the Mediterranean Chicken. But the real surprise are the Spicy Chicken wings. These are done just right with the balanced combination of spicy/sweet and tender and juicy on the inside. If you love wings, you can't miss these wings.

Service is friendly, efficient but not fussy. Parking is sometimes tough in the evenings but not impossible.

The girlfriend and I were going to get Mexican in the mission but after a friend of ours mentioned that he had Little Star the other night, we were hooked. I've heard of this place many times but never had the opportunity to go. We quickly changed plans and ordered a pie for pick up.

Maybe I'm spoiled by Chicago, or maybe it was an off night, but I might be one of the few that thought this place was just 'ok'

Zachary's and this place come close to being authentic, but ultimately something was missing. It could be the sauce that tasted a bit flat, or the size of the sausage that was tiny in my opinion. Don't get me wrong it was good, but I think people over hyped this place and my expectations were that of a Giordano's or Pequod's in Chitown.

BTW, Pequod's is probably the best I've had. Look up the pictures here on yelp and you'll know what I'm talking about when I saw tiny sausage!
