Cal Italia - This was the pizza I chose and it was by far my favorite. A classic italian pizza, this was cooked in a lower temperature oven than the first two, and the crust was noticeably less charred. That was its only drawback though, because everything else about this was amazing. With three different cheeses as its base, prosciutto on top and covered in sweet fig preserve, balsamic reduction and Parmesan shavings, this pizza made my day. It is easy to see why the Food Network awarded it the gold. I will have a hard time not ordering this every time I come here in the future.

-

Overall, this was the best pizza place I have tried so far in the city and with a menu so massive, it will take many visits to try all of the options that caught my eye. I especially want to come back and try some of the pizza romana.

Came here on a holiday weekend for lunch.  Put our name on the waitlist and when we arrived, our table was ready!   We ordered the Margarita pizza, pepperoni pizza, salad and calamari.  It was so good, as always!   Friendly staff.  We come every year when we visit the city for fleet week!

Cons: no AC

I am so glad we decided to dine here. The food is absolutely delicious, there is definitely a long wait to get to the food but if you were willing to stick it out the wait is well worth it.
The pricing is average not expensive and not cheap, the appetizer we decided to start with was the mushroom-based meatball, I have been to Italy two times but I have never had a more delicious meatball in my life. The seasoning was just perfect and the taste is very unique. The portion size is perfect as well definitely able to share it with about three people or four.
We were told that the New York style pizza was the most popular so we decided to try that and I am glad we did because it was fantastic. It was not your average pizza, and it was very satisfying and filling.
The service was great as well our waitress was so sweet I wish I remembered her name. Honestly the only thing that I did not like about the place is how long the wait was, but I totally understand why there is a long wait. If I ever return to San Francisco I will definitely eat here again.

Over priced pizza but it was good. I was disappointed that for $25 you get a four slice pizza. My friend and I were so hungry we didn't notice that the pizza they brought out wasn't the one we ordered. But by the time we realized we were halfway through. We should have said something but again the pizza was really good. If it gets crowded you can get a seat at the bar. When we went on a Friday evening the wait was over an hour. The service and staff are very friendly.

The pizza is overrated. I have tried better pizza in other places. But the pasta is amazing. The pasta is actually underrated. The line is pretty long. I came at 1145 in Saturday and there was a pretty long line.

Delicious! The wait is worth it.
We actually just came in for the coccoli (cause we loved it so much in Italy) and it was exquisite, not as overseas but we understand that.
Service was nice and very efficient.
;)

So my friends and I were recommended this place by our Lyft driver, and we ended up having to wait for about 2 hours before getting seated. The bright side was that they took down our number, so we ended up walking up to Coit Tower before coming back. There are also some pretty good gelato places nearby.

They served bread with a variety of dipping sauces first, such as a tomato and olive oil one and one sweet oily garlic one. We ended up trying two of the award winning pizzas and the linguine which had a variety of seafood.

The pasta ended up being excellent even though I believe this place is more well I known for their pizza. The seafood tasted fresh and the sauce was pretty well made. The pasta was also cooked closer to al dente than most of the pasta places I've been to over here.

Both pizzas were good, especially the Margarita, which had the best balance of flavor and toppings. The Cal Italia did feel a little lazily made though, especially with the balsamic reduction (?) being just one big plop in the middle instead of swirled throughout the pizza.

Overall great place!

This place should be re-named to Prima Donna Pizza.

On a weekday around 2:00 two of us walked in and were immediately seated at a large booth. We ordered pizza and wine. I get a text from my husband that he's close by and could he join us. Sure I say, we have plenty of pizza and space. But NOOOOO alert the pizza authorities we have a late comer! We were very rudely informed that it's strictly against "policy." Well ok I get that during peak times but look there are several empty seats, our order was already placed, and we had a big booth to ourselves. The server would make zero exception, would not give us a third plate, not empathic or apologetic in the slightest and then proceeded to straight up ignore me when I asked to take the pizza to go. We ended up sitting at one of the many open tables right outside by the slice house.

Their pizza is pretty good but not THAT good. Certainly not good enough to put up with the restaurants attitude and inflated ego.

Hard to give a margarita pizza a 5 star review but they came as close as someone could. If the inner bottom of the pizza would have been just a tad more crispy and cooked they would have achieved such a rating.  (so the pizza would hold its weight and not spill half the slice into the plate). The salad was delicious. Walnuts were a nice touch.

Italian is usually simple and ehh where I am located so this was nice.

Got delivery from Tony's last night due to COVID-19. The pizza arrived barely warm and the Caesar salad was utterly depressing (three tiny crostini and not all the lettuce was fresh). In terms of portion size, the salad could last for two meals and the pizza likely for 3. Once reheated the slices were yummy, but for ~$45 before tip I expected more.

i've now officially tried all 3 deep-dish spots in the bay area(little star, patxi's, zachary's). little star had its good points and its bad points. pizza-wise, i'd rank it last place among the three. i just wasn't that impressed. patxi's was so much better to me. it was greasier(again, a good thing), cheesier, and the sauce wasn't too chunky. prices and wait-time are about the same. our pizza was a little too small, but that's our fault for not getting the large. i wish they had a medium, though...

drink-wise, i'd rank them 2nd. patxi's, again, comes in #1 because of their $1 pbr's. it's only $2.25 here, which isn't bad, and all alcoholic drinks are a dollar off during happy hour. they also have mixed drinks here, which is a nice touch.

little star dominates the other 2 in terms of appetizers in deserts. the other two only have salad for apps, little star has hot wings and garlic bread. the hot wings were amazing! big, juicy, spicy, and it had a smokey/different flavor to it. i loved it more than the pizza. it is convenient, considering all deep-dish pizza's take 30+ minutes to make. for desert, we had the chocolate chip/cookie dough gelato. it was also fantastic. the other two places don't have desert at all.

lastly, i'll compare convenience/service. i'd rank them dead-last. the crowd was very douchey and annoying. this is a restaurant, not a frat party, you dumbasses. our waiter was very nice, no complaints there. patxi's wins because they deliver and they serve by the slice(so does zachary's, but only during certain hours).

overall, it was a cool experience. i think i'd actually come back here for the wings and gelato, and maybe try the thin crust. but if i'm craving deep-dish, it's patxi's all the way.

Seriously - the most amazing pizza ever!  the crust is what makes it so amazing!  Pizza is probably the one food that I could have every single day for the rest of my life, and I have been all over the world trying different pizzas, and this has to be one of the top pizzas I have ever had. Even after eating Pizza in New York city.

I always go deep dish and get the garlic bread. The garlic bread comes out quickly while the deep dish cooks. They are both amazing. I've been to Chicago and this deep dish is as good or better than most pies I had there.
THE BEST PIZZA I have had in America!!!!! not only great pizza BUT great service!! ALYSSA was awesome. Great customer service and so friendly and willing to help! Highly recommend!!

The fact that this place has a 4.5 star average scares me as I'm beginning to realize what I may be in for now that I live in California.

Saturday afternoon, for whatever reason around 4pm I suddenly had a craving for deep dish pizza. Not sure why, i generally never get cravings for it, but none the less, I had a craving and it wasn't going away. I hopped on yelp and after reading briefly it didn't seem like a hard choice: Little Star was the place to go for deep dish pizza in San Francisco.
To add to my later disappointment, my girlfriend wasn't at all in the mood for it, but I did one hell of a job convincing her how good it would be so she hopped on board.

We peeped the menu on-line and ordered the 'classic' and 'little star' 9" deep dish pizza's. The garlic bread also got a nice review so we added that to the mix. The nice gentlemen on the phone confirmed my order, gave me my total and informed me that it was cash only. I liked that he did this because I've been to multiple places that haven't and it really sucks when you show up with just a credit card.

So, parking wasn't easy but since I knew I'd be quick i blocked the parking structure next door, ran in and grabbed my food. The place was packed and actually looked like it would be a fun place to grab a beer and pizza. My food was ready and they had me out of there in just a minute. So far so good.
I get home and I can already taste the food. we open up both boxes, dig in, and I just give my girlfriend a look. She can tell, and she starts laughing(a sympathetic laugh) because she knew how much i was looking forward to this.
The pizza certainly wasn't terrible. It just wasn't really that good. The crust is very different. I believe its cornmeal which seems to be why some people love it, but not this guy. The peppers and mushrooms on mine weren't flavorful and the texture was very bad. All in all just not good.
My girlfriend was pretty blah with her description as well but I generally don't like spinach pizza so i didn't try. The sausage chunks were large which was nice, and tasty, but the pizza just didn't do anything for me.
About 10 minutes after my first bite we realized we ordered the garlic bread and got excited again because we thought that may salvage a little bit of dinner. Well, we opened the bag, found a loaf wrapped in foil with a plastic container that had butter inside. I opened the foil and didn't smell any garlic. They just gave us bread and f'in butter. At this point I nearly hit myself in the face with a beer bottle. I may have given the place 3 stars initially(since they don't have 2.5), but not after this.
One of the 5 star reviews I read below actually said they consider this better than the deep dish they have in Chicago. I have never been to downtown Chicago, but I've been to the outskirts. I've also had deep dish all over the northeast and I don't know what the hell this person is talking about. Generally i consider Pizzeria Uno to be 'airport/mall' food, but I guarantee if I lined up the 'Chicago classic' from uno against the 'classic' from little star, I think people who love little star would fall over from how good the Chicago classic is. I just really can't believe that this is considered awesome deep dish pizza.

I'm going home for Christmas very soon, and there are a ton of great places to eat high end food. I won't be going to any of those places however. They have those here in the Bay. No, when i land back east, it's gonna be all about chicken wings, pizza and deli sandwiches. Hmmmm, I can't wait!

Brian, the owner of Little Star contacted me about my review and explained the situation that they had on Saturday and apologized for his host. It makes me feel better to know that this is an establishment where the owner takes the time to read the yelp reviews and respond to any unpleasant experiences. Go Brian! I'll give them a second chance

i don't like pizza.

what i really mean is that i don't like pizza in general. too much bread, too much waxy cheese, too little sauce (and too little seasoning in said sauce!), too much meat with nitrite. blech.

my boyfriend lives in the east bay, and has only experienced zachary's deep dishes. honestly, i can't remember my last experience there except for the insanely long line of people spilling out onto college ave.

however, at little star, we walked in and were almost immediately seated even though there were about 6 tables ahead of us who were all, unfortunately for them, not deuces. i picked the house chianti (meh) and he had the boont amber (yum).

all of the staff were cool and really attentive.

our server, a plugged/inked/pierced/all-around-nice-guy, told us the special, let us mull over the menu for a few minutes while he took care of some other tables, and then came back when we were firm on the caprese salad and mediterranean chicken pizza.

the caprese was lovely. fresh buffalo mozz with plum tomatoes and shaved basil sitting in a pool of aged balsamic and extra virgin olive oil. two pieces of sourdough toasts accompanied the dish and we did not regret pouncing on it like lions to freshly slaughtered prey. this is the kind of caprese salad i like to make with good balsamic and fresh mozz. the only thing i would have done differently, would have been to add heirlooms instead of plum tomatoes for sweetness.

what can i say about the pizza that countless of other people haven't said before? honestly, i hate pizza dough, but this is the best cornmeal-flour dough combo i've ever tasted. it held up well against the filling and had a great crunchy crust. the sauce was decent, and the chicken/artichoke/green olive/feta filling was very tasty.

warning:

cash only, but kinda expensive. there's an atm onsite that only charges $0.25 so i guess that's a plus. also, the two slices i inhaled made me feel like i ate an entire pie by myself. the small size is more than enough for 2 people. no delivery, but plenty of take-out.

The addition of Little Star Pizza last fall has made my favorite neighborhood even more enjoyable. I can't think of a better location for this place. It's comfortable hip vibe is home to many locals. The familiar background music (all jukebox) , along with the vivid, punchy artwork, set the tone for a light & happy evening with friends.   The lengthy wine, beer and cocktail list aid in creating ample leisure time!
--THE FOOD: I have never met a pizza I didnt like...but I REALLY enjoy the variety of pies available. The option of thick or thin is just the beginning. The trademark "Little Star" thick crust pizza, is by far their showboat. The ricotta cheese and fresh chunky sauce blanket the pie. Though the cornmeal crust is a unique delicacy, the flavors atop the pie create a meal on their own.  I'm also quite impressed with the vegetarian, and non red-meat options. The thin crust Chicken Pesto is also a favorite of mine. --DESSERT: It is nearly impossible to not gorge myself when visiting LSP, but on the slim chance that I'm still hungry (or feel like splurging) I take full advantage of LSP's dessert menu. All desserts are made on the premise by a specialized dessert chef. Perhaps the most popular, is the Cheesecake. Words can't describe how light, fluffy & dream-like it is. I also recommend the gelato. Various flavor are available, depending on the availability each night. It, too, is dreamy and parallels the Italian wonder! --OVERALL: Overall, I'm so very impressed with my local pizza joint. LSP is a place where people know youre name (or learn it quickly). It's the perfect Sunday  night dinner with friends, or a place to kick off an evening of bars or music.   Once a Divisadero secret, Little Star Pizza has become not only a place of great eats & relaxation, but a warm gathering place for locals.
p.s. my friend owns the place!  :)
The buffalo wings are fantastic.  NON-FRIED, just enough spice, garlicky but won't give you garlic breath fantastic wings.

Great atmosphere and fabulous bartender! The deep dish is quite tasty. In comparison to Patxi's- less greasy, able to eat more than one piece, and different offerings as far as toppings. Great jukebox and beer selections.
Have to thank Yelpers here.  As highlighted, cherry corn scone was truly amazing!

I have a creepy tendency to walk into this bakery, take in deep breathes of air as I look at everything for sale, and leave.

Well, I finally manned up and finally got the courage to grab a brown bag and go bread picking. I was with my cousins, one of which strongly recommended the giant chocolate chip cookie ($2). It wasn't what I had in mind for my first Arizmendi Bakery purchase, but I did just eat lunch. So I decided to go with the cookie and walked up to the register with my, and both of my cousins', purchases. The cashier was incredibly friendly and sang, or perhaps rapped, our items as he took my money.

The cookie was delicious! I found myself having to tell myself to slow down because I was quickly eating the entire cookie. But lack of self restraint left me empty handed within minutes.

In the end, good service, good food.

this place is great.  so fresh its 'to live for'

go in and try their pizza.  i don't usually recommend a non pizza place to try pizza but this is very good and people buy it over and over.  its fresh and its the uncommon ingredients used to perfection.

go here if you really like baked goods also.  they have excellent muffins, focaccia(so fresh and many different kinds).  these guys should attend a farmers market and get their secret out but alas the secret is here and if you know about it...its up to you to share it.

the only problem with this place?  parking if you don't know where to find it...especially on a sunday.  

the other problem.  sometimes there is this creep older looking asian guy who is an agressive pan handler.

This place is a co-op, everyone who works here is an owner. They bake fine breads, pizza and a few sweet treats. Their baked goods are always high quality. When they first opened I lived around the corner, it wasn't as busy as now, and I got to know the friendly staff.  I have sinced moved to the slower pace of the coast by Santa Cruz but stop by when in S.F. for my PhD program. The staff these days seem a bit stressed and less social than those early days of less business.

Got a three mushroom pizza from here and it was one of the best pizza's I've ever had.  They spread the top with olive oil and garlic.  Loved every bite and even loved it after it got cold when I had it for a midnight snack.  Definitely a place to stop by.  Gave it four stars because the wait is a little long but that might be because there are so many ppl waiting in line for the pizza!  Not a lot of seating so plan on getting this to go.

Fresh pizza, fresh bake goods and a very cozy place.  Although the pizza is not very filling for a fatty like me, it's always so good. I really liked the yam + goat cheese combo.  It's cash only but it's only half a block away from Bank of American and Wells Fargo, so that shouldn't be a problem for anyone.
Thank you, Arizmendi.  On the rare occasion that I jump out of bed in the morning, it's usually because I'm looking forward to your scone of the day.
The pizza here is amazing and the chocolate chip cookies melt in your mouth.  They have mastered the art and I have fallen in love with pizza and cc cookies all over again!

This is the best bakery in SF! Everything is great and fresh and the pizza is awesome.  Who doesn't love a place that post on the website their daily pizza menu for the whole month???? Seriously! Amazing scones, cookies and focaccia---nothing will disappoint and service is fast and friendly.

I mean, the reviews say it all since there are over 900. But i'm bored and I yelp when i'm bored so here's my 2 cents.

Arizmendi seems to be a sister spinoff of the revered Cheeseboard Collective in Berkeley. I love Cheeseboard and fortunately for me, even after graduation I get to experience something similar to it. Arizmendi offers a different pizza each day and they are all vegetarian. I've tried this place many many times and every pizza has been great. Whether it is a triple mushroom pizza with a sesame vinaigrette or a simple heirloom tomato pizza with garlic oil, the ingredients and cheese always work well together.

I haven't tried much of the pastries, but I get the cheddar and green onion scones from time to time.. and they are delicious as well.  

Tiny tiny issues:
The place is small so if you have a big group, it'll be better to take the pizza to go and enjoy it elsewhere.. The park is so close by so that shouldn't be a big problem! Lines can get very very lone around 12- 12:30. Therefore I feel the best time to come here is sometime around 11:30 because not will the line be fairly short, but they don't bring the pizzas out until around 11:30. This means they'll be fresh and hot.

Also, it's cash only but this shouldn't be a big deal, esp if you have BOA since there's one down the street. I'm going to miss this place when I move =(

FELT SO SILLY KNOWING I WAITED 2 HOURS FOR TONY'S PIZZA WHEN THIS PLACE IS RIGHT NEXT TO IT. :(

They seriously don't even compare. Golden Boy is best pizza in the world in my book! Go here instead of waiting for hours for average pizza and okay service at Tony's.

Awesome friendly staff and amazing pizza! Worth the trip to SF just for this!!

Amazing Mouthwatering Pizza.

I had garlic clam and combo. The crust was perfect. Tomato sauce, cheese, and toppings were in perfect proportions. Counter-style seating.

Tip: Ask for corner pieces...

I saw some reviews here for the Golden Boy Pizza place in San francisco and thought I would chime in.  I really liked the food here.  Pizza was great, and so was the pasta.  My friend got Lasagna, and said they really liked it.  If you are going to go to the City, and get some Italian food, give these folks a try.  I will return.  Great beer on tap too.

Bill
Small pizza joint in San Francisco. You cannot order a specific pizza unless you want to order the whole stack. Their pizzas taste delicious. Also, a veggie friendly place.

Amidst all the different pizzerias in North Beach and the Broadway area, this is the one place I'd pick for a good slice of pizza! My friends and I literally walked from Montgomery Bart Station to Golden Boy before heading out to The Warfield for a concert. So yes, you could probably call us fans of this place! Haha!

My usual selection is the Clam and Garlic pizza. Such a unusual combination at first glance, but it works wonders on the taste buds if you're keen on garlic. The clam is subtle and not too fishy and it lays on top of a crust that has a similar texture as focaccia. And I love how it's in square slice form.

A close second for me would be the pesto/veggie.

So sad when they closed the San Mateo location, so trekking the walk to this location is the small price to pay to enjoy this gem of a slice.

Good pizza!  Being from NY, I am a pizza snob, so giving this 4 stars has to tell you something. We had to grab something quick and we were not expecting much. To our surprise, we had a hot slice within a minute and it was great. Go here!!! YUMMERS.

Saw on Yelp this is the spot for late night drunk pizza needs and boy was it correct. The line was pretty long and almost went to the end of the block. The pizza was worth the weight though! We got the garlic clam and it was amazing! Be careful of people trying to cut the line though, there was this couple who tried to cut behind us and nobody in line was having it.

Um, can I just continually praise this place?

I took some New Yorkers here yesterday, and they claim to have the highest expectations for pizza and they were crying from joy with the garlic and clam.
One of the best cheap eats in No Beach...and open late for those who need something to soak up their alcohol! :D
DAMN!!!!! The best pizza I have ever had!  The crust was thick and fluffy with a perfect crispy-ness to it! LOADED with topping and full of flavor!  Perfection!

My favorite deep dish pizzeria ever.  The salad is a great way to start the meal.  Great selection of beers and wines by the glass.  Never have room for desert but never left unsatisfied.  Stay awesome Little Star!
I think this is the best pizza in the Bay Area.  Period.  If you don't like Little Star Pizza: fuck you.

we decided to come here on a tuesday night. the wait was 15-20 minutes for a table so we opted to sit at the bar.  sometimes sitting at the bar is not bad at all.  you have one dedicated waiter right in front of you all the time!  haha ... he was super attentive.  kept asking us about water and drinks etc etc.

they actually offer thin crust pizzas as well but we just opted for the special of the day deep dish which was a meatball, red pepper, ricotta, spinach pizza.  it was good.  i havent had deep dish in a while and im no connoisseur by any means.  but it wasnt too heavy.  there was just the right amount of cheese, crust, sauce and topping.

This location has visually interesting decorations and art, plus the bar is great for a good beer. We didnt have time to sit for a deep dish, so instead tried the thin crust garlic and chicken pizza. I gotta say it was verrry salty. So much that it ruined the enjoyment of the pizza. We ate it all cuz we were hungry but i dont think ill be having this again. Perhaps I need to try the deep dish to really review the place right.

Ignore all that shit I was talking about Little Star back in 2007. My initial gut reaction against a new establishment opening up along my beloved Divis Corridor is usually suspect, but under the weight of time & experience, Little Star is TRUE BLUE West Add elite. I've come to be a fan of deep dish pizza because of their Classic pie, & for no other reason. Yeah, the thin crust isn't the best pizza in the world, but it's much better than passable. Forgive me, Little Star. Pals?

what more can be said about little star? 952 reviews worth feels like enough. not sure why i haven't written mine sooner, but i've been a fan of this place for a long time now. their deep dish pizza is a seriously delicious meal, and what's left tastes just as good (and maybe better?) for lunch the next day. the thin crust is not too bad either. it's all about the cornmeal crust and chunky tomatoes in the sauce.

get there early to get a table. no reservations, cash only but the atm inside charges a very nominal fee. happy hour till 6:30. several decent wines and beers to compliment your meal or to be had at the bar. deep dish pizza takes a while to cook, so order right away of you're hungry. or just call ahead and get take-out. mmmmmmmhm. you're a star.

Im a through and through New York style thin crust girl and I have never liked the deep dish styles because I found them soggy and unappetizing every time I tried them. I eventually stopped eating them till I visited Little Star with friends. Their pizzas were game changing for me. I loved EVERY bite! I was pleasantly shocked to find myself polishing off the crusts-which I never eat! Yay!! Thank you Little Star for making me appreciate the beauty of Chicago deep dish. Also a special shout out to the uber friendly n laid back staff :)

The thin crust pizza was incredible! A buttery, crispy crust and delicious fresh ingredients made for an amazing pizza eating experience. I especially love that they have whole roasted garlic and sun dried tomatoes...yum! They also have great Champaign drinks to sip on while you wait for your table. Overall I highly recommend this restaurant and I will most definitely be back for more!

Little star is a fantastic pizzaria. I love the neighborhood and it's got a lot of great food but little star has to be up in the top 3 or at least in the discussion. I was told to get the deep dish and it didn't disappoint. We were lucky enough to get a table by walking in but we've noticed that this place can get pretty busy so setting up a reservation is probably best. Make sure you also keep in mind that if you go with the deep dish it takes 30 mins for them to prepare it.

We got a deep dish with garlic, sausage, pepperoni, and moz. Super delicious, great service, and the environment was perfect for a casual dinner or a date. Our pizza came out to $25. Not bad for a meal that's going to feed you for at least 2 sittings. I'll definitely be back! I hope you love it as much as I do.
Love this place! I've only done take out but it's always ready when they say and always a very friendly staff.

I was walking through the Mission District and saw a bunch of peeps standing outside this bakery, shoving single slices of gourmet pizza!  This place is great!  Totally understated and delicious, unassuming, and an all-together great place :)  This place reminds me of Cheese Board Pizza in Berkeley - thoughtful combinations of ingredients, simple, fresh, and delicious every time.  The only reason they're not receiving 5 stars is that some of their pizzas are better than others... i've also tried their other baked goodies, and their corn scorn is off the hook!!!  SOOOO good!  Their lavender cookie was too fragrant for my taste, but all in all, their other goodies are pretty damn good!!  I also like their service, very unassuming and earthy, which is great... I do wish, however, they had more places to sit...

All in all, I would highly recommend this place!

Out of towner here from Florida.. this place is simply delicious! One of, if not the best bakeries I've ever been to! Plus it's a co-op which makes it even better. Go support this great place! Back home we don't have many places like these, if one were to ever pop up I know I'd be a regular customer daily. The locals around here need to appreciate the awesomeness they have!
I don't even like scones!!!!! Ever .. EVER! Arizmendi is DELISH!!! I can't get enough!! The fact that I work right by them is a death trap!!! love love love.

I've always wondered about this place. I see the lines and go is that place really that good? On my way home Friday there was about five to ten minutes until they closed and I saw they were still open so I walked there to see what they had.

There was bread, scones, muffins, and cookies. I looked around and tried to be quick since I know they were trying to close.

I read the ingredients to see what was in there and I saw no raisins and went that's a winner for me. I saw the scones and went, I wonder how those will taste. I bought two strawberry blueberry scones. OH man! They were good!

They had some moisture and the texture was good. I'm glad I stopped by.

I will be stopping by again hopefully soon for some more of these yummy scones.

We were coming back from Ocean Beach and stopped here on the way home. I wanted to try everything it looked so good. We got the strawberry coffee cake and some cheese bread. SO good. I wish I lived closer to here.

A Co-op to me is pretty cool, and Arizmendi Bakery has to be one of my favorite ones to visit. Their blueberry coffee cake is just to die for, the crust is so buttery, and just crumbles in your mouth. And if you like pizza, their focaccia bread is a nice option for lunch, or dinner.
Best scones! Made with fresh fruit and not so sweet, just the way I like them. Can't eat just one

OMG Focaccia!

But seriously, beyond generous portions of focaccia topped with awesome cheese and vegis.  1 slice of focaccia is a meal!  They serve much better focaccia than the Valencia branch (at least in the 2 times I have visited each).

One of the top bakeries in the city (along with Acme).  They are so popular their residential neighbors upstairs have put up signs trying to get people to stay away, but despite their protests still has great bread and a large number of customers to prove it.

I'm over my head because I still haven't tried their pizza yet, and which is why I'm holding off on another star. I usually buy their some here and they have great selection to choose from, including blueberries, strawberry, chocolate, etc. line are efficient and you pick as you move up in line. I'm drooling just thinking about their pizzas: mushrooms, sweet potato, manchego cheese, spinach, etc. I love creativity!

how do they cram so much crack into these baked goods?  how do they expect us to wait until 8 am on Saturdays and Sundays, and survive all through the day on Mondays?  

only the collective knows.
Get their simple margharita pizza. It was the best among the other ones we tried there. Definitely make reservations ahead of time, otherwise the wait can be long.

I'm sure their pizza is every bit as good as people may claim. We planned our night to specifically eat dinner here. Unfortunately I was not able to eat here, due to the fact that I was "dressed in Santa attire." (A Santa hat and a red tank top) The bouncer said "my manager told me to refuse service to anyone in Santa attire." My friend and I came to SF to explore all that the city has to offer. We are 40 year old professionals who just wanted to enjoy a nice dining experience. I would completely understand if they refused service to those who were intoxicated, but that was not the case. I would exercise extreme caution when attempting to dine here, as one would would assume they will discriminate based on the clothing that you wear.

Delicious Pizza; large servings. Dough is a medium to thin crust with lots of toppings.
Great restaurant and going to Tony's Slice is a great idea when you need a quick and delicious meal.

Good pizza! Very flavorful, a little pricey for the large at $45. All we ordered was pepperoni, very classic style, crust was perfect, the whole problem I had with the pizza was the amount of grease. It was  an insane amount. Just make sure to workout after. Also BRING napkins to dabb all the grease off!

3.5 stars

The menu here is an amalgam of many cities' pizzerias. Classic Margherita -- Tony's got that, but in limited offer. Whether you think east or west coast is the best coast, they've got a pizza that represents where you're from. If you're indecisive, the choices will have your head spinning.

Grad school buddy & I met up for a meal & I really think my disappointment stems from ordering the wrong items. Little Italy salad was plain despite the interesting list of ingredients. I chose the Sausage & Stout pizza (only 23 made per day), made up of hearty & heavy beer sausage & fontina cheese on a doughy crust. There's stout in the crust, a sweet stout reduction drizzled atop, & the pie is finished with beer salt. Their commitment to stout is astounding!

As unique as our pick was, I couldn't stop wishing I'd ordered a calzone or Margherita to share -- something with a marinara base. Looking forward to trying these specific items next visit.

I absolutely enjoyed my Ketel One Moscow Mule. So refreshing; it went down a little too easily.

Ultra friendly hostess, bartender, & wait staff. Everyone we encountered had the best attitude.

Amazing pizzas! ALL OF THEM. There are so many types to choose from it's hard to go wrong. Even the gluten-free pizza is amaze-balls. My boyfriend is from Italy and he is very picky with pizzas but he approves of this place. Highly recommend!

Food: 5/5 Price: 3/5 Service: 5/5 Ambience: 5/5

*** MICHELIN Guide 2016, 2017 ***
*** Food Network ***

TONY'S PIZZA!!!! Dang this place is good, beyond good. It's been on my wish list forever. After 3 attempts of more than 2hr long waits, I came in at 12pm on a weekday right when they open and got my table in 15 minutes. Apart from being on the Michelin guide, Tony's Pizza had won the World Pizza Cup, gold medal winner las vegas 2014, gold medal winner food network pizza champions challenge, gold cup winner international pizza championships, and much more. Many of the pizzas have limited servings per day due to the precious imports of Neapolitan and Italian ingredients. They offer several styles of pizzas which include Neapolitan, Classic American and Italian, Sicilian, Pizza Romana, Gluten Free and New York, Detroit and St. Louis Style. We finally settled on 2 of the award winning ones - MARGHERITA and CAL ITALIA.

MARGHERITA 12" (world pizza cup winner naples, italy 2007) is Napoletana Style - 900 Degree Wood Fired pizza, limited 73 per day. Dough finished by hand using caputo red flour then proofed in napoletana wood boxes, san marzano tomatoes D.O.P., sea salt, mozzarella fior di latte, fresh basil, extra virgin olive oil. The pizza had a thin and soft bottom crust, slightly wet middle, chewy and doughy outer crust. It was pretty small, around 10 inches. This was my absolute favorite pizza!! It is quite pricey at $21 for such a small size, but it is SO GOOD. the mozzarella balls are melted perfectly, chewy yet not too rich nor salty, and the crust is just beyond this world.

CAL ITALIA 12" (gold medal winner food network pizza champions challenge) is Classic Italian Style - 650 Degree Gas or 700 Degree Electric. The pizza was a hand tossed rustic medium crust with asiago, mozzarella, italian gorgonzola, croatian sweet fig preserve, prosciutto di parma, parmigiano, balsamic reduction, no sauce. It was slightly bigger than Napoletana Margherita, around 12 inches, priced at $23. The crust was thin and crispy at the bottom(you can hold it up parallel to the plate), and had a crispy outer crust. I loved the sweet fig preserve and honey that gives the pizza its sweetness, and asiago cheese and prosciutto for its saltiness. It was slightly too salty for me and the asiago cheese was a bit too rich after a while. However, great pizza.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Second visit, tried something different.

LITTLE ITALY salad - mixed greens, chopped castelveltrano olives,walnuts, imported italian gorgonzola, olive oil, balsamic reduction, cherry tomatoes, shaved parmigiano. Huge portion, very very delicious. Loved the dressing & cheese combo!

NEW YORKER 16" (gold medal winner las vegas 2013) is Coal Fired Style - 1000 Degree. Serves 2-4. Mozzarella, hand crushed tomato sauce, natural casing pepperoni, sliced italian fennel sausage, calabrese sausage, ricotta, chopped garlic & oregano. This one is about twice the size as Margherita or Cal Italia, and you definitely get your money worth. LOVED the ricotta and mozzarella on tomato pizza. The meat combo was a bit too heavy, but very delicious nonetheless. Order this if you're hungry and want something good and hearty.

Favorites:
* MARGHERITA ($21)
* NEW YORKER ($29)
* LITTLE ITALY salad ($12)

Others:
* CAL ITALIA ($23)

This was an amazing meal. We got the award winning pizza and spit it between 2 people. It was a sweeter type of pizza which I enjoyed. The service was good not great though. They have a lot of outdoor seating. Very good and would recommend for lunch or dinner.

I really wanted to give this place 5 stars and be totally blown away but unfortunately our service last night was not the greatest. If you come during or a little after the dinner rush there WILL be a wait! And parking is horrendous. Not sure about parking as we are not from here but we ended up at the top of a steep hill to have to walk all the way down to the pizzeria.
The restaurant is on the corner and has outdoor seating as well. We sat in the bar area which was cozy, and intimate. We were not immediately greeted and once our waiter did come his personality although I'm sure hes a very nice man was just bland and not attentive. He did offer his opinion on the pizza he enjoys but that's where it stopped. Never once were we asked if refills were needed we always had to ask. My boyfriend literally tried to flag him down three times at one point and then literally had to yell excuse me to get a beer ordered. And mind you this was right before the dinner rush and or leading into the rush...
I even had to ask for plates and silverware when our salad was brought to us with a spoon to serve everyone at the table but no plate or silverware to eat it with.
The food is what is the real winner here! We started with meatballs as an appetizer. So yum! Tasted homemade and were just the right size. Cesar salad was next which was okay. I feel their dressing could be better. We chose the New Yorker pizza (one of their award winning) with pepperoni, sausage, ricotta cheese and mozzarella. Star of the show! We devoured our pizza and truly enjoyed it.
All in all the environment is very casual and mellow. Good food, and price is okay for the area.

I just ordered a pizza from Tony's Pizza Napoletana and was eating it. So far so good until I saw a hair that resembled a curly pubic hair in the pizza. Soooo nasty!!! I called them before they closed and no answer. WTF.

Garlic and clam pizza with an ipa is my go to when I come to this place. It's super simple, the only down part is that the counter next to the wall has its sheets pretty close to the counter and there is a line most all the time when iv been here but that's because it's great pizza.

So the other night I was waiting for my friend to show up - we were going to Soto Mare next door. I kept looking at the pizza, looking at the pizza, and just couldn't resist. Already had another pizza slice somewhere else that day - but hey - one more won't hurt! Got a slice of sausage pizza - it was a deep crust with barely anything on top. Didn't compare with the other slice earlier that day. Well it was a few bucks cheaper. But I'll pay more for GOOD pizza!
Walk up and order. Long lines and not much indoor seating but delicious pizza. Would highly recommend if you are taking out or at least aren't counting on sitting down.
Worth the wait! Good vibes inside and the pizza was on point.

We came here for a pre-dinner slice of pizza - the signature garlic clam slice. I was impressed with the slice, which had a ton of toppings, sitting on a thick focaccia crust. They reheat the slice when you order it, so it comes out piping hot! Overall, service was quick, price was cheap, portion was large, and pizza tasted great. Would 100% recommend for a cheap lunch/dinner/snack!

Not worth the hype. I don't know if it's drunk people that have reviewed this place thousands of times or what, but it is so overhyped. It would be worth it if you were already in the area and you just snagged a piece quick, but making a special trip and waiting in line for 30+ minutes behind a man smoking weed in your face is not worth it. If you do go, order the pepperoni or sausage, avoid the veggie.

With all that said, the service by the restaurant was top notch. He made me feel extremely valued as a customer. That's worth a lot these days.

I'm from the LA area and I can't seem to find a pizza place as great as Golden Boy's.  Every time I visit SF and we walk through North Beach, there's always a huge line coming out of Golden Boy Pizza.  I'm always too hungry to wait in line for food; but, this time we finally decided to give this place a try line or no line.

There are 6 pizza options at a time all lined up in the front window under a dull red light like hookers in the red light district.  The pizza's probably a lot cheaper, cleaner and a lot more delicious.  There was a selection of the classic pepperoni, sausage, cheese, combination, vegetarian and a one of a kind garlic and clam pizza.  Clam!?!  I decided that I gots to get myself one of thems.  Just in case, we got a sausage combination for backup.  Each slice is toasted right before going out which gives the crust a delicious crunch.  Mmmm I'm gonna go ahead and say, hands down, best crust I've ever had!  Toppings were super fresh too.

Note: those who like thin crusts will not like this place.

I recently moved from Seattle to North Beach and I was looking for a good place to go when I came across this place. I saw a lot of reviews on Yelp and when I saw this place it really stuck with me. The menu is very fresh but also has everything you would expect from pizza. To begin with the pizza, the base was huge and the toppings were on point. The sauce was fresh and the flavors were wonderful and we got the chicken pie! We also got a salad that was very good and the only reason I didn't give this a 5 star rating is because I think there's a better pizza in the area so I didn't give it 5 stars for being that special. I also went with the salad and the chicken pie I had but that one was just too good if I didn't add the toppings. It had the best sauce I've ever had from another place and that's why I gave it a 4 with the salad. If you're in the area and looking for a pizza with great sauce, then give Golden Boy Pizza North Beach a try!

Their pizza is good! It's super cheesy and the crust is nice and doughy. Veggie pesto and pepperoni are delicious. Garlic clam is good too but it gives you major garlic breath afterwards. Always try to get something straight from the oven.

The place is small and cramp. Service is nice and friendly.

It was a sunny day walking around the North Beach district with two of my friends that I brought along with to San Francisco, breaking their City cherries. We were looking for a quick bite to eat: something not too big, but just right to snack on before adventuring to other neighborhoods. We came upon this small shop due to the line that was piling through the entrance that only fits one person at a time. When it was time for us to order, the worker helping us pointed out which pies were which. We decided to share two slices of the clam and garlic pizza between the three of us. I will tell you, I was shocked out how good this pizza was. The first thing you taste is garlic, then you bite into the perfected texture of the crust, and pieces of clam in each bite. At only four bucks for a sizable slice of one of the best pizzas I have ever eaten, I have to say, damn good stuff.

I finally got a chance to try Little Star.  Because it was crowded and loud we ordered two thin crust pizzas for take out instead, and the pizzas were very good.  We had a Pesto Chicken minus the onions with spinach and sundried tomatoes added on.  For my taste this was the better of the two with fresh ingredients and great taste.  The White Pie was super garlicky and good too, but I prefer a little meat on my pie.  I didn't really notice anything special about the crust, but next time we'll try the deep dish.

I was starving when I came home to see this on my kitchen table.  When I first saw the pizza, I thought someone had brought Zachary's.  In comparison, the extra ricotta adds extra cheesiness and a creamier texture.  I love the chunky tomatoes on top, but I think the crust here is too thick, and it doesn't have that sweet doughiness that I like.  Still, this was really satisfying on a cold, rainy night.
The Pom-Pagne is huge and delightful.
Little Star is a staple for me and the group of friends. It's not quite authentic Chicago but its fantastic. Always just delicious and satisfying. Definitely definitely worth a go.

We tried the Little Star deep dish pizza at Little star, and it was pretty rad. The place was pretty full, but the wait did not take long. The crust was buttery, and the cheese to tomato sauce ratio seemed just right.
The Little Star classic:  best cure for Chicago homesickness.  I'm pretty sure it made me sick once but I'm still giving it five stars (that good).
Good pizza...great service, but way too long a wait for pizza.  I thought deep dish would be deeper and the crust left more to be desired...but I loved the pesto thin crust.

Mmm- Very tasty and perfect ! "The Little Star" thin crust was better than most pizza I have had. We also had a garden salad that was the perfect size for 2 of us to share. Our waiter was very cool, too. Good stuff.
Tasty pizza! Friendly service, good for a late night snack.

It's worth the wait!!! I mean what is in the damn sauce?!??! It is so good! I've never been a big fan of deep dish, but this place does it for me. The chicken wings are also spectacular. Also, if you want to skip the wait you can always call in ahead of time for pizza pick-up.
Probably my favorite bakery in all of SF! I can't really walk by without getting a roll.

My first purchase was just so-so (I forget what it was), but since then everything has been yummy. My only disappointment is that they don't put olive oil on the focaccia. I also wish they were open seven days a week.
Amazing sourdough bread, focaccias and pizzas!
I don't know what else to say... Their daily pizza is out of this world delicious.

The way I found out that they close for the Holiday's was funny.  I had a craving for anything!   As I approached another person was also going towards the door.  I think we both realized they were closed.  Yet we both looked through the windows in hope a miracle (was the season to expect a miracle); would occur and there was someone in there baking.  I still recall we both slowly looked at each other and again turned to the window with loud sigh!  The staff does deserve a vacation because they (as Tina would sing) Simply the BEST.  I am lucky to live walking distance way!
Super Deliciousness!!! Absolutely heart the gluten free pumpkin muffins!! Staff is great also.
Soooo good!!! Their "chocolate thing" is to die for! An their baguettes are delicious.

I have really only tried their pizza here which is delicious- especially if you get it there when it is fresh and warm! After looking at other reviews I will have to try some of their pastries and cookies soon (which always look delicious!) I would recommend this place to any one craving something sweet or a healthier piece of pizza!
I just love their half baked pizza! ... and their almond cookies.

Not quite as delicious as Cheeseboard in Berkeley, but a close second. I highly recommend their Chocolate Things and Cheese Rolls, as well as their daily pizza. The staff is always friendly and courteous as well.

OMG!  This pizza is soooo good!  Freak yeah!  I was walking through North Beach searching for North Beach Pizza, and asked this guy where it was at.  He showed me, then said that place two shops down is my personal favorite(Golden Boy Pizza).  Of course I went to the favorite place.  He was so right they sell by the slices range $2.50-$4.00?

The place is small, but you'll most likely find a place to sit, or you can stroll down the street and eat at the park.

Stumbled across it on our way to meet up with some friends. Figured we'd stop and get a bite to eat, and this place smelled awesome so we decided to eat there.

It was super cramped and tiny. The pizza slices are of decent size, but were rather bland.

The pizza wasn't terrible, but I wouldn't go out of my way to eat there again.

Dear Golden Boy Pizza,

You're trying to make me fat, and what's worse than this initial crime is that you are succeeding. I would hate you, if I wasn't stuck in the paradox of loving you so much.

Your thick, juicy slices of pepperoni, veggie, Greek, and Hawaiian are going to be the death of me one day, but the irony is they'll also be my salvation.

I guess they call you Golden Boy because you can get away with murder and still be loved.

Lurv,
Chunky Thighs and Clogged Arteries

This place has heavenly goodness shaped in the form of square pizzas.

We stumbled upon this place one night after dinner nearby.  The pizza was calling to us from the store window.  We made a pact to come back and try it out.  We've been back three times since!  This is hole in the wall place that serves pizza, beer, wine, and soda - nothing else!  That is why they do the pizza right.

Clam and garlic - a must have
Combo and pepperoni are also very good
All less than $4 each for a big square.  Once ordered, they pop your slice into a hot toaster oven to heat up!

So delicious that my bff and I came here after dinner last Sunday.  We sat down, ordered beer and split a clam and garlic slice.  Needless to say, that is not recommended after you've already had dinner, but what can I say, I was seriously craving this pizza!

So i was hungry, and decided I wanted Pizza!

Got on my phone, got to Yelp, typed in Pizza in SF, and I found myself waiting in line for 20 minutes. Luckily, i became great friends with the guys behind me and the time passed by a lot faster. Note: PARKING IS HORRIBLE!!!

Advice:get a friend to drive u so s/he can wait in the car while u get in line.

This place opens until 2am on Saturday, and i was there at 11pm. Can't imagine how crowded this place would've been if it was 1:30am, when ppl from clubbing are hungry and searching for food!

Apparently, there are three types of pizza per day. Man, the pesto with zucchini and mushroom was SOOOOOOOOOO good. It was pan fried on a spongy bread type of thing (not chicago or NY style).

This place gets an extra star b/c the pizza are out on display, but they still pop them into the oven so they are hot and fresh! YUMMMMMMM

man, i want some right now!!!!!!!!!

the pizza guy was nice too when i told him it was first time there!

It's good for the bready-square-type of pizza, but I prefer Cable Car pizza on Broadway for their gigantic, NY style thin-crust pizza. The good thing is that the pizza comes out piping hot, topped generously, and very cheesy.

I thought the combo was better than the clam....who says you only have to have one slice?

I had some friends visiting from out of town & we did a touristy Alcatraz tour. Afterward one of them suggested pizza in North Beach, but didn't know where to go. I texted my roommate. His response: "Golden Boy!" Good call on his part.

It's definitely kind of a dive, but it's delicious and cheap and delicious. It's Sicilian style pizza, which I like and the place doesn't have a zillion toppings and weird kinds of pizzas, which I also like. Everything is pre-made, and they just heat it up. There's only five options (cheese, pepperoni, clam/garlic, veggie, and combo). I went with the combo which has pepperoni, sausage, peppers, onion, & mushroom.  It was yummy!  I could taste all the different toppings and the crust was chewy.  It didn't fall apart and wasn't too dry.  They also serve beer, which is also a plus.

There's not a lot of seating, but who cares? It's only pizza. Stand and eat if you have to! It's been awhile since I've done the late night North Beach scene, but I can see where this place would get pretty crowded at the end of the night on the weekends :)

so here's the trick with this place...parking is ridiculous.  so make sure you bring a friend...one person runs in while the other person parks illegally at a fire hydrant or double park your booty somewhere.  grab the pizza...jump back into the car...and go go go!!!

we couldn't decide what to get...so we got 4 different slices..clams & garlic, pesto vegetarian, pepperoni, and combination.

MmMMmMMMMhMmMmmmm...what can i say?  there wasn't even a crumb left in the box.  everything tasted really fresh...and 4 slices cost $14.50...not too shabby.  my only complain which is probably one of my preferences...i would've liked a little more sauce on the pizza...wifey, on the other hand, thought it was perfect...

this place is the real deal...good pizza in an awesome poppin neighborhood...minus the parking...perfect for a drunken night out and needing some good ole carbs to prevent a hangover.  YUMMY!!!

Who ever said square pizza was not good? Must have been someone who never tried Golden Boy Pizza. This place is LEGIT! HUGE pieces of pizza topped with all kinds of good stuff.

A whole bunch of friends ordered 2 TRAYS of the combination...man o man was this pizza good. Ate ONLY 3 slices and I was STUFFED.

The staff was friendly and made an exception for us...usually they don't make trays after a certain time, but the guy was nice enough to do it for us. I will definitely be coming back here when I'm in the area.
Really good pizza and really good service. I will eat here again and again.

Pizza in North Beach, definitely the place for pizza. We came in with no reservation but got a fun seat watching the pizza being made for the wood burning oven. A little tight and next to the service station but no wait and pretty private, its good for me!

We had the americano which essentially has almost everything on it. I enjoyed it immensely but eat it fresh cause the crust will be mushy if you take it home. The crust was crunchy and soft at the time time. You could taste the quality in the ingredients, super staff, fun atmosphere, people eating here really enjoyed it.

Next time, I want to try their gigantic meatballs and the square pizza. So many items to choose from, everyone will happy.

Not the best pizza I have ever had but pretty dang close.  A lot of hype around this place and I believe it is well deserved.  We did not feel like waiting for a dining spot inside since there was line just to get your name on the list. We slipped over to a side entrance that let you order by the slice or an entire pizza if you were willing to wait.  We got several different types of slices so we could get a feel.  Their variation on meat lover pizza and a pepperoni pizza were great.  We grabbed five fountain cokes and ate outside on tables they provide along the sidewalk.  All of that for under $60.  The staff was efficient, friendly and seemed genuinely happy to be at work.  Please note that one slice of pizza is like size of two slices at most places.  We were glad we gave it a try.  I didn't think I could stand to see one more clam chowder in a bread bowl this week.

Came here for dinner with a co-worker and really enjoyed the ambiance, drinks, food, and service!

Although there was quite a long wait, we were able to bypass this by using the Yelp waitlist tool to add ourselves to the list while walking over from our office. We still had to wait about ten minutes, but that drastically cut the time down from about an hour to a hour and fifteen minutes.

We were seated by the pizza oven. While some may not like this type of bar seating, we LOVED it! It was really cool to get to watch the chef make all the different kinds of pizzas, not to mention it smelled amazing.

We choose to order the sangria, tartufo crostini, and a margherita pizza. The sangria was perfect to share, as it produced 4 glasses. Furthermore, it was delicious! The tartufo crostini was also amazing. Felt super meaty and buttery, almost like eating clams on toast. However, the pizza was a definite standout as it was really tasty and was handed directly to us from the pizza chef we were watching!

Overall: I really enjoyed my experience here and look forward to coming back!

Best pizza in SF!!!  It speaks for itself. Highly recommend the New York thick crust. Amazong?
They also have the best cannoli!  And a wide selection of great tasting beers.
Love it! I'm not a pizza person but their grandma style pizza is really good and got me like pizza now! Highly recommended, well deserved 4 stars on yelp!

Went here on a Friday night, early (530ish). They had a 30 minute wait. They said we could go walk around and see the cute shops just up the street. After 20 mins they texted us and we went back and were immediately seated.

All time best pizza I've ever had. I have not been able to find a Honey Pie pizza anywhere else and it was my all time favorite pizza I've ever had. The margarita was also amazing! And to top it all off, we had some Lillet Blanc Fries. Oh my gosh. It's frustrating to try to put in to words how amazing it is.

Ordered the Stromboli. Taste was good: stuffed with fresh cheese, pepperoni and topped with garlic. The service on the other hand was spotty. For the price, it was a bit overcharged for overall taste. The area is busy on weekends!

And they play bomb music.

Tony's Pizza is amazing!! The worst part is trying to decide on a pizza or two or three!! We had the great Grandma, stout and sausage pizzas - they were wonderful! We also had the fried artichoke and green beans - so good! We are already planning our next visit!!!

Decent tasting pizza, but it didn't blow me away like expected and the dining experience left a lot to be desired. My wife signed up for the wait list online and we arrived well before our names were supposed to be called. The wait list stated that there would be a table ready for us at 7:30 PM. As soon as we checked in, the hostess told us that we would have to wait another 30 minutes. This wasn't exactly music to our ears, as the waiting area was packed, and we walked from Montgomery Street and had to wait outside in the cold. Once we were seated, we were given a table outside, along Union Street. If I'm going to eat in a restaurant, I literally want to be IN a restaurant. We weren't even asked if we wanted to be seated outside.

On to the food:

The wife and I started with the garlic green beans, which the wife happened to love. We then ordered their famous Margherita and the New Yorker. Between the two, the New Yorker tasted better overall. Even though it had more toppings, the dough still stayed crisp and manageable in my hands, as opposed to the Margherita, which got soggy after the second slice. I understand this is a Michelin rated establishment, but I've honestly had better elsewhere. This is purely subjective, but I believe their prices don't justify their product. Will we be back? Probably not.

Oh man it's good. I was debating and debating coming here. I was aiming for Il Casaro, but since they removed their wait list feature (I hate waiting) I just chose the best pizza prospect I could find.
I am SO glad I did, oh man. The wait list time was pretty accurate and super easy to use. I checked in about 20 mins before we were seated and just had a little sit in the park before the text to say our table was ready.
Between three of us we ordered the calamari, caesar, and three pizzas. The calamari is a huge portion (as it should be for $17) and was good. The Caesar was stand out.
We went for Cal Italia, the Bianco Tonno and the Some Like it Hot. The Cal Italia was really good, mild and a little sweet. The Some Like it Hot was okay, not my personal cup of tea and super spicy, but the crust was delightful. Tonno.... oh my god. Amazing. I could eat five to myself. Seriously. Oh my god.
Desserts left room for improvement. We ordered one cannoli (looked OK) and two gelatos (OK). Probably not worth the money as there are some really good cafes and bakeries in the area.
Service was really attentive and friendly, with recommendations happily given and constant water service. The hostess in charge of reservations was a little sharp, but I guess they're super busy so it's understandable.
I LOVE when the pepperoni is under the cheese. This makes me so very happy. The crust is delicious. Their pizza converted me from a thin crust lover to a deep dish person.

It's pretty easy to miss this little place. We actually drove by 3 times looking for parking and were still unable to locate where little star was. That was until I actually spotted a "little star" and I got a little peek inside the restaurant. Place seemed a bit like those shady night clubs where they open a little slit and ask you for a password before you come in. Just my opinion.

We found parking a lot easier than we were anticipating which was good because SF street parking could be a little B. We got in, the restaurant seemed to be lit only by natural sunlight haha. Not super crowded on a Thursday evening. We were promptly seated and then ordered of course the deep dish pizza and an order of spicy chicken wings. The deep dish was a bit disappointing...I guess that's what happens when things are hyped up. I was expecting some sort of fiesta in my mouth but it never came. The chicken wings were actually pretty good. Pizza on the otherhand, could have been better. I think the sauce was a bit too tart for my taste and needed more of a marinara zing to it. The pie itself did look very appetizing. Maybe a different combination would have made a difference? Prices aren't to die for either. Pretty reasonable. I don't think the pizza is good enough for me to crave in the future though.

3.5 stars

Truly so happy SF opened a Chicago style pizza that may even surpass Zachary's in Oakland!  The cornmeal crust is actually a bit richer than Zachary's, so that is a win in my book, but my family actually marks the pies down for the buttery crust.  The service is not pretentious, but the atmosphere is a bit cramped.  Try it!
I finally got a chance to eat at Little Star Pizza.  My friend and I split the mixed salad and a small classic pizza.  It was delicious.  I will be back!

Little Star, Delfina, Golden Boy, Pizza Orgasmica...there are many pizza places in the city that word has it 'do not suck', because let's be honest, West Coast pizza sucks. That's right, I said it, and you should have known this already. Golden Boy is my favorite so far but after trying Little Star it's going to be my local favorite (the schlop on Lower Haight is only good for drunk eating).

Ambiance (4): Standard issue hipster-ish interior with low lights, mixture of wood and metal, and some art on the wall. Not complaining, it's good to go, just not what I expect of a pizza joint.

Food (4): They are known for their deep dish but after going to Chicago a few times, I have sworn off deep dish pizza. It's just too much...too much! We had a thin crust with pancetta, goat cheese, chicken, and I don't remember what else (it had me at pancetta). It was pretty tasty and the crust was good and crisp. We ordered the smaller size since we were having wings too and it was just the right size. The chicken wings were not bad, but I haven't had a chicken wing that doesn't remind me of microwaveable buffalo wings since Sports Grill (new English rule: double negative bad, triple negative good). This might be related to the wings not being grilled, which is my preferred wing preparation method. In terms of drinks, I appreciate that they have tempranillo and malbec in stock in addition to the usual suspects, so if you like red wine, they are bound to have something that appeals to your tastes. Of course they have beer and white wine too. Also the 10 dollar corkage fee is appreciated.

Service (4): Great, friendly service. The timing of the dishes arriving was perfect and I don't know if it's coincidence or the server putting in the order in a certain way or us eating at just the right rate. Anyway, I felt welcomed and being taken care of without the incessant and forced niceties of some fancy restaurants (I am looking at you Gary Danko). There always seems to be a wait to get a table though, but what can you do when the place has good foodie cred?

Value (4): The prices of all menu items seemed just right. That includes the cost of drinks and I already mentioned the corkage fee.

Overall: I liked this place but did not love it like I do Golden Boy. The quality is good and the flavors were good but just not amazing. However, this the best option in my area, so next time take out will be the way to go to avoid the wait. Oh and if you have a deep dish craving, this is one of the few places in the city that I have spotted it so far.

Hey dudes, I'm not just being contrary to be contrary, on the contrary, I'm just trying to be honest.  

(OK, skip this first paragraph, it's shite!)

I think that saying you love one pizza and hate the next is an almost useless exercise.  Pizza is just one of those things that is done so many different ways, that one persons favorite method is the next persons death.  I don't know you, you may be my inverted pizza doppleganger.  Do you like Pizza Hut, Chuck E. Cheese, Escape from NY Pizza, Pizzeria Delfina, Patxi's, Orgasmica, etc...  I'm sure if I had the time, and patience I could go on and on about crust styles, cooking styles, toppings, sauces, etc.  but I don't and won't.  Having said that Pizza made with crap is gonna taste crap, and pizza made with quality ingredients, has a chance.  If we cut our pizza teeth together, compared pizza notes together, sat down and philosophized about pizza, if I knew where you were coming from, then I could take your advice.  Hey wait, I could read your other pizza reviews, but I'm just too lazy for that and prefer to rant a little.

Anyway, I digress.  I can't say I'm a fan of Little Star pizza.  The first time I went there, I got one of their deep dishes and one thinny to share.  It was long ago, but the one things I remember was there was no balance to the toppings on the deep dish, i wish i could remember which one it was, but I do remember it coming out too salty, needing something to contrast the salt to bring it all together.  There was something mediocre about the thinny too, but I forget.  The second time I went to LS, whatever.  I had another pizza there tonight and was disappointed once again.  This time just a plain cheese thin one; this is like the blank canvas of pizzas, upon which a great pizza can be built, but also could and should be great in it's plainness.  So, in addition to the crust being burnt (this should NEVER happen), I found the crust too chewy to be enjoyable and wasn't too jazzed about its flavor when I got to the end.  I wasn't crazy about the sauce and even the cheese was not that great, I think too thick for a thin crust, but that's just my opinion, take it or leave it.  So, i don't like their pizza, you do, I think we can still be friends.

I do like the ambiance here, the dark dining room, quite music, I remember the bartenders being friendly, comfy couches to wait the two hours it can take to get a table.  Even the ATM has a pretty cheap service charge, which is great since this place doesn't take plastic (wtf).

P.S. PBR = VOMIT  (maybe we can't be friends)
I love Little Star so much I want to take it behind the middle school and get it pregnant. Deep dish to die for.
If you are patient you'll be rewarded with some quality deep dish pizza, but watch out for the health tax!

I prefer the location in Valencia better but the pizza is still delicious here. I feel like this location is smaller than the one on Valencia so the wait tends to be longer. I've been here multiple times and have had to wait over an hour each time. But the last time I came really early (at like 6) and there was no wait, so I was pleased, but then again I came on a Wednesday night. I brought my parents and they loved the pizza but they didn't like the dim lighting in the restaurant...

Anyways, on the recommendation of a friend, on Sunday, boyfriend's brother's girlfriend brought home the my favorite, the Little Star, but this time with sausage (deep dish of course) and it was AMAZING! I didn't think the Little Star could get any better but it did!

Chicago-style pizza fans REJOICE!  Having moved to SF from Chicago, I've had Lou Malnati's shipped here just to savor the tomato-smothered, cheesy, goodness. No more now that I have Little Star.  Order the "Classic" deep-dish.  I've had it my last four visits and cannot seem to move on to a new order as the "Classic" is soooo damn good.

Delish, delish, delish.  Excellent customer service, except: the lines are long and there is little parking to speak of in the neighborhood.  The latter isn't unusual, so just take Muni or plan enough time to park several blocks away if need be.  But I feel there could be two people helping up front more often.  It's almost always been only one person at the cash register.  Oh: their pizza is OUT of this world so stop by for a lunchtime slice.
Super yummy! We got the corn blueberry muffin and the specialty scone, raspberry plum. They have a $10 minimum for debit cards so make sure you have cash, or just grab another muffin for later!

This bakery is AMAZING!

I started going here every Sunday after shopping around the Farmer's Market on 9th ave. I've had their sliced pizza, which comes out freshly baked with great topping, as well as their sourdough chocolate, both of which tasted great. You can tell the quality of their baked goods just by the heavenly smell that stretches outside onto the street.

My only complaint is that you need to make a 10 dollar minimum purchase if you're using a card, which can be a pain if I just want something small and a coffee. Besides that though, highly recommend!

yum yum yummy!
they have it all right.
good baked goods from the earth to their oven to our mouths!
and if you're on a bike they knock of another 5 or 10% or something..
and if you get someone with a smile.. it makes it even better!

Artichoke!!! Parsley!!! Onion!!! a good portion of the pizzas are not worth it, buuuuuuuut the artichoke/parsley/onion one is a whole different story, i've been known to leave work early to get a fresh slice.
This place is the bomb!  I' ve been going there for years and love the fresh bread and pizza! go!

My dream is to one day live inside the Arizmendi bakery. It is a magical place full of the most delicious breads, pizzas, and breakfast goods you could possibly imagine.
The corn cherry scone is TO DIE FOR but just about everything else i've sampled is amazing as well. I live about an hour away from SF, and since I can't go every morning for breakfast I had to find the recipe online so I could make them myself. However, nothing compares to the real thing, fresh from Arizmendi.

The only downside is the lack of room to sit and enjoy my food/coffee, but I won't take off points for that because the baked goods are so incredible!!

This place is awesome and not just for the bread.
The tabouli is a hidden treasure - so yummy!
Also I have a crush on one of the employees.

Cool place. Super fast considering I stood in line with a cool crowd for 5 minutes. Got 2 pieces of the balsamic vinegar pizza, went and ate it in the park. Good pizza, flavorful because of good ingredients (rather than just lots of cheese and sauce).
Oh yea and $4.50 for 2 pieces of pizza is a good deal.

This place is saaa-wwww-eeeet!   Their employees always seem happy and I always feel welcome, which in turn makes me spend more money.   Not near my apt but I take an extra bus just to get to this place at least twice a week.  Well worth it.  Anyone who hasn't tried this place is missing out.

Don't be fooled by the reviews! It might be all paid. The pizza was HORRIBLE HORRIBLE HORRIBLE to say the least. We ordered Pesto veg, 2 slices of cheese, and 2 slices of meat lover. I have never had such bland and tasteless Pizza in my life. I don't recommend this place and literally out of of words for the 4.5 star rating it has. It's a HOAX!

Really good pizza. We came here late at night and had to wait 10-15 mins in line. We got a slice of the pesto, combination and pepperoni. The pesto one was probably our favorite. The slices are rectangular so you don't get any crust. The dough is a bit thicker but I enjoyed it. The interior is very small and it can be hard to find a seat and the line of people waiting to order never seemed to slow down.
Thick crust pizza with burned cheese on the bottom, can it get better than that?  Great local beers on tap and friendly staff.

The BF raved about this pizza for so long that when my daughter and I finally tried it - it was OK. I mean we weren't blown away are anything.
Our favorite pizza place is Settebello in Henderson, NV. (where we live)
Anyhow, I wouldn't say that we wouldn't patronize Golden Boy cause I would- I'd try other pizza with different toppings - maybe the other toppings would add to my flavor bar. We just got a cheese for me and a cheese and pepperoni for my daughter.
I think it was about $3.50 to $4.50 per square (no slices here) and you can always get it heated up.
Now, the BF on the other hand is a huge Golden Boy fan and I believe will be one till the day he enters SF 49er Heaven.

*** Small place with a line outside (in SF that means almost always in the cold) and you can't help but notice that the bar is completly covered in random stickers of or about everything & anything.....***

We happened upon this place late night with a line out the door and vowed to return the next day.  So glad we did!! Standing outside looking at the slices, the young man next to me said "try the garlic parsley clam, it's the best!" He then shared how he'd grown up in the area and been eating their pizza since childhood.  With a review like that how could I not try it?  It was amazing!! The crust was crisp and the the toppings delicious.  Just GO!

If you have ever walked by this small shop and wondered "why the line?", in this case the line does not lie. This small pizza shop is SO good I would go out of my way for a slice of any of their pizzas any day.

The Garlic is a little strong, so if you're not a fan of having garlic on your breath you might want to order something else, but it's hard to go wrong with any of their pies. This place is CASH ONLY, $3 a slice. Portions are generous, and there is limited seating in the back.

Go with a friend, have a conversation in line, and grab a few slices to enjoy over a cold bear or soda. If they're busy (as is often the case) you might have to wait a bit to get your order, but remember it's worth the wait.

my definite to go drunk late night pizza spot.  hands down the best pizza in the whole san francisco.  so tasty and so delicate.  its like having a fancy pizza without the fancy and the pizza which didn't make any sense.  me and my friends have been coming here for quite some time and they do open until late nights for those late night munchies.  grab a beer and grab a slice of pizza and enjoy all the graffiti they have inside the shop.  they can even give you a marker if you kindly ask them for one.

I rarely fall in love with just one pizza maker but I must admit that this here is love! I'm not only saying this because it was 2am and I've had a couple of drinks, because I've had pizza after 2am before. Not like this though. Not like this.

I wasn't expecting much just a quick fill for my growling tummy. What I got was ooey gooey deliciousness!! The cheese stretched for days when I took a bite. The crust was airy, light and had just the right amount of thickness and crunch. The sauce was outta this world! Yup. Sure was. Saucy amazingness is all I can say about that.

Ugh. Why must all my loves be so far away?! We shall meet again lover.

Cute and delicious square pizzas. My husband and I ordered: 2 pesto vegetarian, 2 clams, and 1 combo. The pesto was good, but lacked some oomph compared to the other pizzas. Definitely come back for the clam pizza. Lots of clams, garlic, and parsley. YUM! My breath still tastes like garlic. My husband said the combo pizza was pretty good.

Total cost: $18.75. Cash only place. ATM is located in the back of the restaurant.

Perfect little pizza joint in SF (and boy do they like their pizza up there). The quadrilateral pizza arrangements in the window are definitely the clincher; you have to go in after that. The decor is super punk rawk but with a homey feel (check out the family photos on the pizza fridge).

After having my Hemp Ale, I only had room for one slice so, after a meaty dinner the night before, I opted for the vegetarian pesto which was DELISH! Great crust-to-toppings ratio, flavor and variety. If I had room I would've tried the garlic clam pizza hands down - it smelled like garlicky heaven.

Golden Boy Pizza is serious nommmm.
We beat the dinner rush and got a table with our two kids. It gets loud fast but the pizza is amazing and the staff is great.
