This is by far the best deep dish pizza I have found in the city.  Almost as good as the real deal deep dish from Chicago. Little Star has a great atmosphere and a good selection of music on the jukebox.  What I didn't like was the extremely long wait to get your food.  Don't wait till your starving to go here.  You may pass out of hunger before you get your pizza.

This place makes me quiver and jump for joy because it's so delicious.  Every part of the deep dish pizza is amazing from the tomatoes to the toppings to the delicious crust.  It's even amazing the next day.  It gets really crowded, very loud and I always have to wait.   Nearby parking sucks and it's a cash only... all of which I don't care -the pizza's that good.
Little Star was great. I haven't had deep dish and like it that many times but this flipped the script. The house special was loaded. Took it home and ate it for breakfast the next morning.

Little Star Pizza is by far the second best pizza i have ever laid my taste buds on. I came here yesterday with the in-laws and could not wait to get my grub on! Unfortunately, i really had to wait. I endured 30 mins of bickering from the two, until the pie was ready. But oh my $%%^&*(lgjvsdsd[ae. Sorry my tongue fell on my keyboard. Was it worth the wait! We ordered one large special which i believe was meat balls, spinach, peppers and cheese, as well as chicken pesto. They were equally delicious! What makes Little Star different from the "other guys" is their rich and almost maybe home made tomato sauce, as well as their pie crust! The crust is NOT doughy!  Its not dry, tasteless, or overwhelming. It has sort of a flaky, buttery, melt in your mouth, kinda nom nom nom nom to it! Definately a place I would wander back to ! (without the bickering of course =)
what can I say.  Can't wait for the new one to open in the Mission.  All other pizza spots in the hood are hearby served notice.

I would always see this place when I go to the Independent, but would never really have the time to stop by.  Luckily, earlier this month, I finally had a chance.  Their deep dish is brilliant.  I had the pepperoni and cheese, pretty basic, but it's what I like.  I'd say this place beets Zachary's, but for deep dish pizza, Paxti's is my favorite.  Little Star is a very close second though.  It's very nice inside.  I imagine if we needed a table we would've needed to wait because the place was packed.  We ate sitting on the sidewalk in front of the Independent, which went great actually, I really enjoyed it.  I'm sure I'll be coming back for the full dining experience.

I love me a deep dish little star pizza from little star!  Yes, both the the particular pie I'm speaking of and the name of the establishment in which it is baked is called little star.  Their thin crust is good too, but the deep dish..... fahgeddaboutit.  I've eaten in at little star once and I'm hip to it's vibe-age.  You'll love it too if you're in to darkness and candlelight.  While joining me to pick up a pizza my father referred to it as "sketchy" :)  Sure enough he enjoyed several slices!

little star is my heaven.
the little star pizza itself is the best pizza i have ever had!!!!
the mediterranean one is pretty good too.
even their salad made my mouth water.
they offer pbr in a can. now tell me where else i can get that and an awesome slice of pizza.

if i could i would go to little star every day but unfortunately i cant.

best deep dish pizza i have ever had. BJ's is shit compared to this.

Not a fan of Deep Dish Pizza? You will be... Not a fan of Vegetarian Pizza? Eat the "Little Star" and You will be...Corn bread crust is insanely delicious. Everything else is too with the combo of the freshest tomato sauce, spinach, feta, mushrooms and other wonderful ingredients. This is a pizza you can't stop eating even after your full! Classic sausage jus as good. So fun to dine in or do take out. My cousins and I had the best time here last night! Super festive* With already a billion rave reviews, all I can say is this place is a must do~

it's a co-op, it's delicious, it's pear scones, it's amazing cheese things, it's amazing cheese, it's baby friendly, it's radical basque priest friendly.....Ladies and Gentlemen: It's AAAAAAARIZMENDIIIII!!!!!!

I stop here every weekend, sometimes twice.  It's the best bakery I've found in the city, and certainly the neighborhood.  Out of all the other Arizmendi bakeries around the bay that I've visited, this one gets the closest the recipe originals at the Cheese Board in Berkeley.  For breakfast the scones and pecan rolls are my favorites.  Pizza of the day starts at 11:30am and you can get a half-baked one to take home.
lavender shortbread = heaven on earth. get a bagful, some tea, and cruise over to the cal academy, sit on the steps and bask in the deliciousness.

a little backstory on how i discovered arizmendi:  my dog managed to come down with pancreatitis which is pretty serious.  she had been euphemistically "sick" for a couple of days (i'll leave out the details since i'm going to transition to food in just a sec).  long story short is she continued to be sick until things weren't the right color and a trip to the 9th avenue emergency vet on a saturday morning at 5 a.m. was required.  so i'm sitting there as tests are being run before the sun has even risen and i begin to smell baking breads.  mind you, i'm sitting in an emergency veterinary clinic which unmistakably smells of dog and, more specifically, sick dog.  at some point after the vet tech has encouraged me to come back after a little while because it's going to take some time to get the results, i step outside to figure out where this fantastic odor is coming from (no, not the sick dog smell).  that's how i found arizmendi.  and when it opened its doors at 8 a.m. that morning, i was the first customer inside.  

now, i'm happy to tell you that the dog has made a full recovery and i've not needed to return to the emergency vet.  but a trip to arizmendi is now an almost weekly journey.  if i lived anywhere near the inner sunset, i'd be there every morning until i weighed 300 lbs.

as for the baked goods (i've still not tried the pizzas), i don't even like scones but arizmendi's are divine.   the pecan roll is unreal.  do not leave this place without one.  you can eat it tomorrow if you're not in the mood for a sweet.  i assure you that you will not regret this purchase.  the chocolate thing (basically a brioche roll with chocolate chunks) is baked with so much love that i could taste it.  the coffee cake changes daily and i can safely say that the apple and the berry varieties are off the hook.  the freshly made english muffins (they've been warm every time i've bought them) are superb.  

my only complaint:  there was orange rind in the king cake.  king cake has cinnamon in it.  king cake does not have orange rind.  i've forgiven arizmendi for this small transgression.  i'll order my king cake online from new orleans.  otherwise, i've not met a bread product i didn't like at arizmendi.
blueberry cornmeal muffins. and coffee. please don't change, arizmendi...please don't change.

BEST BAKERY IN TOWN. Only issue I have is some (not all) of the dyke women who work there are clearly anti kids. One told my kid to shut up when he gave out a scream of joy because he was about to GET PIZZA. I was shocked that a women who CLEARLY doesn't bathe would question a child-fact is her stink was more annoying than my child yelling yeah to pizza (for the record that women is no longer there) and yes I told her she stunk-which apparently no one has ever told her because the shocked look on her face said it all. Those of us that live in the neigborhood will put up with such attitudes because the whole of the place is what counts-not one person...but prices are going up...and so has attitude. Not sure it can hold its 5 star ranking much longer. Pizza over the last year and half has gone down hill (was easily at one time the best pizza in the city..easily). And they seem to either lack bakers or they are getting lazy because they rarely have the same selection of pervious years. (i live right next to this place and have for the last 8 years). Nonetheless, even with all my complaints..still holds its own against the northbeach barkeries. Bewarned though, this place is BEYOND PRETENTIOUS.

mmm...great veggie pizza on sourdough crust.  my friends and i ordered pizza from here tonight, and it was light baked so that you finish baking it at home.  the flavor of the day was tomato and artichoke hearts, and it was yummy.  i think i like the pizza at cheeseboard better, but then again, it probably just depends on which flavor you get.  i want to come back and try the dif breads here as well!

This bakery has been around for as long as I can remember but I'm shooting myself in the foot for not trying it sooner. Even my dad has been here before! The bf and I visited for the first time a few weeks ago to grab some goodies for breakfast before heading over to the Alemany Farmer's Market. I grabbed a raspberry and rhubarb scone and he grabbed a slice of coffee cake. The scone was moist and tart with the perfect amount of sweetness on top. The coffee cake was sweet and paired well with the coffee we grabbed at Drip'd across the street.
    We returned again today to grab a quick bite for lunch. He got me a slice of the pizza of the day which was tomato, feta, garlic oil, parsley and onion and he grabbed a slice of the foccacia with roasted potato, onion and mushrooms. Both items were tasty and fresh out of the oven. The pizza had a nice bite to the crust. The foccacia had a slight sourdough taste to it which was nice. I can't wait to come back and try more items because everything has been amazing so far.
Yum. Thank goodness I do not live near this bakery, otherwise I would be 10 pounds heavier. For an occassional treat, this bakery has great options.

The pizza is pretty good here. What separates their pizza from the crowd is that the crust has a slightly crunchy exterior but is chewy on the inside -- kind of like how a french fry is supposed to be. And they have the best pecan rolls in San Francisco; actually, here I had the best pecan roll I have ever had in my life.
my favorite place for delicious pizza in the city. We had margarita pizza, meat ball gigante and the New Yorker pizza. Everything is so delicious

It would have received one star for the burnt pizza we received but the waiter was very courteous and helpful so for that I'm giving it three stars.  

The night before my husband and I saw this on the Food Network as being rating #3 best pizza joint in the USA.  So we trekked it out to SF to try it out.  We ordered what was featured to be its specialty, the Margherita Pizza.  When we received it and I took my first bite all I tasted was charred crust; definitely couldn't taste pizza!  I told the waiter and he said that all the pizza's come out like that because of the oven.  Well HOW IN THE WORLD would this pizza be rated #3 in the USA if it's so burnt.  I told him they just need to watch it closer.  He asked if we wanted to order something other then what we ordered for our second pizza just in case it came out burnt...... :-O whaaaaa ummmm sure.  We ended up ordering the Stromboli instead.  The Stromboli was killer.  The featured pizza........ NOT SO!  It would be killer if the cooks would just keep an eye on it before it got burnt!  

Was the hype on the Food Network and the trek out to SF worth it?  NO!!!  Truly disappointed!

Eh. Visited San Fran for the weekend and this was the most reviewed pizza spot. Honestly I was not impressed. They said it was medium crust and it was very thin in my opinion and crunchy. Also very greasy and very hot. And for a "personal" pizza that was the most expensive small pizza I have ever paid for.

HUGE SERVICE ISSUE! We came here for my friend's birthday dinner on Memorial Day as several people said the pizza is great. I will start by saying the pizza is very good, which is why I still gave two stars instead of one. However, the night was very much hurt by the horrible service.

Tony's does not take reservations, so they say to be prepared to wait 1.5-2 hours for dinner. We put our name down for 5 people and went to Joe's across the street for a glass of wine. We were told it'd likely be about a 1.5 hour wait. We were texted only about 45 minutes later saying our table was ready and that our entire party needed to be present at the hostess stand within 5 minutes or they would give away our table. We rushed to pay our bill at Joe's and also frantically called our 5th friend to hurry over because she had been expecting to not have to be there until at least 30 minutes later. Once we arrived, the hostess forgot we had 5 people and not just 4 and asked us to wait a bit. We waited an ADDITIONAL 50 minutes!!! Don't force us to rush over from across the street saying our table is ready only to force us to wait almost another hour sitting in the squished area next to the hostess stand.

Finally, we are getting seated and I mention to the women that it is my friend's birthday. I ask if they can bring out a dessert for her. The woman says yes and asks if tiramisu is okay. She even makes sure to confirm which one of my friends is the birthday girl. She says she will let the waiter know. Once seated, we wait for at least 15 minutes, and no waiter comes by (not even to get us water.) By now it is past 9pm (they stop guaranteeing tables at that time even if you're on the wait list as the restaurant closed at 10.) We are hungry and inpatient.

The menu can be pretty overwhelming because there are a TON of options. And for the average person, it's kind of hard to really know the difference between Detroit, New York, Sicilian, California, Grandma, and Classic Italian. We wanted help from our waiter, and we're pretty sure he was high. He was speaking so quietly and didn't seem to have much energy to help us make a decision. We ended up getting the prosciutto coccoli to start, the Cal Italia pizza, the New Yorker pizza, and a carafe of red sangria to share. The food is good however a lot of their pizzas are very saucy and me along with another of my friends don't actually like tomato sauce that much. So that was more unfortunate for us, but others did like it. The Cal Italia doesn't have tomato sauce, but I didn't really like the sticky fig preserve.

The final straw however came with us being done with our food and waiting 20 more minutes. No one came by to offer a dessert menu or to pack up our leftovers or even to bring the check. The restaurant was essentially closed, and we were one of the last tables in the restaurant. Finally, I went up to our waiter to ask where our tiramisu was and to get the check. He looked at me with a blank stare and said the woman never told him about a birthday or a dessert. HELLLO ARE YOU KIDDING. Then he says needs to go and check to make sure they can still bring the dessert because the kitchen has already closed... Thankfully, they did end up bringing it out but it wasn't the best quality (kind of melted). Also, he even still charged us $8 for the dessert....

I will not be coming back unless I happen to have 3.5 hours to waste while people stop by to serve me when they feel like it... I can get good pizza somewhere else without this frustration, especially on a birthday.

We were thoroughly delighted with our afternoon pizza feast. As you can see, four pies for three teenagers & a mom seems extreme but after miles of walking the city for a week we were ready!  Best pizza we'd ever experienced.

This review is for TONY'S A GO GO, a couple of doors down....

Walking into North Beach, we are at Stockton and Union, AKA Gemignani Corner. Tony Gemignani is a LEGEND in the pizza world. A former competitor and Team Captain for Team USA at the World Pizza Championships in Italy, Tony is a 9-time World Champion, and is soooo badass, that the Italians had asked him to stop competing. They were tired of getting their asses whooped in their own home turf! He still goes to the World Pizza Championships, but this time as a judge.

Its cool to see that he set up shop in North Beach, not only to share his award winning pizzas, but also to share his knowledge at his pizza school.
Tony's restaurant had a pretty long wait, so we got a couple of slices to go.
We even caught a glimpse of Tony himself giving a tour of his operation .

The crust was a perfect combination of crunchy and chewy, just the right amounts of tomato sauce and cheese You can taste and see the quality of ingredients used in making all of his pizzas. I so wish he would set up shop in Las Vegas......ALOHA!!!
Favorite pizza I've had in SF so far! Tony's is a solid option to grab takeout or dine in if you are in North Beach.

The pizza we had was underwhelming, but I remain hopeful.

With all the awards and reviews of this place I was expecting to blown out of the park no matter what pizza we ordered. However, I feel like the pizza we ordered is just not the one they are known for.

We got the New Haven Lou and the crust was very tasteless. I have had other places where I will eat the pizza from tip to crust. But this pizza crust was very blah. The toppings were great, you can tell the mozzarella was fresh. I really enjoyed it but when you got to the crust it was like a cold shower on an exciting evening. :/

But the bread and dipping oils they provide before your dinner were awesome. Got to LOVE the garlic and agave nectar - two things I would never had thought to put together are wonderful.

I really want to give this place another try when we come back to the Bay Area, however, I was disappointed that place did not impress me the first time. But, I remain hopeful. :D

Had the New Yorker and it was probably the best pizza I have ever eaten!!  I would recommend taking an Uber to get there as parking is tough and if you plan on walking you are gonna be dealing with SF's homeless problem.  Make sure you get your name on the list early using their on-line waiting app.

Relatively short wait. Met some friends at the park kitty corner and before they got there went over and put my name in on he wait list. They text you when the res is ready. Went back to the park and let the kids play.  Wait was about 30 minutes and we got a text sayin table was ready. Headed over and was sat right away.

The place is pretty small with a bar area when you first walk in with a dining room connected in the next room over. They also have a large patio outside.  We sat in the adjoining room. There menu is extensive. There is a style of pizza available for whatever officianado you claim to be. Coal fired, wood fired, Sicilian, regular, Italian, New Jersey, New York, St. Louis and even Detroit. Some items are limited in the amount they sell each day so be aware. We chose a Sicilian called the grandma butcher. Had a thicker focaccia type dough. Lots of meat. We also got a spicy regular crust called the diavlo.  Both were really tasty. But really pricey.  $28 for one and $40 for the other. Both good size and lots of toppings. 2 peronis 2 pizzas and tip $100.  But we fed 3 adults and 3-10 yr olds.  

Special thanks to the server and management. The busses came up and took our pizza to be boxed. He thought we said to toss it.  Pizza was gone. They stepped up and made us a whole new one to take home. Even though we only had a half one left.

Overall a great experience

HEAVEN. 4 words: Garlic and clam pizza. effing amazing. Cash only. I would buy the whole freakin pan if I could. The dough is so fluffy and the crust is super buttery and crunchy on the outside and fluffy on the inside-- I want to cry tears of joy just thinking about it.

I had this somewhat distant strong memory of loving this pizza........ I had it again & damn was I right. I think it's all about the right balance this place somehow achieves to perfection. Combo slice is where it's at - some pepperoni, sausage, tons of veggie toppings. Mate loves the clam and garlic as well. Anyway, yep Golden Boy. Thank you.
Bring your appetite... and cash! (Cash only, ATM in back) This place rocks!! Super tasty thick cut slices that will make your mouth water! Be wary of long lines around lunch time!
Best pizza ever. I just wish it was bigger because the line is always insane, but really the best pizza I've had in the city.

The food itself is the star of Golden Boy Pizza.  My partner got the garlic and clam pizza and loved it, and I got one slice of plain cheese and one slice of pepperoni.  With a bit more sauce, this would have been A+ but served as it was, I'd give it a B+.  The place itself has VERY limited seating, all at a countertop, perhaps capable of holding 10 people (at most).  Lines are long and most customers are ordering their food with no expectation of eating inside.  Inside of the establishment itself, there is blaring heavy metal music but no other atmosphere to speak of.  Service was friendly and, sometimes attentive and sometimes oblivious.

Pizza is somewhat like an injured bird.
One middle square of clam garlic & a Stella .... This is:
BELA LUGOSI'S DEAD & FREEBIRD !!
blended into an alchemy of the beyond
perfection of a Golden Boy slice.
 It's akin to a religious sacrament the one dozen times I've sat down at this quonset hut onto a 50s style diner stool....
If it was completely quiet at Golden Boy that would be more than enough, but add the juke box music selections which have been as boppin as the pizza is WONDERFUL!!
And the staff has always been fun to watch !! Let's go now. I think about GB
all the time!

Wow what a great experience.  There was a line but it moved quickly and we were rewarded with some of the best pizza I've had in years.  Great toppings & a magical crust proved to be a excellent combination. Plus they have a great selection of ice cold beer. A top spot to try

Went up to visit from LA and tried this place because of the reviews. I got the combo pizza and my gf got the veggie pizza, this was literally the best pizza me and my gf ever had. It's was so good and the crust was just right. We literally went back the next day lol we first went on a Thursday night and we walked right in, ordered and sat down. Then we went back Friday night and there was a line outside. I understand why, the pizza is great. The people who work there are super nice and friendly, even the people eating in there are nice and friendly. Good vibes all around and it made this dine in experience even better. It is CASH only so make sure you have it, if not they do have a ATM in the back near the restrooms. If we ever drive back up to SF from LA we will definitely stop by this place again. Thanks for everything.

The pizza flavors here are unique and all delicious. Service is okay but the ambience of the place kind of gives a IDGAF vibe. I don't remember the type of beer I had but it was some sort of light beer that tasted surprisingly sweet! I don't know if it's because my taste buds have been so used to dark European beer, but this one was pretty good. Seating is very limited, but it seems like most people do takeaway anyways. Most pizza slices are about $3 each
Simple, awesome flavor, incredible place to eat pizza, great service, i will come back.

Delicious pizza! I came here on a Saturday night with a small child, and the staff was super accommodating in setting up the table with a high chair, closing the door (it was getting a little chilly), and providing a little cup with water. It's not a huge place but it cozy and comfortable enough. We had the thin crust Italian Combo pizza, the crust is not cracker thin, which is just a rip off, but decent thickness. The toppings were all great, but the black olives are super salty. No biggie, i just picked them off. All in all, good pizza in the city. Definitely want to go back and get the deep dish next time.

Chicago style pizza and a waitress I couldn't quite read. That sums up my experience. The food here is delicious. I had a chicago style pizza with mozarella on top. I'd check the pictures, the food is as good as it looks.

Totally BLAND.  I was expecting greatness.  I had heard it compared to Zachary's and I was looking forward to a great deep dish on this side of the Bay.  The atmosphere was dark (nothing special, just dark) and very loud (just from patrons talking) and the pizza (vegetarian) was completely bland.  All I could taste was the crust - which was interesting, but not particularly flavorful and not enough to carry the pie.  I'm giving it two stars since there will always be a redeeming quality to bread and cheese, but otherwise this place is an over-rated bust.

Really, the only bad thing you can say about this place is that it's insanely difficult to get a table.  The thin crust is divine, the deep dish is out of this world, and if you have room, the cheesecake and gelato are a perfect finish!!  Go with an appetite and a lot of people so you can try a lot of things.  Or just get take out once a week and work your way through  the menu!

the pizza will own you.
the beers will compliment.
the drink specials will titillate.
the aromas will seduce.
the service will accommodate with a smile.
the jukebox will let you know you are not as indie as you think.

You're probably reading this review because you just read my review on Zachary's in Berkeley.  Well, here we go . . . strap on your seat belts and hold tight.

LITTLE STAR IS THE SHIZNIT!  

They use this great corn meal crust which is sooo crunchy and delicious.  The pizza variety is wonderful and the service is immaculate.  The venue could be a little bigger and brighter, but I guess that's the ambiance they are going for.  If you want to get a seat, be ready to wait at least one hour on any given night.  Yes, this is how popular they are.  

They have a good wine list and delicious deep dish pizzas.  Try them all!  Keep in mind that one slice is probably equivalent to one pound.  I'm not joking!  They are hefty pizzas and they are very tasty.  

My gripes?  Well, the wait is always long and parking is very difficult.  Let me warn you that they are in a bad neighborhood so be careful on where you park.  If you take a cab there, even better.  If you are in the mood for a great deep dish Chicago style pizza, check out Little Star.  You will then realize why I prefer Little Star over Zachary's.  There is no comparison in my eyes.  

Can I get an "AMEN?!"

We went to this place at 6:30 pm Sunday, based on the reviews here and got immediate seating "because the person before you got a beer and then walked out."  (Note to self: take the hint next time.)

The place was packed.  Contrary to the reviews and the LSP website, the music is nothing special.  There was one Elliott Smith track, but for the most part it was standard top 40 radio: Sting, Radiohead, and R.E.M.   But played at ear-shattering volume.  I've been to quieter rock concerts.

It took close to an hour to get the pizza, at which point we got doggy bags and took the pizza to Cafe Azur because we just couldn't take it any more.  I was partially deaf, my 19 year old brother's ears were ringing, and his girlfriend had a headache for the next two hours.  

Great pizza, but you have to be drunk to find this appealing.  Either that, or you REALLY REALLY want to be cool.

Incidentally, I've tried posting this review on citysearch.com, and it just never shows up.  Makes me doubt citysearch's objectivity, to say the least.  As at least one other person did, I signed up on Yelp specifically to warn people off this place.

Best pizza I've had in years.  The sauce is out of this world! The thin crust is amazing and the deep dish absolute perfection.  I like starting with the Mixed Greens Salad which is nicely balanced.  It's pretty loud and can fill up fast so go early.  Also, they don't deliver which really bums me out when the rain is coming down and I'm wishing I had a nice hot slice of comfort food. But, they are worth the trip. (note: cash ONLY for pick-up!)
Great salads, delish pizza -- my favorite pizza place in SF.  I miss it now that I'm in NY.  Definitely better than Zachary's -- something in the crust and sauce that's just tastier.  Yum.

This little star will always hold a place in my heart.  The original location somehow captures a ghetto underground neighborhood vibe that the new mission location surprisingly can't master.  Go figure.  Who's hipster now, bitches?  The cramped quarters and candlelight make the heart grow fonder.  The tomatoes on that deep dish make me moan like Rachael Ray biting into one of her 30 minute meals.  This little star is an easy five star for me.

i love this place!  happy workers, happy enviroment and lovely food.
good organic coffee and the best chai in town.  everything here is great... there is a good variety to choose from so there is something for just about everyone.

Arizmendi holds a special place in my heart. It was here at Ye Olde Neighborhood Organic Baked Goods Cooperative that I first outed myself as a lover of the oat scone and learned that I was in good company. In truth, oat scones don't sound particularly enticing, but these little puckshaped cakes are crispy on the outside, yet surprisingly moist inside. How you can do that with something made of about 75% oats baffles my mind. So the oat scones are my first choice at Arizmendi.
Second choice is the Scone Of the Day, huge and fluffy with crunchy sugar on the outside and yummy fruit like apples, berries or apricots on the inside.
Third choice is the occasional cheese roll, chocolate thing, bran muffin, corn cherry scone, banana walnut muffin, pecan roll, brioche roll, or any type of cookie. Or whatever else. I'll eat it and like it.
Maybe pick up a challah, pizza, container of olives, some jam or honey, a dip or two...so yeah, I'd do all my shopping here if I could afford it, and if I found carbo loading to actually be helpful for running and not just an excuse to eat stuff that tastes good.
Even though The Beanery is down the street with loads of good coffee to be had, I like the coffee at Arizmendi too, and there's that dude who always thanks me for bringing in my humongazoid commuter mug and gives me  like ten cents off. Then he comments that I need a haircut, which is fine because it prevents me from lingering and blowing all my huge wads of cash.

This is SF, people.  Worker owned?  Check.  Young dudes/dudettes, covered in flour, playing tunes, baking?  Check.  Millions of carbohydratic calories of anti-Atkins cheese rolls, fruit rolls, muffins, fruit cakes, pizzas, baguettes?  For spare change that you find in the netherworld of your purse or pocket?  Check.  I like Howard, who does graphic design and has been a "worker-owner" for a while there.  Their holiday items are awesome and thoughtfuly done also, but they lost the baked peace symbol, hung like a horseshoe from near the ceiling.  I miss that one, seemed like it would've made an excellent logo.  The only problem is when people show up with their Hummer sized strollers and decide to take up all the space available because, well, I guess they feel they're allowed.  One other nice vision I've had there: one of the workers very patiently helping one of the less than fully mentating homeless folks, who was just trying to get some coffee.  This is SF, truly, thoughtfully and deeply.  Those looking for the flaky, the French or the delicate will not find it here; come for dense breads that pile into the stomach, packed with nuts, fruits and chocolate.  This is the food you pack for a hike or survival situations, or for a party with friends, not a wedding.

I am so bummed it I've been in the city for 5+ years and just now tried this bakery.  The skinny baguettes have a perfect crispy crunchy crust.  The foccacia bread pizza was delicious!  And my last purchase was the blueberry scone and that was great too.  The smell the second you walk into the bakery is amazing.  The only bummer is that they don't take credit cards there.  I will definitely be back the next time I'm within a mile radius of this place!! One last thing...if you rode your bike there, they give a 10% discount!

I remember a couple years back when I was working in the Sunset I would jump off the N, scuttle over to Arizmendi and buy a cheese roll or a bialy and jump back on the N and get on with my day. After work, if I was up for it, I would stop over and get a slice of one of their ever changing pizzas for a snack on my way home. The only reason I miss working in the Sunset is that sole reason. Their breads are to die for and,  this might spark some debate, their pizzas rival the Cheeseboard's.

the city bread is the greatest loaf of bread in san francisco, except when ACME makes the meyer lemon rosemary loaf at the Ferry Building.  you'll need to get two though, because they will be eaten that quickly.    also, the pecan rolls, the coffee cake, and the brioche are excellent.   it's always crowded, and you'll get yourself rushed and bustled around, and they may give you a hard time if you got your coffee elsewhere, but it's totally worth it.
Great bread and Pizza. They give a special discount if you ride your bicycle there.

their espresso is cheaper than starbucks, and you can use organic milk! beyond that, you can get a blueberry muffin with a nice crust of sugar on top... and wonderful pizzas, all while knowing it's a co-op! so you are indulging in cheap, good eats, while being responsible.

I frequent Arizmendi quite often on my lunch breaks. They make exceptional thin-crust pizzas (today's was basil, tomatoes and cheese) which change daily. I am a fan of their breadsticks ($0.75 each). They are extremely long, dusted with parmasan and olive oil and have specks of salt crystals all over the top. They are even good a few hours later, just pop them in the oven for a snack. I have tried their chocolate mint vegan cookie ($1.75), which was delicious, their cheese buns, their scones and their olive breads. This bakery is a gem! Just remember, they are open every day of the week except for Mondays.
shortbread so good, it'll make you slap your mama!
Fantastic pizza. Both the deep dish and thin crust were amazing. Love the $2 PBR's. Great atmosphere and friendly staff.

Really amazing pizza! First time having deep dish so I can't compare, but it was phenomenal! A small is a decent size for one person -- had 2 slices left over -- but was a bit pricey ($23). The photos made it look incredibly saucey, but that was because the sauce was on top of the cheese. Take out took 30min, but worth the wait! Would definitely go back!

We ordered to go...part of our 7x7 list, we were close by, and had to come here.  All the ingredients were fresh and the crust of the pizza was buttery x chewy...and damn good.  Not only were the ingredients some of the freshest that I've ever had on a pizza, it was the mozzarella cheese that stole the show.   Order anything on the menu, it's all good!!

i really dig the thin white pie and the pesto chicken (both with and sans chicken)...
and i checked tonight and they don't take credit cards now only their valencia location does.

try their wings. they are spicy, delicious, tasty creations.

little star. i love you.

Other people have said it, but I'll say it too. Thank you Little Star. You removed the need to cross that pesky bridge to go to Zachary's.

If you haven't been here yet, you should make plans soon. The pizza is delicious, better than Zachary's in my opinion...though I understand that is really a religious debate more than anything.

The only downside is the wait (45 mins is common). Oh, and you have to like chicago style pizza. But if you don't, that's fine with me, just means I'll get seated quicker.

Ok....so I'm a little bit of a fanatic when it comes to pizza.  Sure I'll eat Round Table (since that used to be my favorite but I use far too many napkins soaking up the grease floating on the top).....but they are a poor substitute for Little Star Pizza.  The best part you ask?  I do NOT have to soak up any grease.  This pizza is delicious and my mouth is watering just writing about it....literally.  It's a bit pricey and out of the way, but well worth the drive and the money.  Did I mention that I love this place?  Just be aware that there is VERY limited seating at this location and a bit drafty when the door is left open.  I would like to see them add a few more appetizers since their menu is very limited.  I can't wait to savor the flavor of Little Star again.....
I can tell that if you like deep-dish pizza, this is the place for you. I enjoyed the atmosphere, and the staff were very obliging on this unseasonably hot day with multiple pitchers of water.

I love Little Star Pizza! I am so lucky their Divisadero shop is right in my hood. The pizza is always fantastic. My favorite is the deep dish Mediterranean chicken pizza. I also love the thin crust White Pie, and their mixed salad is just right. They have friendly, attentive wait staff, and the service is always good. I go to Little Star at least twice a month. Sometimes I get a table with a friend, sometimes I sit at the bar and have a beer, and sometimes I order a pizza to take home. They do get very busy, so be prepared to wait for a table during peak hours. It is definitely worth the wait! YUM.

I've always preferred deep dish over thin crust pizza but I never knew how good it could get until eating here!

We got a half Little Star and half classic pizza.  I liked the Little Star toppings more but what really made the whole pizza stand out was the cornmeal crust.

We called in for takeout and in total we had to wait about 45 minutes (from calling to picking up the pizza).
Really enjoyed this place.  Nice space.  Very good pizza.  Wings were awesome too.  Very good beer selection.  Good deep dish pizza with an excellent sauce and not too filling.  Wait was lengthy.

Grabbed lunch here about a week ago. I had two slices of pizza, which are square slices if you didn't know. Also, they only take cash and there's a $2.49 charge on the atm in the back. I ordered the combination and clams and garlic. The combination was pretty good l, but the cashier seemed lazy when explaining what was on the toppings. The clams and garlic was quite average. Two slices was definitely filling.

This is a completely sober review. From my understanding, Golden Boy is a prime drunchies spot, but my friend has crowned it her favorite pizza of all time, so we came for a lucid dinner. The store front is next to Chubby Noodle and is quite small.

Golden Boy serves satisfying foccacia bread pizza. It's "baked-to-order," which means they reheat the slices in an oven for a fresh, quick aroma. I got a slice of the garlic and crab ($4) and my friend got her favorite, the combination. The breading is fluffy and soft ("Just like Pizza Hut!" in my friends' words. I'm not going to put myself on record that Pizza Hut is quality pizza, but there is admittedly something about that dough...). The garlic can be a bit overwhelming if you had more than one slice, but I thoroughly enjoyed this affordable dinner. One slice is enough if you are looking for a light meal.

For to go orders, boxes only come free if you order over 3 slices, but they will wrap up the slices in foil and a paper bag. Cash only!
Bad. Sauce, cheese, crust. All bad. Service was fine but save yourself the wait and go to Tony's around the corner instead.
I normally do not use the word "OUTSTANDING" but the pizza was so good.  I had the garlic & clams with a cold beer.  Next time back, will differently return.

Getting a late night slice at Golden Boy Pizza is a San Francisco rite of passage. If you're out in North Beach and need some pizza before you head home, Golden Boy is your place. Tip: head over before bars close, otherwise you'll be standing in a long line for quite some time.
One of the best pizza I've ever had!  Discovered this during a North Beach food tour and will be back for sure.  Everyone in our group LOVED this pizza.

Very impressed with the pizza. Fresh and tasty :) The turnover of pizza sales is so frequent that most slices you get is often just fresh out the oven or just coming out! Outdoes the competition on price too. Definitely going back there again.

This pizza is awesome if you enjoy such food as:

-McDonalds
-Red Baron Frozen Pizzas
-Jack in the Box
-High School Cafeteria Food
-Food Found In The Trash
-Raw Uncooked Dough
-Country Waffles
-Taco Bell Left Out All Night
-Canned Seafood
-Pesto From China
-Brown Cardboard Boxes

Also, if you absolutely hate tomato sauce and despise cheese on your pizza, this is the place for you! CASH ONLY FOLKS! Get there early and prepare to wait in a long line of people with similar culinary tastes of those listed above! You can share cooking tips for your next meal of Hot Pockets!
This place is great and but too much people during weekends. I personally love beef pizza, thick crust square cut pizza with rosemary and other herbs baked into the crust.

This place had awesome pizza and the place welcomed us to San Francisco. We had pizza in our hand and were walking the streets late at night making our first nite here pretty darn cool. The pizza slices are kept near the window and if you wanted an entire box of pizza (because they were boxed shaped) you can choose which ones would go in your box to take home. It catered to people's wants. Downfall is they only accept cash.

I've been hearing great things about Tony's for the longest time, and since my girlfriend and I were at the North Beach fair, we figured it was as good a time as any to try it. There's several locations on the block baring Tony's name, but the one we wanted served up the slices.

After a short wait in line, we ordered a slice of the pepperoni and a cheese to share. I thought the crust was perfect on the pepperoni, but a tad overly burnt on the cheese. The flavor was delicious though and it wasn't too oily. The pizza was hot and fresh because they cycle through so many pizzas daily that nothing ever sits for long. At $5/slice, it's a fairly expensive pie, but I'd definitely come back for another on occasion.

The pizza was served up fast and hot, though the indoor seating is very much limited. There's a few spots outside too, though they were also totally full when we were there. Overall it was an enjoyable experience and I understand why Tony's is frequently called the best pizza in San Francisco.

Food: 7/10

Service: 7/10

Price: $

Atmosphere: 7/10

Well we finally ate at this famous North Beach pizza spot.  We braved the line concept, got there at 11:30, so only a half hour wait.  We were seated in a nice booth by the bar.  The hostess and servers were very friendly, and obviously liked their jobs.  

We decided to go with the classic pizza, the Napoletana, the crust was very good.  The kale salad had a really good dressing, and our side of garlic oil, spinach was so good.  I had a glass of red wine, my husband had a Peroni on tap.  The atmosphere was good, definitely will go back, even though it's not in my hood.

Pizza was amazing! We got the Italian style pizza with fig, prosciutto & balsamic and it was the best pizza I've ever had. The hostess was bitchy, but I couldn't take a star off since the pizza was so good.  She was the dark haired girl with the nose ring through her nostrils.  We got in line 15 minutes prior to opening and there was probably 10-15 parties in front of us. We asked for the circle table by the window that was open...and she said "you will get what is available.  We are a party of 5 and she sat us right next to the table we asked for. Then she gave the party of 5 behind us the table we asked for. Could she be any more rude? Our waiter was great and food was quick. Might just want to reconsider the person that makes the 1st impression...the hostess.

My favorite pizza place to go to when I'm in town! Pizzas are great service is fantastic! Please try the cannoli if you go there they are AMAZING!! Also had a great waiter his name was Alex he did a great job!
Delicious. No other words. Perfect crust, original style. Very friendly staff. Serious inquires only.

BEST pizza in San Fran! We waited in line before they opened, and there was a long line. We were seated quickly once they opened. It was darkly lit with a bustling atmosphere. Get the New Yorker pizza! The cheese was so fresh, and if you're a thin crust lover, this is the pizza for you.

Absolutely recommend, we will definitely be back!! The wait was quite long though over an hour, but the food was worth the wait.

Seafood Linguine // 5
The clams were fresh, homemade linguine was delicious, sauce was good, generous portion.
Flaws: none (:
Recommend:

Kid's Cheese Pizza // 5
So good!!! Very cheesy. Nice and hot.
Flaws: none (:
Recommend:

Note: coming here again absolutely with my kids!! Definitely recommend!

______________________________________________________
                               Disclaimer!!!
1-4:
:( = horrible
:| = ok
:) = good
:D = best of the best!!
Hands down the best pizza in the world. No joke! Get the New Yorker.... it's so amazing you just can't believe how good it Is.... pictures are The New Yorker & The Detroit

Best pizza ever! The salad and meatballs were amazing as well. We went on a Monday night which wasn't too crowded but it was a little bit of a wait. They do ask for your number to text you when your table is ready that way you can walk around. I suggest hopping down from the car checking in then finding parking because it takes forever to find parking in the city. The service was fast and everyone was friendly. The tables were a bit close together but if you don't mind it then that's good for you hopefully you get a nice seat partner. The pizza was really fresh and the salad was perfect. The menu is huge so make sure you come starving.

I love Tony's pizza!! The reason for 4 stars is because there is always a long wait!! I hate waiting when I'm hungry!!

I dined here 2 times, but I bought pizza by the slice next door numerous of times!!

First time we ordered, we ordered 2 pizzas and garlic bread for 2 people! The first pizza had chicken, Roma tomatoes, and greens. A bit to healthy for my, but my husband love it. The 2nd pizza was the original tomato pie with cheese. Simple, but that's the way I like it! Crust was so wonderfully crisp.

The 2nd time we came here, my younger cousin wanted to go to BJ's for some pizza. I told him I know the best pizza place so I brought him here. We asked him what kind of pizza he liked, it sounded like the New Yorker. So we got the largest size! It had pepperoni, 2 types of sausage, tomato sauce, mozzarella, ricotta, basil, garlic, and oregano! He loved it!!!

I will return!!
I don't get what's so great about this place. Average bakery.
I'm not a fan of the provolone olive bread. Stick with the sweet items or the pizza. Some small tables and seating are available inside so you don't have to truck all your goods somewhere else.
great pizzas (squash and garlic, yum!) and baked goods. arizmendi is the bomb.

I LOVE their daily pizzas. You'll love them too if you like thin crust, more non-American pizzas. Their baguettes are awesome too! And I am so addicted to their cinnamon rolls with all their gooey goodness. I forget what they're actually called though. You MUST try if you are in SF.

One of my absolute favorite bakeries in San Francisco.
Their muffins are good, their cookies are okay, it's their breaded items that make this place great.
What makes this place exceptional:
-Their cheese sticks.
-Their daily pizza. Go to their website and check out their daily pizzas, and make sure to stop by on that day. Most of them are fan-freakin-tabulous, others can be a little on the weird side.
-The breads. They have a lot of good bread here. But again, check out their bread schedule as some of their breads they don't make every day.
What could be better about this place:
-Their bread schedule. I don't mind having a pizza schedule as I don't expect them to make 20 different pizza's a day, but I wish that more of their breads were offered on an every day basis, not on a schedule.
-Their seating. Very limited seating. Not bad when it's not busy, but when they are busy don't expect to find a seat. I don't usually come here with the intention of finding a seat as I've come accustomed to not being able to get a seat here.

arizmendi is consistently tasty for their scones and this is my go to place for tasty pizza. i have tasted most of their variations of vegetarian pizza (save for the mushroom pizzas, because i hate mushrooms) and my absolute favorite is the yukon gold potato pizza, because it's such a comfort food. sure, you might think potatos and pizza don't belong together, arizmendi will prove you wrong. it gets pretty crowded during the weekends, and yes it's cash only but everything is so affordable a quick run to an atm close by is never a problem for me. plus, all the workers are always really friendly.
simply delicious. warm pecan roll with coffee. salted carmel frosted chocolate cake.
woah. just had their chocolate cake with salted caramel frosting. get it.

is it really pizza?  it's more of a hollow interpretation of pizza, with all of what i love in a pie flagrantly missing.  people all lined up, standing around like zombies outside eating their oily pizza, made us curious enough to try.  thankfully, it wasn't very good so we will not have to deal with the crowds again.

Hands down, one of my favorites in San Francisco. All their baked goods look delicious. So far I have had the mint chocolate chip cookie, pizza, and currant scone. All were delicious and baked to perfection. Cannot go wrong by going to this place. You are sure to find mouth watering treats :)

I'll start by saying pizza is my favorite food item, it always has and probably always will be! I eat it every chance I can and ive worked in a pizza joint for years and still never got tired of it. Little Star has so far been the best pizza ive ever tried!!! I ordered the hot wings, classic deep dish with pesto on top in addition to the red sauce just for extra flavor and a to go order of a large thin crust half white pie half chicken pesto. Well the wings were ok nothing special but I enjoyed them. As for the deep dish WOW so so good me and my girlfriend over ate and wondered why we got another to go. So I paid my tab after stuffing our faces got my to go pizza and went to the car...well I had no reason to even take another bite but I did! I grabbed a slice of the thin crust white pie and it must have been the best bite of pizza ive ever taken!!! Im blown away by Little Star and i highly recommend you stop by here!
The food here is pretty good I would recommend it and I will return yummy...

This place features great deep dish Chicago style pies....mmmmm. Sink your teeth into these! The decor is hip unlike cheesy (pun intended) pizza joints.  I love the music they play there.  Go late and you'll find yourself waiting in a line.

FEB 2006 Update: Had take-out deep dish from Zachary's on College (ALWAYS too insane to try to eat there), and I think Little Star beats it hands down -- their sauce and crust are way yummier!
JAN 2006: I got take-out deep dish (the "Little Star") and a salad: Still so yummy!
JAN 2005 Review : After driving around for 10 minutes trying to find a parking space, I was thinking this place better be really good - and it was! I hadn't had deep dish in a few years since last braving the crowds at Zachary's in Berkeley and after eating theirs it really made me regret that time lag. The crust was crispy and the tomato sauce was yummy -- perfectly spiced (we had the "Little Star"). We also had the green salad which was perfect. Good, friendly service. The jukebox was fun, too. I've had atke-out from there since then and the quality was just as good, though better to eat deep dish on the spot. m 1/2006 takeout deep dish (the "Little Star"): Still so yum!
Review from 1/2005: After driving around for 10 minutes trying to find a parking space, I was thinking this place better be really good - and it was! I hadn't had deep dish in a few years since last braving the crowds at Zachary's in Berkeley and after eating theirs it really made me regret that time lag. The crust was crispy and the tomato sauce was yummy -- perfectly spiced (we had the "Little Star"). We also had the green salad which was perfect. Good, friendly service. The jukebox was fun, too. I've had atke-out from there since then and the quality was just as good, though better to eat deep dish on the spot.

I  usually prefer NYC style but I loved their pizza! Their salads were also wonderful. I didn't indulge in the garlic bread that my friend ordered but the head of roasted garlic they brought for it looked like a lot of fun. I was not expecting the champagne cocktails to be as addictive as they were. A friend and I ate here two nights in a row before concerts at the Independant and it was just as good the second night as it was the first!

Of the pizza I have had in the city so far, Little Star is easily one of the top in my list. (If only they delivered or were closer to me!) The deep dish is excellent, with a perfect crust, fresh sauce and great topping combinations. The thin crust is really tasty as well. I love the caprese salad as a perfect appetizer for one or two. They have a great selection of wines and beer. The atmosphere is casual, but classy and kind of fun. Service has been alternately really friendly and great, and bordering on rude and neglectful. Other than this, Little Star is an awesome pizza place.

oh man - this place is sooo yummy!
a deep-dish pizza place in san francisco.
i actually think it's better than the oh so famous - zachary's in berkeley.

we ordered the wings - with a dry rub and served with carrots and a yummy blue cheese dressing dip. then for the deep dish pizza - a small with half little star and half sausage combo!

crowded place - worth the wait... but may just order them to-go next time!
yummy! can't wait to have another slice!

The pizza is good but not exceptional, we found the tomato sauce way too overbearing. The service wasn't the greatest either, barely acceptable.

The worst part... no ATM/credit card!!! No mention of it at the front desk or on the outside of the restaurant. That's just ridiculous.

Sorry, this was a one time.
The pizza here is very good, the atmosphere kind of reminds me of restaurants in NY how they have curtains at the door and its very dark inside.

Great deep dish pizza place! been here twice and i'm very satisfied with the food here, great setting, very low key, a little "emo" because it's dark, but I like it! I can't remember what we had, but I think it was called the Little star or something, but all I remember is how incredibly fresh the tomatoes tasted and pack with flavor! The garlic appetizer was tasty as well. yum yum, I want some now!

Vibe: Hip.
The restaurant walls are coated with thousands of stickers and tags. Even the bathroom walls are. Love it.

Food: Bomb diggity. For you thick crust lovers, this is your home.
Super cheesy but not in an overwhelming way, and no taste buds will be screaming "too much sauce!" In other words, the near-perfect combination of everything (I say 'near' because I recently had New York pizza...sorry.)
As for the toppings, I actually like the combo more than the famous clam and garlic piece, so it is all personal preference.

Service: Cash only, so watch out!
Nothing else to complain about though. You'll have a good experience.

Would I come back? I already do, quite often!

Don't be discouraged by the dark setting, narrow entrance, loud music playing in the background, and the occasional long line.

The pizza here is delicious and the service is quick and friendly. The square slices of garlic&clam, roasted veggie, and pesto are my favorites!  

Roughly come up to about $4 a slice and close enough to Washington Square Park where you can sit in the grass on a nice sunny day.

Cash only!

Best pizza in town! The guys behind the counter are super sweet! Only bad thing is that they only accept cash, but if you don't have cash on you, there is an ATM machine in the back. Price is pretty reasonable!
loooooove here, every pizza's nice and fresh and good price! there's always line, which means everybody loves it. don't miss it! clum and garlic is my fav.
Pretty damn good. Friendly service. Not crazy about sitting and eating in the restaurant (bar seating only), but taking the pizza to the park nearby makes for a lovely afternoon. Prices are fair.

Okay, this is just me, but, when I fly in to San Francisco, just after I check in, this is usually my first stop. I love this pizza!! I've tried several different pizzas, all I've had are good. The clam/garlic is unique, and excellent! My favorite is the Combination.
The restaurant is small and often crowded. But then, I don't come here for plush, comfy seating. I come for the pizza. Good selection of beer to accompany.

I've always walked by this pizza joint and never had a chance to try a slice of pizza due to the long line but I finally did and the cheese pizza was real good! Square cut pizza slices and served hot! We also ordered the clam & garlic pizza but we prefer the traditional toppings on our pizza and not seafood. The service was good, a cool spot to have a quick bite. This place is tight in space so be sure to take it to go.

It is the best pizza in the world. Golden Boy Pizza is the reason I love San Francisco. I wish they had a delivery to LA ;-) great pizza for great price. Beers are just $5 so get the darkest one. I ate 3 slices there and bought 6 more slices and took them to LA. I can't wait to back there and have 10 slices

Pizza was delicious! Love the crust and super fast and friendly service. It's a tiny place, all bar stools seating. Definitely look for the hand pointing it's finger down and bam you found the Golden Boy Pizza
Really fantastic pizza. Had Carmel Pizza yesterday and both my son and I liked Golden Boy a little better. Different style pizzas, both great though!

Cheese scone and the pecan roll were yummy.  Have yet to try the other items.   Coffee down the street at Beanery is a bit more flavorful than here.  As well known, this place has a line always - no matter what time of the day.
It's amazing have such a fresh and tasty bakery just down the street. Great muffins, pizza, and bread. And they're worker owned. So everyone seems to care just a little more (and there's no tip jar.)
Yum!!! Vegan mint chocolate chip cookies...

Fantastic food!!! Pizza was superb, baked goods divine.  Ambiance, seating availability and cashier 'tude took it down a notch, but SO GOOD.  A must go to!  And, bring home the scones for the morning after
Came here last week with my girlfriend and ordered a corn cherry scone and some pizza. SO GOOD. Will definitely be coming here often!
J'ai  supprise, pour cette place. C'est vraimont magnifique.

Are you kidding me? It's a bakery with bread and sweet stuff. How could it not be good? But it's not just good, it's f'n great!  I LOVE arizmendi cheese scones. If I meet a man that I enjoy this much, I will do anything for him.  Seriously.  I live 4.5 miles away. I walk 9 miles round trip just to have 5 minutes with the cheese scone. I have yet to meet a man for whom I would do anything close to that.  I have loved the cheese rolls in the past, but not so much recently. They seem to depend on the baker, and my last few visits they were too hard, actually hurt my jaw eating them. And too small. And not enough cheese!
But the Olive-provolone bread? oh YEAH! And the chocolate things? Yep. Yumma yumma. I love bread. I love sugar. I love bread and sugar. And cheese. They have it all.
The pizza does not appeal to me. I like traditional pizza, not fancy topping stuff without tomato sauce. But they occasionally have something called "lunch lady" pizza in the focaccia case that I like. It's mostly bread with some tomato sauce and cheese. My kinda pizza. Mmm mmm.
Ah Arizmendi, I love thee.
I just tried the new one on Valencia last week (on a cheese scone day, of course. I looked it up to make sure). It's a nice space, but the counter person was not nice.  She was not pleasant at all. And while taking my money she started talking with her coworker and reading something. She was about to close register without giving me my change, and when I said something, she gave me the nastiest shit-eating look. WTF?
Well, that's hipster Valencia for you.  The cheese scone was not as good there, either. It was...different. Maybe the baker fell of his/her fixie that day? I dunno. I'd go there if walking by, but I'll continue my 9 mile hike to the inner Sunset when I'm hankering for some good baked goods.
This is a lovely little bakery with fabulous pecan rolls and scones. The coffee is good. But the scones would make any Brit feel at home. I look forward to trying their savory pizzas.

Stopped by during the morning of bay to breakers and was greeted with a line of eccentrically dressed racers.  All the baked goods looked amazing - ended up trying a muffin, corn cherry scone, and shortbread.  The muffin and scone were both a bit dry but tasty enough.  The unassuming shortbread was surprisingly flavorful and rich.  Will have to return for the pizza.
The scones are some of the best I've ever had. Easily worth the bike ride across town. Particularly the cherry scones. Yumm.

The meatball gigante is sooo good! The sauce is incredible. The difference between the sea salt burrata and regular one is just the addition of cheese, which didn't add that much flavor. The waitress told me each meatball was 13oz.

We also got a neapolitana pizza, which the menu says is award winning and capped at 73. It was good but didn't meet my hyped up expectations. Extremely thin.

Wait was 90 minutes and service was slow once seated.

Visited here on a Sunday Evening. Came around 6 and was told an hour and a half wait. Came back at that time and they were nowhere near ready. We ended up sitting outside as the wait would've been double had we waited for an indoors seat. Would definitely recommend the Yelp waiting list feature as you can see how many people are in front of you, we didn't know about this until we saw others using it.

Other than this, the pizza is definitely good! Also so much variety in which pizza you get and how they're cooked, so there is going to be something for everyone!

To this day, Tony's "The New Yorker" is the best individual pizza I've had on the west coast.  Their standard pizzas are solid but if you are visiting and can only order one, I would get the New Yorker.  The sauce is flavorful with a unique sweetness to it and the blend of cheeses (including ricotta, unusual) is delightful.  Crust harmonizes softness and crispiness in the way that every standard-bearing pizzeria aspires to create.  Believe the hype, Tony's is the real deal.
The pizza here is just phenomenal. We had to wait in line for 50 minutes but trust me. It is completely worth the wait.

I finally had the chance to visit Tony's today with 18 (yes) friends to celebrate a milestone in my life.  I have to say this place lived up to the hype and I will explain why.

First, and in my opinion most important.  Tony's lets you sample global and regional pizza styles in one place, at the same time, under the proper conditions (correct ovens, dough, etc.)

Second, to go along with point one you are able to try really good pizza from all over the world.  I do not eat pizza often; however, as a self proclaimed foodie--my palate is no slouch.  Caveat: I consider eating here similar to americans who have only have americanized chinese food, then walking into an authentic chinese restaurant and being perplexed that orange chicken is not on the menu--not realizing that is not really chinese.  The same analogy applies here.  If you are used to eating your local Magherita, Napoletana, etc. it may not have been the real deal thus when you have the real deal your palate is confused.

Now, on to the food! Given the size of my party I was lucky--I got to sample 5 different styles of pizza and 6 pies so I can say and I had a great sample of the menu.

Pizzas I sampled:

First two pizzas::
Margherita - very light and fresh tasting. The wood fired taste was definitely present I liked it a lot but I prefer meat on my pizzas! However this was a high quality pizza.

Third pizza:
New Yorker - This was my second favorite pizza, I loved the sausage and pepperoni; however, what really sets this pizza apart is the ricotta cheese--it adds a dimension to the pizza that I have never tasted before.  If you like NY style pizza this is a must try.

Fourth Pizza:
La Regina - This pizza was amazing!!! I have never tasted anything like this combination before.  Granted, if I had not been with a group I would have never tried this pizza as I am a pepperoni and sausage guy.  However, I must say this pizza just did everything well - a great balance of the bread, cheese, sauce, and toppings with the contrast of cheeses.  Also, if you are in a group the Sicilian pizzas are best because they are a little thicker and will help to fill up the party.  Also, the size of the Sicilians are larger than the other pizzas (except the 22inches which are the largest) so you will get more pizza for your buck.  Next time, I will try the Fratellanza to see how it compares!

Fifth Pizza:
Tartufo - This was my first time trying a truffle pizza and I must say it was good. I was not sure of what the hype was about truffles but now I get it.  This was definitely a rich pizza with a great flavor profile and its texture was light and thin like the Magherita crust.

Sixth Pizza:
New Haven Lou - I never would have ordered this (or any pizza other than the New Yorker on my own!) which is why I am glad I came with a large group.  A friend in the group was vegetarian and I must say as the last 2 slices I had (I had quite a few slices!) this was a very light, healthy and refreshing/ palate cleansing pizza.

My personal favorite: La Regina (1); New Yorker (2); Tarfuto (3); Magherita (4); New Haven Lou (5).  This takes nothing away from any pizza (I am a meat lover).

The most important point for me to highlight about Tony's is that each of these pizzas had a totally different flavor profile so each slice I tried was a totally new and amazing pizza experience.

Finally, none of the pizzas I had were "greasy" as you typically get at a pizza shop--definitely the highest quality pizza I have ever had.

Lastly, the staff was amazing very friendly and helpful in working with our large party!!

I will be returning.

I came to the restaurant the other night with my two friends.

Atmosphere: The wait is usually pretty long, so we met there at 5:30pm on a Monday and it was only about 40 minutes which wasn't terrible. The restaurant itself however was SO hot and stuffy.

Food: We were originally going to just get 2 pastas and a pizza, but my friend said she didn't think that was enough so we also got bread and a giant meatball. it was WAY too much food because the pasta dishes were so much bigger than we were expecting.

Bread: homemade and amazing. comes with a balsmic dip and also a garlic/ agave dip which is delicious. 5/5
Burratta Meatball: humungous! I wasn't a huge fan of the meat, probably because it was veal, pork, and beef, but i'm also not a huge meat lover. If someone who loves meat were to come to Tony's, I would recommend it. For me personally, 3/5.
Margerita pizza: they only serve 73 a day, so you can only get it if you come early. It was amazing. Perfect. Very Italian. LOVE. 5/5
Pasta Genovese: Pesto pasta which I loved. Pesto was not quite as good as it was in cinque terre in Italy, but it was still really good. I don't think the pasta is made in house at Tony's, at least it didn't taste like it. 4/5
Pasta with Pink Sauce: or vodka sauce or something. Rigatoni noodles which are so good, and also the dish itself was delicious. also, 4/5.

Overall: So glad we didn't get wine because I was already way too full. I will definitely be coming back for more pasta.
The New Yorker is the best! Hands down! Also the garlic bread is  one of our favorite pizzas in the city and we have tried almost all of them!

Seriously. Best pizza I've ever had (yes, you read that right AND Forbes magazine agrees with me)! And the meatballs quite literally melts in your mouth. Worth the wait, but remember you can get the order for delivery - EXCEPT the famed Margherita :/

This place was pretty good. Be prepared to wait. We waited an hour to get a table on a Sunday evening around 430pm. The garlic cheese bread was amazing and so were the meatballs. We got the New Yorker pizza. I personally don't like spicy foods and the pepperoni and sausage on it was too spicy. They serve fountain coke products and also offer a 10% military discount for active duty. Over all the food quality was pretty delicious. Service couldn't been better though.

Amazing food, and unbelievably amazing service.
Everything was delicious, definitely recommended

I have to give this place a bad review despite the fact that I enjoyed the food. The service was despicable. On our way out of the restaurant my boyfriend overheard the hostess say "Thank god they're finally leaving!" Are you kidding me??? We had spent maybe 10 minutes talking after we paid the bill. No more than 10 minutes. And we had spent over $125. That's just plain rude.

If you like the pizza, I'd recommend going to the Little Star in the Mission- It doesn't have any of the problems that are so frequently mentioned in the reviews of this one (i.e.- too dark, too loud, crappy service, etc.).
I love their salad and crust... especially the texture. deliciousness baked in an oven. Awesome date place also and great service. could get super busy so call in or reserve early.

I REALLY miss Chicago pizza and this is the closest I've gotten to Giordano's stuffed spinach pizza in the city.  The corn meal crust is different but yummy.  I've actually never eaten in - always call ahead for pick up.  They offer delivery now (through a third party that brings your pizza via bike) but a large pizza ends up being $40 with delivery charge and tip.

I really enjoy Little Star's deep dish, but both Zachary's and Patxi's are better.  That's not to say that it's not delicious, I'd definitely nosh on Little Star's pizza before a lot of things in the world.  Their unique twist on deep dish is the addition of cornmeal to the crust.  It tastes good, but there is something too crispy-crunchy about it for my taste.

Excellent pizza, both thin and thick, and a great selection of beers on tap.  It's a real neighborhood institution - perhaps more with families than with the hipsters that are moving into nopa in a big way.

A bit noisy, and sometimes the wait for a table can be a bit long, but very pleasant.

Back in the day I would hang out with my Divisadero hipster friends and we would gobble deep dish pizza and they would drink PBR and all would be angsty in the world.  My hipster friends have mostly grown up and I'm pretty sure they don't drink PBR any more but the pizza is still fabulous and how kind are the servers for making us a pizza that was half a special a quarter cheese and a quarter something else.

Only been here for take out, but the deep dish never fails to impress. The chicken wings are incredibly original-- blackened and spicy rather than typical saucey BBQ wings. Wings and a small deep dish is the perfect amount for two people, and it's affordable enough to be a great option when it comes to take-out pizza.
....why there have a great vegetarian Pizza like this in the world ?  i eat 2 times a month when the full moon and no moon day , and noe where could take me out of them on that days , thanks

The deep-dish pizza was really, really good (and I'm from Chicago...a deep dish snob). We did a make-your-own version of sausage, fresh mozzarella, and fresh basil that was the perfect combination of flavors. I also tried the Little Star pizza which I liked, but didn't love.

The crust was really well-done, and I thought it was a good cheese to toppings ratio. Service was fine--a little weird--but food was great!

So after putting in another 18 hour day, my BF and I were *not* interested in cooking - so we rang ahead to Little Star (one of the few pizza places that  has actual anchovies  - Yays!) and our thin crust vegetarian with anchovies was ready and waiting for us when by the time we got there - double yays!  We always pick up a handful of napkins because we *know* we'll eat a slice on the way home! Possibly the *best* pizza in SF.   If there is any better, (a) let me know so I can try it out, and (b) if it is 'better' I'm not optimistic that it would be *magnitudes* better.  The staff and clientele are cool, jukebox is quite decent.

Love love the no frills artisan pizza to go. You line up and order at the counter whether eat in or take out.
Simple but great selection. The board behind the counter reads " If you  don't  see it, don't ask for  it " .... witty.
If you see the clam wh garlic then you must ask for that. It's the best in the house I think. Even better if you  eat fresh from the oven. Probably the best slice of pizza you can ask for.
The vegetable slice is good that you can taste the fresh vegetables.. excellent alternative to the  cheesy pepperoni.
Did I mention how the cheesy abundance that makes the pizza exceptional. Then complimented by the crispy yet fluffy crust.
At 10pm on fri after a hard week at work, the fresh from oven clam garlic pizza taste like the beginning of a great weekend.
Have a great weekend

Typically long line. Sicilian style, i found it less delicious than it looked. The flavor just did not come through.  On the positive side, generous portions and one of the more reasonably priced meals you can find in this way overpriced city.

Cheap late night food, pretty overrated for pizza that's just ok. Clam and garlic tastes mostly just like garlic, combo nothing special. Thick dough, not enough tomato sauce on either. Didn't leave a good feeling in my stomach.

The crust was good.  But the sauce and cheese were so lackluster.  I was pretty bummed after waiting in that line.  Love the vibe of the place and I had a good time.  Kid behind the counter was rad but the pizza was a bore.  I tried a piece of cheese and a meat supreme
Four words. Clam and garlic pizza. Just do it. You're welcome. I'm getting hungry just writing this. Also - remember to bring cash.

CASH ONLY! But know it's worth every penny of that hard earned green. The service is quick but they won't make a fuss. Just be ready to ask any questions when it's your turn. The pizza is by far one of the best I've had in a loooooooong time. Hard to find a solid deep dish and I've been searching ever since Chicago. To be entirely honest we had gone to Tony's first, but after their hostess basically shoo'd us away because they were closing in an hour we came here. BEST DECISION EVER.

Don't miss out and get your ass over for a slice!
The clam and garlic pizza is the BEST!!!! Will definitely come back for that. $4.25 one small piece. Two pieces are enough. The only concern for me is the combo and veggie are too oily.
An institution that I never miss when I am in the SF Bay Area once a month. I find any excuse to grab a corner piece of veggie, or combo, or clam. You can not go wrong with any choice here.

I should start this by saying I am a pizza snob. Tried their clam pizza during lunch time. The pizza was not reheated all the way. I've had Sicilian style before but I wasn't impressed with the crust here. I loved the garlic but I kept wondering what the pizza would taste like if it had been heated all the way (it was just warm). The workers here were nice and friendly. The cheese did not taste that great. They are cash only. I feel like this is a great place if you need a quick bite and work in the area.
Thank you for fattening this hobbit up even more with your delicious pizza! Not a lot of room inside the place, but it's great to buy pizza and sit at the nearby park. I shall return with Gandalf :))

I have to say that I prefer the Oakland outlet of this wonderful bakery. I love the coop vibe and the sense of pride everyone involved shows in what they do. Pizza is seasonal and creative and the scones are out of this world. I guess it is just navigating that part of the sunset that pulls a star from this gem.

They bake truly amazing baguette, and I am picky about baguette.  Bread is not the kind of thing many people notice, but I have served Arizmendi baguette at dinner parties and people often ask where the bread comes from.  I also love the corn cherry scones, zampano, x roll and cheese roll for breakfast--all great alternatives to overly-sweet pastries.
THE ENGLISH MUFFINS!  Never has the world tasted such goodness!  Seriously!  Try them out.

Scones, brioches, muffins, breads, even the coffee... all are delish.  One star off for the akwardness of picking out your treat and then moving over to the line to pay.  It's more difficult when you're 1/2 asleep and low on blood sugar.  But worth it.  Closed Mondays!
I vacationed in San Fran Christmas 09, and loved their scones so much I had a different one every day 4 days in a row!  Fresh daily, tender inside, perfect crustiness outside, delicious!

all i can say about this place is WOW!! i went there with five friends, they sat us right away. i told the waiter we were really hungry so they got us our food quickly. the waiter was very polite and helpful. the place was beautiful!! if you are looking for the most pleasant meal of your life, i recommend this place...awesome!! will be back very soon
i want to make babies with the provolone and olive rolls every saturday.....and maybe also on thursdays.

My friend and I was there at around 4 pm on Thursday, April 11, 2013 to buy a whole pizza. We asked them to help us divide the whole pizza into four bags so we can share it with some of our friends who have never tried it before. When the male worker was cutting the pizza, both my friend and I witnessed that he gave two slices from our whole pizza away to another customer and cut the remainder of our pizza into eight slices to give to us. When we brought this issue up to the female cashier, she questioned the male worker if he gave two slices of our whole pizza away. The guy lied and stated he did not. The cashier stated if there's eight pieces in the bags then there's no missing slices. We checked all the slices before eating and found out that four of the slices were half a size of a regular slice. Since they are an employee owned business, I'm not sure if they are trying to cheat people to gain more profit. I have been a supporter of them for many years and now I have to think if they are worth supporting. So be careful of what you buy there.
my only gripe here is that this friendly co-op bakery isn't open on mondays. i guess my mom was right, the universe does not revolve around me. *sigh*
great bakery in the inner sunset...i usually order the chocolate things and the pizza slices...yes...pizza. love em. one prob is its cash only...but thats not star-deduction-worthy, is it?

you know, the first time, i wasn't a huge fan of the cornmeal crust....

the second time, my ex was REALLY constipated (like over a week...how does one survive something like that?)...and she was hoping that little star would do the trick for her....it didn't...maybe something to do with the cheese?  duh!!!!
