now, the third, the fourth, the fifth, the sixth, and in about 30 minutes...the seventh time......yum!  i'll never doubt you again, little star....

Oh, Little Star Pizza.... how I missed my slice of Pi. Since I was a bit spoiled in Chicago and Saint Louis with their deep dish pizza, I feel that I know what it takes in the deep dish realm. I really enjoyed the Brass Monkey pizza we ordered from here.  We gobbled our slices up like that and had tons left over for the week ahead. It was sort of pricey for pizza, but this definitely one of the better places for the dish in SF. The crust is one of the best parts for sure!

I had their thin crust pizza delivered to me. Their delivery service they partner with is horrible. They came about 1.5 hour after I placed delivery and the delivery guy didn't have change on him. The pizza costed about $22 and I had $40 on me with two 20s. The guy told me it was his first delivery of the night so he didn't have change. I'm confused, isn't it a part of their job to have change? I considered under paying him with a $20 but felt morally wrong. I let him keep the almost 100% tip. I hope the pizza is good at least, I think to myself. The pizza is fucking tiny like 6" for a $22 pizza (well, technically $40) and it was horribly underwhelming. Never ordering from here again. Epitome of San Francisco overpriced bullshit.

After a long, hard, workout I'm sitting here day dreaming about slices of Little Star Pizza.  I swear, they are dancing right before my eyes as I write this review.  It's a good thing (I guess) that I don't live in the area, but man, it's only matter of time till I'm back to tame that nasty deep-dish-devil that resides in my belly.  Till then, I'm gonna go head and pretend everything I'm biting into today is pizza.

it just keeps getting better and better.  top notch deep dish.  i've loved this place from day one. a fellow who works here used to use my garage space to store his scooter --  very impressed with what he's done with since then.

one caveat:  bring cash.  they don't accept credit/debit cards (although they added an atm machine).

Their cornmeal crust is amazing.  It is a great date place because it has comfort food with cozy decor and a friendly crowd.  I was raised on Zachary's, but occasionally enjoy cheating with Little Star.

The pizza is orgasmic (deep dish classic), the salad (mixed green) is incredible, and they have sierra on tap!

Don't forget your white belt, Chuck Taylor's, and skinny jeans...this place is too cool for school!

Just to verify I own none of the above, I just live vicariously through the hipsters in this joint.

YUM!

5 big mothas for this one!

Wow -- this pizza is delicious! So many veggie options and they really load up that veggie pizza.  I say this after ordering way too much takeout and I'm going on my third straight LSP meal. I'm still not tired of it!

I really enjoy Little Star. I love the fact that they also have Kermit Lynch's Bandol and Cab Franc on the list. The key to this place is to get there early or do take out. I love their juke. Pizza is excellent. Service can be spotty. Also, it is cash only. FYI there is an ATM on premise.

I *never* would have tried a refried beans pizza. But I was outvoted. And it was SO GOOD.  It was the Sunday night special with onions, tomatoes, avocado, mozzarella and queso fresca.  Who would come up with that??  It's pretty obvious that these people are pizza geniuses.

Clam Garlic Pizza 4/5

Why did it take so long for me to get to this place?!  This style pizza is on a focaccia type crust which is springy and about 1/2 to 3/4 inch tall. At first glance, it didn't seem appealing. However, the bottom and edges have excellent crunch, so you get the best of both worlds. Crunchy edges with soft moist center. The awesome sauce and flavor puts it all together for me.
Excellent pizza the sausage is bomb I would def recommend trying this joint out if your in the area and have a craving for pizza

The husband and I were treating a friend who lives in town to dinner and had wanted tonys pizza origionally but the wait was two hours! So we walked up the street to see if the reviews were true about this place and they so are!!
After a short wait and a long line we got to the counter, seeing my husband using a crutch she told us to grab the seats next to her at the bar and continued to serve us from there and while managing the til managed to keep us happy with some help from the nice man behind the bar. Not only was the service great and the pizza delicious but the dough was so light and crunch! The pesto was not overbearing on the pesto pizza and I even ate the mushrooms, onion, and tomato ontop. That is a big deal for me!
Everything tasted fresh and the food was really cheap. 27$ covered 6 slices, a beer and 4 sodas.
Needless to say it is a definite thumbs up!!

It is a small building so don't expect to be able to sit down and eat, though.

Surprised by dough quality and solid flavor. The guy there was quick and made good suggestions. I would go out of my way to get a slice here compared to most other pizza in sf. I would say best quick pizza in the city.

Amazing pizza! highly recommend it and its delicious to order and just enjoy every bite as you sit outside and listen to the sounds of the city at night.

Great ingredients and even better crust and dough.

FOOD:
1.) Prolly Combo Pizza = I forget specifics, but just remember it was gooooood

SERVICE:
Order and eat at at counter

ATMOSPHERE:
Pretty small, nothing fancy, just counter seating, few tvs playing sports

One of the best pizzaries of San Francisco! HANDS DOWN! The square style makes it very apeasing. The pizza is delicious becasue it is the baked dough is extremely soft therefore melting the pizza in your mouth.

Hint: Do not be picky about your kind of pizza, get what they have is ready so you can eat right away and not have to wait for them to make what you want. If your like me, once you walk inside and smell the aroma, you need a slice ASAP!

This place is like a dive bar/pizza place and couldn't be more awesome. Even the menu on the wall has personality.

My boyfriend and I were doing a mini restaurant crawl through Little Italy and needed a good appetizer. Saw the slices in the window and knew we had found the perfect way to start our eating adventure that evening. I was really tempted by the garlic and clams but since I wanted to leave the door open for some smooches later I chose the sausage instead. The crust is good and bready, and the cheese wasn't greasy at all. In fact, for a slice of pizza it was relatively light, if that's even possible. We bellied up to the bar to enjoy our slices and the vibe was great. Good punk tunes playing in the background, friendly staff and customers. We felt like we'd been there before even though it was our first visit.

If you're looking for a good slice, a cold brew and a cool atmosphere, check this place out. And bring cash.

Best pizza in San Francisco. Hands down. I'd gladly pay more for this pizza but you don't have to, the price is great. Be prepared to stand in line during peak hours. This place is popular and totally worth it. You go Golden Boy, you go.
The clam pizza was delicious! And the server was very friendly. Remember cash only! Would definitely go back.

Their pizza are out of this world, best pizza ever
I have tried margarita, pepperoni and another one I can't remember but it had meat and all sort of vegetables
I Highly recommend this restaurant

The ultimate Pizza experience!
Great customer service, great food... A wonderful experience.

OK, you know by now, it's a big deal.  They have a bunch of different ovens (including a coal fired one that goes up to 1000 degrees!) and specialty pizzas that are designed to be cooked in each oven.

We tried two, and probably the two most famous pizzas here.  The margherita (from the wood fired oven at "only" 900 degrees), and the New Yorker (from the much heartier 1000 degree coal fired oven... which somehow I assume will kill me later and or contribute to global climate change... anyway, that would be fine with me because the margerita was the superior pizza by far.)  So.  All those things you've heard about how pizza is supposed to taste in Italy?  Their margherita pizza has all those things... at least according to my friend who's been to Naples for pizza.  And as a non-Naples-visitor I'll just tell you that it was damn good, with the dollops of mozzarella loaded with flavor and just the right amount of basil.

Oh, right!  The wait here is legendarily long, but they will take your phone number and text you when your table is ready.  Just be sure to respond in five minutes.  We arrived at about 5pm on a holiday Monday and they said the wait would be an hour; it was actually about 30 minutes (be ready for that text!) which we spent at the "other" Tony's - the bar around the corner, which I highly recommend.  The bartender said a more typical wait quote was 2-3 hours.

Everytime we come to San Francisco we have to grab a pizza from Tonys! After going to Italy  I am a Margarita pizza lover through and through and the Margarita pizza from Tony's is the closest thing I've found in the U.S thus far. They also have this spicy olive oil which is fantastic! Although I always get the Margarita, they offer a multitude of different pizzas cooked in several ways (with different ovens/temperatures erc) Highly recommend coming here!!

It was our first time in SanFran! We had the try the Pizza that was top rated in the COUNTRY! We (my hubby n 2 kids) kept hearing about this amazing pizza n figured we'd stop by. Went on a Friday 8pm and saw it was a 2 hour wait. Got on the list n ended up giving up. Ended up eating somewhere else. We then got a text at about 10pm. "Your table is ready" at about 10pm! It's true the wait is likely long.

We returned the following day n were told 1 hour 15 minutes at about 6pm Saturday. We were seating by 620pm! Parties were incomplete and we ended up being seated. I love their seating policy! U snooze u lose! Keep it pushing! On to the next compete party!  

NEW YORKER & MARGARITA
We had to try the two top sellers n of course the SANGRIA.  Two pizza was just enough for 4 people. The food was AMAZING  and I believe that I would have been pleased even if I waited 2 hours for my food.  

MORAL OF THE STORY
Try this place it's HIGHLY recommendable. Ask around n the locals n staff will know/rave about it.  

The 30 bus leaves u right on the corner of the park that's accross the street. (Union St.)  Which was great considering we were near Union Square n the 30 also picks u up there.
Horrible pizza! Low quality ingredients, rude staff and so not worth the hype! The bread was tough and the cheese tasted cheap! Would never go back again, such a waste!
Best pizza I've ever had. It's one of those sacred places that you only tell the privileged. The owner has the accolades to back it up. Wiki him, awesome true life bio.

The Neapolitan pizza meets the hype. It was amazing. Get there early because they only make a certain amount each day. There is a story that the number matches the owners lucky number. There isn't luck in great pizza...it's in the recipe and preparation and it didn't disappoint. Service was top notch also.

The best pizza you can get in San Francisco. The wait is usually really long so plan accordingly. I also ordered Tony's via Postmates a few times but you should plan to wait 1-2 hours to get it delivered. I stick with the classic cheese which is good for 2 people. I've tried the Cesar Salad as well which comes with real anchovies.

Excellent food and service! I literally asked during the meal if marrying the pizza was too far. Our waiter and the whole staff wonderful and accommodating. Definitely would recommend if you're in San Fran. However don't go up the Filbert steps to get there, it might make it seem more fulfilling but it's not. Not at all.
The Little Star Deep Dish is delicious. Packed with onions, spinach, garlic, ricotta, feta, and mushrooms. Makes for amazing leftovers too. They have a good music selection.

Aw man...this place is the sheeit! The wings/garlic bread are pretty much 'must orders' every time we're in there...the wings are more fried chicken-esque than hot-wings style, and they're SO good when they come out of the kitchen. The garlic bread is pretty nutso too - you get to squeeze out the toasted cloves and spread 'em on the bread yourself...very tasty. I've had both deep dish and thin crust there, and you can't really miss with either one. We usually go with the Little Star deep dish, but check the nightly specials - they usually have some really good stuff they throw together with all kindsa good ingredients. It's a great spot for big birthday parties too...we had over 20 heads in there for my bday not too long ago, and with tip it came to just over 20$/person...we had tons of beer/salad/apps along with 4 pizzas - definately good bang for your buck.

Both the deep dish and the thin crust are great. The wine selection is decent and YES...any place that serves $2 PBR's is a winner in my book. My only complaint was that impossibly bland Caprese salad. I know tomatoes aren't always in season which means that unless you can get a decently sweet tomatoe I would suggest not even bothering. The wait staff is friendly and bartender is great. I was one of the first customers here. The bartender and I had a conversation about the neighborhood and I called it NOPA. She said I was full of shit and that the neighborhood name didn't exist. So Ms Bartender...guess what the name of the restaurant down the street is? NOPA sucka. Validation baby...v-a-l-i-d-a-t-i-o-n.
Very good pizza, definitely on par with Zachary's

The veggie pesto pizza is awesome. Cheese pizza also great. Quick service with pizza prepped ahead of time but re-heated perfectly. This pizza reminded me of pizza back on the East coast. Hidden gem. Not a ton of room to eat, so grab it to go.

CASH ONLY! ATM in the back. This place is bet for Togo orders. Only bar stools inside. Friendly employees, clean, very good pizza and slices do squares are generous. They have a good selection of beer on tap.
Awesome pizza! Loved the crust, and the fact that you can see employees making the pizza! I had the classic cheese square and it was really good!
Completely hit the spot for pizza & beer.  Crust was light and crispy for those crust lovers!

Was across the street at the church for a wedding and got super hungry! Of course every girl wants to devour some pizza while wearing a tight formal dress. The garlic clam was amaZeeeeeeing. The slices come in squares. But huge squares. One slice will def get you satisfied. What's cool is that it's kinda like a pizza bar? I guess. The only reason I knocked one star off is that it was a bit dirty.  Good place to try out!
I've lived in NYC for a good portion of my life and this is the best pizza I've ever had.  There.  I said it.  Hope I don't end up in the Jersey swamps for this.

So everyone from NY always rips on California pizza joints.  I'm guilty of it too but to be honest I don't think the pizza in CA is as bad as New Yorkers make it out to be.  Little Star is a good example.  The pizza here was pretty good (even by NY standards)  and they had some really interesting tasty champagne cocktail drinks.  My only complaint is that the stools at the tables were crazy high and not very comfortable and they only took cash.

Damn , over 400 reviews. must be good right? Well it is..........yes you will wait awhile but they have a good beer and wine selection. When you finally get seated and order, things are truly flowing. Attentive staff (rebecca) and when the pizza arrives................worth the wait.

Of course Little Star gets five stars. This place is fast becoming a San Francisco institution. I prefer this location with its long wait and moody lighting because it is where I fell in love with the most perfect pizza on Earth.

My love affair with pizza goes way back.  Shakey's pizza was a staple of our family gatherings growing up in Angeles City (Philippines) and ever since then I've always been on a search for great pizza.  I've also drifted between being a fan of Chicago style pizza vs New York style pizza.  I'm back in my Chicago style pizza phase hence my review of Little Star.  The pizza here is comparable to Zachary's.  I also love the fact that I don't have to drive all the way to Berkeley for a good deep dish pizza.
Get out of your comfort zone and try the clam pizza as I did.... you'll ruin any other pizza as I did for myself... amazing!

I freaking LOVE pizza! This place adds the freaking cherry on top of my pizza obsession!

My Husband and I have been living in the city the last 6 months (we used to come to the city almost every weekend before moving here, hence the move)  and have tried PLENTY of pizza by the slice throughout the city. So when my husband found this place, I was ecstatic! Since then, the only pizza I ever crave is a Golden Boy slice!

On our first visit we ordered a slice of cheese, pepperoni, veggie and the garlic clam. I am always on the lookout for that perfect cheese and pepperoni pizza. I feel like some places over cook the pepperoni, there is too much cheese and not enough sauce etc. This place however, has gotten it down!!! It was the right amount of cheese, the pepperoni isn't over cooked, it's till soft and I love how each of the slice had the right amount of cheese and sauce ratio! (a big deal in my book)

Veggie slice- Your typical veggie pizza. If you are a vegetarian it has a lot of veggies so you can't go wrong.  For me, it had too many olives and mushrooms.

Garlic & Clam- OMG! THIS IS AMAZING!!!! If you love garlic and if you love seafood, this is the slice for you! I cannot express to you how amazing this tasted!  I think that everyone should try this slice regardless of how you feel about seafood (unless you're allergic to seafood).

BOTTOM LINE:  I can eat here every day and be happy!

It is definitely a really good deal. In San Francisco, it is hard to find a slice of pizza less than 5 bucks per slice for that kind of quality. It is crispy with an adequate amount of cheese in addition to it being very well seasoned.

Not my favorite style of pizza but fun to try.
Small eating area with bar stools and a small ledge to eat on. Would not be good for a large party. I ordered a square of each: pepperoni, sausage, and veggie. The sausage pizza was by far the best of my choices.
I prefer the pizza at North Beach Pizza at Grant and Union.
Awesome gourmet little pizza place.  The ingredients were definitely high quality.  Highly recommend this place.  There is nothing else like it.
Ery day ery day I could eat this ery day even on a bench homie we don't really play, ery day ery day ery day sauce on my face don't care what anybody say
The Pizza is great! Margarita was my fav. This place does get packed so plan on waiting in line and for a table (in or outside) for a little while especially around lunch & dinner time frames.
Legitimate slice, lives up to the hype. Had the classic cheese - 4/5. Phenomenal crust and great crunch overall. Insider tip - Get a slice next to the main entrance, almost no wait.
Best pizzas outside Italy but no match to the original. Should have more Bresaola options with pine nuts, olive oil, Parmesan etc.

Out of the Bay delicious; the best pizza I've had.  The NewYorker is the best one on the menu.  The sauce is amazing.  The crust is soft enough to fold over.  Oh, don't forget to order meatballs for your apps.

Most definitely one of the best pizzas in San Francisco California if you have the chance and you got the luxury to just order and pick up and go during to the Scoville. Make sure if you're out of town or check this place out it's definitely worth it this guy is an All-Star he's been on TV hell he's even got a picture with Mario Batali hit this place up it's the bomb diggity ...Enjoy a pie..

The pizza is legendary, and for good reason. Had the Margherita and it didn't disappoint... but it also wasn't *that* much better than some of the less expensive competition . My recommendation is to make a mission of it: try the margherita at Tony's, Il Casaro, and Del Popolo. All three make a mean margherita, but for the price the latter two are a better deal. Tony's is iconic and delicious though -- worth a try

We really love pizzas and have had some really great New York style pizzas before so going in the expectations were really high. But I can tell you, these guys know their pizzas. A lot of fun, the waitress was very patient with us, they did bring us the smaller size pizza that we hadn't ordered but immediately rectified the mistake and got us the large New Yorker - a spectacular treat. Wait times weren't so bad - 30 mins or so, always best to put yourself on the waitlist through Yelp before you start to drive here. We killed time by going upto the Coit Tower and running back down, just to earn those extra pizza calories

High quality pizza and cheese bread
My family is gluten free and this pizza in their opinion was ehhh ok ???
I would recommend this pizza... i has it delivered next time I will dine in pizza is always better when you dine in

We found this place through yelp and decided to try it out. We waited about 10 mins and was seated outside. After being seated our drinks came and we ordered our food and that was the last time we ever saw our waitress. We asked 2 other waitress for refills after waiting for ours to come by but both said okay and never brought one out, so we were left with empty cups. We also had to go inside to request our check, and ended up tipping our buser since he was the only one who made any effort to assist us. In all honesty the food was amazing but the service was terrible.

We need Tony to open a location in my neighborhood - 24th Street in Noe Valley is calling your name!  We drive across town every few months for our pizza fix.  We tried the gigantic meatball for the first time, it was amazing.  We always order at least one margarita pizza and another new kind to expand our repertoire.  The only complaint is that we can't get there as often as we want.  Tony - please join us in Noe!

"I'm from Chicago and pizza in California is wrong in most every way. Zachary's, from what I understand, is an exception, but I'm not down for the roadtrip. Finally Little Star opens a few blocks from my house and the pizza is ridiculously good. so good.

The service? Not good. To the waitresses and bartenders with the attitudes: It's pizza, get over yourself. Yes, it's a popular joint...like about 100 other joints in the city. But when all you do is toss the pizza on my tiny table and never come back...well, you're not tippable.

The place is so loud that you have scream to people just inches from your face. I've been there twice and decided that from now on, we order takeout so we don't pay extra to tip bitchy people for a decent pizza.

OK went here last night, after an hour wait we were finally seated, and starving.  But what?  THEY HAVE NO APPETIZERS LEFT, NO GARLIC BREAD, NO WINGS (which are the only two appetizers that they offer).  After this disappointment, I order the only salad that they have on their menu (which I guess counts as an appetizer, but I ordered it as an entree) and my boyfriend got a pizza.  Asked if they could add chicken to the salad to make it a little more filling and the waiter (who was the best part about the experience) said that normally they are not allowed to do so.  What?  Not allowed to please the customers?  Whatever.
Then my salad comes out (without chicken) about three minutes later.  But no pizza for my boyfriend.  After about ten minutes, of my staring at my salad and not eating it, the waiter realized his mistake and took the salad back.  Finally, the salad and pizza were ready and they brought out our food (this time there was chicken on my salad) but then the kicker, NO RANCH!! Ranch is essential for pizza (so says my bf) and they do not serve it.  Horrible experience and the food was nothing to write home about!

ok, i've revised my little star estimate, since the new location on valencia is worlds-WORLDS better than the earlier experience i had on divis. Got to admit...the pizza is delicious and the service was much, much better. also recommend getting takeout. Worlds quicker.

I guess deep dish pizza isn't my thing, because I wasn't blown away or anything. We also tried the garlic bread, but it was weird. It does come with a whole clove of garlic, but be careful to only use the middle of the clove. If you put the edges of the clove on the bread, it can get a little choke-y. With the garlic bread you also get a big cup of melted butter. The deep dish is super filling though, and was enough for the three of us.

Amazing.

A little pricy, but for about $25 you get a meal for two, plus enough for breakfast the next morning. And it tastes so delicious. Every time I've eaten here it's been amazing culinary experience, Chicago-style taste that just satisfies.

Great pizza, horrifically bad service.

We don't expect to be seated quickly on a Saturday, not a problem. Wait was longer than estimated, again, no big deal.. Then, 15 minutes sitting at our table, no service, water, nothing.

Finally ordered at the bar. The bartender was awesome. He brought our drinks right out, our salad, and received our generous tip for his services.

Wait staff kept wandering by our table empty handed, refusing to make eye contact. We left, still wondering who exactly was supposed to be our server, but thankful for that bartender!

A shame, really, they do have fantastic pizza. We'll be ordering it to go in the future... like all the smart people who accidentally elbowed me in the back on the head on their way to pick up their food.
This place is my obsession! We always get the deep dish with spinach, mushrooms, and sausage. My mouth is watering just writing this review! Soooo yummy! Best pizza in SF hands down!

We were recommended Little Star by a few friends that knew my love for a good pizza. Having never tried it I was excited to taste the deep dish pizza.
The overall space is way too crowded to sit and have an enjoyable dinner without having to hear about your neighbors problems of the day.
After we were cramped into our table the next shocker was opening the menu. I am used to high prices but this was over the TOP!! Really? Its only pizza!! The prices were enough to make me walk.
Finally, after ordering the pizza arrived. On a scale of 1-10 I give it a 5. it was tasty but I felt like I just ate a rock. Straight to my gut and stayed there all night.
Overall I will not be going here again nor will I recommend it to friends.
Little Star is a 2 star in my book!

Went there for lunch in the past, and were not too thrilled by their food.  Went for dinner this time, and we thought it was awesome!  Deep dish vegetarian pizza was great. Ordered large pizza for 3 of us. Waited about 30 mins on a Sat night, but ordered the pizza at arrival so it was ready for us by the time we got a table. You'll love the pizza, try it! The garlic bread, not so much! Lol, they give bread & whole pieces of garlic, so would recommend to skip that.
their deep dish pizza is amazing, good beer also

Been coming here since 2014 LOVE this place the only con is that you have to wait in a looong line this place crowds up and the inside is kinda gross ask for to go but other than that it's bomb! I moved to the east bay and still come here when i get the cravings.
Don't understand the hype... it is nice to find a place open late. But pizza is just ok.
The clam and garlic pizza is a religious experience. Nice people. Very affordable. Best pizza in North Beach. Hours vary but always open until at least 11pm.
Amazing.   Even if you think you want thin crust NY pizza, don't pass on this once in a lifetime taste.  Amazing.

The people I babysit for just brought this home tonight, and I think I'm in love. I probably could've been paid in pizza and been totally okay with it. Yes, yes, yes. The vegetable one isn't really my favorite, but the bread will blow your mind. It's so...wow...

What can you say?
It's just straight up excellent!
Best pizza in North Beach!
Please keep it local!

Dude this pizza is the best I've ever had.  But I like medium crust pizza. Not pan, not thin, but a decent thickness.  Awesome dough!  We had the pepperoni.  They put the pizza in an oven after ordering to crisp the bottom and "reheat" it.  It's sounds lame but trust me, it's served tasty and it comes out fresh!  I've never had such an awesome underneath bottom crisp like this before.  $3.95 a square (slice) and good cold $5 pint drafts.  Go there!
It ain't Tony's. But totally depends on the style of pizza you enjoy. On Tuesdays, when Tony's is closed, you can hit up Golden Boy. :)

My wife and our friends did our own " pizza tour" of North Beach trying different places and styles. Golden Boy is absolutely one of the best. We went there twice within an hour.... Pesto Clam-Combination-Sausage-Pepperoni..... so simple yet so unbelievably good. I love the square-I cannot wait until our next " slice-fest tour"
@feedyourfacewithmarkandjason.... ck out our review and follow us.
Great slice of pie. I wish I had room in my belly for more pie!!! Great food & service for a reasonable price.

Good deep dish pizza, the thin crust is just alright. If you can't decide, definitely go for the deep dish. The atmosphere of cute lil' restaurant was nice. Very comfy feeling. A little on the pricey side though.

The pizza is great, but the place is dark and cramped. It's very loud with all the people crammed in and music playing.  The waiters are less then enthusiastic and look more like someone you would see at a hip hop or punk club.  I don't think I would dine in again.
I have the garlic clam pizza and it was good . I ate it 2 hours later and it was still good . Good choice and good food

Yes, go. It's great. No New Yorkers, it won't remind you of anything at home. Yes go with an open mind and accept that there can be delicious pizza even in SF. It's a thick-appearing crust that somehow goes down deliciously light. My only mistake was getting 1 piece. Get 2 and make one of them the garlic + clam. Sit at the bar, get a beer, and soak in the music and dirty nostalgic wallpaper of bumper stickers, sharpie messages, and posters.
Best pizza in the World. It melts in your mouth and i think the owner of this place put some kind of drugs in it...... it's addictive!

Focaccia bread pizza, great idea.

It's your standard slice of pizza place, except that it's on focaccia bread, and that's a big enough difference that it's worth checking this place out.  It's got a punk rock vibe, tons of stickers of bands and stuff all over the walls, but it's not very big, so you're most likely not eating inside.

The pizza is tasty, not cheap, but about what you'd expect.  Probably not my favorite slice in the city, but it's a good change of pace from your standard options.
Don't take the 3 stars in a bad way. it really was "A-OK", in fact, it was quite tasty. Nevertheless, it was just pizza. Good place to go for a pizza and some beer, but bring cash.

Not a huge fan of corn, nor am I big on thick crust pizza, but Lil * does something that works well and I love their pizzas! It can be hard to get a table right away, they only accept cash, and I think they are closed on Mondays if Im not mistaken. Those are the things to watch out for, other than that its GREAT!

I order the Deep Dish Brass Monkey- (Not on the menu for some reason) AMAZING. Almost like lasagna. The chicken wings are BOMB!I wish I could figure out the spices -the recipe for it. I would make them at home. Instead I spend all my money at Little star, but that's okay.

I had a slice of the deep-dish Mediterranean Chicken pizza. What's in a Mediterranean Chicken you say? Chicken breast, artichoke hearts, red bells, green olives, onions, & feta. Crust was crunchy and thick, I'm not sure if I prefer it that thick. You can definitely taste & see the garlic, there was a lot of it, which I liked.

it's not chicago.
it's not zachary's.
though it's not that bad. i would definitely come back for some if i was in the hood & mood for deep dish pizza.
once again, it's neither of the first 2 though it'll do for san francisco.

Great experience. My cousin took me here around 3PM on a Sunday. We were looking for a snack and cheap beers. Somehow this place runs with 2 people and  a line out the door.
Pizza was good but not the best. Beer was good cold and priced right. For what we were looking for, everything worked out swimmingly.
Square'ish' pizza just got served...here. Better than school square pizza times infinity with a cherry on top.
Best slice on the west coast.  The clam and garlic pizza is incredible.  Worth the 20 minutes in line and the trip to the ATM (though it's 2016, cash only???).

Love Love Love this place. The clam and garlic is a must! So good line out the door, but worth the wait! Been going here for years and the service and quality of food is always top notch! Must visit if in San Francisco.

Great pizza, limited variety, but fast and ready.
The only time they did not have a line up was when it was closed! But the service was fast and friendly. And the line up assured us that the food was fresh!
Excellent pizza, period. Long waits at times but worth it.

Screw calories! If you are on a diet, don't even bother coming here. I came here with 3 friends and split the Little Star (spinach, garlic, onions, feta, and love). Generally I am a thin crust lover, but the deep dish style here has converted me. The food is super flavorful and filling (the small size fed 4 of us). They also have a few beers on tap to wash down your pizza. So, so good. Because everyone else is privy to the deliciousness of the pizza here, there will most likely be a wait. At 6 on a Saturday we endured a 30 minute wait, but totally worth every minute.

Well i dont think they need another 5-star review, but i just cant help myself from writing. I had their classic deep dish pizza and it was fantastic. I didnt expect the crust to be so crunchy and not as heavy as other pizza place. Service was great, the waitresses and the bartender were very nice and accommodating. The cocktails were alright, not as special tho

Very overrated, in my opinion. Decent, but not great. I prefer Giorgio's in Crocker galleria to this place.

The crust is much thicker than most pizzas, which is my biggest issue.

BEST Pizza Ever! I love pizza, so for me to say it's the best I'm not playing! The New Yorker was awesome... the sausage was fresh , the tomato sauce was flavorful, crust crispy to a perfection, and just the right amount of cheese.  5

I was very please with the pepperoni New York style pizza. We also had the margarita pizza and weren't  impressed. The calamari was good and we would get it again. I was happy with how accommodating they are for children as well as the online waitlist. Our seating was within ten minutes of our quoted time on a busy Saturday lunch.

The food here is really good. The sausage is really good and the size of the sausage and peppers exceeded my expectations. The stout pizza was really good although I'm not sure it's one I would always want to get.

I highly recommend this restaurant.

Waited for 2 hours.   Finally made it to position 1 in wait list.  Then some else showed up and "checked in" after we were on site for 1.5 hrs.  Then got moved back and was told that is the way it is.  Super frustrating.
Post Dinner update-food was really good.  Had the New York pizza and the Neapolitan.  Both were very good.  I would come back for the food.
The waitlist thing seems to be a glitch and I would use it more as a guideline for how long you have to wait.  Got on waitlist at 6ish it said 50-60 mins. Arrived at 630, app said we would have table at 650. Got seated almost at 8.

It was overall pretty good. The pizzas were a nice 16" cut into 6 slices, though a little on the pricey side at $26 for cheese. The sauce (even if it was a little too much on the pie) and cheese were excellent, the dough even better. The service was great. We were quoted a 45 minute wait time, but through Yelp Waitlist, we were seated within 10 minutes! We will most likely come back here on our next trip to the Bay Area.

We'd been itching to get here for awhile, but an aversion to standing in line combined with the limited quantities of the margherita pizza always made us shy away. Last weekend though, we were in the area just as they opened so we made it into the line and got a seat at the bar (because the rest of the tables filled up. literally. Within 10 minutes of them opening. I'm not kidding when I say this place can be nuts).

We ordered two cocktails and a side of deep fried green beans to start with. There was actually a *lot* of green beans, we couldn't finish them all (at least without leaving room for pizza which, let's face it, is the only reason to go here).

Our pizza came out pretty quick and it looked amazeballs. Like, awesome liquidy sauce, dripping cheese, chunks of basil. I couldn't wait to grab it.

This isn't really "slice" pizza, expect to eat it with a fork, but who cares when it comes to pizza this good. We made quick work of the entire pie without feeling like we'd overeaten.

The cheese could be a *slightly* bit better if they went with a buffalo mozzarella instead of just regular. Don't get me wrong, the cheese is great and amazing quality, but there was just a small bit of *oomph* that I felt was missing, that made other pizzas I've had just a bit more memorable than this one.

That being said, if you find yourself in the area and either it's early enough or the line isn't there, check this place out. Fair warning though, if there's no line, chances are they're sold out of their limited quantity pizzas, which is one of the main reasons to go here.

My bf and I tried this place after we Uber pooled with this couple from New Jersey that said that this place is better than any place in Jersey or NY, so we had to try it. We were both leaving Beretta and they were not impressed with Beretta's pizza at all, so we had to try Tony's since we like Beretta a lot. She especially recommended the coccoli, which is basically fried dough with cheese and meat. It's very good, but we preferred the meatballs and pizza.The meatball gigante is amazing. We ordered the one with the egg and calabrese. It comes with a delicious spicy arrabbiata-like sauce that we also dipped the coccoli in.

Since then, my friends and I have been trying different pizzas each time to see which we like the best. They've all been good, but some are way better than others. The menu is so huge and they all sound good, so we will get through it all eventually, lol. The longstanding favorite is the prosciutto e pomodorini with arugula, cherry tomatoes, mozzarella, prosciutto, and amazing parmigiano. The crust on this one is perfect too.

Their pride and joy seems to be the margherita, and while it was good, it was kind of hard to eat because it was so flimsy and it was good, but nothing to write home about. My cousin, bf, and I were just meh about it, even though we wanted to love it.

The sausage and stout pizza was a little too sweet for a pizza and we didn't love all of the flavors together, but this one has the best crust of all of them we've tried thus far. It has a delicious flavor with a hint of stout. I wish we could order this crust with other toppings.

As much as we wanted to love the tartufo, ours came undercooked and a little soggy, and the flavors were just okay. The wild mushrooms kind of overpowered the flavors of the truffle, prosciutto, etc. We took it home and cooked it more and while that made it better, the crust still wasn't a favorite by far.

The Barcelona sounded amazing, but was just okay. Maybe we just don't love breakfast pizza (although in theory it sounds amazing)? It had manchego cheese, jamon, egg, etc.

The New Yorker is our second favorite, although you should only order this one alone if you go, or order it and eat it last since it's so rich that it will overpower anything you eat after it, or fill you up too much. We were served this one before a less in your face one and that messed up our palates for sure (I couldnt say that less douche-y without getting my point across, but it's true) It's very saucy, with mozzarella, dollops of ricotta, sausage, and pepperoni, etc. The crust was so good since it was coal fired too. It's a huge pizza and is so rich, but highly recommended.

Please go to this place! I would recommend the prosciutto e pomodorini to start with if it's your first time. Okay, my essay is done. Thanks for bearing with me.

It's really good pizza.

Got the margarita nepoletana and the coal fire New Yorker. Both were great, wasn't a fan of the ricotta on the New Yorker but I definitely dug everything else about it. Wait was about 1 hour on a Sunday during a warriors game

With over 2,000 reviews, I got nothing new to add.

I came here on Thursday, around 1:30PM, after my walking tour around the Coit Tower. The place isn't packed, I got the Margarita (only 70 of them are made a day). It is thin sliced and a tastes great. They also have craft beer which is a bonus for me.

Overall, a bit pricey, but worth a visit.

What we got: Detroit style pizza

Wow! The Detroit was AMAZING. Big enough for 2 people and flavorful with every bite! Definitely the best pizza I have had in a while. The hype is real!

The wait can be pretty long though. We waited about an hour and 45 minutes. It's located next to a lot of dessert/coffee shops so we were able to kill some time that way.
Tybg. Blessed to have such deliciousness. Thank you for the love. Clam pizza. Extreme pizza. Great pizza. You have saved us with your lovely

This place is legit. Best pizza I've had in SF. The slices are loaded with super fresh toppings. The customer service is great and there are tons of beer on tap. Golden Boy will definitely be the go to pizza joint when we're in the area.

I wouldn't say they are the best pizza spot in San Francisco or the best square Ive had in my life but the food is always fresh due to the high customer turnover.
I'm a little disappointed but the small little oven they have in the front to re-heat the pizza as well as the lack of options but overall, I do recommend them for a good square slice and I have been back often.

The combo slice is definitely the best slice.
Mmmmmm...the pan pizza was to die for. It was filled with fresh ingredients and the pizza itself had lots of flavor. We will definitely be back to this place for there other pizza selection.

THE pizza place in San Francisco. Hands down! Thick, cheesy, hot, delicious, cheap slices. Draft beer at the bar, TV's playing the game, and a great staff that makes me feel great everyday.

Love you guys and I enjoy supporting such a great place!
-Naem from Wells Fargo

It's Pizza after all, so I'll keep this simple:  Best Deep-Dish in the city.  Cool atmosphere with Beer & Wine.  I usually get the Veggie Deep-Dish and add Pepperoni.  I know, I know...but Pepperoni on my pizza is like Catcher In The Rye for assassins...I just have to do it and I don't know why.  The pizza is amazing and I would go here more often if they a) had a better parking situation...it's on Divisadero b) took plastic....nothing sucks more than making an extra stop or c) HAD DELIVERY.  Pizzas are not cheap here (in the grand scheme of Pizza) but they are filling.  I can hold my own when hungry and can barely make it through 2 1/2 slices here without feeling sick.

Ok, obviously the pizza rocks, you know that by now, but in this world of cash only institutions did you know Little Star has an ATM that only charges $.25!  I was at the Independent the other night and their machine rakes $3!  Blasphemy.  I shouldn't be so happy to get charged anything to pay someone but there you have it- 3 months and this city has warped and twisted my idea of happiness...oh- one other tidbit- deep dish takes 20 minutes to cook, thin crust only 15 for those getting hungry around 4:20pm or thereabouts...

Not a 5 - can't compare to Zachary's. But, who wants to trek across the bay when you can stay home. No delivery :( Which means I have to walk there and wait for a LONG time. But - wow, havent found any pizza in the city as good as this. Really worth it. Heard great things about the new location. Only go for deep dish, otherwise there is no point in waiting.

Has the boys over at Zachary's met their match?  Can this be a new SF vs. East Bay rivalry?  I'm more the traditional NY-style (thin crust; minimal if any toppings) kinda guy.  But to keep me on top of my game, I venture into the deep(-dish) area and try the hearty stuff.  This particular trip to LSP was my first.  Went with a bunch of work colleagues for one's b-day feast.  So with a pack of 14, it was imperative that we get there early. 6pm to be exact.  The hostess quickly accomodated us although we had to squeeze a bit and the waitstaff was attentive to our big group the entire night (cute too!).  Being the big (that is, appetite-wise) pizza eater that I am, I was a bit curious about the sizing of the pizzas... a "large" was ONLY 12 inches wide.  So we ordered a combination of some thin crusts and deep dishes.  On the thin side, the vegetarian and chicken pesto.  On the DD side, the Little Star, Mediterrenean and Classic.  I claimed that I could consume a whole large pie by myself, and so was carefully watched the entire night by some colleagues who doubted my claim.  The pizzas themselves were incredible.  I'm never one to really eat veggie pies... but this one was so deelish.  That cornmeal crust is awesome, but quite filling.  So after eating my first slice, I knew that my "whole pizza" claim was going to be tested...

Then I went to the dark side... each slice of the different DD pies was so good, it reminded of my younger, "better metabolism" days in college when I was a lot of active and thus could inhale slices and slices of pie.  This night was not the case... after the 4th slice, I was reaching an immediate slow down point.  But the Pesto Chicken thin crusd was calling...

Not to be missed... the Chicken Pesto offers a real clean taste... not-too-overly-done on the pesto, and the chicken wasn't dried out. This was a great slice of pie.

I finished the night having consumed 6 slices (4 DD's, 2 thin) and a pint of pilsner.  Although I was able to walk it off throughout the course of the night.. I knew that I would make my return to LSP many more times in the future, and probably go through the same ritual!!!!
Hits the spot for your late night craving if you are in North Beach. Good crust and toppings. Each bite is full of flavor.

Been coming here for over 15 years and can't believe it's taken me this long to write a review. I take all my out of town guests here as there are few places in North Beach with amazing, affordable bites. I always recommend the red sauced slices--cheese, pepperoni, sausage, etc. Though it's worth splitting between 3-4 people the clam garlic b/c everyone should have that experience. This place is an SF classic! Still has the old SF vibes which has now become rare with gentrification.
Amazing pizza , delicious , good price, always busy, open until 2 am on weekends, must go , cold beer

Pizza. Oh Pizza. Let's face it. We all know Pizza.

And if you know Pizza you know why Golden Boy is so tasty. So perfect.

It's the reheat for sure. It's the choices of topping. It's the dough. It's the sauce.

There is no better honest Pizza Slice in The City. There are fancier ones and they are good in a different way. This is real Pizza at it's very finest.

I would put any single slice of Golden Boy up against any slice in NYC, Chicago and the real Pizza capital of the US....Detroit.

I love you Golden Boy.
I'm ADDICTED to the pesto!  Little garlic shake takes it to the next level (sm. glass shaker at bar). Remember to bring cash.

Great. The line on a Friday night was 1:45 so we went out for a drink and then went in and sat at the bar and ended up ordering from there. Bartender was awesome and the bar seemed just as good as a table to me. Pizza was fantastic and I've eaten plenty a deep dish in the Windy City.

I don't really like pizza in general.  It has to be really good for me to waste the calories, you see.  Little Star gets 5 stars because I love their pizza-not like, LOVE.  I'm glad they don't deliver.

Terrific pizza.  The thick crust is better than Zachary's...it's the sauce people, cleaner, less muddy than Z's.  For me, the thin crust is where it 's at.  Plain cheese thin, but I'm from that great City to the East and that's how we do it.   Worth the wait, decent wine by the glass, dimly lit for that Blanche duBois effect...

tried to go to the location in the mission district, but for whatever reason it was closed that night (night before the super bowl).  so we wound up at this location.

very good pizzas.  we had the classic and the little star with pepperoni added.  i liked the little star with pepperoni the most as the rest of our party did.

i felt their pizza was fairly comparable to zachary's .  though both places have some differences, i can't say a like one place over the other.

one of the differences, which i kinda liked, is little star seems to use some cornmeal in their crust.

I'm partial to more tomato based sauce on my pizza vs extra cheese and Little Star's signature pizza deep dish delivered (figuratively).  Although it's veggie it sure tasted meat-like what with the shrooms and spinach and such.  The crust was great, they were practically bread sticks in and of themselves.  Me and two of my boys went on a Sunday night and the line was out the dough (damn, I'm good).  If it weren't for the company, people watching, and blue pedal pilsners, I might have quietly smoldered because of the 50 some odd minute wait to be seated (we were quoted 20).  I'll also have to remember to pass on the $9 microwave caliber chicken wings in lieu  of additional meat toppings on my pie.
Amazing deep dish pizza. It's gotta be the crust. Yes, the crust. The buttery, flaky, crust goodness. It is definitely one of my top 5 pizza places of all time.

Ordered spaghetti and meatballs on Sunday night ~6.30pm through Postmates for pickup and my spaghetti didn't have any meatballs!! How can you forget the most key ingredient in a dish with it in the name?!??  Did not realize until I got home and no one answered the phones when I tried to call.    Disappointed in the quality and not sure if I'll be revisiting this local joint.
This is my favorite pizza place from now on. New Yorker and the Detroit Pizza are the best yummm

We loved this place! We had lunch here - and the gluten free pizza was one of the best we'd ever had. It's hard to find a fantastic gluten free pizza, but their sauce and cheese just made it! The caesar salad was one of the best I'd ever had. Caesar salads are all about the dressing, and theirs was perfect. The salad even came with 3 little whole anchovies on the top. The classic house salad was also lovely (yes lovely, that's truly the word that describes it) - the greens were perfectly dressed with a balsamic/oil dressing....with some yummy cheese and walnuts.

Service was spot-on. The gal was friendly and welcoming. It was all just so great! We left feeling content and happy. Isn't that what a good dining experience is supposed to do to you?

Yes the pizza is amazing(and expensive). Be prepared to wait . This would be a five star review except for the fact they do not control their outside eating area. Nothing ruins the " fine dining pizza experience" like the waft of shit or watching someone dog thru the trash while you eat. I understand this is not tonys problem but I think if you charge $40 for a pie you should clean up your outside seating area . If you're not willing to patrol the area maybe only offer inside seating.

I'm apprehensive to be leaving such a terrible review, but this was hands-down the worst customer service I've ever experienced, and I wouldn't want anyone else to have to deal with what I just dealt with.

I placed an order for takeout - nothing extraordinary - just a few pizzas, pastas and salads. Our CEO is in town from Chicago and went out of his way to have Tony's, as he had heard nothing but amazing things. Long story short, after 3 hours, half a dozen phone calls, and being hung up on by the customer service rep on Tony's end, they finally tell me that they gave my order to the wrong driver, and would refuse to remake mine.

I am honestly in shock after placing a $120+ order to have been treated so poorly. Giving this one star is a huge overstatement.
Best pizza in San Francisco. New Yorker was great. Young Italian couple with beautiful accents next to us highly recommended the margherita. He said 'oh we're Italian, trust me it's good.'

Had lunch here on a Sunday. Same day the San Francisco marathon was running, so the city & more particularly North Beach was very busy. We waited about 30-35 mins for our party to be seated. The wait wasn't too bad. Anything worth eating in the city had a little bit of a wait & we really wanted to try the famous margherita pizza. The hostess assured us they weren't running out anytime soon because the first lunch seating had just started... We just needed our table to be ready and we were golden.

We started off with a calamari appetizer and went with half traditional style batter and the other half with some seasoning/spice or what they call calabrese style. Both were very tasty especially with a squeeze of lemon. The portion was enough for us 3 hungry folks.Good stuff.

We, of course, ordered their famous margherita pizza.  It was good. The crust was pretty damn good. The basil & mozzarella flavors really shined through. I would order it again, for sure. These people are the pizza experts. On the menu, they list the temperature and type of oven each pizza is baked. Name it, they make it. Amazing...

We also had the deep fried Manhattan calzone. It was filled with meatballs, mozzarella & ricotta cheeses and garlic. It was sooo good. Never had anything like that before. It was crunchy, cheesy... flavorful. I suggest you order the calzone deep fried. Delish.

For dessert we went with the pistachio panna cotta. It was very good. Panna cotta is usually a winner. But this pistachio version Tony's serves is real good. I recommend it.

Service was good. Our server was attentive but not smothering. I have no complaints.

NY in SF, I like it! Feels like this place I liove in Sodo, love the casual, feel. Pizza took some time which is good! I loved it, stayed simple with a coke and margarita Za. It was a perfect experience  on a Wednesday for lunch.
We had the margarita pizza...it was amazing; the crust was excellent...well the entire thing was. Great area to people watch.

My fiance and I joined her siblings for dinner at Tony's a couple weeks ago. Her brother lives down the road from the restaurant and eats there often. To save us from having to wait for hours, he went by the restaurant a couple hours before we were supposed to arrive and put our names on the list. I would highly recommend doing this as they send you a text when your table is ready.

We shared several different appetizers and one pizza. Some of the dishes were amazing and some were only so-so.

Little Italy Salad - This was the best dish that we ordered! While that statement my sound like an insult to the rest of the food, it really isn't. This salad was just really that good. The melange of flavors and textures was superb. The slight bitterness of the salad greens was balanced by the sweetness of the crunchy walnuts, the saltiness of the chopped olives, and the earthiness of the gorgonzola cheese. I would highly recommend starting your meal with this salad.

Coccoli (sea-salted fried dough) with prosciutto and burrata - If you love the fried dough you get at carnivals, you must try this dish. Each bite of the pillow-soft, savory fried dough with a little bit of creamy burrata spread on top of it and a slice of salty prosciutto on top was packed with flavor. My fiance wasn't crazy about this dish, but the rest of us enjoyed it.

Deep Fried Green Beans - If you are looking for a good vegetable side dish to go with your pizza, this is a good option. They were slightly crunchy and not too oily.

Garlic Bread with Cheese - Much to my dismay, the cheesy bread was topped with entire cloves of roasted garlic. I like a little bit of garlic, but an entire clove is too much for my taste.

Gluten Free Breadsticks - This was the only appetizer out of the five we tried that I would not recommend (even if you are gluten free). The breadsticks were basically flat, soft crackers without any flavor.

Coal-Fired New Yorker pizza - My fiance's brother orders this pizza every time he goes to Tony's. The crust is incredible. It is thin, crisp, and has the nice bits of char from the coal-fired oven. The toppings of the pizza looked incredible on the menu, but were kind of disappointing in reality. The tomato sauce was sweeter than I would have liked it to be. The sweetness of the sauce was then exacerbated by the slight sweetness of the dollops of creamy ricotta cheese. The sweetness of these two ingredients completely overpowered the other toppings. While I would definitely recommend ordering a coal-fired pizza, I would avoid the New Yorker unless you like sweet pizzas.

I think that the quantity limits on certain pizzas and drinks ("limit of 23 per day!") is a little gimmicky, and that listing the awards that certain pizzas have won is extremely tacky (i.e. "Gold medal winner Las Vegas 2013"; Really?). Nevertheless, the food is decent and the service is great. If you are in the city and want some tasty Italian food, you should check out Tony's.

Crisp on the outside, fluffy on the inside - try the garlic/clam. The slices are light but filling. Service is great - friendly and quick. Only bar seating so don't come in looking for a long, comfortable meal.

If you want a square of pizza, you can't do better.  I've been dropping in here since the 80's.  A slice and a budweiser is an amazing combination (unfortunately, I can't drink at the moment).
Atmosphere at the sit-down counter is great.  Top service.
Favorite is the pesto vegetarian.

This place was recommended by a good friend as a Local's favorite. We stopped by and found it to be completely true. The pizza was fantastic with plenty of cheese and toppings. The crust is thick and fluffy and definitely filling and the flavor was fantastic. The only bad mark is that one of the slices we got was a little burnt after being reheated, otherwise a great experience!

This is possibly the best "by the slice" pizza in town and my new North Beach addiction.

20 years ago when I worked downtown there was a pizza place on Kearny, it was a walk up window really, that made big square pizzas in a big pan and sliced it in square pieces. I can't remember the name of the place and it's long gone but they had awesome pizza.

I don't know what it is about square pizza that's so good but but this place usually has a line out the door.

Golden Boy pizza is honestly worth traveling to North Beach for, and I haven't tried their famous clam and garlic yet.

Try to get a corner piece, or at least an edge.

Ah yes, yet another positive review of Little Star. When my friend told me about this place, I was like, "Corn meal does not belong in my pizza crust," but it turned out better than expected. Being that I'm from New York, and therefore a pizza snob, I can only say that the pizza was good, but didn't exactly meet my ideal. It wasn't bad, just different. Also, because I'm from New York, I have a very particular notion of what makes for a good chicken wing - and that is deep fried wings slathered in a sauce of butter and Frank's Red Hot. The Little Star wings were tasty, but not what I look for in a wing. We sat in the back and it was a lot darker than the pictures suggest. Our table was kind of tipsy, but after a few glasses of Racer 5, so were we, so it didn't matter. Our server was friendly, but not particularly attentive. By around 9:00, the place filled up with people hanging out around the bar and generally being more casual than us, which I think is the way to go at Little Star.

Update: Went again last night. The place seems to be much more popular now. The vegetarian deep dish we had was better than expected but I'm still ambivalent about the wings.

And another thing: Enough with the comparisons to Zachary's. The crusts are completely different, people!

Thanks to our good friends at Yelp, we finally discovered a great pizza place in our neighborhood. The thin crust white pie with garlic olive oil, mozz, zucchini, feta and fresh tomatoes is better than any pizza we ever had in NY!

Delicious. The Little Star Special is definitely the best. After being a Zachary's fan for a long time, what makes Little Star possibly better is the delicious cornmeal crust, the fact that it's a little lighter than the greasiness of Zachary's. It's a "light-tasting" Chicago-style pizza, if that exists. I'm not a big fan of the ambiance at the restaurant, which is dark, and very loud. It's a good place for hipsters to hang out and have a drink. Have not tried the garlic bread, salads, or cheesecake (which I've heard good things about). If you don't want to drive across the bridge to Zachary's, definitley a good place to go.
best deep dish in SF. NOT as good as Zachary's. probably better than Paxti's. I like NOT buttery crust.

The clam and garlic pizza is many a magical thing: it's the perfect soaker-upper of booze, the ideal tool for sabotaging your Paleo diet, a sure-fire way to prevent smooching and/or close-talking, and the best $3.75 you'll spend in North Beach (except perhaps for a cup-o-gelato).

The crust is fluffy and foccacia-like with a crispy edge, a perfectly moderate amount of sauce and cheese, and then...the potent sprinkling of clams and garlic. It's like biting into a savory, odoriferous cloud of carboliciousness.

Seriously, when you're friends insist on interrupting your pub crawl to wait in the seemingly eternal line for a square slice of Golden Boy grub, follow them. And then, stop at the corner store for some breath mints, gum, and toothpaste. They may be able to put a dent in that clammy-garlic aroma you'll be living with for the next 2 days.

Best slice is SF!  Great atmosphere too - head on in for a beer and some punk music.  Best part is that it's cheap too.

This place is an institution.  Great for lunch or dinner.  Expect to wait in line.

Go for 2 slices.  Highly recommend the sausage as well as the clam.

Truly GOLDEN.

What is this mysterious clam and garlic pizza you speak of? It's easily the most talked about slice of pie on their menu, but I swear, every time I hit Golden Boy for a quick bite after sashaying through the neon-lit streets of North Beach, they never have it available. Wamp, wamp, wamp. But when the elusive clam pizza goes ghost and your mind is already set on devouring a cheesy piece of Sicilian-style comfort, I always end up setting on the second string, and it's not necessarily the worst thing in the world.

I can't say that if I were stone sober in the middle of the day I'd crave a slice of Golden Boy's goods, but for late night food with a bit of a buzz rattling the dome, it's hard to argue there's any better option in all of San Francisco. Typically, by-the-slice pizza joints around town are utilitarian at best, with little to no thought being put into taste or ingredients. The only goal is to feed the zombie apocalypse of drunken twenty-somethings before complete anarchy ensues, but here, things are different. It's more than a calorically-dense sponge intended to soak up the liters of Fernet flowing through your veins, it's actually a quality bite time after time. For that reason alone, Golden Boy is king.

Do your best to avoid during absolute peak hours, as the line has a tendency to grow 20 deep. But if you can manage to arrive just before the big rush, you're in the money.

YUMMY!  go!  immediately!   we shared  the salad with fresh mozerella which was very yummy.  and then had the deep dish.  a little too much cheese overload for me, but both were excellent!  tasty cocktails and beers.  and a great great jukebox!  this place is hip, fun and buzzin.  great place to take a date.
Pretty much the best pizza ever. Ridonculously loud inside though. But you're probably eating too hard to talk anyway.

im eating the left-overs right now. deelicious deep dish. crust is like, grainy, like corn meal and so good.

ambiance inside is more than any other pizza joint, no, they are above a "joint," they are a restaurant. pizza restaurant. beer on tap is prime. small menu, my favorite, easy to choose from and you know they will make it well.

the servers were a little too quick for my taste, taking empty  bottles from my hand and all, but good service all in all. will return.

Yum, yum, yum! I was told by a co-worker that I had to go here if I wanted some good deep dish pizza. Although this was only the second deep dish style pizza I've ever had, I must say, it was DAMN good.

Get there early because I had to wait for almost 2 hours. It's worth it, but if you're as impatient as I am, you might just end up leaving. Parking is a bit tough in this area, so if you can take public trans, I'd recommend that. I would also suggest going in a small group (2-4 people) because this place isn't that big. Very limited seating.

The pizza is ALWAYS so delicious.  Every time. Never fails. A bit of an attitude sometimes.. my boyfriend and I went in on A tuesday night at around 5. The hostess told us to sit anywhere so we chose a 4 top in the back, and then the waitress asked us to move to a tiny table in the front to save that one for big parties.  It was still nearly empty when we left.  But even though the staff can sometimes have a 'tude, the food makes up for it.

Square Pizza is kind of irregular food like:
use square white bread for a hamburger
or spam sushi, shit like that.
But this shit is Bad, it means GOOD, very GOOD SHIT!!!
The pizza is so hot and so square like bitch!
I love all of them, bitches and son of bitches.
It is so ghetto-food like. But, come to think of, most modern fancy foods are came from ghetto food, like Sushi as example. Sushi was once low-life people's snack in japan before. So as Ramen.

I must say, the best pizza by slice in the city.
I've been here for many times but I totally forgot to review, I think because I come here too often, there are many places I go but do not review.

Also, the place does not need Yelp reviews to get popular.
The place is strong enough to keep the business going without all dombass YELP HIP STARS.

Hey Golden Boy, You Rock!
You Don't Need the Stupid looking round red Yelp sticker.
Pizza is really good and line is always out the door, down the sidewalk. Luckily if you don't want to wait there are tons of good pizza places in this area; you are in little Italy after all.

My sister will be disappointed in this review, but here goes...

I've been to Golden Boy a few times after hearing rave reviews from my sister and brother in law. My fiance is a PIZZA LOVER so I knew we had to check this place out.

Golden Boy is a small joint with a selected menu. Thats actually whats great about them. You come in, get your pizza within minutes and top it off with a beer - IN and OUT. Their pizza's are reheated when you order unless you order by the sheet which I assume comes fresh.

I've tried all of their pizzas and I'm just not impressed. They should add more meat. I find myself biting around the pizza trying to locate a sausage or pepperoni. Same goes for their clam pizza, where are the clams?

I dont mind a doughy pizza, but the dough has to be something I can eat by itself. I felt like their dough was plain and was left craving for something more. Perhaps if the bottom was toasted longer for a nice crunch?

While I'm not in love with their pizzas, I will definitely be back. It is in a great location, staff is friendly and for $3.75 a slice, they had me at hello.

Pizza that gives Zacharys a run for its money!  My friend and I split a small salad, garlic bread and then splurged and decided to get two small pizzas so we could try the deep dish and thin crust.  Left sassy happy and we each had leftovers for a couple more meals! I've passed by the spot before and from the outside it looks to be a more romantic setting --- au contraire! While I am sure one could have a lovely date here, it is a casual setting. I am glad they don't deliver; I would eat pizza too often!

Awesome pizza, awful service. Don't get me wrong, the pizza is absolutely stunning, but the service is atrocious. I live a few blocks away and have been here numerous times, and the service gets progressively worse.

Bad visit #1: Sat outside on very tilted sidewalk tables. Took 10 minutes for our server came out. Ordered everything at once, took forever to get. Had to ask for our cocktails again, which arrived in dirty glasses (lip stick stains).

Bad visit #2: Sat inside by the window at a larger table. Ordered three pizzas (NY, cali, and Honey Pie -- tasty!), along with a mixture of cocktails, beers, and sodas. No refills were given on sodas, and no one asked if we wanted to order more drinks.

Bad visit #3: Came on my anniversary to get a honey pie for my GF (her favorite). We were seated outside by the slice house. This was a Sunday night and it was pretty busy. Only one waitress was working, which was unfortunate. We waited 15 minutes for our waitress to come out. We put our drink orders in and ordered bread and meatballs, which came out before the drinks. Bread was served with balsamic glaze rather than balsamic vinagerette (strange). We sat for another 20 minutes waiting to put our actual order in, and it turns out they were out of the Honey Pie. This was very discouraging, so we asked for a few more minutes to look for something else. Another 15 minutes go by with no waitress in sight. We flag down the hostess who was walking by from the slice house, and we ask for our check. I tell her about our slow service, and she doesn't seem to care. She comes back a few minutes later and slaps the bill on the table and walks off. We pay $30 for two diet cokes, meatballs, and bread. Bit disappointed that there wasn't an apology for the slow servive. At this point, our alternative options for dining have largely closed in the area, and my GF is starting to get upset. We end up getting take out from Calzones, where the bartender manages to cheer up my GF with drinks and jokes.

TL;DR: Awesome pizza, awful service.

WHY DOESN'T TONY'S TAKE RESERVATIONS?

I have loved the New Yorker Pizza and Lillet Blanc Fries at Tony's since I first set the delectable creations on my tastebuds years ago, and I have eaten at Tony's (and its derivatives) many times over the years. However, I am compelled to give the flagship establishment only 3 stars because of the ridiculous wait times and absolutely dreadful service from the management. (This is why this is called "Yelp," btw.)

My wife and I invited a few of our friends (5 others, for a party of 7) to join us as we celebrated my birthday on a Monday night -- what we thought would be a relatively slow evening. We told everyone to meet at 7PM, and we arrived about 20 minutes early because we anticipated a bit of a wait. We then walked across the street to the bar area of another establishment to enjoy a drink or two while we waited. But to our dismay and increasing hunger, it wasn't until shortly before 9PM that our table became available. And to add to insult to injury, they seated us outside under a malfunctioning heat-lamp (of which they were well aware). Anticipating inside dining on a typically cool San Francisco summer evening, two of the ladies in our party wore dresses. When we politely (but earnestly) objected, a person who seemed to be the manager was very rude and snide to us.

I don't really understand why the owners of this establishment refuse to employ a reservation system. This would alleviate the inconvenience and pain of so many. We are locals, and we want to support our favorite local eateries. But if they refuse to adapt while catering only to tourists, we will simply take our business elsewhere. And I can't imagine any tourists enjoy waiting 2+ hours and enduring rudeness from the staff either.

I'm not sure what all the hype is about. This pizza is meh ... barely ok. The prices are entirely too high for the auto i get and the service was subpar. I wouldn't return and didn't enjoy the experience.

We joined the waitlist in Yelp and waited for more than 1.5 hours (1 hour after checking in).
When the table was ready, we came and they told us that they had put us for seat on the outside (it was raining really bad and windy at that time).
We asked if we can eat inside and they said that we need to re-reserve and wait in the queue again.

We ended up sitting outside cause we don't want to wait anymore. We ordered Margherita and the food was already cold when it came. The rain was sprinkling on our food too.

I placed a delivery order on doordash at 6:30 and it said the restaurant was preparing my order for 2 hours. I called the door dasher and asked if he could check in on the order status. He was told it would be another 50 minutes. Cancelled my order, won't try to order from here again.

Best pizza in sf. Maybe the best in my life. I got the cocco or whatever they call the appetizer bread with a spicy salami and arugula. Oh my god it was so good. The bread was so soft and doughy and salty and tasty. All together it was like heaven. We got the squash blossom pizza which I completely did not understand when I ordered. For some reason I thought it would be squash and not flowers from a squash plant. I was wrong and it was beautiful. The cheese was on point and the dough was still heaven. My only complaint is that when I get prosciutto on pizza, it all comes off when I take the first bite and I end up eating the whole slice in like one bite and then it's over and I'm sad. This pizza deserves to be savored.
A must do when in San Fran.  Eleven different styles of pizza for every cuisine.  The meatballs are amazing.

Good place!! The wait was not too bad for a saturday night - ended up going next door to get a slice to wait for the margherita!! so good. The cocktails were great as well!!

Nice date spot.

Got the gluten free margarita and this was good, nothing to write home about. The burrata was on thick focaccia and was tremendous! Next time here I will try the very thin crust. The different ovens they use and organize their menu by is interesting and provides something we don't get at home or at the normal wood stove pizza oven restaurant. Will be back to try a handful more types by the slice.

Serve spaghetti in a big bowl ( do u know the different between spaghetti and noodles? )
Very thick spaghetti ( not crispy )
Too much sauce ( and bad tast too )
Silverware from museum ( godzilla collection )
I think those people wanna serve u a very good looking dish like proffesional photos...hey guys I wanna eat tasty meal i dont waana take selfie with the dish.

Today was my first time going to this place sober. It was funny coming inside and actually seeing light. I did not remember going into this place at all. I just remember being wasted and waiting for pizza. Regardless, going there for happy hour between 5 and 630 is probably your best bet. It's not too crowded then and they have $1 off beer. So a pint of good beer for $3.50 is a good deal to me. I have not had the Thin crust pizza yet but I have had the Deep Dish. The deep dish I don't think is as good as chicago pizza but I do like their tomatoe sauce and I think the crust takes great. Next time it's on for the thin crust pizza.

Pretty good, and I like that they have both thin and thick pizzas.  But their thin pizza is not as good as Cheeseboard and their thick pizza is not as good as Zachary's.  We also felt that we were rushed out when we were almost finished.

The only reason that I'm not giving it a 5 star rating today is that I've only tried it once. The Deep Dish tastes a lot like Pizano's in Chicago. A flaky, light but crispy crust with a good helping of cheese and toppings.

I had the special for the night. Meatballs, Pepperoni, Ricotta and Spinach. Well, the special was with Mushrooms instead of Pepperoni but they were more than happy to modify it for us. The pizza took the typical 25 minutes to come out. We arrived right as the opened so there was no wait. By the time we left though there was a line out the door.

The best part of the pizza was the meatballs. If they've got them the night you go, you owe it to yourself to order them. They are a bit spicy, but not too spicy.

We ordered a small pizza (9") for two people. It was the exact right size for the two of us. We didn't order an appetizer. If there are three of you, get a small and an app and you'll be fully satiated.

Yum Yum!

Oh, Jebus! That was so damn good. The crust, the crust, the crust. Come hungry and patient. We got the Little Star large deep dish. I want to marry the pizza if it was possible and socially acceptable. Go!

bomb
thats all i can say
it was so good
service was cool
atmosphere was cool
jukebox

pizza was unreal
Ehh....came back to try the classic. meh....had one slice and was sick of it. Guess I gotta stick with the little star...that one was delicious

I'm from the east bay and around those parts it's all about zachary's spinach and mushroom deep dish.
A few weeks ago some friends mentioned Little Star and said it was very similar to Zach's
They were right, and that is a very very good thing

The signature "Little Star" deep dish pizza is a slice of tomatoey heaven with a crunchy cornmeal crust.
A large feeds four people perfectly (2 slices each.)

I also love the way they serve their garlic bread do-it-yourself style with a head of roasted garlic, a cup of creamy butter, and slices of toasted bread all ready to assemble and enjoy.
First time I had corn beard as the pizza dough.  It turned out to be a good idea.  Had some wine with my gourmet pizza.  Its a rather unique place.  You gotta try it.

I'm having a difficult time just writing this review b/c I'm starting to salivate. SERIOUSLY.  I'm dreaming about the melted cheese and mouth-wateringly delicious cornmeal deep-dish crust.  (nom nom).  It's the perfect base for whatever topping(s) you choose.

Since we had bread and roasted garlic to start (yummy), my friend and I shared a small pizza that was half Brass Monkey and half Italian Combo.  It was the perfect amount of food for two people who also "had" to have beers to boot.

I like the "Brass Monkey" despite the confusion about its name.  Are they paying homage to the Beastie Boys?  Or is it this the house's version of a liquid cocktail to which the song refers?  I'm a person who needs ANSWERS.  But I guess that still won't prevent me from ordering it again.  It's their "Little Star" (spinach blended with ricotta and feta, mushrooms, onions, garlic) plus sausage.  I'm not sure why SF has all these secret menus.  Why all these mysteries, Little Star?

Back to the pizza - the Italian Combo was nothing special, but still very good.

The only downside of this place is the price, but you definitely feel full even after having one slice so I guess you get what you pay for.
