The only drawback is the small size.  I love the pizza but wish I didn't have to wait 45 minutes to eat it every time.  But I do anyway, so more proof that its awesome.

Only good wings i've had on the west-coast. Great gourmet pizza and good beer selection. Trendy interior low-light conditions. Hip place but expensive, it was really busy when i went, we were seated at the bar which turned out to be really fun.  The bartender spilled an almost full beer on me and was very apologetic, got me a new one and help dry me off, we made a good time out of it.  
This place tends to be busy, but don't pass it up. i recommend going at night.

This is the best pizza I've had in years!!! Yummy!!!

Love the ambiance. Yes there is usually a wait, but it's worth it! Friendly servers and did I mention that the pizza is great?!?!

You can also get your pizza to go &, bonus, they will do 1/2 and 1/2 so you can get two pizzas in one :)

The best Pizza in the bay area. Period.

Oh yeah, its cheap and they have good brew on tap and solid a juke box.

Little Star has the best deep-dish pizza around.  Forget your Zachery's or Paxtis- Little Star leaves those guys in the dust.

The quality of their ingredients is great, their corn-meal crust is amazing and two slices is more than a full meal.

I'd advise you to call your order in and pick it up, waiting for a table takes forever and the place itself is a little lacking in atmosphere.

Only reasons they don't get 5 stars are:
-too noisy inside,
-long wait times,
-they only accept cash
-parking can be tough
-they don't open until 5pm

We lucked out the other night and got seated right away...and the pizza was delicious as always! I used to live in the East Bay, so Zachary's was the place to go for deep-dish, but I think I've found a new favorite with Little Star...

I don't think there's much I could add to the glowing descriptions that people have already given except as to inform ya'll of Little Star's eco-friendliness.

Not only are these guys members of the Viv network (doyouviv.com), but they're also eco-friendly beyond the standard call of duty.

Their composting program is remarkable, and their recycling is throughly comprehensive.

All of this is very suprising for such a popular spot, with such great food, and with such a following purely for pizza-sake- But nonetheless, little star gets 5 stars as a sustainable business.

...and as you can see- they get 5 for the food. (thats 10 stars!)

just go and eat there. its that simple. i would recommend it to anyone who visits SF.

I went in last night with a friend for dinner. We had such a great evening. After being in hospitality for so long, it is so rare to find both of us relaxed and enjoying a meal out. Not only was our server unintrusively attentive (right on time to pour wine, water, etc) but well informed. She was right in steering us to share a small salad. We also ordered a large Little Star so that we were sure to have plenty to go home with. I am salivating while writing this just thinking of my leftover piece in the fridge.
They also have a fab juke box. I appreciated the songs from Dirty Dancing last night. RIP Patrick swayze.  
Little Star Pizza is a gem. I hope spreading the word will not ruin it!

Simply the best pizza in town.  I love the thick crust, I think it is cornmeal and the thin crust almost equally.  Friendly folk are there to help.  I usually get carry out, but nice inside if you are there earlish otherwise expect a wait.

Some of the best pizza I've had on the planet. If you love deep dish you have to stop in here.

i could go on and on about the place (and I do, to my friends) but there's really no need to belabor the point. If you are reading this and hungry then head over right now.

We had a great experience here! Started with the fried artichoke and a salad which were good but not terribly memorable. The pizza was delicious though! We opted for the pizza romana I:

Basil, garlic, cherry tomatoes and olives
Sopressata, arugula and parmigiano
Sweet fig, Gorgonzola, balsamic reduction and prosciutto

All sections were equally delicious! Can't wait to go back and try another style of pizza.

Yes we waited and so happily next door at Tony Niks and had a blast walking back in time to a classic bar of North Beach. Back to pizza, we sat at a cozy booth in the bar and enjoyed ourselves to the fullest! Started with the meatball app, amazing! Next we had the Carbonara wow, this did not leave us disappointed,  will talk about it for a long time.  Finished our meal with a cold fired new Yorker! We finished the left over pizza the next morning, cold , and still amazing!

Tony's is probably the most expensive slice house in town...and it's worth it, not because of size but because of quality and pizza finesse.  There are about 6 or so giant pizzas on display (specials of the day, NY cheese $3.75, pepperoni $3.95, Sicilian), featuring several kinds of crusts. Choose a slice or opt for stromboli, calzone, and sandwiches.

* Californian pizza with NY style crust ($5): One of the best crusts I've ever had; it's super thin, firm, foldable, a light char from the pizza oven, and crispy. The edges of the crust are puffy. The crispy yet chewy crust is addictive. The slice is topped with sweet creamy ricotta cheese, mozzarella, thinly sliced onions, peppers and mushrooms. There isn't too much cheese and it isn't greasy. The tomato sauce is just right.

It's a charming spot with one table inside and outdoor seating. Wander in and see which pizzas are available that day. Order at the counter and your number is called once they've heated your slice.

Look, the food IS great. But the hostess with the nose ring was so horrendous that it ruined the entire evening. She told us it was a 2 hour wait list. So we put our names down and went around the corner for drinks... then 1 1/2 hours later we get a text saying we have 5 minutes to get there or we lose our table. So we skull our drinks, run there and she has us on a table outside in the cold. So we asked if we can maybe let someone else take that one and we wait for one that is inside. She was really rude and told us we had to wait another 45 minutes so sent us away again... 50 minutes late we turn up and she is like "oh yeah I can seat you now". Clearly had forgotten us.

We then sat and waited 15 minutes for anyone to take our order and even then he would only take out drink order. He then gave us the wrong bottle so we had to wait longer! Finally got to order and when the food came it was good but one of the pizzas were burnt. They were busy but they really should have been politer about it and there was no need for their rudeness seeing as we had to pay $200 for the meal.

Ridiculous wait, with no reservations. Plan ahead, because you'll want this pizza.

My wife and I ordered a New Haven Lou and a margherita . Both were outstanding, and for very different reasons. The crust on my margherita pizza was perfect; crisp, with some give in the middle. Little dark toasted spots on the bottom. Nicely salted tomato sauce made the whole thing refreshing and delicious. The New Haven Lou was a contrast of great cheese with  hot chili pepper bits and greens. Glad we got two pizzas that were so different. These guys seem to do it all.

They made a pretty good manhattan, too!

As I left the city a Lyft driver mentioned take-out from this place was the way to go, and the slices from right around the corner are outstanding. Food for thought!

If this was local it'd be our pizza of choice, easy.

Let me first establish that I am not crazy about pizza, or even Italian food in general. I am hardly an expert on what qualifies as "good pizza" or "awesome meatballs" as I don't have large sample size to draw from.

That said, I thought that this was some pretty damn good pizza. Get there early and get their signature margherita pizza - and if they're out, go to their by the slice place around the corner. It is probably the most expensive pizza you'll ever order, but it was better than the custom pizza we added to our order. Other appetizers were ordered as well, including a meatball. Everyone seemed to enjoy everything, but I really only recall the two pizzas. The staff was friendly and prompt. The wait here can get a little crazy, but make reservations and hope they're not out of their margherita pizza!

As Rinky said in her review, Anna C. introduced us and Marian G. to Tony's.  The restaurant itself has been open since the end of June, while the pizza school in the back has been here much longer.  Despite being so new, it feels well established, thanks in part to the fact that the building looks and feels like old-time North Beach, but also because service is seamless and attentive.  It's nicely situated on the corner of Stockton and Union and is divided into two rooms.  You enter the room containing a long bar and several booths.  Up a couple of steps to the right is another room that contains the pizza oven and several tables.  Behind the pizza oven in a separate room is the pizza school.

Rinky has already given an excellent description of our meal and of the margherita pizza.  They make Italian-style, American-style and Sicilian-style pizzas.  I loved the Sicilian-style Fratellanza crust, which was thick, almost focaccia-like, w/ a seductive crispness to the bottom w/o a hint of black.  The tomato sauce was piquant, the cheese made strings like the mozzarella of my childhood and the pepperoni, salami and sausage were abundant.  The mushrooms were wonderful.   The round pizzas are served on beautiful Italian ceramic pedestal dishes that could be used as cake stands. The Sicilian pizzas are oblong and served in the pans they're baked in.  I ordered iced tea and had a choice of sweetened raspberry or bottled and very slightly sweetened Tazo black tea.  I chose the latter and it was perfect, what I would expect from Tazo.  

Anna ordered meatballs to take home to her husband and I followed suit.  A container of 6+ good size meatballs w/ sauce cost only $5!   Portions are generous and dishes are well prepared.  Sometimes when I go out w/ these ladies the company outshines the food.  In this case, they enhanced and complimented each other.  We had a great time together as always and ate exceedingly well.  If I lived in San Francisco I'd be over here all the time.

Tonight for dinner Alan and I shared the three pieces of pizza and the meatballs, a little pasta and the brussels sprouts I cooked yesterday.  It was a sumptuous repast.  Even reheated, the pizza was excellent, although not as revelatory as it was straight from the pizza oven.  The meatballs were delicious and their texture was exquisite.  The sauce was flavorful.  It's been many years since we spent much time in North Beach, but this was so delicious, I don't think it will be that long before I find a way to come back.

I need a five star review to start off the New Year right and live up to my new shiny 2012 Elite badge.

I won't talk about the great signature award winning Margherita pizza, baked 90 seconds at 900 degrees.

I won't talk about the genuine Negroni cocktail, complete with the orange twist (next time burn the twist to release the oil).

I won't talk about the environment nor location, right on North Beach in the middle of the Italian district of San Francisco.

What I will tell you is there was a hot bombshell sitting across from me that made me forget how great my dining experience was.

My 5-star rating is for the food only. We loved the food.

Pics of some of the items we've tried:
- Margherita pizza yelp.com/biz_photos/tony…
- Cal Italia pizza yelp.com/biz_photos/tony…
- Little Italy salad yelp.com/biz_photos/tony…
- Calamari yelp.com/biz_photos/tony…

My rating doesn't include service.

Service on the other hand is mixed, some waiters are very good, and some are just average or worse. We got the latter kind. Our server's name was Moon. He seemed more interested on the tip that he was going to get for our large food order.
- didn't ask if this was our first time at this restaurant
- didn't explain the different types of pizza
- didn't explain that the Calamari Calabrese style was a spicy option

We overheard the waitress for the table behind us providing all that information to her customers without being asked to. I'd call that good service, unlike our waiter. He just repeated to us "Do you want to order more?" a couple of times, even though we had ordered plenty. I thought that was pushy.

He took a very long time to get our drinks (our table was next to the bar), but when we got them one of them was incorrect. We didn't complain because we just wanted to have a good time. Later I found that I got charged an extra drink (both the wrong drink and correct drink we never got had been billed). The most outrageous part was when I got my statement, the total for this meal included a few extra cents more than what I had approved (I usually round up totals, no cents). I guess he wanted to roundup his tip to the nearest dollar. Not worth my time to complain to them, other than writing about it here.

4.5 Stars

Hey, TO-nay! *cocks collar*

We finally made it over here on a warm Friday afternoon.  I was really looking forward to it.  Having eaten at Tony's Castro Valley Pyzanno's all the time, I was ready to taste something more traditional.  

We walked in just after 1pm and were seated quickly, baby in tow, on the dining side of the restaurant, instead of the bar side.  While the bar side may have a game on to watch, and you might get your drinks quicker, it just wasn't that appealing due to the low light atmosphere; ask to be seated on the other side...much brighter and you get to see the pizzaiolo at work.

We started off with a Caesar salad, to get a little greens in our meal.  It was one of the best Caesar salads that I've eaten. Not too heavy on the dressing, and the greens were bite size.  The shaved parmagiano reggiano topped it all off.

We came for the authentic Margherita and it did not disappoint.  The authentic Italian imported ingredients really sets it apart from all other pizzas in the area.  Not too mention that a 900 degree wood-fired oven also helps out in charring the crust just right.  The crust was thin, with a little crispness, and some good chew consistency.  The sauce was perfect.  The mozzarella, basil, sea salt, and olive oil all added to the perfection beautifully.  The middle does tend to sag due to the sauce, but to me, that's normal.

We had also ordered a Prosciutto e Pomodorini pizza, which is cooked in an Italian domed brick oven with similarly fresh ingredients of Prosciutto di Parma, arugula, and heirloom cherry tomatoes.  I was a little put off at first when it came to our table. The crust's edge looked like it had been formed, almost mimicking a Pizza Hut-style pizza.  I thought it should've looked like the Napoletana-style, a little flatter, but it reminded me of his pizzas at Pyzanno's.  Taste wise, the toppings selection were great on this. The crust is a little thicker than the Napoletana, but it was good.  We didn't really get to finish this, but upon taking it home and re-heating it on the grill, it was excellent.  I preferred the wood-fired Napoletana-style better though.

We didn't experience any of the bad service from staff that some cried about.  Everyone seem to be friendly and helpful, especially since we had our little one with us.  I thought for a moment that Tony was goin' to serve up #32 (or whatever # it was) of 73 to us, but alas, he skipped our table.  I'm sure this  place gets busy later in the evening, so you do risk waiting (especially if you plan to have a large party, but don't intend to make reservations ahead of time).  I definitely want to come back to try the other pies (New Haven being one of them) and the pasta.

Living right across from it has its up and downs. For one, it's an easy fix when you have nothing in the fridge and Chinatown's closed. The combo is just delicious. "Get me the meatiest one!" is what I'd say when I ask my roommate to grab a slice for me.

It's no Za, but it's decent.

Down side, despite knowing it's a bad idea, you'd still be tempted to get it for breakfast out of laziness.

This place is SO legit - whether you are in a hurry and just want to grab something quick or looking for munchies after going out at 2am, Golden Boy Pizza is there for you (yes, it opens late!)

This is the only non-thick crust pizza place I like, usually I am not a fan of those, but this place does things right! My favorite here are the the combination and vegetarian. The vegetarian pizza even uses pesto sauce instead of tomato sauce...adds a bougie touch to this hole-in-the-wall :) Perhaps it's because the pizza has a tons of toppings but one slice is enough to fill you up and pizza here is not cheap ($3.75 for a slice that's not just cheese or peperroni)

Complete hole-in-the-wall (ie. small, not exactly the cleanest place, quick, friendly waiters) but definitely one of the most famous pizza places, if not most, in North Beach aka Little Italy with a bunch of other legit Italian places. It's a must try!

I love Golden Boy Pizza. I don't care that they are cash only, the pizza is will blow your mind away, so a trip to an ATM is definitely worth it.

I had the cheese (heavenly) and vegetarian (hearty and heavenly) and was so happy that I ate another cheese. It was that good, I didn't care how full I was.

Ate at the bar stools admiring the workers working the dough. They noticed, and next thing you know I'm back there slamming dough down on the baking sheet. I was terrible, of course, but it was a doughy blast.

Great people, amazing food. What more can you ask for?

This place is the best ever. I haven't had a bad slice yet! Cash only, and they close the door at 11:30 and sell from the window after that. When it's gone it's gone so get there before the bars let out! :)

Best pizza in the hood even though I once had slice with a screw in it back in the day when I was a kid; jamming "green onions" on the old school juke box.  Also, 5 stars to the server who has to deal with all the late night drunk doops.

Yuuuuuuge Golden Boy fan as my  Jersey crowd likes to say. I made my way here after sampling some delectable beers at the Rogue bar right down the street. Tony's, another SF pizza tradition, was closed and there Golden Boy was welcoming me with open arms.

Upon walking there, I noticed a drunk fool, only a couple stores before GB, inhaling a greased up mouth-watering delight. The taste buds were fully warmed up at this point, so, I made my way to the 5-6 person line on the sidewalk. The combo was the pizza of choice at the time, although the lady said pepperoni and cheese were warming up in the oven, but the medley of toppings and the fact I would have to wait a mere 2 minutes made my decision rather easy.

Wow, if you like sicilian pizza, a.k.a square pies, then Golden Boy is a place on your bucket list. I'm actually writing this review the next day and my hands are still so greasy that my keyboard is indeed a well-oiled machine. Optimal balance of meat toppings (pepperoni/sausage) and veggie toppings (peppers, onions, tomatoes).

I love the fact that you order right from the street and never even had to make my way inside the join, where you almost get that street cart vibe. However, Golden Boy will not be closed up like any of those vendors for a long, long time.

I'm pretty sure I'd still love this pizza even if I wasn't always intoxicated while eating here.

I vote for combo.

Have you ever thought to yourself,  "Gawd, I'd love to have a piece of that!"?
That is what I  think when I see a tray of Goldies veggie pizza. The best.

The pizza is between a 3.5 and a 4. The pizza dough felt and taste it very focaccia like. I like traditional NY style pizza and this is not it. The clam pizza was 3 star, good but I would not get again.

My boyfriend and I make an annual trek to our favorite city, San Francisco from the deep depths of San Bernarghetto. Last year we wanted to save some fundage on our trip and looked for lesser-priced alternatives when eating out. We fell in LOVE with Golden Boy Pizza. It reminded me of days when I visited Queens, NY and my friends and I would hit the all-night pizza joints for a slice or two of awesome pizza. The place is small, so don't expect to bring in a party of 8 and get a table. At the most you'll stretch out across a small bar facing a wall, but that wall is fabulous with its vast sticker collection ranging from Kurt Cobain's mug to Beatles lyrics.
The day we went a young woman was the barmaid/waitress/pizza guru and she was perfect. Took our order (2 combos, one with 2 slices of pepperoni and the other with 1 clam/garlic one cheese). She made sure everyone in the joint was comfortable, had drinks in front of them and even talked sports with the locals.
The pizza was amazing! The garlic clam pizza has left me dreaming of my return this July. I cannot recommend it enough. GET.IT.
Do yourselves a favor and try it out. If you find yourself wanting great food at a low price then make the trek to Golden Boy. You won't regret it.
Deep Dish. Cornmeal Crust. Loud so do pick up.

Went here with 2 of my friends. We decided to sit at the bar for happy hour drinks, appetizers and pizza. The food and service was very good.
The bartender was ready to help us with a good attitude.
There isn't a big selection of drink besides beer, wine and champagne cocktails. But the Champagne drinks were very good especially the black cherry. We also ordered the ginger drink and orange creamsicle.
My friend ordered the buffalo wings which were not your typical saucy wings but instead breaded with spicy seasoning. I highly recommend this appetizer! it was so good.
I've had the deep dish pizzas here which are really good, so we decided to get the thin crust special with broccoli, sausage, mozzarella and black olives.
the portions are very large, the small pizza was filling for 3 girls.

this is one of the best pizza places i have been to in San Francisco. !
not only is the food amazing but the service is even better!
i would definitely go here again!

I'm a pizza aficionado and found this to be the  best in SF out of 10 to 12 places I've been to, same with the Valencia location. The deep dish is truly Chicago, with the cornbread, hints of, in the crust, like Gino's near Rush Street.

Definitely the best pizza in San Francisco.  It's not as good as Zachary's in Berkeley, but I live in San Francisco, so I guess Little Star is my new go to joint (except not really because I don't live in the neighborhood, and you know how San Franciscans are, if it's more than an 8 block walk away, it's kiiind of farrrrr) .... I would totally get fat from pizza if I lived within 8 blocks though, delicious.

very good pizza. better than zacharys! both their deep dish and thin crust are crispy! chicago style pizza in SF!

they have such a great variety so try all of them!

It's not Chicago deep dish but it's damn close!  I love all of its chewy goodness, tangy tomato sauce, and yummy toppings.  The garlic bread is incredible.  So is the spinach salad.  And unfortunately for me, I can never seem to get out of this place without ordering all of the above.

If you are watching your figure, stay away from this place.  It's dangerous to your wardrobe.

Recently went here with family and was very happy with service and especially the food. We ordered the deep dish and 3 diff kinds and enjoyed every slice :).
The parking was the issue but thats a norm in this area.

I will definitely be back to Little Star soon :)

- food: delicious
- atmosphere: loud / cramped but fun
- price: who cares
- staff: hipster / friendly

additional info:
- amazing jukebox

Tried the mediterranean deep dish a small between me and my friend (6 Slices $20.00) We were FULL!! The beer was great! Atmosphere - HIP Parking can be tricky (metered but free after 6pm) I came here just because of the reviews and I tried to get there early since it was said that the wait can be long (We were seated immediately exactly at 6pm) but it quickly filled up was I glad we got there early. A bit noisy but that was part of the experience. The waiter staff was very attentive. two thumbs up!
This place is packed out the doors sometimes. Phone in your order and take that pizza to go, pick it up and its just as yummy at home!

Me and my girlfriend came here during the North Beach Festival looking for some tasty pizza. Saw the pizza at the window and it looked amazing. It was SQUARE PIZZA, how awesome is that? Im use to the triangular pizza.

Anyways I got a pepperoni and my girlfriend got the plain old cheese pizza. Both cost me an even $6. Totally worth it. Pizza had lots of toppings, tasted awesome and the crust was awesome. I usually dont like crust but I LOVED their crust.

Will definitely be back. Love their pizza! =)

I grew up in North Beach and nostalgic memories of Golden Boy Pizza fill my mind whenever I think of my elementary and middle school days... My friends and I would mosy on over to Golden Boy's in our catholic school uniforms and order a slice or two of pizza after school. We thought we were so cool... Ha.

The square-cut pizza here is simple, cheap, and delicious. Not super greasy, generous toppings, and freshly baked on a tasty crust. The place itself is small and exudes a dive bar hole-in-the-wall vibe, but it's all part of the magic. Metal stools line the wall and bar counter. Local flyers are tacked on the walls and windows. Beers on tap. Cash only.

All the pizzas are amazing, but the clam and garlic is BOMB.

I really don't understand the hype. The pizza is decent...it's not amazing. People who rave about this place must come only when they are drunk.

I like to ask for the pizza to be extra crispy, which means they just put it in the oven for a bit longer.

Golden Boy is my favorite go-to spot for the late night munchies... even though I live a (Bay) bridge away. It is definitely worth the $5 toll. Sure there are a lot of open-til-late pizza joints in SF but Golden Boy is by far theee best!! And you know it has to be theee best because there is still a line out the door at 2 in the morning.

The garlic clam, the pesto, the combo.. Ohh so golden in my mouth!!

TEAM SQUARE PIZZA!! :)

P.S. It is hard to miss this place, just look for the finger pointing right at it.

OH EM GEE! Golden Boy Pizza has been on my brain since it last touched my lips on Saturday evening!  I don't know how I have lived here for 6 months without it!  

The line was long but it was definitely worth the wait!  Yum! I can't wait to get another slice of the cheesy goodness!

Truly average.  I ate here a couple of times several years ago and I recently returned.  It was a disappointment.  The last couple of times I've been to Golden Boy, it was late and I was getting the remains of their veggie pesto day.  I thought it was good, not great, and certainly not "OMG".  I recently tried it during primetime hours with the vegetarian pesto coming right out of the oven.  Have my taste buds changed?  Have my standards risen?  It's just nothing special.  In fact, after a slice or two, I was sick of it.  The crust was doughy, the sauce undetectable.

Other pizza ruined forever?  I don't think so.

Please note:  Cash Only.

Thank you Yelp God for leading us to yet another yummy place to eat! I got a classic plain cheese pizza and it did not disappoint. This style of pizza is a mix between New York and Chicago pizza. Great sauce, buttery crust that's not too thin or too thick and golden cheese. Perfection at it's best. The place is cool as well.
Would I go back? Hell yes!

Best pizza in the city after a night of drinking. The fact that this place also serves beer makes Golden Boy close to perfect. Be sure to get here before they close the doors and make you wait in line outside. As fun as the people watching can be at that time of night I'd prefer to sit inside with my beer and slice.

Golden Boy is where it's at!

The best pizza crust ever! Just got back from Golden Boy and boy are we in love! The hubs had the classic pepperoni and I had the pesto vegetarian.  When we heard a garlic and clam tray was coming fresh out of the oven we ordered a slice of that too.  Yum!  

Good music, great service, delicious pizza and reasonable prices.  Only downside was searching for parking, but its the city and we are willing to overlook this detail.

Sorry no pics, in my mouthwatering stupor I forgot to take any.

I haven't written a Yelp review in about two years. Now that I'm living in San Francisco, I think I need to get back into the swing of things. So let's start with Golden Boy Pizza. It's just good. It's thick, it's cheesy, it's greasy. It's pretty much everything you need it to be.

Its a small place and gets crowded, so you might be eating in the cold, but it's so warm and delicious, you won't even care.

GO NOW!

I'll wait for you, Pizza, in good health and in bad.  I'm not a pizza fan--GUILTY!  but my Chicagoan friends are, and this is the closest we can get to deep dish pizza (minus BJ's).  Although they expressed the differences, this is still San Francisco, so let it be known that we gots our own deep dish now.  Little Star doesn't take reservations, and is not an ideal place for parties larger than 6.  Most tables fit 4, but bigger party = more varieties of pizza, right?  That was my mentality coming into this.  With a party of 8, we ordered 3 pizza's: the classic, the pesto chicken thin crust which we made into a deep dish, a thin crust vegetarian piece w/ feta, and chicken wings!  All of it was good, unless the hour just made me hungry.  I typically don't like the crust of pizza, but I think the crust on this deep dish is the best part!  Crunch Crunch.  One restroom to share among all.  Well-composed service.  Pizza can get messy when not handled right.  Wear something you don't mind getting dirty :)

The atmosphere is spartan, with blue and gray walls and a rust-colored cement floor, but nobody's coming here for the decor. Thick-crust, aka Chicago, pizza lovers are attracted by the deep-dish pies with their crunchy cornmeal crusts. The signature Little Star is stuffed with a mix of spinach, ricotta and feta cheeses, and mushrooms, then topped with a thick, zesty red sauce. The white pie is a bit of a misnomer, considering it combines mozzarella, feta, garlic, and olive oil with colorful zucchini and tomatoes. A selection of cracker-thin crust varieties are available as well. It's not likely you'll have room for the delicious housemade cheesecake, but gelato is known to aid with digestion, at least in Italian families. Always crowded, with a jukebox playing classics adding to the din. I'm glad I live around the corner, because parking's a major problem in this mostly residential neighborhood.

I am giving Little Star 4 out of 5 based on their service.  The pizza is REALLY good if you like deep dish...its perfect!  I went on a Friday night (really busy) and they said the wait would be 45 minutes.  That was fine with us, we saddled up to the bar.  But afte an hour and half, and four beers later, we were STARVING and really annoyed.  They should have just been honest about the wait from the jump.  After investing that wait, we just decided to stick it out.  Moral of the story- prepare yourself for a very long wait.  The ambiance is cool- very hipster, dark, rock-esque, but the waiters and waitresses are too cool for school.  Part of the motif I guess!    Overall- great pizza, bad service, long wait.

Cailifornia, lets get something clear. Pizza state, you are not. I know that short of tongue service, im not gonna find a decent pizza in this city, so im done looking for good pizza, and resolved to look for "roundish pie looking things that have an Italian flair about them." We got the garlic bread, and im down with roasted garlic, and fresh bread like a nun is down with lead panties. We got a thin crust and deep dish. They were both ok. I liked the crust on both, but the zauze was really acidic, like, more acid than a Burning Man notebook. But what really singed the shorties was while we were finishing off our beers after they cleared our plate, one of the waitstaff, in the most feigned politeness since Diane Keaton saying "Im just tired, thats all", they asked us to "Please think about leaving because they had people waiting." Granted, we got there at about 530 to beat the rush, but it was 700pm! WTF? An hour and a half is too long? If i had a derby on, id have forecefully grabbed my brim and announced a "Good Day" to him, and with a twist of my waxed moustache, and a quick snatch of my cane, whisk off into the foggy streets of Cantlesbury to wage my chances against the Ripper. But i dont, so we pounded our beer and we complained amongst ourselves.

so effin' good....it hurts!!! seriously, the next day my poor body kept craving some of that delicious pizza with all the fresh toppings: sauce that tasted like tomatoes, olives that tasted like kalamata, and the cheese...oh man, don't get me started on the cheese!! this place is highly addictive...be warned! good jukebox, drinks, food, and people...what more do you want? some people think the wait is a problem, but i say it shows how many people have good taste!

it's sunday night, which means my brain is fried and i have nothing funny to say. but heed my words, little star pizza is the best deep dish pizza in the city. in the state. in fact, the best anywhere up to the chicago city limits.

I have been versed on the zodiac, constellations and twinkle twinkle....but LITTLE STAR.......LITTLE STAR.....what's that?   Don't let the name fool you....this place is kind of a big deal.  From the outside you just see a black door with a sign of a tower with a star above it...but don't mistake it for a muslim bake shop....walk in and experience the chillness of this spot.  I did not sit and dine because I wasn't so fresh after a 2 hour workout at the gym but I did sit in there to wait for my thin crust classic pizza, little star Chicago style pizza, spicy wings, and cheesecake.  The place is just down to earth and chill....it relaxed me like I was in the Himalayan mountains in a secret spring behind the waterfalls having a bubble bath.  The thin crust pizza was very delicious, but the Chicago style pan pizza was insane in the membrane.....it's like having two meals in one.....first you have your pizza of choice (I got the little star...which has spinach and feta cheese on a cornbread crust) and then they put a mote of thick pizza sauce in the middle....very addicting.  I was on a strict diet for two weeks and I put it on pause for that day like I was playing Nintendo WII to use the bathroom and had 4 slices of the Chicago style, 3 slices of the thin crust, 5 spicy wings (which were just alright for me....not spicy at all), and a slice of some tasty homemade cheesecake.....oh snapples was that good!!!  That was like a month ago and I am still feining like a crack baby.....I know they be sprinkling some crack on the pizza....it just doesn't add up.  Oh yea!!! plus they have dranks (Ebonic definition - alcoholic beverages)...next boys night out we are going to hit this spot up.  Prices are more than other pizza joints but well worth it.

The pizza here is so delicious that I ate so much of it over the course of a year that I got sick of it and haven't had it in months now. I've eaten here (well, mostly take out) dozens of times--I remember a time when I got pizza here once a week. Both the thin and deep dish pizzas are excellent--spicy, flavorful sauce and crispy, perfectly textured crusts in both cases. I think the deep dish here is a little better than Zachary's, but it's a close call. It's definitely better than the crap I just had in Chicago--totally due to my own bad decision in the place, I'm sure (or so I've been told...now I have to wait til next time damnit!!). But actually perhaps my favorite thing at Little Star (other than the fab jukebox) are the the chicken wings--so. good. This deep affinity could have something to do with my pizza burnout, but really I've always loved the wings....just more so lately. Cheap PBRs (normally like $2 a can I think?) are a plus, too. And the champagne cocktails are served in a huge glass--or at least they were, last time I ate inside. I knocked off a star because I was truly annoyed when this place switched to CASH ONLY! WTF? It's not like it's a cheap, divey joint AND in the beginning they did accept credit cards, which makes it all the more irritating. Ah well.

worst dining experience ever! after ordering over $100 in food and drink  the owner rudely pushed us out to door to make room for a new table after he thought we had been sitting long enough.  very unprofessional and quite rude! on top of that it's super loud...so loud that you can hardly even hear the painfully hip tunes in the back ground.  pizza was ok... certainly nothing to go nuts over.

geez.. i've walked/driven by this place like a gazillion times... never really paying attn due to the dark entry of this place. finally, after a couple of ppl told me great things, we thought to try it out.. made an order to go, ready at the exact time (1/2hr) . classic, large, deep-delicious. crzy thing was it was still 5:30p and the place was already packed, every table taken.. parking around the area can be a PITA, but as Sam(uel Jackson) Adams says... "MMM MMMM GOOD.... "

(See pics) A recent visit had us tried some dishes that we had not had a chance before. White anchovies antipasti was very nice if you love anchovies. Quail Egg potato chorizo pizza was interesting and not traditional. It was experimental but not sure if I want to order it again. Caputo margherita pizza was very delicious, almost as great as the limited classic ones. The bucatini was rich in taste.

Drinks wise, I usually prefer a draft Peroni but had paired the food with Gragnano and Tempranillo and they were all very good. Italian wines are very food friendly for its lighter taste and not overwhelm the dishes.

Service was very very good even they seated us close to closing time and we stayed quite late while they were cleaning up without interrupting our meals.

Right on for all your great food and service!

First off, we were all pumped up to check out this place because it came highly recommended by my girlfriend who used to live in SF.  Much to our surprise the restaurant is closed on Mondays and Tuesdays.  What?  I guess when you are THAT good you can do whatever you want right???  (side note when our excitement had been crushed we headed across the street to the Original US Restaurant-Amazing).

So we returned on Wednesday with full intention on experiencing the highly recommended to see what the hype was about.  We got there right before it opened with others who did the same.  While we waited the windows and tables were being cleaned.  The place really does have a presence from the outside and is always good to see a little love given however they did miss the outside tables where there were old hard breadstick in multiple places (remember they were close a couple days).

We were seated quickly.  They had a full bar to the left of us.  The server was great.  Since we hadn't been there before she explained all the temperatures of how the pizzas were cooked which kinda left our heads spinning.   Not fully getting the concept of the different degrees versus crust etc.  We started out ordering the Caesars Salad with Chicken.  When it came out the server chick quickly realized that it was missing chicken.  The salad looked so amazing I was willing to settle but she wisked it away.  It took about 20 more minutes to have another which by this time we were starved.  The chicken was freshly warm placed on top. No arguments there.   It was missing the parm shaved on top that we saw on the first salad which would have been nice since we were already teased with it.  Salad was dang good still.

We decided to order the New York pizza because I had seen good reviews about it on Yelp.  It was a thin kinda crust, a little too crunchy for us but we were already warned.  It had a lot of meat which we are more simple than that-we should have just stuck with one kind of meat.  Meatlovers would love this.  So needless to say I think we may have ordered the wrong thing to our liking but it was still good just a little too much.  Like I said the whole menu thing was confusing.  

So the star of the show was ....drum roll....the kids mac and cheese.  I think it was the best mac and cheese we ever had.  My daughter ate probably less than half (it was a big bowl) and the BF ate most of the rest.  It seriously was his favorite thing we had here. LOL  The mac was big mac noodles with a homemade cheesy cream sauce.  Fantastic and on the children's menu! haha

Bathrooms were clean.  There was only one bathroom with a sign and people were waiting in line the whole time.  Totally awkward-in front of tables.  When I got up to wait the chickie finally told me that there was another next to it.  Hmm nice to put a sign and maybe make them a men/womens.  Just a little thing.

Super good.  Great server.  Cool ambiance.  We will be back the next time we visit but may try a 900 degrees (versus the 1000 degrees) pizza - I think that's the one that leaves the crust a little doughy.  Still confusing.  LOL  The bill was around $60 minus the tip - most expensive lunch we had while in San Fran (with just sodas).

They say that zen is achieved when one lives in the moment. That, when you expect nothing, you receive everything.

I was told that the wait would be an hour. No problem - I actually didn't care. A man asked me to watch his standard poodle while he went in to make a reservation. A homeless guy petted the dog a patted me on the shoulder - no problem. A woman went into the crowded restaurant with a stroller - I didn't care to the point of holding the door for her. I really was in no hurry.

The hostess said to me: "We have a seat open at the chef's station - are you okay with that?" That's a question that doesn't have to be asked twice. What an unbelievable turn of good luck.

I sat just a few feet away from the 900F oven and watched choreography. Three chefs - one main and two support, churning out pizza after pizza with care. The staff work hard and take pride in their craft - just like the shirt says. They were having fun and so did I.

Pizza is spectacular. The high points are the crust and the sauce - both sublime.

I think I learned - or continued to learn - something very basic tonight. Thank you Tony's Pizza.

Montana - you're the man - thanks.

San Francisco is magic. Several things make it magic. One for me is Tony's Pizza. As I use to say at home​, in Italy​, here you get the best Pizza napoletana of the planet. Perfect, from the border to the center i a blaze of taste made by high quality ingredients. It is the very first place I visit after my arrival from Europe or USA. The ways you can find the Pizza here are amazing. The care for temperature and cooking time make any Pizza you ask for as the best. In the small room they have not many table but from each table you can feel the "aroma" of an italian pizzeria, you feel at home. This happens also to not italian people, as i had as feedback from american colleagues. I could not leave San Francisco without coming here again.

Such an amazing, authentic Italian restaurant.  I felt like I was dining al fresco in Naples!  We started with the Tony's salad.  It was fresh and delicious.  Then we had the giant meatball with veal, beef and pork, smothered in the most flavorful, delicious marinara sauce and topped with burrata.  Then we had the margarita pizza.  It was so wonderful with crisp, thin crust that was soft and chewy as you bite.  The sauce, the cheese, the basil were all delicious with small droplets of olive oil on top.  For dessert I had a gorgeous cappuccino with the traditional biscotti on the side and we ordered a chocolate chip cannoli to share.  I've never been a fan of cannoli.  The shell is always tasteless and generic and the cream inside is usually too thick and dense and also tasteless.  This cannoli was incredible.  The shell was light and crisp and delicately sweet.  It tasted fresh with the most delectable, soft creamy filing that tasted so, so good.  Next time you're in the beautiful city by the bay, make your way to the North Shore and dine at Tony's.  You won't regret it!

Not the best pizza in the world like they claim to be. Very pricey and only one server! Would NOT recommend the drink "richie" it is SPICY. The Margherita pizza was okay. Nothing special, definitely not world renown. I would skip this place.

This is my absolute favorite pizza place in SF but their customer service / delivery options blow. They won't accept delivery orders through anything other than Uber eats - which in 2017, is pretty asinine. With frequent technical difficulties, and the fact that Uber is an awful company with awful values, it's very frustrating to only have that option. Maybe think about accepting a good old fashioned phone order? You know, kind of like how pizza places have been accepting pizza delivery orders for, I don't know, probably the last 50 years? Just a thought.

I would give this place six stars if I could.  Hands down, the best pizza I've ever had.  This restaurant dethroned Gino's Pizza in Chicago as my favorite.  I had the coal-fired (1000 degree) New Yorker.  Went to San Francisco in the summer of 2013, and I almost didn't leave the city when it was time to leave - all on account of this place.  Incredible.

Flew in from L.A. for The best Pizza, meatballs and great service!!!!!  Highly recommend when you come to San Francisco!!!!!!
Thanks Tony
Hands down the best pizza in SF!!! Tony is the man! Also his pizzas are exactly like what I had in Italy this summer. There is no better Pizza joint on the west coast than Tony's.

This is more my style of Pizza. Square slices are not as messy, and the gentle spices added to each slice are sublime! Thick crusts and thick pizza topped with plenty of cheese and not overdone with the tomato.
Parking is near impossible of course but I had no idea so many crackheads and tweakers lived in this part of town. Good for them, movin on up!

This place has the best pizza in norcal.so many fans can't be wrong. If your an east coast  transplant you will be suprised pleasantly as I am every time I get to this hole in the hills of sf. you can breeze in on a weeknight but weekends expect its standing room only.

Typically this place seems to be overrated first i ate there and found their though sometimes are too doughy specially in peak hours, Second i have had more decent pizza slices elsewhere, Delivery can be a pain sometimes but finally the place seems ok if you are really rooting for a pizza slice.

Holy hell. Great fucking pizza.
I came in to grab legit pizza for the first time in a year since I was working in Korea and came to SF for vacation. I ordered the clam and garlic pizza slice.. for under $5.
Put that stuff in my mouth and it was AMAZING.

It looks heavy because of the toppings and cheese... but the bottom is crisp and fluffy. it isn't heavy at all! It is so savory and delicious... def come by and grab a slice. COME!!!
Everything is amazing at Golden Boy Pizza.  The sauce is off the hook.  My husband craves it all the time!  Thanks for great pizza and great service!

IT"S EXCELLENT - AFTER A NIGHT OF A LOT OF DRINKING...

Other then that, hit up North Beach pizza if they're open.  WAY BETTER.

Ok there's pizza and there's pizza!  You've heard of the pizza and sex metaphor? Well it is somewhat true...sometimes any pizza is good and satisfying, but life is too short to eat average pizza!  Golden Boy is not average pizza...it's delicious...if you love thicker crust, square cut like you can get on the streets in Italy.  I love all kinds of pizza and cannot say which is the best, otherwise that would be like picking one wine.  For this style, it is the best in the city!
See my other reviews for other types...

Square pizza?!?!?

So used to the triangle way of pizza, some large, some extra large,
and others "large" and "toppings". As I roamed around North Beach,
found some "inspiration" from above, a hand pointing to this place
on Green Street between Bannam & Jasper Place.  Was it a sign?

I went in... found various kinds of pie, squared!  In cheese to
various toppings and combos!  From $2.75-3.75 for a slice.
Had the sausage and it was delicious! The foccacia bread tasty and
flavorful, nice amount of sauce, cheese and with sausage placed on the
corners.  Nice presentation.

The gal behind the counter was great, taking care of her customers
and letting others in line know she will get to them ASAP.  That scored
brownie points!  Overall, a nice find!

To totally twist (or screw up) an Adam Smith term... a visible hand from above will guide you to great pizza.  Enjoy!

SQUARE PIZZA!

I got very excited when I looked through the window and saw that the pizza was in squares and not triangles.

I got two slices, the pepperoni and the combo. The combo was pretty good. The pizza dough is really fluffy and soft and it's pretty thick. I took the pepperoni home and when I got home, the bag was all oily. Normally, I would think that it would be gross but it proved that the pizza was good. It was greasy and it was still delicious when I got home. I just had to reheat it again.

They only have a few options for pizza toppings but the place is also pretty small too.

I've only come here once but when I get the chance to make the trip again, I would want to come back.

I love Pizza so much the guy who takes my order at Papa Johns knows me by my voice on the telephone. And sometimes he calls me just to chat. Which is confusing. I am not confused because he is a man and I am straight. Gender Roles don't concern me. But Pizza Rolls dooooo

When I was looking for a place to eat late at night I walked from Union Square to this wonderful establishment and let my salivating orifices do the rest.

Visit this place for the best pizza in San Francisco!

Seriously some of the best pizza I've ever experienced anywhere. Ever. And we eat a lot of pizza. We had spent the day hiking at Muir Woods and were famished and were lured in by the positive reviews. Luckily we beat the rush and were seated quickly. There were four of us including two hungry teenagers. Our waiter was shocked by our Midwestern appetites and tried to talk us out of ordering two large pizzas. We went with one deep dish and one thin, both pepperoni and sausage. To our waiter's surprise we demolished every last bit. Deep dish pizza is one of my favorite things and this rivaled the best I've had in Chicago and outshone several of them. The crust was the perfect blend of crispy buttery-ness and pillow-y lightness. The sauce was well seasoned and complex without alienating the teenagers and the cheese was high quality and plentiful. This is high on our "must eat" list for our next visit to San Francisco.
Ordered the classic deepdish pizza, it was very good but overpriced, $19. Had the wings and they were ok. Waitress was very attentive. Will try again

This is easily one of my favorite restaurants on Divisadero. It's impossible to go wrong with the Chicago-style options, and the thin crust Greek is one of my favorite pizzas ever. Don't forget to check the specials!

Had the think crust meat pizza. It was pretty good; not a true think crust. Crust was crunchy and had good flavor. overall, it's overpriced. They don't offer many variations on the deepdish and it's too pricey to order a cheese and add toppings.
Yes it's truly the best deep dish in the Bay Area.  Better than Zachary's.  If you have a freind who disagrees, I'd challenge her to a blind taste-test.  Honest tongues prefer Little Star.
Love this deep dish-style pizza. Great for date night!

ahhh, it was just what i wanted and expected.  got out of the john legend concert and was starving for some pizza.  ordered a pint of the blue star wheat.  delicious and shared the thin crust classic with a friend.  the service was fast and friendly.  the setting was great too.  dark with mod bulb lighting fixtures.  it was a down tempo feel for a pizza joint.  i'd go back in a heartbeat.

It's WORTH THE WAIT. I don't care how many people are in front of me, I'll start with a drink at the bar, and wait for my table. I'm still in disbelief I hadn't heard of Little Star Pizza until now. Their deep-dish pizza is a must-try. Unlike other pizza joints, Little Star is a bit more classy. Great vibe, great wine selection, and perfect for intimate groups.
It was worth the 1 hr wait.  We tried the thin crust pesto and the deep dish mediterrianian. i loved the corn meal crust on the deep dish.

I'd give 4 1/2 if I could....1/2 star off for noise. I'm fine with some mood music, but not so loud I can't hold a conversation with my family. Food was excellent...best caprese salad I've ever had. 2 deep dish pizzas were soooo good. Definitely coming back for more!

Truly as good as it gets.  My advice for SF eating...follow the crowd.
The line was out the door and wound down the street. We waited around 2:30 PM on a Sunday for almost half an hour to make it to the door and order 'at the window'.  We both had the cheese pizza and ordered to eat in since we were lucky that 2 barstools had just opened up at the otherwise full counter (max seating 20ish). Excellent service (very funny too) and delish food. We were served from a new pie straight out of the oven and piping hot...no reheat needed even though they will heat up the ones in the window for you if you are served from there. One relatively fair size 'slice' which is really a 4inX4in deep dish square was $4.  A full tray of cheese was $40. Cash only. TOTALLY WORTH IT. I wanted to go back again and would have if I had more time and not an already long list of places I wanted to try out. Will go back next time I am in SF.  Worth the wait and the price.

probably the best pizza I ever ate.  Well balanced and the crust is crunchy but yet soft. The waitress there name Lori I think, is a sweetheart. Just a beautiful personality. Highly recommend it to any pizza lover. Will come back with some friends.
This is the best pizza joint in SF. It's by far one of the most delicious crusts. The crust is extremely crispy and the tomato sauce is exceptional.
Golden Boy is one of the best pizza joints in the city! Good food good service. Always make it a point to stop by whenever I'm on that side of town.
Just touched down in the Bay, already Yelped places the eat late night. Golden Boy had great reviews, was so excited to try it. WASN'T DISAPPOINTED! Amazing pizza! Loved loved loved the clam pizza!
Very unique place and eye appealing slices!  Forget the calorie count and  see for yourself !

Visiting San Francisco for the weekend; on our way back to our hotel we wanted a quick bite. This place did not disappoint. (5) stars, friendly staff, prices are great for what you get, pizza is the Best!
this was some amazing pizza! had it to go then went over to park to devour this  crust was so crispy yet soft and toppings were just to die for! Now I know why SFO has such high standards for pizza

This place is incredible. The service is quick, they prices are great, and the pizza is incredible. I recommend getting two slices to try multiple flavored. The clam and garlic was excellent, as was the pesto. I can't wait to go back to try the rest!

Remember to have cash on you! I got two slices in a to go box for $8.50.

Goooood pizza and beer. I ordered mine and started eating as soon as it was handed to me. Swapped a bite with a friend and theirs had been heated in the oven, and mine was stone cold! Theirs was much better due to slightly crispier crust and hot cheese. However, since mine was still good cold, I will have to go again and rewrite a review if I get a hot piece :)

The best pizza i have had in a really long time! They have tons of different styles of pizza and you really can't go wrong with any of them. I live close by and have made this my default pizza joint.

The bar tenders are all very friendly and Stephanie is super nice. The people that you meet at the bar are usually really friendly and are surprisingly mostly local.

If you are looking for what pizza to order, if you are there for the first time, go with the Napoletana Margherita Pizza and then discover others from there.

This is a momentous month for CA.  Gino's is now in the Bay Area!!!  It brings a tear to my eye to think that we finally have good pizza and Italian Ices here on the west coast.  OK, so we still need good bagels and knishes, but let's not dwell on that.

Tony has done such a wonderful job at making an old school place and hitting some key chords of people like me...a pretty out-spoken New Yorker.  Tony is in his element at this spot and I wish him the very best in his new adventure.  I know it will continue to be successful.

All the best!
Great gluten free pizza and gluten free beer. Nice service also, with outdoor seating right on the park.

Went here last night. Wasn't too bad of a wait once we were on the waitlist. The pizza is awesome and the garlic bread is delicioussssss. The ambiance of this place is nice and lively and relaxed. We shared a table with two other people and ended up having a nice discussion and time with them as well. Awesome place!

Some seriously delicious pizza!!! The menu can be overwhelming, however our server did a great job describing how the menu worked and the different types of pizza. Wish I remembered his name because he was really great. If management is reading this.. he was young, light brown hair with glasses. We enjoyed the most recently awarded pizza the Porto which was so very good. I'm hungry just thinking about it. Also of note, the cocktails here are very good as well! Noisy boy was my favorite- light and refreshing.. perfect for a warm sunny day here in SF.

Great pizza, loved the variety.
Do yourself a favor and check in on yelp and get on the waitlist.

Delicious pizza and salad!  Worth the trip up the hill from fisherman's Wharf....a short hungry walk up the hill and a full belly walk down the hill.  We will definitely hit this spot up every time we are in San Francisco!!  It gets busy but it's worth the wait....

This place had a pot of hype around it, and it exceeded our very high expectations. We got the Giant Meatball and the award winning Margherita Neapolitan style pizza. Both were absolutely incredible! The pizza was very light and airy, and the meatball was incredibly flavorful. However, if you are expecting to get a slice with a firm, crunchy crust, that is NOT what this style of pizza is. Neapolitan is supposed to have a fluffy crust with a somewhat wet center, so complaints about the pizza's 'soggyness' are a reflection on customer preference, and not the pizza's preparation. Luckily, they have a tone of different pizza styles if you don't like Neapolitan style. We sat at the bar, and the bar tender was very attentive and friendly. Great experience at Tony's!!

One of the best Margherita pizza I have had. Our cab driver had suggested this place . Once we reached there for lunch we were asked to wait for over an hour luckily they had empty chairs at the bar . But hey the pasta and pizza were great . They have limited vegetarian selection thou.

It was a 30-45 min wait for 3 at 4:30 pm on a Sunday. We ordered a few drinks at the bar, which were pretty enjoyable.
- Bernardino Cobbler: a delicious fruity drink, on the sweeter side
- Noisy Boy: refreshing spicy drink
We were seated at a booth next to the oven. It was getting a bit hot in there.
We ordered:
- Meatball Gigante: Wild Mushroom, Pancetta, Cream Sauce - by far the best meatball I've ever had. So freaken delicious. Melts in your mouth.
- Cheesy Garlic Bread: so yummy, it comes with marinara sauce but we were dipping it in the leftover creamy/marinara meatball sauce.
- Chorizo Mussels: the dish was also cooked in a similar marinara sauce. This is when the food started tasting one dimensional based on the similar sauces.
- Margherita Pizza: looks delicious but was burnt. Everytime I took a bite, my tongue tasted the bitter char on the bottom of the pizza. This was the most disappointing item for the evening.
- Spaghetti and Meatball: again the meatballs were on point.
Would definitely return for the Meatballs!
Good stuff indeed, but it doesn't come close to Zachary's.

The best Chicago style pizza in the Bay, even better than Zachary's in my book.  The cornmeal crust was already enough to swing my vote, but I also have a strong preference for their sauce.  It's not as overwhelmingly tomato-ey.  I wish they were open earlier on the weekends, and there can definitely be a wait, but the pizza is the best. I've been to this location and the one in the Mission, and much prefer this location even though it's further away, just has a better vibe and had a better service experience here.  The service is minimal, but they're cool peeps, and I don't need a ton of attention in a pizza joint.
still the best pie in the city. nuff said
This place was great. The deep dish classic pizza was amazing. Don't miss the garlic bread. We'll be back soon to sample more of their menu.
omg, thee best jukebox evar!!11!1!!
Best and most likely most fattening pizza in town.  Their deep dish cheese w/ the sauce on top is amazing....oh so good.
Best deep dish pizza. Great crust. Freshly made so be prepared to wait, but definitely worth it.
Little Star Deep Dish pizza is solid. It's a good choice is you're craving deep dish pizza.
Worst Pizza I have had in a long,long time....Chicken wings were disgusting!!!!!  I'd rather eat DiGiorno and buy crap from CostCo

Let me preface this review by stating that I am one of the millions of asians out there that have a wee bit of a dairy allergy. Translation: I am in no way a connessieur of pizza. However, I've been known to suffer the consequences now and then (or take some Lactaid pills) to enjoy a nice slice of pie. And I've heard such rave reviews of this place that I just had to put my food allergies aside and check it out. What I really appreciated was that they were more than happy to make my thin crust pesto-chicken pizza with minimal cheese so that I didn't leave the place with massive abdomonal pain and/or nausea = we could go out to bars after dinner. And I really appreciate that. I went to dinner with a couple of friends, and included in the trio is a vegetarian. So needless to say, when searching for dinner venues we're confined to those that accommodate vegetarians and the lactose-intolerant. And here, all three palates were happily fed. The pizza was delicious, the prices more than reasonable, and the service was superb. I'm definitely going back there again!

Golden Boy Pizza can best be described as Little Caesar's with quality ingredients. It's no-frills, it's convenient, and it satisfies on a small budget. Don't expect wood-fire or deep-dish goodness here; other than some fancy toppings like pesto and garlic, this one's strictly by the books.

i don't get the hype?

seniores is better, so is gaspares, and village pizza.

its good, probably amazing when you're wasteyface, but i dunno man, i would never crave it.
Golden boy is god, bow before him. Fcuk off all other pizza. This coast sucks (other than g boi).

While in San Fran on our way up the coast we Yelped ideas for lunch. So glad this spot was at the top of the list.

Everyone working there was friendly as were the customers sitting at the bar. Service was quick and ordering is simple. They are cash only so keep that in mind. We tried a few different slices and they were all delicious. Their crust is AMAZING.

The building is fun! Stickers and posters cover every inch of the walls and bathroom. Even with all the graffiti it seemed very clean.

One of the best pizza places I've been to in the Bay Area. The taste from those squared slices is unique and keeps you wanting more. This place is also super affordable! Beware: the line could get a little long, and you might not be able to find a seat inside, so be patient. It's all worth it though!

Good but not great I was suprised to see so many good reviews.  Pizza was good but not a good as a Chicago pizza.  Took it to go so maybe the expirience would ha e been better is we stayed but it was imposable to get 6 seats  near each other.
Wandered across this place while visiting San Fran. Pizza was great! Small place but fun hangout. Servers were fun to look at too!

Stopped here because I was craving pizza. There are quite a few pizza places in the area. It's a walk up and order with only about 5 choices of pizzas, but I went simple and got the pepperoni. It was extremely tasty! They make sure you get a hot piece and the customer service was surprisingly good for it being so busy. We stood and ate in the back until a stool opened up. My pizza craving was satisfied!

Cash only. There was a small line at 630 on a Sunday evening but totally worth it! Tiny place but there's some seating at the bar. Pesto veggie pizza was delicious! Going back to try the cheese for sure

Hands down one of the best pizza I've had. I got the cheese and veggie pesto and it Was off the hook. The crust was airy/crispy and the ingridents were fresh. Can't beat the awesome tap lineup either, I   had an ice cold Freshed squeezed IPA to wash it down. Two slices and a beer was $12. Can't beat it.

Most satisfying experience if your looking for something that is delicious & tasty, I definitely recommend getting the New Yorker! Each bite is filled with the intense flavors of what a true pizza lovers dream of.

The meatball appietizers are amazing. Definitely the show stopper. The wait if worth it; however, they need a.c. we went the only weekend sf was over 100 degrees. The service was ok. We had the margharita pizza (limited #). It was just ok. A little too soggy. We also ordered the carbonara. Not exciting at all. There are plenty of other pizzas we want to try, so we will be back. And did I mention the meatballs!

Well it's our first night back in San Francisco and we are taken by our guests to a wonderful l pizza restaurant in the heart of Little Italy. Wow, as the photo shows and whole flatbread pizza can barely be eaten by four guests. I don't know the name of the pizza, but it was delicious. And we sat out until dusk chatting and eating.

This is most definitely my favorite pizza place ever! If you're going to spoil your taste buds, this is the place to do it.  The pizza is tender and the sauce, toppings and cheese blend together in a way that feels and tastes like a dream. I don't think there is a better Italian place in this universe. You'll never want to eat pizza anywhere else after you go here.

Come hungry because they serve a lot of food and it can be heavy (it's hearty pizza). The service was exceptionally good--our server made everything personal and was extremely attentive, but not like creepy attentive.

I went with the New Yorker pizza and some cheesy garlic garlic bread. This can be more than enough for 2 mildly hungry people. The New Yorker is a top seller and it's no wonder why when you try it. It packs lots of flavor and taste without the hints of processed food.

There is a special Margarita pizza on the menu where they have enough dough to only make 73 of them. They can make a similar Margarita pizza but it won't be using the exclusive/limited dough that's enough for only so many pies. Obviously, if you want this, you have to come when it opens. Do you think it's very American to only want it because it's limited and you'll do what it takes to get it?

At any rate, as one of the most popular places for pizza in North Beach, I think they live up to the hype and their product is very good. I like how they have different ovens that cook at different temperatures and the servers know something or two about the pizza.

If you're in a group of more than 2-4, good luck getting a spot to sit during peak eating hours. They do not take reservations so be prepared for a wait. But don't worry there's like 50 bars in the area and you can leave your phone number.

Warning: Possible hour long wait no matter what time you arrive. But worth it. Don't come hungry.

I love all the options they provide including appetizers, pastas and salads.

Tonight we ordered the calamari appetizer which can be shared between 4 people. The little Italy salad was also quite large but delicious. The quail egg pizza was perfectly thin with burrata.

The last time we came, we had a quail black truffle pizza and the gigante. The gigante was a bit heavy but delicious.

I will happily return to try the other pizzas!

Wanted to try Tony's because it got such good review.  So, my hubby and I walked there on a beautiful day and sat at the bar.  We ordered the margarita pizza because the menu said they only serve so many per day.  So it has to be great, right?  When it came out, it was not only burnt, but it was cold.  It was something similar to what a child would serve from an easy bake oven.  And it was $23.  Needless to say we were very disappointed.  Other food around us looked good.  But we weren't as lucky.
Came for lunch, and to keep things concise it was authentic, decadent and absolutely delicious. Highly recommend trying the carbonara!

First there was an hour and a half wait. This was a Saturday at 7pm. The great thing is that they will call you when your table is ready. So we hit a wine bar around the corner and took in more of the North Beach character.

Once called the only bad thing about Tony's is trying to choose the best pie. So we. Tried the meatball appetizer and it was great. Finally settled for the New Yorker and it was phenomenal. Lots of fresh toppings, perfectly cooked thin crust and loaded with flavor. Fresh bread with multiple dipping sauces was served as a free appetizer.

Can't wait to go back!

Overpriced pizza and 45 minute wait- not worth it. We had the margherita pizza and the new yorker. The gentleman working at the front had an unpleasant attitude. For pizza i would rather go to calzone's - 5 minute walk

This place is a nice complement to the other place we ate at in the area (Cafe Baonecci) on this trip.  This is purely a pizza place and does a thicker style pizza that's thicker/heavier.  It's pretty unique.  You can order by the slice (about $3.50-$3.75 a slice) and you'll probably need 2 slices for lunch.

The selection of pizzas is a lot more limited but I have to say, you MUST try the clam and garlic one.  Yes it sounds weird, but the combination of tastes and the tasty crust underneath was absolutely delicious!

Clam and garlic?  On a pizza?  Ok, I'll try it...and I'm glad I did.  The flavors of the garlic, cheese, parsley, and clam worked it's magic coming together on top of a fluffy foccacia bread crust.  Perfect with a nice cold brew or to soak up your brew.  At $3.75 a slice it's cheap eats for sure.  Be prepared to stand in line, but it's so worth the wait!

One of my favorite post- going out pizza joints.

Garlic clam parsley pizza and the mixed veggie pizza- win.

*The simultaneous crunchy/soft crust is the best part.

The line gets long after 1:00AM so come before the bars close to avoid them. Not much seating in there and if you do, you'll be awkwardly facing the wall or the oven while you and your friends sit in a line. :)

-HungryHungryPongy

Fantastic pizza! The Sicilian style slice is hard to get ahold of in California and these guys are just great! The clam and garlic is probably their signature, I always get at least one slice of it. The sausage is also excellent and you get a big slice for only a few dollars. They also have a good beer selection. It's not a big place but it has lots of character. Also be careful when you first touch your slice because it's super hot!
I like the light crust on focaccia bread and the easy square portions and the variety of toppings and a favorite for sure.... YUM!!!!!!!!!!!
Great local spot with a lot of flavor, good price for a slice a pizza on the go in Little Italy.
Delicious pizza! Crust can be a bit doughy, but flavors are fantastic. I've eaten here before and after a night out and both times were equally fantastic. Can't wait to return to Golden Boy Pizza!
Some of the tastiest damn pizza I have ever had!  The clam pizza rocks, friendly service and definitely worth a short wait in line.

i love love love this place!!!  another reason to drive forty-five minutes to the city!  i dont come to the city for shopping, just the food.  I've never had a DELICIOUS square shaped pizza until four years ago when he first took me here.  

i don't normally like thick crust pizza, but this is an acception!  i hate pan pizzas because the extra dough right underneath the toppings taste under cook and it grosses me out... but not here!!  crisp, light, yummy.  oh my.  

the walls are entertaining with all the pictures and stuff too.

So far, this is my favorite pizza in San Francisco.

Thick crust with fun toppings and oh so yummy. Yum.
not bad deep dish- not overly cheesy or greasy, but the crust was surprisingly dry and thin; pretty cornmealy.  most importantly, arrive EARLY- they fill up fast.  open at 5 on wkends.

This truly is some unique and amazing pizza. Definitely more of a date restaurant than a pizza joint and the price reflects that. The deep dish is very deep (the two of us only managed to cram down half of a large pie), the corn bread style crust is revolutionary, and I love the sauce on top style. I also love the fact that the drink selection is cheap and reasonably priced. I HATE restaurants that overcharge for drinks, I go for the food not to pay $3 for a coke or $6 for a beer and Little Star understands that. My only complaints, which are by no means reasons not to go there, are that there could be a little more variety on their "specialty" pizzas, I would expect some more unique ingredients and combinations out of a place like this and the second would be that the sauce could use a little work. Maybe it was just the day that I was there but the sauce struck me as a little too tart, perhaps undercooked, and not salty sweet like I like my pizza sauce. But I'm getting into the nitty gritty here, a lot of which is personal preference. I will be back.

Long-ass wait for a table last Thursday, but KILLER cornmeal, deep-dish crust.  Where have you been all my SF-life?  I didn't have a pizza hang-over like when you eat deep-dish in Chi-town (my privilege for 4 years at Uni), that over-carb-ed, over-cheezed buzzy feeling.  It's deep-dish that has been Californ-ized with that NorCal water in the crust.  We had the Little Star and the thin-crust White Pizza (not that great, by the way).  I also have to say that "White Pizza" is called "white" according to some folks back in NY because NOT ONLY is the creamy base ricotta (and maybe some garlic) instead of RED sauce (See?  White!), but it also does not contain ANY red items.  A little basil chiffonade, some cracked black pepper I've seen, but not really chopped tomatoes.  That's missing the point, I believe.  Also, white pizza is not license to slap on the cheese- it's kindof a delicate balance.  So, thumbs up on the cornmeal crust, beer selection, champagne cocktails and the NOPA hipster code (i.e. black tees)  that's just shy of pretentious and thumbs down on the "white" pizza and the wait.  I heard the owners are young, so I guess there's  room for improvement.

little star has the best chicago style pizza! yummmm.. The place is a little hard to find since its stuck between big houses but trust me once you walk in, you'll forget all about your worries. the place has a nice atmosphere. dim and clubby feel and a little tight in space. gets kinda loud at some parts but its okay when you're chowing down those delicious pizzas.

good, solid san francisco pizza place. best deep dish in the city for sure. it takes a while to get it but that's mostly because they're always slammed. the specialty pizzas are pretty good, though you can't go wrong with building your own. again, deep dish is the way to go. best to go ahead of dinner rush if you want any chance of getting a table

damn, didn't realize this place had so many reviews! if you love deep dish style pizza, you'll definitely want to try this place out! parking isn't easy, and sometimes the wait can be long. but if you can, just grab a seat at the bar area...

Came here famished on a Saturday night.  Circled the area for 15 minutes with my friend, until we finally realized that maybe I should at least put our names on the waitlist... did that, then circled the area for another 15 minutes looking for a spot. Parked. Went in and waited for another 20-25 minutes. The hostess was very nice, and came over to us to give us updates on our table every so often. We get seated finally - waitress brings over water, we put in our order for garlic bread and their special for the night - Large thin-crust pizza with pancetta, arugula, mozarella and fontina cheese. The bread came out fairly quickly, was OK - it's french bread (very soft, yum) served with a tiny bowl of butter and huge bunch of garlic cloves you spread on yourself. The pizza was good, but reeeally salty cos of the pancetta - so I ended up taking all the pancetta off.. but other than that, was pretty good... didn't like the crust very much, ended up not eating it. The waitress was very attentive and nice.  She even sliced the 3rd slice of pizza in half so we could split it evenly for our take-out boxes, haha.  With my glass of sauvignon blanc and my friend's ginger beer, the bill came out to be around $40 - so $20 per person, not too bad... I'm not sure if I'd come back here anytime soon cos of the long wait, and the pizza didn't blow my mind. Too harsh? Sorry..

best deep dish i ever had since i had it in chicago! it just takes forever to get seated and they dont take reservations so get there early!! it also takes forever to get the pizza after you sit down and order it so if you're hungry, order some appetizers because you'll be waiting long! lol ... the place is tiny and cramped.. its a dark "romantic" place i guess but its so cramped and tiny that you're practically eating w/ the stranger next to you so dont go there with huge groups or else you'll be waiting DAYS to get seated.. its a cute place to go with just a date or a few people... but anyways .. the pizza- AMAZING!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! any flavor no matter what.. even if it sounds gross... i guarantee you will LOVE it! like normally i dont like anchovies or onions or spinach on normal pizza.. but somehow, they know how to make these things taste better than cheesecake!! lol
dining in romantic low lighting and deep dish pizza. i think i recall the food being ok but not amazing.

Excellent pizza and customer service the best pizza in sf ! I will def return I would highly recommend this pizza place! It would be even better if it was brick oven I'm not as easy person to please so that should tell you they earned this review

Planning a trip back to west coast and Im thinking- "yea, what was that slice I dogged out there late nite, stuff was good, why cant you pump gas in Oregon, it had a big neon finger, multi variable calculus, good cheese and tasty spices"

So I search yelp and YES, got it! This place is great, very happy to find a tasty, unique slice on the West Coast. After treading through the rest of the state to find a regular pizzeria with a good slice, figures that it takes me to Joe D's hometown to find it.
