Pizza with great sauce, great cheese, and service is efficient.  No, they're not that fast, but they try to be and they are super friendly!

I had the cheese, since it was my first time and I wanted to make sure that the base was good, and it was great!  Next time, I'll order a few slices... XD  Dough = perfect consistency.  If you're looking for thin, this is not the place for it.  However, if you want good dough, fresh flavors, and just delicious stuff--this is IT!

Seating = limited.  I stood outside and enjoyed my fresh slice, instead of trying to cram inside the place.  

Prices = reasonable. (My slice was $2.75, the specialty slices are around $3.75 to $4.00)  Cash only!

Five Stars
Maybe this isn't a fair review because I've only been here after a night out.. But awesome pizza and fast-enough service! Can't beat them squares.

Tips and Fun Facts
Cheese-licious in every bite, for real. Vegetarian friend loved it here.

If you want thick, cheesy, topping-laden pizza then this is your place. If you're in North Beach and want a quick bite then this is definitely your place.

I've eaten the pizza here both sober and not. Tasted about the same either way. At least they offer plenty of pieces without crust in their large sheet pizzas. Sure, an inside slice is a little messier to eat, but the topping bonus more than makes up for it.

I have had pizza at 2 places in SOMA and this is the best. (The other forgettable bite was on Broadway)

PROS
- The price is right, slices $2.75-3.75
- Options- cheese, pepperoni, veggie, and clam and garlic!
- Note: Clam and garlic will leave u w/ garlic breath. Enjoy w/ platonic pizza partners
-  not TOO much cheese, and generous amount of sauce
- Since it's so popular, every slice is fresh and warm

CONS
- Cash only
- Skater boi music
- Long line (20-40 minute wait is normal)
- Not a lot of sitting room

This place was suggested by my buddy. It was an interesting punk pizza parlor. The pizza was cheap and really good. I went with the Clam and garlic, as suggested by the server. It wasn't bad. Not as flavorful as I expected, but then again, do clams really have much flavor? They taste like whatever sauce they're in, just a bit saltier and chewier. Anyway, it was good. My friend got some sort of multi-veggie slice, which was great - full of flavor. Thumbs up to free refills of soda.
And the pizza server was really pretty cool. It's actually unbelievable how cheap it was!

Great reviews, but definitely not the best pizza place I've been too.  Great service, really tiny place, but the pizza was nothing special.  The pizza itself was pretty heavy with oil, but the plus was the fresh ingredients.  I feel this place is rated a little too high.
Cheese squares and IPA is my power lunch.

OMG. Clam and garlic pizza, is there anything else to say?!

Where in the city can you get this in SQUARE form and on focaccia?! Nowhere (that I know of)!!!

My sister said she got two slices the last time she came here, so I happily ordered two slices for myself. She failed to mention that she only finished one and took the second slice to go! They are pretty large slices and they are hearty so it filled me up easily.

The clam and garlic pizza was SO delicious. I mean you have to be a fan of clams and garlic or it'll be completely disgusting, but it wasn't to me! It was incredibly delicious.

We got the sausage, pepperoni and combo slices as well. The Combo is totally worth it. They toss everything on there. The pepperoni and sausage were pretty laughable, only because the number of pepperoni on her "pepperoni" slice was 4 and her sausage slice also had four sausages as well. Why so skimpy on the meat but yet the combo is FILLED completely with toppings? So weird.

Otherwise, the parking sucks here... it's North Beach/borderline Chinatown so what do you really expect? The pizza is totally worth the trip!

If only work was a little bit closer, I can see that slice of clam and garlic pizza in my life on a weekly basis!

Sensational slices of Sicilian pizza here. I was hyptonized first by the fact that Golden Boy has a window display of piping hot pizzas from their deck ovens. Walking past the narrow bar stool alley and situating myself in the rear while I waited for my friends, I was further hypnotized by the two chefs in the back going through the tedious routine of preparing dough, rotating pizzas currently in the oven, and slicing up finished pizzas.

The dough preparation had a beautiful cadence to it, and a good sign that this is pizza worth a damn. When not preparing dough, the preparers would use nothing but a chef's knife and a towel to rotate the scorching hot pizza pan without so much of a though at burning their hands. Given my fear of burning myself in a toaster oven, I would fail miserably at this feat.

At last, my party joined me and we prepared to indulge in some slices. After watching the preparers for the good part of 10 minutes like some starving creep, I proceeded to order 4 slices, doubling up on the works and rounding out my order with a pepperoni and a pesto slice. Why only 4? I had eaten dinner only two hours prior, and despite declaring myself as "stuffed," one snack during into a second dinner.

Well, screw any remorse, because after my server provided me with four fresh slices of pizza and I took my first bite, holy hell was I in heaven. First of all, the Sicilian is just the perfect canvas for some quality low-moisture mozzarella, and Golden Boy matches that perfectly. The cheese marries the golden, crispy and doughy crust and sends you into pizza bliss, with each bite taking you closer to a culinary climax leaving you wanting more.

The pepperoni was exceptional, with the perfect amount of sliced, rounded meat in every bite. The works was phenomenal too, just bursting with flavor without stealing the show from the marvelous cheese or crust. As for the pesto, I expected a little more basil flavor, but still enjoyed it enough to dream of my return to Golden Boy. Next time, I'm ordering a full pan and will eat it all.
my mouth says yes, my thighs say don't be a fatty mcfatterson fat.  it's so damn good but hard to stop eating even when you're full after the first piece.  friendly staff and decent prices.  eat it.

Yes, Little Star definitely gets 5 BIG stars in my book. We were in the mood for some thick ass deep dish pizza so, naturally, we left our decision up to the yelpers, and, obv, we were not disappointed. On the outside- this place kind of looks like a hole, but step inside and you'll find a sweet little place that looks like IKEA has decided to design restaurants. We couldn't get a table right away so we got a drink at the bar. The bartender gave us his attention immediately and we exchanged friendly and humorous banter while we waited. After we sat down at our table the waitress came and took our order. She was super nice and gave us her recommendations. A friendly staff is so key for me and I was glad to see that they weren't another pretentious restaurant with employees that think they're too cool for school. We ordered a salad and the Little Star deep dish (such a clutch decision- thanks waitress!). They say it takes around 30 minutes to cook the pizza but it sure didn't seem like it. Once it got to our table, talking ceased and the grubbing began. The pizza was cooked perfectly and we were incredibly satisfied when we were finished. I've never been to Chicago but something tells me that when I go to eat pizza there, I'll have something to compare it against. Thanks, Little Star!
oh em gee. had the deep dish and i can not give less than 5 stars. i'm not gonna say it's better than zachary's, but i had absolutely no room (hahaaaa no pun intended) for complaints.

We went on a friday nite around 10 and it was really crowded so we got it to go.  The 30 minute wait for the deep dish to go was worth it!!  Despite walking down the street eating the deep dish w/ my drunk eyes half open, the pizza was amazing.  It wasn't too wet from the veggies the way that Zach's or Paxti's gets wet:( The crust was crispy, not too doughy, and sauce was really good.  Unfortunately it's not open for lunch on the weekends, but I'll be back again sober w/ my eyes fully open to fully enjoy this great pizza!

Best pizza ever!!  Totally worth the 45 minute wait for a table.  We had the chicken pesto thin crust and the classic deep dish...both perfection in their own way.  I am still full from tonight and can not wait to go back.  Loving the fact that we live so close.  Good bye to all the crappy pizza chains as we will never be ordering from you again!!!!

more like a 4.3.  

i'm a ny pizza guy, but enjoy any pizza if it's good.  deep dish pizza that isn't pretentious.  we got a large half classic and half little star.  the little half was the shiznizzle and the classic was ok.  it really wasn't that expensive considering that we could have had 4 people share it easy.  we also got a small pizza and b/c we came early enough (thanks to you yelpers who made us paranoid about the wait), beers were a dollar off.  our total bill with tip was 40 bucks.  delicious and i will be back.

Good pizza.  I prefer the thin crust, but even their deep dish is pretty decent.  Good beer selection too.  Huge positive is that when you're done eating, there are usually cabs in the neighborhood which is pretty clutch in SF.

This place is awesome, and has greattttttt pizza! Def the best I have eaten out in Frisco by far. The place is cool and chill and has a good ambiance. Staff is friendly and they provide great service. Def will go again! I'm salavating justing thinking about the Pizza! :)
I'm a bit biased because i'm not a fan of deep dish pizza.

Excellent deep dish pizza- the crust has a nice crispiness and there's loads of tomatoes and oozy cheese on the pizza!!  I liked the sausage and veggie versions :)  The wine list is simple but good. The service was good.  The prices are a tad high, but the pizza's quality is top notch!!

Pizza to my face.

That's pretty much all I wanted around 11am on a Sunday morning. Connecting brilliant ideas with brilliant actions, a couple friends and I decided to finally try Tony's after 6+ years living in the Bay Area and *still* not having tried it.

Game plan:
- Drive to Tony's. Utilize friend's handicap parking permit to outwit the parking apocalypse that is North Beach. Check.
- Arrive by noon to evade long lines and wait times. Actual arrival time 12:20pm. Opt for 0 minute wait option and eat outside. Check.
- Order the infamous limited-to-73-pies-a-day edition Margherita Pizza and seek out recs for other pizzas from our server. Result: Orders of the New Yorker and Detroit Style Red Hot. Check, check, check.
- Order more "limited edition" menu options - aka Meatballs Gigante with Sea Salted Buratta. X2. Duh.

Overall our weekend lunch at Tony's was superb. Three completely different styles of pie gave us a real range in our pizza experience. The floppy and light Margherita was my personal fav (I have a weakness for a simple Margh). The group in general loved the selection of hearty and spiced meats on the New Yorker on a thicker crust. Finally the Detroit Style was another change of pace with square slices of a thick, garlicy buttered crust and generous amount of cheese. All great in their own way!

Good pizza, but the classic pizza was not classic Italian for me.. Had the classic Italian, which did not quite remind me of my daily pizza in Italy.  Maybe it's the water? I could devour an entire Italian pizza anywhere in Italy, not just Naples (which I have tried too) no way I could have eaten the entire classic with proschuitto.  Italian pizzas to me are Airy and light.

Looks like I have to come back for the Napoletana.

The bartenders were good, and the drinks were good, but best of luck to find a seat.

Ciao, alla prossima

Been here a couple of times now and haven't been disappointed. They actually do better at various regional pizzas than the Italian ones in my opinion. The Saint Louis style pizza is truly authentic and somehow better than I've ever had in Saint Louis. All the ingredients are quality. Without reservations I can easily say this is the best pizza in SF.

Went there last night and loved it! They don't take reservations and even on a weeknight, the wait was long! But thankfully I got on the Yelp waitlist, and only had to wait about 15 minutes after checking in. Highly recommend getting on the waitlist -- some people just walked in and the wait was 1.5 hrs.

We ordered their award-winning Margherita Pizza and the Pasta Genovese. The pizza was good, authentic Italian pizza. But I wish they had more diverse vegetarian options with more veggies. All of their vegetarian pizzas were essentially variations of the Margherita pizza. Also there were only 6 thin-crust slices, and the pizza was $24 so definitely pricey and we were still hungry.

Thankfully, we had also ordered the pasta which was extremely filling. Fresh, house-made pasta made to perfection! Absolutely loved it.

Overall, the food was delicious, but the restaurant could have more vegetarian options. Also it was extremely pricey -- for two of us, the total came out to $62 for just two entrees (no appetizers, drinks, dessert).

We arrived without a reservation on a Thursday night with 6 people. Forget it, most people would have said. The hostess was very accommodating though and assured us we would have a table with an hour. We gave our cell # since they have a notification system (just make sure you respond within 5 min!) and went to the North Beach bar up the street for some drinks. Came back for another drink in the jam-packed bar and boom, table ready.  As Carles says, "Let's get to it!"

What kinda place only serves a limited number of their signature dishes each day? A damned good one, that's for sure. We got 3 of the day's 73 margherita pizzas and they were fantastic. Big slices of mozzarella and a sweet sauce - tastes just like home (well, almost - home unfortunately doesn't have an awesome wood-fire oven).

And the mussels. Oh my god the mussels. They has a chorizo sauce on them that was just amazing. We even got the non-carnivore in the group to eat these things and he said how amazing they were.

idk abt our waiter, but i gotta say our pizza we ordered was hella fucking bomb. i always order ranch and wait for it to get to the table to start eating, nah bruh, i ate the whole thing, scratch that i devour that shiii

Literally knew nothing about this joint. Just googled "Best Pizza in North Beach" and this came up. Took a buddy here on a Saturday around five. We totally got lucky and were seated within 35 minutes.

Ordinarily I don't wait to be seated. This was the best wait experience. They literally will text you when your table is getting ready and you have plenty of time to get there. On top of that, tech savvy people will follow the text link which tells you how many people are ahead of you. A+ for managing demanding crowds.

The pies speak for themselves. Michelin rating well deserved. Shared a pie with my buddy. Soooooo good. This place lives up to the hype. Totally respect the craft!

As stated in my other reviews, I am a non-fancy looking Asian guy.  So when an individual such as myself come by around the richer by the day North Beach area, especially to a restaurant, you kind of begin to expect not to be taken seriously.  

However, I must say, my experience at Tony's Pizza was great!  We went during the evening hours and the wait was about an hour.  After providing our name to wait for a table, they offered to text us when our table was ready.  Once we sat down, our waitress (who was very nice and professional) took our orders.  I ordered a Stramboli and for the price, it was amazing.  The pizza we ordered was HUGE!  I was quite surprised at the size of their portions (which is great!).  

The space is not the biggest as half the restaurant is a bar, and there are several booths for those with larger than 2 groups.  However, it's well worth the wait.

The staff here is friendly, and treated us very well.  I can appreciate an establishment where non-fancy looking individuals such as myself is treated with respect.

We had a group of 5 on a Saturday night, so we had to wait 3 hours for a table. I didn't think it was anywhere near worth that. I mean, the pizza is pretty tasty, but there really are LOTS of places around SF where you can get top-notch pizza and don't have to deal with the ridiculous situation this place has going.

The fact that they're so popular really cuts down on the experience. Even after the 3 hour wait, we continued to have problems. They were out of quite a few items, including the margarita (except for the suboptimal dough version, LAME). We were also told that we had just one shot at ordering. So no ordering a few more pies if we decided we were still hungry.

One of the 4 pizzas we ordered was truly spectacular (the Jersey). The others were okay, but really could have been way better. The one I was the most excited about, The Barcelona, was downright mediocre.

I really don't get the hype around this place, and its popularity really kills the fun.

Horrible service!  The food is ok but we are never going there again. They told us we had an hour wait and since we had no other plans for the day, we agreed.  An hour and thirty minutes later, they called us to a table that was outside in the rain.  Not under an umbrella or over hang.  In the direct RAIN.  Water was pouring on the table.  We refused to sit and asked to sit inside.  The rude, unprofessional manager said we would need to be now at the bottom of the wait list.  We couldn't believe it and they didn't care, so we left.

The fact that this is so highly rated makes me really pessimistic that there's actually good pizza in SF.  Sorry, I'm from the Northeast where there's no excuse for bad pizza.  I know there's tons of East Coast transplants here so I still have some hope that something either exists already or finally will someday.

That said, this place isn't bad, so long as theres no line, and there always is.

Hit or miss. Sometimes they make the pizzas really savory and there are a few times when the taste of the bread fell flat. I think the dough/bread makes or breaks a pizza.  Sometimes also, there's not enough topping so I feel like I'm just eating flavored bread. I'm not sure whether the times I thought their pizzas were really good was because I was extremely drunk....but it seems to frequently happen that way. I love it when I luck out and get a slice that was really new. You could tell if it's a brand new pizza when the bread is very fluffy and the meat toppings are still juicy.

Usually if you go later in the evening, when the drunk monkeys are stumbling out of the bars, the line is obnoxiously long and there's nowhere to sit inside. When the line is really long, I try to avoid this place because in my opinion it is definitely not worth the wait. If you don't mind standing in the cold to satisfy your drunken munchies, it is worth a try.  Well....at least once.

I'll tell you why this pizza joint does so well VS the rest of the options in North Beach.
Drunks and Freshly made melted cheese.
Yes while the other joints make  a bunch of pies than let them dry up in their window golden boy is always baking pies one at a time and bringing them out hot.  The pizza is good but is not a 5 star pizza like the rest of the drunks here claim. lol

Best. Pizza. Ever.

My friend took me here after a late night of drinking and I remember thinking the next morning that the pizza was delicious but it must have been a case of the drunken munchies.

It isn't. I have had pizza from Golden Boy several more times since then and every time it delivers on all levels. Herbs baked into the dough, perfectly melted cheese, flavorful sauce, great toppings.

The line is indeed long at the later hours but it is worth the wait. Decently priced as well and worth the money.

This was on the Foodie food tour and it was our last stop.

After a full day of eating, we were all given a choice of any 1 slice of pizza. I had the... gosh I dont remember the name but it had everything on it. There was just about every veggie you could imagine, also very cheesy. mmm

I will be honest I am not the biggest fan of pizza, unless I make my homemade pizza, with everything homemade. Well I must say, I actually enjoyed this pizza. I would maybe like the dough to be a little softer... maybe I was just too full at the point when I was eating the pizza.

The place was packed, we barely found a stool to sit on. There was a lot of people standing in the back. If you are planning a visit, I would maybe take it to go, expect to get very friendly with strangers.

I've been wanting to try this spot to see what all the rave is about. I tried the famous clam garlic & combo and they're both very good. The clam garlic is very garlicy so if you love garlic like I do you will definitely enjoy it. Is it the best pizza I've had? No but if you're craving pizza and want to grab something good and quick with a cold beer on the side, this is a perfect spot.

Yes, it's cheap and yes the staff & music are great. But the pizza itself is doughy, chewy but not very tasty. The best one was clam & garlic but the cheese one or combination ones were a letdown. Got to Baonecci or Sotto Mare instead, a bit pricier but it's a more genuine real Italian experience.

This is my favorite pizza in San Francisco. I think it's better than most pizza's I've tried across the United States. It a focaccia style pizza. They have a combo, vegetarian, clam & garlic, cheese, sausage and pepperoni. It's about $4 a slice, cash only. It is well worth the wait.

went today and had a combo slice! amazing! hands down  the music was blasting the ballgame was on the big screen it was crowded but everyone was doing their own thing. After all it is San Francisco! had that slice washed it down with Dr Pepper and headed to get my tattoo next-door at Tattoo Bugaloo ! awesome times!
Best pizza in town the bread they use is fluffy and the pizza slices are huge very filling this is my new favorite pizza spot by far fresh ingredients!
Authentic Chicago style pizza. The Italian is perfection at its very best. Better than Patxi's. Not as good as Zach's. Go here. Eat. Be happy.
This is the best deep dish pizza around. The tomatoes on top aren't overly tart, it's perfect. Plus the cornmeal crust ensures that it won't come out soggy. Must try.

Totally dig their deep dish and their crust. Normally I'm someone who leaves the crust behind, or give it to my dog, but not Little Star's! Like their menu and service is fairly nice. Bit of a scene to get seated there though.
Wow - amazing pizza!  We went for the deep dish and it certainly lived up to the hype.
Seriously good pizza with a cornmeal crust.  Amusing 80s pop always on the stereo.

I don't want to pose as the World's Greatest Expert on Chicago-style deep dish pizza, but my credentials are pretty good. I'm in my early fifties, so I come from the era when you were either an Uno's family, a Due's family, or a Gino's/Giordano's family. We were Due's fans. Then Uno's sold out to corporate interests, Due's faded, and Lou Malnati opened up his place across the street from my house back in 1971. The Brian Piccolo Foundation fundraisers and the fairly constant stream of Bears and Cubs and Blackhawks (defenseman Eric Nesterenko was another neighbor) spurred the popularity of Malnati's, but it was the pizza that made it a legend. And the family - Lou and Jean and Marc and Rick are just good people. It was nice to be in their place, they made you feel welcome.

So, like every Chicagoan, I get my jones for some of the Real Thing. I had been to Zachary's and Patxi's, and then I started hearing about Little Star, and reading all the praise here. I went there the other day and ordered the Chicago classic: sausage and onions and bell peppers and mushrooms, and, as is my habit, substituted black olives for mushrooms.

There's no doubt that this is the genuine article. No prefab Uno's, no "what the hell is THIS" Pizz'a Chicago nonsense (and can we please punish the advertising mastermind who came up with that ridiculous spelling of "pizza"?) , this is a real Chicago-style deep-dish pizza. And it's a thuddingly average specimen. The crust has little too much cornmeal, it's more oily than buttery and flaky. Mine was perfectly done, but it seems like it would burn pretty easily in another minute, and that it would reheat much too tough. (It did toughen too much when reheated. Notable fail - one of the essential joys of the Real Thing is that it reheats well. I spent one summer hanging with friends, most of whom worked at Malnati's or at Gabby Hartnett's Bowling Alley across Lincoln Avenue. We'd bowl and close the alley, then go across to Lou's. Lou would give whoever was working a break to sit down with us; he'd often join us himself. We'd order whatever we wanted, and when the bill came, it would be for one medium cheese. And when Lou learned that I lived across the street, he'd always make sure I took home the leftovers. "What, you got somewhere else to go so fast you can't drop this off at home first?" I had leftover Malnati's for lunch at least twice a week all that summer. Rest in peace, Lou; you were a sweet man!) The cheese was very good and in the right proportion. The onions and bell peppers were UNDERCOOKED. Too much raw veg flavor, too much crunch. Only the crust and perhaps the edges of pepperoni slices are supposed to crunch in the Genuine Article, not the veggies. It's Comfort Food.

The most important part is the sauce. There's gotta be a lotta sauce. I estimate the proper sauce-to-other ingredients ratio in the Real McCoy to be about six times the ratio in your average delivery thin pizza. It has to be rich and chunky, but it ISN'T just chopped tomatoes. It's a SAUCE - it has to be cooked. The Little Star sauce is so acid, so jarring with uncooked flavor, that I immediately took up knife and fork to probe and see if someone suffering from temporary insanity had put GREEN olives in my pizza instead of black. Whew - not the case. But a HUGE disappointment, after the accolades of Yelpers.

They serve the Goods here. It will quiet your Jones. And while I'm sure that some of the complaints about service I read here have validity when the crowds are out the door, I showed up at 5 pm and I found the service to be very friendly, although the place is a little dark for my taste. But this deep-dish will not thrill you, it will not make you exclaim "My God! It's like I never ate pizza before I tasted this!" it will not excite that instant sense memory that is the essence of food nostalgia. Like Patxi's, it's good. Serviceable. More than acceptable. But it doesn't come within a mile of Zachary's, which could open up in Chicago any day and do a land-office business, even up against Malnati's.

After a day of hiking in the Headlands, "The Little Star" and some beer was just about the perfect way to put an exclamation point on a beautiful day.  What really separates Little Star from other deep dish pizzas is the great combination of delicious sauce and unique crust.  While we recently moved across town we will still have to make our way back to the best deep dish pizza the city has to offer.
The best deep dish pizza I had in my life! You must try  their Little Star pizza!  If you go there, be ready to wait; but believe me, it is definitely be worth it.
I was never much of a deep dish pizza fan, but Little Star managed to change that...so good and addicting.  I also love their garlic bread.  So much more tastier than Zachary's.
Deep dish......wow! I avoided this place for years, what a dunce I was! Goodbye Pizza Orgasimica.Little Star has the best cornmeal pizza in San Francisco.

A unique light and airy square pizza that will please even the die hard round pizza eater. The pizza are on display in front of the window so you can make your choice before you enter the counter inside. Very very reasonably price for such heavenly pizza. No lines for me on a Good Friday before Easter around noon!

You know when pizza tastes the absolute best? When you're drunk of course!!!

So we stumbled out of Amante and are instantly transfixed by the smell of pizza in the air. The line looks long but not too long that it discourages you.

My review is mainly an ode to the garlic, clam and parsley pizza! I don't think the idea of clams on a pizza sound appealing to most of the people I've raved about the pizza slice from heaven about. But trust me!!! It's amazing....so amazing I want some more, just thinking about it makes my mouth water. I am soooo sad that I can't have it any time soon since I don't live in SF. But you bet your butt I'm making a beeline to this place the next time I'm in town.

In the meantime my new goal in life is to search high and low for a local place that has clams on their pizza menu topping list!!!

Garlic clam pizza! Love the rectangular slice of pizza, toasted in the oven for a nice crispy crunch.  This place is cash only.
nice seating by the counter.  friendly service and they have beer options.
Had the pepperoni pizza and the garlic and clam pizza and they were delicious. Great seasonings on the pizza

You're not coming here for ambiance. You're not coming here for customer service. You're coming here for freaking delicious pizza at ridiculously cheap (for SF) prices. It's a down and dirty kind of place. Pizza nowadays is actually pretty expensive (even at like, Round Table - what's with that??) but at Golden Boy you can order a whole sheet that feeds a good amount of people for a very reasonable price. Crust is thick and soft and I really enjoy the pesto and vegetable combinations. This is definitely a spot I have repeatedly visited.
The pizza was great!  Especially after drinks on Saturday night.  It was very garlicky but still amazing.

The line is always worth it for Golden Boy Pizza after hitting the bars in North Beach. Quite frankly this is one of the better pizza spots in the city. The garlic and clam sounds a bit weird at first but it's surprisingly good!

The pizza here is absolutely fantastic !
So is Amanda behind the counter !!!Always smiling and great customer service, regardless of how busy the place gets, which is almost always !!!
David too is jovial and helpful !
Thank you !!!
Love this place!!! Pizza one of the best I've had! And the vibes are amazing!!! A must when in San Fran
Best thick crust pizza I ever had.   Nuff said......

This is probably the best thing crust pizza in San Francisco. Topping are spaced perfectly and not overabundant. Very tasty gourment ingredients. Even thought I'm not a big fan of deep dish but the simple tomato was very, very tasty.  CASH ONLY! They have ATM inside for a low fee.
Still great deep dish. Now available in the mission and the east bay. Yum.

Great pizza and a nice place to go all around.  Again, great pizza!  I wish they had just a couple of non-pizza options for the folks that don't want to have pizza with the rest of the table.  But, perhaps that is the point.  They are a pizza place after all and a fantastic one at that!

It has a cornmeal crust.  A very obviously, very cornmeally crust.  If you think your Chicago pizza should have this then you'll like it.   I don't want my deep dish to be overpowered by crust; especially cornmeal.  For the best Chicago deep dish... hands down, it's Zachary's.  And I hate crossing that darn bridge.  But if I'm going to commit to the calories, I'd rather go there.

This is my favorite pizza ever! :)  I love the trendy romantic ambiance.  The staff is very friendly and theres a juke box where you can select songs to be played if you are so inclined.  Theres candles on the tables and its very dimly lit inside, so even though it has a tendency to be very loud, my husband and I enjoy going there on a date night.  It can sometimes be a little bit of a wait, but well worth it!  I love the deep dish veggie pizza, we always get the garlic bread and the spring mix salad.  I like things salty so their food is always a little underseasoned for me, but if you ask for salt they will gladly bring some for you and then the food is just homey, awesome, comforting - great.  If you were to eat it without the salt, the flavors dont really pop to me.  The garlic bread is so interesting, it comes with a whole head of roasted garlic, butter and sourdough.  It is wonderful; if you're really broke, go for that and a coke and you'll be a happy camper.  You can tell all the ingredients are fresh and organic, it tastes like you went outside and picked everything from your garden.  The deep dish pizza is not doughey it has a lot of cornmeal in the crust so it makes it a new interesting take on pizza.  Its an experience for me, not just the same old boring pizza. :) Highly recommended.  Only one con is that I have noticed a little inconsistency here; sometimes out of this world and sometimes just good. :( Still high on my list of favs. Pretty tight inside, so I wouldn't bring a group larger that five.

we tried the mediterranean chicken deep dish pizza and it was delicious!!! the crust was really good and the pizza was extrememly thick, definately a knife and fork type of pizza. their garlic bread was strangely tasteful, the bread was like any other sour dough i've had but it came with butter and a grilled garlic, we had to spread our own garlic. overall the pizza is extremely filling and worth the price. i would recommend getting the small deep dish if you want to feed 4 people, the large pizza will feed about 6 people.

Visiting from NYC where there is an abundance of good pizza, of course I had to find SF's best. Decided on Little Star after seeing it #1 on many Yelp lists and I was not disappointed. My friend and I went around 7pm on a Sunday night and were seated immediately, though maybe just by luck because when we left there looked to be a long wait. Everything on the menu looked great but in my opinion all the thin crust pizzas were priced $2-3 more than the usual "specialty" pizza restaurant in NYC (like Roberta's). We decided on thin crust Italian and deep dish vegetarian to share. Thin crust Italian came out first (and fast!) and it was actually way better than I expected.. something about the garlicky crust was unique to what I've had before. Trying not to make ourselves full we anxiously awaited the deep dish vegetarian. SO GOOD. We took home the leftovers and let me tell you.. they were just as good cold. Hipster servers (I live in Williamsburg so I can say that) were nice.. but I mean your usual hipster servers. Crowd was mixed.. definitely a good place to come with friends and share plates. I guess this is like the Roberta's of SF. Will definitely be back next trip.

three words for little star: better than zachary's.

the namesake pizza, which we had was fantastic. also, the caprese salad was made from very fresh ingredients and was very tasty.

The pizza is very good here but the restaurant itself is noisy, crowded and full of wannabe hipsters. I came here a few days ago and my date and I had to scream at each other to carry on a conversation. Probably best to avoid this place entirely on the weekends, or maybe I will order carryout next time around. I actually prefer the thin crust pizza to the deep dish but it could be that I am a little weird. Salads were a little uninspired in my opinion. The waitstaff was fairly attentive and polite.   Oh yeah. cash only also, don't forget!
best pizza i have ever had.. there chicken wings are also off the hook.. i try and eat here every month

Girlfriend and I were super excited to try Tony's Pizza Napoletana (after seeing it on Diners Drive-ins and Dives). We had a business trip to San Francisco in April 2015, and arranged with the (very gracious) concierge at the Hilton San Francisco financial district to drive us over to pick up some pizza for lunch.

We viewed the menu online, and called to place our order. My girlfriend made the call, and since I was working out of our hotel room - with heavy deadlines - she asked the woman who answered if they would take my credit card over the phone so she could go pick up the order. The woman said yes, and the promptly hung up...WTF??? We called back, and then ordered 1 each of the Margherita and Honey pie. We paid over the phone, but since we had the initial disconnect I felt it was best that we go to pick up the order together. We were never given an order # (which is important to how their process works - so be sure to get one when you order over the phone). We were told the order would be about 20 minutes, and so we arrived 20 minutes later. The woman behind the counter (I think the same one who took our order) said it would just be a couple of minutes. We waited about 20 more minutes, and almost got the wrong order given to us. The staff was not warm, however they were very busy (it was lunchtime after all). We finally got our pizzas, and drove back to the hotel to enjoy them.

Both pies were good, but the attitudes and the final product were not on par with what we expected.

I love pizza almost as much as I love pho, so I was super excited when my friend suggested we grab a post-Turkey day lunch at Tony's.

Our eyes, however, exceeded our stomach capacity, so we ordered way more than necessary.  To start, caesar salad, chorizo mussels, and giant meatball.  Plus, a margherita pizza and a pizza romana (option III) to finish.

Caesar salad:  Good, but not remarkable.

Chorizo Mussels:  The sauce was to die for, but the slices of crunchy bread soaked in the sauce were divine.  The mussels themselves, however, left little to be desired.  The mussels were tiny and the mussel taste was a little overpowering.  Either they weren't that fresh or they were washed adequately.

Meatball Gigante:  Nearly 1 pound of meat.  With a daily limit of 25 according to the menu.  We got the sea salt berrata option.  It was alright.  The sauce was good.  The berrata was yummy.  But, the meatball itself was slightly overcooked.

Margherita Pizza:  Limit of 73/day according to the menu.  The mozzarella was fresh and the sauce was tangy goodness.  Overall though, I have to admit I've had better.

Pizza Romana (Option III):  With the pizza romana, you essentially get to try 3 different pizza combos.  For option III, the first section is arugula, proscuitto, and parmesan.  It was tasty, but I would have liked a bit more proscuitto, or a stronger tasting proscuitto.  The second section with a meatball, white cream sauce, and chopped garlic was yummy in my tummy.  I love garlic, so this isn't surprising, but it may be too much garlic for someone that isn't a garlic lover.  The last section with gorgonzola, dates & pecans, apples, and honey & nutella was a little too sweet for me.  After a few bites, I had to stop.

Overall, it was a pleasant dining experience, topped off with an impromptu (or at least it seemed so) pizza spinning demonstration.  Our waitress and the busboys were fabulous:  attentive, knowledgeable, and genuinely friendly.  

Apparently, there is usually a 1-2 (or even 3) hour wait for dinner.  I'm not sure it's worth the wait, but if you're trying to avoid the crowds, I suggest getting there about 15-30 minutes before they open to snag one of the first tables for the day.  It's worth that 30-45 minute wait!

Tony's never disappoints!  My cousin that is visiting from out of town shared the meatballs and 1/2 Margherita, 1/2 Prosciutto & Arugula Pizza at the bar.  Awesome!! Thank you Stephanie, our Mixologist for making my BD celebration so Special!!!

This is probably my favorite pizza place in the city! Tony's sales pizza by the slice and or a whole pie if you like! From the homemade sauce to whatever toppings you love on your pizza, each ingredient is fresh, piping hot and full of pizza pie love. The best way to beat the long line, is to order in advance as the wait can be up to 30 minutes just to get into the door ( especially on a Saturday). Once you get inside, flash the cashier a smile and order everything on the menu and enjoy!

The best pizza I've ever had!! First day in San Fran I was craving a pizza and got to Tony's right when they stopped sitting people but luckily there was a couple of spots opening at the bar and we decided to grab them....and Yumm! The bartender was professional and made some great drinks. The food came out quickly and we were checked up on a lot to make sure everything was great. It sure was! Thanks Tony's!

They've got it all ... Giant slices that are super flavorful, deep dish that looks quite rich (not my thing, but some seen to love it), and best of all, vegan and even gluten-free options. There's even a special menu for personal pizzas made in the wood fire oven. And unlike some, this gluten-free crust is excellent.

I was in town for a couple of days and my cousin wanted to show my boyfriend and I around SF. We got into town pretty late on a Friday evening , but ended up at this cute little joint in North Beach (Little Italy). I wasn't expecting much from this hole in the wall, but from what she told me the pizza champion owner makes some awesome spaghetti and meatballs and award winning pizzas! No joke!

The owner Tony Gemignani was very nice and came to greet us at our table. I didn't know this at the time, but I recently saw him on an episode of the Food Network Challenge and he won every round in the challenge. Super cool right!? And what's even cooler is he makes the pizza right infront of you! Anyway, we ordered the spaghetti and meatballs, linguini and clams, and a margherita pizza to share between the 3 of us. Definitely hands down the best spaghetti and meatballs I've ever had in my entire life! I'm usually not a big fan of meatballs, but this one stole my heart or my stomach rather. The pizza is baked in a wood fired oven so it had a nice smokey taste and was fresher than any pizza I've ever tasted. There is a limit of 73 pizzas made per day so make sure you get your hands on one of them cause this place is a must try if you're in San Francisco!

EXCELLENT fresh tomato sauce on their margherita pizza hands down! Uber tender and flavorful meatballs. And huge, fresh, delicious salads *nom nom*

Though a bit turned off by all the burnt blisters on the pizza crust yet a crust a bit too chewy (which keeps Zero Zero's margherita pizza still #1 in my book), Tony's is still a quaint lil' lunch getaway in northbeach worth venturing to.

And across the street is gelato.

Yum :)

And, one more for the record: GET THE MEATBALLS.

Tried out Tony's Coal Fired Pizza & Slice House next door to the restaurant one.  It's got like 1 table inside & several outside.

One big slice of the Calif which is a Vegetarian pizza is $5.  Damn expensive slice.  It was ok, kinda soggy in the middle, but thin crust.  Outer crust is boring to eat.  Needs a side of olive oil!

Meh, probably won't be back.  Guy cashier wasn't the friendliest & slightly deaf I think!

Tony and I were meant to be. Arrived 6:30 on a Saturday night to hear there was a 1.75 hour wait. A minute later two bar stools opened up. 10 minutes later we had our draft beers and bread with olive oil and garlic to dip. 15 minutes later a sublime pizza with a chewy crust I also dipped into olive oil along with a caesar salad made with dark green Romaine leaves that perfectly balanced healthy with decadence.

I'm not sure how I'd have felt if we'd waited for 2 hours for the same meal, but this first experience was pure magic. Can't wait to return.

DA BOMB DOT COM. Haha the deep dish is here is really good. seriously, try any of them. Have also tried the thin crust pesto chicken which was also delicious.  Pizza here is a bit pricy but is so worth it.  Wait for the food or a table can be long so get there early.  They wouldn't seat us until our whole party arrived so we actually had to wait an extra 25 minutes while watching them give our table away.  But they did let us preorder once everyone arrived so that was nice.  Really good service, really good food.  Also, parking sucks around here so yeh..get there early.
Recommend the Little Star, Classic, and the daily special. Good, casual vibe but can get really loud.
Great Pizza! Consistently good every time I go there or order take out. Thin crust or deep dish. They do a really good white pie too. And now they accept credit cards... even better.
A tasty place for pizza.  Always enjoy a pie from Little Star.

The pizza here is good. I did not like the corn bread crust first but now I like it. I am giving only 3 stars because you can't get anything special done on your pizza. I have asked for extra olives several times but never got anything but a few. Also, I have asked the pizza to be NOT cut a couple of times and even though order taker clearly put the note on the order the kitchen either did not bother reading the note or ignored it.
Try these: the "little star" (deep dish) and the white pie (thin crust).
I'm a big fan of the deep dish pizzas. I love the crispy corn meal crust and Little Star also makes a mean salad. Love this place!
Their deep dish pizza is the best I've ever had.  Fantastic cornmeal crust.  A+ for food and flavor. The place is small and cozy, can get a bit loud for dinner, but still worth it. Love this place.

the best pizza I have ever had the pleasure of trying. seriously, I will have to hit up the local del taco in Newark in order to satisfy my drunken desire for booze food since I live in the area. I have been to Chicago, had the deep dish there, and by far, little star takes the cake. I absolutely loved the corn bread crust; however, please increase the toppings as there wasn't enough ricotta or chicken on the pizza. as well, the garlic bread was cheesy goodness that didn't make me want to take a deuce in the bathroom shortly afterward (thank you pizza hut). the deep dish takes 30 min to make, so plan out your night accordingly. :)

This place has great Zachary's-style (or, if you like, Chicago-style) pizza with cornmeal crust and without the BART ride/plane to Chicago. It also has appealingly dim lighting and a near-perfect jukebox. The name makes Madonna's abominable "Little Star" get stuck in my head, but that's no one's fault but my own.
I have used this. Nice place with delicious foods. All food items are well tasted. My most favorite item is Garlic Clam.

This place is utterly average. I came here late night and got a cheese, veggie pesto and clam & garlic. They were all semi average even for 11 pm. Probably never going to come here again unless I move in upstairs and am very hungry and its 11 pm. Everyone needs to calm down and try real pizza.

The pizza was delicious, the beers were cold and the atmosphere was rad. I was looking for a more hole in the wall divey pizza joint and I found it. There is awesome music on, TVs to watch the game, and fresh slices of pizza ready for you. I definitely recommend coming here, but it's hard to find a seat when it's busy. Just pop a squat at the bar. Staff was really friendly too so I would definitely go back.
Best pizza in the city. Ordered a cheese and pepperoni pizza that were decent size. Definitely will make someone full very quickly. Highly recommend.

A decent spot to get a cheap slice of pizza. It's one of the best slices you can get in the area. Not the best place to sit down unless you've had a few. The music, which is mostly punk and metal, is annoyingly terrible and loud.

The pizza is tasty, and the crust is the real highlight here. Crunchy, thick and light at the same time. Never had anything like it. The restaurant is not a place where you would want to spend a lot of time. Basically eat and leave. But the pizza is satisfying.

I've heard about Tony's and Golden boy from local friend foodies so I was in the area on what seemed a dead Sunday night in North Beach. I found a parking spot right at the door, I guess if I like it I'll be returning at 10 pm on Sundays because this seems too easy for a top reviewed place. Um, no line? Walked in and ordered right away from the braided beauty behind the counter. I had intended on ordering every available slice choice but it's a cash only joint and I wasn't about to pay their fees from the ATM in the back. I settled on a cheese and a pepperoni slice since I only had $8. I got it to go so it was wrapped in two pieces of checkered paper and stuffed in a bag. I was expecting a small box but no big deal. The dough is a thick pan style with a soft bottom crust. The only crunch you'll get is from the crispy cheese edges. It's doughy but not chewy. I'm pretty sure what gives this pizza the great flavor is the sauce. The dough is good, the cheese and seasonings are great, but the sauce is awesome! It makes the pizza. I'll be back, on a Sunday night at 10, with cash..

This is by far the best pizza I have tried. I recommended the pepperoni or just plain cheese. The clam & garlic was a little too garlicky for my taste buds but still very delicious. This is a must try place!

Ok, as a NY'er, I really really wanted to hate this place when I saw the reviews..... But F*Ck, it's good! Thick, crispy edge pizza gooey goodness. And the staff is actually nice, not common for a pizzeria. Damn you SF... I kinda like you

I've actually been here sober once and it was even better than the other times when I wasn't. You can't say anything bad about hot, fresh slices of goodness...

Update: best bet is to wait for a fresh pan if its not too crowded, otherwise you run the risk of it being under/over cooked...

Oh my Friggin' God!
Best damn Pizza this lifetime.. Thicker than thin crust, little lower than Chicago style.  So damn fresh and tasty, a  real treat anytime of day or night.. Cornmeal crust is the Awesomest!
Gotta try this at least a dozen times!

Great pizza, too popular which ruins the experience sometimes.
But food, service is spot on

Love this place. Too many great pizzas to choose from. Pricey but worth every penny. Good beers on tap beyond the standards. Wine list is excellent as well. There is almost always a wait for a reason. Get on the list, walk in and have a glass of wine across the street at original Joe's until your table is ready.
To date ... the best margherita pizza I've ever had ... if here ... definitely come here!!!
The food was amazing! Elmer was hell of cool bartender. I had the New Yorker it was an amazing experience! Wow! So much fun!!!!
Great meatballs and Pizza!! Service at the bar was great! I will be back next time I am in San Fran

My favorite Italian food in literally all of the U.S. (I lived in Italy for a year so I am quite particular.) The only issue: Tony's needs to expand. Its popularity and lack of reservations makes it almost impossible to eat there without waiting for literally three hours, especially on the weekends.

Food:
i tried the Margherita, you know the traditional stuff from Italy. I never tried a Margherita pizza in the US, thus this is my first in the US. The crust was cooked in a stone oven, but it was maybe a tad too thin towards the center of the pizza. My understanding was that crust is suppose to be slightly crispy due to the fact that its cooked above 800 degrees F. The crust was crispy towards the edge, but since it was too thin near the center, the cheese and oil soften the center. The crust was still good tho, you just have to becareful when you eat. You could taste all the ingredients and nothing was too overwhelming or masked any of the other toppings. But this is a margherita after all.  This is the type of pizza was more of a snack for us fat Americans, but its one of those specialties of Tony's.

Atmosphere/Service
the wait was ok for this place, about 20mins on a thursday around 6pm. service was speedy. we asked the waitress for recommendations, she explained the differences on the menu but didnt really give us recommendations.

Conclusion
Cute place. Food was pretty good. I will come back again to try different pizzas. They use different crusts for different pizzas, I will have to try another one next time.

I came late on a Friday around 9pm. There was no wait, or line and were seated right away. Ordered the New Yorker. It was pretty delicious. Was told after the fact that they also serve good margaritas. Would come back to try. Service was also really good, attentive and friendly server.
Holy crap cake we loved this place. Awesome New York pizza and wonderful service. Come here and be loved and stuffed

After reading numerous Yelp accolades  for Tony's and considering my weakness for Neapolitan pizza we finally decided to give it a try while in the neighborhood this last Saturday.

Tony's from the outside doesn't look like much. There is limited outside seating, somewhere in the range of 6-7 tables. The inside dining room is actually two rooms that are joined by a narrow hallway. We arrived for lunch and the wait for the table was about 30 minutes, and that is exactly how long it took. They can call you when the table is ready so you're free to mingle around if you don't feel like waiting at the spot.

We were seated in the smaller room, next to the entrance and opposite of the bar. The decor is pure old school San Francisco, almost out of the Dirty Harry movie. Leather booths, minimal artwork, long bar, very soft lighting...

The server was at the table in very shortly and brought food and wine menu. I am not much of a wine person and decided to go with Anchor Liberty IPA off the draft. The beer selection is not the best I have seen but more than appropriate for an Italian restaurant. They have a multitude of mixed drinks and wines on the menu so no one gets disappointed.

We ordered some meatballs and a Caprese salad to share for an appetizer. The meatballs were superb with tomato sauce very flavorful and the beef perfectly seasoned and soft, but not spongy. I was a bit surprised with Caprese as it came with mixed greens layered in between sliced mozzarella and tomatoes. It was still good, albeit nontraditional.

For the main course we had to go with the pizza. With so many different styles to choose and different crusts baked at different temperatures, it is not easy to make a selection. But being here for the first time the choice is easy: the award winning Margherita. After all, the restaurant has it right in their name: Pizza Napoletana. The price is a bit steep at $19 for a pie that is not huge by any means. To be honest I could probably finish the whole thing by myself with no issues. However, on the day of our visit we had numerous snacks the same afternoon and were not starving so the appetizer and the pizza hit the spot.

Tony's Margherita is really that good as they say. Dough is thin but soft at all the right places with a bit of a burn on the crust. The cheese shines through and fresh tomato+basil flavors come through as expected from the minimal, but effective combination of toppings. I cannot say that Tony's is the best Neapolitan pizza I ever tried but it's damn close...

If you really want to try Neapolitan pizza the way it is supposed to be, Tony's is a no-brainer. We will be back.

The pizza is decent, though Zachary's is better. Service was good but they give you the stink-eye and come by every 2 minutes to ensure table turn. We weren't there long but it was clear they wanted us there even less time. Lame.

Good.. not great.. but it is really all about style of pizza.  This is good pizza but really not my style.  I am not sure what style it is... the dough was a little flat for me.  But overall I did enjoy the pizza.
Little star pizza is a great pizza place. There pizza are some of the best in SF. I have never had deep dish before until Little Star and it was great. The crust was nice and the sauce was delicious.

Im torn. Little Star: I found you first. Paxtis: I found you second. You both rocked my world. You both took me in and comforted me with your mouth-wateringly tasty pizza. I cant decide. Maybe we can all live together, as one of those alternative-to-the-traditional style relationships? You would each feed me, and I would love both of you equally.
Awesome food awesome people. Well worth your time and money and calories. Ranks right up there with Zachary's and Chicago Fire.
Possibly the best pizza I've ever eaten, a decent beer selection, and acceptable service.

hello there all, Mary here.  I wrote a week or so back about a problem I encountered here.  I think it's only fair that I report the resolution.  The owner, Brian, called me and apologized sincerely for my experience and put me on the credit list for a free pizza.  He called me as soon as I left him my number and he spent some time with me on the phone discussing the issue, and you know, I get the feeling he is a nice guy.  Thank you Brian for responding in a decent way.  That's good business.

We love this place. We both grew up on New York thin crusted pizza, and Little Star's is fine, but their thick crust version is in a class of its own. Corn meal crust, not soggy, not greasy. The cheese is under the incredible sauce. Then you can add things on top, including fresh mozzarella. Good salads too. We have eaten it there and taken out. While the cost for a pizza may seem steep at first, these go a long way, quite filling.
It's all about the deep dish veggie. Staff can be snooty and the ambiance quite loud, But if you like great pizza this is the spot.

Shatteringly crisp crust on the thin crust pizza. Flavor balance was perfect, just the right amount of salt. I had a simple tomato and basil pizza and thought it was fantastic. I'm from the east coast and although there are similarities, the crust is not like any other I have had. It was uniquely crisp and crackling from the first to the last slice. That is rare. Definitely worth the trip.  They were a tad expensive for pizza, but no worse than Mellow Mushroom back home. We ate two 16 inch, conservatively topped pizzas (word to the wise, excessive toppings will sink you if you are trying to eat cheap, but well ) and an order of garlic bread for fifty bucks.

By far my favorite pizza by the slice place in the city.  Unlike most pizza by the slice places in the city where the slice is soggy and thin, GBP makes square pizzas that are just the right size and texture.  I've tried 3 of the kind they serve (cheese, pepperoni, and their combination pizza) and each was absolutely delicious.  They also have bar style seating at the place if you want to eat on site.  

So if you're in north beach and looking for some good pizza - GO HERE!

Once you've had square, you'll always go there.
Yummy. Had the pepperoni. Very good. I always see the pizza on it's way to Caffe Trieste and finally had the opportunity to try some.
Tasty, cheap, filling, hot out of the oven. Perfect rainy day food.
Cash only.

This was an add on to my SF food tour since my friend called it the best slice in the city, with the preface that this isn't Chicago pizza.  I just walked in and took a few slices to go for lunch since parking is somewhat an adventure around here.  I walked in and there was a mom and her kids in front of us and there were a couple of guys inside eating.  The place is kind of a hole in the wall.  One of the creepshows sitting in the bar told the mom she needed to come back at 1am, when the line is out the door.  They needed to kick this guy out cuz really, his attempt at marketing for them failed miserably.  Why would someone want to wait in a longer line that is full of creepshows like him for this?  

The pizza itself was actually decent, though I like mine a bit more crispy.  It is Sicilian style, so crispy it is not.  It is actually more like focaccia.  Since I ordered quite a few slices, they gave me a large box for them.  The slices are about 7" squares.  When asked how many I got for myself, I said 4.  Apparently this is another example of me eating way more than normal humans, as anytime anyone asked about where I had eaten, they looked at me in a mixture of disgust and amazement when the 4 slices at one sitting was mentioned.

I'll paint the picture.  You're out late after a night of drinks and taxiing around from Rick House to Tunnle Top to Ambassador and then back to North Beach. It's late and you just want to get home, but suddenly your mesmerized by the glow of the giant finger pointing down to your new destination.  All you can think of is a perfect square of soft thick cheesy pizza goodness.  No crust, you love crust, but tonite you don't give a crap about it.  All you want is that slice of goodness.  You pay the taxi driver and walk towards your dream Pizza.  You suddenly realize that you're way to tired to wait in the long line so you just keep walking to North Beach pizza and buy an almost equally satisfying slice.  
Next time Golden Boy, Next time....

Best pizza in the city hand's down.

As mentioned by others: order the clam garlic, but really all the different flavors are great.

Cash only

Draft beers + pizza = zomg perfect start to a night of bar hopping around north beach.

If you are having trouble finding the place and the huge line doesn't give it away (line moves fast), looking for the sign - a huge lighted neon hand with a finger pointed toward the door :)

Family never lets me down!

we love to share "our fave spots" with each other when we visit each others hoods.

The cousins newest find was Golden Boy Pizza!

The Hubby has been craving a competitor to the old school Square Pan Pizza... Golden Boy has definitely come close according to him... and that says alot because he's a picky eater!

had the veggie and the cheese... definitely deserves a go back!

We visited this place by pure chance, we were in the neighborhood to go to a near by restaurant but they had a two hour wait. We passed by this pizza joint three times and on the third time we finally decided to just try it.

They have five different pizzas and the one we tried was the clam and garlic pizza. WOW!!!!! Who would have thought up that combo, but whoever it was is a genius. I love garlic and that pizza had tons of it and I love clams and the pizza was filled with little clams. This place was such a great find and I'm so glad we decided to try it.

The line may look intimidating but it's not bad. Just try it as an appetizer before dinner or as a snack. I can't wait to go back.

Ok, pizza is definitely a very difficult food item to rate (in my books) because I generally find all types of pizza pretty much the same (after having tried pizza all over the world), but Golden Boy Pizza definitely pizzazz that puts it over a 3 star rating.

I've only ordered takeout from this place, so I won't be able to give a complete review of the restaurant but I can attest to the fact that Golden Boy Pizza is a must-try if you're a pizza lover. Sicilian is my favorite and Garlic Clams is a close second (although its a bit too salty in my opinion).

Pizza is pizza, but it takes a really good pizza place to put it over the marks  of average and that is exactly what Golden Boy does.

The only negative about this place is the wait (took about 30 minutes) just for a slice of pizza and parking is pretty difficult, especially on a weekend. But if you are around and have time to kill, have a slice over at Golden Boy's.

Stopped by after having a Pad Kee Mao at King of Thai...some friends wanted to get it, and it looked pretty damn good from the window.  The square slices stood out, and I was convinced I had to have one.

I found out the slice I spied from the sidewalk was the CLAM pizza, which sounded amazing (not everyday you run into Clam Pizza).  I was a bit disappointed, as it was kinda bland a tasteles (topping wise). The dough/crust was damn good though!

Nothing bad, but not spectacular, and this is all judging off one slice of Clam pizza (I'm sure the pepperoni was great, as my friends loved theirs).  My only warning is that they have the slices sitting out, and pop it into the oven to heat it up once you order it...not my cup of tea.

I stopped by Golden Boy Pizza with a friend the other weekend.  We were craving a simple snack, and I was definitely not disappointed.  In fact, I've already returned!  As another review already mentioned, the Garlic Clam/Clam Garlic slice was delicious.  The pizza slices are fresh, the ingredients are of high quality and the setting is unique.  I also appreciate the small squares.  It reminds me of how a lot of thin-crust pizzas are cut in Chicago (the rare moments when you don't opt for the deep-dish.)  The bar style is a nice touch in North Beach on a busy night as well.  The prices are not ridiculously expensive, unless you consider a few dollars to be highway robbery.  The service here is also efficient and friendly.  

I asked a strange tourist if I should tip or not.  He looked at me with glazed eyes and muttered "Yuuuuuuh."  Was that a yes?  That can give you an indication of the clientele.  However, if you do stroll in here with your Financial District suit on, no one will really care.  So as I was leaving, I dropped in a bit of change because I thought that we definitely got what we paid for.

Absolute delight for a pizza lover ! The variety of crusts and flavors is totally worth the $$. Long wait Times though. Reserve your spot in the line using Yelp so you don't spend too much time waiting in line.

Oh Tony's, your wait is too long and your menu is hella confusing. I really don't care about the ovens, just the pizzas. The menu is all over the place with the different ovens and the different pizzas cooked in each. Who cares?

We ordered the margherita, that only 70 get made a day, and the flavor was good but the crust was soggy. We were especially disappointed as just the previous week we had an excellent margherita pizza at Pizzeria Mozza, with a light and airy crust. Tony's  was good, but not worth waiting forever good.

On the other hand, the penne with vodka sauce was excellent.

Secret: avoid the lines. go next door. Same pizza just counter service.

Pizza is soooo good!
If you want to eat at the restaurant I suggest going early.  We came Saturday at around 730pm and was told the wait would be 2.5hours!  We decided to walk around to kill time hoping someone would drop but no luck.  After an 1.5hours we decided to just go next door.  By the time we were done we got the text that our table was ready and it was about 2.5hours later.  
Well worth the wait.  We got a pie of each Sicilian style Burratina di Margherita and coal fired New Yorker.  Best Margherita I've had outside of Italy.

Wonderful lunch!  Great service, great cocktails, great food, great atmosphere.... perfect hidden gem.  Try the fried green beans, Caesar salad, margarita pizza, passion fruit and agave signature cocktail.  One of San Francisco's best kept secrets!!!  Not sure if they have reservations, so plan to stand in line to wait for a table.

best pizza in san francisco!  id even go so far as to say best pizza in the bay area (cheeseboard for thin crust).  if you order thin crust here, you are an idiot.  this place has better deep dish than zacharys because of its delicious crust.  we like to get the little star and add sausage.  you can eat there and it's fun but the real way to do this pizza is sitting in front of the TV with tons of napkins, beer, and a nice degrassi marathon.

my first visit to little star was a saturday night. we went early - 6 pm to ensure a quick seating since the reviews mentioned it gets crowded. we sat right away and ordered a bottle of wine and two small pizzas for variety - a pepperoni thin crust and the chicken deep crust. deep crust was better than the thin crust ---good.  friendly and attentive service. check it out.
delicious...i love the cornmeal pizza crust...I eat here everytime I'm in the neighborhood!

We ordered two pizzas. The first, was a 16" medium crust cheese and pesto. The crusty, traditional flour crust gave a good solid, almost crunchy contrast to a hot, wet, topping of melted mozzarella and fresh pesto. It was a perfect combination. Our second pizza was a 14" vegetarian deep dish pizza with olives, mozzarella, tomatoes, zucchini, bell peppers and oregano. It usually comes with mushrooms, but we opted not to have them. This being said, I now believe the mushrooms would have been a fine addition. Even without the mushrooms, the pizza was fantastic. The crust was more of a corn meal mix with a gritty, well browned outside to it that give it a unique opposing texture in the mouth. The bed of the crust was lined with mozzarella, then the vegetables were in the middle, with a bed of tomatoes resting on top. Outstanding. The combinations are well thought out, balanced and tasty. The lighting was low, and the restaurant was large enough to feel like there was enough personal space, but cozy enough to feel warm amongst fellow pizza aficionados who also happened to be in the know as to where some of the best pizza is in San Fransisco is.

The Detroit pizza here always has my mouth watering. They only make a certain number of these per day so sometimes they sell out! It's always busy so be prepared for a wait. Inside is small but in a good way there is bar seating and an additional seating area in another room where a big wood fired stove is. Love the old Frisco vibe inside and I've never had bad service here
The Margherita pizza is awesome!  They only make 73 per day.  The coal fired New Yorker is excellent.  Also need to have the Pizza Romana which comes with three separate flavors.

Hip little restaurant in Little Italy with a cool, laid back vibe and very friendly staff. Definitely use the waitlist feature on Yelp as lines can be long.

Only negative is our seat, located near the pizza oven, was quite warm from the heat. Not terrible but definitely a warm spot.

Pizza was awesome and huge!  Had the 20 inch New York style and was in heaven. You will not leave hungry!  Definitely the place to stop for a good pie in San Francisco.

Its was nice place and very popular! We reserved on yelp before go and we still wait at the door around 25 mins. So prepare yourself to wait! We went there four people and ordered garlic bread( very delicious and so good! We love it!) New Yorker pizza and meatball pizza. Meatball pizza very big. So just letting you know you should calculate like that. I don't eat pork and when I first look the menu I saw meatballs pizza and I thought its beef but they have sausage on it. So I have to order another pizza. Server was really nice... I don't remember her name but definitely she deserves good tip  but welcoming person was rude ! I don't remember her name too! By the way it's very nice place to go and eat real Italian pizza !!!!! You should try, I will definitely go back again!

I had high expectations of this place after reading raving reviews on yelp and was really disappointed. DON"T GO THERE UNLESS YOU HAVE PLENTY OF TIME ON YOUR HAND. Small place, limited seating, average service, average pizza, big price, and ridiculously long wait time.  It has a tiny sign which is hardly visible from the street. We drove right past it even though we had a map and the address. We went on a Saturday evening around 5:45pm, and the place was already pretty crowded.  We were seated right away, which turned out to be the only positive about this experience.  And since we knew what we wanted, the waiter had our order immediately.  When we saw a lot of people streaming in to line up at the cashier, we realized they were here for take-out orders, and at one time there were more people standing in line than those sitting down at the tables.  After waiting for about 20 minutes, I started to see a pattern.  Waiters were coming out of the kitchen with stacks of big and small take-out boxes, but most of the eat in customers were kept waiting. As the time went by I started to get impatient and wanted to leave.  Finally after 55 minutes, our two small 9 in. pizzas arrived separately.  But I had totally lost my appetite.  The deep dish mediterranean chicken is average and the thin crust pesto is nothing special.  We each had one slice and decided to leave. I will never go back.Total disappointment!  The food was definitely not worth the 55 min. wait time.  Final words: Don't go there when you are hungry, and prepare to wait an hour for something you can get at any pizzeria.
this place has the best pizza in the Bay area,  the last time I was there the service was very fast and the food as always was delicious

My friend I just had dinner at Little Star or at least attempted to.  We ordered the chicken pizza we took a couple of bites, but the chicken was reeeally dry. I typically will eat anything that is put in front of me. We told the waitress who graciously offered to make us another pizza. We decided to split it. I wanted something different, but my friend decided she would give the chicken another try. There we were chatting and patiently waiting for another pizza when a guy (who we later found out was the manager) came to our table. "Why would you order the chicken pizza again if you didn't like it the first time, you are going to get the same thing" he said somewhat accusingly. We were both really surprised... oh I don't know maybe you won't cook it until its bone dry for the second time. There was no apology from him nothing. It really did feel like we had made the mistake and he came to the table to chastise  us .We left money for the salad and wine and left.  This maybe the worse customer service ever... and he was the manager. The pizza it typically good, but not that good to put up with that attitude.

First time getting food from here after hearing so many great raves from friends-Yep it's pretty good, par with Zachary's but it's on this side of the bay! Deep Dish is really flavorful, can't wait to try the thin crust. Why 4 stars? Their On-Line ordering system is kind of a major FAIL! Created an account, gave them all my info, placed an order, showed up when I was supposed to...and, no pizza. The system is new, they never got my order,etc etc etc. But then like magic my order came through the system 45 minutes late..."Do you still want the pizza?" "Well you've already charged me for it so yeah, I do" waited another 25 minutes past pickup time and they finally finished my order. Moral of the story? Skip the ONLINE ORDERING!!! Pick up your phone and call it in to another human....or if you do do an online order CALL to make sure they got it. This is for the Valencia location-other branches don't do online ordering. Also the front staff was great, knew someone screwed up and offered me a free drink-kudos to them for actually noticing...

Sat at the chefs table and it was fantastic. The food here is out of this world and the service is spot on. Really enjoyed the fact that we could utilize joining the waitlist online while walking to the restaurant, this made our wait time super short. I highly recommend eating here and if you have the time to spare, wait for the chefs table. It makes the experience all the more enjoyable. My husband can't wait to go back, especially to participate in their pizza workshop that they offer.

My little sister had this bookmarked, so when I mentioned to her that I wanted a slice of pizza she quickly mentioned Tony's Pizza.  We took a cab to get here on time and that was an adventure in itself, but the real adventure is when the waitress showed up with the super adorable can of bread, I knew then that I was in for a treat!  

We were undecided on what pizza to get it was between the New Yorker and Cal Italia.... the waitress recommended the New Yorker hands down, so that's what we got.  Pizza came out so fast and it looked as amazing as it tasted!  Talk about food porn!  Man that was delicious!  I wish I had more room in my stomach to have eaten three slices rather than two, but no luck :(.  My mouth is turning water as I'm writing this.  The oh-so-perfect tomato sauce, the ooey gooey cheese, the spicy stacked pepperoni, the juicy sausage, the creamy ricotta and the salty-just-enough-crisp crust... give your mouth an orgasm and wanting more!  The only thing I regret is giving our half left over pizza to a homeless guy (lol jk I don't regret it, but I do sort of).  

You MUST, MUST go to Tony's if you're in San Francisco and their customer service is fabulous as well!
if you like deep dish...this place is the best for it in the city.....lets go!
All hail the drunken grease induced food coma caused by this incredible Detroit style pan pizza.... you're welcome!
Great pepperoni pizza. Good clam and garlic pizza ( a bit too much garlic for me though). Cold, cheap beer! I'll be back
To put it simply, best pizza in the universe. It's square, it's big enough to have to use a fork and knife when you eat, and it's served super fresh and super hot out of the oven.

Hands down, best pizza around town. wasn't too stoked about the Clam and Garlic (I'm not too into seafood). but the pepperoni and sausage was AMAZINNNGGG.. this place is a must try whenever you're in the area.
It's the perfect place for a fat slice of the best pizza. The way the cheese and sauce go perfectly with the dough. Even the clam and garlic pizza, perfect combination. I recommend.

The pizza was great, but it can get expensive when you buy it by the slice. It looks like a trashy bar and the ambience sucks. The employees were bitchy college girls and were unfriendly to my parents.

I want to start by saying that the pizza was delicious! You should know that this pizza is on focaccia bread. That is what makes it so unique, but that could also be why some people don't like it. Just FYI :)

I was in SF for work, so I was spending a lot of time eating alone. This restaurant it perfect for dining solo. They actually have zero tables. It is only bar seating.

I hate going new places alone and feeling super out of place because I don't know what is going on. Assuming that other people have the same fear I want to let you know what I learned from visiting.... You walk in and order right away standing at the bar. You can order for here or to go. Then you pay, CASH ONLY! They hand you your slice and you either find a seat or head back out the front door. I didn't realize this and just took a seat and assumed I would order after. Not the case. Luckily one of the girls behind the bar was nice and accommodating.

Yummy and would return. Just know what to expect.

Key takeaways
1. Not good for groups. Good for dining solo
2. Bar seating only
3. Cash only (ATM in back)
4. Order first, then find a seat.

every single person that hears my bag and my friends bag was stolen inside the pizza place are always surprised that no one did a single thing to help us. every single one. never coming back here and I hope the staff steps up to the plate. we didn't even get a "im sorry that happened inside our restaurant".

The mushroom pizza was a crowd favorite. However, the combination pizza had too much going on. The pepperoni was tasty but could've used sausage or mushrooms for added taste. Customer service is great here! I ordered two sheets to pick up for a party and waited not very long for pick up.
Awesome pizza - perfect crispy crust. Hot the clam and garlic and the veggie and both were delicious. Great service and perfect mood music playing. Worth the walk from down by the Wharf.

The location is great. Great view of Washington square park. Our server was far from friendly and slow. The Napoletana Marina seemed burnt on the bottom - and lacked flavor. The classic American pepperoni Crust was amazing and the sauce was delicious.
