Tony's pizza is seriously f***ing unbelievable!!   Absolutely positively the best pizza I've had in the City yet...   Yeah, it's THAT good!!

My wife and I stumbled here after missing our reservation @ Hillstone.   She drove in today to have lunch with me and we were hoping for a terrace, but that fell through.   We found a great parking spot on Stockton @ Green and we were tempted to go to Viva, our favorite go-to joint for a quick tasty bite to eat.   Instead, though, we chose to be adventurous so we strolled down Columbus and ended up at Washington Square in front of Tony's Pizza Napoletana.

"Hey, babe," I said to my wife, "I read about this place.   Yelp reviews are off the hook!  You in for some pizza?"    She acquiesced and we waited patiently for about 15 minutes until we were seated.

I started off with the Bone Marrow Crostini while my wife opted for the Salami Tapenade.   Both appetizers were tasty, but certainly far from worthy of 5 stars.   Quite honestly, the bone marrow was not nearly what I've tasted at Epic Roasthouse or Bistro Jeanty in Yountville.   Nevertheless, that was just the appetizer and we were here for the pizza...

We knew from the get go we ordered way too much pizza, but that was part of the idea:  so we could taste each other's pizza and, if we liked it, to have plenty to take home for leftovers.   I ordered the Wild Robiola Pizza, complete with mozzarella, burrata, robiola cheese, wild mushrooms, truffle oil, prosciutto & arugula.   My wife decided to go with the New Yorker pizza, a grand affair full of mozzarella, hand crushed tomato sauce, natural casing pepperoni,
sliced italian fennel sausage, ricotta, chopped garlic & oregano.

Service was on the slow side... I went through 1 and a half glasses of Montepulciano before I was served my pizza, and I didn't drink particularly fast.   Still, we weren't in a dire rush so we chatted about life, our kid and the daily chores that needed to be done.

Then the pizza came...

The New Yorker pizza came first and I must say it won against the Wild Robiola pizza *hands down*!!!  Actually, we sort of agreed that if we could take the toppings of the Wild Robiola pizza on the crust of the New Yorker, we'd have the perfect pizza.   Nevertheless, the New Yorker pizza as is was absolutely amazing and totally delectable.    The crust was cooked to perfection and, as I said above, this was by far the best pizza I've ever had in the City.

I cannot wait to come back to Tony's for some more pizza!!!
This place is great and worth the wait in line. I had the garlic clam pizza and was satisfied to the max. I like the decor and the people that worked there were nice.  I wanna go back soon.
Good pizza, worth the line. The veggie pesto is great, and the place has good atmosphere.
I've eaten here several times in the past and this time was just as good as I remember.  Hot bubbly cheese, crispy crust, and always fresh.  Absolutely delicious!
I've been here several times. Always solid, delicious pizza. Never fails. Cheap too!
The best pizza I have ever had, South Beach is known for its bars....but  this pizza is unreal

This is another place I will go there every time when I go to SF....is next to the seafood place that I mention it before....there pizza dough are so chewing, soft....always long line waiting....MUST try...i love their garlic clam pesto....full of clam on top of it...yummy....
Okay pizza great punk rock graffitti atmosphere SUPER SMALL
this place is alright , nothing amazing , especially considering the long ass lines. its kinda plain and bland tasting. id rather have Tony's or northbeach pizza

This pizza is SO AMAZING! We wanted a quick bite but somewhere we could sit down. The cashier was super nice & very fast. Since we were starving the food was ready very fast. Pizza was crunchy & so delicious. Highly recommended it here!
The best take-away pizza in the city!!! Nothing better than grubbing on a slice while checking out North Beach.
Outstanding pizza and pasta. My son and I went here for dinner and had a great time. Food was amazing, staff was friendly and atmosphere was cozy and warm (and we ate outside in February).

Magical pizza experience. The servers are super helpful and will steer you the pie of your dreams.  

Expect to wait for a table. I do like that you can wonder off to a nearby bar and that the hostess will call you when your table is ready.  That's a nice touch.

First, a disclaimer: I would have given this five stars were it not for the host, Tyler.

Second disclaimer: I worked in the service industry for years, so my patience/sympathy for those who work in it is pretty high.

Oh, Tyler. Where to start. First order of business: If you are on the phone while, oh, enough parties come in that that they begin lining up outside occurs, I have some simple advice: put the caller on hold for a second, turn to the people and tell them, "I'll be with you in a minute, thanks for waiting." Nope. If, after ten minutes (we counted), you are still not off the phone, ask someone else to help you. Secondly: seat people in the order you take their name (in regards to the number in their party, of course). What. The. Hell. I thought we were all participating in an episode of 'Punk'd,' but then I remembered we were not famous.

Onward! From start to finish, this food was so thoughtfully prepared and absolutely to die for.

Apple Salad: Light and amazing, apple vinaigrette was not too sweet, and ho, little scooped out balls of apple! Delightful.

Margherita Pizza (__/73): I'm sure it's all been said before. Better than Delfina, better than Beretta. The sauce was so incredibly balanced it made you realize how acidic or sweet most other sauces truly are. Just enough oil, just enough cheese.

Pasta Pomodoro w/garlic bread: Super light and fresh and good. We ate our way through a lot of everything, but what I liked was that we didn't leave with that heavy. post-italian food coma. Everything was light and simple.

We watched Tony as he prepared everything and it was like watching an artist, truly. He even took two patrons back into the kitchen to see how something worked. It was amazing, and I will definitely be back. Hopefully, Tyler will not.

We stopped by this place because we had read that Tony won some kind of "World Pizza Contest".  The first thing we notice is that it's very busy, the second is that the Margarettas are great.  We love the food and can't wait to come back.

Peace

Went here on a Friday evening so we expected a long wait. We were told 1.5 hours but they are nice enough to take down your number so you can get a drink around the corner and not miss your name being called. The wait turned out to be less than an hour almost so that was a pleasant surprise.

The menu is a bit daunting with all the styles of pizza but we had to try the classic Margherita and luckily they had 3 left! This cooks the fastest so it was brought out in minutes and was oozy goodness. it was perfect timing, we had just finished our meatball appetizer which was good but not memorable. The margherita is a must and I can't wait to compare it to the ones in Italy when I go in September.

The best part of the meal however was Cal Italia pizza which is award winning . We wanted a pizza with prosciutto but with a different taste than the margherita and this was perfect. I only have 1 word for the first bite (and second and third...) : Orgasmic! This is by far the best pizza I have had besides a margherita and I would drive an hour, spend 30 mins finding parking, wait another 1.5 hours in the freezing cold just to taste this again.

I am a Pizzerie Delfina lover but this place really makes you rethink your priorities. I am slightly torn but next time I am craving authentic italian style pizza, I just might choose Tony's over Delfina!

4 stars only because the meatballs were not memorable. Would give 4.5/5 if I could!

GET THERE 30 MINS BEFORE THEY OPEN. or have fun standing in line or risking them running out of a pizza you want. I got there early and was seated immediately and got our pizzas near moments after ordering. def super pricey for pizza, but it was delish. the crust was great too, not that thin cracker stuff you get at a lot of other trendy pizza places. super fresh ingredients. wonderful.

Do you remember the best thing you've ever eaten?

It seems like a simple enough question, yet, for all their capacity to indulge and sate, food experiences can be remarkably forgettable. Sure, everyone's got a preconceived list of favorite dishes in their heads, but can they actually remember what it's like to eat them?

Just for kicks, let's say you love clam chowder. It's your favorite dish. The tastiest thing you've ever had...Well, you're a damn fool because soup sucks (it's just salty water), but I digress.

Now, can you close your eyes, toss your head back, and remember what the best bowl of New England's finest tastes like? Can you recall the rich heft of salty butterfat lapped up then bathed over your tastebuds? What about the mealy give of an overstewed potato as it thaws between your teeth? Or the slickness of mollusk-perfumed cream lingering on your balmy lips? I just went from five to midnight.

So, then, can you? Do you? I can. And I do. I remember everything. I remember walking down Stockton Street on a slightly-too-cold afternoon. I remember my gut trying to claw its way out my midsection, us having waited forty minutes for a table. I remember the dank, over-lacquered burgundy furnishings. I remember the sunset glow of the sideroom stone oven. I remember the infernal smacking of the hipster girl across from us as she ate her lunch, and I remember my fists balled up ready to knock the ugly out of her thick framed glasses. I remember the congeniality of our waiter. I remember mountains of complimentary bread. I remember a lot of good but otherwise forgettable food.

And then it came. Margherita. My queen. Hovering above us, it steadied itself on the server's fingers as he placed a tray stand in the middle of our table. A perfectly imperfect circle, it jutted out in weird places, as though it were, or had once been, alive. And, to a certain degree, it was. The cheese sizzled and seethed, the sweaty fists of steam roiled, and the sauce swam within itself, shimmering with promise. Now, I don't want to sound profane, but gastronomic desire is not so different from its sexual counterpart, and so, at that moment, I was one horny bastard.

Thus, despite all my reservations about indulging in piping hot pizza, I dug in. And while the roof of my mouth was indeed ravaged, it was worth it. The toppings being distributed inequitably (as they should), one bite was creamy, another was sharp, and yet another, grassy. Each leaving just a hint of its character in the subsequent bite. Floppy by virtue of saturation (but not inundation), the paper-thin pie still managed to have a firm bite to it, like great pasta. The sauce itself was light and smooth, almost watery, with no acerbic edge, but robust with tomato flavor. Ideal for carrying the richness of melted mounds of snow white dairy. The crust, bready, airy, but with a tinge of crinkle, was all the best things about the ass of a pizza brought together.

But there was something there more important than mouthfeel, or flavor, or delicacy. It's that thing you just can't put your finger on when something truly amazing happens. How do I say this--it was a belt or shock or tinge of enlightenment. Unfiltered happiness. And maybe it's because I am a lonely, lonely guy, but I feel a truly great meal is like a fine woman (or man--your mileage may vary). It fills your chest with satisfaction in a way that only the most primal of indulgences can. It is, too, philosophical, the memory giving you insight, perspective, and daydream fodder.

Let me put it to you in fewer words. This was the single greatest thing I've ever eaten. And if that isn't worth five stars, I don't know what the hell is.

God I need to meet new people.

I ordered a Coal Fire New York pizza, an Americano pizza, 6 pieces of meatballs, Little Italy Salad, cheesy garlic beard, and side of ranch sauce that I never got for delivery. Very disappointed because the food was not hot/warm and I only live less than 10 minutes walk away from the restaurant. The delivery guy stacked other food over my cheesy garlic beard. When we opened the box, four pieces of beard was stuck on top of the box and we tried to pull the beards off, but all the cheese was stuck on the box. The crusts for both pizza and the beard was ridiculously hard. My dad, who has trouble biting hard food, was not able to eat it at all. He ended up eating last night's left over for dinner.

The meatball was pretty good, so I give it a 2 out of 5.

Great place for a pizza!  We stopped off based on The Yelp review and ordered a medium pepperoni and mushroom pizza. Good ingredients cheese, sauce and toppings. Crust as good as well maybe a little on the crustier side.  The two of us had dinner for less and twenty bucks and enjoyed every bite.
So yummy and unique! Love  the atmosphere and different flavors. Definitely a unique try in San Fran.

For those who crave cheesy, cheesy, cheesy pizza...this is the spot.
I grew up in the North Beach, so TRUST me when i say this IS THE SPOT! I always stop and get a slice when Im out on Grant and Green on those crazy Friday nights, or on Broadway gettin some tipper love on Saturdays, its always good.

FYI Dont bite on the pizza too quick you'll burn the roof of your mouth...do it and you'll see what Im talking about..HAHAHA

Definitely solid pizza. I think the sauce gives it a little something different. If you want a sit down place this is not the restaurant for you. The space is pretty small and tends to be packed but that's because the pizza is so good! The employees are pretty friendly and efficient. If you are ever in north beach this place is certainly worth a visit! Oh ps did I mention that for a slice of cheese it is only $2.75. Cheaper than every other pizza place in north beach. Yay!

So, I am not usually the biggest fan of pizza...I am also pretty picky as I worked at a pizza restaurant for years and am kind of burnt out on it. Well, the Golden Boy has rocked my world.  I had the combination and they put plenty of toppings and sauce, it was fresh, cheap and very hearty - this is no pansy slice of pizza.  It may also have helped that I was a tad wasted.  They get extra points for being open so late to accommodate SF's riff raff.  I didn't give five stars because the line was long and we had to wait a while in the cold - I know this is part of the hole-in-the-wall charm, but that doesn't make waiting in the cold any less annoying. That said,  I will definitely be going back for more.

Best  Italian-style pizza in North Beach if not a huge chunk of SF. I don't mess around with pizza. I know what I'm talking about. The New York styles are OK but Golden Boy serves up more than a snack. Their focaccia crust is made by hand and a slice can serve as a meal.  It's a narrow, shotgun floor plan so it gets cramped during a rush. I love the locale and the girls are hot!

Two slices and an import beer $10-$14
Nothing new to add,...it's predictably delicious every time i visit north beach, sober or smashed!!!

A good place for a quick and tasty meal on a focaccia type bread.

The slices are deceptively filling. We ordered a beer and 2 slices each and had a hard time finishing. I appreciated the simple slices of pepperoni more than the complex pesto.  Was entertaining and filling and nice to catch part of a Giants game.

It was kinda hard to get our waitresses attention when we wanted to leave but all in all a good experience.

I've been looking for a place like this for months here in the Bay Area.  It's big-fat-square-pizza by the slice loaded with fresh toppings.  The dough, the cheese, the sauce; all flavors come together to create an Italian-American master piece.  Also, try the dark brew Hemp Ale on draft.  When it comes to sloppy pizza joints, it doesn't get any better than this.

If you are ever in SF and want great pizza.... This is your place.. I just wish they were opened later.  As I find myself in SF going to the clubs and or bars, if they served past the 2 am mark they would get my business.

Oh baby, this is great pizza.  The ingredients are damn near perfect (the sauce is probably the best I've ever tasted) and the crust is some sort of architectural miracle.  I'd suggest keeping it simple -- too many toppings obscures the majesty of the slice.
Amazing PIZZA!!! Always in the mood for their combination slice. And a good beer on tap isn't bad either!

A great find in SF, open late, cool decor with inviting staff. I had the cheese my wife got the loaded, she thought hers was better than mine but I thought mine was awesome. Was reheated from the window and cheese was melted, tongue burning hot. Love it !

Super convenient when you do not feel like waiting for a slice of pizza. There is often a moderate line outside during late hours on the weekend but overall a fantastic place for a grab and go meal. Not to mention, the pizza is fantastic! :)
Great square pizza with just the right amount of char. It gets busy but the waitresses are upbeat and friendly. Cash only.

Was deeply disappointed with this place. I read amazing reviews about it and came to check it out. I'm visiting San Francisco for two days and walked about 30 min to get to Golden Boy Pizza. When we got there, the line was pretty long but we didn't mind waiting because the pizza looked good and the servers seemed fast. I sat down with my girlfriend and we each got a slice and a beer. We sat down and talked and chilled and when I realized my bag was gone. I had my purse stolen INSIDE the restaurant. I talked to the staff and no one did anything about it. They didn't even look around or ask the patrons about it. NOTHING. We asked about the surveillance camera and they refused to give us access to it. Inside my bag I had my wallet with my cards and my drivers license, I had my sweaters, my go pro , a bottle of champagne for the night and much more. I'm from Brazil and I've been to some grungy places , but I've NEVER had anything stolen from me INSIDE A RESTAURANT. that's absurd !!! What kind of trashy place is this ??? What really upset me is that no one moved a single finger to help us out. Because I chose to sit down in this place, I'm gonna have to cancel my trip and leave two days earlier than planned because someone stole my bag inside the restaurant and I have nothing left on me. Thanks golden boy. Your patrons are real trashy and your staff doesn't give a fuck about what happens to their customers.

I've eaten a lot of pizza in my day, but Golden Boy is the best in my opinion. The crust is crunchy, the toppings are tasty and fresh, and I like the square shape. My favorite is the Clam and Garlic. It is soooooooo good. Never had Clam and Garlic pizza anywhere else. Whenever I get the chance, I come here for it. I also really like their combo pizza, they put zucchini on it which I love! They put on just enough sauce rather than slathering it like some places do, so you can still taste all the toppings. Their prices are pretty reasonable too. The inside is fairly small so its def more of a take out place. The only downside in my opinion is that even late at night there is often a huge line. Takes a while to move through it too but to me the wait is worth it. Just don't expect to stop by to quickly grab a slice because there is nearly always a wait. Its great they are open late too, it makes a perfect snack after a night out. Golden Boy certainly knows how to do pizza right!

i can't get too worked up over this pizza.  the crust needs...something.  it's not substantial enough.  it's not crispy enough.  it's lacking...something.  

the clam pizza's pretty good tho.  

warning:  don't go here if you hate really friggen loud heavy metal with your so-so pizza.  

i imagine beavis and butthead would really dig this joint.

Normally, I would never even think of eating a square piece of pie, but I got off work late and had a mad craving for pizza. It was close to the house.  So I finally broke down and tried the square pizza.  To my surprise it was pretty good.  The crust was nice, soft, and full of flavor.   There were plenty of toppings that went to the edge of every last square piece of pizza.  If you go in there before all the bars let out, you can sit inside and drink beer with you square piece of pie.  if you don't make it in time, they serve pieces through the window. Over all, I will be back again.
Pretty delicious and even better the next day. A piece of this is easily split into 2 small meals. For $3.75! The pesto vegetarian is a favorite.

Good pizza hard to find parking. (unless you want to pay $10 across the street at the garage) Don't order the pizza sheet (whole pie). Takes 45 minutes to make and feeds 1000 people. Get individual slices. They bake them again to get them all crispy and nice. The combo is the best. If your feeling a little daring try the clam pizza. You wouldn't even realize its clam till they told you. Good friendly neighborhood pizza joint. A few beers on tap and a nice plasma TV with the game on. So far the best pizza in the city.

You haven't had pizza until you had GB's clam and garlic! Order a glass of beer, and relax in the faux dive atmosphere.

If the game is a good slice of pizza without the fancy restaurant, this place is the clear winner. Only con is that the slices are thicker than average, so if you like thin crust, this is not your place.

I can't say I'm a pizza know-it-all, but damn this pizza is good. The Margherita here is one of the best pizzas I have ever had. Crush is perfect, toppings are fresh and delicious.

The variety of pizza preparations is beyond me, left to be appreciated by those of who know the difference between ovens, flour and water proportions, and whatever else.

Good drinks too, good service, fun atmosphere.

Do not come here if any of the following apply to you:

1.) You are in a hurry
2.) You are on a budget
3.) You are on a diet.

Got it? Okay good. Now prepare to have the best pizza you've ever had in your life. That's a pretty bold statement to make. There is pizza on every corner in America, and probably tens of thousands of pizza restaurants. But trust me, this place is special. They've won the world pizza cup twice with their margharita pizza, the menu showcases the different pizza oven options available, and they have some really off the wall haute cuisine pies in addition to the standard selection. This is the pizza lovers Mecca. Make the trip at least once in your life.

Authentic Neapolitan pie, just make sure that's what you're into!  I'm sure there are equal or better versions in the city, but everything from the crust to the sauce to the overall balance and proportions were correct.  Recommended.

A friend and I have been meaning to try Tony's since before it opened and we finally ventured out this evening.  We arrived around 6:30pm on a Friday and the wait was 30-40 minutes for two.  I think we waited a little longer than that but it seemed reasonable.  Plus, they brought around a meat and cheese platter to satisfy our hunger while waiting, very nice touch.  

Once we were seated. the service was very speedy and friendly.  I was quite impressed by how fast all of our food came out.  Our waiter gave us a "tour" of the menu which I found very helpful.  He described the four different styles of pizza and how they were cooked differently in specific ovens as well as gave us some guidance about the portion sizes.  We opted for the famous Margarita pizza, determined to see what the hype was about.  We accompanied this by a pear and arugula salad with gorgonzola and pecans that our server recommended.  

While waiting for our meal we were served two types of bread, one crusty and the other more like a foccacia along with olive oil in three vessels, one pure, one with pesto and one with fresh garlic.  The pesto was by far my fav but all were good.

The salad is a very generous portion, easy to share with 2+ people! I was impressed.  I've had this combination on salads before and this was very good, but not the best.  I'm not sure what it was lacking but I think it could be slightly improved.  

Next was the pizza, superb!  The crust is simply out if this world, a perfectly divine combination of crisp and chewy with that nice wood burned fire flavor.  Honestly, the crust in the middle of the pizza was a little on the softer side, almost too much but the outer rim made up for it.  My friend thought there was too much olive oil but the truth is I loved every drippy bite of it.  The mozzarella and basil were fresh tasty as well.  The sauce is really just pure tomatoes of the highest quality, very simple.  

Overall, I'd say the crust is what makes the pizza.  There was nothing wrong with the toppings, but margarita pizza has never been my favorite so I'm looking forward to trying other combinations.  However, I know that only the margarita gets the special flour flown in from Italy, so perhaps the other crusts won't compare.  I can't wait to return and try more! Split two ways, drinking water, my share of the meal with tip was $18, not bad for an upscale restaurant and some of the best pizza I've ever had (and yes, I've had pizza all over Italy as well as many other parts of Europe so I am partial to thin crusts and minimal toppings).

Oh, and to make a great experience even better, if you site on the right half of the restaurant, you get to watch Tony work his magic preparing the pizzas in the 900 degree wood oven!   I thoroughly enjoyed this portion of the whole experience.  Tony also periodically wanders out to chat with customers which I thought was nice.  I didn't get to meet him but maybe next time!

I've heard about this place through some other local blogs and recommendation services and figured I needed to see it for myself. I went with a group of 5 and had exceptional service, little waiting time and great food.

I definitely recommend their famous margarita pizza, but their calzones are good too. I didn't order both, just tasted my friends ;)

Keep it up Tony!

We came here for lunch on the Veteran's Day holiday.  Both sides of the restaurant were pretty packed, and we were hoping that this place would be worth the wait.  We waited about 20 minutes for a table and were located in the cramped table next to the small booth outside the kitchen door.  My fiance had the Americano pizza, which wasn't bad, and I had ordered the rigatoni with chicken--eh.  

Our waiter had to be reminded by one of the ladies at the oven to take our order, and when he finally came, he didn't even bother to write it down our order! I understand that a calamari appetizer, Americano pizza, and rigatoni with chicken may be a simple order, but he forgot to even place the order for the calamari.  He never even checked on us once we got our food.

All in all, the pizzas may be award winning, but that's about it.

Best pie this side of the Mississippi. You cannot find pizza this good anywhere else that I've tried. Admittedly, I still need to get to A16 and Flour + Water, but have been to Picco. This place is amazing.

I've had the Grimaldi's and Lombardi's of New York and I've had Due's deep dish in Chicago, and now I've had Tony's. It ranks up there.

You've all heard by now that they won a pie making contest in Naples and now only make 70-some-odd pies per day of the winning margherita pizza. And they have marvelous beers on tap. If you miss good pizza and are tired of Pizza Hut (which is admittedly a junky joy on the right day and with the right craving), get thee to Tony's.

So many variations of pizza available here, with 7 different types of pizza ovens available to choose from. I haven't been disappointed yet, great tasting pizza, not a lot of parking available, but that's to be expected in San Francisco. Always a crowd waiting to be seated, the pizza is well worth the wait, but the good thing is that they will text you when your party is ready to be seated, but don't go too far, you only got a few minutes to get back to the restaurant and check in with your FULL party.
We ordered the margarita napolete. Took a decent 10 min for the order. I found it to be pretty soggy , wouldn't recommend.
Pizza perfected... We had the New Yorker... Coal fired pizza with ricotta cheese, pepperoni, fennel sausage tomato sauce-excellent!
Just delicious. I love Golden Boy Pizza it is the best Sicilian-Style Pizza in the city!!!!! The vegetarian pesto pizza is amazing.

Everything you could ask for in a pizza place plus a nostalgic 90's vibe. Expect to enjoy a little Rage Against the Machine, Nirvana or Metallica with your slice. Plus a television in  a non-distracting area. nice. Excellent service -- trays of pizza are cooked as needed and slices are heated up when you order them --- THE WAY IT'S SUPPOSED TO BE DONE! A small bar dining area -- perfect -- any more space would be intolerable. Perfect cheese/sauce/crust/topping ratio.

If you like Sicilian style pizza, then you should definitely check this place out. I've had most of the slices there and have yet to be disappointed. The atmosphere is pretty authentic as well.

It's worth the trip to North Beach for a slice (or two) and a beer. FYI, it is cash only.

Pretty good place to grab a square thick pizza piyaaa.

Very small inside but a cool italian atmosphere. Short wait in line usually and the slices are only 3$

open late and they have a good selection of Beer.
Beer and Pizza, top it off by walking a block to the strip club, what else do you need?

What I like most about this place is walking by and smelling the fresh pizza coming out of the oven. The smell just pulls you in... its amazing and when I watch Ninja Turtles, I imagine the pizza in the movie smelling like that.

Golden Boy is some mmm...mmm...pizza. Our tour guide in San Fran recommended the pizza joint where there's a giant finger pointing towards it. Uhh...yea we had no idea how to look that up on Google maps, but we found it regardless. Crunchy crust, well seasoned sauce, stretchy warm cheese, and yummy veggies on top, what more could you ask for?

First we tried one pepperoni and one cheese slice and was impressed, then after the tip from Yelp, we tried a clam garlic slice...tadow!  I only regret not having ordered this first...amazing!  I ordered the 2nd to last slice then two women came up and noticed only one was left...she made it very clear to me non-verbally that I had just ordered HER pizza.  Haha!  It tasted even better knowing that this was THE SPOT and we had THE SLICE.   Nice!  Lastly, my wife and I did think this joint is best for older kids, though our 1 and 3 year olds had a bit of a difficult time.
We went on a late Saturday night, We were very hungry and MAN OH MAN what a wonderful delight!!!!!!!!!!!!  great combo.... we will be going back!!
This is not only the best pizza in San Francisco, it's better than any pizza I've had nation wide. I dream of Golden Boy pizza at night. Enough said?

Golden Boy Pizza is especially yummy if you are out drinking all night, hungry and freezing cold with only $6 in your pocket. The sheets of pizzas are FRESH off the oven. They are warm since they are very popular. The slices are in square. I would have given them 4 stars if they just put a little more tomato sauce in their pizzas.

The place closes at midnight. Golden Boy has to watch out for Tony's pizza. It has taken over the now closed La Spiaggia Delicatessen and will sell pizza by the slice.

THE pizza spot in North Beach. Sit at the bar or counter and your piping hot squares will be out in minutes. Pair with one of the beers have in tap and it's an unbeatable combo. I think the move here is the Pesto Vegetarian. Oh, and they play the illest jams. A definite must go.
Great great pizza! Awesome service, variety of beers and alcohol options, amazing vibe, will definitely come again !
Just like Italy only cheaper! I loved it. The beauty was in the simplicity, 6 flavors to choose from at $3.50 a slice ( more like a hunk o pizza). Delish!

My girlfriend and I were searching for a tasty inexpensive pizza joint in the north beach area and came across this hidden gem. We were intrigued by the pizza on display. Seemed like there pizza was very fresh and tasty. We decided to give it a try, and sure enough we were very pleased. My only disappointment is the lack options with flavors they have to offer. Otherwise the service was great, and the food was great. They also serve beer on tap which is a plus. Overall a great environment, and a good time. Highly recommended.

I was visiting SF from texas and I accidently stumbled upon this hidden gem of a pizza place.  First you have to understand I'm not a pizza fan... I really don't care for it, but holy crap these square pizza are like crack.  My wife ordered a clam pizza and it was frigging awesome... that I decided to buy another pizza slice, which I came to find out the combo wasn't as good as the clam and my pizza limit is 1 slice. That still didn't change my impression of the clam pizza that's why i'm giving this place a 5 star.  I would give this place 3 stars for service, but I've come to realize that almost everyone in SF is pretty unfriendly.
Great value. Local hole in the wall. Rock music, beer and a slice

Delicious place! Loved it. Came here for dinner and it was worth the wait. It was a 2 hour wait on a Sunday afternoon, but luckily the gentleman was kind and sat us in 1 hour! The pizza was yummy. Our waitress was ok at the beginning, she came off tough but after she knew what we wanted she was cool. We got a chorizo pizza omg so yummy! I don't remember the name of it but it was yummy! Affordable too! One medium size came out to $27. It's worth it!

Ya know, I was really expecting to be wowed and amazed. Welllllll I wasnt:( We sat at the bar and ordered a pizza there. The service at the bar was great. Very attentive staff and good vibes too. Seriously, the dips for the bread are what really stood out during our entire meal. The dips are off the chain!! The infused oil and sweet pepper oil dip.. ahhh so good. Now, on to the margerita pizza. It had some really charred spots on the bottom and took away from the flavor of the crust and well the rest of pizza. Did I mention a butt load of grease too? Yup! Maybe I should've sent it back? I don't know, but I do know this... I will probably only return for the bread and dip and drinks at the bar! I still have not come close to my New York pizza moment. The search continues.

GREAT place! There's always a wait, though. Be prepared to wait even at 3pm on a weekday and know that it is well worth the wait.

I love the Detroit pizza as well as the mushroom and arugala pizza. The spinach and feta salad is wonderful with the house made balsamic dressing that comes with it. Finish with the in-house cheesecake and you'll have had an overall delicious dinner experience.

We finally got around to going!  A pretty broad selection of pasta & pizzas of various styles, & also an impressive bar for a pizza place.

A 45 minute wait for 5, but the hostess took our number & we wandered down to Tony Nik's for a cocktail, so it was 45 minutes well spent.  You can eat inside or out, and since it was a nice night, we went with out (though there are heat lamps for the coldblooded among you like myself).

Appetizers:

Fried green beans - Fresh & tasty!  Without the oil at the bottom of the dish, you'd never know they were fried.  We were expecting something more like deep/batter fried beans, but I think actually enjoyed these better.  Crunchy & seasoned with all kinds of goodness.  Highly recommend.

Garlic bread with mozzarella - Pretty much what it sounds like; a half-loaf (meaning a full loaf cut long-ways down the center) of thick garlic bread with a generous amount of fresh mozzarella melted on top & then sprinkled with seasoning.  You could tell that this was VERY fresh mozzarella - it had a very milky character.

Calamari - We went with the calabrasi option, which is slightly spicy.  I liked the flavor of it (sort of smoky & concrete-y), but it was a bit chewy.

We also had a half-bottle of red wine, though I can't remember now what it was.  It was excellent & went well with the food; on the other hand it was $26 for a half bottle.

Pizzas:

There are several options here.  You can get classic Napoletana, a number of traditional Italian-style pies, several NY style options, or one of the Sicilian pan-style pies.  Napoletana, Italian, and NY pies are 12 inch pies with 6 slices; the Sicilian pies are about an inch or an inch and a half thick crunch & serve 2-3, depending on how hungry you are.  We tried:

The Bronx - a NY style pie with salami.  Tasty!  (Then again, I love salami.)  Needed more sauce.

The Original Tomato Pie (De Lorenzo style) - Very basic New Jersey-style pizza - just sauce, cheese, and if you order De Lorenzo style, Italian sausage.  We LOVED the sauce on this one!  Rich, complex, savory, and plenty of it!  I personally thought it could have used more cheese.

Margherita - The Napoletana-style pizza that won the 2007 World Pizza Cup!  (You didn't know there was a World Pizza Cup, did you?  Heh.)  They only make 73 per day, but we were apparently in time for one.  Alas, while it was quite good & there was nothing wrong with it, I would not say it was the best Margherita pizza I've ever had.

Quail Egg with Speck - This was like having breakfast on a pizza; I felt like I was having bacon and eggs (with a bit of spinach), which was actually pretty tasty.  Nothing wrong with that.

So yeah.  Great food & very tasty pizza (especially the Tomato Pie), but I wouldn't say it rises to the food-gasmic level.  Also, kind of pricey for pizza.  After tax & tip, the bill for the five of us was $170.

We stopped by this place after kicking around China Town for a few hours.  It didn't disappoint!  We tried the pesto veggie, meat and veggie combo and the clam and garlic.  Wow!  All three were good, but the clam and garlic was amazing!  It's definitely worth making your way to North Beach for.  We'll be back next time we're visiting SF!

I just love the menu board. Take a minute and read all the little messages on it. It's a crack up. The Garlic/Clam pizza is awesome, crispy, slightly burnt bottom on the crust, just the way I like it. The place is tiny, and packed for a reason.

Best pizza in SF-- or so I thought until I tried Little Star on Divis.  Still, it's right up there.  The dough is kind of focaccia-like with great toppings.  My only gripe is that they could mix up their toppings a little to offer more variety.

Hands down best Pizza in the Bay Area!Every time im in SF i try to stop by Golden Boy for some Grub.The pizza is Great if its not Fresh out the oven they heat it up for you in there Little Toaster,soo hott i've Burned the roof of my mouth Almost Everytime i've been there..The sauce is perfect i hate pizza with to much sauce they way they do it is on point.The only Problems i've ever had with this place is Parking Because its in the Heart of North beach.And Sometimes this places is so Busy it takes 10 minutes just to order your slice even at 3 in the morning ive seen the line out to the Street.Thats how you know its good pizza!
Pizza is great, atmosphere is nice. Hemp beer is good. Fun place all around. Will definately come back next time we're in town!

First of all, a word about the servers, since they seem to be disparaged a lot in some of the reviews here:

They were fantastic, from the host who greeted us, to the bartenders who poured while we were waiting, to the superb servers, who kept things moving out to our table at a steady clip.  And, Tony wasn't there on the night we went!  

Next, a word for Tony Gemignani, who is one of my pizza heroes:

Thank you for bringing the Bay Area a place where they can sample the best of the world's pizza styles under one roof.  

From his world award winning classic Neopolitan pizza to the great interpretations of Chicago and California style, to the addictive New Jersey pizza (I didn't know they served the sauce on top of the pie in the Garden State), every pizza was excellent..

His Cirigliano oven is an item of envy, having come straight from Italy and turning out the perfect slightly-charred crust, perfectly seasoned cheese pizza.  The only rival to this pie in SF I've seen is A16, and their pizzas can be a little inconsistent when it gets busy.  Tony's was perfect.

If you have to have something besides the pizzas, try the truffle fries, which were amazing, and the meatballs.    

For a total pizza experience, provided by a man who is leading the pizza charge in the Bay Area, you've got to try Tony's.

Ah Tony! How much I wanted to love your offering... deep sigh.

Where to start?

We went to Tony's on a Saturday evening. Not the best decision, but I was huuungry for a pizza, and nothing but Tony's would do. The wait's 1.5 hours; but I'll gladly suffer, for Tony's da man.

After suffering through 84 minutes of sheer agony, we finally got our table. We were ready to order before our butts could even touch the chairs.

Tony's is famous for their pizza margherita; and that's what we'd come to eat. Now Tony says that they make only 73 of them with the special San Felice flour per day; and by the time our butts were ensconced in those chairs, the special dough was long gone. But, that's our fault and you can't blame Tony for it. So we ordered the next best thing, the "margherita extra", made with the not-so-special Caputo flour. And we also ordered another type of pizza, the "original tomato pie", also known as the "upside down pizza" with cheeze under the sauce. And, for good measure, the stir-fried spinach with garlic as an appetizer.

Our upside-down pizza came first. It was quite good. The sauce was flavorful, the crust was medium and well done. We quickly dug into it with excitement (and overdue hunger).

Next came the Margherita Extra. Whoa... what a disappointment. Even though both pizzae(?) were supposed to be "medium rustic crust", the M.E. was very thin crust. That, in itself, isn't a killer. The worst part was the sauce: it was absolutely flavorless! It was as if someone opened a can of tomato puree and just poured it on the pizza. There were no herbs or spices in the sauce; and it was thin and runny. And then, there were just 6 basil leaves on the entire pizza. Come on, you need more than just 6 paltry leaves! Anyways: the M.E. was a big disappointment.

One final insult: they forgot to bring the appetizer, and brought it after we'd dug into the pizzas. I'll chalk that up to a busy night; but I'm guessing, with all the hype, every night is probably a busy night for them.

All in all: I was disappointed. Given the crowds and the lack of parking in North Beach, I don't think I'll be back again.

First off, I have to say that you have to be nuts not give this place at least 4 stars. My friends and I came here on a Friday night and it was 1.5 hours wait. Sounds long but the good thing is that after you put your name down, they take down your phone number as well so you can totally hit up a bar or something nearby and wait for the hostess to call you. Now that is customer service!

We got three pizzas between us and a bottle of wine. First we got the Prosciutto Pomodorini. Usually, I don't like arugula but on this pizza it was really good w/ the cherry tomatoes and prosciutto. Then the New Yorker and it was freaking AMAZING. really good italian sausage and the ricotta.. holy cow it is to die for. Super creamy and rich, takes pizza to a new level. Lastly we had the award winning Cal Italia. A white pizza that was also seriously to die for. The wine our waiter paired with our meal was also quite delish and complimented everything.

This is one of those places where you think to yourself 'Man I gotta try everything on the menu and just go down the list' and that is exactly what I am going to do. Every time I come back I'm gonna get something I've never gotten.

Forgive me Tony's Pizza, I was wrong.
I actually wrote a review for the Pizza place up the block saying that they were better than Tony's and that there was no reason to bother with the wait.
WRONG
What happened was I called and tried to order a mushroom and sausage pizza to go and that was a whole confusing ordeal because there are like 10 types of crust and 5 ways to cook it.  I ended up with an ordinary pizza that was no better than the place up the block, which I like anyway.  
I have been here a few times now and had the full explanation of the menu and have tried a few different pizza types.  
Wow, they make Pizza exciting again.  Pizza is delicious, we all know this, but these guys are the experts.  It's like they're putting on a pizza clinic.  
Each time I go I love what I order and I see something else on the menu that get's me excited for the next visit.

I would give 5 stars to this place, because the Napoli style pizza is damn good; unfortunately it gets only  three for the following reasons:

1) It's overpriced ($19 for a pizza margherita, really?).
2) There's a constant line.
3) The ambiance is just okay.

That being said, if you are really craving for a Napoli style pizza, that's the place where you wanna be.

This location of Tony's is located next to the restaurant Tony's Pizza Napoletana next door and is a great alternative if you don't feel like braving the 1-2 hour lines just to sit down. You simply order at the counter and your order comes out 15-20 minutes later (unless you order one of the slices already behind the counter.) The quail egg, white rose potato and guancale Californian style pizza comes highly recommended.

The ingredients include: mozzarella, white rose potatoes, rosemary, calabrese peppers, chorizo, quail eggs, guanciale (pork cheek), cowgirl creamery fromage blanc, lavender sea salt. The potatoes are thinly cut and offer a lovely unexpected crunch in the pizza. The cheese is creamy and provides a great burst of flavor. Oh and the quail eggs are soft-cooked and still runny on the inside--perfect for smearing over the rest of your pizza.

We also got the gigante meatball with marinara sauce. At $9 for a giant meatball, it's a little pricey, but definitely worth trying once.

Carry your selections outside to the little sidewalk deck with cute tiled tables for a lovely summer night meal. I guess we ordered right because as we ate, a few different people at neighboring tables looked on enviously and asked what we ordered.

Outstanding!
We weren't expecting such a light, crispy and airy slice of pizza after seeing the size of the crust. Boy were we surprised by the complex flavors and light, airiness of the crust..absolutely delicious. The gal behind the counter was so friendly and helpful too..loved it!

Got here by chance after getting hungry and my friend said locals usually comes here to grub. I said let's go and when I got there it took me by suprise its a small place with people brushing aginst you when they go by. I order a slice with clam and a slice of pepperoni both were delicious. The clam piece I would eat it any time I get a chance it was that dam good. Never had rectangular slice of pizza anywhere before it was my first time. Will probably order a whole pan next time lol.

best pizza in North Beach , BRING BACK THE DRAFT ROOT BEER
love the place , bath room scarrrry , part of its charm

we had just come from a small dinner, but i was pretty full. because of this, i didn't even have my own slice. just a couple bites. but what i tasted was the best sicilian i've ever had. the pizza was thick, cheesy, packed with toppings, and at a perfect temperature. the sauce was amazing. the prices were awesome($2.75-$3.75 per slice). there was plenty of counter seating. and the young lady working was very sweet despite how many people were there. they have beer on tap and they are conveniently located in the heart of north beach. i will surely be back to have many slices.

Yum! Huge squares for $4 or less! I've tried the cheese pizza as well a the clam & garlic. The dough is thick, chewy, and flavorful. Clam & garlic leaves a STRONG garlic taste/smell in your mouth the rest of the day, but that just means it's doing its job right?? Love it!

I have never found the best slice of pizza in the Bay Area until I came here, not intentionally. I actually had just finish lunch not long ago, maybe 30 minutes? We were walking around the neighborhood and right when I turned my head, I saw  a big sheet pan of hot, fragrant pizza right at my nose level in the front open window. I know I'm a pig and I admit that to anyone and everyone. I really was full but the smell just kept me walking towards the door. I went in and got a slice of heaven! The fact that the pizza is made on foccacia dough, it's a plus already with out tasting it. It's slathered with lots of topping! After taking one bit, I couldn't stop and finished it in literally 2 minutes top. I was SO FULL, I was gonna die from food coma. Worth every pain I had to go through in my stomach after eating that. Not that the pizza had made me sick but because I ate so much food, it made have the BIGGEST food coma I've ever had, and trust me, I've had a lot!

While this place has apparently been an icon of North Beach since 1978, I've only been there a couple of times --but it's already one of my favorites. Unfortunately, I don't live right in the city and can only come occasionally, but it's worth traveling for. It's a small, unpretentious place that always seems to have a line. Among other things, this means the pizza is always fresh from the oven. One of the main problems with average pizzerias is that you get stale slices that have been sitting around for a while. That never happens here. I generally prefer plain cheese, but they have a variety of other kinds as well, such as pesto, vegetable and various meat toppings. The only bad thing I can say about a place like this is that it makes ordinary pizza, which you get in most places around the country, harder to tolerate. But I appreciate that there are still people who make quality, reasonably priced and delicious foods the traditional way.
3.5 reminds me of pizza rustica in miami.  slices go out pretty quickly.  sausage slice -- need to cut into 4s to get 1 sausage on each piece.  stopped by to check out the canada/usa hockey game...
one of my favorite pizza place. pretty nice place to eat pizza with beer.
Super good pizza!!! It's a little hidden spot, but super good! Cash only- ATM in the back :)

Amazing food! I really love the mussels, the pasta was delicious as well but if it had more sauce it would've been perfect, the lasagna  was amazing and really saucy. I would definitely come back here again if I had the chance to. I checked if there were any other chains and sadly this place doesn't have any :( overall the staff was really nice and the food was delicious!
Best pizza I've ever had! They have tons of different styles with different types of ovens. Really a unique pizza experience.
Worth the wait in line for table..the New Yorker pizza was sublime.  Situated in North Beach and quite easy to find.  Fried calamari was fantastico too.  Wil definitely be back

First of all, who are these morons who get really hammered, go to a restaurant then still feel it necessary to post a review on Yelp?  "I know I was really drunk when I ate there, but I just wasn't that impressed".   Here's a clue hammerhead:  don't post a review.

I don't read the long reviews, so here it is.  Tony's is the best pizza in SF.   In ANY category (deep dish, thin crust, Sicilian, etc.).   Very authentic and fresh.  The meatballs are also slamming.  

Bit of a wait, so go early (before 6).

This is right up there with the best pizza I have ever had. The place is always busy and rightfully so, but it's worth the wait. Here are some tips from my experience there.

If you have a party of 2-3 people, put your name on the table list when you arrive, but check the bar top every so often for open seats. The same full menu is available at the bar and more than likely you will be sitting down before your normal table would be ready. Also, the bartenders are very knowledgeable and personable so that makes the dining experience that much better. If you have a party of 4 or more, you will be waiting so don't be too mad when the hostess tells you it'll be an hour or two.

As far as pizza goes, I suggest ordering two pizzas from different menu sections and planning on taking home the leftovers. The combo my party of three had was the Margherita and the New Yorker. This allowed us to taste two very different styles of pizza and topping combinations. There were about three slices left which made for an excellent breakfast the next day. Overall an excellent place turning out great pizzas.

In 2010 I joined yelp and wrote a review for Tony's. In 2012, I returned to Tony's. My boyfriend was buying me lunch. He said I could have anything. I said....I want the margherita pizza. His eyelids dropped a little and his jaw clinched ever so slightly. I could tell...he was thinking....."What no meat!?" So...I bucked up, and I delved deeper into the menu. I swallowed hard and looked at the "Americano" section. This seemed like a bad idea. A very bad idea.

Then...the Old Smokey called out to me like a beacon...nay...bacon of light. (why not right?)

We ordered. We ate. And we ate some more. We delighted in the fried breaded? bacon. Then we squealed with glee over the fresh beef bursting with flavor. We shrieked over the creamy rich and yet spicy bbq sauce. My boyfriend gulped down his third piece and euphorically asked..."What is on this pizza???" Cilantro my love. Cilantro.

Then we agreed it was the best we had ever had.

Best pizza I've ever had! After having tried Michael's pizzeria in long beach (which had beat Tony's as the best pizza in the country) I knew I had to try this place. I ordered the cal italia which is one of their most popular dishes and it was perfect. If you are in the San Francisco area you have to try this place.

AMAZING!  Since the first bite it's been my favorite place for pizza...EVER.  The drinks, appetizers, and desserts are great and the staff are very attentive and friendly.  

Note: There is almost always a wait to get a table so keep this in mind when going.  It's always worth the wait.

Rolled into town today and my daughter asked for pizza, but not that regular ol' pizza. Quickly yelped and found Tony's. It was a quick walk up from the Wharf and boy were we glad we picked it!

We had the Eddie Meunster, which was freaking to die for. 13 year old daughter says the ambiance, food and awesome music causes us to give a solid 5 stars.

Try this pizza. Seriously.
Fantastic pizza!!!  You're going to have to wait because there is always a line but truly worth it.  The meatballs were amazing as well!!!  Highly recommend.

My boyfriend introduced me to this pizza place, and I've got to say I'm hooked! Best pizza by the slice place in North Beach, by far. The pizza is always boooomb, and they have several selections to choose from already made, and just pop it in this little oven behind the register to reheat it (which I don't mind at all since the pizza is always so so good!) Also, they have very limited seating and they tend to get pretty packed on the weekends between 10-2 am when the North Beach drunk crowd decides they're hungry, so I usually take my slice to go. Best place to go for a quick, thick, tasty slice of pizza. And I hear they've opened up a location in San Mateo recently so it'll be good to have a Golden Boy on the Peninsula! Knocking one star off because this place is CASH ONLY! Ugh!!

something in their sauce...is it cocaine?  whatever it is, i'm addicted, plus a pitcher of hemp ale (a ha more illegal substances???) is really cheap and tasty.  if i'm in north beach, you can bet i'm there.  oh yeah, its just far enough off columbus to keep the tourists away.  for me, that's a good thing.
good slices.  this place is a nice for simple late night food.

Apples-to-apples disclaimer: this is the best pizza you will ever order through a window and wait to be re-heated.  No hand-crushed, locally grown organic spelt grain crust with special Napa goat cheese toppings here.  This is more like those big puffy squares of pizza they gave you in elementary school except the dough is delicious and crispy and not nearly as puffy, the sauce is pleasantly spicy and the toppings are "all growed up."  I try not to leave any visit to SF w/o picking up at least one slice to take home.  Usually the clam and usually accompanied by at least a second slice of pesto.  Plus I think I met Amos Lee here but I can't be sure.  That is neither here nor there, I suppose.

There aren't too many things in life more satisfying than a 1am hot slice of sausage pizza @ Golden Boy after a few rounds of drinks.  Just make sure you're not here too late or you'll find yourself in the back of a long line praying to the man above that a slice remains when your number's up!

When I was 17 I used to go here and eat several slices of pizza with a root beer.  I also used to order it to go, the issue was the pizza never made it home.  I've revisited since and coupled the pepperoni with a guinness, now that does the job. While it may be lost on some I always enjoyed looking up at the ceiling pretending you're eating in a train car.  Warning: the pizza is addicting and will power won't help you.

We ate the garlic pizza which was super good and the clams were perfectly seasoned. We also had the combo which was so full of mushrooms, sausage, tomatoes, onions and melted mozzarella--lots of it. The crust was crispy on the outside but on the thicker side. It was amazing! However, seating is limited and the music was quite loud. If they also had salad, that'd be a bonus to the delicious pizza! Overall though, I was EXTREMELY satisfied by the pizza and would go back in a heartbeat!
It was ok, nothing to write home about. I feel like a lot of people eat this after a night out when everything tastes great.

excellent pizza. the employees arent always the friendliest but i give them credit since the place is always pretty busy. a very cozy atmosphere, and good for a quick eat. a must try if you're in to pizza.

Love the atmosphere and music! Very relaxing and laid- back, server was very friendly. We ordered a slice of garlic & clam, pepperoni, pesto vegetarian. Pesto vegetarian was our favorite! We went ahead and got a second order of that.
not exciting taste-wise, but a good way to soak up liquor!

yes. good pizza. not your traditional triangular shape though, but thick and rectangular and full of flavorful toppings.  its best when they have it fresh from the oven.  friendly staff and great food - an awesome straight to the point joint in north beach. and just a note, beware of the long lines that form on the sidewalk.  you know what that means, you should line up too =)
Nice, thick crust-vegetarian pizza is excellent. Family had pepperoni and enjoyed it as well. Loved it!
not particularly enamored with the $3.50 lukewarm veggie combo slice (omg, it's square!  omg, cornmeal crust!), but after a $10 pitcher of stella, i have fond (albeit hazy) memories of this place.
go get the clam/garlic! one of the best pizzas I've ever had.
so good.  the best of course when you're drunk and hungry.  but pretty much great any time of day.
love the garlic clam! their specialty! thats the only thing i get here because its so good. had 2 slices! a good slice of pizza is hard to find and golden boy delivers! big time!

The fact that this place has such a high rating has further reinforced my belief that people on the West Coast don't know what good pizza is. It's completely bland; I have a hunch that folks like this place more for its hole-in-the-wall diner-like atmosphere than its food.

Went here  on a Friday night.  The line was long and we had to wait outside.  The girl at the counter was very rude and charged us for 3 slices when we had only bought 2.  The pizza was good but service was bad.

We bought a few different slices (cheese, pepperoni, and clam). It was delicious with the bottom slightly crunchy and the rest super hot and soft. The cheese and pepperoni were our favorite! Will definitely go back to try the other slices and get a whole pie for gatherings!!!
People watching haven. Loved the crust. Right amount of sauce for the veggie pizza. Best in Little Italy! Nice staff btw!

GREAT pizza!! Finally after multiple attempts, we were able to try Tony's. Go early and go on a rainy day - it works! Three different pizzas each with a different sauce for a distinct taste! Definitely going back!

I'm going to say, I didn't love this pizza. It's voted some of the best pizza in the US and I have to say, I just don't agree. The oven pizza was good but the crust wasn't crispy and felt too soft to me. It really depends on how you like your pizza I suppose, but with all the hype centered on this pizza I just don't think I'd vote it some of the best I've ever had. That being said, the service was great and our dessert (tiramisu) was incredible.

TIP: To avoid the wait, see if you can't get there around 5/530 ish and put your name in. They were prepared to seat us right away but we were waiting for friends so we asked to be seated at 730 and they were wholly accommodating.

I would certainly say this is a fun destination spot and to give it a try, just don't expect to have the best pizza of your life.

We heard a two hour wait. Walked up to host and gave our name; they took a number to text us and told us about an hour. Great, we grabbed a beer next door and 25 minutes later we had a table! Must confirm and have WHOLE party there in 5 minutes to be seated. We got the gigantic meatball for an appetizer; it has veal, sausage, and pork. It rivals my great grandmothers recipe. Then the margaherita pizza. Everything a true Italian pizza should be. I can't say enough, this is a MUST. HAVE.

Dang Tony! This pizza was amazing. I wouldn't think that San Fran would have good pizza but this place is great! The Ol' lady and I sat at the bar rather than wait for an hour. The bartender was real solid, JP, he told us what to order. We ordered the New Yorker and it was fabulous. If your wife doesn't chicken out, get the Motorhead Detroit style also. Hit this place up.

Waited an hour for a table. It was worth it! We hung out at Washington park across the street. Friendly staff and delicious pizza and pasta. Afterwards we ate gelato across the street! Pistacio is best!

This yelp member has been out of reviewing commission for a while but after eating at this place, Tony gave me something to yelp about!
Delicious! Wonderful service....
We ate with a party that had 6 people and it was perfecto!
Spicy Calarmi, deep fried string beans, Cesar Salad were all wonderful starters to this meal. The Pizza Margherita, the Salsiccia and the Bronx were also equally delicious.
The Panna Cotta and the Affagato were all the perfect ending to an outstanding meal!

Oh perfect Christmas Eve! Who knew I would experience you before the end of the world. And I almost believed the Mayans too with SF on this day- deserted, slightly eerie and even more romantic. We even had awesome weather- cool, crisp, with just enough warmth radiating from the one sunny day in Norcal Winter.

We walked hand in hand to Tony's, the one and only, hahah. Okay maybe there are a few places with the same name in Little Italy, but this is the only Tony's that matters. We walked through the door and stood at the desk where they greeted us and seated us within five minutes, not bad.

Our server recommended a carafe of pinot. It was smooth, velvety, and opened up like a rose. Then our meatballs arrived. I cut into my steaming hot ball, so damn juicy. I moved each piece around in sauce for perfect flavor all the way to the very last bite.

Finally our Margherita, "900 degrees wood fired to perfection pizza" was delivered and I sat mesmerized. I was taking a mental picture of little mozzarella pools slightly bubbled up on our thin fluffed up crust. Was this dough brought back in a time machine from 19th century Naples. Did they bring back Raffaele Esposito to make his pizza for our last meal? What a way to go!

"Drinking good wine with good food in good company is one of life's most civilized pleasures."---     Michael Broadbent
Good wine? Check
Good food? Check
Good company? CHECK
Our dining experience may have been a civilized pleasure, but an experience like this made me want to do uncivilized things.

This review is dedicated to :!

The Romana is the one of the best pizza's I've had. Ever had that problem when you could never decide what pizza toppings to get? The Romana has you covered. It's an enormous pizza split into 4 flavors with 6 slices of each flavor. I had Romana #2 (you can choose from 4 flavors) with 5 people, and we struggled to finish it. At $35 and feeding 5 comfortably, it's a good deal in my book.

We also tried the award-winning margherita as an appetizer because we just had to try it. It was excellent. Must-try if you are a "no-bullshit" pizza type of person.

I don't have much to comment on service as I went for lunch (right at noon when they opened). I'll probably continue to do so because when we left the lunch line was huge.

FIRST IMPRESSION:
My friends and I went to Tony's slice shop (next door to the restaurant) to satisfy our sudden urge for pizza. We were greeted with a small storefront churning out some absolutely delicious slices!

THE EATS:
The group ordered just about everything they had, and it was all good, but I have to highlight two pizzas specifically.

1) California -- This pizza had meatball, garlic, ricotta, and Parmesan (beyond the pizza pie staples). The cheese was hot and stringy, giving you that sought-after commercial-style bite that really takes two or three to get it all. Ricotta gives this pizza a surprisingly sweet side, balancing out the salt in the mozzarella and meats.

2) Romana -- I'd compare this pizza to a margherita pizza, as the main topping was tomato. But add some shredded basil and a sweet and tangy balsamic demi glacé drizzle, and you'll learn to love the spectacular balance of acid, sweet, and salty. So good!

THE VERDICT:
This was some of the best pizza I've had. I'm no connoisseur, but I do know good food when I come across it. This will most definitely be a repeat stop on all my future San Fran visits. Yum!

The pizza was very very good, though I don't believe probably quite the best in the city. The crust is thick and fluffy and it's light on sauce. It wasn't greasy at all which was awesome. I really like the atmosphere. It's a small dark hole in the wall with lots of random things and stickers on a wall from past patrons. They were playing heavy metal music pretty loudly which fit those that were working there. Although it doesn't seem like a family friendly place, the help was very friendly and interactive with the kids when they wanted to watch them make the pizza. It's a perfect place to get a slice to go, but it's also a fun lively place to stay and eat if there's a stool available.
My go to pizza joint. I love foccacia. Slice of sausage. Slice of pepperoni. Never had a bad slice.

So this review is 1 month late. I am a transplant from South Chicago..... So like every other Chicagoan I like pizza just as much as every New Yorker. I lived in North Beach for a long while but every time I would walk by Golden Boy nothing but long lines. I have tried many many pizza places and will say little Italy in San Francisco Doesn't impress me pizza wise at all. The dough and sauces are all off IMO. Eventually I was strolling through the area with my best friend and saw that there wasn't a line! So we jumped on it and went in. The woman who was working was extremely polite very cool enthusiastic employee I wish I remembered her name she does deserve credit. I purchased 8 slices of pizza. Four for me four for my friend. The pepperoni and pesto slices 2 each for me. I can't remember what my friend ordered, but we were both impressed with  the quality

It was the Giants parade and there was only one girl working, so I waited online for about twenty minutes. The pizza was great, but as a New Yorker I don't deal well with lines, especially long ones. I recommend the only one I tried, the combination - yum!

Hands down the BEST "slice" in the city. Everything is fresh, from the hand made dough to the daily delivered veggies. Its all done Sicilian style and very simple. It makes me laugh when someone pops in looking confused and says "..what've you got?" when there are plainly only five styles laid out in front of 'em (although the clam and garlic slices are conspicouously concealed at the end of the cheese slices)The pesto-veggie is great and the combo is packed with tons of great stuff. Good beers on tap, and a great root-beer on tap for the kiddies (free refils).   If you can get a stool at the main counter on the weekend you are in for a treat. Tony is a freakin' riot...loud music and lotsa laughs ask him for the wireless controller if you wanna try your skills at the playstation hidden behind the counter. I know everyone has their favorite spot for pizza, and I have my favorite for an entire pie, but the heavy-weight champ of pizza by the slice is definitely Golden Boy.

I don't crave anything in North beach. except This pizza. it's so good i can't even explain. there's only a couple places that make me want to start eating meat again. this is one of them. their pepperoni pizzas make me salivate to no end. i'm salivating as i write this. what a palette tease. (sigh)
best pizza in sf. nuff said.
delicious sicilian style pizza.  tasty anytime of the day, and at it's best after 2am!

Went for a trip to San Francisco for the weekend. We went for a seg way tour of the town and the guy doing the seg way tour highly recommended the Golden Boy pizza. The next day we wne t to Golden Boy pizza for dinner, the line up wasnt to long and moved fairly quick. When it was our turn to order we chose the clam and pesto and cheese. The guy behide the counter was running the place on his own because the other employees had left for the day. Let me tell you he handle the place well on his own. When it comes to pizza this place knows how to make a great pizza, and great toppings. I will return one day for sure!!!
their square pizza is to die for! i always get the vegetarian pesto pizza. i think the magic is in the crust. it's the perfect thickness and it has such a nice crisp!

Hands down...best pizza! You may have to wait up to 90 minutes to be seated (depending on the day and time) but it's well worth it. Put your name in and walk across the street to OJ's bar to have a drink or two. They will text you when your table is ready. If you're not in the mood for meat, get the Margarita. Otherwise get the New York. The meatball appetizer is the best I've had. I forgot to mention the service is great and there's a cool vibe at the bar. They play reggae and r&b music.

We ate here three days in a row... Need I say more? Saw this place written up in Sunset magazine on my flight down to San Francisco and decided it was serendipity. We did the "buy by the slice" restaurant next door to the sit down and as such, never waited to order and only waited about 5 minutes for our slices to toast up in the coal oven.

Our friend came into town the second day we were here and wanted to order a gluten free pizza for himself at the place we had raved about. He was thrilled with his mushroom and truffle oil pizza. As for us, we ate the margherita and picante pizzas, along with the sausage calzone. The calzone was a little bland for me, but I could eat either of the other two slices tomorrow and be trilled to be eating them for the fourth day in a row. Really. That stuff is addictive. On second thought, this is actually a warning that you, too, may be sucked in to eating here repeatedly and kept from trying new things due to your cravings. Just saying...

Really good pizza.

I fell in love with pizza in Napoli, at this little hole in the wall restaurant called "Pizzeria De Matteo". Every time I go to Italy I'd make sure to get over to Napoli for this particular pizza. A simple marguerita served on a tin plate, with the pizza spilling off it, topped with gorgeous basil and olive oil. There are few meals that give such a simple and basic level of satisfaction.

I wouldn't say that Tony's quite hits that mark, but they aren't far off. In all fairness I made the mistake of ordering a rustic crust when what I really wanted was the classic Napoli crust, which is super thin. That being said, although what I did get wasn't quite what I wanted, it was very good. I also tried a slice of their quattro formaggio and one with fig on it. Those were both good, but I'm a sucker for simplicity.

Next time, and there will definitely be a next time, I will order their classic Napoli marguerita and perhaps the rating will go from a 4 to a 5.

Friday night dinner at 6 pm. Near immediate seating. Wait staff was pleasant. Gave us a run down of the different pizza's and how they are strategically arranged on the menu. Go for the "T" down the middle was my impression.

Bruschetta - Awesome. Heirloom tomatoes. Yum yum. How can you go wrong. Delicious. The plate was also nicely decorated by a frame of olive oil and basalmic vinegar drops.

Meat balls - Awesome. My only criticism is that they could have been a little hotter and maybe a bit of searing on the outside to aid a bit of crisp texture. Otherwise no complaints.

Magherita pizza - Gotta go for the Gold right! The porcelain tower plate was a nice touch. Fabulous. Delicious. I can see how others may not like it. The center part of the pizza (the tips of each slice) was soggy. And yes there is a bitterness to the crust. But that sogginess was actually pretty damn good because all the flavors are concentrated at the tip and the dough kinda mops up all the flavors. Besides on bite the tip is gone and you're on to the rest of the pizza with a perfectly crisp and dry crust. As for the bitterness, that's a taste preference. I personally like the bitterness. Dunno how to explain it except that I liked it. It's kinda like a dark chocolate vs. milk chocolate thing.

Well worth it. Gonna come back for the other pizza flavors next time. Can't wait. Good job Tony.

A 1.5 hour wait is no problem, as long as you deliver solid Pizza like Tony's. Baseball playoffs on the Bar TV, cold beer on tap, great friends, great conversation and to wrap it up, some of the best pizza I've had at a restaurant (I'm kind of weird in that I love Round Table above all others).

We had the Margherita and the Sicilian style Colombo.  Both were outstanding and left me very stuffed and happy. Service was solid and prices very reasonable ~ only about $20 per person for the two pizzas, a salad, plate of meatballs and sodas.

4.5 stars for this wonderful slice of pizza heaven!

You haven't truly had good pizza until you've dined at Tony's Pizza Napoletana.  Seriously.  The pies here are THAT good - and it doesn't surprise me that the Margherita is acclaimed and has won honors!  The dough is always the perfect consistency - crispy and chewy at the same time.  I usually don't eat crusts of pizza because there is too much dough, but the crusts on these babies are pretty much doomed when I'm here.  I've tried several different kinds of pizzas on the extensive menu and look forward to my next trip here.  I'm salivating as I write this review.

Yes! Tony's has opened pizza-by-the-slice next door!  

Absolutely delicious and staff are very nice.  I just wish they offered more variety including a good veggie option by-the-slice.

Pricey but worth it!  (avoid getting a drink - splurge on the pie and get drink at corner market)

In a neighborhood full of pizza and pasta options, Tony's is one of the few that we frequent again and again. The casual atmosphere and good food make it a perfect spot for meeting up with friends.

One of my favorite things about this restaurant is that though they don't take reservations, you can leave your cell number and they will call when a table is open. Since we live so close, this means I can put my name on the list then either have a glass of wine at home or head to Tony Nick's for a cocktail or two. Beats awkwardly standing outside the bathrooms waiting for a table.

I think this place is best for a group of 4-6. Any fewer and it is hard to justify getting more than one pizza and it is much more fun to sample and share. Any more and it is hard to get a table in this cozy space.

Our faves are:
- The Margherita (only 73 made per day)
- The meatballs
- The Salsiccia pizza

And while the prices may be a bit high for medium sized pizzas, you have to appreciate that the reason they don't taste the same as the pizza around the corner is because all those quality ingredients are flown in straight from Italy. Yumm!

Holy Moly.
I went here about 6 months ago and told Stacey T we had to go when we both were in town. It was better than I remembered!!
Sure its super crowded and they do not take reservations. -But they take your cell # and will call you when your table is just about ready.
I love meatballs, just like anyone else, but I had NO IDEA meatballs could taste so good! They are easily overlooked on the menu, but soooo worth getting.
Their signature margherita is the best pizza I have ever had. ...and I have had alot of good pizzas.

Best NYC slice in San Francisco. Cheese was melty, sauce was so fresh and tomato-y and the crust was perfect. My BF used to live in NYC and is my personal pizza expert.. it got his stamp of approval which is huge.

Trust.

I liked this place.  Simple bar like setting.  I had the combination pizza and liked it a lot!  It was better than the other place I went to a couple doors down.  Last weekend I was on the search for the best pizza in North Beach that was served in a bar/cafe like setting . Only made it to 3 places before I got full.
golden boy's is the perfect food after a night out in north beach.   so yummy especially when you get one fresh out of the oven.  my go to's are the  combination or the vegetarian.

this is my go to place for fast pizza when my boyfriend and i crave pizza. they always have fresh baked pizza at the window and you can have your pick with what you fancy. the pizza is a perfect ratio of pizza dough with the cheese and toppings. each bite is very delectable. just one slice is not enough. just try this place if ever you are in north beach.
Close to 10pm, 9 months pregnant. Must have pizza right this second. A big, satisfying pizza. These giant, doughy squares of hot cheesy goodness hit the spot big time.

Two slices, a bud lite, and a cup of SF's finest water for $10 flat. Not bad. Cash only. I dropped by here during the North Beach Festival with my husband. We heard from my friend that we needed to try the pesto clam pizza which was very garlicky. It was good but I think I am going to just get the sausage with veggie slice next time. The crust is nice and chewy with the right amount of crisp on the bottom. My husband had a slice of the pepperoni pizza. He enjoyed it. Line was long but the guy who served us was nice. There were two lines, one outside which was moving slower than the line inside.  We grabbed two stools in the back and enjoyed our pizza there.
