Only had the cheese. Great in a thick crust, ample cheese. 4 stars even after accounting for the patriotic regalia, which is over the top.
good, cheap and next to Gino & Carlo
Cheap fast late night spot in North Beach. The square pizza is a real hit, and served up later into the evening. Really like the sausage pizza, along with veggie.
Awesome pizza, great crust!  Love getting pizza from here after a night of drinking.  Definite must if you are in the area and in the mood for a slice.
Somehow every time I try to eat here the fates work against me and it never happens. Last time I was in line for a slice and they closed the front door on my face. Jerks.

SUCH a good and legit pizza place. the place itself is small and narrow and it gets a bit stuffy towards the back of the joint but its worth it. i got the pesto vegetarian pizza which was sooooooooooo good. i havent really had anything like it and i loved the dough-iness of the pizza. my boyfriend and i were craving it the day after we had it. were definitely going to go back!!!

Best pizza I've had in a while. Place is a total shithole but those places usually breed the best pizza. Don't expect nice service but you get what you pay for. one or two slices of 3 dollar pizza was enough to eat. Well worth the price. YUM

love this place! my family and i were in san fran and once we passed by the wonderful aroma of golden boy, there was no turning back.  we got a couple pitchers of beer and sat and enjoyed a wonderful slice of pesto vegetable pizza.  never had anything like it before.  

i will come back here very soon

small place.
best pizza.

love love love their pizza!
i always used to have my golden boy fix. i moved but hey! they opened one up in san mateo so the lower half of the peninsula can enjoy some too!

the boys that work here are so nice and polite, i know some of them are brothers

friend from Atlanta was shocked that i had not been to golden boy pizza (which he apparently tries to stop at whenever he makes it to SF) several months ago.  did not seek it out.  drunk one day, wandering back from bar, found the deliciousness that is golden boy.  damn, that was a decent slice. didn't actively try and return.  friend moved into neighborhood.  stopped by for quick bite. doh.  now i am hooked.  great pizza, ok beer selection, friendly staff. doesn't dethrone  Pino's Pizza in boston, which holds a special place in my heart, but a very good (square) slice.

This is an excellent option when you had a couple of glasses of wine across the street to pop over for some great slices.  It's our go to for years and we still love to make a stop when visiting the Bay Area.

This place was okay, and if it weren't for the crazy number of five star reviews I would probably give it three, but... really? The best pizza you've ever had?? Do you live in a box?? Have you not been to Delfina, Flour+Water, Little Star, Zero Zero? I was craving pizza the other night and hopped onto Yelp. This place had really high reviews so my husband and I headed over to North Beach. It was like 11:30pm on a Saturday night, so we got to stand in line in front of a bar where a myriad mix of drunk sloppy people hobbled in and out, many of them deciding to join us in line. My guess is that this is where most of their Yelp reviews come from-- if you are drunk and hungry on a Saturday night and you are near this place, then get in line and you will be greatly rewarded. The Sicilian crust will do its best to absorb your Kamikaze shots. One thing I will say about this place is that the sauce was very flavorful. I would totally come back here again if I were nearby and hungry for a quick bite, but it's not worth traveling to and is definitely not close to the best pizza you can get in the city.

Staff are very friendly and nice. Food price reasonable. Quality is awesome for the price. Good menu selection. I taste their Pep,Italian Sauage, Combination their good. Have good crust flat bread style.  If you like pizza i would recommend this place to you.

Square slices, crisp, foccaccia style crust.  Sauce is a little sweeter than NY style. Cheese was good but not memorable. Not greasy at all and it was so hot it burned my mouth so I'll give it 4 stars, instead of 3.
So good! Cash only. Great atmosphere. Seating along long bars in the back looking at walls covered with stickers. Casual. Accepting. Wonderful slice of pizza with beer, wine, or soft drink.

Avoid this place at all costs. I called in to order a pizza, and they told me it'd take 50 minutes. So, I showed up in 50 minutes and paid. And, guess what!  They lost my order.

No one apologized and it took them another 10 minutes to find a manager (who was also rude) to get me a refund.

This place thinks they can treat people like crap just because they're popular with tourists, and I'm, for one, over it.

I hope the owner teaches his or her staff some manners and professionalism.

Go up the street to North Beach Pizza for better service and nicer people. (Oh, and if you ever actually want to eat the pizza you ordered!)

Tony's Coal-Fired Pizza and Slice House makes some of the absolute best sandwiches that you will ever encounter.  In other words, I couldn't disagree with Nick B. anymore if I tried.  

My husband and I are big fans of Tony's, but hate the long wait.  We were convinced that Tony's Coal-Fired was a nasty knock-off of the original and refused to visit the joint for several months after its opening.  However, after we discovered that Tony Original and Tony Coal-Fired are the same Tony, we tried it out... and LOVE it!  It's our favorite go-to spot in the neighborhood.  We have taken visitors and locals alike.  Out of probably 15 different people only 1 person hasn't loved it -- he's only "liked" it.

Here are our favorite sandwiches in order of awesomeness:
- Turkey Club
- Meatball
- Reuben
- Rachel
- Italian Beef (the one with cheese)

Many of the others are great, too, but these are our standout favorites.  

Tony doesn't simply know pizza, he knows good food.  On the next sunny day, I recommend walking over to Tony's, buying a sandwich, and heading to Washington Square Park to eat.  You won't be sorry.

The first time I came here was amazing - pizza was perfect, service was really friendly, and the whole experience was great.  

The second time was less enchanting but still solid.  The pizza was still great and we got in there early enough to get one of the limited-number/prize-winning margherita, which was delicious.  My personal favorite was the sicilian with lil cherry tomatoes, and a drizzle of balsamic - so so so good.  Less impressive was a primavera option - the piave seemed out of place and the tomatoes were sort of hard and chewy.

The biggest concern I had, on the second visit, was with the hostess.  She was just really hostile and cranky.  We were waiting on the 4th member of our party - and we weren't demanding to be seated or anything (we understood the policy of needing to have everyone there to be seated), so I don't know what the attitude was all about.  But she was straight rude, totally unnecessarily.  I understand it's hard to deal with lots of waiting parties at a popular restaurant, but plenty of hosts/hostesses handle it with grace.  The crowds aren't getting any smaller, homegirl, so you might need to check the crankiness.

Busy busy busy - all the bar seats were filled and soon the booths. My sis and I were seated and ordered cheese pizza with pepperoni (her) and white wine mussels, with deep-fried string beans for me. The beans were delicious and covered with diced garlic but crunchy and good, enough for three hungry people. The mussels had the best taste I've tasted ever though the quantity was less (about 13 pieces), with two toasted bread slices but as they were placed IN the bowl and not on the plate below, it was very soaked BUT tasty!!! VERY busy to the last minute there!!!

We came in last week and were excited to try this place after hearing that it was "the best pizza in America." Overeager, we ordered the margherita pizza, the quail egg/potato/chorizo pizza, and the cal italia pizza. The margherita pizza was decent, but a little bland. It wasn't anything out of the ordinary. On the other hand, the quail egg/potato/chorizo pizza was really, really delicious. I wish that we'd ordered extra eggs on the pizza because the combination of all 3 ingredients tasted amazing. I loved how the unique flavors worked together. The cal italia pizza was also delicious. The slight sweetness from the fig preserve worked well with the different cheeses that were used.

The ingredients were all very high-quality and the flavors worked well together; matched with a perfect-baked crust, these pizzas are definitely contenders for the being the best in America! Needless to say, we left with extremely full and satisfied stomachs.

What's there to say about Tony's that hasn't been written already? I'll try this: they have a garden (and actually harvest their own honey for some of their new pies) on the roof of the building.

Other than that - yes, it's amazing. Yes, there will probably be a long wait if you're coming here any time after 7:30, regardless of the day of the week. Put your name in and head to Dell'uva or Mario's for a glass of wine or a beer before the hostess calls you. And yes, you will likely have Tony himself coming around and checking on you to be sure it lives up to the hype. It will, esp. if you get the Pizza Campari or NY.

Showed up on a busy Saturday night around 645 with a group of 4.  The waiting list is extremely long, and the wait was about 1 hour 45minz to 2 hours.  Went straight to the bar, and got couple seats.  The good thing is that they serve you regular menu at the bar as well, and it's first come first serve.  

The highlight of the night is the Giant Meat Ball, it made of Veal, Pork and Beef.  It's so tender and the tomato sauce has a hint of spicy which made it even better.   It's a must have from the meun.  Besides that, we had both the quail egg, white rose potato and guanciale and Garlic and clam pizza.  The second pizza is lacking of a pinch of salt and some extra garlic.  Other than that, everything else was pretty good.  

Please allow yourself half an hour to find parking in that neighborhood, otherwise there is a parking lot on Vallejo Street between Powell and Stockton.

Overrated!!!  Happily got a seat quickly outside because it was raining.  
Waiter was missing for 15 minutes at a time.
Ordered pizza with a request for non-sweet sauce but got that sweet sauce anyway.  Waiter was like, oh well.
Didn't like the cold buffalo mozzarella on top. Wasn't expecting cold cheese on a pizza.
So spent $30 on bad pizza and bad experience. Done with Tony's.

Plan ahead, there can be a lengthy wait for a seat.  Check in and then plan on walking around a bit, they will call on your cell phone, just don't go too far.  The food was great, we ordered two pizzas, a Stromboli, and a calzone.  We could have dined comfortably on just half of that for four people.  But hey, pizza for breakfast? Classic!  They do have take out if you don't want to wait.
The menu is extensive and even tell how the pie is fired- cool!  The waitress was really nice and made our day - even at 10pm on a Sunday!  Try it, you'll like it!

My bad.. the only other time I was here was on St. Patrick's Day weekend, and I feel bad about the last review I wrote.  My husband told me that during that St. Patty's weekend the pizza wasn't as good - like the flavors weren't all there.  And after my second visit, I realized he was right - probably because it was so damn crazy packed and thus cooks couldn't refine their cooking flavors as usual that crazy weekend.

Well I gave this place another chance over this past weekend, and I have to say... we had some pretty damn good pizza. I always check to see how good a Napoli-style pizza is by ordering the Margarita. And definitely, this one was DAMN delicious!! We also ordered the New Yorker (which I ordered last time I was here) and it was ridiculous... the sauce, the spices in the meat - it was exceptional. Then we ordered the arugula and prosciutto pizza - REALLY good, though I thought the grease from the cheese spread onto the arugula, and that was a bit weird, like it wilted the greens a little bit. But I'm not gonna argue at all - pizza was still damn good.

Nonetheless, this place rocked this time, and NOW I understand why everyone talks about Tony's in North Beach! DEFINITELY a must-go-to if you are in North Beach, especially with a group of friends.
Love Golden Boy especially the clam and garlic.  Laurie provides amazing service.

It might seem as though i give 5 stars to everything, but the way i see it i only take time to write reviews for places i feel deserve 5 stars.  why publicly bag on other places.  they know they're bad.  and i'm not talking michael jackson bad.

So me and my brother and cousin stumbled upon this heavenly spot on my 21st birthday (a few years back), so naturally drunkeness leads to hunger.  This was the closest spot open past the bar hours, so we said f it, let's just get this.  we thought we were in heaven.  we got the pesto vegetarian (because that's what was left), and were more than pleased.   but then again we were drunk....

...which spurned a second trip to golden boy when my brother visited me again.  oddly we kept thinking about this spot individually ever since, it went a little something like this:
me: what do you wanna do when you're up here? you wanna go anywhere in particular?
brother: no, not really.
me: are you sure?
brother:  no...
me: okay...
brother:  well, this is gonna sound a little stupid...
me: what?
brother:... you remember when we got drunk in... what is it called... north bea...
me:  I WANNA GO BACK AND EAT PIZZA TOO!!!!!
brother:  BUT WE WERE DRUNK!! DO YOU EVEN REMEMBER WHERE WE WERE?!?!?
me:  DAMMIT!!!!! that's right....

so we ever so desperately combed the north beach area, trying to piece together that night, and after much strain in trying to resurrect the brain cells we killed that night and some sheer luck in recognizing random things from mental snap shots of the night AND LOTS OF WALKING/CIRCLING the same 6 block area, we finally found the hole in the wall.  literally, the hole in the wall, they were doing some facade reconstruction and past it many times during our quest.

so sober taste buds agree with drunk taste buds.  it was delicious.  okay, honestly, the pesto vegetarian could have a little more flavor, but the pros outweigh the cons.  the crust is PERFECTION.  it's like light crispy focaccia.  toppings are tasty.  and even though someone else could label it bland, it still gives me and my brother a sense of satisfaction when we bite into the crispy deliciousness.  clam garlic is DELICIOUS.  you could get cheese, pepperoni, etc, but why? you can get that everywhere else.  and root beer on tap.  what a GREAT idea.  we always make it a point to visit our favorite west coast pizza stop every time he visits me.  the only thing better on the west coast to us is pizzarito in SoCal.  but i heard they closed the one on the west side/manhattan beach.  so golden boy is now number one.  but to me blondies is a close second due to slice size and the blanket of cheese.  I take that back.  what is up with blondie's???  It's seriously been going downhill lately.  sucks, it used to be such a good deal back in the day.  so sad when you cross a good pizza place off your list.  but i had cheesy sticks from west coast the other night, and thankfully those are still delicious.
It will knock ya out!!!  Fast, fresh, great for what it is.  Nice place to take a breather from the bars and get some grub.
let me just say that like Chinese food, pizza in this city is mostly gross but this place has the best pizza I've ever had! the garlic clam and veggie combo slices are the best!
Well worth driving from the east bay just for a slice.  Hands down the best Pizza in the bay area.  Tastes the best at around 2AM after a few bears in.

I defy anyone to try this pizza and tell me it isn't one of the best pizza's ever. Just stroll by Golden Boy, take a look and a sniff of that fabulous pizza as it sits in the front window and you're hooked.  I'm a vegetarian so the Pesto Vegetarian is my favorite but there are varieties of pizza for vegetarians and carnivores alike.  I just had a slice today and it was to die for.  I love everything about Golden Boy Pizza and would even go so far to say it is one of the top 10 pizzas in San Francisco.  So do yourself a favor and get yourself to Golden Boy.  You will be so glad you did.
The pizza is good, but it's by no means mindblowing. It's perfect if you're hungry in the middle of a drunken night in North Beach, but I wouldn't come here sober.

Probably the best sicilian style pizza you can get in North Beach, let alone San Francisco. The texture of the pizzas are just right and every slice is piping hot. The clam garlic and combination are definitely the must-trys. However, for some reason, I don't see how a joint with a hard rock background goes hand in hand with a knife and fork when eating pizza...
Good hangover reliever after a night of drinking. Mariissa rules on Friday and Saturday too.  They are a little cheap on cheese or else five stars.

Perhaps my favorite pizza in town - you can taste the oregano, herbs, garlic, olive oil - all my friends that I have taken there are hooked.  The simple pizzas are my favorite: cheese, or pepperoni, and the sausage is great.  Tip: if you're taking some home and want to reheat a slice or more, the best way is to turn up your oven to the highest on bake, wait for it to get really hot and then throw in the slices on a cookie sheet for about 5-7 mins.  Taste SO much better than reheating them at say 375 degrees for a longer period of time.  I know it might be a waste of energy, but you can't fuck around with good pizza.

If you love pizza like I do, this is the spot.  I have eaten pizza in this town since I was a kid and I love this new place.  Get there early and if you're in a group arriving separately, every man for himself, this joint packs out fast!  I highly recommend the Margherita (and not just because I dated her in high school).  This pizza has it all, chewy crust with just a bit of charring and a perfect sauce...oh, no I'm starting to "Jones" for the stuff!  Really, if you don't like this pizza you are either loaded or addicted to the Costco combo slice with a Diet Coke.  Seriously, this place makes pizza making a religion.
P.S. If the place is full, you can still order at the bar!

I can not stress how much I liked this place! The server does make a difference too! First time was my favorite! We ordered the meatballs (which are totally worth it!!!) and the New Yorker! Oh.my.goodness. The New Yorker was amazing! Hands down my absolute favorite pizza ever! I eat pizza about 3 times a week minimum. All different kinds from frozen to delivery. This is awesome! This pizza has a some burnt areas but that's part of the taste and it's not bad! Yup I said it. Burnt isn't bad. We,however, expected this because we spoke to our server about the options. He told us it would come that way and we loved it!!! During our trip, we ran into some other travelers and I made it a point to mention this place. My whole trip was made because of this place. Needless to say, we went back for a second time and tried the Detroit. It was more a deep style pizza just not as deep. It was good but I would say stick with the thinner crust ones. Also, if there are rowdy kids they tend to give them some dough to play with to help quite them down. We experienced it. Thank goodness for dough!

When I found out that St. Louis style pizza existed in San Francisco, I nearly died! Naturally, because I'm from the "Show-Me State," I was skeptical (yes, this review is about to get cheesy - NO PUN INTENDED, maybe). I've been eating St Louis style pizza since I've had teeth, so I think I'm a pretty good judge of STL or not STL. I am NOT an Imo's fan, which is the McDonald's of STL pizza. I'll eat it if that's all I can get, but I'm more of a Talayna's/Serra's kind of lady. Enough about me, let's get down to the pizza.

A+ for the tiny pepperoni
A+ for the provel cheese
B for the crust. I really loved that it was cut into tiny squares just like back home
C- for sauce. It's really too sweet. I read another review where they agreed. I hope that they change the sauce someday. It tasted better as a leftover, but still too sweet.

If you've never had STL pizza before, tell your friend to get it and try some of theirs. I don't know many people who aren't from Missouri that actually enjoy STL pizza. I love it, but maybe it's an acquired taste? Something about the cheese. Provel is a very melty blend of cheddar, Swiss and provolone.

Anyway, I will definitely go back to Tony's. I do hope that they improve their STL sauce, but there are so many other kinds of pizzas to try. I can't wait to go back.

Five stars for the great staff.

One tip: If you're driving, don't forget to bring quarters. If you happen upon a metered spot, it's $2 an hour/2 hrs max (coins only.) I think that's Mon-Sat. If you forgot to bring change, the Citibank down the street has friendly people in it and they will sell you a roll of quarters.

I loved it. This is probably one of the best pizza places I've been to in the bay area and the closest tasting to a New York Calzone I've had. The Margherita was brilliant. I most definitely could have eaten 2 whole pizzas on my own.

The only problem I have is that it is an hour away from home. And honestly there are just TOO many options (Not saying it is a bad thing, I'm just a simple menu kind of guy), as our group was being read all the options my head started to hurt but for people who enjoy a variety of selections it is truly amazing. All the bread styles, toppings, etc. They have a brick oven that they cook with and it just makes everything so much better!

I went on a Sunday afternoon at around 3 so it was only a 15 minute wait, but I wonder what it would be like on any given dinner time. The service was good, the wait for the pizza was a bit long but worth it, and the overall atmosphere of the restaurant was nice. Must definitely go again.

Great pizza place!! The famed margarita was fantastic, as were the fried dough appetizers! The service was great -- to the extent the waitress even let my daughters order a custom (red cream) sauce for their kid pastas...always like it when kids are kept happy!
Absolutely delicious pizza pizza !!! Totally recommend just be ready for a really long wait time

Congratulations on "The Pies Have It, A passion for pizza, perfection" on the front page of the San Jose Mercury News by Jessica Yadegaran. Today's article mentions Tony Gemignani becoming the first American to win the title of World Champion Pizza Maker.  

I've had the pizza he won with and you can too.  It is drool worthy!

Tony's is the real deal. I am from Italy and I can see why it won the world championship. I got the Margherita and it brought back the flavors from home. They also have other stiles of pizza that are very good.
If you want a taste of Italy, that's the right place to go!

MANAGEMENT AND WAITSTAFF TAKE NOTE---YOUR HOSTESS IS COSTING YOU BUSINESS!

1 star (actually ZERO)  for the "service"  2 on balance---- just because I know the pizza is really good (4-5 star).

Here's the T.  Last night, a Thurs., two of us go there at 9:15 PM.  Several tables outside are empty as we walk by.  I notice a few empty seats at the bar when we enter.  The few tables they have inside are all occupied.  

So, the two of us enter.  There is a "hostess"   at the stand and another young woman off to the side.  The hostess never looks up.  The other woman looked as if she may have worked there or may not have.  She made eye contact and smiled so I assumed she did and said hello.  I said we had a party of two.  The snot-nose at the "hostess" desk looks up abruptly and snaps, "That will be 45 min to an hour!" Then, she zips her yap and looks at me with a pissed off impatient look.    

Multiple tables outside were open as were multiple chairs at the bar.  There was only a group of 3 sitting there waiting ahead of us for MORE than ample seating for all.  Ummmmm and they did not close for nearly two more hours......  

Well, I have no patience for BS from some snotty 20-something Susie so I said we'd pass.  Other hostesses suggest the to go store front they offer next door. This one did not.  She just looked back down and said nothing.  Oh, and by the way when we passed by those empty tables outside 20 min. later they were still EMPTY.

So, Jezzabelle, you just cost your business about $100+ in revenue and your servers an easy $20+ tip!  Not only that, we live here in SF...born and raised.  I've sent a lot of people to Tony's over the years....NO MORE!!!  Now you cost your coworkers and owners a lot more, honey......a lot more than the min. wage they are paying you to turn away business I might add!

I hope your managers and coworkers read this and rip you a new one.......I just did not have the energy to call you out on your piss poor arrogant attitude last night.

Oh yeah, because I knew about the to-go they offer next door we got a few slices......PASS on that.  Only order fresh made.  By the time it sits there in the display for hours it's dry and lack-luster.....you could get the same quality anywhere. Order fresh and get the real experience.

There is nothing I can say that will do this restaurant justice. You have to eat here. Tony has plenty of restaurants with incredibly well trained chefs that cook amazing pizza. I had this pizza roll and this pizza that was just to die for. The interior is a site to see. I enjoyed it here with good friends.

Edit: the cal italia! So rich and a nice thin Crust. And the stromboli...... Omfg......
Great pizza, nothing like throwing down a slice of zza as your stumble home from the bars in Northbeach.

Making pizza that tastes good to drunkards is not exactly a culinary skill.  It would be harder to TRY to make pizza that they WOULDN'T like.  I'm not a square cut fan but wouldn't mind if the pizza was better.  But there are way too many pizza joints with outstanding pizza to settle.

Got into San Francisco late and Sodini's was closed and we were starving. Saw Golden Boy was opened and there were some empty seats at the bar so we went in. Loved the hot, thick crust pizza very much. It reminded me of the deep dish pizza I used to get in Philadelphia as a kid. We all loved it and I was able to get a cold beer and my friend was able to get a glass of wine. The waiter/bartender was awesome. He was very friendly and did a great job of making sure everyone was taken care of in a very efficient manner.

WOW - if you are staying in Union Square, or anywhere near North Beach, and you love pizza, you've got to stop in to Golden Boy.  Don't expect much atmosphere or service.  It's a bare bones kind of place.  The staff was definitely friendly.  The pizza - just a real good taste.  Different for sure.  Not greasy, and didn't 'bother' us after dinner at all.  After walking for hours that day, that pizza was the bomb!  Check it out.
This is my favorite pizza place in the Bay Area. Great  location, fun atmosphere, delicious pizza, friendly staff.  Highly recommended. Have a drink after at Columbus Cafe, also nice.

This is my FAVORITE pizza place in the bay. I have never been disappointed. I have been to sooooo many pizza places in SF and just been plain grossed out. Get the clam pizza... it's the best. ohhh sweet sweet clams...
Whenever I'm in north beach, i absolutely have to get a slice here everytime. they have long lines but it goes by quickly.
Some of the best pizza in the city. There is nothing like a smoking hot center slice of chess from this place.  Sicilian slices at their best flavor and value.  Great hardworking staff too.

Southern Italian pizza enthusiasts mecca! By far the best pizza spot in north beach! Always packed, so be prepared to wait! Although a good way to pass the time, make a new friend with another hungry person in line!

NOT the best pizza in North Beach! I went to four different pizza places in one day, and this was the worst of the four by far. North Beach and Tony's are better options. The tomato sauce is flavorless, the dough can't decide what it wants to be, and the cheese is just o.k. Interior made me feel like I was in a surf town, also.
Love this place. A cold beer with awesome pizza. A tiny little place, probably not a good idea to take a large group unless it's in the middle of the day. Always really loud metal playing.

I love this place.  Been here twice.  It's like a hole in the wall but the food is good which makes up for everything.  The line is long, but don't worry they serve pretty fast.  I recommend this place to anyone.
Hands down the best pizza place in on the planet. If this joint was a woman she would have me wrapped around her finger for life!

I was on a pizza mission and had stopped (on 2 different days) to sample the very thin designer pizzas offered at high rated places in North Beach.  Those pizzas were pretty good but after I had one a few doors down from Golden Boy, I was still hungry.  Walked into the bar and ordered a slice of cheese.  One word, heavenly.  The 1/2 to 3/4 of an inch crust was light and airy.  Great flavor.  The young lady that attended to the heating of slices  was wonderful.....full of smiles and asked multiple times if I'd like a refill on my diet coke.  Just a great experience at about 1/4 the price of the designer pies.  Will return on my next trip to the area.

Best Pizza in SF ...small place with fewer choices and square pizza slices....but undoubtedly the best in SF...Combo and veggie are awesome...yet to try others but certain they'll be as good as these....
Barely lost pizza wars today to Tony's Coal Fired Pizza.

It's okay food, but definitely not real Italian pizza.  I lived in Italy for a year and was hoping to find real Italian pizza in the Little Italy of San Francisco, but this wasn't it.  Overall, it was good pizza, but not what I was looking for.  It is very reasonably priced, however, so if that's what you're looking for then this is the place.  We got two slices of pizza, a beer, and a coke for $11.75 - a deal in this city.

when i'm driving around SF and i see someone eating a pizza slice that is triangle i get sad. its never actually made me cry, but still sad. why you ask? well because the best pizza in the whole world is made at golden boy. and their pizza happens to be rectangle. it also happens to be affordable. come to think of it its also very filling. as for toppings theyve got just about any thing youd think of, and some you probably wouldnt think of. sausage? check! mushroom? check! clam? yes! make that a resounding yes! clam and garlic pizza is the shtuff, and i feel sorry for you if youre too scared. slices run from 3ish to almost 5 per. they open at 11 i think and are open late. beers on tap. wine. soft drinks. its kind of small, and finding a seat is hard (only bar seating available) but its good there or on the go. seriously, listen closely. if you dont know about golden boy pizza youre missing out on one of SFs best kept secrets.

A couple of Saturdays ago I found myself walking around North Beach, just checking out the scene and sipping a few drinks (I am from Seattle so I was just exploring)...On my first pass up the street around 9:00pm I noticed a fairly long line coming from this place...didn't think much about it until I came wandering back down the street about an hour later, and noticed that the line had shrunk to only 4 people...so I walk up to one of the people in line and asked "Hey what's the story with this place?"  The guy I asked turns slowly around to me and says"You don't know?"..."this place is THE BEST PIZZA IN THE WORLD" ..So I say well then I better give it a try, and proceed to order a slice and a beer and sit at the bar...Then my favorite band (Pearl Jam) comes on the pleasantly loud stereo speakers and the beer is frosty cold...and then it happens...I take a bite of what I can hands down say is THE VERY BEST PIECE OF PIZZA I HAVE EVER HAD..then a sip of my ice cold frosty beer...while the PJ song hits it's chorus...A little tear wells up in my eye...Perfect moment accomplished..thank you Golden Boy Pizza!!!!!

pizza.....4 stars! Service 1 star. i would have given this place 5 stars had it not been for the poor attitude of one of the young girls that took the orders. the pizza itself is great. i had actually come here once before and it was closed and so on my next trip to san fran i vowed to go back. i asked the young lady if they had pepperoni and sausage together on one pizza and she said that they were separate and the only one that came with both meats together was a combo pizza with mushrooms and other stuff. so my friend ordered the combo and i said i just wanted the pepperoni for myself. so they brought out a sausage and we were confused as to why they did that and the order taker comes over and says that i ordered the sausage AND the pepperoni, which i did not as i told her that. instead of just saying ok and preparing a pepperoni pizza, she proceeds to tell me that she can make me a pepperoni pizza but she has to charge me for the sausage one too. SORRY that's when this place failed epically. Whether she heard wrong or got things confused or whatever, she should have just said ok, no problem, it will be 5 or 10 minutes for the pepperoni and that would have been fine. But no, after i told her i WAS NOT going to pay for something i didn't order, she clearly was frustrated, had an attitude and snatched the sausage pizza from the counter and throws it away in a trashcan in front of me with an attitude and says something like "fine" and says she will make the pepperoni one. i told her she could save the attitude as it was uncalled for. i will never come back to this place. the pizza is great but i did not appreciate that. i just wanted what i ordered. if she got the order wrong, no problem. fix it and move on but dont argue with customers. never coming back.

Best pizza in SF and quite frankly can compete with any top pizza joint in the US.  Best sweet and hot sausage and peppers on the west coast.  Meatballs are very good as well.  Always crowded with a line down the street, and that line exists for a reason.  Highly recommended.
Best pizza in SF. Classic pepperoni rustic crust is awesome. Get fried artichokes too.

I was in the neighborhood yesterday so dropped by the slice shop hoping to try the Detroit pie, no such luck, so we went next door and ordered a Romana. The pie is huge, rectangular, and comes out on a board.

There are three variations, each divided into three sections with different toppings ("no substitutions"), so it's sort of like getting three small pizzas. Two of the triple combos had one dessertish section (Gorgonzola with sweet figs and balsamic reduction or with dates, pecans, apples, and honey), which didn't sound appealing, so we got the third, which had all savory combos. Pepperoni a bit greasy a la New York "Ray's" style with oil dripping down my wrist, pesto with goat cheese was rich and creamy, ricotta with big slices of fleshy sweet-hot red peppers and linguisa was something new to me. All were pretty good, albeit a bit greasy or juicy, so messy to eat.

The crust was very thin but didn't get soggy. Presumably it was inspired by the famous focaccia / pizza bianca at Forno Campi de' Fiori, and the toppings were loosely inspired by Rome's pizza a taglio aka pizza rustica shops. I doubt there's anything like this in Rome.

The menu says a Piccola ($32) "serves 2-3," but I estimate it was roughly 12" x 27" (about as much pizza as a 20" round pie), so two people would have to have huge appetites to polish one off. Maybe two teenage boys. I think each section was cut into nine rectangular slices.

Coal-oven pizzas including white pie with clam and garlic are now on the menu in the restaurant. That's definitely next on my list.

This is the perfect place to take visitors from out of town.  Over an hour wait for pizza feels like a jail sentence but with a good plan you can pass the time.  They will text you when your table is ready sooooooooooo.....
- That leaves plenty of time to go up the street and grab a snack/candy at Z. Cioccolato's.
-  Then take your sack of snacks/candy to a number of near by bars and get a beer while you await the text from Tony's.  

The menu is a lot to get through especially when your hungry.  I wasn't really paying attention but there are like 2x ovens with varying in 2x-y degrees that cook the pizza 2xy different ways at varying thicknesses with only like 72 margharita pizzas being made per day and on and on and on. (run on sentence intentional).  It brings on the analysis paralysis.

New Yorker is good and not greeeeezzzzy despite the gobs of meat toppings.
Cal Italia was sweet and savory.
Good pies BUT if you just want to get some pizza, I feel like this place is too much work.

You know about risk/reward, how you have to decide if the perceived reward is worth the risk you're taking to achieve it?  Tony's is a question of wait/reward.  Are you willing to wait an hour for solid pizza?  In an area surrounded by pizza places?  Based on the rave reviews, we were, and we were thoroughly meh'd by the experience.

This place needs a bigger space.  A wait at 4:30 on a Thursday is not a selling point.  Inside it's nice and quaint and clean, and service was prompt and friendly, but they needneedneed a bigger space.  The menu is an amazing thing to look at.  They have seemingly dozens of different pizza ovens and make every style of pizza you can conceive of.  Our salad to start was huge and family style and a solid way to start a meal, even if it was mostly greens.

We were irked by the fact that we were told that our first choice of pizza was unavailable because of problems with the oven, only to hear the table next to us order it successfully 15 minutes later.  We ended up with a thin crust mushroom pizza, and it was good, but not great.  Would it have been better if the hype/wait wasn't so intense?  Probably.

So, in conclusion, ask yourself about wait/reward.  Is the wait 20 minutes?  Go ahead, you'll have a solid, authentic pizza.  Is the wait 2 hours?  Go elsewhere, it ain't THAT good.

During a great staycation in North Beach, a local recommended that we try the new place down the street- Tony's.

I have no complaints.... at all.  The bartender was so friendly and even got Tony to bring out a special appetizer for us of figs, Parmesan and a balsamic reduction just cause i mentioned i liked figs.  As for the drinks, they were all amazing, made with fresh, local muddled fruits including a peach Bellini and a white nectarine mint julep.

We shared the Greek salad and "THE" margarita pizza which definitely
deserved to be the 2007 World Pizza Cup Winner in Naples, Italy.   Tony even came back to see how everything tasted.

Top it all off with a delightful affagato.... can't wait to go back!  I just hope that it doesn't get to busy to get a spot at the bar.

I'm almost afraid to reveal my favorite seats in the house - the counter in front of the Neapolitan Pizza oven.  You get front row seats to watch them make your pizza and you get to eat it while it is center of the sun hot. Burnt tongue aside, this is the only way to enjoy a magherita pizza.

The Cal-italia was too sweet and rich for me but don't listen to me. I'm a pizza purist.

Good pizza.  Bad pasta.  My fault for ordering pasta ONE time there... so be warned.

I love their calzone with ricotta.  It isn't a fancy pizza... just a good solid pizza.  Be prepared to wait for a table.

Tony's Pizza Napoletana is a 10 Time WORLD CHAMPION PIZZA MAKER FACT ! HANDS DOWN WORTH THE WAIT ! Tony and his staff are attentive and friendly ..... The Meatballs (Gigantic) and the sauce are out of this world. Now you can eat outside as well as the bar area inside. Great bartenders that make a STIFF DRINK !

When my Cousin and her boyfriend were visiting from ITALY, our family took them here one night . The Best compliment they gave for all the food ....but especially the PIZZA was ..... "It's just like home"

USA Today claimed that this is the best pizza in the country (travel.usatoday.com/dest…) and I thought I'd try.
FI don't eat pizza that often and am far from being a connoisseur but I did find it very good. A shame they ran out of their award winning Margherita so I couldn't try that one, but what we had (New Yorker, Fear & Loathing and forgot the third one) was excellent.
Service was nice even though they were super busy.

The annoying part is that they are very popular so there was like an hour wait or something. We left our number and went for a drink and they called us, which is cool but I wish I had known in advance because I was super hungry and that hour wait was torture.
Another issue is the freaking North Beach parking situation, but if you don't drive, it's all good I guess.

I'm not going to lie, I prefer my pie, well, pie shaped, and less doughy.  HOWEVER, this pizza ain't crap.  I was super stoked on my veggie slice (is that right terminology? Their portions are square.  I mean, you don't get a slice of brownie.  But I digress.).  It had lots of different veggies piled on top of mozzarella and pesto, served with real silverware at a bar with plenty of seating and a nice selection of beer (Racer 5 IPA? Yes, please).  Now, I'm that asshole who likes to have my cake (pie?) and eat it too, so if my pizza has pesto sauce solomente, I'm going to want some marinara to boot.  The pizza jerk behind the counter (he was very nice) obliged and apologized that it would be cold.  It didn't matter.  Everything was tasty and satisfying, and for a Wednesday night they were doing quite the tidy window service business.  Definitely a good spot if you're in the mood for a quick bite and you're over on that side of town.  Especially when you're drinking.  I have seen the window service get pretty busy on weekend nights.
the best pizza ever, if you go once I guarantee you, you will want to go every day.
i expected great things and found it to be over hyped, go to tony's a block away

Golden Boy has the best pizza I have ever eaten in my life. I have been living in San Francisco for years. I think Golden Boy Pizza has the best pizza in the city. A few months ago, I invited a friend to join me and have pizza at Golden Boy. My friend is Italian, and he was visiting San Francisco for the first time in his life. He had never eaten at Golden Boy Pizza. After my friend had finished eating his slice of pizza, he told me that it was excellent. Sometimes, lines of up to 15-30 people form at the front door, especially during the evening on Fridays and Saturdays anywhere from around 6PM to after midnight. However, on those occasions when there is a line, it moves quickly. The service is fast. Obviously, all of those people think that the wait of a few minutes to eat Golden Boy pizza is worth the time. Golden Boy serves a whole lot of pizza. It is always fresh. The freshly baked pizza goes from the oven to the front display case. When a customer places an order at the front register, one of the staff places the pizza in the microwave to heat it up to maximum palatable temperature. The pizza always tastes fresh and delicious because any pizza in the front display came out of the oven only a few seconds or a few minutes before you placed your order. I eat pizza at no other place. When I want pizza, I'm off to the Golden Boy.

almost 5 stars for this dump... really???  golden boy is only good when you have had 15 beers, 10 shots of whiskey and 5 car bombs!  their pizza sucks!  the BS hipsters love it though.  they think, "its square it has to be cool!"  frankly, it's square, greasy and will give you the shits in the morning.  what the fuck, is everyone out of their mind today?  it's crap pizza that gives you the craps!  hell no and no way will i go ever again.  i don't care how hip you get.  fuck this shit hole!
THE MEATBALLS ARE TO DIE FOR !!!!!!!! Pizza was amazing as well! Green beans are tasty too !

Per all of the recommendations, we ordered the Margherita pizza - which reminded me of Italy (and makes me want to go back).

The pancetta salad we ordered was delicious - good size for two people to share and the staff was very friendly.

As this place is right around the corner from my place, next time I will probably just order pizza to go. The atmosphere is OK but nothing special.

Tony knows pizza, that's for sure. Pick from the menu or customize the thickness of your crust. My favorite was the pizza with Prosciutto. We asked to have it made extra thin and it was amazing. It was not too salty, which often times is the case with prosciutto, just perfect.
We also had the meatballs, which were delicious and so was the sauce it came with.

Overall, 4 people, 2 salads, 1 side dish of meatballs, 3 pizzas and we ate it all. That's how good it was! See for yourself.

Wait wasn't too bad. On a Wednesday at 7.30pm, table for 4, about 20 min wait.

My 2nd experience at this place on 8/13/2010: Wait on Friday at 6pm, about 20 min. Food excellent. Service on the other hand.... I wasn't that thrilled this time. My husband's ice cream was almost melted by the time he got his espresso for his affogato and other little things that can make a special night out a drag... I would still go back, though.

Came back and gave another sammie a try - this time grabbing a chicken parm wedge.  It was good, another satisfying sandwich from Tony.  Had another slice of cheese, which was once again good.

So far my sandwich ratings:

Meatball - 5 stars
Chicken Parm wedge - 4 stars
Chicago traditional Italian Beef - 3 stars

The pizza here is on my short list of top pizzas to eat.

Having tried Capo's already, yum deep dish. Had to try the slices here, well worth it, even though you'll end up eating outside or carry out... The place doesn't really have inside seating.

$3.75 for a cheese slice, two slices and it is a 12" box worth of goodness.

They also serve slices of deep dish, in case that is what you're after without and entire pie.

Great woodfire crisp crust, even if you take it home and reheat it in your oven.

I've been coming to Tony's for the past 2 years and with rare exception have not visited another pizzeria. This is the best NY Style pizza I've had on the West Coast. Hailing from New York, that's a fact so don't even argue. Fuhgettaboutit. ;-)

A bit pricey but considering its location, it's not as expensive as it could be. Service is quick and friendly.

We ate at Tony's on the recommendation of several people; one of which who commented it was the best place for pizza in SF.  The place was extremely busy at 5:30 and the initial estimate from the host was 1 hour and 15 minutes.  We waited for a little bit then decided to eat at the bar which cut our wait in half.

We ordered the house wood-fired pizza and it was delivered very quickly.  If you like a thin crusted pizza was crispy crust, this is not for you. It was tasty, but just not what I like. My wife, however, likes this kind do she enjoyed it more than I.  I also ordered meatballs and they were very good.  The kale salad was very good also.

Overall, it was a good experience but just not my personal favorite kind of

Some Italians you can never forget - and this is one of them! The wait is LONG, I repeat, LONG. But we ended up seating at the bar and it was just as great of an experience. We had their regular margarita pizza and delicious spaghetti and meatball pasta. So so so so so so so good. This was truly amazing. It's worth the wait - so go!!!

Wow is all I have to say the giant meatball with burrata is fantastic  and good thing to split. The Tartufo pizza is really good get that for lunch and no dinner required. Definitely worth the wait if the wait time is long.

First off, I will start off by saying I have already been here 4-5 times in the last month and a half, and I don't live in the city.  Yesterday, I stopped by here with my girlfriend and it was better than ever.  The drinks from the bar were innovative and tasty, and the food was out of this world.

We have not been disappointed once here but I would definitely recommend the Margherita Pizza.  A thin, crunchy crust with a taste of the wood used to cook it baked right into the crust, and the freshest ingredients I have ever tasted since I was back in Italy.

This does not overshadow any of the other great food:  SALADS with sweet balsamic vinegar that accentuates every bite, LASAGNA that has a pop of tomato and cheese that dances on your taste buds, and GREAT Sicilian pizza with a crust that is crunchy (no matter if it is a center or end piece).

Lastly,  the bartenders and Tony himself are amazing.  Extremely friendly, helpful, and will to take a few minutes out to just chat about food or whatever.  The service has always been quick and friendly, and as stated above, this does not eclipse the quality of the food in the slightest!

Thank you Tony and I hope to be a regular as long as you are around!

Worth the wait, especially if you are prepared. We were told it would be a 2 hour wait. We walked a few blocks to grab a refreshing beverage and the wait flew by. It was actually 1-1/2 hours. Once settled in at a sidewalk table, our charming waiter, Dario, suggested we try the New Yorker, a thicker pie, baked in the coal, rather than the wood, oven. It was fantastic! The ricotta infused tomato sauce stood right up to the fennel sausage, crisp pepperoni and creamy, fresh mozzarella. A glass of Sangiovese wine was the perfect pairing.

the new yorker pizza is delicious and the calamari as well. BUT i have bad experience with waitress with blue color hair (forgot to asked her name) she literally yelling at us when she explained she want to take our order even she's not our waitress. we so speachless because she think we stupid not understand that, but we do we just suprise she talk too loud and her body language is not friendly. i am totally upset because she make me and my husband felt humiliated. i think her manager should check how many people she treated bad because she just not the waitress of the table but doesn means she can act offensive toward us.

This is the first time I have written any review good or bad on Yelp.  In fact our experience at Tony's was so incredible it compelled me to set up an account and write this review!

My girlfriend and I decided to go to North Beach for some good Italian food but neither one of us could decide where to eat.  We wandered past Tony's once but had never been there and decided to keep looking.  After walking for a bit more we decided to go back and check out the menu.  It was packed (always a good sign in a restaurant) and we had heard it was good.  We decided to eat there and sat at the bar.

This was where the experience began.  We were welcomed with open arms to Tony's by Robvell the bar manager.  Robvell treated us like royalty.  We were new to Tony's and asked what was good.  Robvell and his extensive knowledge of the menu and his bar suggested the best meal we have had in a long time with the best wine to go with it.  The food was incredible!  We felt like we were on vacation from the way we were treated.  After sitting there for a bit we noticed that he treats everyone like royalty, as well the entire staff at Tony's treats everyone incredible!  

That said, as we were sitting there one of the servers (or so we thought) came to the bar with a couple amazing cheese and meat platters.  She stated to Robvell to give them out to everyone at the bar because they had made too much in the kitchen.  Later we met the server which happened to be one of the owners Nancy.  Nancy could have been like a lot of owners and not have time for us, but instead she took the time to talk to and get to know us.  

Tony's Pizza is now our favorite Italian food restaurant for the amazing service and incredible food!!

This is one of my favorite places to eat in all of San Francisco.  

My recommendation is to sit at the bar instead of wait for a table.  The bartenders are charming and make great hand crafted cocktails.  Don't forget to order meatballs to start.  There really sin't anything bad on the menu.  

If you want good pizza it doesn't get better than this!

I honestly don't understand the hype of this place.  The sauce is bland.  The crust is not well cooked.  And, as for the Pizza Cup trophy, I googled around a bit and found the web site for the contest doesn't exist so I'm gonna have to call phony on that.

Honestly, the pizza isn't close to my 3 other favorites in SF, which out of fairness, I won't mention here, except to say, the name of one starts with a D, the name of the other is two words (F+W), and the other is a little bar joint in the same neighborhood as Tony's (as a local for the bar joint pizza place, everyone knows it).

Meh on the pizza, double meh on the contest trophy claims...

Absolute favorite pizza ever!! After searching on Yelp for best SF pizza, I discovered Tony's--authentic Italian. Tony's is special because it brings the element of cooking as an art. The best pizza I've ever had in my life. My favorite and family's favorite is the Tartufo and the Margherita is also quite delicious. While the wait is long and the service needs some help in terms of quality and treating customers nicely and not ignoring them, the wait is worth it. Ambiance is fun.

Food is VERY good.  This is more about the service.  Told us it was 15- 20 min wait...  45 later.  My sons pasta took 40 min to come out.  Sucks because I like the food.  Might be a while (if ever) when I go back.

Never had pizza like this before and it is outstanding! Ok, yes... The service here sux. But I am by no means here for that. I can deal with shitty service as long as the food is good. Best meatballs I've ever had in my life as well as pizza.

10 stars!!!! Tony's has a special place in my heart, I feel like home whenever I eat here. ITS WORTH THE WAIT. Just get a drink from the bar while you're waiting, Elmer is the most amazing bartender I've ever met and makes very tasty cocktails! I can't even find a word to describe how delicious the pizza is, my favorite has to be the green top with added sausage, basil and garlic (ohhhhh your breath will be kicking afterward but don't be scared) Definitely top 5 must eats in SF!

I tried the Cholula and Diavola pizzas, gorgonzola fries and calamari as starters and was sadly disappointed paper it sounds good. The prices are reasonable the choices are great but when factored in with poor service and lacking flavor two stars is being generous.... sorry to say.
Maybe it's gone to their head that business is good so far that their staff feels they can be condescending and elitist but I thought I was dining at a local pizza place not a 5 stars restaurant me.
All in all I'd skip it order from somewhere that delivers and call it a day.

Roaming around Northbeach, you will notice that there are quite a lot of pizza places.. That's because you're in little Italy, Duhh! But Tony's is different... It's like when you were a kid, and action figures were cool and all.. But nothing compared to your Ninja turtles! That is what Tony's Pizza Napoletana is, Tony's is that judo chopping Michaelangelo that always beat up all your other action figures!

This place is just awesome, it's real laid back, the food is amazing and the people are super chill! I came here the other day and had their New Yorker, which is a rustic style pizza (coal fired oven cooked, i believe).

I would say go here and come back often!

Some of the best meatballs I've ever had. So tender and delicious with a flavorful and bright tomato sauce. The margherita lives up to its reputation. Great crust and just the right amount of cheese. Don't miss out.

We were really excited and willing to wait the two hours. However, we ended up leaving due to the very rude bartender. The host told us that we could wait for the bar which we did, for an hour. After the hour wait we found a place at the bar. The bartender told my mom that we needed to get up and let these other people sit there because "they waited longer." Go to Golden Boy instead.

After calling ahead we arrived and were told our pizza still needed some time.  We payed, and happily waited. After 15 minutes of waiting we were told they forgot to make our pizza.  We decided to wait for them to make it since we came across town for this pizza.  An hour later our pizza was finished. We were never offered anything whilst we were waiting nor a discount.  This lack of attention, and horrible customer service is unacceptable.

My friends and I bought a variety of slices to compare and contrast. The pepperoni and sicilian were ok but the California style pizza was amazing! We wanted to try the meat lovers and margarita but they were out of the meat lovers and margaritas are only sold in PIES not slices.

The new york style pepperoni was pretty good but the California was definitely the best one there. They also sell bottled coke through a vending machine which I thought was pretty awesome.

This place has delicious pizza.  We got a pizza romana and 2 large pizzas.  This was waaaaay too much for 4 of us, but perfect for having some awesome pizza leftovers for the next day.  The romana basically mimics a full meal with an 'appetizer', 'entree', and 'dessert' section of the pizza.  Never had it before, but I thought it was pretty good.

The food's awesome, but the biggest downside is definitely the wait.  I think we waited for almost an hour to be seated.

This an extended To Go or Take Away of Tony's restaurant. It is to right of the restaurant. Lines can be long on the weekends, but worth the wait. Pizza slices & whole pies are sold along with a couple of subs or sandwiches & soda/water.  There variety of slices to choose from.  Someone I know who grew up in the East Coast, said this pizza very comparable to the East Coast ones. We have been there a few times and the slices are consistently good. They usually heat up the slices. Pizza slice prices are around $5 a piece, but the slices are big. For pizza taste that you can get in the East Coast, the pizza slices here are worth it. For larger groups, I recommend ordeing a pie.

We cried when Pysano's (THE place for pizza in Castro Valley) closed, and have been eager to get into the City to try Tony's coal-fired pizza. WOW. My only regret is that it's not possible to get a sampler of all the different pizza types he offers.

We got the coal-fired New Yorker at the take-away  counter because it was an hour wait to get into the restaurant. Within about 25 minutes we had our pie, and it was the best thin-crust pizza I've had outside of NY state. The crust was heavenly -- and much better than the crust on Tony's Pysano's pizzas. It was blissfully blistered and charred, not too dry.

The tomato sauce appears to be fresh and hand-crushed. The sausage and pepperoni appeared to be handcrafted as well, and the spicy bite of the pepperoni was nicely tempered by generous dollups of ricotta.

They sell Mexican Cokes (yay!) but no beer (boo).

Small nit: there is no menu posted, and not until we got to the order-taker that we could see the extensive menu. I'd looked at the menu online ahead of time, but if I hadn't, I'd have been a little peeved about that... I need to mull over my choices then arm-wrestle my hubby over what to get. It also slows down the whole order process, since you get stuck behind people who need to mull it over, arm-wrestle with spouses, and have explained to them the differences between Detroit, Chicago, Coal-fired, etc.

If you're in North Beach and want to go the pizza route, this is the place. Parking is tough (they're right on Washington Square), so plan accordingly.

Also, although the sidewalk tables look inviting, unless you get the seats next to the building, they are on a deceptively slanty sidewalk - sitting is awkward - and you are about an inch and a half from the street and exhaust-belching tour buses. Once you get your order you might want to head over to the park to eat it instead.

The price was too much, and the hype was just a bit over done for the place. The pizza was good but it wasn't out of this world as in, you HAVE to go here and wait in line. There's plenty of just as good pizza places.

My brother and I wanted to eat Italian quick in North Beach so I yelped and off we went. I got the calzone, it had ricotta, pepperoni, olives and onions. It was big and filling. It was prob a 4 out of 5, delicious but not the best possible. My brother had a slice of cheese that was the bomb! I wished I had gotten pizza but was still very happy with the calzone. THere was no wait and it was under $15, well spent!

Great Italian food.  I had the spaghetti and meatballs and my daughter had a pizza.  Was great food.  Now I know why the wait list was so long.  The only negative thing I could say is try not to sit by the pizza oven when it is busy which is probably all of the time.  It gets really hot!

We came here for lunch on Saturday and the wait was 45 minutes. However, the wait was completely worth it since it's the best pizza I've ever had! We ordered the Cal Italia. The crust was thin and crispy, and the combination of sweet and salty was perfect. My husband also ordered the meatballs and he is an Italian New Yorker, and said they were as good as his grandmother's which says a lot. Make your way to Tony's you won't be disappointed.
Always busy in a good way. The pizza is great. I always opt to sit outside near the heating lamps to observe the locals. Nice selection, great neighborhood too.

Tony's Pizza is by far the best pizza in the city. No joke.

How is it that I haven't reviewed it yet? I have been here so many times and I literally have a hard time going and not ordering my new favorite pizza the Cal Italia. It is a "sweet pizza" because of the fig jammy on top with the proscuitto and cheese. Its a no red sauce pizza, which I learned is called White Pizza.

Of course the Margarita Pizza is delicious, just like it Italy.

**If its not too busy, and you have a small enough group, ask to eat by the pizza oven in the side room. Its a real experience to watch the pizza masters in their element working and to see your own pizza be made.**

On Easter we also got a free Panettone, which I thought was a really nice mom and pop touch. I enjoyed it very much and left happy! So glad to have some great pizza in my 'hood.

After enjoying a show down the street during our last night in San Francisco we decided to check out this place since the reviews were good and we love a Nepalitano slice. The first thing we noticed was the smell. Not really sure what it was but the bar (front room) had a distinct odor.

We were seated very quickly by the hostess and our server came by pretty quickly. We ordered a salad and split it; it was excellent. There were a few pieces of funky lettuce that we picked off but the rest of it was great. Nce croutons, shaved Parmesan, grape tomato goodness.

The pizza came out and while the flavor was good it was incredibly wet. The crust had the potential to be awesome, based on the outer edge but was kind of a sloppy mess. I'd definitely come back, maybe earlier in the day, and give it another shot. All in all, not bad for a late night when you're in the area and fiending some pizza.
Great service, smiley waitress and yummy pizza. Their Marguerite pizza is the best!  Big variety of drinks.

Waited 30 minutes in line at 11:30 to get a table for 4 right when they opened. Before 12:30, all tables were full. Server was super helpful at describing items and making recommendations. We started with the Coccoli with prosciutto. The fried dough was like a savory doughnut. My friends liked it by itself without the filling. Next we had the meatball gigante with mushroom cream sauce. Wow! BEST meatball I have tasted. The cream sauce poured on top was delicious but I can tell that the marinara sauce by itself was what made this dish. Next we had the pesto linguine. Very good as well. We had the New Yorker pizza on the Detroit crust. It was a huge slice with dough similar to a focaccia. Very large and a little hard to eat. My friends had already tried this on the New York crust and they preferred the NY crust vs Detroit. I also LOVED the Purity cocktail I ordered. Vodka, basil, ginger liquer, lime and bitters. Served in a small glass but so refreshing.

This pizza is decent and overhyped. If you want a good coal fired pizza to to URBN in San Diego, they are the closest to the style from New Haven, CT. (Where Frank Sinatra sent his NY driver to get pizza for him.) I recommend adding mashed potato and bacon pizza to the menu with a white sauce, then I could easily see you acquiring 5 stars.

NOTHING tastes as good as sweet revenge.

Let me just start by saying, that's not the type of revenge you're thinking of, it's a drink.

I went to Tony's with a friend one day to grab lunch because she's been raving about the pizza and the drinks there. We both are grey goose lovers, so she said I would love the drinks that they make there, and she was absolutely right. I fell in love that day, with my sweet revenge and my truffle pizza.

The full name of this wonderful drink is Polly Purebread's Sweet Revenge. It's made with Grey Goose la poire, St. Germain Liqueur, grapefruit and lemon juice, egg white (yes, i said egg whites and don't worry. you wont get salmonella)  and vanilla bean syrup. It tastes like a refreshing light sweetened water. Dangerous because three hours later the next thing you know... you're on your eighth one. If I had it my way, I would order it in a pitcher.

Depending on  the season, the truffle pizza may vary. When we went, $39 dollars for the pizza. Not a bad price to pay for truffles shavings. (Mind you, I'll eat almost anything with truffle shavings or truffle oil) We killed the pizza and then I wanted to lick the plate it came on.

The only thing bad about this place is the wait, but its well worth it.

Rainy Friday night started with dinner at Tony's.  Packed as always, I put my name on the list and was told an hour.  Went to the bar and had a beer to wait for my friend.  1 beer, then 2 beers.  About 40 mins. into the wait, phone rang and table is ready.

Started with the spinach salad, which had onions, sunflower seeds and goat cheese dressed with balsamic vinaigrette.  Really good.  Next was an order of the meatballs.  Three large meatballs in a great, fresh tomato sauce.  Great flavor and actually very light.  Final course was one of the pizza's.  We had the New Yorker, with various meat products.  Entire pie was great, right mix of cheese, sauce and meats.  Crust was perfectly done.

Service was a little slow, but we weren't in a huge hurry.  If we were it would have made a difference.  Overall, we had a great meal.  Best of all I had a $25 gift certificate, so entire dinner was $14 after the gift certificate.

The Good:

Pizza dough tossing demonstration at 8:45p on Sat night- guy was as skilled as a hooper - doing behind the back, under the leg - impressive.

Margherita pizza, Marinara pizza (no cheese - vegan), sausage pizza.
I rarely eat more than one slice of pizza (being lactose intolerant) and yet managed to devour 4.5 slices of the very thin pizza topped by juicy, fresh tomato sauce. Italian salad also fresh and quickly devoured by all in our group of 12. Italian fries with truffle oil - addictive.

Food arrives quickly.

Marnie - the manager - who so kindly offered to seat our additional unexpected guests in a table for 3 behind us. The other guests wandered away and Marnie even offered to hold the table for a few minutes while someone called him.

Our server was a very pleasant woman who had a warm smile and positive attitude.

Clean bathrooms - though they need to have bigger trash cans - and there are two - one isn't marked, but door painted black and sign indicating vacancy status above door knob (bathrooms separated by wine room).

The wait is long but the hostess will take your mobile # and call you when your table is ready.

After ordering 6 pizzas, 1 salad, 2 fries, the bill including tip came to $18 per person (we were a party of 12). Very reasonable.

The Bad:

The more complicated pizzas per J were not as a tasty as the simple pizzas.

The wait for a table for 12 people was 120 minutes starting at 6p. They DO NOT take reservations whatsoever for any size party.

I checked on the status of our table (though I wasn't the one who made the reservation) and the hostess told me "A Younger Woman already inquired."  Landmark comment for me - no one has ever said anything like this to me---maybe I should dye the gray hairs at my temples. I'm only 41! (The person who made the reservation is in her early 30s.) Still, her comment didn't dissuade me from checking in again 30 minutes later.  "Older" women like myself can be so annoying, right?

Don't go in large groups on a Saturday night unless you are prepared to wait two hours and be crammed into a booth.

I am always on hunt for good pizza, especially on the West Coast.  I am a major fan of thin crust NY style pizza.  I saw on Food Network's Crave that they ate pizza from Tony's, so I looked it up.  Any place that offers different styles of pizza based on the temperature of the oven has to be legit.

Took the family on a Saturday at 1pm, the place was soooo crowded, but we did get a table after the 20 minute wait.  We ordered the NY Pizza and Margherita.  It was NYC amazing!  The crust of the Margherita was texturally very different, thin and delish.  The best part was that it takes them like 90 seconds to cook the pizza, so the pizza hit the table immediately.  Oh, we had the Caesar salad.  You could tell that was fresh  as well.  

If I lived within walking distance, I would eat at Tony's 5 days out of 7!  The next real challenge is figuring out which pie I like best.

One of my favorite pizza places in San Francisco, despite the fact that I'm a deep dish guy at heart.

I like sitting out in the parklet, too.
Very good pizza for eat in or take out. Be prepared to wait if you want to sit. Pizza is thin crust and cheesy.  Tony's is a solid second option for pizza while in he Bay!

Excellent service... the best pizza!   Used the wait time with yelp; and when we got there, hostess was so kind; she saw my tired 13 year old and said " we've got your table".  Our waiter was kind and sweet.  We ate, enjoyed and were on our way!   Best first eve in SF

We decided to go here after seeing it on the top pizzeria articles produced by Yelp. It was about a 45 min wait for inside and open seating outside on a Wednesday evening at about 8pm. The group of four of us got three meatballs, Margherita Pizza, and tartufo. The meatballs came with plenty of sauce and were good as advertised. Although I would recommend getting the giant meatball as they say it keeps the same flavor and is at least unique/fun. The Margherita Pizza was selected because of the awards and reviews- you could tell the ingredients were fresh, quality, and well cooked. It was very tasty! The only catch, was lack of substance... but it's a Margherita Pizza so that should be expected. The tartufo Pizza was a hit as it came with a good amount of quantity and quality ingredients. A good bite! The experience was great and held up to the name/reputation based off what we ordered, but would definitely be interested in some of their other pizzas which have much more substance and filling qualities- good thing the menu is so big we can!

This is a review by a vegetarian

$3.94 for a large slice of NY style. It's fine but nothing special. Maybe I should have tried the more sofistimakated styles of pie.

I'll go back once and get something different,  if results don't improve I'll move on to Sodini's.

Good pizza? Absolutely. Worth the price? Highly debatable.

They make simple pizza's like Margherita's and some more complex ones and broils them mainly in a wood-over pizza. Crust comes outs with nice specks of char but the taste of the toppings did not sing out like I would expect from a high quality pizza. Supposedly pastas are the hit here but I would rather get some Delfina pizzas for this price. Salads are good as well.

It took 3 of my carpooling buddies to convince me that Tony's Pizza was amazing and I finally got to try it for myself.

We ordered 3 flavors: 1000 degree Coal Fired Original Tomato with Cheese ($19), the Classic Cal Italia ($18, the Famous Food Network Gold Medal Winner), and the 900 degree Wood Fired Napoleonata Truffle ($20 ish, minus the market price truffle).

Each had its own unique flavor but surprisingly my favorite was the Truffle.

Truffle was made on a medium crust, with burrata mozzarella, triple cream cheese, wild mushrooms, argula for bite, parmiagano, and truffle oil instead of shaved truffles. This pizza was wonderfully flavorful. I don't even like mushrooms, but the use of the non-garden variety made it much more palatable, as well as the creamy cheeses.

My second fave was the Cal Italia more for it's unique combination of flavors - the savory of the prosciutto, the strong melding of asiago, mozzarella, and gorgonzola cheeses, sweetness from the fig preserve drizzled all around, and some balsamic for tangy-ness. Ahh the marriage of the best flavors. My only complaint is that the crust is overly thick. I would have preferred a thinner crust to fully appreciate all the flavors going on.

And finally but not least, the original tomato and cheese. Seemingly simple, the tomato sauce here is what makes this pizza. It is full of oregano and basil and other spices that makes it a little sweet and full of Italian goodness. And the crust is nice and thin, great texture from the coal fired oven.

We ordered the pizzas as take out so it had sat about 10 minutes before we got to it. I can only imagine how delicious it would have been had we consumed it straight from the oven.

Next time. I will be back for you Tony's Pizza!

We came here on a double date. Started out at the bar with a bottle of fantastic sauvignon blanc and the burrata boat (warm pesto, topped with a sweet sun dried tomato relish, fresh basil, procuitto wrapped baguettes). I didn't try the appetizer, but from the sounds that my dinner companions made, it was safe to say that they found it delicious.

After a 15, 20 minute wait, the waitress showed us to our table. The table decided on the Margherita and Cal Italia pizzas (both award winners, whatever that means) and the Swiss chard to start.

The Swiss chard was a warm salad (sauteed dirty girl farms swiss chard, Iacopi farm white gigante beans, pork chorizo) and packed quite the punch from the chorizo. Our table loved it, even the ones that aren't fans of the green stuff. Definitely something that I want to recreate at home. I highly recommend it.

The Margherita (dough mixed by hand using san felice flour then
proofed in neapolitan wood boxes, san marzano tomatoes dop, sea salt, mozzarella fior di latte, fresh basil, extra virgin olive oil ) is what Tony's is known for. They only make 73 per day. Thankfully, we didn't have to push any old ladies down the stairs to get our mitts on one. Maybe it was the high expectations, but it was rather anticlimatic. The crust was a bit soggy from the sauce and droopy. The ingredients all tasted fresh but I just didn't get all the fuss was about.

The Cal Italia (asiago,  mozzarella, imported italian gorgonzola, sweet fig preserve from Croatia, prosciutto di parma, parmigiano, balsamic), now that was up there with the best pizza that I've ever had (Cheeseboard at Berkeley is still #1 though). The dough was crispy on the bottom and chewy on the sides. The proscuitto wasn't dry or burnt and simply melted in my mouth. The kicker though, was the fig preserve and balsamic drizzle (my nizzle). That sweet and savory punch was so creative and totally did it for me. Everyone at the table were blown away.

Tony's definitely take pizza making seriously. The pies are categorized by the type of ovens they're baked in and one can tell the attention to detail in the food. I will definitely be back to try the others on the menu.

Perhaps it's just me.  But I don't get why only make 73 pizzas a day for the margherita.  I know it's to commemorate the award winning pizza, but there are other ways to commemorate- like displaying the trophy in a glass case, or putting the award on a wall.  It's not a new idea, but it works and it gets the points across.  

Why 73 pizza limit?  Is it so hard to make the margherita sauce?

After all that gimmick, I was expecting to have a pizza that's on a great-to-I'll have-wet-dreams-about-you-tonight-level.  But sadly, it's not.

Margherita and the Quail egg pizzas are amazing. These definitely aren't your usual ginormous Costco pizzas. They're smaller by diameter and come as thin crust with the perfect amount of everything. If you're suuuuuper hungry, you might be able to eat a whole one yourself.

Tip: Order for takeout or from the slicehouse next door to avoid the tremendous wait for a table.

Best pizza in San Francisco and possibly ever!

They do a limited number of certain pizza's daily like the margherita pizza. The use different styles of firing the pizza too like coal and different woods. Also, they make the best gluten free pizza crust. It's tasty and very similar to a normal pizza crust! This place is the yummy!

This is some of the best pizza in San Fran! They have  4 different oven types - gas, charcoal, wood and electric. Then you get to pick what temperature the oven is at! This results in more than a few different styles of pizza. It's almost overwhelming!

We had a New York Pepperoni pizza. It was perfectly cooked and really good. The drink selection is also awesome however the old fashioned I had nothing special for the really high price tag. I was disappointed and could have made something much better at home. I guess some people like this, I myself expect a mixologist gourmet cocktail when I am dishing out that much coin.

That's the only reason this place loses a star: $$$ Price.

The pizza and drinks are all 20-30% more than what I want to spend. I guess that's because rent is so high in the area. It's worth indulging once and awhile here.

Went to lunch here with my best friend for birthday and the wait wasn't too bad if you come early.. Got seated approximately within 15mins.
I highly suggest ordering the pizza above all else. We ordered the spinach salad and it was pretty blahhhhh. Get the margarita pizza and your set.
One of the better pizzas I've ever had. Ordered the New Yorker... Typically a long line but we ordered it ahead of time and picked it up. Definitely recommended.

It's like I can go on vacation for an evening.
they don't have great food like this on the west coast...
OR do they!

Get the pizza.  Real Pizza.  Margharita, so you can enjoy the flavors.
And get it large. You'll want the leftovers.

I went here for my co-worker's birthday lunch.  He's Italian and kept talking about how this was the only place you should ever eat for Italian food/pizza.  So we ventured out of the office a little before noon hoping to beat the lunch rush.  Mission accomplished.  In fact, it was busy, but not to the point where anything was lacking.

We ordered:  Pizza Margherita, Romano's Original Stromboli, spinach salad and Italian Gorgonzola fries.
