Everything was so delicious.  I was actually full walking out of this restaurant and we had leftovers.  The service was really good and extremely attentive.  Tony was also there making pizzas and stopped by to check on all the tables.  He sat down with us for a chat and when he found out that it was my co-worker's birthday, bought us a round of drinks.  I'm definitely a fan of the restaurant, the food, the service and Tony.

Tony's Pizza Napoletana is like experiencing greatness.

What can I say that hasn't been said before?

Had lunch here after Halloween weekend. Sat outside- it was one of those warm November afternoons.

Seated within 15 minutes. Worth the wait.

Service was on-point. Had the delicious Naples style pizza with truffle-essence- AMAZING! I could only imagine how one with actual $1,000/per pound truffle would taste.

Pretty good, but Tommasso's is still my go-to for pizza in the city....

Very interesting pizza flavors - highly reco the pancetta/porcini. The salscicia is also good and the margherita was just ok. the salads are nothing to write home about, but the wine list was pretty good.

I do wish they would take resos...we waited a ridics long time for an early Thurs dinner.

To sum it up, this is the best Italian pizza I've had in the US.  

I spent years living, traveling, and eating my way through Italy.  The best pizza I've ever had was actually in Naples, home of the Margherita.  So, 5 stars to Tony for winning the championship in Naples, and for bringing a taste of Italy to SF.

I had dinner here with a good friend of mine from Italy.  He had the Margherita and I had the Diavola (sopressata, buffalo mozzarella, and arugula).  Both were amazing and the best we've had outside of Italy.

OMG!!! I finally got to try this place and I love it! Came here during the week and I got to order the Margherita and New Yorker. The Margherita was a delish. I really like the sauce and everything on it. As for the New Yorker, it was good but it wasn't a wow wow.

Also had some kind of spicy pasta spaghetti looking dish and it was good!

Oh, this place is pretty much always packed so be ready to wait.

The wait is absolutely worth it. The food is delicious. Some of their pizzas show limited quantities on the menu -- only 73 margherita pizzas are made daily, for example. They have different ovens (gas, wood, coal) for each style of pizza, so ordering from different parts of the menu is a tour of pizza possibilities.

Perhaps my expectations were too grand.  After all, I had heard only great things from every article I read about Tony's, all the Yelp reviews, and the guy won a pizza award in Italy!  When I heard there were four different types of pizza made in four different types of ovens - I was more than excited, I think I peed my pants a little bit.  

I waited until my sister came into town to visit with her pizza loving boyfriend (he had a shirt that simply says, "pizza is the best") to try Tony's Pizza Napoletana.  I figured with five people we could actually order all four types of pizzas and not look like total piggies.  The wait was not nearly as long as I had imagined, although we did go on a Sunday night.  And the staff was friendly and attentive (especially the bartender who really knew his stuff).  

On to the pizzas.  Luckily our pizzas were somewhat staggered so we were not confronted with all four pizzas at the same time.  The Sicilian was very thick (as was expected) but surprisingly lighter than I had expected.  The dough is filled with tiny pockets of air so it was more of a focaccia base than a dense dough.  Oddly enough it was one of my favorites of the night - even though I am a thin crust pizza person.  The Margarita was tasty, but I guess I was expecting more since this was the pie that won such praise in Italy.  Crust was very good and charred, but I am not sure it was any better than Delfina or A16.  Both the Italian style and American style were disappointing - I would not order either again.  Very average pizza with a crust somewhere between thick and thin, its like it could not commit to either.  

If you are in North Beach then Tony's is a good option for dinner in an area filled with tourist traps.  But I am not sure I would trek out here again, there are better pizza options in the city.

Fantastic pizza joint! It was surprisingly busy for a Wednesday night but the wait was only about 10 minutes even though they told us it would be a 30-40 minute wait.

The Margherita pizza is superb as advertised. The crust is thin and crispy. The sauce is delicious and the cheese just melts in your mouth. I can see why it's such a big hit.

The Cholula pizza is found under their "Classic American" section and is another good choice. Though not as great as their Margherita pizzas, the Cholula is much more meaty with an emphasis on spicy. They use jalapeno peppers to give it a kick. The hot sauce blended with the cheese works wonders on the taste buds and works nicely with the chicken and chorizo bits.

Our waitress was very very cheerful -- almost as if she had too much coffee. Nevertheless, we enjoyed her service and the pleasant attitude she provided.

The only gripe I had was that we sat outside on a windy night. The heaters did not work very well so we were suffering a bit. Fortunately, the pizzas warmed our stomachs right up. If I can find parking, I'm definitely coming back again! Big thanks to my friend who took me here for my birthday and was gracious enough to treat!

4 stars.

This review is with respect to the slices that they were selling on the sidewalk. Don't waste your time with these at future North Beach street festivals...

Order a sit-down meal inside to see what the hype is all about...

Summary: Great NY pizza and meat sandwich takeout.

The place is mostly carryout, with very limited seating. I tried a slice of cheese NY pizza ($3) and Chicago combination (beef + sausage) sandwich ($9).

Pizza was thin, with a crispy and chewy crust, melted cheese, and a tangy sauce. Great example of NY pizza.

Sandwich was on soaked chewy/spongy Italian bread, with a generous amount of sliced roast beef, a split sausage, and spicy (spicier than I expected) peppers. An excellent example of an Italian beef sandwich.

They had a variety of other pizzas (Romano, Sicilian) and sandwiches that I didn't try this time. Looked interesting though.

I'll definitely go back again, particularly for the beef sandwich.

Loved it! So the crust I wasn't that much of a fan of, had a whole slew of pizza from NY to woodfire to coalfire, and while each one was scrumptious, the crust just doesn't do it. I've said it once, and I'll say it again, it's something about west coast pizza where the crust ends up soggy in the middle, I don't know why. Like the pizza is GREAT, but when I pick up a slice, the tip always falls forward then the toppings slides off.

Regardless I still give 4 stars. Wait is long, yes get over it, but pizza comes out fast and fresh. My favorite of the night is between this spicy chorizo and potato pizza and the thin crust, mozarella and sausage pizza. The first one because there was this amazing creamy cheese that they dolloped randomly, and as you bit into the spicy chorizo and peppers, the cheese would cool your mouth off. Loved it! The thin crust because of the sauce, the sweet tomato sauce which was the best sauce ever! I didn't even care for the sausage, I just picked it off. Loved the tomato sauce! Drooling over it!

Visited here because I read so many great reviews. Ordered the margherita pizza and one of the pasta dishes. You can really see & taste that their food is made from scratch and with love. No wonder their pizza was voted best in the US a few years ago.

The server was attentive and helpful. The patrons at the bar looked like they were having a great time, so that's what I'll probably end up doing next time. Definitely will grab a pizza next time I head out there.

I was vacillating between 4 stars and 5, and decided to go with 5 because the pizza really was that good.  I'm a bit of a pizza snob, but this place was pretty perfect.
We went for a late lunch, so we had no problem snagging a table.  Our waitress was very friendly and upbeat, and was happy to answer questions and make recommendations.  We decided on the margherita pizza and the mushroom/truffle pizza.  Both were excellent, but I'm a purist and the margherita was my favorite. :)
The ingredients were top-notch, the dough was perfectly seasoned and chewy, and I loved it.  Nom nom. About $15-$20/pie, which probably serves 2.  Highly recommended.

yumm!
Basically, I came here with my hubby. We ordered their Margherita Pizza which was deeeee-licioussss. Thin crust, thin everything.. (5/5) After you eat it, you don't feel yucky like other pizzas. This is perfect for 2 people.
I usually like meatballs so we also ordered 3 meatballs from them. It was also really good (4.5/5) It wasn't salty like other places and it had a little spice to it. Not sure if it was from pepper or something inside but I loved it!
Price was pretty reasonably.. Not too high, not too low.. I can say one negative thing about this place: I DON'T LIVE IN SAN FRANCISCO and I'm already craving their pizza!!!! sigh.. I must visit SF a little more often to visit wonderful restaurant like this one.. I will definitely be back soon.. :D

Why is that when I moved to SF from NYC, all I do here is eat pizza?
I know why, because Tony's pizza is here in SF.
Yes, it's touristy. Yes, it's crowded. But for good reason.

I love their meatballs with burrata cheese.
I have to admit, every time I am there I only order The New Yorker pizza, which I have to say is nothing like New York style pizza. Nevertheless, it's amazing. The fresh tomato sauce with ricotta cheese on a thin crust is better than anything I have ever had in New York.

Get there early and have a drink next door at Tony Nicks while you wait.

This pizza was delicious. I ordered a slice off the meatlovers and it was jam packed with meat on every edge of it.

This isn't a place that I would recommend going to with a large group or even if you want to sit and comfortably eat. It's a place to go, grab a slice, and sit at the park and grub on.

The thin crust was superb and it was all just so flavorful. The only reason I docked it a star was because it was about 5.25 for a slice...I can get a whole pizza from pizza hut for that price -- I know it's not the same, by far, but still!

If you are a fellow Pizza lover, Tony's should be next on your pilgrimage to find the greatest slice in America. Within the last 12 months, I've eaten at Grimaldi's (both Brooklyn and Las Vegas), Lombardi's and now Tony's. I have to say Tony's belongs in the same category as these Pizza heavyweights.

Don't waste your time with anything other than the Margherita pizza. I'd recommend you order one per person. Not because they are small, but because they are that GOOD.

best garlic bread ever!!! tons of whole gloves of garlic.
the hippie stromboli: yum!!!
The dough is pretty bad tasted like Indian bread really weird .. Don't get the wood fire style .. One hour and 30 min wait cold meatballs

This review is for the little pizzeria 2 doors down from the main Tony's restaurant that the hostess directed us to, which just had Tony's pizza by the slice. Pizza was good! Greasy but authentic :) Nice little spot!

Why on early would you eat pizza while in a city known for food??  My wife and I learned of Tony's from the hop on hop off  bus. We heard the hype and read the reviews but we are tough critics.  Hands down best pie we've ever had. Do yourself a favor and get one while in SF. You won't be disappointed.

This place has the best pizza, service, and also a great atmosphere!
The meatballs and green beans are a definite must for appetizers. If there is a wait, it is well worth it! We'll definitely be back!

This was a delicious pizza.  There were 3 of us and we each ordered our own pizza; the Margherita pizza, which there are inly 73 made per day, the Cal Italia, and the Sausage and Stout.  The Margherita was by far my favorite.  A simple, but delicious pizza.  The crust was so soft and the sauce was sweet.  The Cal Italia was crunchy and too sweet because of the fig preserve, although it was my friend's favorite for that same reason.  The sausage and stout had the most intense flavors and was the crust was the most unique because of the stout flavor.  My husband had the Boulevadier cocktail and raved over it the entire meal.

*Gesturing with two hands*  This place, it's as good as it gets, capisce?

But seriously, this place makes a serious pizza pie.  I tried the New Yorker, which was crispy and spicy, thanks to the pepperoni and sausage, and a little more than enough for two people.  We made a good choice, but I can't wait to come back and try one of their other appetizing choices.

The service was bustling and prompt at about 80% capacity.  We arrived towards the end of a lazy SF walking excursion at about 4pm with no wait (for inside seating).  All the outside seating was packed on a beautiful day.

A well run establishment, and among the best pizza I've ever had, along with Serious Pie in Seattle.  Good luck getting a table at regular dinner hours.

I'm fairly certain I didn't order the right pizzas, and wished I had read these reviews before trying Tony's. If I had done my research better, I probably would have gotten the 5-star experience that everyone else on Yelp had.

The first pizza we ordered was the Napoli, which on the menu is described as having mozzarella, basil, sea salt and olive oil.  However, the pizza we received had an added topping, something brown and fairly sweet, that threw off the flavor of the pizza. I'm still trying to figure out what it was.  We also ordered Frank's True Italian - good but I think Pauline's does the pesto pizza better.

Next time I'll order the Margherita.

Tony makes an iconic pizza that puts North Beach on the culinary map.

His margherita could easily be sold in Napoli; it's perfection. There really is nothing more to add.

Tip: if he's out of the Margherita (made with San Felice flour), you can always ask for a Margherita made with the Caputo flour.

The BEST pizza I've ever had and I'm not exaggerating!

Arrived a few mins after noon and was able to snatch the last table available.  Tiny quaint little place.  Already knew what to order as I've heard so much about their two medal winners.

Margherita Pizza - World cup winner in Italy...truly lived up to all it's expectations.  The sauce and cheese just melts in your mouth and the crust has the perfect slight burnt and crispiness.

Cal Italia - Food network challenge gold meal...a sauce less but sweet pizza...sounds weird but tastes amazing!  The figs are a hit!

The pizzas only come in one size...it's about equal to a small at most pizza places.  And they are very light so one person can finish one pizza on their own.  I must say though that it's quite expensive at $18 a pizza but it's well worth it!  Can't wait to come back!

I'm a stern critic of pizza joints having worked in one myself - had a whip cracked on me by a strong yet fair owner gentleman who knew his way around making sauce and crust. So, that's in my bones.

TPN - I would give 3 stars for good taste, etc. 1 extra star for the outstanding service. Hannah - I'm looking at you - thanks for making our dinner awesome.

Gotta be honest - worth $70 for dinner for 2? Hmmmmm. Debatable.

Coming from New Haven (home to the famous Pepe's and Sally's Pizza), I was curious to see the best pizza that San Francisco had to offer. After being deterred by the long wait next door at Tony's Pizza Napoletana, I decided to get take-out and was told to come here. This place mostly has its own pizza by the slice but you can actually order any freshly made pizza from Tony's Pizza Napoletana too.  

A friend and I opted to go order something from Tony's Pizza Napoletana and decided on  the international award winning "Burratina Di Margherita" which says "serves 2-3 people." This Sicilian pizza definitely filled 3 hungry people. It has incredibly fresh ingredients and tasted delicious.

Another friend opted for pizza by the slice and also tried some of our whole pizza. He seemed to think the whole pizza was better but it's a little unfair because it was freshly prepared.

For anyone looking to try Tony's and wanting to cut the wait in half, I'd highly recommend coming here.

I found myself craving some pizza after getting a few shots of Jameson at Savoy Tivoli, and that's when Tony's Pizza came to the rescue.

It was almost closing time for them so they let us have two slices for the price of one. Under 5 bucks? Sweeeet! There weren't many choices left at that point, to which I got a slice of the Cheese and my friend got the Pepperoni. I thought we were going to get the pizza served as is but they even popped that stuff back in the oven for us.

We sat outside at one of the tables they had and started to scarf down our food. The pizza looked simple enough, but it tasted like magic at the moment. It wasn't overly greasy, cheesy enough without being overwhelming, and the crust was crispy yet soft.

I think I may have found my go-to stop before I head out for round two at the bars.

If you have the desire and patience to wait for a table inside, choose to sit and cuddle close under the heat lamps outside, or elbow your way to the bar-first come first serve- (where they serve their full menu), you are in for an amazing, well worth the wait treat!

I split a margarita pizza to die for, with what I believe was Mozzarella Fior di Latte, and while the crust was a little soft and doughier than I usually go for, it worked well, and tasted spectacularly close to something you would find straight out of a fantastic, not touristy, neighborhood ristorante in Italy.  

I also split a mojito sans rum, with a lemony twist and a generous splash if lemonchello.  It turned out to be very light and delightful, and this coming from someone who does not think of either rum or regular mojitos in such an appealing light!  I do, however, wish, that our bartender put a lot more mint in the drink.

I feel it would be very unfair to mention anything about slow service, given the restaurant was bustling the whole time, so mark my words Tony, I will be back!

LET ME TELL YOU LITTLE STORY:
I came hungry with my boyfriend.
The server was fantastic, funny, friendly, helpful. Wanna be her friend.
We ordered the New Yorker. It came in all its glorious splendiferous steaminess.
Our jaws dropped. Drool dripped.
We bit in. Trumpets blared and angels sang in glory.
I had an orgasm in my mouth. Then I had 20 more.
I fought with my boyfriend over the last slice of a pizza that is meant for around 6 people.
It was gone in 7 minutes flat.
We are not fat people. Truly. Ask the waitress. We just were seduced by the absolute magnificence that was Tony's Pizza.
If this doesn't make you want to go to the best Pizza place in SF, I seriously don't know what you want from life.

I had high expectations for this place based on reviews and word of mouth. I finally decided to give it a try and came for dinner on a weekday.

With an anticipated wait time of 25 minutes, we patiently waited for our table as waiters walk by with hot crispy pizzas tempting our noses.

However, it actually took about 40 minutes before we were seated.

We ordered their famous Margherita & New Yorker. The Margherita was delicious; light yet flavorful, with a crispy & thin crust. The New Yorker was also great; I especially enjoyed the texture of the ricotta and the flavor of the sausage.

Overall I was happy with our meal. Their pizzas are on the pricier side, but to me it is quality over quantity. The wait is a bit long, so next time if I return I would probably plan to come a little earlier before the dinner rush. Supposedly their meatballs are good (based on many orders we saw tables get), so that's something we may have to try next time. I probably won't be rushing over here anytime soon, but I may have cravings for it once in awhile.

What's with SF and the lines you have to wait in? Every restaurant has them!

This was one place where it was definitely worth it. Showed up at noon (when they open) and there was a large crowd milling around, no rhyme or reason to the crowd, just everyone kind of jams in to the front when they open.

Seated at 12:30. Right next to the pizza oven. Right next to Tony. Awesome.

Ordered two of the daily 73 Margherita pizzas available, a Cal Italia, a side of green beans and plenty of bread and amazing olive oil.  Four large appetites were filled with a couple slices leftover.

The Margherita pizza is so simple I hate ordering it, I prefer meat on my pizza. But, this slice seemed to have been dipped in awesome and then served hot out of a brick oven. Holy amazeballs. It's quite possibly my favorite pizza ever. I don't live in SF, so I have only had it once, but from the stomach-rumbling memories it stirs, I will definitely be back.

The Cal Italia was also good, but next to the Marg, it didn't resonate as long.

They have sweet ceiling fans also.

That is one long line! You gotta put your name in at the door and head down the street to Tony Nick's (dive bar) for a drink while you wait. Or if you're lucky you can catch Tony flippin pizza pies in the park across the street.

Are you a pizza connoisseur? Then you will enjoy this place. The crust and sauce are made with perfection. You can create the rest.

Buon appetito!

We came here as a group and ordered way too many pizzas. The ambience is great and the food is fairly good.

Just a quick tip: we ordered a bunch of pizzas and they were all great but my favorite was the SWEET POTATO PIE. It's more of a desert pizza because it was maple syrup, bacon, sweet potatoes, and kale, but it definitely was a good eat.

The deep dish pizza was great and the rest of them were wonderful.

Perhaps the best part of the whole scene was when one of the guys from the back came out and started to spin the dough in the air for us all. That was cool and certainly added a unique touch to the restaurant.

Enjoy!

Tony created his margherita pizza as gift to the food gods of euphoria, and now it walks among mortal men.

IMO: if a man tears down an oven brick by brick and travels it brick by brick 8k miles across the other side of the earth to capture the essence of the Napoli winning pie, then you better believe it's damn good.

No reservations are taken, first come first serve which equates to 1-1.5 hr wait in the evenings....but DEFINITELY worth the wait. And the crust for the "original masterpiece" is only made for 70  pies or so, so  it may be out before you get there.

Best pizza I've ever had!! We were lucky enough to get one of the 73 Margarita pizzas on our first visit and came back the next night because it was so delicious. The bread prior to the meal is also great. $4 cans of beer doesn't hurt either.

Outdoor seating is great!

The pizza here was quite possibly the best I've had outside of New York. Actually it rivaled NYC. We had the kale salad and the Quattro forni pizza. Both were outstanding and came out very quickly. Service was prompt without being overbearing. I'm glad we came in during the mid-afternoon lull though be aura you could tell this place gets busy otherwise. I will definitely come back if I ever find myself in The City again.

I've always wanted to try Neapolitan pizza so I decided to get their award winning margherita pizza which they claim to have only a limited amount per day but that didn't seem like the case because they kept serving them. The price was $25 bucks and after tax was around $28. I shared the pizza with my girlfriend and we were both still pretty hungry. I can't say it was good because it was my first neapolitan pizza but definitely not worth it. The flavors were decent but I rather spend my money else where. Tasted like slightly burnt bread with tangy tomato sauce. Don't trust food network on what "real" or "authentic" pizza should be. Just buy a regular greasy slice of pizza.

My boyfriend and I came here after seeing it featured on the Travel Channel. I had high expectations for their margherita pizza since the show said it won awards and was top rated in the world. Unfortunately the food was disappointing. The crust was burnt and not very flavorful and the pizza was soggy. We also ordered the sea salt bread and prosciutto appetizer. I thought it was okay, but not anything to write home about. I would say overall the best part of the meal was the mozzarella, which was fresh and flavorful. I am just shocked because there was a line halfway down the block before they opened, but I think that this place is probably featured in tourist pamphlets and books creating the demand. So far the best pizza place I've found in SF is Pizzetta in the Outer Richmond.

Great Neapolitan style pizza!  I had their famous simple margarita pizza and it was excellent.  Great sauce, smokiness from the coal oven and chewy crust.  I added extra fresh garlic with olive oil and wish I had asked for more basil.  This place is definitely a must try.

From someone who easts pizza a LOT, I can safely say this is the best pizza i've ever had.  Long waits are worth it. We had the which has apparently won the most awards - Sicilian La Regina - OMG amazing. Thick crust that melts in your mouth. Don't be thrown off by the prices, you'll have plenty to spare. Two of us didn't even get through half of it.

Holy cow pizza!! The best I ever had, I wish they had beef toppings, sucks for the non-pork eaters.

Had a vegetarian pizza and a slice of their cheese pizza, both are amazingly good. This is the best pizza joint I have ever been to.

Be warned, parking here is a nightmare and on the weekends there would be atleast a 2 hour wait. Also indoors it's extremely hot and humid because of their oven, it's a pretty cramped place and that's why I'm taking a star off.

If your ever in SF , it's a mist to come here for a great pizza.

Get the New York pizza! I've never had pizza as delicious as this one! The cheese is to die for! Go see Jose at the bar!!! He makes amazing drinks and is such a pleasure to talk to! He made our trip to Tony's that much better!!!!

Best pizza ever! The menu is a lil overwhelming and pizza is by far and away my favorite thing on the planet, soo...we ordered 4! Each one was better than the last. It was a beautiful progression and we went from sweet to savory to spicy and back again...ended with honey pie, which was mind blowingly bomb! Our waitress, who was amazing, sweet and must have a degree in pizza informed us that they have their ownbee hives on the roof!! What? So special!  One sweet and one savory is the way to go....we will be back. I am in pizza heaven. Can't wait till I'm not full so I can scarfi

One of our favorite pizza places in SF (we are also fans of Capo's). The hostess with light brown, curly hair, however, should reassess (or whoever placed her there should reassess) her attitude and interactions with customers.  There was no line so I walked up to the stand - she was looking down at her tablet/computer doing something so I waited a minute to not interrupt. She didn't acknowledge me whatsoever - didn't look up, no "be right with you," no smile - so I finally said "hello."  She STILL ignored me, and after a long pause STILL without looking up once or even a greeting, flatly said, "there's a two hour wait."   She didn't ask if I wanted to put my name down - just gave me five words.  I laughed and left.  Sometimes you just have to find the humor in people who do their jobs so poorly.

The margherita pizza here is amazing. The sauces that came with the bread were delicious. The salad I had for an appetizer was really good. The pizzas serve two people. With drinks and food it ended up costing about $19 per person. Not bad at all considering how great the experience was.  "Tony" came out to check on us several times.

I was entertained by how different the traditional pizza was when compared to the "american" pizza. Thin crust is definitely the way to go.

Tony's a pizzaiolo who's puritanical about quality pies and it comes through on the menu that covers a ton of Italian, American (and Californian!) styles of pizzas cooked in three different types of ovens.

The meal was off to a great start with perfectly poured Negronis and speck-wrapped chunk of creamy burrata drizzled with olive oil that was so good you weren't sure if you should eat it or rub it all over your face.

In my book, the true test is the Margharita.  The wood-fired crust and fresh mozzarella were perfect, but the sauce (and I know it's supposed to be thin and spare) was kinda weak...was it just me?

The Cal Italia  is a HUGE departure from traditional italian pies, but what an incredible trip with a fig-based 'sauce' and drizzles of balsamic-reduction over a smoky cheese topping.  

The Scarola Con Pancetta was the table-favorite with mozarella, peppered goat cheese, pancetta and sweet piquant red peppers that balanced the creamy cheeses with a not-too-spicy kick.  

There were a bunch of other pizzas, salads and appetizers that I can't wait to go back and try.  

I'm strongly considering turning Tony's week long class in Neopolitan pizza making intp my next sta-cation.......

I wandered into this place while they were still setting it up and got to talking with the owner.  He said pizza.  I said nice.  He said authentic Napoli style.  I just returned from Naples and still had the basiganol in my teeth and have made thousands of pizzas in my lifetime.

Prove it.

I was floored.  It brought me back to this little place in Pozzuoli Naples where they yell at you from the kitchen because they don't write the order down then bring you some wine and sit with you at the table and talk about the family.  

We ordered the calamari with some hot peppers and a basic margarita pizza.  I could not stop eating it.  Had to grab a calzone to go and yeah, that pretty much rocked my shorts too.

This is one of those places that will be around forever if they manage it well and maintain that level of quality.  I hate giving them 5 stars because now I won't be able to get a table but these guys have tipica Napoletana perfetto!

Bravo!

I didn't know pizza could taste and feel so light. Well, not untill I set foot into Tony's at least.

The award wining Margarita pizza with it's super thin crust absolutely fits for any meal of the day. Yes, even for breakfast. The crust and dough were so thin, you could almost see through it from the bottom. The (can not be any fresher) mozzarella cheese, tomato, basil and not to forget the light and aromatic red sauce all added up to to a truly unforgettable experience. I finally realized what it really meant when people say, "Real Italian is far from being heavy, but it is simple and delicious."

The meat ball (limited amount is served each day) was super big and that itself could be a meal. It was amazing.

So, go people because it will change your (American) idea of Italian just like it did mine.

Terrific pizza and the meatballs were so tasty! The food was 5 stars, our server was very good, but the host was terrible.

He told us it would be a 45minute wait. He never called so we came back after 50minutes. He said it would be one moment and that we were the next table. We waited for 40minutes while WALKS-INS took tables. He said it was because he was giving us the best table in the house. Maybe that was true, but we indicated (after we were asked) that we wanted the FIRST TABLE AVAILABLE. He should have AT LEAST asked if we wanted the 2-3 tables that were given away before us.

After we were seated and had liquid in our hands, well, alcohol, we were much happier. Once the food came, we were thrilled!

This is my spot for pizza in the Sucka Free. The thing I like about Tonys is the diverse style of pizza they have.  They have thin crust, american, detroit (sqaure deep dish) and many different flavors.\

Last time we ordered the special margherita, its really really good, the dough melts in your mouth, its so thin, but it isnt raw.  Theres just enough sauce, and with each bite you get some cheese and basil, really everything a pizza should be.  They only make 73 a day so make it happen!

We also had a spicy sopressata pizza, that had a spicy oil on it, it was damn good!!!!!!  

To top it all off a side of meatballs, that came it a bowl of gravy (red sauce) which I used to dip my crust.

Damn, writing this makes me want to go to Tonys get some pizza, you should too, now!!!!!

I can eat this pizza all day every day ---- absolutely delicious.
I went with a big group and we got all diff kinds of pizza -- all delicious, you can't go wrong

It's the real thing. It's Italian and it's Pizza!!
We showed up to a 30 - 60 minute wait. We went outside and sat at their outdoor tables next door until they called us on our phone, they had the 2 counter seats in the room on the right side. Awesome-fun seats to watch all the pizza making! We ordered their yummy garlic bread, full of big chunks of garlic, and hmmm, I forget what they called it, but a pizza that had sausage and pepperoni. I saw all the others being made and wanted to try a whole handful of them! The pizza was great and I am pretty picky. I would love to go back to try more. Next time I'm in SF, I will definitely return.
Someone said parking was awful...I didn't have any problem. There are meters all around and I found one right away.

Overall recommendation: GO!!!! Enjoy!!! But, it does get crowded, so remember to stop by to get on their list and then they'll call your cell when the table is ready.
Ciao!

The pizza was perfect like no other pizza I have eaten (sorry Emilia's), but then that was what I was expecting.  The kale chips on the other hand, were an appetizer afterthought that turned out to be a Spanish-Inquisition surprise attack of mind blowing awesome.  

Two other added bonuses: (1) the meal was also less expensive than I thought perfect pizza would be (in San Francisco no less).  And (2) they take your phone number and call you from the wait list, and so you're free to wander around nearby Washington Park while you wait.
The pizza is amazing here!  this place is always packed and after trying the pizza it all makes sense!  good customer service.  pizza fans should try this spot!

This is one of the places I know I must re-visit every time I'm in San Francisco. My aunt has been coming here for ages and has never been disappointed. The staff is always so friendly and welcoming, especially the bar staff. The pizza is the best I've had and there are lots of great options, and the creative cocktails are always unique and delicious. We always end up ordering way too much food and take it home for later. Don't let the wait get you down--this place is worth every minute of it.

Forgot to mention that they only have ONE bathroom!  The place is usually packed in the bar and the restaurant.  There was a line of 4 or 5 people.  After 5 minutes of waiting with no one leaving we left. This was the "straw that broke the camel's back" for my husband who was already disgusted as I was with the HORRIBLE service.
Honestly overrated. The wait time is ridiculous. Pizza is mediocre. Meatballs are good though!

Well- nice service.  Friendly and prompt.  But 35-40 bucks for a small pizza??   Are you kidding me?    $100 for a modest lunch for three.   And believe me it was modest.   After I got over the shock and realized it was the first time I'd been robbed with my eyes open in SF, I vowed I wouldn't let THAT happen again.   No way.

The food is great but they need some serious help with their seating procedures. We were quoted an hour twenty inside or twenty minutes outside on a Sat night. The hostess failed to mention you can not drink outside which is why the wait was so short.

Tables sat empty for more than 10 minutes with out being bussed meanwhile the line wait times increased.

Tony, bus your tables and get more people in. Servers walking past a dirty table over and over is unacceptable.

The pizza was okay - not great but it was the disorganization of the place that brought the stars down!!

You walk up and order and expect to get the pizza from the case that just was brought out of the coal fire but no they reheat the pizza for you...it was weird so you end up waiting longer for reheated pizza not to mention we waited 15 for this process to happen.  The dough as a result of the second bake was tough...in north beach with so many good restaurants I would say step your game up Tony!!

We came through on a Sunday afternoon- off-season as far as tourists- and were seated immediately. But I will say that within 30 mins., the place was packed. So, there! I've let you in on the secret time to get into this terrific little pizza place: 4-4:30PM

We ordered their "special", the pizza that won Tony the award at the festival in Naples a few years ago. He was the first American to ever win it.

It seems that ricotta cheese has replaced the traditional mozzarella on the top. I wouldn't have thought of it, but it was good.

Oh, Tony's parents happened to be seated at the table next to us and Tony came out from behind the counter to chat them up.

My husband and I each had our own antipasti. He hates anchovies and I love them. I ordered the lovely "white anchovies" on a bed of greens. They melted in my mouth. None of that feathery stuff I'm accustomed to eating on other anchovies. My husband had a charcuterie plate- a selection of sliced Italian meats and cheeses. He was quite happy with that.

Per a Yelp suggestion, we ordered margaritas, and found them especially tasty. Way to go, Fellow Yelper! All in all, a wonderful meal.

I really wanted to love this place, seeing as how it's in the sights of so many local pizza connoisseurs, but it fell short of my expectations. I ordered the award-winning margherita pizza both times I visited. The sauce is tasty, with a pure San Marzano flavor, and the crust is simultaneously crisp and chewy, but the char really gets in the way of the flavor. I felt like I couldn't taste the base flavors of the pizza over the burnt dough, even if it's more authentic that way. The pizza is also pretty small, enough to feed one hungry person.

$19 + tax and tip is quite a lot of money, and I'd rather spend it elsewhere. The margherita pizza at Emilia's Pizzeria in Berkeley is cheaper, larger, and in my opinion, tastier.

(That's not to say I don't admire the incredible craftsmanship that goes into making these pizzas. Imported ingredients! Four ovens! I hope this place continues to thrive.)

We tried this because it was near Cobb's.  It was crowded on a Sat night, as expected in North Beach.  We asked the bartender (great service BTW) if we should have the margherita or the truffle pizza and he suggested the former.  We started with the fried green beans which were very good.

However, the pizza was just fine.  Our crust was soggy and not that appealing.  I'd go as far as to say Amici's is better by a longshot.

Pizza margarita is a work of art! The New Yorker will blow your mind.  Also love the slice "window" and and just about everything on the menu.

Fortissimo!

The concierge at the Four Seasons insisted we try this place when my mom told him she was craving some great pizza and he was totally right--it was some of the best pizza I've ever had though the wait was, accordingly, pretty long.  We went on a Saturday afternoon and waited about forty minutes at which point they asked if we'd like to sit at the pizza chef's counter.  We were happy to do so and it was fun to watch them make pizza after pizza in the wood burning oven (one of seven different ovens, i think).  They really seem to have it down to a science.
My mom ordered the proscuitto pizza and I had ordered the tomato pie from the coal fired (1000 degree) oven--I was told that one had the crispiest crust.  When they brought my pizza out, they gave me a tomato pie with cheese which wasn't what I ordered, but the restaurant was slammed and I didn't want my mom's pizza to get cold (plus i considered ordering that one anyway) so I kept the pizza despite their offer to remake it.  It was a happy mistake because the pizza was amazingly good--really thin, crispy crust, flavorful tomato sauce and just the right amount of cheese.  
Next time I'm in the city and craving pizza, I'll come back and order the absurdly large, but drool-worthy garlic bread that we saw others eating--serious carb attack.

I've heard about Tony's for years and have always wanted to try it.  FINALLY I got my chance.  WOO HOO!

Soooooo. The wait totally sucked!  But I knew what I was getting myself into so really no big deal.  The hostess told us it would be an hour and a half.  We ended up waiting two hours.  We were a part of 6 with a high chair and two other kids.  So I get there aren't to many spots for us.  Anyhow when we were seated the brought us over a few complimentary appetizers.  that was very gracious and not expected at all.  The waiter came right over.  He was fantastic.  He took our drink order and said he would be back to take our order.  

I ordered the pizza Margherita.  Absolutely deelish! It was perfect in every sence of a true Napoletana pizza.  We also had the meatballs.  OMFG (oh my fucking god) these meaty balls were amazing.  So good I coulda slapped my mama after eating them!!!  The green beans were also good.  The food is great.

The restaurant itself is super cute.  Very clean for such a busy place!

I say all in all I'd never wait two hours again for pizza.  But the food is excellent. The customer service is excellent.  The atmosphere is excellent.  This is a great place.  Good job Tony G.   Your food rocks!!!
Sunday night, 9 pm, and we had to wait an hour.  Totally worth it!  The pizza is amazing!!
I do not understand the hype around Tony's.  There are better pizza places in SF. Desapointed by the meatballs antd the maguerita pizza.  The service is below average as well.

I was told that when in North Beach, go to Tony's.  Glad I followed my buddy's advice.  Killer margherita pizza paired with some great beers on tap.  Love the fact they had San Diego's Ballast Point beer flowing.  Scupin was the hottest seller of the eve.  I arrived at about 5:30 or so and it was jam packed  Being alone, I just got a seat at the bar.  Well, no it wasn't that easy.  I had to stand and wait for about 15 or so minutes, and then finally one opened up.  Met some nice guys at the bar.  Enjoyed my pizza very much.  Right on, Tony.  I'll be back.
Waited in line until it opened. The pizza was wonderful! It was probably one of the best pizzas I have had in a long time.

Fantastic pizza with plenty of options. A lot of the combinations sound bizarre, but they work. The Eddie Muenster is a winner with fried kale, honey, lemon, calabrese peppers and bacon...spicy and sweet all at the same time. Be prepared to wait awhile, but it is so worth it!

Uh... Got the meatball appetizers to go and its tomato sauce was so salty.
Now I know their food is NOT consistent.

That means, the Margherita pizza we didn't like last month could be better some days, but I am not sure if we come back to try that.

Ok. So I tried it. Good but not the best. I got a slice. I will try the restaurant next time and I think that should bring up the stars. I see where it could be great pizza but it needs to be fresh not reheated.
Was worth the money for a slice.

From the moment we walked in the door we were looked after. We were impressed by the quality craft beers on tap, and the pizza was incredibly good. We highly recommend as a stop off before going up Telegraph Hill.

Delicious huge meatball with mushroom sauce!  Sooo flavorful.  They pour the mushroom cream sauce over the meatball which already comes with marinara sauce so it is like a rose sauce.  The Margherita Napoletana pizza was perfectly cooked but i felt slightly lacking in flavor.  Maybe it was because we were seated outside and our food got cold really quickly, so i didn't feel like the food was as good as expected.  Slightly disappointed but was glad i got a chance to try it!  Make sure you sit inside so the cold SF wind doesn't ruin it for you!

Very busy all the time, and of course it's the city, so parking is a joke. That being said, the damn pizza is great. Their crust is off the hook. I suggest going during the week on off times, but I suggest going.
What a surprise. Ordered the Americano, was not what you think fresh sausage, multi colored bell peppers. Awesome crust. And let's not forget the bacon bacon and even more bacon cooked to order l

Bad pizza and bad service! After reading all of the reviews I bought into the "hype"! Went there on 9/2/17 tried to get a table for 2. There was an hour and 45 minute wait. That's fine I don't mind waiting for good food. We waited and had a slice of pizza next door. (Not a bad slice)!

We finally got a table and they said there wasn't any wood fired pizza because of the heat wave. Ok, I understand... it gets hot in the kitchen during a heat wave. So we had to change our order to a "Sweet Grandma pie". After waiting for 20 minutes, the waitress came back and said they didn't have anymore of the sweet grandma pie either. We then ordered the "classic New York" pie. Everyone around us, who was seated after us, got their food before us. Our order must have got put to the back of the line, again! The drunk guy next to us dropped an entire pie on my wife's feet. His girlfriend had her foot on the table, and was showing  the rest of their table, her bunions. Gross! (Look at the surveillance camera). However, after all of this, I'm still not upset! It's a Saturday night in San Francisco! You have to expect stuff like this to happen when you go out. Moving on...

We ended up waiting an hour for our "New York Pie". After already waiting 1 hour and 45 mins to be seated. (All of this for some pizza! I'm expecting this pie to be delicious). Which being from the NYC/NJ area, I can say that this pie was a disgrace to New York Pizza and Pizza in general!The dough was ehhh, it lacked cheese and the sauce?!... Gross!! Like sweet tomato paste! It was a very sweet pasty sauce, sort of tangy. This was unlike any New York pizza I've had. Even if they didn't call it a New York Pizza, I still would have hated it! I've had a million slices of pizza in my life. I know pizza. This Pizza was on the same playing field as a quality frozen pizza, or pizza from a national pizza chain. Not the quality that you would expect from a local Italian restaurant/pizzeria! I hate to be so harsh on a local business. The only positive thing that I will say is that the waitress gave us an order of meatballs on the house because we waited so long for our food. The meatballs were good. She was great! Everything was out of her control. Everything from the food to the dining experience was terrible! The place even smelled like a dirty bar. Maybe I ordered the wrong thing... I'll never be back!

Delicious food and wonderful service! We went a little after 5:30 and got a table right away. We brought our own bottle of wine and they opened it for a corkage fee of $25 (cheaper than any of their bottles listed). Highly recommend the coccoli appitizer! So yum!

The pizza was pricy, but in my opinion completely fair priced and worth every cent. It looked like it may be greasy upon first glance, but it definitely didn't taste like a greasy pizza that will have you drinking vodka waters later at the bar. Our waiter was bubbly (but not annoying) and everything was done in impeccable time. Thank you Tony's Pizza, I will be back.

best pizza in San Francisco. there, I said it. so what wannfightaboutit

You just can't go wrong here. The pizza is ON POINT every single day (except Tuesdays when it's closed).  The prosciutto balsamic is mind blowingly good.  Of course the cheese is sort of just a necessity to try here - it is the staple of which all else comes alive. worth it.

one instance I was sitting at the bar and I asked the 'keep for something new to try off the menu and he told me to try a burger. after that, there was really no turning back either. Tony's also makes some of my favorite burgers and fries in North Beach.  I forget the keepers name but he gave us his business card and was an absolute legend

I've always noticed their signs for "Italian Beef Sandwiches" but never got around trying one until recently.  I go the combination sandwich, which was an italian sauce AND italian beef piled into a sandwich.  THIS THING WAS SO FUCKING GOOD and unbelievably packed with assorted meats.  I would be happy to bring my family from Chicago to this place for a good beef.  this is a treat that almost doesn't exist anywhere else in San Francisco and believe me, I've been on the look.  Eaten a ton of beef sandwiches whenever in Chicago and I glad to be able to cut out that commute.  

if you're just looking to try the pizza - get a couple slices at their location next door and take over to enjoy in Washington Sq. Park!

I had lost hope of finding good pizza in SF and then I stumbled upon Tony's.... The sauce on their margherita pizza tastes exactly the same as what I'd had in Naples.... and the crust.... and the puddles of mozzerella... with the few crisps of basil... Too bad I had to share it! Take note that particular pizza is very thin and small - if it wasn't so expensive I'd order one just for myself!
We also tried the Italian Prosciutto Pomodorini. We requested ricotta on it - and that tasted even better than the margherita. The salty prosiutto with warm milky ricotta was heaven in each bite. Thankfully this pizza is larger and more substantial.
Can't wait to go back and try some of their other combos!!

I am not a huge pizza person nor do I eagerly search out italian dinners. However, this may have been the best pizza I have ever had.  A perfect place for friends or family to get together over a great slice or two, or in my case a bunch. Great service, friendly staff, and just unbelievable food.

We had the half-half Calamari and the New Yorker. The food was so good it prompted me to write my first Yelp review. Easy 5 stars.

I'm a New York transplant who has lived in Italy. In other words, I take pizza very seriously. Life is too short to have bad pizza.

I used to live in Italy a block from a place that made brick oven pizza and I've never found anything that could come close to the deliciousness that came out of their oven. Until I found this place. Simply amazing.

Now the line on the other hand... well let's just be glad they have a bar to wait at :)

On a return visit for lunch, we got to sit at the counter in front of the pizza oven and chat with the staff, including Tony. It was a great experience for two foodies.

Tried the fries, which were life-changing. Seriously, they are so, so good. It seems weird to order fries at a pizza place, but just do it. We also tried the margherita pizza, and thought it was delish. Again, I found myself admiring pizzas at other tables, so obviously we need to go back again and try more.

The New Yorker is probably the best pizza Ive ever had. I only wish they delivered to SOMA...although that could be dangerous.

The wait can get a little ridiculous (they dont take reservations) but picking up from the slice house next door is really convenient.

The sheer deliciousness of this restaurant has jolted me out of my pizza complacency. It's as though Tony the master pizzaiolo went out to dinner in North Beach, noticed that the restaurants there are generally not very good, and decided to defend his homeland's reputation in the food capital of the American West.

The masterstroke in my opinion is that this joint is ready to meet you at whatever level you'd like to experience it. You can get a pre-made calzone warmed up for you for $6. You can get a fresh pie made in 15 mins in the $20s to go share with at least one friend in the adjacent parklet. This can be one of like 4 different styles of pizza. You can eat a sit-down $50-person meal with fancy wine and cocktails, although they don't take reservations. Suits me, but caveat reader.

Highly recommend that you go here at least once if you have ever enjoyed a slice of pizza. The place is basically pizza heaven.

This place was recommended by the great Italian deli around the corner, they said that it's the best pizza on Earth so we had to try it and so glad we did.  They have several gold medal winning pizzas on their menu and I've never seen so many different types of pizzas (crust style, way it's cooked, etc).  It was fantastic but the most expensive pizza I've ever bought.

This review is for the Take out window around the corner. Horrible customer service. I got better service in places where a slice costs $1. Embarrassing for such establishment.  $60 for 2 pizzas and I've been ignored and got cold soggy pizza 1 hour after I ordered.
I ordered over the phone, asked when would it be ready, showed up on time for the to be ready. Having winning hungry toddler waiting in the car was adding the urgency for pizza to be on time. Pizza wasn't ready, I was asked to wait 5-7 mins which is fine. 10 min later on the pizzas showed up. Where is the second one? Nobody knows. 10 mins later they bring over a stack of pizzas for delivery. I asked if any of those are mine. "No" keep waking. Delivery guys picks up his order leaving one pizza sitting there. I asked again if it's mine. "No" By that time I have to go get my hysterical kid from the car. Came over with the baby, keep being ignored by staff. Finally loosing my patience and start asking everybody working there where is my order. Apparently it was sitting on the counter all this time. I didn't even get a sorry.

What to say about "Tony's Pizza Napoletana"... expect to wait at least an hour to be seated!  lol. That could be said about many places, but especially here. Upon our arrival, we we greeted by the friendly host, gave or name and cell number, (so they could text us when our seat was ready), and spent our time exploring the area and people watching while we waited--great location across the street from the park. The place was packed, but our waitress was fast, friendly, and brought our drink order and took our food order in a timely manner. Be forewarned:  the portions are substantial!  My wife and I could have easily shared either a pizza or stromboli and left stuffed. My wife ordered the " honey pie" pizza which had these delicious caramelized onions, and I had the "hippie" stromboli with wonderful feta cheese and a side of pesto for dipping. Either of these would have been enough food for both of us, but we managed eat everything and wobbled away.

The ambiance was "bar-like", trendy, noisy, and fun, with indoor table/booth and bar seating, and some outdoor sidewalk seating. I don't believe the place is air conditioned, as it was uncomfortably warm during our visit, but apparently the weather during our visit was unusually hot.  Word or advise:  ask NOT to be seated at the table nearest the restrooms!  We were seated at that table, (after waiting 1-1/2 hours, we took what was available), and although there were no problem with " bathroom odors," it was a little awkward eating while people were hang out in front of our table waiting to use the restroom.  The restrooms themselves were very clean and well stocked.

Would I go back again?... probably not.  The food, although plentifully and tasty, it was nothing mind blowing and overpriced, but " when in Rome,"...

We went there cause we heard it is the best pizza in the city. We waited about 2 hours to be seated. Pizza was very good but pricey. It's about $22 for just plain Margarita . One pizza is more than enough for one but not for two person. Menu is big with a lot of pizzas for different tastes. Service was fast. Location is great. We will visit again when we are in San Francisco .
The best pizza in SF. If you don't feel like waiting for a seat in the main restaurant head next door for a slice to go.

Pizza was good, mozzarella was good, try gnocco fritto.
A good experience, they should put a bit more effort in having waiters learning right the italian names but the food was good.

This place is absolutely fantastic. Expect a wait even until close, but well worth it. Tony's utilizes numerous different styles in various ovens and each pizza is truly unique. Our experience was fantastic and everyone felt that they really do pay attention to fine details including the ingredients. Overall, well worth the wait and cannot recommend it enough.

The restaurant was full that night, so we went for a pizza to go (it's 2 doors down). Good thing is you can order and then eat outside on one of the tables, so it's not that different from actually being in a restaurant, except the choice is much more limited and you don't have the service of course.
We ordered a full prosciutto/pear pizza, and were happy for once in the US to get a real Italian pizza... Dough is thin and crispy, prosciutto is tasty. Ordering process is smooth and smiley.
Definitely a solid pizza, the best we've had in our 3 week roadtrip in the Northwest.

So I had heard a lot about how Tony's Pizza was so amazing and my first thought was, really? How AMAZING can pizza be? But, yes it is sooo yummy!!

I tried it for the first time in March and have already been back twice. They really aren't kidding about that Margherita pizza and it's secret recipe for the dough! I had it twice and then once on regular dough because they had ran out! They only make 73 per day. (I will leave it up to you to go and find out the reasoning behind this.) You must try it on their special dough! I lucked out on a week night and a weekend day.

It also is a bonus that they happen to sell my favorite white wine... Ceretto Blange Arneis. It is light and smooth with a slight effervescence at the end of every sip :)

Be warned, it can be a long wait for a table! I lucked out and found seats at the bar twice and once waited an hour for a table, but like I said, it is worth it!

This place has some EXCELLENT food.   We ordered the fried string beans for an appetizer which was pretty darn good. For our main meal my wife and I ordered a Margherita Pizza and the Manhattan Calzone.

Our waiter Ben was great. He was very attentive and always had our drinks filled.

Welcome to Pizza Heaven. Try to get here early so you can get one of the famous pizzas where they only make about 63 crusts a day.

I would also recommend to experiment a little bit and try one of the pizzas from a different kind of oven.

Great price as well, but if you dont get here early you have to wait to get a table for a long time.....

Larger than life.

Tony's epic beats: youtu.be/7EzU8QMun0g

Tony's epic slices: So big you need to fold in half. Classic New York style.

Others have said service is rude. Not my experience at all. In fact the girl taking my order wanted to make sure if I reheat later to use the oven.

Never microwave Tony's.

Advice was appreciated but unnecessary. Delicious slice never made it home.

And yes I admit it. I did love this song: youtu.be/1jkH7An7dKk

Weekly Cheat Meal Alert!

Rating: 3

Dish(es): Margherita Pizza

Review: Big disappointment. A great looking pizza could only be this bland. No flavor, served lukewarm. Won't be back again.

Cheat meal wasted.

There is a long wait, but I hovered the bar to grab a "quick" seat. Either way the wait is well worth it. It was my first time here and i ordered the Margherita Pizza with a side of meatballs which were both delicious. I will definitely be back the next time I'm in town.
Wow I like Tony's pizza! It's a great slice but I am more of a deep dish pizza person so I am giving 4 stars. Definitely recommend Tony's pizza!

One of the few really good pizza places in SF. It's a good place to grab some drinks and a pizza with friends or co-workers after work. It does get busy for dinner though and if you can't wait around, go next door to buy a slice and eat it in the park on a nice night!
Been here twice. If you use the waitlist on Yelp, the wait isn't too bad. But the food is absolutely worth it!

Every time I hit San Francisco now I make it a point to come here because I genuinely like the food. However, the last couple times the service has been awful. At the slice to go side, the girl(s) that work there have snapped at me for not hearing my number being called from outside. It gets crowded and hectic in that part of the restaurant, I get it, but there's no need to yell at a loyal customer for not being able to hear your order being called. Further, the food quality here is not as great as the actual sit down spot.
So, the next day I decide to give the sit down spot a go before I left San Francisco. The waits are always long, I get that too; the hostesses can definitely try to smile and be a little more pleasant and welcoming. When we finally sat down, we got seating outside and were ignored for over 20 minutes. This is unacceptable, considering I counted 3 busboys and the manager walk by before our server ever came to us. By the time I got my food, I was just so displeased with the service that I didn't even think it was all worth the wait.
My suggestion is, order a whole pie to go and enjoy it in your hotel room and skip the bad service all together.

You can't go wrong with this place for pizza. Every single pizza I've tasted here has been amazing. Crust is thin, great texture. Toppings and sauce are fresh, and waiters give great suggestions. I will say though, I might have liked Defina's pizza a tad more, but Tony's is great as well.

Tips:
- Sitting in front of that oven is unbearably hot, I commend the cooks for being able to work in front of that thing all night.
- NO RESERVATIONS, come early.

I was really disappointed, the pizzas have no test. Bread is to big. We better go to pizza Hut....
Don't lose your time on the line , there is Origina Joe's at the opposite, the best restaurant in SF....
FK! i bought into it. He's fking awesome. Capos is also amazing
Good stuff!  I'm digging the Detroit Style pizza with it's crunchy, garlic buttered corners and addition of cheddar cheese with mozzarella.

This place is great I recommend it not from the area and went on a whim. You will not regret this place. Ask for Theresa she is a fun and great server. After a long walk up hill And down to get here she was welcoming and got us drinks ASAP. If back in the area again I'll be back.
Loved loved their pizzas... checked Yelp and saw a review that is a must visit place for Italian food.. it didnt disappoint.. great pizza .. love the atmosphere too

Best pizza in San Francisco!  Margherita Pizza and Rosemary Patata Pizza were fabulous!  Service was very friendly and helpful as usual, helping us navigate the diverse menu to find the pizza we needed!  Recommend highly!!

Tony's pizza is delicious. The customer service leaves a bit to be desired, as there is always an extremely long wait for the pizzas, and the prices are a bit steep, even for the more basic pies. Overall, delicious and would recommend a visit! Several vegetarian options :)

This place has some of the best pizza in SF. NOT NY PIZZA,  but great nonetheless. Famous for the marg. pizza but get the big square one with three different pizzas in one. Took one hour to get seated, but worth it.
R

Super packed in the restaurant and the wait is rediculous  for a table. Thank gosh they have a pizza takeout shop 2 doors down. I'm gluten free do I was beyond excited when they has a GF pizza.   I've had multiple GF pizzas in my life , so I def know when ones good. I ordered a GF pizza w/ pepperoni And spinach. The GF pizza was $22 after taxes and for 2 toppings. This wasn't a huge pizza bc it's GF. Also the price is reasonable given it is GF.  

After eating most if the pizza, I just couldn't stop eating it bc it was sooo yummy and the best GF pizza I've ever had. It tasted just like a normal pizza ! So worth it! This was my fav  food I've had on my SF vaca. I will def return to  Tony's!!! Love the pizza !
This is the best pizza in town very similar to New York slices and the beef sandwiches are delicious my favorite is the 4 cheese

Wow! This place was incredible! My husband and I stopped in SF on our PCH road trip totally craving pizza! Obviously we couldn't not go to Tonys after looking at the reviews on here for the place! Yeah the wait sucks but its totally worth it!! We got the giant meatball for an appetizer and it was damn delicious! And ordered the New Yorker and ughhhh it was amazing! Even though we were totally full we still ate the entire pizza and walked around fat and happy!
Omg this is best pizza I have ever had. We ordered the New Yorker and the Meatballs and we were NOT disappointed. This place is worth the hype. I can't wait to come back!!!
From Chicago and most pizza in san francisco is inedible except for Tony's. Tony's is the only place to get pizza here. Competes with the best

Tony's is amongst the best overall pizza places in SF.  That said, there may be a few other pizzas in SF that can rival Tony's 'art', but the overall combination of ambience and offerings at Tony's are unparalleled. Their mix of multiple styles of pizza cooked in different ovens is unmatched in the city, and perhaps well beyond in the surrounding areas.  Not to distract you from the great pizzas, but the salads, appetizers, and desserts are all great as well- a Caesar to start and an Affogato to finish are always worth considering!

The wood-burning oven pizzas are the 'creme de la creme' of Tony's- so don't get distracted by the other 6-7 styles offered!  Most of the other pizzas styles are great- but the wood-burning oven pizzas are the real deal.  My personal favorite is the 'New Yorker'- however I'm not sure if this is offered in the wood-burning oven any more?- on my last visit it was offered as one of his coal-fired pizzas, and it was delicious as well.  The wood-fired margherita pizza is Tony's 'legend'- he has won awards for this and I'd say I see him there making them himself 4 out of 5 times that I visit.  The slice house is excellent for what it is as well, but don't confuse the two- they are different creatures serving different purposes and NOT serving the same pizzas.  

Be aware that Tony's Napoletana can be complicated to get into - almost always very busy - and closed on Mondays/Tuesdays.  *Hint- you can get pizza at the bar if you see an open spot.  Sometimes lunch is your best bet to avoid a wait- but sometimes there are lines of people waiting before their opening.  Be persistent and don't give up!  Many do- and go to the Slice house instead and are less impressed with their experience as they have not dined on the full pizza-power of Tony.

Do yourself a favor and try Tony's- their pizzas are also available for take-out and I have heard they have a limited delivery radius as well.  But the pizza will not be the same unless presented straight out of the oven on to your table.  The only other pizzas in SF in the same conversation as Tony's Napoletana's wood-fired pizzas are those found at Una Pizza Napoletana, A16, and Flour+Water.  And thats it!
I'm already looking forward to my next visit!

Parking in this area sucks.
The place is small and there were no booths so we sat at the bar.
Pizza was $19.00 (I got my own because my friend is fat ad didn't want to share).

Size is small compared to other places.
My crust was burnt.
It wasn't that great. Not $19 great.
Other than that not worth the hassle to get to north beach. Stuffed crust pizza hut! I crave.

Service was good and probably only because my friend comes here about once a week and leaves good tip (we left $10 on a $45 tab... Yeah, seriously?! Really?!!!! Ugh)

The other good thing was that the pizza didn't feel too unhealthy. I actually didn't feel like shit after! Hurray!

Best. Pizza. Ever.

Try the pizza called "gigante".

I had to add another sentence so Yelp would accept this review as one written in the English Language.
Fogetboutit!!!!! Solid 22 inch NY Style Pizza n side of pasta n Meatballs....mmmm that's a good meatball!

Awesome Pizza! Had Margherita and New Yorker for our family of 4. It was perfect. Be prepared to wait if you want to get a table. There is a to go window where you can order by the slice. Washington Square is adjacent to Tony's so you can chill and wait for them to text you when your table is ready.

We were just here and tried to get a table and the hostess was extremely rude. We asked what the wait time is and she said 30 minutes and I asked if it's the same next door since we're out of town and have never been there before and she gets a real attitude and says 'yes, it's 30 minutes' like we're idiots. We left and went to Acquolina next door and are glad we did, it was really great.

I'm shamed, chagrined, embarrassed, bewildered, nonplussed, perturbed, disturbed, dumbfounded and dumb to have discovered this unbelievable pizza after living in the Bay Area for 10 years.  

If you like pizza, don't be as shamed, chagrined, embarrassed, bewildered, nonplussed, perturbed, disturbed, dumbfounded and dumb as I was, and get thee to Tony's posthaste.

Great pizza! Great atmosphere! Great staff! Was very busy, but friendly. I had margherita pizza, which won the world pizza cup title, and it definitely lived up to that. Paired with the house chianti it was molto bene!

HOLE-E-CRAP.

I'm racking my brain trying to think if I've had better pizza in my life... aaaaand: nothing.

So many different varieties of pizzas owing to their different ovens (gas, wood-fired, coal-fired), crust styles, and flavors. Very reasonable prices for the quality of food (fresh ingredients apparent) and the fact that they also have a huge cocktail menu, wine menu, and several beers on tap.

Casual atmosphere, great service, win win win!

Gets packed later in the night, even on weekdays, so it's better to either come early, make reservations, or come as one or two people and sit outside/at the bar.

Great for large groups, kids, adults, anyone who can chew and smile.

Not a place where you can expect to sit and chat for a drawn out, three-hour meal-- they've got tables to turn!

Only a few tables scattered around outside which can be pretty chilly on some days, this place is worth finding. No ordinary pizza, they know their dough. The crust on the slices, and the ciabatta bread on the paninis, will have you coming back. I know I will!

Great service, ok drinks, the pizza was stellar, probably the best crust ever. We had the Sam Lorenzo, New Jersey style pizza. The spinach salad was just ok, kinda skimped on the goat cheese and pecans, but passable. We got there right at noon and were seated by 12:15, well worth trying if in the area.

Worth the wait. Pizza's are served by the crust style. If you have a really good server, they will tell you that they are running out of certain crusts, and you can reserve one, and determine toppings later. Hands down the best pizza I have ever had

Recommended by our bartender at the hotel.   If I would have known about it we would have gone back again before our trip was over.  

Excellent! Great staff who were attentive and we were seated as soon as we walked up.  

Of course we had the award winning pizza and it was fantastic as was the calamari.  

Next time another pizza or pasta and salad to complete our meal.

Highly recommended and a do not miss place when in San Francisco.

The margarita pizza and 1000° oven is a can't lose decision. Meatballs were pretty damn good also. If you ever make it out to San Francisco and you're in the hankering for a good pizza check this place out. Stay away from the pepperoni or you will be burping it up all night, it's kind of heavy.

This place has a lot of hype built around it, but it really deserves this hype.  I talk highly about it to any friend or family who comes to visit, and even my pizza connoisseur friends are extremely impressed.  If you go, you should try to get there a bit earlier than when you'd actually like to eat though as there typically is a long wait, but their famous Mozzarella pizza is worth it.

Tony's is definitely top notch for pizza. Delicious as they can get with a ton of variety. Was thrilled to actually meet Tony and he baked a superb custom creation for my tastes. Great overall experience and enjoy every time I come here. The wait is worth it!

I truly do not understand the hype.

We finally tried this place last weekend. We were hesitant to go to the restaurant, since we don't like to wait in line. So when a flyer arrived announcing a new delivery service, it sounded like the perfect solution.

The menu for ordering was confusing, and unless I missed it somehow, pizza Napoletana was not an option.  Some reviews mentioned the coal-fired pizza, so we ordered that instead, along with a pastrami sandwich.

The pizza arrived 20 minutes late, albeit on a cute delivery bicycle. The delivery person was apologetic and gracious, so I wasn't upset about the wait.  What I didn't care for was the fact that both items were delivered cold and had to be heated before we could try to enjoy them.  Hmm, maybe a motorized delivery vehicle would make it easier to deliver the food hot.

As for the food, it was just OK. The pizza crust was very good but the sauce tasted like tomato paste.  The sandwich was just OK.

Maybe we'll be willing to try again in the restaurant for one of the touted limited edition margarita pizzas, but based on this experience, it's unlikely.

My favorite pizza place!  Nothing beats Tony's Pizza.  Been coming here for Valentine's day the last two years.  Tony's doesn't take reservations but we go for a late dinner and never have to wait more than 10 min. for a table.  My favorite is the margarita pizza and a side of meat balls!

Best pizza in SF? Yes! Longest waits in SF? Also, yes. Sit at the bar and hang out with Jose (I know...a Jose at a Tony's...well, it just works). Jose is super nice and an awesome bartender! But wait, it gets better...there's something called Coccoli (Italian) and it is NOT to be missed. It's like eating fresh bread from the oven of [insert famous chef here]. Get the version with the burrata cheese and prosciutto. If you can't stand the wait you can always get a slice to go next door :)

Pizza is great here, but the service is terrible. After being told it would be an hour and 15 minute wait, we were seated after Two hours and 15 minutes. The Stoner waiter kept us at the table nearly an hour after we were done. Couldn't manage to bring the bill. Finally I have him my credit card (without the bill ever coming) and it took over 20 minutes to process it. No wonder there is such a long wait. Turn over the tables already.

Solidly average.

Not sure what all the hype is about. Had the famous margherita pizza and little Italy salad. Both were forgettable. The salad didn't have anything to set it apart from any other salad. The pizza lacked any real flavor. Hardly any basil and the mozzarella was unimpressive.

Not to mention we had a one hour wait at 9 on a Wednesday.

tl;dr - not worth it, go somewhere else.
